Text

Produced by An Anonymous Volunteer GREAT EXPECTATIONS -LSB-1867 Edition-RSB- by Charles Dickens this work etext98/grexp10.txt scanned from a different edition-RSB- Chapter

I My father's family name being Pirrip, and my Christian name Philip, my infant tongue could make of both names nothing longer or more explicit than Pip.

So, I called myself Pip, and came to be called Pip. I give Pirrip as my father's family name, on the authority of his (Pirrip) tombstone and my sister,--Mrs.

As I never saw my father or my mother, and never saw any likeness of either of them -LRB-for their days were long before the days of photographs-RRB-, my first fancies regarding what they were like were unreasonably derived from their tombstones.

The shape of the letters on my father's, gave me an odd idea that he (father) was a square, stout, dark man, with curly black hair.

From the character and turn of the inscription,

``Also Georgiana Wife of the Above,'' (the character turn)
I drew a childish conclusion that my mother was freckled and sickly.

To five little stone lozenges, each about a foot and a half long, which were arranged in a neat row beside their grave, and were sacred to the memory of five little brothers of mine,--who gave up trying to get a living, exceedingly early in that universal struggle,--I am indebted for a belief I religiously entertained that they had all been born on their backs with their hands in their trousers-pockets, and had never taken them out in this state of existence.

Joe Gargery, who married the blacksmith. Ours was the marsh country, down by the river, within, as the river wound, twenty miles of the sea.

My first most vivid and broad impression of the identity of things seems to me to have been gained on a memorable raw afternoon towards evening.

At such a time I found out for certain that this bleak place overgrown with nettles was the churchyard; and that Philip Pirrip, late of this parish, and also Georgiana wife of the above, were dead and buried; and that Alexander, Bartholomew, Abraham, Tobias, and Roger, infant children of the aforesaid, were also dead and buried; and that the dark flat wilderness beyond the churchyard, intersected with dikes and mounds and gates, with scattered cattle feeding on it, was the marshes; and that the low leaden line beyond was the river; and that the distant savage lair from which the wind was rushing was the sea; and that the small bundle of shivers growing afraid of it all and beginning to cry, was Pip.

Hold your noise!'' cried a terrible voice, as a man started up from among the graves at the side of the church porch.

'' '' Keep still, you little devil, or I'll cut your throat!'' A fearful man, all in coarse gray, with a great iron on his (man) leg.

A man who had been soaked in water, and smothered in mud, and lamed by stones, and cut by flints, and stung by nettles, and torn by briars; who limped, and shivered, and glared, and growled; and whose teeth chattered in his (man) head as he (man) seized me by the chin.

A man with no hat, and with broken shoes, and with an old rag tied round his (man) head. '' Oh! Don't cut my throat, sir,'' I pleaded in terror.

'' Pray don't do it, sir.''

``Tell us your name!'' (the man)
said the man. '' Quick!''
``Pip, sir.'' (unknown)
``Once more,'' (the man)
said the man, staring at me.

'' Give it mouth!''

``Pip. Pip, sir. '' (unknown)
``Show us where you live,'' (the man)
said the man. '' Pint out the place!''

I pointed to where our village lay, on the flat in-shore among the alder-trees and pollards, a mile or more from the church.

The man, after looking at me for a moment, turned me upside down, and emptied my pockets. There was nothing in them but a piece of bread.

he (man) was so sudden and strong that he (man) made it go head over heels before me, and I saw the steeple under my feet,--when the church came to itself

When the church came to itself,--for , I say, I was seated on a high tombstone, trembling while he (man) ate the bread ravenously.

'' You young dog,'' said the man, licking his (man) lips,

``what fat cheeks you ha' got. '' (the man)
I believe they were fat, though I was at that time undersized for my years, and not strong.

Darn me if I couldn't eat em,'' said the man, with a threatening shake of his (man) head,

``and if I han't half a mind to`t!

I earnestly expressed my hope that he (man) wouldn't, and held tighter to the tombstone on which he (man) had put me; partly, to keep myself upon it; partly, to keep myself from crying.

'' (the man)

'' '' Now lookee here!'' said the man. '' Where's your mother?'' '' There, sir!'' said I. He (man) started, made a short run, and stopped and looked over his (man) shoulder.

'' There, sir!'' I timidly explained. '' Also Georgiana. That's my mother. ''

``Oh!'' (he)
said he (man), coming back. '' And is that your father alonger your mother?''

'' Yes, sir,'' said I;

``him (man) too; late of this parish.'' (I)
``Ha!'' (he)
he (man) muttered then, considering. '' Who d'ye live with,--supposin' you're kindly let to live, which I han't made up my mind about?''

'' My sister, sir,--Mrs. Joe Gargery,--wife of Joe Gargery, the blacksmith, sir.''

``Blacksmith, eh?'' (he)
said he (Blacksmith). And looked down at his (Blacksmith) leg.

After darkly looking at his (Blacksmith) leg and me several times, he (Blacksmith) came closer to my tombstone, took me by both arms, and tilted me back as far as he (Blacksmith) could hold me; so that his (Blacksmith) eyes looked most powerfully down into mine, and mine looked most helplessly up into his (Blacksmith).

'' Now lookee here,'' he (Blacksmith) said,

``the question being whether you're to be let to live. You know what a file is?'' (he)

After each question he (Blacksmith) tilted me over a little more, so as to give me a greater sense of helplessness and danger.

'' Yes, sir.'' '' And you know what wittles is?'' '' Yes, sir.'' '' You get me a file. '' He (Blacksmith) tilted me again.

'' And you get me wittles. '' He (Blacksmith) tilted me again. '' You bring 'em both to me. '' He (Blacksmith) tilted me again.

I was dreadfully frightened, and so giddy that I clung to him (Blacksmith) with both hands, and said,

``If you would kindly please to let me keep upright, sir, perhaps I shouldn't be sick, and perhaps I could attend more.

'' (him)

Or I'll have your heart and liver out. '' He (Blacksmith) tilted me again. '' He (Blacksmith) gave me a most tremendous dip and roll, so that the church jumped over its own weathercock.

Then, he (Blacksmith) held me by the arms, in an upright position on the top of the stone, and went on in these fearful terms:--

``You bring me, to-morrow morning early, that file and them wittles. You bring the lot to me, at that old Battery over yonder.

You do it, and you never dare to say a word or dare to make a sign concerning your having seen such a person as me, or any person sumever, and you shall be let to live.

You fail, or you go from my words in any partickler, no matter how small it is, and your heart and your liver shall be tore out, roasted, and ate.

Now, I ain't alone, as you may think I am. There's a young man hid with me, in comparison with which young man I am a Angel.

That young man has a secret way pecooliar to himself, of getting at a boy, and at his (boy) heart, and at his (boy) liver.

That young man hears the words I speak. It is in wain for a boy to attempt to hide himself from that young man.

A boy may lock his (boy) door, may be warm in bed, may tuck himself up, may draw the clothes over his (boy) head, may think himself comfortable and safe, but that young man will softly creep and creep his (man) way to him (man) and tear him (man) open.

I am a keeping that young man from harming of you at the present moment, with great difficulty. I find it wery hard to hold that young man off of your inside.

I said that I would get him (man) the file, and I would get him (man) what broken bits of food I could, and I would come to him (man) at the Battery, early in the morning.

Now, what do you say? '' (me)

'' Say Lord strike you dead if you don't!'' said the man. I said so, and he (man) took me down.

'' Now,'' he (man) pursued,

``you remember what you've undertook, and you remember that young man, and you get home!'' (he)
``Goo-good night, sir,'' (I)
I faltered.

'' Much of that!'' said he (man), glancing about him (man) over the cold wet flat. '' I wish I was a frog.

At the same time, he (man) hugged his (man) shuddering body in both his (man) arms,--clasping himself, as if to hold himself together,--and limped towards the low church wall.

As I saw him (man) go, picking his (man) way among the nettles, and among the brambles that bound the green mounds, he (man) looked in my young eyes as if he (man) were eluding the hands of the dead people, stretching up cautiously out of their graves, to get a twist upon his (man) ankle and pull him (man) in.

When he (man) came to the low church wall, he (man) got over it, like a man whose legs were numbed and stiff, and then turned round to look for me.

Or a eel!'' When I saw him (man) turning, I set my face towards home, and made the best use of my legs.

But presently I looked over my shoulder, and saw him (man) going on again towards the river, still hugging himself in both arms, and picking his (man) way with his (man) sore feet among the great stones dropped into the marshes here and there, for stepping-places when the rains were heavy or the tide was in.

The marshes were just a long black horizontal line then, as I stopped to look after him (man); and the river was just another horizontal line, not nearly so broad nor yet so black; and the sky was just a row of long angry red lines and dense black lines intermixed.

On the edge of the river I could faintly make out the only two black things in all the prospect that seemed to be standing upright; one of these was the beacon by which the sailors steered,--like an unhooped cask upon a pole,--an ugly thing when you were near it; the other, a gibbet, with some chains hanging to it which had once held a pirate.

The man was limping on towards this latter, as if he (man) were the pirate come to life, and come down, and going back to hook himself up again.

It gave me a terrible turn when I thought so; and as I saw the cattle lifting their heads to gaze after him (man), I wondered whether they thought so too.

I looked all round for the horrible young man, and could see no signs of him (man). But now I was frightened again, and ran home without stopping.

My sister, Mrs. Joe Gargery, was more than twenty years older than I, and had established a great reputation with herself and the neighbors because she (Gargery) had brought me up

``by hand.

Having at that time to find out for myself what the expression meant, and knowing her (Gargery) to have a hard and heavy hand, and to be much in the habit of laying it upon her (Gargery) husband as well as upon me, I supposed that Joe Gargery and I were both brought up by hand.

She (Gargery) was not a good-looking woman, my sister; and I had a general impression that she (Gargery) must have made Joe Gargery marry her (Gargery) by hand.

Joe was a fair man, with curls of flaxen hair on each side of his (man) smooth face, and with eyes of such a very undecided blue that they seemed to have somehow got mixed with their own whites.

Chapter II '' (me)

He (man) was a mild, good-natured, sweet-tempered, easy-going, foolish, dear fellow,--a sort of Hercules in strength, and also in weakness.

My sister, Mrs. Joe, with black hair and eyes, had such a prevailing redness of skin that I sometimes used to wonder whether it was possible she (Joe) washed herself with a nutmeg-grater instead of soap.

She (Joe) was tall and bony, and almost always wore a coarse apron, fastened over her (Joe) figure behind with two loops, and having a square impregnable bib in front, that was stuck full of pins and needles.

She (Joe) made it a powerful merit in herself, and a strong reproach against Joe, that she (Joe) wore this apron so much.

Though I really see no reason why she (Joe) should have worn it at all; or why, if she (Joe) did wear it at all, she (Joe) should not have taken it off, every day of her (Joe) life.

Joe's forge adjoined our house, which was a wooden house, as many of the dwellings in our country were,--most of them, at that time.

Joe and I being fellow-sufferers, and having confidences as such, Joe imparted a confidence to me, the moment I raised the latch of the door and peeped in at him (our) opposite to it, sitting in the chimney corner.

When I ran home from the churchyard, the forge was shut up, and Joe was sitting alone in the kitchen. ''

Mrs. Joe has been out a dozen times, looking for you, Pip. And she (Joe)'s out now, making it a baker's dozen.''

At this dismal intelligence, I twisted the only button on my waistcoat round and round, and looked in great depression at the fire.

``Is she (Joe)?'' (unknown)
``Yes, Pip,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe;
``and what's worse, she (Joe)'s got Tickler with her (Joe). '' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
Tickler was a wax-ended piece of cane, worn smooth by collision with my tickled frame.

'' She (Joe) sot down,'' said Joe,

``and she (Joe) got up, and she (Joe) made a grab at Tickler, and she (Joe) Ram-paged out.

That's what she (Joe) did,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

said Joe, slowly clearing the fire between the lower bars with the poker, and looking at it;
``she (Joe) Ram-paged out, Pip.'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

``Has she (Joe) been gone long, Joe? '' (I)
I always treated him (Joe) as a larger species of child, and as no more than my equal.

Well,'' said Joe, glancing up at the Dutch clock,

``she (Joe)'s been on the Ram-page, this last spell, about five minutes, Pip.

'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

She (Joe)'s a coming! Get behind the door, old chap, and have the jack-towel betwixt you. '' I took the advice.

My sister, Mrs. Joe, throwing the door wide open, and finding an obstruction behind it, immediately divined the cause, and applied Tickler to its further investigation.

She (Joe) concluded by throwing me--I often served as a connubial missile--at Joe, who, glad to get hold of me on any terms, passed me on into the chimney and quietly fenced me up there with his (chap) great leg.

``Tell me directly what you've been doing to wear me away with fret and fright and worrit, or I'd have you out of that corner if you was fifty Pips, and he (chap) was five hundred Gargerys.

'' (monkey)

Where have you been, you young monkey?'' said Mrs. Joe, stamping her (Joe) foot. ''
``I have only been to the churchyard,'' (I)
said I, from my stool, crying and rubbing myself.

``Churchyard!'' (sister)
repeated my sister. '' If it warn't for me you'd have been to the churchyard long ago, and stayed there.

Who brought you up by hand?'' '' You did,'' said I.

``And why did I do it, I should like to know?

'' (I.)

exclaimed my sister. I whimpered,
``I don't know. '' (I)
``I don't!'' (sister)
said my sister. '' I'd never do it again!

I know that. I may truly say I've never had this apron of mine off since born you were. It's bad enough to be a blacksmith's wife -LRB-and him (blacksmith) a Gargery-RRB- without being your mother.

For the fugitive out on the marshes with the ironed leg, the mysterious young man, the file, the food, and the dreadful pledge

'' My thoughts strayed from that question as I looked disconsolately at the fire. I was under to commit a larceny on those sheltering premises, rose before me in the avenging coals.

'' Hah! '' said Mrs. Joe, restoring Tickler to his (man) station. '' Churchyard, indeed! You may well say churchyard, you two.

You'll drive me to the churchyard betwixt you, one of these days, and O, a pr-r-recious pair you'd be without me!''

As she (Joe) applied herself to set the tea-things, Joe peeped down at me over his (man) leg, as if he (man) were mentally casting me and himself up, and calculating what kind of pair we practically should make, under the grievous circumstances foreshadowed.

After that, he (man) sat feeling his (man) right-side flaxen curls and whisker, and following Mrs. Joe about with his (man) blue eyes, as his (man) manner always was at squally times.

'' One of us, by the by, had not said it at all. '' My sister had a trenchant way of cutting our bread and butter for us, that never varied.

First, with her (sister) left hand she (sister) jammed the loaf hard and fast against her (sister) bib,--where it sometimes got a pin into it, and sometimes a needle, which we afterwards got into our mouths.

Then she (sister) took some butter -LRB-not too much-RRB- on a knife and spread it on the loaf, in an apothecary kind of way, as if she (sister) were making a plaster,--using both sides of the knife with a slapping dexterity, and trimming and moulding the butter off round the crust.

Then, she (sister) gave the knife a final smart wipe on the edge of the plaster, and then sawed a very thick round off the loaf: which she (sister) finally, before separating from the loaf, hewed into two halves, of which Joe got one, and I the other.

I felt that I must have something in reserve for my dreadful acquaintance, and his (acquaintance) ally the still more dreadful young man.

I knew Mrs. Joe's housekeeping to be of the strictest kind, and that my larcenous researches might find nothing available in the safe.

On the present occasion, though I was hungry, I dared not eat my slice. Therefore I resolved to put my hunk of bread and butter down the leg of my trousers.

It was as if I had to make up my mind to leap from the top of a high house, or plunge into a great depth of water.

The effort of resolution necessary to the achievement of this purpose I found to be quite awful. And it was made the more difficult by the unconscious Joe.

In our already-mentioned freemasonry as fellow-sufferers, and in his (hunk) good-natured companionship with me, it was our evening habit to compare the way we bit through our slices, by silently holding them up to each other's admiration now and then,--which stimulated us to new exertions.

To-night, Joe several times invited me, by the display of his (hunk) fast diminishing slice, to enter upon our usual friendly competition; but he (hunk) found me, each time, with my yellow mug of tea on one knee, and my untouched bread and butter on the other.

At last, I desperately considered that the thing I contemplated must be done, and that it had best be done in the least improbable manner consistent with the circumstances.

I took advantage of a moment when Joe had just looked at me, and got my bread and butter down my leg.

Joe was evidently made uncomfortable by what he (hunk) supposed to be my loss of appetite, and took a thoughtful bite out of his (hunk) slice, which he (hunk) didn't seem to enjoy.

He (hunk) turned it about in his (hunk) mouth much longer than usual, pondering over it a good deal, and after all gulped it down like a pill.

He (hunk) was about to take another bite, and had just got his (hunk) head on one side for a good purchase on it, when his (hunk) eye fell on me, and he (hunk) saw that my bread and butter was gone.

The wonder and consternation with which Joe stopped on the threshold of his (hunk) bite and stared at me, were too evident to escape my sister's observation.

'' What's the matter now?'' said she (Joe), smartly, as she (Joe) put down her (Joe) cup. '' I say, you know! '' muttered Joe, shaking his (hunk) head at me in very serious remonstrance.

'' Pip, old chap! You'll do yourself a mischief. It'll stick somewhere. You can't have chawed it, Pip.'' '' What's the matter now?

'' repeated my sister, more sharply than before. '' If you can cough any trifle on it up, Pip, I'd recommend you to do it,'' said Joe, all aghast.

By this time, my sister was quite desperate, so she (Joe) pounced on Joe, and, taking him (Pip) by the two whiskers, knocked his (Pip) head for a little while against the wall behind him (Pip), while I sat in the corner, looking guiltily on.

'' Manners is manners, but still your elth's your elth. '' '' Now, perhaps you'll mention what's the matter,'' said my sister, out of breath,

``you staring great stuck pig.

You know, Pip,'' (sister)

said Joe, solemnly, with his (Pip) last bite in his (Pip) cheek, and speaking in a confidential voice, as if we two were quite alone,
``you and me is always friends, and I'd be the last to tell upon you, any time.

But such a--'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

he (Pip) moved his (Pip) chair and looked about the floor between us, and then again at me--
``such a most oncommon Bolt as that!'' (me)

'' Joe looked at her (Joe) in a helpless way, then took a helpless bite, and looked at me again. ''

``Been bolting his (Pip) food, has he (Pip)?'' (sister)
cried my sister.

You know, old chap,'' said Joe, looking at me, and not at Mrs. Joe, with his (Pip) bite still in his (Pip) cheek,

``I Bolted, myself, when I was your age--frequent--and as a boy I've been among a many Bolters; but I never see your Bolting equal yet, Pip, and it's a mercy you ain't Bolted dead.

My sister made a dive at me, and fished me up by the hair, saying nothing more than the awful words, ``You come along and be dosed.

Some medical beast had revived Tar-water in those days as a fine medicine, and Mrs. Joe always kept a supply of it in the cupboard; having a belief in its virtues correspondent to its nastiness.

At the best of times, so much of this elixir was administered to me as a choice restorative, that I was conscious of going about, smelling like a new fence.

On this particular evening the urgency of my case demanded a pint of this mixture, which was poured down my throat, for my greater comfort, while Mrs. Joe held my head under her (Joe) arm, as a boot would be held in a bootjack.

Joe got off with half a pint; but was made to swallow that -LRB-much to his (I) disturbance, as he (I) sat slowly munching and meditating before the fire-RRB-,

``because he (I) had had a turn.

'' (he)

'' '' '' Judging from myself, I should say he (I) certainly had a turn afterwards, if he (I) had had none before.

Conscience is a dreadful thing when it accuses man or boy; but when, in the case of a boy, that secret burden co-operates with another secret burden down the leg of his (boy) trousers, it is -LRB-as I can testify-RRB- a great punishment.

for I never thought of any of the housekeeping property as his (boy)--united to the necessity of always keeping one hand on my bread and butter as I sat, or when I was ordered about the kitchen on any small errand, almost drove me out of my mind.

Then, as the marsh winds made the fire glow and flare, I thought I heard the voice outside, of the man with the iron on his (man) leg who had sworn me to secrecy, declaring that he (man) couldn't and wouldn't starve until to-morrow, but must be fed now.

At other times, I thought, What if the young man who was with so much difficulty restrained from imbruing his (man) hands in me should yield to a constitutional impatience, or should mistake the time, and should think himself accredited to my heart and liver to-night, instead of to-morrow!

The guilty knowledge that I was going to rob Mrs. Joe --I never thought I was going to rob Joe, If ever anybody's hair stood on end with terror, mine must have done so then.

It was Christmas Eve, and I had to stir the pudding for next day, with a copper-stick, from seven to eight by the Dutch clock.

I tried it with the load upon my leg -LRB-and that made me think afresh of the man with the load on HIS (man) leg-RRB-, and found the tendency of exercise to bring the bread and butter out at my ankle, quite unmanageable.

But, perhaps, nobody's ever did? Happily I slipped away, and deposited that part of my conscience in my garret bedroom. ''

'' said I, when I had done my stirring, and was taking a final warm in the chimney corner before being sent up to bed;

``was that great guns, Joe?'' (I)

Hark!

``Ah!'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe. '' There's another conwict off. '' '' What does that mean, Joe?'' said I. Mrs. Joe, who always took explanations upon herself, said, snappishly,
``Escaped.

While Mrs. Joe sat with her (Joe) head bending over her (Joe) needlework, I put my mouth into the forms of saying to Joe,

Joe put his (my) mouth into the forms of returning such a highly elaborate answer, that I could make out nothing of it

Escaped. '' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

Administering the definition like Tar-water.
``What's a convict? '' (unknown)
but the single word
``Pip.'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
'' There was a conwict off last night,'' said Joe, aloud,
``after sunset-gun.

Who's firing?'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

said I.
``Drat that boy,'' (I.)
interposed my sister, frowning at me over her (Joe) work,
``what a questioner he (questioner) is.

And they fired warning of him (questioner). And now it appears they're firing warning of another. '' (me)

'' Ask no questions, and you'll be told no lies.

It was not very polite to herself, I thought, to imply that I should be told lies by her (Joe) even if I did ask questions.

At this point Joe greatly augmented my curiosity by taking the utmost pains to open his (questioner) mouth very wide, and to put it into the form of a word that looked to me like

``sulks.

'' (me)

But she (Joe) never was polite unless there was company. '' Therefore, I naturally pointed to Mrs. Joe, and put my mouth into the form of saying,
``her (Joe)?'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

But Joe wouldn't hear of that, at all, and again opened his (questioner) mouth very wide, and shook the form of a most emphatic word out of it.

Mrs. Joe,'' said I, as a last resort,

``I should like to know--if you wouldn't much mind--where the firing comes from?'' (I)

But I could make nothing of the word. ''

``Lord bless the boy! '' (sister)
exclaimed my sister, as if she (sister) didn't quite mean that but rather the contrary.

'' From the Hulks!'' '' Oh-h! '' said I, looking at Joe.

``Hulks!'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
Joe gave a reproachful cough, as much as to say,
``Well, I told you so.'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

'' And please, what's Hulks?'' said I.

``That's the way with this boy! '' (I.)
exclaimed my sister, pointing me out with her (sister) needle and thread, and shaking her (sister) head at me.

'' Answer him (boy) one question, and he (boy)'ll ask you a dozen directly. Hulks are prison-ships, right `cross th' meshes. '' We always used that name for marshes, in our country.

I wonder who's put into prison-ships, and why they're put there?'' said I, in a general way, and with quiet desperation.

'' It was too much for Mrs. Joe, who immediately rose. '' I tell you what, young fellow,'' said she (Joe),

``I didn't bring you up by hand to badger people's lives out.

People are put in the Hulks because they murder, and because they rob, and forge, and do all sorts of bad; and they always begin by asking questions.

I was never allowed a candle to light me to bed, and, as I went upstairs in the dark, with my head tingling,--from Mrs. Joe's thimble having played the tambourine upon it, to accompany her (Joe) last words,--I felt fearfully sensible of the great convenience that the hulks were handy for me.

It would be blame to me and not praise, if I had. Now, you get along to bed! '' (she)

I was clearly on my way there.

Since that time, which is far enough away now, I have often thought that few people know what secrecy there is in the young under terror.

I had begun by asking questions, and I was going to rob Mrs. Joe. No matter how unreasonable the terror, so that it be terror.

I was in mortal terror of the young man who wanted my heart and liver; I was in mortal terror of my interlocutor with the iron leg; I was in mortal terror of myself, from whom an awful promise had been extracted; I had no hope of deliverance through my all-powerful sister, who repulsed me at every turn; I am afraid to think of what I might have done on requirement, in the secrecy of my terror.

If I slept at all that night, it was only to imagine myself drifting down the river on a strong spring-tide, to the Hulks; a ghostly pirate calling out to me through a speaking-trumpet, as I passed the gibbet-station, that I had better come ashore and be hanged there at once, and not put it off.

I was afraid to sleep, even if I had been inclined, for I knew that at the first faint dawn of morning I must rob the pantry.

to have got one I must have struck it out of flint and steel, and have made a noise like the very pirate himself rattling his (pirate) chains.

As soon as the great black velvet pall outside my little window was shot with gray, I got up and went downstairs;

every board upon the way, and every crack in every board calling after me,

``Stop thief!'' (me)
and
``Get up, Mrs. Joe!'' (me)

In the pantry, which was far more abundantly supplied than usual, owing to the season, I was very much alarmed by a hare hanging up by the heels, whom I rather thought I caught, when my back was half turned, winking.

I had no time for verification, no time for selection, no time for anything, for I had no time to spare.

I stole some bread, some rind of cheese, about half a jar of mincemeat -LRB-which I tied up in my pocket-handkerchief with my last night's slice-RRB-, some brandy from a stone bottle -LRB-which I decanted into a glass bottle I had secretly used for making that intoxicating fluid, Spanish-liquorice-water, up in my room: diluting the stone bottle from a jug in the kitchen cupboard-RRB-, a meat bone with very little on it, and a beautiful round compact pork pie.

I was nearly going away without the pie, but I was tempted to mount upon a shelf, to look what it was that was put away so carefully in a covered earthenware dish in a corner, and I found it was the pie, and I took it in the hope that it was not intended for early use, and would not be missed for some time.

There was a door in the kitchen, communicating with the forge; I unlocked and unbolted that door, and got a file from among Joe's tools.

Then I put the fastenings as I had found them, opened the door at which I had entered when I ran home last night, shut it, and ran for the misty marshes.

There was no doing it in the night, for there was no getting a light by easy friction then; Chapter III

I had seen the damp lying on the outside of my little window, as if some goblin had been crying there all night, and using the window for a pocket-handkerchief.

Now, I saw the damp lying on the bare hedges and spare grass, like a coarser sort of spiders' webs; hanging itself from twig to twig and blade to blade.

On every rail and gate, wet lay clammy, and the marsh mist was so thick, that the wooden finger on the post directing people to our village--a direction which they never accepted, for they never came there--was invisible to me until I was quite close under it.

Then, as I looked up at it, while it dripped, it seemed to my oppressed conscience like a phantom devoting me to the Hulks.

The mist was heavier yet when I got out upon the marshes, so that instead of my running at everything, everything seemed to run at me.

The gates and dikes and banks came bursting at me through the mist, as if they cried as plainly as could be, ``A boy with somebody else's pork pie!

The cattle came upon me with like suddenness, staring out of their eyes, and steaming out of their nostrils,

``Halloa, young thief!'' (me)

One black ox, with a white cravat on,--who even had to my awakened conscience something of a clerical air,--fixed me so obstinately with his (thief) eyes, and moved his (thief) blunt head round in such an accusatory manner as I moved round, that I blubbered out to him (thief),

``I couldn't help it, sir!

It was a rimy morning, and very damp. This was very disagreeable to a guilty mind. Stop him (thief)! '' (him)

It wasn't for myself

Upon which he (thief) put down his (thief) head, blew a cloud of smoke out of his (thief) nose, and vanished with a kick-up of his (thief) hind-legs and a flourish of his (thief) tail.

I couldn't warm my feet, to which the damp cold seemed riveted, as the iron was riveted to the leg of the man I was running to meet.

I knew my way to the Battery, pretty straight, for I had been down there on a Sunday with Joe, and

Joe, sitting on an old gun, had told me that when I was `prentice to him (man), regularly bound, we would have such Larks there!

However, in the confusion of the mist, I found myself at last too far to the right, and consequently had to try back along the river-side, on the bank of loose stones above the mud and the stakes that staked the tide out.

Making my way along here with all despatch, I had just crossed a ditch which I knew to be very near the Battery, and had just scrambled up the mound beyond the ditch, when I saw the man sitting before me.

I took it!'' All this time, I was getting on towards the river; but however fast I went, His (man) back was towards me, and he (man) had his (man) arms folded, and was nodding forward, heavy with sleep.

I thought he (man) would be more glad if I came upon him (man) with his (man) breakfast, in that unexpected manner, so I went forward softly and touched him (man) on the shoulder.

And yet this man was dressed in coarse gray, too, and had a great iron on his (man) leg, and was lame, and hoarse, and cold, and was everything that the other man was; except that he (man) had not the same face, and had a flat broad-brimmed low-crowned felt hat on.

All this I saw in a moment, for I had only a moment to see it in: he (man) swore an oath at me, made a hit at me,--it was a round weak blow that missed me and almost knocked himself down, for it made him (man) stumble,--and

He (man) instantly jumped up, and it was not the same man, but another man! then he (man) ran into the mist, stumbling twice as he (man) went, and I lost him (man).

'' It's the young man! '' I thought, feeling my heart shoot as I identified him (man). I dare say I should have felt a pain in my liver, too, if I had known where it was.

I was soon at the Battery after that, and there was the right man,--hugging himself and limping to and fro, as if he (man) had never all night left off hugging and limping,--waiting for me.

He (man) was awfully cold, to be sure. I half expected to see him (man) drop down before my face and die of deadly cold.

His (man) eyes looked so awfully hungry too, that when I handed him (man) the file and he (man) laid it down on the grass, it occurred to me he (man) would have tried to eat it, if he (man) had not seen my bundle.

He (man) did not turn me upside down this time to get at what I had, but left me right side upwards while I opened the bundle and emptied my pockets.

Brandy,'' said I. He (man) was already handing mincemeat down his (man) throat in the most curious manner,--more like a man who was putting it away somewhere in a violent hurry, than a man who was eating

He (man) shivered all the while so violently, that it was quite as much as he (man) could do to keep the neck of the bottle between his (man) teeth, without biting it off.

'' What's in the bottle, boy? '' said he (boy). '' it,--but he (boy) left off to take some of the liquor. ''

I think you have got the ague,'' said I.

``I'm much of your opinion, boy,'' (I.)
said he (boy). '' It's bad about here,'' I told him (boy).

'' You've been lying out on the meshes, and they're dreadful aguish. Rheumatic too. ''

``I'll eat my breakfast afore they're the death of me,'' (he)
said he (boy).

'' I'd do that, if I was going to be strung up to that there gallows as there is over there, directly afterwards.

He (boy) was gobbling mincemeat, meatbone, bread, cheese, and pork pie, all at once: staring distrustfully while he (boy) did so at the mist all round us, and often stopping--even stopping his (boy) jaws--to listen.

Some real or fancied sound, some clink upon the river or breathing of beast upon the marsh, now gave him (boy) a start, and he (boy) said, suddenly,--

I'll beat the shivers so far, I'll bet you. ''

``You're not a deceiving imp? You brought no one with you?'' (unknown)

'' No, sir! No!'' '' Nor giv' no one the office to follow you?''

``No!'' (he)
'' Well,'' said he (boy),
``I believe you.

You'd be but a fierce young hound indeed, if at your time of life you could help to hunt a wretched warmint hunted as near death and dunghill as this poor wretched warmint is!'' (he)

Something clicked in his (boy) throat as if he (boy) had works in him (boy) like a clock, and was going to strike. And he (boy) smeared his (boy) ragged rough sleeve over his (boy) eyes.

Pitying his (boy) desolation, and watching him (boy) as he (boy) gradually settled down upon the pie, I made bold to say,

``I am glad you enjoy it.'' (I)

I had often watched a large dog of ours eating his (boy) food; and I now noticed a decided similarity between the dog's way of eating, and the man's.

``Did you speak?'' (I)
'' I said I was glad you enjoyed it. ''
``Thankee, my boy. I do. '' (The man)
The man took strong sharp sudden bites, just like the dog.

He (man) swallowed, or rather snapped up, every mouthful, too soon and too fast; and he (man) looked sideways here and there while he (man) ate, as if he (man) thought there was danger in every direction of somebody's coming to take the pie away.

He (man) was altogether too unsettled in his (man) mind over it, to appreciate it comfortably I thought, or to have anybody to dine with him (man), without making a chop with his (man) jaws at the visitor.

I am afraid you won't leave any of it for him (man),'' said I, timidly; after a silence during which I had hesitated as to the politeness of making the remark.

In all of which particulars he (man) was very like the dog. '' '' There's no more to be got where that came from.

'' It was the certainty of this fact that impelled me to offer the hint. '' Leave any for him (man)? Who's him (man)?'' said my friend, stopping in his (man) crunching of pie-crust.

'' The young man. That you spoke of. That was hid with you.'' '' Oh ah!'' he (man) returned, with something like a gruff laugh.

``I thought he (man) looked as if he (man) did,'' (I)
said I. The man stopped eating, and regarded me with the keenest scrutiny and the greatest surprise.

'' Him (man)? Yes, yes! He (man) don't want no wittles. '' '' Looked? When?''

``Just now. '' (unknown)
``Where?'' (unknown)
``Yonder,'' (I)
said I, pointing;
``over there, where I found him (man) nodding asleep, and thought it was you.

He (man) held me by the collar and stared at me so, that I began to think his (man) first idea about cutting my throat had revived.

Dressed like you, you know, only with a hat,'' (I)

I explained, trembling;
``and--and'' (I)
--I was very anxious to put this delicately--
``and with--the same reason for wanting to borrow a file.

I wonder you shouldn't have been sure of that,'' (I)

I returned,
``for we heard it up at home, and that's farther away, and we were shut in besides.

'' (I)

'' Didn't you hear the cannon last night?'' '' Then there was firing! '' he (I) said to himself. '' ''

When a man's alone on these flats, with a light head and a light stomach, perishing of cold and want, he (man) hears nothin' all night, but guns firing, and voices calling.

``Why, see now!'' (he)
said he (man). '' Hears? He (man) sees the soldiers, with their red coats lighted up by the torches carried afore, closing in round him (man).

Hears his (man) number called, hears himself challenged, hears the rattle of the muskets, hears the orders `Make ready! Present! Cover him (man) steady, men!'

Why, if I see one pursuing party last night--coming up in order, Damn 'em, with their tramp, tramp--I see a hundred.

Why, I see the mist shake with the cannon, arter it was broad day,--But this man''; he (man) had said all the rest, as if he (man) had forgotten my being there;

``did you notice anything in him (man)?'' (he)

and is laid hands on--and there's nothin'! And as to firing! '' He (man) had a badly bruised face,'' said I, recalling what I hardly knew I knew.

'' Not here?'' exclaimed the man, striking his (man) left cheek mercilessly, with the flat of his (man) hand. '' Yes, there!''

``Where is he (man)?'' (He)

He (man) crammed what little food was left, into the breast of his (man) gray jacket.

``Show me the way he (man) went. I'll pull him (man) down, like a bloodhound.

I indicated in what direction the mist had shrouded the other man, and he (man) looked up at it for an instant.

But he (man) was down on the rank wet grass, filing at his (man) iron like a madman, and not minding me or minding his (man) own leg, which had an old chafe upon it and was bloody, but which he (man) handled as roughly as if it had no more feeling in it than the file.

I was very much afraid of him (man) again, now that he (man) had worked himself into this fierce hurry, and I was likewise very much afraid of keeping away from home any longer.

I told him (man) I must go, but he (man) took no notice, so I thought the best thing I could do was to slip off.

The last I saw of him (man), his (man) head was bent over his (man) knee and he (man) was working hard at his (man) fetter, muttering impatient imprecations at it and at his (man) leg.

Curse this iron on my sore leg! Give us hold of the file, boy. '' (I)

The last I heard of him (boy), I stopped in the mist to listen, and the file was still going.

Chapter IV I fully expected to find a Constable in the kitchen, waiting to take me up. But not only was there no Constable there, but no discovery had yet been made of the robbery.

Mrs. Joe was prodigiously busy in getting the house ready for the festivities of the day, and Joe had been put upon the kitchen doorstep to keep him (Constable) out of the dust-pan,--an article into which his (Constable) destiny always led him (Constable), sooner or later, when my sister was vigorously reaping the floors of her (sister) establishment.

'' And where the deuce ha' you been? '' was Mrs. Joe's Christmas salutation, when I and my conscience showed ourselves.

I said I had been down to hear the Carols. '' Ah! well! '' observed Mrs. Joe. '' You might ha' done worse.

Perhaps if I warn't a blacksmith's wife, and -LRB-what's the same thing-RRB- a slave with her (wife) apron never off, I should have been to hear the Carols,'' said Mrs. Joe.

'' Not a doubt of that I thought. '' '' I'm rather partial to Carols, myself, and that's the best of reasons for my never hearing any.

Joe, who had ventured into the kitchen after me as the dustpan had retired before us, drew the back of his (slave) hand across his (slave) nose with a conciliatory air, when Mrs. Joe darted a look at him (slave), and, when her (Joe) eyes were withdrawn, secretly crossed his (slave) two forefingers, and exhibited them to me, as our token that Mrs. Joe was in a cross temper.

This was so much her (Joe) normal state, that Joe and I would often, for weeks together, be, as to our fingers, like monumental Crusaders as to their legs.

We were to have a superb dinner, consisting of a leg of pickled pork and greens, and a pair of roast stuffed fowls.

A handsome mince-pie had been made yesterday morning -LRB-which accounted for the mincemeat not being missed-RRB-, and the pudding was already on the boil.

These extensive arrangements occasioned us to be cut off unceremoniously in respect of breakfast;

``for I ain't,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Mrs. Joe,--
``I ain't a going to have no formal cramming and busting and washing up now, with what I've got before me, I promise you!

So, we had our slices served out, as if we were two thousand troops on a forced march instead of a man and boy at home; and we took gulps of milk and water, with apologetic countenances, from a jug on the dresser.

In the meantime, Mrs. Joe put clean white curtains up, and tacked a new flowered flounce across the wide chimney to replace the old one, and uncovered the little state parlor across the passage, which was never uncovered at any other time, but passed the rest of the year in a cool haze of silver paper, which even extended to the four little white crockery poodles on the mantel-shelf, each with a black nose and a basket of flowers in his (Joe) mouth, and each the counterpart of the other.

Mrs. Joe was a very clean housekeeper, but had an exquisite art of making her (Joe) cleanliness more uncomfortable and unacceptable than dirt itself.

My sister, having so much to do, was going to church vicariously, that is to say, Joe and I were going.

In his (Joe) working-clothes, Joe was a well-knit characteristic-looking blacksmith; in his (Joe) holiday clothes, he (Joe) was more like a scarecrow in good circumstances, than anything else.

Nothing that he (Joe) wore then fitted him (Joe) or seemed to belong to him (Joe); and everything that he (Joe) wore then grazed him (Joe).

On the present festive occasion he (Joe) emerged from his (Joe) room, when the blithe bells were going, the picture of misery, in a full suit of Sunday penitentials.

As to me, I think my sister must have had some general idea that I was a young offender whom an Accoucheur Policeman had taken up -LRB-on my birthday-RRB- and delivered over to her (sister), to be dealt with according to the outraged majesty of the law.

I was always treated as if I had insisted on being born in opposition to the dictates of reason, religion, and morality, and against the dissuading arguments of my best friends.

Even when I was taken to have a new suit of clothes, the tailor had orders to make them like a kind of Reformatory, and on no account to let me have the free use of my limbs.

'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

'' Cleanliness is next to Godliness, and some people do the same by their religion. Joe and I going to church, therefore, must have been a moving spectacle for compassionate minds.

The terrors that had assailed me whenever Mrs. Joe had gone near the pantry, or out of the room, were only to be equalled by the remorse with which my mind dwelt on what my hands had done.

Under the weight of my wicked secret, I pondered whether the Church would be powerful enough to shield me from the vengeance of the terrible young man, if I divulged to that establishment.

I conceived the idea that the time when the banns were read and when the clergyman said,

``Ye are now to declare it!'' (the clergyman)
would be the time for me to rise and propose a private conference in the vestry.

I am far from being sure that I might not have astonished our small congregation by resorting to this extreme measure, but for its being Christmas Day and no Sunday.

Mr. Wopsle, the clerk at church, was to dine with us; and Mr. Hubble the wheelwright and Mrs. Hubble; and Uncle Pumblechook -LRB-Joe's uncle, but Mrs. Joe appropriated him (Pumblechook)-RRB-, who was a well-to-do cornchandler in the nearest town, and drove his (Pumblechook) own chaise-cart.

When Joe and I got home, we found the table laid, and Mrs. Joe dressed, and the dinner dressing, and the front door unlocked -LRB-it never was at any other time-RRB- for the company to enter by, and everything most splendid.

Yet, what I suffered outside was nothing to what I underwent within. The dinner hour was half-past one. And still, not a word of the robbery.

Mr. Wopsle, united to a Roman nose and a large shining bald forehead, had a deep voice which he (Wopsle) was uncommonly proud of; indeed it was understood among his (Wopsle) acquaintance that if you could only give him (Wopsle) his (Wopsle) head, he (Wopsle) would read the clergyman into fits; he (Wopsle) himself confessed that if the Church was

``thrown open,'' (he)
meaning to competition, he (Wopsle) would not despair of making his (Wopsle) mark in it.

The time came, without bringing with it any relief to my feelings, and the company came. The Church not being

``thrown open,'' (he)
he (Wopsle) was, as I have said, our clerk.

verse,--he (Wopsle) looked all round the congregation first, as much as to say,

``You have heard my friend overhead; oblige me with your opinion of this style!

But he (friend) punished the Amens tremendously; and when he (friend) gave out the psalm,--always giving the whole '' (the congregation)

I opened the door to the company,--making believe that it was a habit of ours to open that

door,--and I opened it first to Mr. Wopsle, next to Mr. and Mrs. Hubble, and last of all to Uncle Pumblechook.

Mrs. Joe,'' said Uncle Pumblechook, a large hard-breathing middle-aged slow man, with a mouth like a fish, dull staring eyes, and sandy hair standing upright on his (Pumblechook) head, so that he (Pumblechook) looked as if he (Pumblechook) had just been all but choked, and had that moment come to,

``I have brought you as the compliments of the season--

N.B. I was not allowed to call him (Pumblechook) uncle, under the severest penalties. '' (he)

I have brought you, Mum, a bottle of sherry wine--and I have brought you, Mum, a bottle of port wine.

Every Christmas Day he (Pumblechook) presented himself, as a profound novelty, with exactly the same words, and carrying the two bottles like dumb-bells.

'' Every Christmas Day, Mrs. Joe replied, as she (Joe) now replied,

``O, Un--cle Pum-ble--chook! This is kind!'' (she)
Every Christmas Day, he (Pumblechook) retorted, as he (Pumblechook) now retorted,
``It's no more than your merits.

We dined on these occasions in the kitchen, and adjourned, for the nuts and oranges and apples to the parlor; which was a change very like Joe's change from his (Pumblechook) working-clothes to his (Pumblechook) Sunday dress.

My sister was uncommonly lively on the present occasion, and indeed was generally more gracious in the society of Mrs. Hubble than in other company.

I remember Mrs. Hubble as a little curly sharp-edged person in sky-blue, who held a conventionally juvenile position, because she (Hubble) had married Mr. Hubble,--I don't know at what remote

And now are you all bobbish, and how's Sixpennorth of halfpence? '' (he)

meaning me. period,--when she (Hubble) was much younger than he (Hubble).

I remember Mr Hubble as a tough, high-shouldered, stooping old man, of a sawdusty fragrance, with his (man) legs extraordinarily wide apart: so that in my short days I always saw some miles of open country between them when I met him (man) coming up the lane.

Not because I was squeezed in at an acute angle of the tablecloth, with the table in my chest, and the Pumblechookian elbow in my eye, nor because I was not allowed to speak -LRB-I didn't want to speak-RRB-, nor because I was regaled with the scaly tips of the drumsticks of the fowls, and with those obscure corners of pork of which the pig, when living, had had the least reason to be vain.

Among this good company I should have felt myself, even if I hadn't robbed the pantry, in a false position. No; I should not have minded that, if they would only have left me alone.

They seemed to think the opportunity lost, if they failed to point the conversation at me, every now and then, and stick the point into me.

I might have been an unfortunate little bull in a Spanish arena, I got so smartingly touched up by these moral goads.

Mr. Wopsle said grace with theatrical declamation,--as it now appears to me, something like a religious cross of the Ghost in Hamlet with Richard the Third,--and ended with the very proper aspiration that we might be truly grateful.

But they wouldn't leave me alone. It began the moment we sat down to dinner. Upon which my sister fixed me with her (sister) eye, and said, in a low reproachful voice, ``Do you hear that?

Mrs. Hubble shook her (Hubble) head, and contemplating me with a mournful presentiment that I should come to no good, asked,

``Why is it that the young are never grateful?'' (I)

Be grateful.''

``Especially,'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)
said Mr. Pumblechook,
``be grateful, boy, to them which brought you up by hand. '' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)
This moral mystery seemed too much for the company until Mr. Hubble tersely solved it by saying,
``Naterally wicious.

'' (Mr. Hubble)

Everybody then murmured
``True!'' (Everybody)
and looked at me in a particularly unpleasant and personal manner. Joe's station and influence were something feebler -LRB-if possible-RRB- when there was company than when there was none.

But he (Hubble) always aided and comforted me when he (Hubble) could, in some way of his (Hubble) own, and he (Hubble) always did so at dinner-time by giving me gravy, if there were any.

A little later on in the dinner, Mr. Wopsle reviewed the sermon with some severity, and intimated--in the usual hypothetical case of the Church being

``thrown open'' (Church)
--what kind of sermon he (Wopsle) would have given them.

After favoring them with some heads of that discourse, he (Wopsle) remarked that he (Wopsle) considered the subject of the day's homily, ill chosen; which was the less excusable, he (Wopsle) added, when there were so many subjects

``going about.'' (subjects)

There being plenty of gravy to-day, Joe spooned into my plate, at this point, about half a pint.

``True again,'' (Uncle Pumblechook)
said Uncle Pumblechook.

'' You've hit it, sir! Plenty of subjects going about, for them that know how to put salt upon their tails.

That's what's wanted. A man needn't go far to find a subject, if he (man)'s ready with his (man) salt-box. '' Mr. Pumblechook added, after a short interval of reflection,

``Look at Pork alone.

There's a subject! If you want a subject, look at Pork!'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)

``True, sir. Many a moral for the young,'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)
returned Mr. Wopsle,--and

I knew he (Wopsle) was going to lug me in, before he (Wopsle) said it;

``might be deduced from that text. '' (he)
-LRB-
``You listen to this,'' (sister)
said my sister to me, in a severe parenthesis.-RRB-

``Swine,'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)
pursued Mr. Wopsle, in his (Wopsle) deepest voice, and pointing his (Wopsle) fork at my blushes, as if he (Wopsle) were mentioning my Christian name,--
``swine were the companions of the prodigal.

Joe gave me some more gravy. The gluttony of Swine is put before us, as an example to the young. '' (he)

-LRB-I thought this pretty well in him (Wopsle) who had been praising up the pork for being so plump and juicy.-RRB- ''

What is detestable in a pig is more detestable in a boy.'' '' Or girl,'' suggested Mr. Hubble. '' Of course, or girl, Mr. Hubble,'' assented Mr. Wopsle, rather irritably,

``but there is no girl present.'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)

'' Besides,'' said Mr. Pumblechook, turning sharp on me,

``think what you've got to be grateful for. If you'd been born a Squeaker--'' (me)
``He (Pumblechook) was, if ever a child was,'' (sister)
said my sister, most emphatically.

Joe gave me some more gravy. '' Well, but I mean a four-footed Squeaker,'' said Mr. Pumblechook. '' If you had been born such, would you have been here now?

But I don't mean in that form, sir,'' returned Mr. Pumblechook, who had an objection to being interrupted;

``I mean, enjoying himself with his (Pumblechook) elders and betters, and improving himself with their conversation, and rolling in the lap of luxury.

Not you--'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)

'' Unless in that form,'' said Mr. Wopsle, nodding towards the dish. '' Would he (Wopsle) have been doing that?

You would have been disposed of for so many shillings according to the market price of the article, and Dunstable the butcher would have come up to you as you lay in your straw, and he (butcher) would have whipped you under his (butcher) left arm, and with his (butcher) right he (butcher) would have tucked up his (butcher) frock to get a penknife from out of his (butcher) waistcoat-pocket, and he (butcher) would have shed your blood and had your life.

No, he (butcher) wouldn't. And what would have been your destination? '' turning on me again. '' No bringing up by hand then.

Not a bit of it!'' Joe offered me more gravy, which I was afraid to take. '' He (butcher) was a world of trouble to you, ma'am,'' said Mrs. Hubble, commiserating my sister.

'' echoed my sister;

``trouble?'' (sister)
and then entered on a fearful catalogue of all the illnesses I had been guilty of, and all the acts of sleeplessness I had committed, and all the high places I had tumbled from, and all the low places I had tumbled into, and all the injuries I had done myself, and

``Trouble? all the times she (Hubble) had wished me in my grave, and I had contumaciously refused to go there. I think the Romans must have aggravated one another very much, with their noses.

Anyhow, Mr. Wopsle's Roman nose so aggravated me, during the recital of my misdemeanours, that I should have liked to pull it until he (Roman) howled.

But, all I had endured up to this time was nothing in comparison with the awful feelings that took possession of me when the pause was broken which ensued upon my sister's recital, and in which pause everybody had looked at me -LRB-as I felt painfully conscious-RRB- with indignation and abhorrence.

Yet,'' (I)

said Mr. Pumblechook, leading the company gently back to the theme from which they had strayed,
``Pork--regarded as biled--is rich, too; ain't it?'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)

Perhaps, they became the restless people they were, in consequence. ''

``Have a little brandy, uncle,'' (sister)
said my sister. O Heavens, it had come at last!

He (uncle) would find it was weak, he (uncle) would say it was weak, and I was lost! I held tight to the leg of the table under the cloth, with both hands, and awaited my fate.

My sister went for the stone bottle, came back with the stone bottle, and poured his (uncle) brandy out: no one else taking any.

The wretched man trifled with his (man) glass,--took it up, looked at it through the light, put it down,--prolonged my misery. All this time Mrs. Joe and Joe were briskly clearing the table for the pie and pudding.

Always holding tight by the leg of the table with my hands and feet, I saw the miserable creature finger his (man) glass playfully, take it up, smile, throw his (man) head back, and drink the brandy off.

Instantly afterwards, the company were seized with unspeakable consternation, owing to his (man) springing to his (man) feet, turning round several times in an appalling spasmodic whooping-cough dance, and rushing out at the door; he (man) then became visible through the window, violently plunging and expectorating, making the most hideous faces, and apparently out of his (man) mind.

I couldn't keep my eyes off him (man). I held on tight, while Mrs. Joe and Joe ran to him (man). I didn't know how I had done it, but I had no doubt

In my dreadful situation, it was a relief when he (man) was brought back, and surveying the company all round as if they had disagreed with him (man), sank down into his (man) chair with the one significant gasp,

``Tar!

I had murdered him (man) somehow. '' (him)

I had filled up the bottle from the tar-water jug. I knew he (man) would be worse by and by.

I moved the table, like a Medium of the present day, by the vigor of my unseen hold upon it. ''

But, Uncle Pumblechook, who was omnipotent in that kitchen, wouldn't hear the word, wouldn't hear of the subject, imperiously waved it all away with his (Pumblechook) hand, and asked for hot gin and water.

My sister, who had begun to be alarmingly meditative, had to employ herself actively in getting the gin, the hot water, the sugar, and the lemon-peel, and mixing them.

Tar!'' cried my sister, in amazement. '' Why, how ever could Tar come there? '' For the time being at least, I was saved.

I still held on to the leg of the table, but clutched it now with the fervor of gratitude. By degrees, I became calm enough to release my grasp and partake of pudding.

Mr. Pumblechook partook of pudding. All partook of pudding. The course terminated, and Mr. Pumblechook had begun to beam under the genial influence of gin and water.

I clutched the leg of the table again immediately, and pressed it to my bosom as if it had been the companion of my youth and friend of my soul.

I began to think I should get over the day, when my sister said to Joe, '' Clean plates,--cold. '' I foresaw what was coming, and I felt that this time I really was gone.

You must taste,'' said my sister, addressing the guests with her (sister) best grace--

``you must taste, to finish with, such a delightful and delicious present of Uncle Pumblechook's!

'' (the guests)

'' Must they! Let them not hope to taste it! '' You must know,'' said my sister, rising,
``it's a pie; a savory pork pie.

'' (sister)

The company murmured their compliments. Uncle Pumblechook, sensible of having deserved well of his (Pumblechook) fellow-creatures, said,--quite vivaciously, all things considered,--
``Well,

Mrs. Joe, we'll do our best endeavors; let us have a cut at this same pie. '' (fellow-creatures)

My sister went out to get it.

I heard her (sister) steps proceed to the pantry. I saw Mr. Pumblechook balance his (Pumblechook) knife. I saw reawakening appetite in the Roman nostrils of Mr. Wopsle.

I heard Mr. Hubble remark that

``a bit of savory pork pie would lay atop of anything you could mention, and do no harm,'' (Mr. Hubble)
and I heard Joe say,
``You shall have some, Pip.

I have never been absolutely certain whether I uttered a shrill yell of terror, merely in spirit, or in the bodily hearing of the company.

'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

I felt that I could bear no more, and that I must run away. I released the leg of the table, and ran for my life.

But I ran no farther than the house door, for there I ran head-foremost into a party of soldiers with their muskets, one of whom held out a pair of handcuffs to me, saying,

``Here you are, look sharp, come on!'' (me)

The apparition of a file of soldiers ringing down the but-ends of their loaded muskets on our door-step, caused the dinner-party to rise from table in confusion, and caused Mrs. Joe re-entering the kitchen empty-handed, to stop short and stare, in her (Joe) wondering lament of

``Gracious goodness gracious me, what's gone--with the--pie!'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

The sergeant and I were in the kitchen when Mrs. Joe stood staring; at which crisis I partially recovered the use of my senses.

It was the sergeant who had spoken to me, and he (sergeant) was now looking round at the company, with his (sergeant) handcuffs invitingly extended towards them in his (sergeant) right hand, and his (sergeant) left on my shoulder.

Excuse me, ladies and gentleman,'' said the sergeant,

``but as I have mentioned at the door to this smart young shaver,'' (the sergeant)
-LRB-which he (sergeant) hadn't-RRB-,
``I am on a chase in the name of the king, and I want the blacksmith.'' (he)

Chapter V '' '' And pray what might you want with him (blacksmith)?'' retorted my sister, quick to resent his (blacksmith) being wanted at all.

Missis,'' returned the gallant sergeant, ``speaking for myself, I should reply, the honor and pleasure of his (sergeant) fine wife's acquaintance; speaking for the king, I answer, a little job done.

``You see, blacksmith,'' (the sergeant)
said the sergeant, who had by this time picked out Joe with his (sergeant) eye,
``we have had an accident with these, and I find the lock of one of 'em goes wrong, and the coupling don't act pretty.

'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

'' This was received as rather neat in the sergeant; insomuch that Mr. Pumblechook cried audibly,
``Good again!'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)
As they are wanted for immediate service, will you throw your eye over them?''

Joe threw his (Pumblechook) eye over them, and pronounced that the job would necessitate the lighting of his (Pumblechook) forge fire, and would take nearer two hours than one.

'' Will it? Then will you set about it at once, blacksmith? '' said the off-hand sergeant,

``as it's on his (sergeant) Majesty's service.

With that, he (sergeant) called to his (sergeant) men, who came trooping into the kitchen one after another, and piled their arms in a corner.

And then they stood about, as soldiers do; now, with their hands loosely clasped before them; now, resting a knee or a shoulder; now, easing a belt or a pouch; now, opening the door to spit stiffly over their high stocks, out into the yard.

And if my men can bear a hand anywhere, they'll make themselves useful. '' (the sergeant)

All these things I saw without then knowing that I saw them, for I was in an agony of apprehension.

But beginning to perceive that the handcuffs were not for me, and that the military had so far got the better of the pie as to put it in the background, I collected a little more of my scattered wits.

'' said the sergeant, addressing himself to Mr. Pumblechook, as to a man whose appreciative powers justified the inference that he (sergeant) was equal to the time.

That's not so bad,'' said the sergeant, reflecting;

``even if I was forced to halt here nigh two hours, that'll do.

'' (the sergeant)

Would you give me the time? '' It's just gone half past two.'' '' How far might you call yourselves from the marshes, hereabouts?

Not above a mile, I reckon?''

``Just a mile,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Mrs. Joe. '' That'll do. We begin to close in upon 'em about dusk.

A little before dusk, my orders are. That'll do.''

``Convicts, sergeant?'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)
asked Mr. Wopsle, in a matter-of-course way. '' Ay!'' returned the sergeant,
``two.

They're pretty well known to be out on the marshes still, and they won't try to get clear of 'em before dusk.

Anybody here seen anything of any such game? '' (the sergeant)

Everybody, myself excepted, said no, with confidence. Nobody thought of me. ''

Well!'' said the sergeant,

``they'll find themselves trapped in a circle, I expect, sooner than they count on. Now, blacksmith! If you're ready, his (blacksmith) Majesty the King is.

'' (the sergeant)

Joe had got his (King) coat and waistcoat and cravat off, and his (King) leather apron on, and passed into the forge.

One of the soldiers opened its wooden windows, another lighted the fire, another turned to at the bellows, the rest stood round the blaze, which was soon roaring.

Then Joe began to hammer and clink, hammer and clink, and we all looked on. The interest of the impending pursuit not only absorbed the general attention, but even made my sister liberal.

She (sister) drew a pitcher of beer from the cask for the soldiers, and invited the sergeant to take a glass of brandy.

I'll engage there's no tar in that:'' so, the sergeant thanked him (sergeant) and said that as he (sergeant) preferred his (sergeant) drink without tar, he (sergeant) would take wine, if it was equally convenient.

When it was given him (sergeant), he (sergeant) drank his (sergeant) Majesty's health and compliments of the season, and took it all at a mouthful and smacked his (sergeant) lips.

But Mr. Pumblechook said, sharply,

``Give him (Pumblechook) wine, Mum. '' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)
Good stuff, eh, sergeant?'' said Mr. Pumblechook. '' I'll tell you something,'' returned the sergeant;
``I suspect that stuff's of your providing.

'' (the sergeant)

Mr. Pumblechook, with a fat sort of laugh, said,
``Ay, ay? Why?'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)
'' Because,'' returned the sergeant, clapping him (sergeant) on the shoulder,
``you're a man that knows what's what.'' (him)

'' D'ye think so?'' said Mr. Pumblechook, with his (Pumblechook) former laugh.

``Have another glass!'' (unknown)
``With you. Hob and nob,'' (the sergeant)
returned the sergeant.

The top of mine to the foot of yours,--the foot of yours to the top of mine,--Ring once, ring twice,--the best tune on the Musical Glasses!

May you live a thousand years, and never be a worse judge of the right sort than you are at the present moment of your life!''

I noticed that Mr. Pumblechook in his (Pumblechook) hospitality appeared to forget that he (Pumblechook) had made a present of the wine, but took the bottle from Mrs. Joe and had all the credit of handing it about in a gush of joviality.

'' Your health. The sergeant tossed off his (sergeant) glass again and seemed quite ready for another glass. Even I got some.

And he (sergeant) was so very free of the wine that he (sergeant) even called for the other bottle, and handed that about with the same liberality, when the first was gone.

As I watched them while they all stood clustering about the forge, enjoying themselves so much, I thought what terrible good sauce for a dinner my fugitive friend on the marshes was.

And now, when they were all in lively anticipation of

``the two villains'' (the fugitives)
being taken, and when the bellows seemed to roar for the fugitives, the fire to flare for them, the smoke to hurry away in pursuit of them, Joe to hammer and clink for them, and all the murky shadows on the wall to shake at them in menace as the blaze rose and sank, and the red-hot sparks dropped and died, the pale afternoon outside almost seemed in my pitying young fancy to have turned pale on their account, poor wretches.

They had not enjoyed themselves a quarter so much, before the entertainment was brightened with the excitement he (them) furnished. At last, Joe's job was done, and the ringing and roaring stopped.

As Joe got on his (them) coat, he (them) mustered courage to propose that some of us should go down with the soldiers and see what came of the hunt.

Mr. Pumblechook and Mr. Hubble declined, on the plea of a pipe and ladies' society; but Mr. Wopsle said he (Wopsle) would go, if Joe would.

We never should have got leave to go, I am sure, but for Mrs. Joe's curiosity to know all about it and how it ended.

As it was, she (Joe) merely stipulated,

``If you bring the boy back with his (boy) head blown to bits by a musket, don't look to me to put it together again.

The sergeant took a polite leave of the ladies, and parted from Mr. Pumblechook as from a comrade; though I doubt if he (Pumblechook) were quite as fully sensible of that gentleman's merits under arid conditions, as when something moist was going.

Joe said he (Pumblechook) was agreeable, and would take me, if Mrs. Joe approved. '' (she)

His (Pumblechook) men resumed their muskets and fell in.

Mr. Wopsle, Joe, and I, received strict charge to keep in the rear, and to speak no word after we reached the marshes.

When we were all out in the raw air and were steadily moving towards our business, I treasonably whispered to Joe,

``I hope, Joe, we shan't find them.

We were joined by no stragglers from the village, for the weather was cold and threatening, the way dreary, the footing bad, darkness coming on, and the people had good fires in-doors and were keeping the day.

'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

and Joe whispered to me,
``I'd give a shilling if they had cut and run, Pip. '' (me)
A few faces hurried to glowing windows and looked after us, but none came out.

There we were stopped a few minutes by a signal from the sergeant's hand, while two or three of his (sergeant) men dispersed themselves among the graves, and also examined the porch.

They came in again without finding anything, and then we struck out on the open marshes, through the gate at the side of the churchyard.

We passed the finger-post, and held straight on to the churchyard. A bitter sleet came rattling against us here on the east wind, and Joe took me on his (sergeant) back.

Now that we were out upon the dismal wilderness where they little thought I had been within eight or nine hours and had seen both men hiding, I considered for the first time, with great dread, if we should come upon them, would my particular convict suppose that it was I who had brought the soldiers there?

He (sergeant) had asked me if I was a deceiving imp, and he (sergeant) had said I should be a fierce young hound if I joined the hunt against him (sergeant).

Would he (sergeant) believe that I was both imp and hound in treacherous earnest, and had betrayed him (sergeant)? It was of no use asking myself this question now.

There I was, on Joe's back, and there was Joe beneath me, charging at the ditches like a hunter, and stimulating Mr. Wopsle not to tumble on his (Wopsle) Roman nose, and to keep up with us.

The soldiers were in front of us, extending into a pretty wide line with an interval between man and man. We were taking the course I had begun with, and from which I had diverged in the mist.

Under the low red glare of sunset, the beacon, and the gibbet, and the mound of the Battery, and the opposite shore of the river, were plain, though all of a watery lead color.

With my heart thumping like a blacksmith at Joe's broad shoulder, I looked all about for any sign of the convicts.

Either the mist was not out again yet, or the wind had dispelled it. I could see none, I could hear none.

Mr. Wopsle had greatly alarmed me more than once, by his (Wopsle) blowing and hard breathing; but I knew the sounds by this time, and could dissociate them from the object of pursuit.

The sheep stopped in their eating and looked timidly at us; and the cattle, their heads turned from the wind and sleet, stared angrily as if they held us responsible for both annoyances; but, except these things, and the shudder of the dying day in every blade of grass, there was no break in the bleak stillness of the marshes.

The soldiers were moving on in the direction of the old Battery, and we were moving on a little way behind them, when, all of a sudden, we all stopped.

I got a dreadful start, when I thought I heard the file still going; but it was only a sheep-bell. For there had reached us on the wings of the wind and rain, a long shout.

It was repeated. It was at a distance towards the east, but it was long and loud. Nay, there seemed to be

two or more shouts raised together,--if one might judge from a confusion in the sound. To this effect the sergeant and the nearest men were speaking under their breath, when Joe and I came up.

The sergeant, a decisive man, ordered that the sound should not be answered, but that the course should be changed, and that his (sergeant) men should make towards it

``at the double.

After another moment's listening, Joe -LRB-who was a good judge-RRB- agreed, and Mr. Wopsle -LRB-who was a bad judge-RRB- agreed. '' (men)

So we slanted to the right -LRB-where the East was-RRB-, and Joe pounded away so wonderfully, that I had to hold on tight to keep my seat.

It was a run indeed now, and what Joe called, in the only two words he (Wopsle) spoke all the time,

``a Winder.

Down banks and up banks, and over gates, and splashing into dikes, and breaking among coarse rushes: no man cared where he (man) went.

As we came nearer to the shouting, it became more and more apparent that it was made by more than one voice.

'' (he)

Sometimes, it seemed to stop altogether, and then the soldiers stopped. When it broke out again, the soldiers made for it at a greater rate than ever, and we after them.

After a while, we had so run it down, that we could hear one voice calling

``Murder!'' (unknown)
and another voice,
``Convicts!

Runaways! Guard! This way for the runaway convicts! '' (unknown)

Then both voices would seem to be stifled in a struggle, and then would break out again.

The sergeant ran in first, when we had run the noise quite down, and two of his (sergeant) men ran in close upon him (sergeant).

And when it had come to this, the soldiers ran like deer, and Joe too. Their pieces were cocked and levelled when we all ran in.

'' Here are both men! '' panted the sergeant, struggling at the bottom of a ditch. '' Surrender, you two! and confound you for two wild beasts!

Water was splashing, and mud was flying, and oaths were being sworn, and blows were being struck, when some more men went down into the ditch to help the sergeant, and dragged out, separately, my convict and the other one.

Come asunder!'' Both were bleeding and panting and execrating and struggling; but of course I knew them both directly. '' Mind!

'' said my convict, wiping blood from his (sergeant) face with his (sergeant) ragged sleeves, and shaking torn hair from his (sergeant) fingers:

``I took him (sergeant)!

It's not much to be particular about,'' (the sergeant)

said the sergeant;
``it'll do you small good, my man, being in the same plight yourself.

I give him (sergeant) up to you! Mind that!'' (the sergeant)

'' Handcuffs there!''
``I don't expect it to do me any good. I don't want it to do me more good than it does now,'' (unknown)
said my convict, with a greedy laugh.

The other convict was livid to look at, and, in addition to the old bruised left side of his (sergeant) face, seemed to be bruised and torn all over.

He (sergeant) could not so much as get his (sergeant) breath to speak, until they were both separately handcuffed, but leaned upon a soldier to keep himself from falling.

'' I took him (soldier). He (soldier) knows it. That's enough for me. '' '' Take notice, guard,--he (guard) tried to murder me,'' were his (guard) first words.

'' Tried to murder him (guard)?'' said my convict, disdainfully.

``Try, and not do it? I took him (guard), and giv' him (guard) up; that's what I done.

I not only prevented him (guard) getting off the marshes, but I dragged him (guard) here,--dragged him (guard) this far on his (guard) way back.

He (guard)'s a gentleman, if you please, this villain. Now, the Hulks has got its gentleman again, through me. Murder him (gentleman)? Worth my while, too, to murder him (gentleman), when I could do worse and drag him (gentleman) back!

'' (unknown)

The other one still gasped,
``He (gentleman) tried--he (gentleman) tried-to--murder me. Bear--bear witness.'' (unknown)
``Lookee here!'' (the sergeant)
said my convict to the sergeant. ''

I could ha' got clear of these death-cold flats likewise--look at my leg: you won't find much iron on it--if I hadn't made the discovery that he (sergeant) was here.

Single-handed I got clear of the prison-ship; I made a dash and I done it. Let him (sergeant) go free? Let him (sergeant) profit by the means as I found out?

If I had died at the bottom there,'' and he (sergeant) made an emphatic swing at the ditch with his (sergeant) manacled hands,

``I'd have held to him (sergeant) with that grip, that you should have been safe to find him (sergeant) in my hold.

Let him (sergeant) make a tool of me afresh and again? Once more? No, no, no. '' (he)

The other fugitive, who was evidently in extreme horror of his (sergeant) companion, repeated,
``He (sergeant) tried to murder me.

I should have been a dead man if you had not come up.'' (companion)

'' He (man) lies!'' said my convict, with fierce energy.

'' He (man)'s a liar born, and he (man)'ll die a liar. Look at his (man) face; ain't it written there? Let him (man) turn those eyes of his (man) on me.

The other, with an effort at a scornful smile, which could not, however, collect the nervous working of his (man) mouth into any set expression, looked at the soldiers, and looked about at the marshes and at the sky, but certainly did not look at the speaker.

I defy him (speaker) to do it. '' '' Do you see him (speaker)?'' pursued my convict. '' Do you see what a villain he (villain) is?

Do you see those grovelling and wandering eyes? That's how he (villain) looked when we were tried together. He (villain) never looked at me.

The other, always working and working his (villain) dry lips and turning his (villain) eyes restlessly about him (villain) far and near, did at last turn them for a moment on the speaker, with the words,
