``You are not much to look at,'' (the speaker)
and with a half-taunting glance at the bound hands.

At that point, my convict became so frantically exasperated, that he (speaker) would have rushed upon him (speaker) but for the interposition of the soldiers.

And any one could see that he (speaker) shook with fear, and that there broke out upon his (speaker) lips curious white flakes, like thin snow.

'' '' Didn't I tell you,'' said the other convict then,

``that he (speaker) would murder me, if he (speaker) could? '' (I)
''

As one of the soldiers, who carried a basket in lieu of a gun, went down on his (speaker) knee to open it, my convict looked round him (speaker) for the first time, and saw me.

I had alighted from Joe's back on the brink of the ditch when we came up, and had not moved since.

Enough of this parley,'' said the sergeant. '' Light those torches. '' I looked at him (sergeant) eagerly when he (sergeant) looked at me, and slightly moved my hands and shook my head.

It was not at all expressed to me that he (sergeant) even comprehended my intention, for he (sergeant) gave me a look that I did not understand, and it all passed in a moment.

But if he (sergeant) had looked at me for an hour or for a day, I could not have remembered his (sergeant) face ever afterwards, as having been more attentive.

The soldier with the basket soon got a light, and lighted three or four torches, and took one himself and distributed the others.

I had been waiting for him (soldier) to see me that I might try to assure him (soldier) of my innocence. It had been almost dark before, but now it seemed quite dark, and soon afterwards very dark.

Presently we saw other torches kindled at some distance behind us, and others on the marshes on the opposite bank of the river.

Before we departed from that spot, four soldiers standing in a ring, fired twice into the air. '' All right,'' said the sergeant.

We had not gone far when three cannon were fired ahead of us with a sound that seemed to burst something inside my ear.

``March. '' (the sergeant)
'' You are expected on board,'' said the sergeant to my convict;
``they know you are coming. Don't straggle, my man.

Close up here. '' (the sergeant)

The two were kept apart, and each walked surrounded by a separate guard. I had hold of Joe's hand now, and Joe carried one of the torches.

Mr. Wopsle had been for going back, but Joe was resolved to see it out, so we went on with the party.

There was a reasonably good path now, mostly on the edge of the river, with a divergence here and there where a dike came, with a miniature windmill on it and a muddy sluice-gate.

The torches we carried dropped great blotches of fire upon the track, and I could see those, too, lying smoking and flaring.

When I looked round, I could see the other lights coming in after us. I could see nothing else but black darkness.

Our lights warmed the air about us with their pitchy blaze, and the two prisoners seemed rather to like that, as they limped along in the midst of the muskets.

We could not go fast, because of their lameness; and they were so spent, that two or three times we had to halt while they rested.

After an hour or so of this travelling, we came to a rough wooden hut and a landing-place. There was a guard in the hut, and they challenged, and the sergeant answered.

Then, we went into the hut, where there was a smell of tobacco and whitewash, and a bright fire, and a lamp, and a stand of muskets, and a drum, and a low wooden bedstead, like an overgrown mangle without the machinery, capable of holding about a dozen soldiers all at once.

Three or four soldiers who lay upon it in their great-coats were not much interested in us, but just lifted their heads and took a sleepy stare, and then lay down again.

The sergeant made some kind of report, and some entry in a book, and then the convict whom I call the other convict was drafted off with his (sergeant) guard, to go on board first.

While we stood in the hut, he (sergeant) stood before the fire looking thoughtfully at it, or putting up his (sergeant) feet by turns upon the hob, and looking thoughtfully at them as if he (sergeant) pitied them for their recent adventures.

My convict never looked at me, except that once. Suddenly, he (sergeant) turned to the sergeant, and remarked,-- ``I wish to say something respecting this escape.

``You can say what you like,'' (the sergeant)
returned the sergeant, standing coolly looking at him (sergeant) with his (sergeant) arms folded,
``but you have no call to say it here.

It may prevent some persons laying under suspicion alonger me.'' (him)

You'll have opportunity enough to say about it, and hear about it, before it's done with, you know.

''

``I know, but this is another pint, a separate matter. A man can't starve; at least I can't. I took some wittles, up at the willage over

yonder,--where the church stands a`most out on the marshes. '' (unknown)

``You mean stole,'' (the sergeant)
said the sergeant. '' And I'll tell you where from.

From the blacksmith's. ''

``Halloa!'' (the sergeant)
said the sergeant, staring at Joe. '' Halloa, Pip!'' said Joe, staring at me. '' It was some broken wittles--that's what it was--and a dram of liquor, and a pie.''

``Have you happened to miss such an article as a pie, blacksmith? '' (the sergeant)
asked the sergeant, confidentially. '' My wife did, at the very moment when you came in.

Don't you know, Pip?''

``So,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said my convict, turning his (sergeant) eyes on Joe in a moody manner, and without the least glance at me,--``so

``God knows you're welcome to it,--so far as it was ever mine,'' (me)
returned Joe, with a saving remembrance of Mrs. Joe.

We don't know what you have done, but we wouldn't have you starved to death for it, poor miserable fellow-creatur.--Would us, Pip?

you're the blacksmith, are you? Than I'm sorry to say, I've eat your pie.'' '' '' The something that I had noticed before, clicked in the man's throat again, and he (man) turned his (man) back.

The boat had returned, and his (man) guard were ready, so we followed him (man) to the landing-place made of rough stakes and stones, and saw him (man) put into the boat, which was rowed by a crew of convicts like himself.

No one seemed surprised to see him (man), or interested in seeing him (man), or glad to see him (man), or sorry to see him (man), or spoke a word, except that somebody in the boat growled as if to dogs,

``Give way, you!'' (that somebody)
which was the signal for the dip of the oars.

By the light of the torches, we saw the black Hulk lying out a little way from the mud of the shore, like a wicked Noah's ark.

Cribbed and barred and moored by massive rusty chains, the prison-ship seemed in my young eyes to be ironed like the prisoners.

Then, the ends of the torches were flung hissing into the water, and went out, as if it were all over with him (Noah).

My state of mind regarding the pilfering from which I had been so unexpectedly exonerated did not impel me to frank disclosure; but I hope it had some dregs of good at the bottom of it.

I do not recall that I felt any tenderness of conscience in reference to Mrs. Joe, when the fear of being found out was lifted off me.

But I loved Joe,--perhaps for no better reason in those early days than because the dear fellow let me love him (Noah),--and, as to him (Noah), my inner self was not so easily composed.

It was much upon my mind -LRB-particularly when I first saw him (Noah) looking about for his (Noah) file-RRB- that I ought to tell Joe the whole truth.

Yet I did not, and for the reason that I mistrusted that if I did, he (Noah) would think me worse than I was.

The fear of losing Joe's confidence, and of thenceforth sitting in the chimney corner at night staring drearily at my forever lost companion and friend, tied up my tongue.

I morbidly represented to myself that if Joe knew it, I never afterwards could see him (friend) at the fireside feeling his (friend) fair whisker, without thinking that he (friend) was meditating on it.

That, if Joe knew it, I never afterwards could see him (friend) glance, however casually, at yesterday's meat or pudding when it came on to-day's table, without thinking that he (friend) was debating whether I had been in the pantry.

That, if Joe knew it, and at any subsequent period of our joint domestic life remarked that his (friend) beer was flat or thick, the conviction that he (friend) suspected tar in it, would bring a rush of blood to my face.

In a word, I was too cowardly to do what I knew to be right, as I had been too cowardly to avoid doing what I knew to be wrong.

I had had no intercourse with the world at that time, and I imitated none of its many inhabitants who act in this manner.

We saw the boat go alongside, and we saw him (friend) taken up the side and disappear. Chapter VI Quite an untaught genius, I made the discovery of the line of action for myself.

As I was sleepy before we were far away from the prison-ship, Joe took me on his (genius) back again and carried me home.

He (genius) must have had a tiresome journey of it, for Mr. Wopsle, being knocked up, was in such a very bad temper that if the Church had been thrown open, he (Wopsle) would probably have excommunicated the whole expedition, beginning with Joe and myself.

In his (Wopsle) lay capacity, he (Wopsle) persisted in sitting down in the damp to such an insane extent, that when his (Wopsle) coat was taken off to be dried at the kitchen fire, the circumstantial evidence on his (Wopsle) trousers would have hanged him (Wopsle), if it had been a capital offence.

By that time, I was staggering on the kitchen floor like a little drunkard, through having been newly set upon my feet, and through having been fast asleep, and through waking in the heat and lights and noise of tongues.

Was there ever such a boy as this!'' from my sister,-RRB- I found Joe telling them about the convict's confession, and all the visitors suggesting different ways by which he (boy) had got into the pantry.

Mr. Pumblechook made out, after carefully surveying the premises, that he (Pumblechook) had first got upon the roof of the forge, and had then got upon the roof of the house, and had then let himself down the kitchen chimney by a rope made of his (Pumblechook) bedding cut into strips; and as Mr. Pumblechook was very positive and drove his (Pumblechook) own chaise-cart--over everybody--it was agreed that it must be so.

Mr. Wopsle, indeed, wildly cried out,

``No!'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)
with the feeble malice of a tired man; but, as he (man) had no theory, and no coat on, he (man) was unanimously set at naught,--not to mention his (man) smoking hard behind, as he (man) stood with his (man) back to the kitchen fire to draw the damp out: which was not calculated to inspire confidence.

This was all I heard that night before my sister clutched me, as a slumberous offence to the company's eyesight, and assisted me up to bed with such a strong hand that I seemed to have fifty boots on, and to be dangling them all against the edges of the stairs.

My state of mind, as I have described it, began before I was up in the morning, and lasted long after the subject had died out, and had ceased to be mentioned saving on exceptional occasions.

As I came to myself -LRB-with the aid of a heavy thump between the shoulders, and the restorative exclamation ``Yah! Chapter VII

At the time when I stood in the churchyard reading the family tombstones, I had just enough learning to be able to spell them out.

My construction even of their simple meaning was not very correct, for I read

``wife of the Above'' (I)
as a complimentary reference to my father's exaltation to a better world; and if any one of my deceased relations had been referred to as
``Below,'' (father)
I have no doubt I should have formed the worst opinions of that member of the family.

Neither were my notions of the theological positions to which my Catechism bound me, at all accurate; for, I have a lively remembrance that I supposed my declaration that I was to

``walk in the same all the days of my life,'' (I)
laid me under an obligation always to go through the village from our house in one particular direction, and never to vary it by turning down by the wheelwright's or up by the mill.

When I was old enough, I was to be apprenticed to Joe, and until I could assume that dignity I was not to be what Mrs. Joe called

``Pompeyed,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
or -LRB-as I render it-RRB- pampered.

Therefore, I was not only odd-boy about the forge, but if any neighbor happened to want an extra boy to frighten birds, or pick up stones, or do any such job, I was favored with the employment.

In order, however, that our superior position might not be compromised thereby, a money-box was kept on the kitchen mantel-shelf, into which it was publicly made known that all my earnings were dropped.

I have an impression that they were to be contributed eventually towards the liquidation of the National Debt, but I know I had no hope of any personal participation in the treasure.

Mr. Wopsle's great-aunt kept an evening school in the village; that is to say, she (I) was a ridiculous old woman of limited means and unlimited infirmity, who used to go to sleep from six to seven every evening, in the society of youth who paid two pence per week each, for the improving opportunity of seeing her (I) do it.

She (I) rented a small cottage, and Mr. Wopsle had the room upstairs, where we students used to overhear him (Wopsle) reading aloud in a most dignified and terrific manner, and occasionally bumping on the ceiling.

What he (Wopsle) did on those occasions was to turn up his (Wopsle) cuffs, stick up his (Wopsle) hair, and give us Mark Antony's oration over the body of Caesar.

This was always followed by Collins's Ode on the Passions, wherein I particularly venerated Mr. Wopsle as Revenge throwing his (Wopsle) blood-stained sword in thunder down, and taking the War-denouncing trumpet with a withering look.

It was not with me then, as it was in later life, when I fell into the society of the Passions, and compared them with Collins and Wopsle, rather to the disadvantage of both gentlemen.

There was a fiction that Mr. Wopsle

``examined'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)
the scholars once a quarter. Mr. Wopsle's great-aunt, besides keeping this Educational Institution, kept in the same room--a little general shop.

She (great-aunt) had no idea what stock she (great-aunt) had, or what the price of anything in it was; but there was a little greasy memorandum-book kept in a drawer, which served as a Catalogue of Prices, and by this oracle Biddy arranged all the shop transactions.

Biddy was Mr. Wopsle's great-aunt's granddaughter; I confess myself quite unequal to the working out of the problem, what relation she (granddaughter) was to Mr. Wopsle.

She (granddaughter) was most noticeable, I thought, in respect of her (granddaughter) extremities; for, her (granddaughter) hair always wanted brushing, her (granddaughter) hands always wanted washing, and her (granddaughter) shoes always wanted mending and pulling up at heel.

She (granddaughter) was an orphan like myself; like me, too, had been brought up by hand. This description must be received with a week-day limitation.

Much of my unassisted self, and more by the help of Biddy than of Mr. Wopsle's great-aunt, I struggled through the alphabet as if it had been a bramble-bush; getting considerably worried and scratched by every letter.

After that I fell among those thieves, the nine figures, who seemed every evening to do something new to disguise themselves and baffle recognition.

On Sundays, she (great-aunt) went to church elaborated. But, at last I began, in a purblind groping way, to read, write, and cipher, on the very smallest scale.

One night I was sitting in the chimney corner with my slate, expending great efforts on the production of a letter to Joe.

I think it must have been a full year after our hunt upon the marshes, for it was a long time after, and it was winter and a hard frost.

With an alphabet on the hearth at my feet for reference, I contrived in an hour or two to print and smear this epistle:--

``MI DEER JO

i OPE U R KRWITE WELL i OPE i SHAL SON B HABELL 4 2 TEEDGE U JO AN THEN WE SHORL B SO GLODD

There was no indispensable necessity for my communicating with Joe by letter, inasmuch as he (our) sat beside me and we were alone.

But I delivered this written communication -LRB-slate and all-RRB- with my own hand, and Joe received it as a miracle of erudition.

AN WEN i M PRENGTD 2 U JO WOT LARX AN BLEVE ME INF XN PIP. '' (I)

'' I say, Pip, old chap!

``I should like to be,'' (I)
said I, glancing at the slate as he (chap) held it; with a misgiving that the writing was rather hilly.

'' cried Joe, opening his (chap) blue eyes wide,

``what a scholar you are! An't you?'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
'' Why, here's a J,'' said Joe, ``and a O equal to anythink!

I had never heard Joe read aloud to any greater extent than this monosyllable, and I had observed at church last Sunday, when I accidentally held our Prayer-Book upside down, that it seemed to suit his (chap) convenience quite as well as if it had been all right.

Wishing to embrace the present occasion of finding out whether in teaching Joe, I should have to begin quite at the beginning, I said,

``Ah!

Here's a J and a O, Pip, and a J-O, Joe. '' (I)

But read the rest, Jo.'' '' The rest, eh, Pip?'' said Joe, looking at it with a slow, searching eye,
``One, two, three.

Why, here's three Js, and three Os, and three J-O, Joes in it, Pip! '' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

I leaned over Joe, and, with the aid of my forefinger read him (Joes) the whole letter.

'' Astonishing! '' said Joe, when I had finished. '' You ARE a scholar. ''

``How do you spell Gargery, Joe?

'' (I)

I asked him (scholar), with a modest patronage. '' I don't spell it at all,'' said Joe. '' But supposing you did?''

Give me,'' said Joe, ``a good book, or a good newspaper, and sit me down afore a good fire, and I ask no better.

``It can't be supposed,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe. '' Tho' I'm uncommon fond of reading, too.''
``Are you, Joe? '' (unknown)

``when you do come to a J and a O, and says you, `Here, at last, is a J-O, Joe,' how interesting reading is!'' (he)

I derived from this, that Joe's education, like Steam, was yet in its infancy. Pursuing the subject, I inquired,--

``Didn't you ever go to school,

Joe, when you were as little as me?'' (I)

``No, Pip. '' (unknown)
``Why didn't you ever go to school, Joe, when you were as little as me?'' (Pip/Mr. Pip)

Well, Pip,'' said Joe, taking up the poker, and settling himself to his (Pip) usual occupation when he (Pip) was thoughtful, of slowly raking the fire between the lower bars;

``I'll tell you.

My father, Pip, he (Pip) were given to drink, and when he (Pip) were overtook with drink, he (Pip) hammered away at my mother, most onmerciful.

And he (Pip) hammered at me with a wigor only to be equalled by the wigor with which he (Pip) didn't hammer at his (Pip) anwil.--You're a listening and understanding, Pip?'' (he)

`Consequence, my mother and me we ran away from my father several times; and then my mother she (mother)'d go out to work, and she (mother)'d say,

``Joe,'' (she)
she (Joe)'d say,
``now, please God, you shall have some schooling, child,'' (she)
and she (Joe)'d put me to school.

'' It were a`most the only hammering he (God) did, indeed, `xcepting at myself. '' Yes, Joe. '' '' But my father were that good in his (father) hart that he (father) couldn't abear to be without us.

So, he (father)'d come with a most tremenjous crowd and make such a row at the doors of the houses where we was, that they used to be obligated to have no more to do with us and to give us up to him (father).

Which, you see, Pip,'' said Joe, pausing in his (Pip) meditative raking of the fire, and looking at me,

``were a drawback on my learning.

Though mind you, Pip,'' (me)

said Joe, with a judicial touch or two of the poker on the top bar,
``rendering unto all their doo, and maintaining equal justice betwixt man and man, my father were that good in his (father) hart, don't you see?

And then he (father) took us home and hammered us. '' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

``Certainly, poor Joe! '' (I)

Joe pursued,

I saw that, and said so.

`Consequence, my father didn't make objections to my going to work; so I went to work at my present calling, which were his (father) too, if he (father) would have followed it, and I worked tolerable hard

In time I were able to keep him (father), and I kep him (father) till he (father) went off in a purple leptic fit.

She (mother) were in poor elth, and quite broke. She (mother) weren't long of following, poor soul, and her (mother) share of peace come round at last.

Joe's blue eyes turned a little watery; he (Pip) rubbed first one of them, and then the other, in a most uncongenial and uncomfortable manner, with the round knob on the top of the poker.

I could not help looking at the fire, in an obvious state of doubt.

'' I sagaciously observed, if it didn't signify to him (Joe), to whom did it signify? '' Certainly!'' assented Joe. '' That's it.

You're right, old chap! When I got acquainted with your sister, it were the talk how she (sister) was bringing you up by hand.

As to you,'' Joe pursued with a countenance expressive of seeing something very nasty indeed,

``if you could have been aware how small and flabby and

Very kind of her (Joe) too, all the folks said, and I said, along with all the folks. mean you was, dear me, you'd have formed the most contemptible opinion of yourself!'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

``Never mind me, Joe.'' (I)

When I offered to your sister to keep company, and to be asked in church at such times as she (sister) was willing and ready to come to the forge, I said to her (sister), `And bring the poor little child.

I broke out crying and begging pardon, and hugged Joe round the neck: who dropped the poker to hug me, and to say,

``Ever the best of friends; an't us, Pip?

'' (me)

When this little interruption was over, Joe resumed:-- '' Well, you see, Pip, and here we are! That's about where it lights; here we are!

Now, when you take me in hand in my learning, Pip -LRB-and I tell you beforehand I am awful dull, most awful dull-RRB-, Mrs. Joe mustn't see too much of what we're up to.

Stay a bit. I know what you're a going to say, Pip; stay a bit! I don't deny that your sister comes the Mo-gul over us, now and again.

At such times as when your sister is on the Ram-page, Pip,'' Joe sank his (Pip) voice to a whisper and glanced at the door,

``candor compels fur to admit that she (Joe) is a Buster.

I don't deny that she (Joe) do throw us back-falls, and that she (Joe) do drop down upon us heavy. '' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

Joe pronounced this word, as if it began with at least twelve capital Bs.

But Joe was readier with his (Buster) definition than I had expected, and completely stopped me by arguing circularly, and answering with a fixed look,

``Her (Joe).'' (me)

A master-mind. '' '' What's that? '' I asked, in some hope of bringing him (Buster) to a stand. '' And I ain't a master-mind,'' Joe resumed, when he (Buster) had unfixed his (Buster) look, and got back to his (Buster) whisker.

I want to say very serious to you, old chap,--I see so much in my poor mother, of a woman drudging and slaving and breaking her (woman) honest hart and never getting no peace in her (woman) mortal days, that I'm dead afeerd of going wrong in the way of not doing what's right by a woman, and I'd fur rather of the two go wrong the t`other way, and be a little ill-conwenienced myself.

I wish it was only me that got put out, Pip; I wish there warn't no Tickler for you, old chap; I wish I could take it all on myself; but this is the up-and-down-and-straight on it, Pip, and I hope you'll overlook shortcomings.

'' And last of all, Pip,--and this '' Young as I was, I believe that I dated a new admiration of Joe from that night.

We were equals afterwards, as we had been before; but, afterwards at quiet times when I sat looking at Joe and thinking about him (Young), I had a new sensation of feeling conscious that I was looking up to Joe in my heart.

However,'' said Joe, rising to replenish the fire;

``here's the Dutch-clock a working himself up to being equal to strike Eight of 'em, and she (Joe)'s not come home yet!

Mrs. Joe made occasional trips with Uncle Pumblechook on market-days, to assist him (Pumblechook) in buying such household stuffs and goods as required a woman's judgment; Uncle Pumblechook being a bachelor and reposing no confidences in his (Pumblechook) domestic servant.

'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

I hope Uncle Pumblechook's mare mayn't have set a forefoot on a piece o' ice, and gone down. '' This was market-day, and Mrs. Joe was out on one of these expeditions.

Joe made the fire and swept the hearth, and then we went to the door to listen for the chaise-cart. It was a dry cold night, and the wind blew keenly, and the frost was white and hard.

And then I looked at the stars, and considered how awful it would be for a man to turn his (man) face up to them as he (man) froze to death, and see no help or pity in all the glittering multitude.

A man would die to-night of lying out on the marshes, I thought. '' Here comes the mare,'' said Joe,

``ringing like a peal of bells!

The sound of her (Joe) iron shoes upon the hard road was quite musical, as she (Joe) came along at a much brisker trot than usual.

We got a chair out, ready for Mrs. Joe's alighting, and stirred up the fire that they might see a bright window, and took a final survey of the kitchen that nothing might be out of its place.

Mrs. Joe was soon landed, and Uncle Pumblechook was soon down too, covering the mare with a cloth, and we were soon all in the kitchen, carrying so much cold air in with us that it seemed to drive all the heat out of the fire.

Now,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

said Mrs. Joe, unwrapping herself with haste and excitement, and throwing her (Joe) bonnet back on her (Joe) shoulders where it hung by the strings,
``if this boy ain't grateful this night, he (boy) never will be!

'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

When we had completed these preparations, they drove up, wrapped to the eyes. '' '' I looked as grateful as any boy possibly could, who was wholly uninformed why he (boy) ought to assume that expression.

'' It's only to be hoped,'' said my sister,

``that he (boy) won't be Pompeyed. But I have my fears. '' (sister)
''

She (sister) ain't in that line, Mum,'' said Mr. Pumblechook. '' She (Mum) knows better. '' She (Mum)? I looked at Joe, making the motion with my lips and eyebrows,

'' And couldn't she (Joe) ask Uncle Pumblechook if he (Pumblechook) knew of a boy to go and play there? And couldn't she (Joe) then ask Uncle Pumblechook if he (Pumblechook) knew of a boy to go and play there?

And couldn't Uncle Pumblechook, being always considerate and thoughtful for us--though you may not think it, Joseph,'' in a tone of the deepest reproach, as if he (Joseph) were the most callous of nephews,

``then mention this boy, standing Prancing here'' (nephews)

``that I have for ever been a willing slave to?'' (I)
``Good again! '' (Uncle Pumblechook)
cried Uncle Pumblechook.

``No, Joseph,'' (sister)
said my sister, still in a reproachful manner, while Joe apologetically drew the back of his (Joseph) hand across and across his (Joseph) nose,
``you do not yet--though you may not think it--know the case.

'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

Well put! Prettily pointed! Good indeed! Now Joseph, you know the case.'' You may consider that you do, but you do not, Joseph.

For you do not know that Uncle Pumblechook, being sensible that for anything we can tell, this boy's fortune may be made by his (Pumblechook) going to Miss Havisham's, has offered to take him (Pumblechook) into town to-night in his (Pumblechook) own chaise-cart, and to keep him (Pumblechook) to-night, and to take him (Pumblechook) with his (Pumblechook) own hands to Miss Havisham's to-morrow morning.

``here I stand talking to mere Mooncalfs, with Uncle Pumblechook waiting, and the mare catching cold at the door, and the boy grimed with crock and dirt from the hair of his (Pumblechook) head to the sole of his (Pumblechook) foot!'' (she)

With that, she (mare) pounced upon me, like an eagle on a lamb, and my face was squeezed into wooden bowls in sinks, and my head was put under taps of water-butts, and I was soaped, and kneaded, and towelled, and thumped, and harrowed, and rasped, until I really was quite beside myself.

-LRB-I may here remark that I suppose myself to be better acquainted than any living authority, with the ridgy effect of a wedding-ring, passing unsympathetically over the human countenance.-RRB-

When my ablutions were completed, I was put into clean linen of the stiffest character, like a young penitent into sackcloth, and was trussed up in my tightest and fearfullest suit.

I was then delivered over to Mr. Pumblechook, who formally received me as if he (Pumblechook) were the Sheriff, and who let off upon me the speech that I knew he (Pumblechook) had been dying to make all along:

``Boy, be forever grateful to all friends, but especially unto them which brought you up by hand!'' (he)

And Lor-a-mussy me!'' cried my sister, casting off her (sister) bonnet in sudden desperation,

``Good-bye, Joe!'' (sister)
``God bless you, Pip, old chap!

I had never parted from him (God) before, and what with my feelings and what with soapsuds, I could at first see no stars from the chaise-cart.

But they twinkled out one by one, without throwing any light on the questions why on earth I was going to play at Miss Havisham's, and what on earth

Mr. Pumblechook's premises in the High Street of the market town, were of a peppercorny and farinaceous character, as the premises of a cornchandler and seedsman should be.

It appeared to me that he (character) must be a very happy man indeed, to have so many little drawers in his (character) shop; and I wondered when I peeped into one or two on the lower tiers, and saw the tied-up brown paper packets inside, whether the flower-seeds and bulbs ever wanted of a fine day to break out of those jails, and bloom.

'' (I)

I was expected to play at. Chapter VIII It was in the early morning after my arrival that I entertained this speculation.

On the previous night, I had been sent straight to bed in an attic with a sloping roof, which was so low in the corner where the bedstead was, that I calculated the tiles as being within a foot of my eyebrows.

Mr. Pumblechook wore corduroys, and so did his (Pumblechook) shopman; and somehow, there was a general air and flavor about the corduroys, so much in the nature of seeds, and a general air and flavor about the seeds, so much in the nature of corduroys, that I hardly knew which was which.

The same opportunity served me for noticing that Mr. Pumblechook appeared to conduct his (Pumblechook) business by looking across the street at the saddler, who appeared to transact his (Pumblechook) business by keeping his (Pumblechook) eye on the coachmaker, who appeared to get on in life by putting his (Pumblechook) hands in his (Pumblechook) pockets and contemplating the baker, who in his (Pumblechook) turn folded his (Pumblechook) arms and stared at the grocer, who stood at his (Pumblechook) door and yawned at the chemist.

The watchmaker, always poring over a little desk with a magnifying-glass at his (Pumblechook) eye, and always inspected by a group of smock-frocks poring over him (Pumblechook) through the glass of his (Pumblechook) shop-window, seemed to be about the only person in the High Street whose trade engaged his (Pumblechook) attention.

Mr. Pumblechook and I breakfasted at eight o'clock in the parlor behind the shop, while the shopman took his (Pumblechook) mug of tea and hunch of bread and butter on a sack of peas in the front premises.

Besides being possessed by my sister's idea that a mortifying and penitential character ought to be imparted to my diet,--besides giving me as much crumb as possible in combination with as little butter, and putting such a quantity of warm water into my milk that it would have been more candid to have left the milk out altogether,--his (character) conversation consisted of nothing but arithmetic.

In the same early morning, I discovered a singular affinity between seeds and corduroys. I considered Mr. Pumblechook wretched company. On my politely bidding him (Pumblechook) Good morning, he (Pumblechook) said, pompously,

``Seven times nine, boy?

'' (he)

And how should I be able to answer, dodged in that way, in a strange place, on an empty stomach!

I was hungry, but before I had swallowed a morsel, he (Pumblechook) began a running sum that lasted all through the breakfast.

'' Seven?'' '' And four?'' '' And eight?'' '' And six?'' '' And two?'' '' And ten? '' And so on.

And after each figure was disposed of, it was as much as I could do to get a bite or a sup, before the next came; while he (Pumblechook) sat at his (Pumblechook) ease guessing nothing, and eating bacon and hot roll, in -LRB-if I may be allowed the expression-RRB- a gorging and gormandizing manner.

For such reasons, I was very glad when ten o'clock came and we started for Miss Havisham's; though I was not at all at my ease regarding the manner in which I should acquit myself under that lady's roof.

Within a quarter of an hour we came to Miss Havisham's house, which was of old brick, and dismal, and had a great many iron bars to it.

There was a courtyard in front, and that was barred; so we had to wait, after ringing the bell, until some one should come to open it.

Some of the windows had been walled up; of those that remained, all the lower were rustily barred. While we waited at the gate, I peeped in -LRB-even then Mr. Pumblechook said,

``And fourteen?

'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)

but I pretended not to hear him (Pumblechook)-RRB-, and saw that at the side of the house there was a large brewery.

No brewing was going on in it, and none seemed to have gone on for a long long time. A window was raised, and a clear voice demanded

``What name?'' (unknown)

The voice returned,

``Quite right,'' (a lady)
and the window was shut again, and a young lady came across the court-yard, with keys in her (lady) hand.

To which my conductor replied,

``Pumblechook. '' (conductor)
'' This,'' said Mr. Pumblechook,
``is Pip. '' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)
'' This is Pip, is it?

'' returned the young lady, who was very pretty and seemed very proud;

``come in, Pip. '' (the lady)
Mr. Pumblechook was coming in also, when she (lady) stopped him (Pumblechook) with the gate.

'' Oh!'' she (lady) said. '' Did you wish to see Miss Havisham?'' '' If Miss Havisham wished to see me,'' returned Mr. Pumblechook, discomfited.

She (Havisham) said it so finally, and in such an undiscussible way, that Mr. Pumblechook, though in a condition of ruffled dignity, could not protest.

'' Ah!'' said the girl;

``but you see she (girl) don't. '' (the girl)
But he (Pumblechook) eyed me severely,--as if I had done anything to him (Pumblechook)!--and departed with the words reproachfully delivered:
``Boy!

Let your behavior here be a credit unto them which brought you up by hand! '' (I)

I was not free from apprehension that he (Boy) would come back to propound through the gate,
``And sixteen?

'' (he)

But he (Boy) didn't. My young conductress locked the gate, and we went across the courtyard. It was paved and clean, but grass was growing in every crevice.

The brewery buildings had a little lane of communication with it, and the wooden gates of that lane stood open, and all the brewery beyond stood open, away to the high enclosing wall; and all was empty and disused.

The cold wind seemed to blow colder there than outside the gate; and it made a shrill noise in howling in and out at the open sides of the brewery, like the noise of wind in the rigging of a ship at sea.

She (it) saw me looking at it, and she (it) said,

``You could drink without hurt all the strong beer that's brewed there now, boy.'' (she)

``I should think I could, miss,'' (I)
said I, in a shy way. '' Better not try to brew beer there now, or it would turn out sour, boy;

''

``Not that anybody means to try,'' (boy)
she (it) added,
``for that's all done with, and the place will stand as idle as it is till it falls.

don't you think so?'' (she)

``It looks like it, miss. As to strong beer, there's enough of it in the cellars already, to drown the Manor House.

'' (unknown)

``Is that the name of this house, miss?'' (boy)
'' One of its names, boy.''
``It has more than one, then, miss?'' (unknown)

'' One more. Its other name was Satis; which is Greek, or Latin, or Hebrew, or all three--or all one to me--for enough.

''

``Enough House,'' (I)
said I;
``that's a curious name, miss. '' (I)
'' Yes,'' she (It) replied; ``but it meant more than it said.

It meant, when it was given, that whoever had this house could want nothing else. They must have been easily satisfied in those days, I should think.

Though she (It) called me

``boy'' (me)
so often, and with a carelessness that was far from complimentary, she (It) was of about my own age.

She (It) seemed much older than I, of course, being a girl, and beautiful and self-possessed; and she (It) was as scornful of me as if she (It) had been one-and-twenty, and a queen.

But don't loiter, boy. '' We went into the house by a side door, the great front entrance had two chains across it outside,--and

the first thing I noticed was, that the passages were all dark, and that she (It) had left a candle burning there.

She (It) took it up, and we went through more passages and up a staircase, and still it was all dark, and only the candle lighted us.

At last we came to the door of a room, and she (It) said,

``Go in. '' (she)
I answered, more in shyness than politeness,
``After you, miss.

'' (I)

To this she (It) returned:
``Don't be ridiculous, boy; I am not going in. '' (she)
And scornfully walked away, and--what was worse--took the candle with her (It).

However, the only thing to be done being to knock at the door, I knocked, and was told from within to enter.

This was very uncomfortable, and I was half afraid. I entered, therefore, and found myself in a pretty large room, well lighted with wax candles.

It was a dressing-room, as I supposed from the furniture, though much of it was of forms and uses then quite unknown to me.

But prominent in it was a draped table with a gilded looking-glass, and that I made out at first sight to be a fine lady's dressing-table.

Whether I should have made out this object so soon if there had been no fine lady sitting at it, I cannot say.

In an arm-chair, with an elbow resting on the table and her (lady) head leaning on that hand, sat the strangest lady I have ever seen, or shall ever see.

No glimpse of daylight was to be seen in it. She (lady) was dressed in rich materials,--satins, and lace, and silks,--all of white.

And she (lady) had a long white veil dependent from her (lady) hair, and she (lady) had bridal flowers in her (lady) hair, but her (lady) hair was white.

Her (lady) shoes were white. Some bright jewels sparkled on her (lady) neck and on her (lady) hands, and some other jewels lay sparkling on the table.

She (lady) had not quite finished dressing, for she (lady) had but one shoe on,--the other was on the table near her (lady) hand,--her (lady) veil was but half arranged, her (lady) watch and chain were not put on, and some lace for her (lady) bosom lay with those trinkets, and with her (lady) handkerchief, and gloves, and some flowers, and a Prayer-Book all confusedly heaped about the looking-glass.

It was not in the first few moments that I saw all these things, though I saw more of them in the first moments than might be supposed.

But I saw that everything within my view which ought to be white, had been white long ago, and had lost its lustre and was faded and yellow.

I saw that the bride within the bridal dress had withered like the dress, and like the flowers, and had no brightness left but the brightness of her (bride) sunken eyes.

I saw that the dress had been put upon the rounded figure of a young woman, and that the figure upon which it now hung loose had shrunk to skin and bone.

Once, I had been taken to see some ghastly waxwork at the Fair, representing I know not what impossible personage lying in state.

Once, I had been taken to one of our old marsh churches to see a skeleton in the ashes of a rich dress that had been dug out of a vault under the church pavement.

Dresses, less splendid than the dress she (woman) wore, and half-packed trunks, were scattered about. Now, waxwork and skeleton seemed to have dark eyes that moved and looked at me.

I should have cried out, if I could. '' Who is it?'' said the lady at the table. '' Pip, ma'am.''

It was when I stood before her (lady), avoiding her (lady) eyes, that I took note of the surrounding objects in detail, and saw that her (lady) watch had stopped at twenty minutes to nine, and that a clock in the room had stopped at twenty minutes to nine.

``Pip?'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)
'' Mr. Pumblechook's boy, ma'am. Come--to play.''
``Come nearer; let me look at you. Come close. '' (me)
'' Look at me,'' said Miss Havisham.

'' You are not afraid of a woman who has never seen the sun since you were born? '' I regret to state that I was not afraid of telling the enormous lie comprehended in the answer

``No.'' (I)
``Do you know what I touch here? '' (she)
she (woman) said, laying her (woman) hands, one upon the other, on her (woman) left side.

'' Yes, ma'am. '' -LRB-It made me think of the young man.-RRB- '' What do I touch? ''

``Your heart.'' (unknown)
``Broken!'' (She)

She (woman) uttered the word with an eager look, and with strong emphasis, and with a weird smile that had a kind of boast in it.

Afterwards she (woman) kept her (woman) hands there for a little while, and slowly took them away as if they were heavy. ''

I think it will be conceded by my most disputatious reader, that she (woman) could hardly have directed an unfortunate boy to do anything in the wide world more difficult to be done under the circumstances.

I am tired,'' said Miss Havisham. '' I want diversion, and I have done with men and women. Play. '' ''

I sometimes have sick fancies,'' she (woman) went on,

``and I have a sick fancy that I want to see some play.

For a moment, with the fear of my sister's working me before my eyes, I had a desperate idea of starting round the room in the assumed character of Mr. Pumblechook's chaise-cart.

But I felt myself so unequal to the performance that I gave it up, and stood looking at Miss Havisham in what I suppose she (Havisham) took for a dogged manner, inasmuch as she (Havisham) said,

There, there!'' (she)

with an impatient movement of the fingers of her (Havisham) right hand;
``play, play, play!'' (unknown)
when we had taken a good look at each other,--
``Are you sullen and obstinate?'' (me)

If you complain of me I shall get into trouble with my sister, so I would do it if I could; but it's so new here, and so strange, and so fine,--and melancholy--.

I stopped, fearing I might say too much, or had already said it, and we took another look at each other.

Before she (sister) spoke again, she (sister) turned her (sister) eyes from me, and looked at the dress she (sister) wore, and at the dressing-table, and finally at herself in the looking-glass.

So new to him (I),'' she (sister) muttered,

``so old to me; so strange to him (I), so familiar to me; so melancholy to both of us!

'' (she)

No, ma'am, I am very sorry for you, and very sorry I can't play just now. '' '' Call Estella.

As she (Estella) was still looking at the reflection of herself, I thought she (Estella) was still talking to herself, and kept quiet.

'' '' Call Estella,'' she (Estella) repeated, flashing a look at me. '' You can do that. Call Estella. At the door.

To stand in the dark in a mysterious passage of an unknown house, bawling Estella to a scornful young lady neither visible nor responsive, and feeling it a dreadful liberty so to roar out her (Estella) name, was almost as bad as playing to order.

Miss Havisham beckoned her (Havisham) to come close, and took up a jewel from the table, and tried its effect upon her (Havisham) fair young bosom and against her (Havisham) pretty brown hair.

'' But she (Havisham) answered at last, and her (Havisham) light came along the dark passage like a star. '' Your own, one day, my dear, and you will use it well.

Let me see you play cards with this boy.'' '' With this boy? Why, he (boy) is a common laboring boy! ''

I thought I overheard Miss Havisham answer,--only it seemed so unlikely,--

``Well? You can break his (boy) heart.'' (I)
'' What do you play, boy?

'' asked Estella of myself, with the greatest disdain. '' Nothing but beggar my neighbor, miss. ''

``Beggar him (Beggar),'' (Miss Havisham)
said Miss Havisham to Estella.

It was then I began to understand that everything in the room had stopped, like the watch and the clock, a long time ago.

So we sat down to cards. I noticed that Miss Havisham put down the jewel exactly on the spot from which she (Havisham) had taken it up.

As Estella dealt the cards, I glanced at the dressing-table again, and saw that the shoe upon it, once white, now yellow, had never been worn.

I glanced down at the foot from which the shoe was absent, and saw that the silk stocking on it, once white, now yellow, had been trodden ragged.

Without this arrest of everything, this standing still of all the pale decayed objects, not even the withered bridal dress on the collapsed form could have looked so like grave-clothes, or the long veil so like a shroud.

So she (I) sat, corpse-like, as we played at cards; the frillings and trimmings on her (I) bridal dress, looking like earthy paper.

I knew nothing then of the discoveries that are occasionally made of bodies buried in ancient times, which fall to powder in the moment of being distinctly seen; but, I have often thought since, that she (I) must have looked as if the admission of the natural light of day would have struck her (I) to dust.

'' He (I) calls the knaves Jacks, this boy!'' said Estella with disdain, before our first game was out. '' And what coarse hands he (I) has!

I had never thought of being ashamed of my hands before; but I began to consider them a very indifferent pair.

And what thick boots! '' Her (Estella) contempt for me was so strong, that it became infectious, and I caught it. She (Estella) won the game, and I dealt.

I misdealt, as was only natural, when I knew she (Estella) was lying in wait for me to do wrong; and she (Estella) denounced me for a stupid, clumsy laboring-boy.

'' You say nothing of her (Estella),'' remarked Miss Havisham to me, as she (Estella) looked on. '' She (Estella) says many hard things of you, but you say nothing of her (Estella).

What do you think of her (Estella)?''

``I don't like to say,'' (I)
I stammered.
``Tell me in my ear,'' (Miss Havisham)
said Miss Havisham, bending down.

'' I think she (Havisham) is very proud,'' I replied, in a whisper.

``Anything else?'' (unknown)
``I think she (Havisham) is very pretty. '' (unknown)

``Anything else?'' (unknown)
``I think she (Havisham) is very insulting. '' (She)
-LRB-She (Havisham) was looking at me then with a look of supreme aversion.-RRB-

'' Anything else?''

``I think I should like to go home.'' (she)
'' And never see her (Havisham) again, though she (Havisham) is so pretty?''

``I am not sure that I shouldn't like to see her (Havisham) again, but I should like to go home now.'' (unknown)
``You shall go soon,'' (Miss Havisham)
said Miss Havisham, aloud.

Saving for the one weird smile at first, I should have felt almost sure that Miss Havisham's face could not smile.

'' Play the game out. '' It had dropped into a watchful and brooding expression,--most likely when all the things about her (Havisham) had become transfixed,--and

Her (Havisham) chest had dropped, so that she (Havisham) stooped; and her (Havisham) voice had dropped, so that she (Havisham) spoke low, and with a dead lull upon her (Havisham); altogether, she (Havisham) had the appearance of having dropped body and soul, within and without, under the weight of a crushing blow.

it looked as if nothing could ever lift it up again. I played the game to an end with Estella, and she (Estella) beggared me.

She (Estella) threw the cards down on the table when she (Estella) had won them all, as if she (Estella) despised them for having been won of me.

I was beginning to remind her (Estella) that to-day was Wednesday, when she (Estella) checked me with her (Estella) former impatient movement of the fingers of her (Estella) right hand.

'' When shall I have you here again?'' said Miss Havisham.

``Let me think. '' (unknown)
'' There, there! I know nothing of days of the week; I know nothing of weeks of the year.

Come again after six days. You hear?'' '' Yes, ma'am.'' '' Estella, take him (Estella) down. Let him (Estella) have something to eat, and let him (Estella) roam and look about him (Estella) while he (Estella) eats.

I followed the candle down, as I had followed the candle up, and she (Estella) stood it in the place where we had found it.

Go, Pip. '' Until she (Estella) opened the side entrance, I had fancied, without thinking about it, that it must necessarily be night-time.

The rush of the daylight quite confounded me, and made me feel as if I had been in the candlelight of the strange room many hours.

'' You are to wait here, you boy,'' said Estella; and disappeared and closed the door. I took the opportunity of being alone in the courtyard to look at my coarse hands and my common boots.

My opinion of those accessories was not favorable. They had never troubled me before, but they troubled me now, as vulgar appendages.

I determined to ask Joe why he (me) had ever taught me to call those picture-cards Jacks, which ought to be called knaves.

I wished Joe had been rather more genteelly brought up, and then I should have been so too. She (Joe) came back, with some bread and meat and a little mug of beer.

She (Joe) put the mug down on the stones of the yard, and gave me the bread and meat without looking at me, as insolently as if I were a dog in disgrace.

I was so humiliated, hurt, spurned, offended, angry, sorry,--I cannot hit upon the right name for the smart--God knows what its name was,--that tears started to my eyes.

The moment they sprang there, the girl looked at me with a quick delight in having been the cause of them.

This gave me power to keep them back and to look at her (girl): so, she (girl) gave a contemptuous toss--but with a sense, I thought, of having made too sure that I was so wounded--and left me.

But when she (girl) was gone, I looked about me for a place to hide my face in, and got behind one of the gates in the brewery-lane, and leaned my sleeve against the wall there, and leaned my forehead on it and cried.

As I cried, I kicked the wall, and took a hard twist at my hair; so bitter were my feelings, and so sharp was the smart without a name, that needed counteraction.

In the little world in which children have their existence whosoever brings them up, there is nothing so finely perceived and so finely felt as injustice.

It may be only small injustice that the child can be exposed to; but the child is small, and its world is small, and its rocking-horse stands as many hands high, according to scale, as a big-boned Irish hunter.

My sister's bringing up had made me sensitive. Within myself, I had sustained, from my babyhood, a perpetual conflict with injustice.

I had known, from the time when I could speak, that my sister, in her (sister) capricious and violent coercion, was unjust to me.

I had cherished a profound conviction that her (sister) bringing me up by hand gave her (sister) no right to bring me up by jerks.

Through all my punishments, disgraces, fasts, and vigils, and other penitential performances, I had nursed this assurance; and to my communing so much with it, in a solitary and unprotected way, I in great part refer the fact that I was morally timid and very sensitive.

I got rid of my injured feelings for the time by kicking them into the brewery wall, and twisting them out of my hair, and then I smoothed my face with my sleeve, and came from behind the gate.

The bread and meat were acceptable, and the beer was warming and tingling, and I was soon in spirits to look about me.

To be sure, it was a deserted place, down to the pigeon-house in the brewery-yard, which had been blown crooked on its pole by some high wind, and would have made the pigeons think themselves at sea, if there had been any pigeons there to be rocked by it.

But there were no pigeons in the dove-cot, no horses in the stable, no pigs in the sty, no malt in the storehouse,

no smells of grains and beer in the copper or the vat. All the uses and scents of the brewery might have evaporated with its last reek of smoke.

In a by-yard, there was a wilderness of empty casks, which had a certain sour remembrance of better days lingering about them; but it was too sour to be accepted as a sample of the beer that was gone,--and in this respect

Behind the furthest end of the brewery, was a rank garden with an old wall; not so high but that I could struggle up and hold on long enough to look over it, and see that the rank garden was the garden of the house, and that it was overgrown with tangled weeds, but that there was a track upon the green and yellow paths, as if some one sometimes walked there, and that Estella was walking away from me even then.

For when I yielded to the temptation presented by the casks, and began to walk on them, I saw her (Estella) walking on them at the end of the yard of casks.

She (Estella) had her (Estella) back towards me, and held her (Estella) pretty brown hair spread out in her (Estella) two hands, and never looked round, and passed out of my view directly.

So, in the brewery itself,--by which I mean the large paved lofty place in which they used to make the beer, and where the brewing utensils still were.

When I first went into it, and, rather oppressed by its gloom, stood near the door looking about me, I saw her (Estella) pass among the extinguished fires, and ascend some light iron stairs, and go out by a gallery high overhead, as if she (Estella) were going out into the sky.

I remember those recluses as being like most others. But she (Estella) seemed to be everywhere. It was in this place, and at this moment, that a strange thing happened to my fancy.

I turned my eyes--a little dimmed by looking up at the frosty light--towards a great wooden beam in a low nook of the building near me on my right hand, and I saw a figure hanging there by the neck.

A figure all in yellow white, with but one shoe to the feet; and it hung so, that I could see that the faded trimmings of the dress were like earthy paper, and that the face was Miss Havisham's, with a movement going over the whole countenance as if she (Havisham) were trying to call to me.

In the terror of seeing the figure, and in the terror of being certain that it had not been there a moment before, I at first ran from it, and then ran towards it.

I thought it a strange thing then, and I thought it a stranger thing long afterwards. And my terror was greatest of all when I found no figure there.

Nothing less than the frosty light of the cheerful sky, the sight of people passing beyond the bars of the court-yard gate, and the reviving influence of the rest of the bread and meat and beer, would have brought me round.

Even with those aids, I might not have come to myself as soon as I did, but that I saw Estella approaching with the keys, to let me out.

She (Estella) would have some fair reason for looking down upon me, I thought, if she (Estella) saw me frightened; and she (Estella) would have no fair reason.

She (Estella) gave me a triumphant glance in passing me, as if she (Estella) rejoiced that my hands were so coarse and my boots were so thick, and she (Estella) opened the gate, and stood holding it.

I was passing out without looking at her (Estella), when she (Estella) touched me with a taunting hand. '' Why don't you cry?

'' '' Because I don't want to.''

``You do,'' (she)
said she (Estella). '' You have been crying till you are half blind, and you are near crying again now.

'' She (Estella) laughed contemptuously, pushed me out, and locked the gate upon me. I went straight to Mr. Pumblechook's, and was immensely relieved to find him (Pumblechook) not at home.

So, leaving word with the shopman on what day I was wanted at Miss Havisham's again, I set off on the four-mile walk to our forge; pondering, as I went along, on all I had seen, and deeply revolving that I was a common laboring-boy; that my hands were coarse; that my boots were thick; that I had fallen into a despicable habit of calling knaves Jacks; that I was much more ignorant than I had considered myself last night, and generally that I was in a low-lived bad way.

When I reached home, my sister was very curious to know all about Miss Havisham's, and asked a number of questions.

And I soon found myself getting heavily bumped from behind in the nape of the neck and the small of the back, and having my face ignominiously shoved against the kitchen wall, because I did not answer those questions at sufficient length.

If a dread of not being understood be hidden in the breasts of other young people to anything like the extent to which it used to be hidden in mine,--which

Chapter IX I consider probable, as I have no particular reason to suspect myself of having been a monstrosity,--it is the key to many reservations.

Not only that, but I felt convinced that Miss Havisham too would not be understood; and although she (Havisham) was perfectly incomprehensible to me, I entertained an impression that there would be something coarse and treacherous in my dragging her (Havisham) as she (Havisham) really was -LRB-to say nothing of Miss Estella-RRB- before the contemplation of Mrs. Joe.

I felt convinced that if I described Miss Havisham's as my eyes had seen it, I should not be understood. Consequently, I said as little as I could, and had my face shoved against the kitchen wall.

The worst of it was that that bullying old Pumblechook, preyed upon by a devouring curiosity to be informed of all I had seen and heard, came gaping over in his (Estella) chaise-cart at tea-time, to have the details divulged to him (Estella).

And the mere sight of the torment, with his (Estella) fishy eyes and mouth open, his (Estella) sandy hair inquisitively on end, and his (Estella) waistcoat heaving with windy arithmetic, made me vicious in my reticence.

'' Well, boy,'' Uncle Pumblechook began, as soon as he (Pumblechook) was seated in the chair of honor by the fire. ''

How did you get on up town? '' I answered,

``Pretty well, sir,'' (I)
and my sister shook her (sister) fist at me. ''

Pretty well? '' Mr. Pumblechook repeated. '' Pretty well is no answer. Tell us what you mean by pretty well, boy?''

Whitewash on the forehead hardens the brain into a state of obstinacy perhaps. Anyhow, with whitewash from the wall on my forehead, my obstinacy was adamantine.

I reflected for some time, and then answered as if I had discovered a new idea,

``I mean pretty well. '' (I)

My sister with an exclamation of impatience was going to fly at me,--I had no shadow of defence, for Joe was busy in the forge,--when

Mr. Pumblechook interposed with

``No! Don't lose your temper. Leave this lad to me, ma'am; leave this lad to me. '' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)

Mr. Pumblechook then turned me towards him (Pumblechook), as if he (Pumblechook) were going to cut my hair, and said,-- ``First -LRB-to get our thoughts in order-RRB-

I calculated the consequences of replying

``Four Hundred Pound,'' (I)
and finding them against me, went as near the answer as I could--which was somewhere about eightpence off.

Mr. Pumblechook then put me through my pence-table from

``twelve pence make one shilling,'' (me)
up to
``forty pence make three and fourpence,'' (me)
and then triumphantly demanded, as if he (Pumblechook) had done for me,
``Now!

: Forty-three pence? '' (me)

How much is forty-three pence?'' To which I replied, after a long interval of reflection, ``I don't know.

Mr. Pumblechook worked his (Pumblechook) head like a screw to screw it out of me, and said,

``Is forty-three pence seven and sixpence three fardens, for instance?'' (me)

And although my sister instantly boxed my ears, it was highly gratifying to me to see that the answer spoilt his (Pumblechook) joke, and brought him (Pumblechook) to a dead stop.

'' And I was so aggravated that I almost doubt if I did know.

``Yes!'' (I.)
said I. '' Boy! What like is Miss Havisham?

'' Mr. Pumblechook began again when he (Pumblechook) had recovered; folding his (Pumblechook) arms tight on his (Pumblechook) chest and applying the screw. ''

Mr. Pumblechook winked assent; from which I at once inferred that he (Pumblechook) had never seen Miss Havisham, for she (Havisham) was nothing of the kind.

Very tall and dark,'' I told him (Pumblechook). '' Is she (Havisham), uncle?'' asked my sister. '' Good! '' said Mr. Pumblechook conceitedly.

I am sure, uncle,'' returned Mrs. Joe,

``I wish you had him (Pumblechook) always; you know so well how to deal with him (Pumblechook).'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

-LRB-

``This is the way to have him (Pumblechook)! We are beginning to hold our own, I think, Mum?'' (unknown)
-RRB- ''
``Now, boy! What was she (Mum) a doing of, when you went in today?'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)
asked Mr. Pumblechook.

'' She (Mum) was sitting,'' I answered,

``in a black velvet coach. '' (I)
Mr. Pumblechook and Mrs. Joe stared at one another--as they well might--and both repeated,
``In a black velvet coach?'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

'' Yes,'' said I.

``And Miss Estella--that's her (Estella) niece , I think--handed her (Estella) in cake and wine at the coach-window, on a gold plate.

And we all had cake and wine on gold plates. And I got up behind the coach to eat mine, because she (Estella) told me to.'' (I.)

``Was anybody else there?'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)
asked Mr. Pumblechook. '' Four dogs,'' said I.
``Large or small?'' (I.)
``Immense,'' (I.)
said I.
``And they fought for veal-cutlets out of a silver basket.

'' (I.)

Mr. Pumblechook and Mrs. Joe stared at one another again, in utter amazement. I was perfectly frantic,--a reckless witness under the torture,--and would have told them anything.

'' Where was this coach, in the name of gracious?'' asked my sister. '' In Miss Havisham's room. '' They stared again.

I added this saving clause, in the moment of rejecting four richly caparisoned coursers which I had had wild thoughts of harnessing.

'' But there weren't any horses to it. '' '' Can this be possible, uncle?'' asked Mrs. Joe. '' What can the boy mean?''

``I'll tell you, Mum,'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)
said Mr. Pumblechook. '' My opinion is, it's a sedan-chair. She (Mum)'s flighty, you know,--very flighty,--quite flighty enough to pass her (Mum) days in a sedan-chair.''

``Did you ever see her (Mum) in it, uncle?'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
asked Mrs. Joe. '' How could I,'' he (uncle) returned, forced to the admission, ``when I never see her (Joe) in my life?

``Why, don't you know,'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)
said Mr. Pumblechook, testily,
``that when I have been there, I have been took up to the outside of her (Joe) door, and the door has stood ajar, and she (Joe) has spoke to me that way.

Never clapped eyes upon her (Joe)!'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)

``Goodness, uncle! And yet you have spoken to her (Joe)?'' (Mum)
Don't say you don't know that, Mum.

-LRB-I beg to observe that I think of myself with amazement, when I recall the lies I told on this occasion.-RRB-

Howsever, the boy went there to play. What did you play at, boy?''

``We played with flags,'' (I)
I said.
``Flags! '' (sister)
echoed my sister.

``Estella waved a blue flag, and I waved a red one, and Miss Havisham waved one sprinkled all over with little gold stars, out at the coach-window.

'' (I.)

Yes,'' said I. And then we all waved our swords and hurrahed. ''
``Swords!'' (sister)
repeated my sister. '' Where did you get swords from?

''

``Out of a cupboard,'' (I.)
said I.
``And I saw pistols in it,--and jam,--and pills. And there was no daylight in the room, but it was all lighted up with candles.'' (I.)

'' That's true, Mum,'' said Mr. Pumblechook, with a grave nod. '' That's the state of the case, for that much I've seen myself.

And then they both stared at me, and I, with an obtrusive show of artlessness on my countenance, stared at them, and plaited the right leg of my trousers with my right hand.

If they had asked me any more questions, I should undoubtedly have betrayed myself, for I was even then on the point of mentioning that there was a balloon in the yard, and should have hazarded the statement but for my invention being divided between that phenomenon and a bear in the brewery.

'' They were so much occupied, however, in discussing the marvels I had already presented for their consideration, that I escaped.

To whom my sister, more for the relief of her (sister) own mind than for the gratification of his (sister), related my pretended experiences.

Now, when I saw Joe open his (sister) blue eyes and roll them all round the kitchen in helpless amazement, I was overtaken by penitence; but only as regarded him (sister),--not in the least as regarded the other two.

Towards Joe, and Joe only, I considered myself a young monster, while they sat debating what results would come to me from Miss Havisham's acquaintance and favor.

They had no doubt that Miss Havisham would

``do something'' (Miss Havisham)
for me; their doubts related to the form that something would take.

The subject still held them when Joe came in from his (acquaintance) work to have a cup of tea. My sister stood out for

``property.

Mr. Pumblechook was in favor of a handsome premium for binding me apprentice to some genteel trade,--say, the corn and seed trade, for instance.

Joe fell into the deepest disgrace with both, for offering the bright suggestion that I might only be presented with one of the dogs who had fought for the veal-cutlets.

If a fool's head can't express better opinions than that,'' (sister)

said my sister,
``and you have got any work to do, you had better go and do it.

After Mr. Pumblechook had driven off, and when my sister was washing up, I stole into the forge to Joe, and remained by him (Pumblechook) until he (Pumblechook) had done for the night.

'' (sister)

'' '' So he (Pumblechook) went. Then I said,
``Before the fire goes out, Joe, I should like to tell you something.'' (I)

``Joe,'' (I)
said I, taking hold of his (Pumblechook) rolled-up shirt sleeve, and twisting it between my finger and thumb,
``you remember all that about Miss Havisham's?'' (I)

'' Should you, Pip?'' said Joe, drawing his (Pip) shoeing-stool near the forge. '' Then tell us. What is it, Pip?''

``Remember?'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe.

'' I believe you! Wonderful!'' '' It's a terrible thing, Joe; it ain't true. '' '' What are you telling of, Pip?

'' cried Joe, falling back in the greatest amazement. '' You don't mean to say it's-- '' '' Yes I do; it's lies, Joe.''

'' But not all of it? Why sure you don't mean to say, Pip, that there was no black welwet co--eh?

'' For, I stood shaking my head. '' But at least there was dogs, Pip? Come, Pip,'' said Joe, persuasively,

``if there warn't

no weal-cutlets, at least there was dogs?'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

'' No, Joe. ''
``A dog?'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe. '' A puppy? Come?'' '' No, Joe, there was nothing at all of the kind.

'' As I fixed my eyes hopelessly on Joe, Joe contemplated me in dismay. '' Pip, old chap! This won't do, old fellow!

I say! Where do you expect to go to?'' '' It's terrible, Joe; ain't it?''

``Terrible? '' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
cried Joe.
``Awful! What possessed you?'' (unknown)

``I don't know what possessed me, Joe,'' (I)
I replied, letting his (fellow) shirt sleeve go, and sitting down in the ashes at his (fellow) feet, hanging my head;

``but I wish you hadn't taught me to call Knaves at cards Jacks; and I wish my boots weren't so thick nor my hands so coarse.

And then I told Joe that I felt very miserable, and that I hadn't been able to explain myself to Mrs. Joe and Pumblechook, who were so rude to me, and that there had been a beautiful young lady at Miss Havisham's who was dreadfully proud, and that she (Joe) had said I was common, and that I knew I was common, and that I wished I was not common, and that the lies had come of it somehow, though I didn't know how.

'' (I)

This was a case of metaphysics, at least as difficult for Joe to deal with as for me. But Joe took the case altogether out of the region of metaphysics, and by that means vanquished it.

Howsever they come, they didn't ought to come, and they come from the father of lies, and work round to the same.

'' There's one thing you may be sure of, Pip,'' said Joe, after some rumination,

``namely, that lies is lies. Don't you tell no more of 'em, Pip.

That ain't the way to get out of being common, old chap. And as to being common, I don't make it out at all clear.

You are oncommon in some things. You're oncommon small. Likewise you're a oncommon scholar. '' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

'' No, I am ignorant and backward, Joe.

''

``Why, see what a letter you wrote last night! Wrote in print even! I've seen letters--Ah! and from gentlefolks!--that I'll swear weren't wrote in print,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe.

'' I have learnt next to nothing, Joe. You think much of me. It's only that.''

``Well, Pip,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe,
``be it so or be it son't

The king upon his (king) throne, with his (king) crown upon his (king) ed, can't sit and write his (king) acts of Parliament in print, without having begun, when he (king) were a unpromoted Prince, with the alphabet.--Ah!'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

added Joe, with a shake of the head that was full of meaning,
``and begun at A too, and worked his (king) way to Z.

, you must be a common scholar afore you can be a oncommon one, I should hope! And I know what that is to do, though I can't say I've exactly done it.

Whether common ones as to callings and earnings,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

pursued Joe, reflectively,
``mightn't be the better of continuing for to keep company with common ones,

'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

There was some hope in this piece of wisdom, and it rather encouraged me. '' instead of going out to play with oncommon ones,--which reminds me to hope that there were a flag, perhaps?''

Whether that might be or mightn't be, is a thing as can't be looked into now, without putting your sister on the Rampage; and that's a thing not to be thought of as being done intentional.

'' No, Joe.'' '' -LRB-I'm sorry there weren't a flag, Pip-RRB-. Lookee here, Pip, at what is said to you by a true friend.

Which this to you the true friend say. If you can't get to be oncommon through going straight, you'll never get to do it through going crooked.

So don't tell no more on 'em, Pip, and live well and die happy.''

``You are not angry with me, Joe?'' (I)

But bearing in mind that them were which I meantersay of a stunning and outdacious sort,--alluding to them which bordered on weal-cutlets and dog-fighting,--a

``No, old chap. sincere well-wisher would adwise, Pip, their being dropped into your meditations, when you go upstairs to bed. That's all, old chap, and don't never do it no more.

When I got up to my little room and said my prayers, I did not forget Joe's recommendation, and yet my young mind was in that disturbed and unthankful state,

that I thought long after I laid me down, how common Estella would consider Joe, a mere blacksmith; how thick his (blacksmith) boots, and how coarse his (blacksmith) hands.

I thought how Joe and my sister were then sitting in the kitchen, and how I had come up to bed from the kitchen, and how Miss Havisham and Estella never sat in a kitchen, but were far above the level of such common doings.

I fell asleep recalling what I

``used to do'' (I)
when I was at Miss Havisham's; as though I had been there weeks or months, instead of hours; and as though it were quite an old subject of remembrance, instead of one that had arisen only that day.

'' That was a memorable day to me, for it made great changes in me. But it is the same with any life.

Pause you who read this, and think for a moment of the long chain of iron or gold, of thorns or flowers, that would never have bound you, but for the formation of the first link on one memorable day.

The felicitous idea occurred to me a morning or two later when I woke, that the best step I could take towards making myself uncommon was to get out of Biddy everything she (myself) knew.

In pursuance of this luminous conception I mentioned to Biddy when I went to Mr. Wopsle's great-aunt's at night, that I had a particular reason for wishing to get on in life, and that I should feel very much obliged to her (great-aunt) if she (great-aunt) would impart all her (great-aunt) learning to me.

Biddy, who was the most obliging of girls, immediately said she (great-aunt) would, and indeed began to carry out her (great-aunt) promise within five minutes.

Imagine one selected day struck out of it, and think how different its course would have been. Chapter X The Educational scheme or Course established by Mr. Wopsle's great-aunt may be resolved into the following synopsis.

The pupils ate apples and put straws down one another's backs, until Mr. Wopsle's great-aunt collected her (great-aunt) energies, and made an indiscriminate totter at them with a birch-rod.

After receiving the charge with every mark of derision, the pupils formed in line and buzzingly passed a ragged book from hand to hand.

The book had an alphabet in it, some figures and tables, and a little spelling,--that is to say, it had had once.

As soon as this volume began to circulate, Mr. Wopsle's great-aunt fell into a state of coma, arising either from sleep or a rheumatic paroxysm.

The pupils then entered among themselves upon a competitive examination on the subject of Boots, with the view of ascertaining who could tread the hardest upon whose toes.

This mental exercise lasted until Biddy made a rush at them and distributed three defaced Bibles -LRB-shaped as if they had been unskilfully cut off the chump end of something-RRB-, more illegibly printed at the best than any curiosities of literature I have since met with, speckled all over with ironmould, and having various specimens of the insect world smashed between their leaves.

When the fights were over, Biddy gave out the number of a page, and then we all read aloud what we could,--or what we couldn't

This part of the Course was usually lightened by several single combats between Biddy and refractory students. --in a frightful chorus

; Biddy leading with a high, shrill, monotonous voice, and none of us having the least notion of, or reverence for, what we were reading about.

When this horrible din had lasted a certain time, it mechanically awoke Mr. Wopsle's great-aunt, who staggered at a boy fortuitously, and pulled his (Wopsle) ears.

This was understood to terminate the Course for the evening, and we emerged into the air with shrieks of intellectual victory.

It is fair to remark that there was no prohibition against any pupil's entertaining himself with a slate or even with the ink -LRB-when there was any-RRB-, but that it was not easy to pursue that branch of study in the winter season, on account of the little general shop in which the classes were holden--and which was also Mr. Wopsle's great-aunt's sitting-room and bedchamber--being but faintly illuminated through the agency of one low-spirited dip-candle and no snuffers.

It appeared to me that it would take time to become uncommon, under these circumstances: nevertheless, I resolved to try it, and that very evening Biddy entered on our special agreement, by imparting some information from her (great-aunt) little catalogue of Prices, under the head of moist sugar, and lending me, to copy at home, a large old English D which she (great-aunt) had imitated from the heading of some newspaper, and which I supposed, until she (great-aunt) told me what it was, to be a design for a buckle.

I had received strict orders from my sister to call for him (I) at the Three Jolly Bargemen, that evening, on my way from school, and bring him (I) home at my peril.

Of course there was a public-house in the village, and of course Joe liked sometimes to smoke his (I) pipe there. To the Three Jolly Bargemen, therefore, I directed my steps.

There was a bar at the Jolly Bargemen, with some alarmingly long chalk scores in it on the wall at the side of the door, which seemed to me to be never paid off.

But there was a quantity of chalk about our country, and perhaps the people neglected no opportunity of turning it to account.

It being Saturday night, I found the landlord looking rather grimly at these records; but as my business was with Joe and not with him (Bargemen), I merely wished him (Bargemen) good evening, and passed into the common room at the end of the passage, where there was a bright large kitchen fire, and where Joe was smoking his (Bargemen) pipe in company with Mr. Wopsle and a stranger.

Joe greeted me as usual with

``Halloa, Pip, old chap!'' (me)
and the moment he (chap) said that, the stranger turned his (chap) head and looked at me.

They had been there ever since I could remember, and had grown more than I had. He (chap) was a secret-looking man whom I had never seen before.

His (chap) head was all on one side, and one of his (chap) eyes was half shut up, as if he (chap) were taking aim at something with an invisible gun.

He (chap) had a pipe in his (chap) mouth, and he (chap) took it out, and, after slowly blowing all his (chap) smoke away and looking hard at me all the time, nodded.

So, I nodded, and then he (chap) nodded again, and made room on the settle beside him (chap) that I might sit down there.

But as I was used to sit beside Joe whenever I entered that place of resort, I said

``No, thank you, sir,'' (I)
and fell into the space Joe made for me on the opposite settle.

The strange man, after glancing at Joe, and seeing that his (man) attention was otherwise engaged, nodded to me again when I had taken my seat, and then rubbed his (man) leg--in a very odd way, as it struck me.

'' You was saying,'' said the strange man, turning to Joe,

``that you was a blacksmith. '' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
'' Yes. I said it, you know,'' said Joe.

'' What'll you drink, Mr.--? You didn't mention your name, by the bye. '' Joe mentioned it now, and the strange man called him (man) by it.

Well,'' said Joe,

``to tell you the truth, I ain't much in the habit of drinking at anybody's expense but my own.'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

'' What'll you drink, Mr. Gargery? At my expense? To top up with?'' ''

``Habit? No,'' (the stranger)
returned the stranger,
