``but once and away, and on a Saturday night too.

Come! Put a name to it, Mr. Gargery. '' (the stranger)

``I wouldn't wish to be stiff company,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe.
``Rum.'' (unknown)
``Rum,'' (the stranger)
repeated the stranger.

'' And will the other gentleman originate a sentiment.''

``Rum,'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)
said Mr. Wopsle. '' Three Rums!'' cried the stranger, calling to the landlord.

This other gentleman,'' observed Joe, by way of introducing Mr. Wopsle,

``is a gentleman that you would like to hear give it out.

'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)

Glasses round!'' '' Our clerk at church.''
``Aha!'' (the stranger)
said the stranger, quickly, and cocking his (stranger) eye at me. '' The lonely church, right out on the marshes, with graves round it!''

The stranger, with a comfortable kind of grunt over his (stranger) pipe, put his (stranger) legs up on the settle that he (stranger) had to himself.

He (stranger) wore a flapping broad-brimmed traveller's hat, and under it a handkerchief tied over his (stranger) head in the manner of a cap: so that he (stranger) showed no hair.

As he (stranger) looked at the fire, I thought I saw a cunning expression, followed by a half-laugh, come into his (stranger) face.

'' That's it,'' said Joe. '' I am not acquainted with this country, gentlemen, but it seems a solitary country towards the river.''

``Most marshes is solitary,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe. '' No doubt, no doubt. Do you find any gypsies, now, or tramps, or vagrants of any sort, out there?''

'' No,'' said Joe;

``none but a runaway convict now and then. And we don't find them, easy. Eh, Mr. Wopsle?

'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

Mr. Wopsle, with a majestic remembrance of old discomfiture, assented; but not warmly. '' Seems you have been out after such?

Not that we wanted to take them, you understand; we went out as lookers on; me, and Mr. Wopsle, and Pip.

The stranger looked at me again,--still cocking his (stranger) eye, as if he (stranger) were expressly taking aim at me with his (stranger) invisible gun,--and said,

``He (stranger)'s a likely young parcel of bones that.

'' (me)

asked the stranger. '' Once,'' returned Joe. '' Didn't us, Pip?'' '' Yes, Joe. '' What is it you call him (Pip)?''

``Pip,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe. '' Christened Pip?'' '' No, not christened Pip.''
``Surname Pip?'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
'' No,'' said Joe,
``it's a kind of family name what he (Pip) gave himself when a infant, and is called by.

Well,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

said Joe, meditatively, not, of course, that it could be in anywise necessary to consider about it, but because it was the way at the Jolly Bargemen to seem to consider deeply about everything that was discussed over pipes,--
``well--no.

Well,'' (Jolly Bargemen)

said Joe, with the same appearance of profound cogitation,
``he (Bargemen) is not--no, not to deceive you, he (Bargemen) is not--my nevvy.

'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

``Son of yours?'' (he)
'' No, he (Son) ain't. ''
``Nevvy? '' (the man)
said the strange man. '' ''
``What the Blue Blazes is he (man)?

Mr. Wopsle struck in upon that; as one who knew all about relationships, having professional occasion to bear in mind what female relations a man might not marry; and expounded the ties between me and Joe.

Having his (man) hand in, Mr. Wopsle finished off with a most terrifically snarling passage from Richard the Third, and seemed to think he (Wopsle) had done quite enough to account for it when he (Wopsle) added, '' (the poet)

--as the poet says.

And here I may remark that when Mr. Wopsle referred to me, he (Wopsle) considered it a necessary part of such reference to rumple my hair and poke it into my eyes.

I cannot conceive why everybody of his (Wopsle) standing who visited at our house should always have put me through the same inflammatory process under similar circumstances.

Yet I do not call to mind that I was ever in my earlier youth the subject of remark in our social family circle, but some large-handed person took some such ophthalmic steps to patronize me.

All this while, the strange man looked at nobody but me, and looked at me as if he (man) were determined to have a shot at me at last, and bring me down.

But he (man) said nothing after offering his (man) Blue Blazes observation, until the glasses of rum and water were brought; and then he (man) made his (man) shot, and a most extraordinary shot it was.

'' asked the stranger. Which appeared to me to be an inquiry of unnecessary strength. '' It was not a verbal remark, but a proceeding in dumb-show, and was pointedly addressed to me.

And he (man) stirred it and he (man) tasted it; not with a spoon that was brought to him (man), but with a file.

He (man) stirred his (man) rum and water pointedly at me, and he (man) tasted his (man) rum and water pointedly at me. He (man) did this so that nobody

but I saw the file; and when he (man) had done it he (man) wiped the file and put it in a breast-pocket.

I knew it to be Joe's file, and I knew that he (man) knew my convict, the moment I saw the instrument.

I sat gazing at him (man), spell-bound. But he (man) now reclined on his (man) settle, taking very little notice of me, and talking principally about turnips.

There was a delicious sense of cleaning-up and making a quiet pause before going on in life afresh, in our village on Saturday nights, which stimulated Joe to dare to stay out half an hour longer on Saturdays than at other times.

The half-hour and the rum and water running out together, Joe got up to go, and took me by the hand.

I think I've got a bright new shilling somewhere in my pocket, and if I have, the boy shall have it.

He (boy) looked it out from a handful of small change, folded it in some crumpled paper, and gave it to me.

``Stop half a moment, Mr. Gargery,'' (the man)
said the strange man. '' ''
``Yours!'' (he)
said he (man). '' Mind! Your own. '' I thanked him (man), staring at him (man) far beyond the bounds of good manners, and holding tight to Joe.

He (man) gave Joe good-night, and he (man) gave Mr. Wopsle good-night -LRB-who went out with us-RRB-, and he (man) gave me only a look with his (man) aiming eye,--no, not a look, for he (man) shut it up, but wonders may be done with an eye by hiding it.

On the way home, if I had been in a humor for talking, the talk must have been all on my side, for Mr. Wopsle parted from us at the door of the Jolly Bargemen, and Joe went all the way home with his (Wopsle) mouth wide open, to rinse the rum out with as much air as possible.

But I was in a manner stupefied by this turning up of my old misdeed and old acquaintance, and could think of nothing else.

My sister was not in a very bad temper when we presented ourselves in the kitchen, and Joe was encouraged by that unusual circumstance to tell her (Joe) about the bright shilling.

'' A bad un, I'll be bound,'' said Mrs. Joe triumphantly,

``or he (acquaintance) wouldn't have given it to the boy! Let's look at it.

'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

I took it out of the paper, and it proved to be a good one. '' But what's this?'' said Mrs. Joe, throwing down the shilling and catching up the paper.

Nothing less than two fat sweltering one-pound notes that seemed to have been on terms of the warmest intimacy with all the cattle-markets in the county.

'' Two One-Pound notes? '' Joe caught up his (acquaintance) hat again, and ran with them to the Jolly Bargemen to restore them to their owner.

While he (owner) was gone, I sat down on my usual stool and looked vacantly at my sister, feeling pretty sure that the man would not be there.

Presently, Joe came back, saying that the man was gone, but that he (man), Joe, had left word at the Three Jolly Bargemen concerning the notes.

Then my sister sealed them up in a piece of paper, and put them under some dried rose-leaves in an ornamental teapot on the top of a press in the state parlor.

I had sadly broken sleep when I got to bed, through thinking of the strange man taking aim at me with his (man) invisible gun, and of the guiltily coarse and common thing it was, to be on secret terms of conspiracy with convicts,--a feature in my low career that I had previously forgotten.

There they remained, a nightmare to me, many and many a night and day. I was haunted by the file too.

I coaxed myself to sleep by thinking of Miss Havisham's, next Wednesday; and in my sleep I saw the file coming at me out of a door, without seeing who held it, and I screamed myself awake.

A dread possessed me that when I least expected it, the file would reappear. Chapter XI At the appointed time I returned to Miss Havisham's, and my hesitating ring at the gate brought out Estella.

She (Estella) locked it after admitting me, as she (Estella) had done before, and again preceded me into the dark passage where her (Estella) candle stood.

She (Estella) took no notice of me until she (Estella) had the candle in her (Estella) hand, when she (Estella) looked over her (Estella) shoulder, superciliously saying,

``You are to come this way to-day,'' (she)
and took me to quite another part of the house.

We traversed but one side of the square, however, and at the end of it she (Estella) stopped, and put her (Estella) candle down and opened a door.

Here, the daylight reappeared, and I found myself in a small paved courtyard, the opposite side of which was formed by a detached dwelling-house, that looked as if it had once belonged to the manager or head clerk of the extinct brewery.

The passage was a long one, and seemed to pervade the whole square basement of the Manor House. There was a clock in the outer wall of this house.

We went in at the door, which stood open, and into a gloomy room with a low ceiling, on the ground-floor at the back.

There was some company in the room, and Estella said to me as she (Estella) joined it,

``You are to go and stand there boy, till you are wanted.'' (she)

Like the clock in Miss Havisham's room, and like Miss Havisham's watch, it had stopped at twenty minutes to nine.

``There'' (I)
, being the window, I crossed to it, and stood
``there,'' (I)
in a very uncomfortable state of mind, looking out.

It opened to the ground, and looked into a most miserable corner of the neglected garden, upon a rank ruin of cabbage-stalks, and one box-tree that had been clipped round long ago, like a pudding, and had a new growth at the top of it, out of shape and of a different color, as if that part of the pudding had stuck to the saucepan and got burnt.

There had been some light snow, overnight, and it lay nowhere else to my knowledge; but, it had not quite melted from the cold shadow of this bit of garden, and the wind caught it up in little eddies and threw it at the window, as if it pelted me for coming there.

This was my homely thought, as I contemplated the box-tree. I divined that my coming had stopped conversation in the room, and that its other occupants were looking at me.

I could see nothing of the room except the shining of the fire in the window-glass, but I stiffened in all my joints with the consciousness that I was under close inspection.

Before I had been standing at the window five minutes, they somehow conveyed to me that they were all toadies and humbugs, but that each of them pretended not to know that the others were toadies and humbugs: because the admission that he (me) or she (me) did know it, would have made him (me) or her (me) out to be a toady and humbug.

They all had a listless and dreary air of waiting somebody's pleasure, and the most talkative of the ladies had to speak quite rigidly to repress a yawn.

This lady, whose name was Camilla, very much reminded me of my sister, with the difference that she (sister) was older, and -LRB-as I found when I caught sight of her (sister)-RRB- of a blunter cast of features.

There were three ladies in the room and one gentleman. Indeed, when I knew her (sister) better I began to think it was a Mercy

she (sister) had any features at all, so very blank and high was the dead wall of her (sister) face. '' Poor dear soul!'' said this lady, with an abruptness of manner quite my sister's.

'' Nobody's enemy but his (gentleman) own!''

``It would be much more commendable to be somebody else's enemy,'' (the gentleman)
said the gentleman;
``far more natural.

'' (the gentleman)

``Cousin Raymond,'' (another lady)
observed another lady,
``we are to love our neighbor.'' (another lady)
``Sarah Pocket,'' (Raymond/Cousin Raymond)
returned Cousin Raymond,
``if a man is not his (man) own neighbor, who is?'' (Raymond/Cousin Raymond)

Miss Pocket laughed, and Camilla laughed and said -LRB-checking a yawn-RRB-,

``The idea! '' (Camilla/Mrs. Camilla)
But I thought they seemed to think it rather a good idea too.

Camilla presently went on -LRB-I knew they had all been looking at me in the mean time-RRB-, ``he (man) is so very strange!

Would anyone believe that when Tom's wife died, he (Tom) actually could not be induced to see the importance of the children's having the deepest of trimmings to their mourning? '

The other lady, who had not spoken yet, said gravely and emphatically,

``Very true!'' (The lady)
``Poor soul! '' (Lord)
Good Lord!' says he (Lord), `Camilla, what can it signify so long as the poor bereaved little things are in black?'

``Good points in him (Lord), good points in him (Lord),'' (Raymond/Cousin Raymond)
said Cousin Raymond;
``Heaven forbid I should deny good points in him (Raymond); but he (Raymond) never had, and he (Raymond) never will have, any sense of the proprieties.'' (Raymond/Cousin Raymond)

So like Matthew! The idea!'' '' You know I was obliged,'' said Camilla,--

``I was obliged to be firm. I said, `It WILL NOT DO, for the credit of the family.'

I told him (Matthew) that, without deep trimmings, the family was disgraced. I cried about it from breakfast till dinner. I injured my digestion.

Thank Goodness it will always be a consolation to me to know that I instantly went out in a pouring rain and bought the things.'' (Camilla/Mrs. Camilla)

And at last he (Matthew) flung out in his (Matthew) violent way, and said, with a D, `Then do as you like.' ''

He (Matthew) paid for them, did he (Matthew) not?'' asked Estella. '' It's not the question, my dear child, who paid for them,'' returned Camilla.

'' I bought them. And I shall often think of that with peace, when I wake up in the night. ''

The ringing of a distant bell, combined with the echoing of some cry or call along the passage by which I had come, interrupted the conversation and caused Estella to say to me,

``Now, boy!'' (me)

On my turning round, they all looked at me with the utmost contempt, and, as I went out, I heard Sarah Pocket say,

``Well I am sure!

As we were going with our candle along the dark passage, Estella stopped all of a sudden, and, facing round, said in her (Estella) taunting manner, with her (Estella) face quite close to mine,--

What next!'' (Sarah Pocket/Sarah/Miss Sarah Pocket)

and Camilla add, with indignation,
``Was there ever such a fancy! The i-de-a!'' (Camilla/Mrs. Camilla)
``Well?'' (unknown)
``Well, miss? '' (I)
I answered, almost falling over her (Camilla) and checking myself.

She (Camilla) stood looking at me, and, of course, I stood looking at her (Camilla). '' Am I pretty?'' '' Yes; I think you are very pretty.

'' '' Am I insulting?''

``Not so much so as you were last time ,'' (I.)
said I.
``Not so much so?'' (I.)

'' She (Camilla) fired when she (Camilla) asked the last question, and she (Camilla) slapped my face with such force as she (Camilla) had, when I answered it.

``No. '' (unknown)
Now?'' said she (Camilla). '' You little coarse monster, what do you think of me now?''
``I shall not tell you.'' (unknown)

``Because you are going to tell upstairs. Is that it?'' (I)
'' No,'' said I,
``that's not it. '' (I)
``Why don't you cry again, you little wretch?'' (I)

Because I'll never cry for you again,'' said I. Which was, I suppose, as false a declaration as ever was made; for I was inwardly crying for her (Camilla) then, and I know what I know of the pain she (Camilla) cost me afterwards.

We went on our way upstairs after this episode; and, as we were going up, we met a gentleman groping his (gentleman) way down.

'' '' Whom have we here? '' asked the gentleman, stopping and looking at me. '' A boy,'' said Estella. He (boy) was a burly man of an exceedingly dark complexion, with an exceedingly large head, and a corresponding large hand.

He (boy) took my chin in his (boy) large hand and turned up my face to have a look at me by the light of the candle.

He (boy) was prematurely bald on the top of his (boy) head, and had bushy black eyebrows that wouldn't lie down but stood up bristling.

He (boy) had a large watch-chain, and strong black dots where his (boy) beard and whiskers would have been if he (boy) had let them.

He (boy) was nothing to me, and I could have had no foresight then, that he (boy) ever would be anything to me, but it happened that I had this opportunity of observing him (boy) well.

His (boy) eyes were set very deep in his (boy) head, and were disagreeably sharp and suspicious. '' Boy of the neighborhood? Hey?'' said he (Boy).

'' Yes, sir,'' said I.

``How do you come here?'' (I.)
``Miss Havisham sent for me, sir,'' (I)
I explained. '' Well! Behave yourself.

I have a pretty large experience of boys, and you're a bad set of fellows. Now mind! '' said he (Boy), biting the side of his (Boy) great forefinger as he (Boy) frowned at me,

``you behave yourself!

With those words, he (Boy) released me--which I was glad of, for his (Boy) hand smelt of scented soap--and went his (Boy) way downstairs.

I wondered whether he (Boy) could be a doctor; but no, I thought; he (Boy) couldn't be a doctor, or he (Boy) would have a quieter and more persuasive manner.

There was not much time to consider the subject, for we were soon in Miss Havisham's room, where she (me) and everything else were just as I had left them.

Estella left me standing near the door, and I stood there until Miss Havisham cast her (Estella) eyes upon me from the dressing-table.

'' (me)

'' So! '' she (Estella) said, without being startled or surprised:
``the days have worn away, have they?'' (she)
'' Yes, ma'am.

To-day is--''

``There, there, there!'' (I)
with the impatient movement of her (Estella) fingers. '' I don't want to know. Are you ready to play?

'' I was obliged to answer in some confusion,

``I don't think I am, ma'am. '' (I)
``Not at cards again? '' (boy)

Since this house strikes you old and grave, boy,'' said Miss Havisham, impatiently,

``and you are unwilling to play, are you willing to work?

I could answer this inquiry with a better heart than I had been able to find for the other question, and I said I was quite willing.

Then go into that opposite room,'' (Miss Havisham)

said she (Havisham), pointing at the door behind me with her (Havisham) withered hand,
``and wait there till I come.

she (Havisham) demanded, with a searching look. '' (me)

Yes, ma'am; I could do that, if I was wanted.'' '' '' '' ''

I crossed the staircase landing, and entered the room she (Havisham) indicated. From that room, too, the daylight was completely excluded, and it had an airless smell that was oppressive.

A fire had been lately kindled in the damp old-fashioned grate, and it was more disposed to go out than to burn up, and the reluctant smoke which hung in the room seemed colder than the clearer air,--like our own marsh mist.

Certain wintry branches of candles on the high chimney-piece faintly lighted the chamber; or it would be more expressive to say, faintly troubled its darkness.

It was spacious, and I dare say had once been handsome, but every discernible thing in it was covered with dust and mould, and dropping to pieces.

The most prominent object was a long table with a tablecloth spread on it, as if a feast had been in preparation when the house and the clocks all stopped together.

An epergne or centre-piece of some kind was in the middle of this cloth; it was so heavily overhung with cobwebs that its form was quite undistinguishable; and, as I looked along the yellow expanse out of which I remember its seeming to grow, like a black fungus, I saw speckle-legged spiders with blotchy bodies running home to it, and running out from it, as if some circumstances of the greatest public importance had just transpired in the spider community.

But the black beetles took no notice of the agitation, and groped about the hearth in a ponderous elderly way, as if they were short-sighted and hard of hearing, and not on terms with one another.

These crawling things had fascinated my attention, and I was watching them from a distance, when Miss Havisham laid a hand upon my shoulder.

In her (Havisham) other hand she (Havisham) had a crutch-headed stick on which she (Havisham) leaned, and she (Havisham) looked like the Witch of the place.

This,'' said she (Havisham), pointing to the long table with her (Havisham) stick,

``is where I will be laid when I am dead.

I heard the mice too, rattling behind the panels, as if the same occurrence were important to their interests. '' (she)

They shall come and look at me here.

With some vague misgiving that she (Havisham) might get upon the table then and there and die at once, the complete realization of the ghastly waxwork at the Fair, I shrank under her (Havisham) touch.

'' '' What do you think that is? '' she (Havisham) asked me, again pointing with her (Havisham) stick;

``that, where those cobwebs are?'' (me)

She (Havisham) looked all round the room in a glaring manner, and then said, leaning on me while her (Havisham) hand twitched my shoulder, ``Come, come, come!

``I can't guess what it is, ma'am.'' (unknown)
'' It's a great cake. A bride-cake. Mine! '' Walk me, walk me! ''

I made out from this, that the work I had to do, was to walk Miss Havisham round and round the room.

Accordingly, I started at once, and she (Havisham) leaned upon my shoulder, and we went away at a pace that might have been an imitation -LRB-founded on my first impulse under that roof-RRB- of Mr. Pumblechook's chaise-cart.

Still, we went at an impatient fitful speed, and as we went, she (Havisham) twitched the hand upon my shoulder, and worked her (Havisham) mouth, and led me to believe that we were going fast because her (Havisham) thoughts went fast.

She (Havisham) was not physically strong, and after a little time said,

``Slower!'' (She)
After a while she (Havisham) said,
``Call Estella!'' (she)
so I went out on the landing and roared that name as I had done on the previous occasion.

If only Estella had come to be a spectator of our proceedings, I should have felt sufficiently discontented; but as she (Estella) brought with her (Estella) the three ladies and the gentleman whom I had seen below, I didn't know what to do.

In my politeness, I would have stopped; but Miss Havisham twitched my shoulder, and we posted on,--with a shame-faced consciousness on my part that they would think it was all my doing.

When her (Havisham) light appeared, I returned to Miss Havisham, and we started away again round and round the room. '' Dear Miss Havisham,'' said Miss Sarah Pocket.

Camilla brightened when Miss Pocket met with this rebuff; and she (Camilla) murmured, as she (Camilla) plaintively contemplated Miss Havisham,

``Poor dear soul!

'' (Miss Havisham)

How well you look!''
``I do not,'' (I)
returned Miss Havisham. '' I am yellow skin and bone. '' Certainly not to be expected to look well, poor thing.

As we were close to Camilla then, I would have stopped as a matter of course, only Miss Havisham wouldn't stop.

The idea!'' '' And how are you?'' said Miss Havisham to Camilla. We swept on, and I felt that I was highly obnoxious to Camilla.

'' Thank you, Miss Havisham,'' she (Havisham) returned,

``I am as well as can be expected. '' (she)
``Why, what's the matter with you?'' (I)
asked Miss Havisham, with exceeding sharpness.

I don't wish to make a display of my feelings, but I have habitually thought of you more in the night than I am quite equal to.''

Very easily said!'' remarked Camilla, amiably repressing a sob, while a hitch came into her (Camilla) upper lip, and her (Camilla) tears overflowed.

'' Nothing worth mentioning,'' replied Camilla. '' '' Then don't think of me,'' retorted Miss Havisham. '' '' Raymond is a witness what ginger and sal volatile I am obliged to take in the night.

Raymond is a witness what nervous jerkings I have in my legs. Chokings and nervous jerkings, however, are nothing new to me when I think with anxiety of those I love.

If I could be less affectionate and sensitive, I should have a better digestion and an iron set of nerves. I am sure I wish it could be so.

But as to not thinking of you in the night--The idea! '' Here, a burst of tears. The Raymond referred to, I understood to be the gentleman present, and him (Raymond) I understood to be Mr. Camilla.

He (Camilla) came to the rescue at this point, and said in a consolatory and complimentary voice,

``Camilla, my dear, it is well known that your family feelings are gradually undermining you to the extent of making one of your legs shorter than the other.'' (He)

``I am not aware,'' (the lady)
observed the grave lady whose voice I had heard but once, ``that to think of any person is to make a great claim upon that person, my dear.

Miss Sarah Pocket, whom I now saw to be a little dry, brown, corrugated old woman, with a small face that might have been made of walnut-shells, and a large mouth like a cat's without the whiskers, supported this position by saying,

``No, indeed, my dear.

'' (a cat)

Hem!''
``Thinking is easy enough,'' (the lady)
said the grave lady. '' What is easier, you know? '' assented Miss Sarah Pocket.

'' Oh, yes, yes!'' cried Camilla, whose fermenting feelings appeared to rise from her (Camilla) legs to her (Camilla) bosom. '' It's all very true!

No doubt my health would be much better if it was otherwise, still I wouldn't change my disposition if I could.

It's the cause of much suffering, but it's a consolation to know I posses it, when I wake up in the night.

Miss Havisham and I had never stopped all this time, but kept going round and round the room; now brushing against the skirts of the visitors, now giving them the whole length of the dismal chamber.

It's a weakness to be so affectionate, but I can't help it. '' Here another burst of feeling. '' There's Matthew!'' said Camilla.

I have taken to the sofa with my staylace cut, and have lain there hours insensible, with my head over the side, and my hair all down, and my feet

'' Never mixing with any natural ties, never coming here to see how Miss Havisham is! I don't know where-- '' -LRB-

``Much higher than your head, my love,'' (I)
said Mr. Camilla.-RRB-

I have gone off into that state, hours and hours, on account of Matthew's strange and inexplicable conduct, and nobody has thanked me.''

You see, my dear,'' added Miss Sarah Pocket -LRB-a blandly vicious personage-RRB-,

``the question to put to yourself is, who did you expect to thank you, my love?'' (a personage)

``Without expecting any thanks, or anything of the sort,'' (Camilla/Mrs. Camilla)
resumed Camilla,
``I have remained in that state, hours and hours, and Raymond is a witness of the extent to which I have choked, and what the total inefficacy of ginger has been, and I have been heard at the piano-forte tuner's across the street, where the poor mistaken children have even supposed it to be pigeons cooing at a distance,--and now to be told--

'' (Camilla/Mrs. Camilla)

Here Camilla put her (Camilla) hand to her (Camilla) throat, and began to be quite chemical as to the formation of new combinations there.

''

``Really I must say I should think not! '' (the lady)
interposed the grave lady. '' When this same Matthew was mentioned, Miss Havisham stopped me and herself, and stood looking at the speaker.

This change had a great influence in bringing Camilla's chemistry to a sudden end. '' Matthew will come and see me at last,'' said Miss Havisham, sternly,

``when I am laid on that table.

That will be his (Matthew) place,--there,'' (Miss Havisham)

striking the table with her (Havisham) stick,
``at my head! And yours will be there! And your husband's there!

And Sarah Pocket's there! And Georgiana's there! Now you all know where to take your stations when you come to feast upon me.

And now go! '' (she)

At the mention of each name, she (Georgiana) had struck the table with her (Georgiana) stick in a new place.

She (Georgiana) now said,

``Walk me, walk me!'' (She)
and we went on again. '' I suppose there's nothing to be done,'' exclaimed Camilla, ``but comply and depart.

It's something to have seen the object of one's love and duty for even so short a time. I shall think of it with a melancholy satisfaction when I wake up in the night.

I am determined not to make a display of my feelings, but it's very hard to be told one wants to feast on one's relations,--as if one was a Giant,--and to be told to go.

Mr. Camilla interposing, as Mrs. Camilla laid her (Camilla) hand upon her (Camilla) heaving bosom, that lady assumed an unnatural fortitude of manner which I supposed to be expressive of an intention to drop and choke when out of view, and kissing her (Camilla) hand to Miss Havisham, was escorted forth.

Sarah Pocket and Georgiana contended who should remain last; but Sarah was too knowing to be outdone, and ambled round Georgiana with that artful slipperiness that the latter was obliged to take precedence.

Sarah Pocket then made her (Pocket) separate effect of departing with,

``Bless you, Miss Havisham dear!'' (Sarah Pocket/Sarah/Miss Sarah Pocket)
and with a smile of forgiving pity on her (Pocket) walnut-shell countenance for the weaknesses of the rest.

While Estella was away lighting them down, Miss Havisham still walked with her (Havisham) hand on my shoulder, but more and more slowly.

I wish Matthew could have that comfort, but he (Matthew) sets it at defiance. The bare idea! '' At last she (Havisham) stopped before the fire, and said, after muttering and looking at it some seconds,--

'' This is my birthday, Pip. '' I was going to wish her (Havisham) many happy returns, when she (Havisham) lifted her (Havisham) stick.

'' I don't suffer it to be spoken of. I don't suffer those who were here just now, or any one to speak of it.

They come here on the day, but they dare not refer to it. '' Of course I made no further effort to refer to it.

On this day of the year, long before you were born, this heap of decay,'' stabbing with her (Havisham) crutched stick at the pile of cobwebs on the table, but not touching it,

``was brought here.

'' (I)

It and I have worn away together. The mice have gnawed at it, and sharper teeth than teeth of mice have gnawed at me.

She (Havisham) held the head of her (Havisham) stick against her (Havisham) heart as she (Havisham) stood looking at the table; she (Havisham) in her (Havisham) once white dress, all yellow and withered; the once white cloth all yellow and withered; everything around in a state to crumble under a touch.

When the ruin is complete,'' said she (Havisham), with a ghastly look,

``and when they lay me dead, in my bride's dress on the bride's table,--which shall be done, and which will be the finished curse upon him (Havisham),--so much the better if it is done on this day!

'' (she)

'' '' She (bride) stood looking at the table as if she (bride) stood looking at her (bride) own figure lying there. I remained quiet.

In the heavy air of the room, and the heavy darkness that brooded in its remoter corners, I even had an alarming fancy that Estella and I might presently begin to decay.

At length, not coming out of her (Estella) distraught state by degrees, but in an instant, Miss Havisham said,

``Let me see you two play cards; why have you not begun?'' (Miss Havisham)

With that, we returned to her (Havisham) room, and sat down as before; I was beggared, as before; and again, as before, Miss Havisham watched us all the time, directed my attention to Estella's beauty, and made me notice it the more by trying her (Estella) jewels on Estella's breast and hair.

Estella returned, and she (Estella) too remained quiet. It seemed to me that we continued thus for a long time. Estella, for her (Estella) part, likewise treated me as before, except that she (Estella) did not condescend to speak.

When we had played some half-dozen games, a day was appointed for my return, and I was taken down into the yard to be fed in the former dog-like manner.

It is not much to the purpose whether a gate in that garden wall which I had scrambled up to peep over on the last occasion was, on that last occasion, open or shut.

There, too, I was again left to wander about as I liked. Enough that I saw no gate then, and that I saw one now.

As it stood open, and as I knew that Estella had let the visitors out,--for she (Estella) had returned with the keys in her (Estella) hand,--I strolled into the garden, and strolled all over it.

It was quite a wilderness, and there were old melon-frames and cucumber-frames in it, which seemed in their decline to have produced a spontaneous growth of weak attempts at pieces of old hats and boots, with now and then a weedy offshoot into the likeness of a battered saucepan.

When I had exhausted the garden and a greenhouse with nothing in it but a fallen-down grape-vine and some bottles, I found myself in the dismal corner upon which I had looked out of the window.

Never questioning for a moment that the house was now empty, I looked in at another window, and found myself, to my great surprise, exchanging a broad stare with a pale young gentleman with red eyelids and light hair.

He (gentleman) had been at his (gentleman) books when I had found myself staring at him (gentleman), and I now saw that he (gentleman) was inky.

This pale young gentleman quickly disappeared, and reappeared beside me.

``Halloa!'' (he)
said he (gentleman),
``young fellow!'' (he)
Halloa being a general observation which I had usually observed to be best answered by itself, I said,
``Halloa!

'' (I)

politely omitting young fellow. '' Who let you in?'' said he (fellow). '' Miss Estella. ''
``Who gave you leave to prowl about?'' (unknown)

``Miss Estella. '' (unknown)
``Come and fight,'' (the gentleman)
said the pale young gentleman. What could I do but follow him (gentleman)? I have often asked myself the question since; but what else could I do?

His (gentleman) manner was so final, and I was so astonished, that I followed where he (gentleman) led, as if I had been under a spell.

'' Stop a minute, though,'' he (gentleman) said, wheeling round before we had gone many paces. '' I ought to give you a reason for fighting, too.

In a most irritating manner he (gentleman) instantly slapped his (gentleman) hands against one another, daintily flung one of his (gentleman) legs up behind him (gentleman), pulled my hair, slapped his (gentleman) hands again, dipped his (gentleman) head, and butted it into my stomach.

The bull-like proceeding last mentioned, besides that it was unquestionably to be regarded in the light of a liberty, was particularly disagreeable just after bread and meat.

There it is!'' I therefore hit out at him (gentleman) and was going to hit out again, when he (gentleman) said,

``Aha! Would you?'' (he)
and began dancing backwards and forwards in a manner quite unparalleled within my limited experience.

'' Laws of the game!'' said he (gentleman). Here, he (gentleman) skipped from his (gentleman) left leg on to his (gentleman) right. '' Regular rules!

'' Here, he (gentleman) skipped from his (gentleman) right leg on to his (gentleman) left.

``Come to the ground, and go through the preliminaries!

I was secretly afraid of him (gentleman) when I saw him (gentleman) so dexterous; but I felt morally and physically convinced that his (gentleman) light head of hair could have had no business in the pit of my stomach, and that I had a right to consider it irrelevant when so obtruded on my attention.

Therefore, I followed him (gentleman) without a word, to a retired nook of the garden, formed by the junction of two walls and screened by some rubbish.

'' (he)

Here, he (gentleman) dodged backwards and forwards, and did all sorts of things while I looked helplessly at him (gentleman). On his (gentleman) asking me if I was satisfied with the ground, and on my replying

Yes, he (gentleman) begged my leave to absent himself for a moment, and quickly returned with a bottle of water and a sponge dipped in vinegar.

And then fell to pulling off, not only his (gentleman) jacket and waistcoat, but his (gentleman) shirt too, in a manner at once light-hearted, business-like, and bloodthirsty.

'' Available for both,'' he (gentleman) said, placing these against the wall. Although he (gentleman) did not look very healthy,--having pimples on his (gentleman) face, and a breaking out at his (gentleman) mouth,--these dreadful preparations quite appalled me.

I judged him (gentleman) to be about my own age, but he (gentleman) was much taller, and he (gentleman) had a way of spinning himself about that was full of appearance.

For the rest, he (gentleman) was a young gentleman in a gray suit -LRB-when not denuded for battle-RRB-, with his (gentleman) elbows, knees, wrists, and heels considerably in advance of the rest of him (gentleman) as to development.

My heart failed me when I saw him (gentleman) squaring at me with every demonstration of mechanical nicety, and eyeing my anatomy as if he (gentleman) were minutely choosing his (gentleman) bone.

I never have been so surprised in my life, as I was when I let out the first blow, and saw him (gentleman) lying on his (gentleman) back, looking up at me with a bloody nose and his (gentleman) face exceedingly fore-shortened.

The second greatest surprise I have ever had in my life was seeing him (gentleman) on his (gentleman) back again, looking up at me out of a black eye.

But, he (gentleman) was on his (gentleman) feet directly, and after sponging himself with a great show of dexterity began squaring again. His (gentleman) spirit inspired me with great respect.

He (gentleman) seemed to have no strength, and he (gentleman) never once hit me hard, and he (gentleman) was always knocked down; but he (gentleman) would be up again in a moment, sponging himself or drinking out of the water-bottle, with the greatest satisfaction in seconding himself according to form, and then came at me with an air and a show that made me believe he (gentleman) really was going to do for me at last.

He (gentleman) got heavily bruised, for I am sorry to record that the more I hit him (gentleman), the harder I hit him (gentleman); but he (gentleman) came up again and again and again, until at last he (gentleman) got a bad fall with the back of his (gentleman) head against the wall.

Even after that crisis in our affairs, he (gentleman) got up and turned round and round confusedly a few times, not knowing where I was; but finally went on his (gentleman) knees to his (gentleman) sponge and threw it up: at the same time panting out,

He (gentleman) seemed so brave and innocent, that although I had not proposed the contest, I felt but a gloomy satisfaction in my victory.

Indeed, I go so far as to hope that I regarded myself while dressing as a species of savage young wolf or other wild beast.

``That means you have won. '' (I)
However, I got dressed, darkly wiping my sanguinary face at intervals, and I said,
``Can I help you?

'' (I)

and he (wolf) said
``No thankee,'' (he)
and I said
``Good afternoon,'' (I)
and he (wolf) said
``Same to you. '' (he)
When I got into the courtyard, I found Estella waiting with the keys.

But she (Estella) neither asked me where I had been, nor why I had kept her (Estella) waiting; and there was a bright flush upon her (Estella) face, as though something had happened to delight her (Estella).

Instead of going straight to the gate, too, she (Estella) stepped back into the passage, and beckoned me.

``Come here! You may kiss me, if you like.

'' (I)

I kissed her (Estella) cheek as she (Estella) turned it to me. I think I would have gone through a great deal to kiss her (Estella) cheek.

But I felt that the kiss was given to the coarse common boy as a piece of money might have been, and that it was worth nothing.

What with the birthday visitors, and what with the cards, and what with the fight, my stay had lasted so long, that when I neared home the light on the spit of sand off the point on the marshes was gleaming against a black night-sky, and Joe's furnace was flinging a path of fire across the road.

The more I thought of the fight, and recalled the pale young gentleman on his (gentleman) back in various stages of puffy and incrimsoned countenance, the more certain it appeared that something would be done to me.

Chapter XII My mind grew very uneasy on the subject of the pale young gentleman. I felt that the pale young gentleman's blood was on my head, and that the Law would avenge it.

Without having any definite idea of the penalties I had incurred, it was clear to me that village boys could not go stalking about the country, ravaging the houses of gentlefolks and pitching into the studious youth of England, without laying themselves open to severe punishment.

For some days, I even kept close at home, and looked out at the kitchen door with the greatest caution and trepidation before going on an errand, lest the officers of the County Jail should pounce upon me.

The pale young gentleman's nose had stained my trousers, and I tried to wash out that evidence of my guilt in the dead of night.

I had cut my knuckles against the pale young gentleman's teeth, and I twisted my imagination into a thousand tangles, as I devised incredible ways of accounting for that damnatory circumstance when I should be haled before the Judges.

When the day came round for my return to the scene of the deed of violence, my terrors reached their height.

Whether myrmidons of Justice, specially sent down from London, would be lying in ambush behind the gate;--whether Miss Havisham, preferring to take personal vengeance for an outrage done to her (Havisham) house, might rise in those grave-clothes of hers, draw a pistol, and shoot me dead:--whether suborned boys--a numerous band of mercenaries--might be engaged to fall upon me in the brewery, and cuff me until I was no more;--it was high testimony to my confidence in the spirit of the pale young gentleman, that I never imagined him (gentleman) accessory to these retaliations; they always came into my mind as the acts of injudicious relatives of his (gentleman), goaded on by the state of his (gentleman) visage and an indignant sympathy with the family features.

However, go to Miss Havisham's I must, and go I did. And behold! nothing came of the late struggle. It was not alluded to in any way, and no pale young gentleman was to be discovered on the premises.

I found the same gate open, and I explored the garden, and even looked in at the windows of the detached house; but my view was suddenly stopped by the closed shutters within, and all was lifeless.

Only in the corner where the combat had taken place could I detect any evidence of the young gentleman's existence. There were traces of his (gentleman) gore in that spot, and I covered them with garden-mould from the eye of man.

On the broad landing between Miss Havisham's own room and that other room in which the long table was laid out, I saw a garden-chair,--a light chair on wheels, that you pushed from behind.

It had been placed there since my last visit, and I entered, that same day, on a regular occupation of pushing Miss Havisham in this chair -LRB-when she (It) was tired of walking with her (It) hand upon my shoulder-RRB- round her (It) own room, and across the landing, and round the other room.

Over and over and over again, we would make these journeys, and sometimes they would last as long as three hours at a stretch.

I insensibly fall into a general mention of these journeys as numerous, because it was at once settled that I should return every alternate day at noon for these purposes, and because I am now going to sum up a period of at least eight or ten months.

As we began to be more used to one another, Miss Havisham talked more to me, and asked me such questions as what had I learnt and what was I going to be?

I told her (Havisham) I was going to be apprenticed to Joe, I believed; and I enlarged upon my knowing nothing and wanting to know everything, in the hope that she (Joe) might offer some help towards that desirable end.

Neither did she (Joe) ever give me any money,--or anything but my daily dinner,--nor ever stipulate that I should be paid for my services.

But she (Joe) did not; on the contrary, she (Joe) seemed to prefer my being ignorant. Estella was always about, and always let me in and out, but never told me

Sometimes, she (Estella) would coldly tolerate me; sometimes, she (Estella) would condescend to me; sometimes, she (Estella) would be quite familiar with me; sometimes, she (Estella) would tell me energetically that she (Estella) hated me.

Miss Havisham would often ask me in a whisper, or when we were alone,

``Does she (Havisham) grow prettier and prettier, Pip?'' (me)

Also, when we played at cards Miss Havisham would look on, with a miserly relish of Estella's moods, whatever they were.

And sometimes, when her (Estella) moods were so many and so contradictory of one another that I was puzzled what to say or do, Miss Havisham would embrace her (Havisham) with lavish fondness, murmuring something in her (Havisham) ear that sounded like

``Break their hearts my pride and hope, break their hearts and have no mercy!'' (her)

I might kiss her (Havisham) again. And when I said yes -LRB-for indeed she (Havisham) did-RRB-, would seem to enjoy it greedily. There was a song Joe used to hum fragments of at the forge, of which the burden was Old Clem.

This was not a very ceremonious way of rendering homage to a patron saint, but I believe Old Clem stood in that relation towards smiths.

It was a song that imitated the measure of beating upon iron, and was a mere lyrical excuse for the introduction of Old Clem's respected name.

Thus, you were to hammer boys round--Old Clem! With a thump and a sound--Old Clem! Beat it out, beat it out--Old Clem!

One day soon after the appearance of the chair, Miss Havisham suddenly saying to me, with the impatient movement of her (Clem) fingers,

``There, there, there!

With a clink for the stout--Old Clem! Blow the fire, blow the fire--Old Clem! Roaring dryer, soaring higher--Old Clem! Sing! '' (me)

It happened so to catch her (Clem) fancy that she (Clem) took it up in a low brooding voice as if she (Clem) were singing in her (Clem) sleep.

After that, it became customary with us to have it as we moved about, and Estella would often join in; though the whole strain was so subdued, even when there were three of us, that it made less noise in the grim old house than the lightest breath of wind.

I was surprised into crooning this ditty as I pushed her (Estella) over the floor. What could I become with these surroundings?

Is it to be wondered at if my thoughts were dazed, as my eyes were, when I came out into the natural light from the misty yellow rooms?

Perhaps I might have told Joe about the pale young gentleman, if I had not previously been betrayed into those enormous inventions to which I had confessed.

Under the circumstances, I felt that Joe could hardly fail to discern in the pale young gentleman, an appropriate passenger to be put into the black velvet coach; therefore, I said nothing of him (coach).

Besides, that shrinking from having Miss Havisham and Estella discussed, which had come upon me in the beginning, grew much more potent as time went on.

How could my character fail to be influenced by them? I reposed complete confidence in no one but Biddy; but I told poor Biddy everything.

Why it came natural to me to do so, and why Biddy had a deep concern in everything I told her (Estella), I did not know then, though I think I know now.

That ass, Pumblechook, used often to come over of a night for the purpose of discussing my prospects with my sister; and I really do believe -LRB-to this hour with less penitence than I ought to feel-RRB-, that if these hands could have taken a linchpin out of his (me) chaise-cart, they would have done it.

The miserable man was a man of that confined stolidity of mind, that he (man) could not discuss my prospects without having me before him (man),--as it were, to operate upon,--and

he (man) would drag me up from my stool -LRB-usually by the collar-RRB- where I was quiet in a corner, and, putting me before the fire as if I were going to be cooked, would begin by saying, ``Now, Mum, here is this boy!

Meanwhile, councils went on in the kitchen at home, fraught with almost insupportable aggravation to my exasperated spirit. Here is this boy which you brought up by hand.

Hold up your head, boy, and be forever grateful unto them which so did do. Now, Mum, with respections to this boy!

And then he (boy) would rumple my hair the wrong way,--which from my earliest remembrance, as already hinted, I have in my soul denied the right of any fellow-creature to do,--and would hold me before him (boy) by the sleeve,--a spectacle of imbecility only to be equalled by himself.

Then, he (boy) and my sister would pair off in such nonsensical speculations about Miss Havisham, and about what she (Havisham) would do with me and for me, that I used to want--quite painfully--to burst into spiteful tears, fly at Pumblechook, and pummel him (boy) all over.

In these dialogues, my sister spoke to me as if she (sister) were morally wrenching one of my teeth out at every reference; while Pumblechook himself, self-constituted my patron, would sit supervising me with a depreciatory eye, like the architect of my fortunes who thought himself engaged on a very unremunerative job.

But he (architect) was often talked at, while they were in progress, by reason of Mrs. Joe's perceiving that he (architect) was not favorable to my being taken from the forge.

I was fully old enough now to be apprenticed to Joe; and when Joe sat with the poker on his (architect) knees thoughtfully raking out the ashes between the lower bars, my sister would so distinctly construe that innocent action into opposition on his (architect) part, that she (sister) would dive at him (architect), take the poker out of his (architect) hands, shake him (architect), and put it away.

All in a moment, with nothing to lead up to it, my sister would stop herself in a yawn, and catching sight of me as it were incidentally, would swoop upon me with,

``Come!

'' (me)

In these discussions, Joe bore no part. There was a most irritating end to every one of these debates. there's enough of you!

You get along to bed; you've given trouble enough for one night, I hope! '' As if I had besought them as a favor to bother my life out.

We went on in this way for a long time, and it seemed likely that we should continue to go on in this way for a long time, when one day Miss Havisham stopped short as she (Havisham) and I were walking, she (Havisham) leaning on my shoulder; and said with some displeasure,--

I thought it best to hint, through the medium of a meditative look, that this might be occasioned by circumstances over which I had no control.

She (Havisham) said no more at the time; but she (Havisham) presently stopped and looked at me again; and presently again; and after that, looked frowning and moody.

On the next day of my attendance, when our usual exercise was over, and I had landed her (Havisham) at her (Havisham) dressing-table, she (Havisham) stayed me with a movement of her (Havisham) impatient fingers:--

``You are growing tall, Pip!'' (me)
``Tell me the name again of that blacksmith of yours.'' (unknown)
``Joe Gargery, ma'am.'' (unknown)
``Meaning the master you were to be apprenticed to?'' (unknown)

'' Yes, Miss Havisham.''

``You had better be apprenticed at once. Would Gargery come here with you, and bring your indentures, do you think?

'' (I)

I signified that I had no doubt he (master) would take it as an honor to be asked. '' Then let him (master) come.''

``At any particular time, Miss Havisham?'' (unknown)
'' There, there! I know nothing about times. Let him (master) come soon, and come along with you.

When I got home at night, and delivered this message for Joe, my sister

``went on the Rampage,'' (sister)
in a more alarming degree than at any previous period.

She (Joe) asked me and Joe whether we supposed she (Joe) was door-mats under our feet, and how we dared to use her (Joe) so, and what company we graciously thought she (Joe) was fit for?

When she (Joe) had exhausted a torrent of such inquiries, she (Joe) threw a candlestick at Joe, burst into a loud sobbing, got out the dustpan,--which was always a very bad sign,--put on her (Joe) coarse apron, and began cleaning up to a terrible extent.

Not satisfied with a dry cleaning, she (Joe) took to a pail and scrubbing-brush, and cleaned us out of house and home, so that we stood shivering in the back-yard.

It was ten o'clock at night before we ventured to creep in again, and then she (Joe) asked Joe why he (Joe) hadn't married a Negress Slave at once?

Joe offered no answer, poor fellow, but stood feeling his (fellow) whisker and looking dejectedly at me, as if he (fellow) thought it really might have been a better speculation.

'' Chapter XIII It was a trial to my feelings, on the next day but one, to see Joe arraying himself in his (fellow) Sunday clothes to accompany me to Miss Havisham's.

However, as he (fellow) thought his (fellow) court-suit necessary to the occasion, it was not for me to tell him (fellow) that he (fellow) looked far better in his (fellow) working-dress; the rather, because I knew he (fellow) made himself so dreadfully uncomfortable, entirely on my account, and that it was for me he (fellow) pulled up his (fellow) shirt-collar so very high behind, that it made the hair on the crown of his (fellow) head

At breakfast-time my sister declared her (sister) intention of going to town with us, and being left at Uncle Pumblechook's and called for

``when we had done with our fine ladies'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)
--a way of putting the case, from which Joe appeared inclined to augur the worst.

The forge was shut up for the day, and Joe inscribed in chalk upon the door -LRB-as it was his (Pumblechook) custom to do on the very rare occasions when he (Pumblechook) was not at work-RRB- the monosyllable HOUT, accompanied by a sketch of an arrow supposed to be flying in the direction he (Pumblechook) had taken.

We walked to town, my sister leading the way in a very large beaver bonnet, and carrying a basket like the Great Seal of England in plaited Straw, a pair of pattens, a spare shawl, and an umbrella, though it was a fine bright day.

I am not quite clear whether these articles were carried penitentially or ostentatiously; but I rather think they were displayed as articles of property,--much as Cleopatra or any other sovereign lady on the Rampage might exhibit her (Cleopatra) wealth in a pageant or procession.

stand up like a tuft of feathers. When we came to Pumblechook's, my sister bounced in and left us. As it was almost noon, Joe and I held straight on to Miss Havisham's house.

Estella opened the gate as usual, and, the moment she (Estella) appeared, Joe took his (Pumblechook) hat off and stood weighing it by the brim in both his (Pumblechook) hands; as if he (Pumblechook) had some urgent reason in his (Pumblechook) mind for being particular to half a quarter of an ounce.

Estella took no notice of either of us, but led us the way that I knew so well. I followed next to her (Estella), and Joe came last.

When I looked back at Joe in the long passage, he (Pumblechook) was still weighing his (Pumblechook) hat with the greatest care, and was coming after us in long strides on the tips of his (Pumblechook) toes.

Estella told me we were both to go in, so I took Joe by the coat-cuff and conducted him (Pumblechook) into Miss Havisham's presence.

She (Havisham) was seated at her (Havisham) dressing-table, and looked round at us immediately. '' Oh!'' said she (Havisham) to Joe. '' You are the husband of the sister of this boy?

like some extraordinary bird; standing as he (boy) did speechless, with his (boy) tuft of feathers ruffled, and his (boy) mouth open as if he (boy) wanted a worm.

'' I could hardly have imagined dear old Joe looking so unlike himself or so '' You are the husband,'' repeated Miss Havisham,

'' ''
``And there weren't no objection on your part, and Pip it were the great wish of your hart!'' (me)

It was quite in vain for me to endeavor to make him (Pip) sensible that he (Pip) ought to speak to Miss Havisham.

The more I made faces and gestures to him (Pip) to do it, the more confidential, argumentative, and polite, he (Pip) persisted in being to Me.

Well, Pip, you know,'' replied Joe, as if that were a little unreasonable,

``you yourself see me put 'em in my `at, and therefore you know as they are here.

'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

Have you brought his (Pip) indentures with you?'' asked Miss Havisham. '' '' With which he (Pip) took them out, and gave them, not to Miss Havisham, but to me.

I am afraid I was ashamed of the dear good fellow,--I know I was ashamed of him (fellow),--when I saw that Estella stood at the back of Miss Havisham's chair, and that her (Havisham) eyes laughed mischievously.

I took the indentures out of his (fellow) hand and gave them to Miss Havisham. '' You expected,'' said Miss Havisham, as she (Havisham) looked them over,

``Joe!'' (me)
I remonstrated, for he (Joe) made no reply at all. '' Why don't you answer--'' well No. You know it to be No, Pip, and wherefore should I say it?

Miss Havisham glanced at him (Pip) as if she (Havisham) understood what he (Pip) really was better than I had thought possible, seeing what he (Pip) was there; and took up a little bag from the table beside her (Havisham). ''

'' Pip has earned a premium here,'' she (Havisham) said,

``and here it is. There are five-and-twenty guineas in this bag. Give it to your master, Pip.

As if he (master) were absolutely out of his (master) mind with the wonder awakened in him (master) by her (Havisham) strange figure and the strange room, Joe, even at this pass, persisted in addressing me.

This is wery liberal on your part, Pip,'' (she)

said Joe,
``and it is as such received and grateful welcome, though never looked for, far nor near, nor nowheres.

And now, old chap,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

'' (Pip/Mr. Pip)

I asked. ''

Thus calling him (Pip) back as I went out of the door, I heard her (Estella) say to Joe in a distinct emphatic voice,

``The boy has been a good boy here, and that is his (boy) reward.

No. Gargery is your master now. Gargery! One word!'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

Of course, as an honest man, you will expect no other and no more.

How Joe got out of the room, I have never been able to determine; but I know that when he (man) did get out he (man) was steadily proceeding upstairs instead of coming down, and was deaf to all remonstrances until I went after him (man) and laid hold of him (man).

'' In another minute we were outside the gate, and it was locked, and Estella was gone. When we stood in the daylight alone again, Joe backed up against a wall, and said to me, ``Astonishing!

And there he (man) remained so long saying,

``Astonishing'' (he)
at intervals, so often, that I began to think his (man) senses were never coming back.

At length he (man) prolonged his (man) remark into

``Pip, I do assure you this is as-TON-ishing!'' (he)
and so, by degrees, became conversational and able to walk away.

I have reason to think that Joe's intellects were brightened by the encounter they had passed through, and that on our way to Pumblechook's he (Pumblechook) invented a subtle and deep design.

My reason is to be found in what took place in Mr. Pumblechook's parlor: where, on our presenting ourselves, my sister sat in conference with that detested seedsman.

'' '' Well?'' cried my sister, addressing us both at once. '' And what's happened to you? I wonder you condescend to come back to such poor society as this, I am sure I do!''

``Miss Havisham,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe, with a fixed look at me, like an effort of remembrance,
``made it wery partick`ler that we should give her (Joe)--were it compliments or respects, Pip?'' (me)

``Compliments,'' (I)
I said. '' Which that were my own belief,'' answered Joe;
``her (Joe) compliments to Mrs. J. Gargery-- '' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
``Much good they'll do me!

And wishing,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

pursued Joe, with another fixed look at me, like another effort of remembrance,
``that the state of Miss Havisham's elth were sitch as would have--allowed, were it, Pip?'' (me)

'' observed my sister; but rather gratified too. ''

``Of her (sister) having the pleasure,'' (I)
I added. '' Of ladies' company,'' said Joe.

And drew a long breath. '' Well!'' cried my sister, with a mollified glance at Mr. Pumblechook. '' She (Joe) might have had the politeness to send that message at first, but it's better late than never.

And what did she (Joe) give young Rantipole here?'' '' She (Joe) giv' him (Pumblechook),'' said Joe,

``nothing. '' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
Mrs. Joe was going to break out, but Joe went on.

'' What she (Joe) giv','' said Joe,

``she (Joe) giv' to his (Pumblechook) friends. ' And by his (Pumblechook) friends,' were her (Joe) explanation, 'I mean into the hands of his (Pumblechook) sister Mrs. J. Gargery.'

Them were her (Gargery) words; `Mrs. J. Gargery.' She (Gargery) mayn't have know'd,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

added Joe, with an appearance of reflection,
``whether it were Joe, or Jorge.

My sister looked at Pumblechook: who smoothed the elbows of his (Pumblechook) wooden arm-chair, and nodded at her (Joe) and at the fire, as if he (Pumblechook) had known all about it beforehand.

'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

'' And how much have you got? '' asked my sister, laughing. Positively laughing!
``What would present company say to ten pound?'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
demanded Joe.

'' They'd say,'' returned my sister, curtly,

``pretty well. Not too much, but pretty well. '' (sister)
'' It's more than that, then,'' said Joe.

That fearful Impostor, Pumblechook, immediately nodded, and said, as he (Pumblechook) rubbed the arms of his (Pumblechook) chair,

``It's more than that, Mum.'' (he)

``Why, you don't mean to say--'' (sister)
began my sister. '' Yes I do, Mum,'' said Pumblechook;
``but wait a bit. Go on, Joseph.

Good in you! Go on!'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)

``What would present company say,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
proceeded Joe,
``to twenty pound?'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
``Handsome would be the word,'' (sister)
returned my sister.

'' Well, then,'' said Joe,

``It's more than twenty pound. '' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
That abject hypocrite, Pumblechook, nodded again, and said, with a patronizing laugh,
``It's more than that, Mum.

Good again! Follow her (Mum) up, Joseph!'' (That hypocrite Pumblechook)

``Then to make an end of it,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe, delightedly handing the bag to my sister;
``it's five-and-twenty pound.'' (sister)

It's five-and-twenty pound, Mum,'' echoed that basest of swindlers, Pumblechook, rising to shake hands with her (Mum);

``and it's no more than your merits -LRB-as I said when my opinion was asked-RRB-, and I wish you joy of the money!

If the villain had stopped here, his (villain) case would have been sufficiently awful, but he (villain) blackened his (villain) guilt by proceeding to take me into custody, with a right of patronage that left all his (villain) former criminality far behind.

Now you see, Joseph and wife,'' (swindlers Pumblechook)

said Pumblechook, as he (Pumblechook) took me by the arm above the elbow,
``I am one of them that always go right through with what they've begun.

'' (me)

'' '' This boy must be bound, out of hand. That's my way. Bound out of hand. ''
``Goodness knows, Uncle Pumblechook,'' (sister)
said my sister -LRB-grasping the money-RRB-,
``we're deeply beholden to you.

'' (sister)

``Never mind me, Mum,'' (unknown)
returned that diabolical cornchandler. '' A pleasure's a pleasure all the world over. But this boy, you know; we must have him (boy) bound.

The Justices were sitting in the Town Hall near at hand, and we at once went over to have me bound apprentice to Joe in the Magisterial presence.

I say we went over, but I was pushed over by Pumblechook, exactly as if I had that moment picked a pocket or fired a rick; indeed, it was the general impression in Court that I had been taken red-handed; for,

as Pumblechook shoved me before him (Pumblechook) through the crowd, I heard some people say,

``What's he (Pumblechook) done?'' (some people)
and others,
``He (Pumblechook)'s a young `un, too, but looks bad, don't he (Pumblechook)?'' (others)

One person of mild and benevolent aspect even gave me a tract ornamented with a woodcut of a malevolent young man fitted up with a perfect sausage-shop of fetters, and entitled TO BE READ IN MY CELL.

I said I'd see to it--to tell you the truth. '' The Hall was a queer place, I thought, with higher pews in it than a church,--and

with people hanging over the pews looking on,--and with mighty Justices -LRB-one with a powdered head-RRB- leaning back in chairs, with folded arms, or taking snuff, or going to sleep, or writing, or reading the newspapers,--and with some shining black portraits on the walls, which my unartistic eye regarded as a composition of hardbake and sticking-plaster.

Here, in a corner my indentures were duly signed and attested, and I was

``bound'' (I)
; Mr. Pumblechook holding me all the while as if we had looked in on our way to the scaffold, to have those little preliminaries disposed of.

When we had come out again, and had got rid of the boys who had been put into great spirits by the expectation of seeing me publicly tortured, and who were much disappointed to find that my friends were merely rallying round me, we went back to Pumblechook's.

And there my sister became so excited by the twenty-five guineas, that nothing would serve her (sister) but we must have a dinner out of that windfall at the Blue Boar, and that Pumblechook must go over in his (Pumblechook) chaise-cart, and bring the Hubbles and Mr. Wopsle.

For, it inscrutably appeared to stand to reason, in the minds of the whole company, that I was an excrescence on the entertainment.

And to make it worse, they all asked me from time to time,--in short, whenever they had nothing else to do,--why

It was agreed to be done; and a most melancholy day I passed. I didn't enjoy myself? And what could I possibly do then, but say I was enjoying myself,--when

That swindling Pumblechook, exalted into the beneficent contriver of the whole occasion, actually took the top of the table; and, when he (Pumblechook) addressed them on the subject of my being bound, and had fiendishly congratulated them on my being liable to imprisonment if I played at cards, drank strong liquors, kept late hours or bad company, or indulged in other vagaries which the form of my indentures appeared to contemplate as next to inevitable, he (Pumblechook) placed me standing on a chair beside him (Pumblechook) to illustrate his (Pumblechook) remarks.

My only other remembrances of the great festival are, That they wouldn't let me go to sleep, but whenever they saw me dropping off, woke me up and told me to enjoy myself.

That, rather late in the evening Mr. Wopsle gave us Collins's ode, and threw his (Wopsle) bloodstained sword in thunder down, with such effect, that a waiter came in and said,

``The Commercials underneath sent up their compliments, and it wasn't the Tumblers' Arms.

I wasn't! However, they were grown up and had their own way, and they made the most of it. '' (a waiter)

That, they were all in excellent spirits on the road home, and sang, O Lady Fair!

Mr. Wopsle taking the bass, and asserting with a tremendously strong voice -LRB-in reply to the inquisitive bore who leads that piece of music in a most impertinent manner, by wanting to know all about everybody's private affairs-RRB- that he (Wopsle) was the man with his (Wopsle) white locks flowing, and that he (Wopsle) was upon the whole the weakest pilgrim going.

Finally, I remember that when I got into my little bedroom, I was truly wretched, and had a strong conviction on me that I should never like Joe's trade.

I had liked it once, but once was not now. Chapter XIV It is a most miserable thing to feel ashamed of home.

There may be black ingratitude in the thing, and the punishment may be retributive and well deserved; but that it is a miserable thing, I can testify.

Home had never been a very pleasant place to me, because of my sister's temper. But, Joe had sanctified it, and I had believed in it.

I had believed in the best parlor as a most elegant saloon; I had believed in the front door, as a mysterious portal of the Temple of State whose solemn opening was attended with a sacrifice of roast fowls; I had believed in the kitchen as a chaste though not magnificent apartment; I had believed in the forge as the glowing road to manhood and independence.

Now it was all coarse and common, and I would not have had Miss Havisham and Estella see it on any account.

How much of my ungracious condition of mind may have been my own fault, how much Miss Havisham's, how much my sister's, is now of no moment to me or to any one.

Within a single year all this was changed. The change was made in me; the thing was done. Well or ill done, excusably or inexcusably, it was done.

Once, it had seemed to me that when I should at last roll up my shirt-sleeves and go into the forge, Joe's `prentice, I should be distinguished and happy.

Now the reality was in my hold, I only felt that I was dusty with the dust of small-coal, and that I had a weight upon my daily remembrance to which the anvil was a feather.

There have been occasions in my later life -LRB-I suppose as in most lives-RRB- when I have felt for a time as if a thick curtain had fallen on all its interest and romance, to shut me out from anything save dull endurance any more.

Never has that curtain dropped so heavy and blank, as when my way in life lay stretched out straight before me through the newly entered road of apprenticeship to Joe.

I remember that at a later period of my

``time,'' (I)
I used to stand about the churchyard on Sunday evenings when night was falling, comparing my own perspective with the windy marsh view, and making out some likeness between them by thinking how flat and low both were, and how on both there came an unknown way and a dark mist and then the sea.

I was quite as dejected on the first working-day of my apprenticeship as in that after-time; but I am glad to know that I never breathed a murmur to Joe while my indentures lasted.

It is about the only thing I am glad to know of myself in that connection. For, though it includes what I proceed to add, all the merit of what I proceed to add was Joe's.

It was not because I was faithful, but because Joe was faithful, that I never ran away and went for a soldier or a sailor.

It was not because I had a strong sense of the virtue of industry, but because Joe had a strong sense of the virtue of industry, that I worked with tolerable zeal against the grain.

It is not possible to know how far the influence of any amiable honest-hearted duty-doing man flies out into the world; but it is very possible to know how it has touched one's self in going by, and I know right well that any good that intermixed itself with my apprenticeship came of plain contented Joe, and not of restlessly aspiring discontented me.

What I dreaded was, that in some unlucky hour I, being at my grimiest and commonest, should lift up my eyes and see Estella looking in at one of the wooden windows of the forge.

I was haunted by the fear that she (Estella) would, sooner or later, find me out, with a black face and hands, doing the coarsest part of my work, and would exult over me and despise me.

Often after dark, when I was pulling the bellows for Joe, and we were singing Old Clem, and when the thought how we used to sing it at Miss Havisham's would seem to show me Estella's face in the fire, with her (Estella) pretty hair fluttering in the wind and her (Estella) eyes scorning me,--often at such a time I would look towards those panels of black night in the wall which the wooden windows then were, and would fancy that I saw her (Estella) just drawing her (Estella) face away, and would believe that she (Estella) had come at last.

After that, when we went into supper, the place and the meal would have a more homely look than ever, and I would feel more ashamed of home than ever, in my own ungracious breast.

What I wanted, who can say? How can I say, when I never knew? Chapter XV As I was getting too big for Mr. Wopsle's great-aunt's room, my education under that preposterous female terminated.

Not, however, until Biddy had imparted to me everything she (great-aunt) knew, from the little catalogue of prices, to a comic song she (great-aunt) had once bought for a half-penny.

Although the only coherent part of the latter piece of literature were the opening lines. When I went to Lunnon town sirs, Too rul loo rul

, in my desire to be wiser, I got this composition by heart with the utmost gravity; nor do I recollect that I questioned its merit, except that I thought -LRB-as I still do-RRB- the amount of Too rul somewhat in excess of the poetry.

In my hunger for information, I made proposals to Mr. Wopsle to bestow some intellectual crumbs upon me, with which he (Wopsle) kindly complied.

As it turned out, however, that he (Wopsle) only wanted me for a dramatic lay-figure, to be contradicted and embraced and wept over and bullied and clutched and stabbed and knocked about in a variety of ways, I soon declined that course of instruction; though not until Mr. Wopsle in his (Wopsle) poetic fury had severely mauled me.

Too rul loo rul Wasn't I done very brown sirs? Too rul loo rul Too rul loo rul --still Whatever I acquired, I tried to impart to Joe.

I wanted to make Joe less ignorant and common, that he (Wopsle) might be worthier of my society and less open to Estella's reproach.

The old Battery out on the marshes was our place of study, and a broken slate and a short piece of slate-pencil were our educational implements: to which Joe always added a pipe of tobacco.

I never knew Joe to remember anything from one Sunday to another, or to acquire, under my tuition, any piece of information whatever.

Yet he (Wopsle) would smoke his (Wopsle) pipe at the Battery with a far more sagacious air than anywhere else,--even with a learned air,--as if he (Wopsle) considered himself to be advancing immensely.

This statement sounds so well, that I cannot in my conscience let it pass unexplained. Dear fellow, I hope he (fellow) did.

It was pleasant and quiet, out there with the sails on the river passing beyond the earthwork, and sometimes, when the tide was low, looking as if they belonged to sunken ships that were still sailing on at the bottom of the water.

Whenever I watched the vessels standing out to sea with their white sails spread, I somehow thought of Miss Havisham and Estella; and whenever the light struck aslant, afar off, upon a cloud or sail or green hillside or water-line, it was just the same.--Miss Havisham and Estella and the strange house and the strange life appeared to have something to do with everything that was picturesque.

One Sunday when Joe, greatly enjoying his (Joe) pipe, had so plumed himself on being

``most awful dull,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
that I had given him (Joe) up for the day, I lay on the earthwork for some time with my chin on my hand, descrying traces of Miss Havisham and Estella all over the prospect, in the sky and in the water, until at last I resolved to mention a thought concerning them that had been much in my head.

'' Joe,'' said I;

``don't you think I ought to make Miss Havisham a visit?'' (I)
'' Well, Pip,'' returned Joe, slowly considering.

'' What for?''

``What for, Joe? What is any visit made for?'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
'' There is some wisits p`r`aps,'' said Joe,
``as for ever remains open to the question, Pip.

But in regard to wisiting Miss Havisham. She (Joe) might think you wanted something,--expected something of her (Joe).'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

``Don't you think I might say that I did not, Joe?'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

Joe felt, as I did, that he (Pip) had made a point there, and he (Pip) pulled hard at his (Pip) pipe to keep himself from weakening it by repetition.

You see, Pip,'' Joe pursued, as soon as he (Pip) was past that danger,

``Miss Havisham done the handsome thing by you.

When Miss Havisham done the handsome thing by you, she (Havisham) called me back to say to me as that were all.'' (he)

``You might, old chap,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe. '' And she (Joe) might credit it. Similarly she (Joe) mightn't. '' '' '' Yes, Joe. I heard her (Joe).''

``ALL,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
Joe repeated, very emphatically. '' Yes, Joe. I tell you, I heard her (Joe).'' '' Which I meantersay, Pip, it might be that her (Joe) meaning were,--Make

I had thought of that too, and it was very far from comforting to me to find that he (Pip) had thought of it; for it seemed to render it more probable.

a end on it!--As you was!--Me to the North, and you to the South!--Keep in sunders! '' '' But, Joe. ''

Here am I, getting on in the first year of my time, and, since the day of my being bound, I have never thanked Miss Havisham, or asked after her (Havisham), or shown that I remember her (Havisham).''

That's true, Pip; and unless you was to turn her (Havisham) out a set of shoes all four round,--and which I meantersay as even a set of shoes all four round might not be acceptable as a present, in a total wacancy of hoofs--

``Yes, old chap. '' (I)
'' '' ''
``I don't mean that sort of remembrance, Joe; I don't mean a present. '' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

But Joe had got the idea of a present in his (chap) head and must harp upon it. '' Or even,'' said he (chap),

``if you was helped to knocking her (Joe) up a new chain for the front door,--or say a gross or two of shark-headed screws for general use,--or some light fancy article, such as a toasting-fork when she (Joe) took her (Joe) muffins,--or a gridiron when she (Joe) took a sprat or such like--'' (he)
``I don't mean any present at all, Joe,'' (he)
I interposed.

'' Well,'' said Joe, still harping on it as though I had particularly pressed it,

``if I was yourself, Pip, I wouldn't.

No, I would not. For what's a door-chain when she (Joe)'s got one always up? And shark-headers is open to misrepresentations. And if it was a toasting-fork, you'd go into brass and do yourself no credit.

a gridiron IS a gridiron,'' (I)

said Joe, steadfastly impressing it upon me, as if he (Pip) were endeavouring to rouse me from a fixed delusion,
``and you may haim at what you like, but a gridiron it will come out, either by your leave or again your leave, and you can't help yourself--
