And the oncommonest workman can't show himself oncommon in a gridiron,--for '' (me)

'' My dear Joe,'' I cried, in desperation, taking hold of his (workman) coat,
``don't go on in that way.

I never thought of making Miss Havisham any present.'' (I)

``No, Pip,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
Joe assented, as if he (Pip) had been contending for that, all along;
``and

Yes, Joe; but what I wanted to say, was, that as we are rather slack just now, if you would give me a half-holiday to-morrow, I think I would go uptown and make a call on Miss Est--Havisham.'' (he)

what I say to you is, you are right, Pip.'' '' '' Which her (Joe) name,'' said Joe, gravely,

``ain't Estavisham, Pip, unless she (Joe) have been rechris`ened.'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

``I know, Joe, I know. It was a slip of mine. What do you think of it, Joe? '' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
In brief, Joe thought that if I thought well of it, he (Pip) thought well of it.

But, he (Pip) was particular in stipulating that if I were not received with cordiality, or if I were not encouraged to repeat my visit as a visit which had no ulterior object but was simply one of gratitude for a favor received, then this experimental trip should have no successor.

By these conditions I promised to abide. Now, Joe kept a journeyman at weekly wages whose name was Orlick. He (Orlick) pretended that his (Orlick) Christian name was Dolge,--a clear Impossibility,--but

he (Orlick) was a fellow of that obstinate disposition that I believe him (Orlick) to have been the prey of no delusion in this particular, but wilfully to have imposed that name upon the village as an affront to its understanding.

He (Orlick) never even seemed to come to his (Orlick) work on purpose, but would slouch in as if by mere accident; and when he (Orlick) went to the Jolly Bargemen to eat his (Orlick) dinner, or went away at night, he (Orlick) would slouch out, like Cain or the Wandering Jew, as if he (Cain) had no idea where he (Cain) was going and no intention of ever coming back.

He (Cain) lodged at a sluice-keeper's out on the marshes, and on working-days would come slouching from his (Cain) hermitage, with his (Cain) hands in his (Cain) pockets and his (Cain) dinner loosely tied in a bundle round his (Cain) neck and dangling on his (Cain) back.

He (Cain) was a broadshouldered loose-limbed swarthy fellow of great strength, never in a hurry, and always slouching. On Sundays he (Cain) mostly lay all day on the sluice-gates, or stood against ricks and barns.

He (Cain) always slouched, locomotively, with his (Cain) eyes on the ground; and, when accosted or otherwise required to raise them, he (Cain) looked up in a half-resentful, half-puzzled way, as though the only thought he (Cain) ever had was, that it was rather an odd and injurious fact that he (Cain) should never be thinking.

When I was very small and timid, he (Cain) gave me to understand that the Devil lived in a black corner of the forge, and that he (Devil) knew the fiend very well: also that it was necessary to make up the fire, once in seven years, with a live boy, and that I might consider myself fuel.

When I became Joe's `prentice, Orlick was perhaps confirmed in some suspicion that I should displace him (Orlick); howbeit, he (Orlick) liked me still less.

Not that he (Orlick) ever said anything, or did anything, openly importing hostility; I only noticed that he (Orlick) always beat his (Orlick) sparks in my direction, and that whenever I sang Old Clem, he (Orlick) came in out of time.

This morose journeyman had no liking for me. Dolge Orlick was at work and present, next day, when I reminded Joe of my half-holiday.

He (journeyman) said nothing at the moment, for he (journeyman) and Joe had just got a piece of hot iron between them, and I was at the bellows; but by and by he (journeyman) said, leaning on his (journeyman) hammer,--

'' Now, master! Sure you're not a going to favor only one of us. If Young Pip has a half-holiday, do as much for Old Orlick.

'' I suppose he (Orlick) was about five-and-twenty, but he (Orlick) usually spoke of himself as an ancient person. '' Why, what'll you do with a half-holiday, if you get it?'' said Joe.

'' What'll I do with it! What'll he (Orlick) do with it? I'll do as much with it as him (Orlick),'' said Orlick.

'' As to Pip, he (Orlick)'s going up town,'' said Joe. '' Well then, as to Old Orlick, he (Orlick)'s a going up town,'' retorted that worthy.

'' Two can go up town. Tain't only one wot can go up town. '' Don't lose your temper,'' said Joe.

'' Shall if I like,'' growled Orlick. '' Some and their uptowning! Now, master! Come. No favoring in this shop. Be a man!''

The master refusing to entertain the subject until the journeyman was in a better temper, Orlick plunged at the furnace, drew out a red-hot bar, made at me with it as if he (Orlick) were going to run it through my body, whisked it round my head, laid it on the anvil, hammered it out,--as if it were I,

I thought, and the sparks were my spirting blood,--and finally said, when he (Orlick) had hammered himself hot and the iron cold, and he (Orlick) again leaned on his (Orlick) hammer,--

'' Now, master!''

``Are you all right now?'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
demanded Joe. '' Ah! I am all right,'' said gruff Old Orlick. ''

Then, as in general you stick to your work as well as most men,'' said Joe,

``let it be a half-holiday for all.

'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

My sister had been standing silent in the yard, within hearing,--she (Joe) was a most unscrupulous spy and listener,--and she (Joe) instantly looked in at one of the windows.

'' Like you, you fool!'' said she (Joe) to Joe,

``giving holidays to great idle hulkers like that. You are a rich man, upon my life, to waste wages in that way.

I wish I was his (man) master!'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

'' You'd be everybody's master, if you durst,'' retorted Orlick, with an ill-favored grin. -LRB-
``Let her (Joe) alone,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe.-RRB-

I'd be a match for all noodles and all rogues,'' returned my sister, beginning to work herself into a mighty rage.

And I couldn't be a match for the noodles, without being a match for your master, who's the dunder-headed king of the noodles.

And I couldn't be a match for the rogues, without being a match for you, who are the blackest-looking and the worst rogue between this and France.

'' '' Now!'' '' You're a foul shrew, Mother Gargery,'' growled the journeyman. '' If that makes a judge of rogues, you ought to be a good`un.

'' -LRB-

``Let her (Mother) alone, will you?'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe.-RRB- '' What did you say?'' cried my sister, beginning to scream. '' What did you say?

What did that fellow Orlick say to me, Pip? What did he (Orlick) call me, with my husband standing by? Oh! oh!

what is equally true of all the violent women I have ever seen, that passion was no excuse for her (Joe), because it is undeniable that instead of lapsing into passion, she (Joe) consciously and deliberately took extraordinary pains to force herself into it, and became blindly furious by regular stages;

``what was the name he (Orlick) gave me before the base man who swore to defend me?

oh!'' (she)

Each of these exclamations was a shriek; and I must remark of my sister, Oh! Hold me! Oh!''
``Ah-h-h! '' (the journeyman)
growled the journeyman, between his (journeyman) teeth,

``I'd hold you, if you was my wife. I'd hold you under the pump, and choke it out of you. '' (the journeyman)

-LRB-

``I tell you, let her (wife) alone,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe.-RRB- '' Oh! To hear him (journeyman)!'' cried my sister, with a clap of her (Joe) hands and a scream

together,--which was her (Joe) next stage. '' To hear the names he (journeyman)'s giving me! That Orlick! In my own house! Me, a married woman!

Here my sister, after a fit of clappings and screamings, beat her (sister) hands upon her (sister) bosom and upon her (sister) knees, and threw her (sister) cap off, and pulled her (sister) hair down,--which were the last stages on her (sister) road to frenzy.

Being by this time a perfect Fury and a complete success, she (sister) made a dash at the door which I had fortunately locked.

What could the wretched Joe do now, after his (Orlick) disregarded parenthetical interruptions, but stand up to his (Orlick) journeyman, and ask him (Orlick) what he (Orlick) meant by interfering betwixt himself and Mrs. Joe; and further whether he (Orlick) was man enough to come on?

Old Orlick felt that the situation admitted of nothing less than coming on, and was on his (Orlick) defence straightway; so, without so much as pulling off their singed and burnt aprons, they went at one another, like two giants.

With my husband standing by! Oh! Oh!'' But, if any man in that neighborhood could stand uplong against Joe, I never saw the man.

Orlick, as if he (Orlick) had been of no more account than the pale young gentleman, was very soon among the coal-dust, and in no hurry to come out of it.

Then Joe unlocked the door and picked up my sister, who had dropped insensible at the window -LRB-but who had seen the fight first, I think-RRB-, and who was carried into the house and laid down, and who was recommended to revive, and would do nothing but struggle and clench her (Joe) hands in Joe's hair.

Then, came that singular calm and silence which succeed all uproars; and then, with the vague sensation which I have always connected with such a lull,--namely, that it was Sunday, and somebody was dead,--I went upstairs to dress myself.

When I came down again, I found Joe and Orlick sweeping up, without any other traces of discomposure than a slit in one of Orlick's nostrils, which was neither expressive nor ornamental.

A pot of beer had appeared from the Jolly Bargemen, and they were sharing it by turns in a peaceable manner.

The lull had a sedative and philosophical influence on Joe, who followed me out into the road to say, as a parting observation that might do me good,

``On the Rampage, Pip, and off the Rampage, Pip:--such is Life!'' (me)

With what absurd emotions -LRB-for we think the feelings that are very serious in a man quite comical in a boy-RRB-

I found myself again going to Miss Havisham's, matters little here. Nor, how I passed and repassed the gate many times before I could make up my mind to ring.

Nor, how I debated whether I should go away without ringing; nor, how I should undoubtedly have gone, if my time had been my own, to come back.

Miss Sarah Pocket came to the gate. No Estella. '' How, then? You here again?'' said Miss Pocket. '' What do you want?

When I said that I only came to see how Miss Havisham was, Sarah evidently deliberated whether or no she (Havisham) should send me about my business.

But unwilling to hazard the responsibility, she (Havisham) let me in, and presently brought the sharp message that I was to

``come up.

'' (I)

'' Everything was unchanged, and Miss Havisham was alone. '' Well?'' said she (Havisham), fixing her (Havisham) eyes upon me. '' I hope you want nothing?

I only wanted you to know that I am doing very well in my apprenticeship, and am always much obliged to you.''

You'll get nothing.'' '' No indeed, Miss Havisham. '' There, there!'' with the old restless fingers.

``Come now and then; come on your birthday.--Ay!

'' (she)

she (Havisham) cried suddenly, turning herself and her (Havisham) chair towards me,
``You are looking round for Estella? Hey? '' (me)
I had been looking round,--in fact, for Estella,--and I stammered that I hoped she (Estella) was well.

Abroad,'' said Miss Havisham;

``educating for a lady; far out of reach; prettier than ever; admired by all who see her (Havisham).

There was such a malignant enjoyment in her (Havisham) utterance of the last words, and she (Havisham) broke into such a disagreeable laugh, that I was at a loss what to say.

When the gate was closed upon me by Sarah of the walnut-shell countenance, I felt more than ever dissatisfied with my home and with my trade and with everything; and that was all I took by that motion.

As I was loitering along the High Street, looking in disconsolately at the shop windows, and thinking what I would buy if I were a gentleman, who should come out of the bookshop but Mr. Wopsle.

Mr. Wopsle had in his (Wopsle) hand the affecting tragedy of George Barnwell, in which he (Wopsle) had that moment invested sixpence, with the view of heaping every word of it on the head of Pumblechook, with whom he (Wopsle) was going to drink tea.

No sooner did he (Wopsle) see me, than he (Wopsle) appeared to consider that a special Providence had put a `prentice in his (Wopsle) way to be read at; and he (Wopsle) laid hold of me, and insisted on my accompanying him (Wopsle) to the Pumblechookian parlor.

As I knew it would be miserable at home, and as the nights were dark and the way was dreary, and almost any companionship on the road was better than none, I made no great resistance; consequently, we turned into Pumblechook's just as the street and the shops were lighting up.

As I never assisted at any other representation of George Barnwell, I don't know how long it may usually take; but I know very well that it took until half-past nine o' clock that night, and that when Mr. Wopsle got into Newgate, I thought he (Wopsle) never would go to the scaffold, he (Wopsle) became so much slower than at any former period of his (Wopsle) disgraceful career.

I thought it a little too much that he (Wopsle) should complain of being cut short in his (Wopsle) flower after all, as if he (Wopsle) had not been running to seed, leaf after leaf, ever since his (Wopsle) course began.

'' (Miss Havisham)

Do you feel that you have lost her (Wopsle)? '' She (Wopsle) spared me the trouble of considering, by dismissing me. This, however, was a mere question of length and wearisomeness.

When Barnwell began to go wrong, I declare that I felt positively apologetic, Pumblechook's indignant stare so taxed me with it.

What stung me, was the identification of the whole affair with my unoffending self. Wopsle, too, took pains to present me in the worst light.

At once ferocious and maudlin, I was made to murder my uncle with no extenuating circumstances whatever; Millwood put me down in argument, on every occasion; it became sheer monomania in my master's daughter to care a button for me; and all I can say for my gasping and procrastinating conduct on the fatal morning, is, that it was worthy of the general feebleness of my character.

, Pumblechook sat staring at me, and shaking his (Pumblechook) head, and saying,

``Take warning, boy, take warning!'' (me)
as if it were a well-known fact that I contemplated murdering a near relation, provided I could only induce one to have the weakness to become my benefactor.

It was a very dark night when it was all over, and when I set out with Mr. Wopsle on the walk home.

Even after I was happily hanged and Wopsle had closed the book Beyond town, we found a heavy mist out, and it fell wet and thick.

The turnpike lamp was a blur, quite out of the lamp's usual place apparently, and its rays looked solid substance on the fog.

We were noticing this, and saying how that the mist rose with a change of wind from a certain quarter of our marshes, when we came upon a man, slouching under the lee of the turnpike house.

``Halloa!'' (Orlick/Old Orlick)
we said, stopping. '' Orlick there?''
``Ah!'' (he)
he (Orlick) answered, slouching out. '' I was standing by a minute, on the chance of company.

''

``You are late,'' (I)
I remarked. Orlick not unnaturally answered,
``Well? And you're late.'' (Orlick/Old Orlick)
``We have been,'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)
said Mr. Wopsle, exalted with his (Wopsle) late performance,--
``we have been indulging, Mr. Orlick, in an intellectual evening.

'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)

Old Orlick growled, as if he (Orlick) had nothing to say about that, and we all went on together. I asked him (Orlick) presently whether he (Orlick) had been spending his (Orlick) half-holiday up and down town?

'' Yes,'' said he (Orlick),

``all of it. I come in behind yourself. I didn't see you, but I must have been pretty close behind you.

By the by, the guns is going again.'' (he)

``At the Hulks?'' (I.)
said I.
``Ay! There's some of the birds flown from the cages.

In effect, we had not walked many yards further, when the well-remembered boom came towards us, deadened by the mist, and heavily rolled away along the low grounds by the river, as if it were pursuing and threatening the fugitives.

The guns have been going since dark, about. You'll hear one presently. '' (I.)

'' A good night for cutting off in,'' said Orlick.

'' We'd be puzzled how to bring down a jail-bird on the wing, to-night. '' The subject was a suggestive one to me, and I thought about it in silence.

Mr. Wopsle, as the ill-requited uncle of the evening's tragedy, fell to meditating aloud in his (Wopsle) garden at Camberwell. Orlick, with his (Orlick) hands in his (Orlick) pockets, slouched heavily at my side.

Now and then, the sound of the signal cannon broke upon us again, and again rolled sulkily along the course of the river.

It was very dark, very wet, very muddy, and so we splashed along. I kept myself to myself and my thoughts.

Mr. Wopsle died amiably at Camberwell, and exceedingly game on Bosworth Field, and in the greatest agonies at Glastonbury. Orlick sometimes growled,

``Beat it out, beat it out,--Old Clem!

With a clink for the stout,--Old Clem! '' (Orlick/Old Orlick)

I thought he (Clem) had been drinking, but he (Clem) was not drunk. Thus, we came to the village.

The way by which we approached it took us past the Three Jolly Bargemen, which we were surprised to find--it being eleven o'clock--in a state of commotion, with the door wide open, and unwonted lights that had been hastily caught up and put down scattered about.

Mr. Wopsle dropped into ask what was the matter -LRB-surmising that a convict had been taken-RRB-, but came running out in a great hurry.

'' There's something wrong,'' said he (Wopsle), without stopping,

``up at your place, Pip. Run all!'' (he)
'' What is it? '' I asked, keeping up with him (Wopsle).

So did Orlick, at my side. '' I can't quite understand. The house seems to have been violently entered when Joe Gargery was out.

We were running too fast to admit of more being said, and we made no stop until we got into our kitchen.

It was full of people; the whole village was there, or in the yard; and there was a surgeon, and there was Joe, and there were a group of women, all on the floor in the midst of the kitchen.

The unemployed bystanders drew back when they saw me, and so I became aware of my sister,--lying without sense or movement on the bare boards where she (sister) had been knocked down by a tremendous blow on the back of the head, dealt by some unknown hand when her (sister) face was turned towards the fire,--destined never to be on the Rampage again, while she (sister) was the wife of Joe.

With my head full of George Barnwell, I was at first disposed to believe that I must have had some hand in the attack upon my sister, or at all events that as her (sister) near relation, popularly known to be under obligations to her (sister), I was a more legitimate object of suspicion than any one else.

But when, in the clearer light of next morning, I began to reconsider the matter and to hear it discussed around me on all sides, I took another view of the case, which was more reasonable.

Joe had been at the Three Jolly Bargemen, smoking his (Bargemen) pipe, from a quarter after eight o'clock to a quarter before ten.

While he (Bargemen) was there, my sister had been seen standing at the kitchen door, and had exchanged Good Night with a farm-laborer going home.

The man could not be more particular as to the time at which he (man) saw her (sister) -LRB-he (man) got into dense confusion when he (man) tried to be-RRB-, than that it must have been before nine.

When Joe went home at five minutes before ten, he (man) found her (Joe) struck down on the floor, and promptly called in assistance.

The fire had not then burnt unusually low, nor was the snuff of the candle very long; the candle, however, had been blown out.

Supposed by convicts. Somebody has been attacked and hurt. '' Chapter XVI Nothing had been taken away from any part of the house.

Neither, beyond the blowing out of the candle,--which stood on a table between the door and my sister, and was behind her (sister) when she (sister) stood facing the fire and was struck,--was there any disarrangement of the kitchen, excepting such as she (sister) herself had made, in falling and bleeding.

She (sister) had been struck with something blunt and heavy, on the head and spine; after the blows were dealt, something heavy had been thrown down at her (sister) with considerable violence, as she (sister) lay on her (sister) face.

But, there was one remarkable piece of evidence on the spot. And on the ground beside her (sister), when Joe picked her (Joe) up, was a convict's leg-iron which had been filed asunder.

The hue and cry going off to the Hulks, and people coming thence to examine the iron, Joe's opinion was corroborated.

They did not undertake to say when it had left the prison-ships to which it undoubtedly had once belonged; but they claimed to know for certain that that particular manacle had not been worn by either of the two convicts who had escaped last night.

Now, Joe, examining this iron with a smith's eye, declared it to have been filed asunder some time ago. Further, one of those two was already retaken, and had not freed himself of his (smith) iron.

I believed the iron to be my convict's iron,--the iron I had seen and heard him (smith) filing at, on the marshes,--but

Knowing what I knew, I set up an inference of my own here. my mind did not accuse him (smith) of having put it to its latest use.

For I believed one of two other persons to have become possessed of it, and to have turned it to this cruel account.

Now, as to Orlick; he (Orlick) had gone to town exactly as he (Orlick) told us when we picked him (Orlick) up at the turnpike, he (Orlick) had been seen about town all the evening, he (Orlick) had been in divers companies in several public-houses, and he (Orlick) had come back with myself and Mr. Wopsle.

There was nothing against him (Wopsle), save the quarrel; and my sister had quarrelled with him (Wopsle), and with everybody else about her (sister), ten thousand times.

As to the strange man; if he (man) had come back for his (man) two bank-notes there could have been no dispute about them, because my sister was fully prepared to restore them.

Besides, there had been no altercation; the assailant had come in so silently and suddenly, that she (sister) had been felled before she (sister) could look round.

Either Orlick, or the strange man who had shown me the file. It was horrible to think that I had provided the weapon, however undesignedly, but I could hardly think otherwise.

I suffered unspeakable trouble while I considered and reconsidered whether I should at last dissolve that spell of my childhood and tell Joe all the story.

The contention came, after all, to this;--the secret was such an old one now, had so grown into me and become a part of myself, that I could not tear it away.

In addition to the dread that, having led up to so much mischief, it would be now more likely than ever to alienate Joe from me if he (I) believed it, I had a further restraining dread that he (I) would not believe it, but would assort it with the fabulous dogs and veal-cutlets as a monstrous invention.

However, I temporized with myself, of course--for, was I not wavering between right and wrong, when the thing is always done?--and resolved to make a full disclosure if I should see any such new occasion as a new chance of helping in the discovery of the assailant.

The Constables and the Bow Street men from London--for, this happened in the days of the extinct red-waistcoated police--were about the house for a week or two, and did pretty much what I have heard and read of like authorities doing in other such cases.

They took up several obviously wrong people, and they ran their heads very hard against wrong ideas, and persisted in trying to fit the circumstances to the ideas, instead of trying to extract ideas from the circumstances.

Also, they stood about the door of the Jolly Bargemen, with knowing and reserved looks that filled the whole neighborhood with admiration; and they had a mysterious manner of taking their drink, that was almost as good as taking the culprit.

For months afterwards, I every day settled the question finally in the negative, and reopened and reargued it next morning. But not quite, for they never did it.

Her (it) sight was disturbed, so that she (it) saw objects multiplied, and grasped at visionary teacups and wineglasses instead of the realities; her (it) hearing was greatly impaired; her (it) memory also; and her (it) speech was unintelligible.

When, at last, she (it) came round so far as to be helped downstairs, it was still necessary to keep my slate always by her (it), that she (it) might indicate in writing what she (it) could not indicate in speech.

As she (it) was -LRB-very bad handwriting apart-RRB- a more than indifferent speller, and as Joe was a more than indifferent reader, extraordinary complications arose between them which I was always called in to solve.

The administration of mutton instead of medicine, the substitution of Tea for Joe, and the baker for bacon, were among the mildest of my own mistakes.

Long after these constitutional powers had dispersed, my sister lay very ill in bed. However, her (sister) temper was greatly improved, and she (sister) was patient.

A tremulous uncertainty of the action of all her (sister) limbs soon became a part of her (sister) regular state, and afterwards, at intervals of two or three months, she (sister) would often put her (sister) hands to her (sister) head, and would then remain for about a week at a time in some gloomy aberration of mind.

Mr. Wopsle's great-aunt conquered a confirmed habit of living into which she (great-aunt) had fallen, and Biddy became a part of our establishment.

It may have been about a month after my sister's reappearance in the kitchen, when Biddy came to us with a small speckled box containing the whole of her (sister) worldly effects, and became a blessing to the household.

Above all, she (sister) was a blessing to Joe, for the dear old fellow was sadly cut up by the constant contemplation of the wreck of his (fellow) wife, and had been accustomed, while attending on her (wife) of an evening, to turn to me every now and then and say, with his (fellow) blue eyes moistened,

``Such a fine figure of a woman as she (woman) once were, Pip!'' (me)

Biddy instantly taking the cleverest charge of her (woman) as though she (woman) had studied her (woman) from infancy; Joe became able in some sort to appreciate the greater quiet of his (Pip) life, and to get down to the Jolly Bargemen now and then for a change that did him (Bargemen) good.

It was characteristic of the police people that they had all more or less suspected poor Joe -LRB-though he (Bargemen) never knew it-RRB-, and that they had to a man concurred in regarding him (Bargemen) as one of the deepest spirits they had ever encountered.

We were at a loss to find a suitable attendant for her (Joe), until a circumstance happened conveniently to relieve us. Biddy's first triumph in her (Joe) new office, was to solve a difficulty that had completely vanquished me.

Again and again and again, my sister had traced upon the slate, a character that looked like a curious T, and then with the utmost eagerness had called our attention to it as something she (sister) particularly wanted.

I had tried hard at it, but had made nothing of it. Thus it was:-- I had in vain tried everything producible that began with a T, from tar to toast and tub.

At length it had come into my head that the sign looked like a hammer, and on my lustily calling that word in my sister's ear, she (sister) had begun to hammer on the table and had expressed a qualified assent.

Then I bethought me of a crutch, the shape being much the same, and I borrowed one in the village, and displayed it to my sister with considerable confidence.

But she (sister) shook her (sister) head to that extent when she (sister) was shown it, that we were terrified lest in her (sister) weak and shattered state she (sister) should dislocate her (sister) neck.

Thereupon, I had brought in all our hammers, one after another, but without avail. When my sister found that Biddy was very quick to understand her (sister), this mysterious sign reappeared on the slate.

Biddy looked thoughtfully at it, heard my explanation, looked thoughtfully at my sister, looked thoughtfully at Joe -LRB-who was always represented on the slate by his (Joe) initial letter-RRB-, and ran into the forge, followed by Joe and me.

'' Why, of course!'' cried Biddy, with an exultant face. '' Don't you see? It's him (Joe)!'' Orlick, without a doubt! She (Joe) had lost his (Orlick) name, and could only signify him (Orlick) by his (Orlick) hammer.

We told him (Orlick) why we wanted him (Orlick) to come into the kitchen, and he (Orlick) slowly laid down his (Orlick) hammer, wiped his (Orlick) brow with his (Orlick) arm, took another wipe at it with his (Orlick) apron, and came slouching out, with a curious loose vagabond bend in the knees that strongly distinguished him (Orlick).

She (Joe) manifested the greatest anxiety to be on good terms with him (Orlick), was evidently much pleased by his (Orlick) being at length produced, and motioned that she (Joe) would have him (Orlick) given something to drink.

She (Joe) watched his (Orlick) countenance as if she (Joe) were particularly wishful to be assured that he (Orlick) took kindly to his (Orlick) reception, she (Joe) showed every possible desire to conciliate him (Orlick), and there was an air of humble propitiation in all she (Joe) did, such as I have seen pervade the bearing of a child towards a hard master.

After that day, a day rarely passed without her (Joe) drawing the hammer on her (Joe) slate, and without Orlick's slouching in and standing doggedly before her (Joe), as if he (Orlick) knew no more than I did what to make of it.

I confess that I expected to see my sister denounce him (Orlick), and that I was disappointed by the different result. Chapter XVII

I now fell into a regular routine of apprenticeship life, which was varied beyond the limits of the village and the marshes, by no more remarkable circumstance than the arrival of my birthday and my paying another visit to Miss Havisham.

I found Miss Sarah Pocket still on duty at the gate; I found Miss Havisham just as I had left her (Havisham), and she (Havisham) spoke of Estella in the very same way, if not in the very same words.

The interview lasted but a few minutes, and she (Havisham) gave me a guinea when I was going, and told me to come again on my next birthday.

I tried to decline taking the guinea on the first occasion, but with no better effect than causing her (Havisham) to ask me very angrily, if I expected more?

So unchanging was the dull old house, the yellow light in the darkened room, the faded spectre in the chair by the dressing-table glass, that I felt as if the stopping of the clocks had stopped Time in that mysterious place, and, while I and everything else outside it grew older, it stood still.

Daylight never entered the house as to my thoughts and remembrances of it, any more than as to the actual fact.

It bewildered me, and under its influence I continued at heart to hate my trade and to be ashamed of home.

I may mention at once that this became an annual custom. Then, and after that, I took it. Imperceptibly I became conscious of a change in Biddy, however.

Her (It) shoes came up at the heel, her (It) hair grew bright and neat, her (It) hands were always clean. She (It) was not beautiful,--she (It) was common, and could not be like

She (It) had not been with us more than a year -LRB-I remember her (It) being newly out of mourning at the time it struck me-RRB-, when I observed to myself one evening that she (It) had curiously thoughtful and attentive eyes; eyes that were very pretty and very good.

It came of my lifting up my own eyes from a task I was poring at--writing some passages from a book, to improve myself in two ways at once by a sort of stratagem--and seeing Biddy observant of what I was about.

Estella,--but she (Estella) was pleasant and wholesome and sweet-tempered. I laid down my pen, and Biddy stopped in her (Estella) needlework without laying it down.

'' Biddy,'' said I,

``how do you manage it? Either I am very stupid, or you are very clever. '' (I)
''

She (Estella) managed our whole domestic life, and wonderfully too; but I did not mean that, though that made what I did mean more surprising.

What is it that I manage? I don't know,'' returned Biddy, smiling. '' How do you manage, Biddy,'' said I,

``to learn everything that I learn, and always to keep up with me?

I was beginning to be rather vain of my knowledge, for I spent my birthday guineas on it, and set aside the greater part of my pocket-money for similar investment; though I have no doubt, now, that the little I knew was extremely dear at the price.

No; because when I come in from the forge of a night, any one can see me turning to at it.

'' (I)

'' I might as well ask you,'' said Biddy,
``how you manage?'' (Biddy)
'' But you never turn to at it, Biddy.''

Pursuing my idea as I leaned back in my wooden chair, and looked at Biddy sewing away with her (I) head on one side, I began to think her (I) rather an extraordinary girl.

For I called to mind now, that she (I) was equally accomplished in the terms of our trade, and the names of our different sorts of work, and our various tools.

``I suppose I must catch it like a cough,'' (Biddy)
said Biddy, quietly; and went on with her (I) sewing. In short, whatever I knew, Biddy knew.

Theoretically, she (I) was already as good a blacksmith as I, or better. '' You are one of those, Biddy,'' said I,

``who make the most of every chance.

You never had a chance before you came here, and see how improved you are!'' (I)

Biddy looked at me for an instant, and went on with her (I) sewing.

'' I was your first teacher though; wasn't I? '' said she (I), as she (I) sewed. '' Biddy! '' I exclaimed, in amazement.

'' Why, you are crying!'' '' No I am not,'' said Biddy, looking up and laughing. '' What put that in your head?

'' What could have put it in my head but the glistening of a tear as it dropped on her (I) work?

I sat silent, recalling what a drudge she (I) had been until Mr. Wopsle's great-aunt successfully overcame that bad habit of living, so highly desirable to be got rid of by some people.

I recalled the hopeless circumstances by which she (I) had been surrounded in the miserable little shop and the miserable little noisy evening school, with that miserable old bundle of incompetence always to be dragged and shouldered.

I reflected that even in those untoward times there must have been latent in Biddy what was now developing, for, in my first uneasiness and discontent I had turned to her (I) for help, as a matter of course.

Biddy sat quietly sewing, shedding no more tears, and while I looked at her (I) and thought about it all, it occurred to me that perhaps I had not been sufficiently grateful to Biddy.

I might have been too reserved, and should have patronized her (I) more -LRB-though I did not use that precise word in my meditations-RRB- with my confidence.

,'' I observed, when I had done turning it over,

``you were my first teacher, and that at a time when we little thought of ever being together like this, in this kitchen.'' (I)

It was like her (I) self-forgetfulness to transfer the remark to my sister, and to get up and be busy about her (I), making her (I) more comfortable;

``that's sadly true!'' (her)

'' Yes, Biddy

``Ah, poor thing!'' (Biddy)
replied Biddy.
``Well!'' (I)
said I,
``we must talk together a little more, as we used to do.

And I must consult you a little more, as I used to do. Let us have a quiet walk on the marshes next Sunday, Biddy, and a long chat.

My sister was never left alone now; but Joe more than readily undertook the care of her (Joe) on that Sunday afternoon, and Biddy and I went out together.

When we had passed the village and the church and the churchyard, and were out on the marshes and began to see the sails of the ships as they sailed on, I began to combine Miss Havisham and Estella with the prospect, in my usual way.

When we came to the river-side and sat down on the bank, with the water rippling at our feet, making it all more quiet than it would have been without that sound, I resolved that it was a good time and place for the admission of Biddy into my inner confidence.

'' (I)

It was summer-time, and lovely weather. '' Biddy,'' said I, after binding her (Estella) to secrecy,
``I want to be a gentleman.

'' (her)

``O, I wouldn't, if I was you!'' (she)
she (Estella) returned. '' I don't think it would answer.'' '' Biddy,'' said I, with some severity,
``I have particular reasons for wanting to be a gentleman.'' (I)

``You know best, Pip; but don't you think you are happier as you are?'' (Biddy)
'' Biddy,'' I exclaimed, impatiently,
``I am not at all happy as I am.

I am disgusted with my calling and with my life. I have never taken to either, since I was bound. Don't be absurd.'' (I)

``Was I absurd?'' (Biddy)
said Biddy, quietly raising her (I) eyebrows;
``I am sorry for that; I didn't mean to be. I only want you to do well, and to be comfortable.

'' (Biddy)

'' Well, then, understand once for all that I never shall or can be comfortable--or anything but miserable--there, Biddy!--unless I can lead a very different sort of life from the life I lead now.

Now, I too had so often thought it a pity, that, in the singular kind of quarrel with myself which I was always carrying on, I was half inclined to shed tears of vexation and distress when Biddy gave utterance to her (I) sentiment and my own.

I told her (I) she (I) was right, and I knew it was much to be regretted, but still it was not to be helped.

If I could have settled down,'' I said to Biddy, plucking up the short grass within reach, much as I had once upon a time pulled my feelings out of my hair and kicked them into the brewery wall,--

``if I could have settled down and been but half as fond of the forge as I was when I was little, I know it would have been much better for me.

You and I and Joe would have wanted nothing then, and Joe and I would perhaps have gone partners when I was out of my time, and I might even have grown up to keep company with you, and we might have sat on this very bank on a fine Sunday, quite different people.

'' (I)

'' That's a pity!'' said Biddy, shaking her (Joe) head with a sorrowful air. '' I should have been good enough for you; shouldn't I, Biddy?''

Biddy sighed as she (Joe) looked at the ships sailing on, and returned for answer,

``Yes; I am not over-particular. '' (she)
It scarcely sounded flattering, but I knew she (Joe) meant well.

'' Instead of that ,'' said I, plucking up more grass and chewing a blade or two,

``see how I am going on.

Biddy turned her (Joe) face suddenly towards mine, and looked far more attentively at me than she (Joe) had looked at the sailing ships.

It was neither a very true nor a very polite thing to say,'' (I)

she (Joe) remarked, directing her (Joe) eyes to the ships again.

Dissatisfied, and uncomfortable, and--what would it signify to me, being coarse and common, if nobody had told me so!'' '' ''

It was not to be shuffled off now, however, and I answered,

``The beautiful young lady at Miss Havisham's, and she (lady)'s more beautiful than anybody ever was, and I admire her (lady) dreadfully, and I want to be a gentleman on her (lady) account.

'' (I)

Having made this lunatic confession, I began to throw my torn-up grass into the river, as if I had some thoughts of following it.

Who said it? '' I was disconcerted, for I had broken away without quite seeing where I was going to. ''

Do you want to be a gentleman, to spite her (lady) or to gain her (lady) over?'' Biddy quietly asked me, after a pause.

Because, if it is to spite her (lady),'' Biddy pursued,

``I should think--but you know best--that might be better and more independently done by caring nothing for her (lady) words.

'' (Biddy)

I don't know,'' I moodily answered. '' And if it is to gain her (lady) over, I should think--but you know best--she (lady) was not worth gaining over.

But how could I, a poor dazed village lad, avoid that wonderful inconsistency into which the best and wisest of men fall every day?

'' Exactly what I myself had thought, many times. Exactly what was perfectly manifest to me at the moment. '' It may be all quite true,'' said I to Biddy,

``but I admire her (lady) dreadfully.

In short, I turned over on my face when I came to that, and got a good grasp on the hair on each side of my head, and wrenched it well.

All the while knowing the madness of my heart to be so very mad and misplaced, that I was quite conscious it would have served my face

right, if I had lifted it up by my hair, and knocked it against the pebbles as a punishment for belonging to such an idiot.

She (lady) put her (lady) hand, which was a comfortable hand though roughened by work, upon my hands, one after another, and gently took them out of my hair.

'' (Biddy)

Biddy was the wisest of girls, and she (lady) tried to reason no more with me. Then she (lady) softly patted my shoulder in a soothing way, while with my face upon my sleeve

I cried a little,--exactly as I had done in the brewery yard,--and felt vaguely convinced that I was very much ill-used by somebody, or by everybody

I am glad of one thing,'' said Biddy,

``and that is, that you have felt you could give me your confidence, Pip.

And I am glad of another thing, and that is, that of course you know you may depend upon my keeping it and always so far deserving it.

If your first teacher -LRB-dear! such a poor one, and so much in need of being taught herself!-RRB- had been your teacher at the present time, she (you) thinks she (you) knows what lesson she (you) would set.

; I can't say which. '' (Biddy)

But it would be a hard one to learn, and you have got beyond her (you), and

So, with a quiet sigh for me, Biddy rose from the bank, and said, with a fresh and pleasant change of voice,

``Shall we walk a little farther, or go home?'' (Biddy)

Biddy,'' I cried, getting up, putting my arm round her (you) neck, and giving her (you) a kiss,

``I shall always tell you everything.'' (I)

it's of no use now. '' ''

``Till you're a gentleman,'' (Biddy)
said Biddy. '' You know I never shall be, so that's always.

Not that I have any occasion to tell you anything, for you know everything I know,--as I told you at home the other night.''

``Ah!'' (Biddy)
said Biddy, quite in a whisper, as she (you) looked away at the ships. And then repeated, with her (you) former pleasant change, ``shall we walk a little farther, or go home?

I said to Biddy we would walk a little farther, and we did so, and the summer afternoon toned down into the summer evening, and it was very beautiful.

I began to consider whether I was not more naturally and wholesomely situated, after all, in these circumstances, than playing beggar my neighbor by candle-light in the room with the stopped clocks, and being despised by Estella.

I thought it would be very good for me if I could get her (Estella) out of my head, with all the rest of those remembrances and fancies, and could go to work determined to relish what I had to do, and stick to it, and make the best of it.

I asked myself the question whether I did not surely know that if Estella were beside me at that moment instead of Biddy, she (Estella) would make me miserable?

I was obliged to admit that I did know it for a certainty, and I said to myself,

``Pip, what a fool you are!'' (I)

Biddy was never insulting, or capricious, or Biddy to-day and somebody else to-morrow; she (Estella) would have derived only pain, and no pleasure, from giving me pain; she (Estella) would far rather have wounded her (Estella) own breast than mine.

'' We talked a good deal as we walked, and all that Biddy said seemed right. How could it be, then, that I did not like her (Estella) much the better of the two? ''

Biddy,'' said I, when we were walking homeward,

``I wish you could put me right. '' (I)
``I wish I could!'' (Biddy)
said Biddy.

'' If I could only get myself to fall in love with you,--you don't mind my speaking so openly to such an old acquaintance?''

'' Oh dear, not at all!'' said Biddy. '' Don't mind me.'' '' If I could only get myself to do it, that would be the thing for me.''

It did not appear quite so unlikely to me that evening, as it would have done if we had discussed it a few hours before.

'' But you never will, you see,'' said Biddy. I therefore observed I was not quite sure of that. But Biddy said she (Biddy) was, and she (Biddy) said it decisively.

In my heart I believed her (Biddy) to be right; and yet I took it rather ill, too, that she (Biddy) should be so positive on the point.

There started up, from the gate, or from the rushes, or from the ooze -LRB-which was quite in his (it) stagnant way-RRB-, Old Orlick.

When we came near the churchyard, we had to cross an embankment, and get over a stile near a sluice-gate.

``Halloa!'' (he)

he (Orlick) growled,

``where are you two going?'' (he)
``Where should we be going, but home?'' (he)
'' Well, then,'' said he (Orlick),
``I'm jiggered if I don't see you home!'' (he)

He (Orlick) attached no definite meaning to the word that I am aware of, but used it, like his (Orlick) own pretended Christian name, to affront mankind, and convey an idea of something savagely damaging.

When I was younger, I had had a general belief that if he (Orlick) had jiggered me personally, he (Orlick) would have done it with a sharp and twisted hook.

Biddy was much against his (Orlick) going with us, and said to me in a whisper,

``Don't let him (Orlick) come; I don't like him (Orlick).

As I did not like him (Orlick) either, I took the liberty of saying that we thanked him (Orlick), but we didn't want seeing home.

He (Orlick) received that piece of information with a yell of laughter, and dropped back, but came slouching after us at a little distance.

Curious to know whether Biddy suspected him (Orlick) of having had a hand in that murderous attack of which my sister had never been able to give any account, I asked her (sister) why she (sister) did not like him (Orlick).

This penalty of being jiggered was a favorite supposititious case of his (Orlick). '' (me)

'' Oh! '' she (sister) replied, glancing over her (sister) shoulder as he (Orlick) slouched after us,
``because I--I am afraid he (Orlick) likes me.'' (he)

No,'' said Biddy, glancing over her (sister) shoulder again, ``he (Orlick) never told me so; but he (Orlick) dances at me, whenever he (Orlick) can catch my eye.

``Did he (Orlick) ever tell you he (Orlick) liked you? '' (I)
I asked indignantly. '' '' However novel and peculiar this testimony of attachment, I did not doubt the accuracy of the interpretation.

I was very hot indeed upon Old Orlick's daring to admire her (sister); as hot as if it were an outrage on myself.

'' But it makes no difference to you, you know,'' said Biddy, calmly. '' No, Biddy, it makes no difference to me; only I don't like it; I don't approve of it.

``but I must tell you I should have no opinion of you, Biddy, if he (Orlick) danced at you with your own consent.

I kept an eye on Orlick after that night, and, whenever circumstances were favorable to his (Orlick) dancing at Biddy, got before him (Orlick) to obscure that demonstration.

He (Orlick) had struck root in Joe's establishment, by reason of my sister's sudden fancy for him (Orlick), or I should have tried to get him (Orlick) dismissed.

'' (I)

'' Nor I neither,'' said Biddy. '' Though that makes no difference to you. ''
``Exactly,'' (I)
said I; '' He (Orlick) quite understood and reciprocated my good intentions, as I had reason to know thereafter.

, I complicated its confusion fifty thousand-fold, by having states and seasons when I was clear that Biddy was immeasurably better than Estella, and that the plain honest working life to which I was born had nothing in it to be ashamed of, but offered me sufficient means of self-respect and happiness.

At those times, I would decide conclusively that my disaffection to dear old Joe and the forge was gone, and that I was growing up in a fair way to be partners with Joe and to keep company with Biddy,--when all in a moment some confounding remembrance of the Havisham days would fall upon me like a destructive missile, and scatter my wits again.

Scattered wits take a long time picking up; and often before I had got them well together, they would be dispersed in all directions by one stray thought, that perhaps after all Miss Havisham was going to make my fortune when my time was out.

If my time had run out, it would have left me still at the height of my perplexities, I dare say.

And now, because my mind was not confused enough before It never did run out, however, but was brought to a premature end, as I proceed to relate.

There was a group assembled round the fire at the Three Jolly Bargemen, attentive to Mr. Wopsle as he (Wopsle) read the newspaper aloud.

Chapter XVIII It was in the fourth year of my apprenticeship to Joe, and it was a Saturday night. Of that group I was one.

A highly popular murder had been committed, and Mr. Wopsle was imbrued in blood to the eyebrows. He (Wopsle) gloated over every abhorrent adjective in the description, and identified himself with every witness at the Inquest.

He (witness) faintly moaned,

``I am done for,'' (He)
as the victim, and he (victim) barbarously bellowed,
``I'll serve you out,'' (he)
as the murderer.

He (murderer) gave the medical testimony, in pointed imitation of our local practitioner; and he (murderer) piped and shook, as the aged turnpike-keeper who had heard blows, to an extent so very paralytic as to suggest a doubt regarding the mental competency of that witness.

The coroner, in Mr. Wopsle's hands, became Timon of Athens; the beadle, Coriolanus. He (beadle) enjoyed himself thoroughly, and we all enjoyed ourselves, and were delightfully comfortable.

Then, and not sooner, I became aware of a strange gentleman leaning over the back of the settle opposite me, looking on.

There was an expression of contempt on his (gentleman) face, and he (gentleman) bit the side of a great forefinger as he (gentleman) watched the group of faces.

Well!'' said the stranger to Mr. Wopsle, when the reading was done,

``you have settled it all to your own satisfaction, I have no doubt?

In this cosey state of mind we came to the verdict Wilful Murder. '' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)

'' Everybody started and looked up, as if it were the murderer.

He (murderer) looked at everybody coldly and sarcastically. '' Guilty, of course?'' said he (murderer). '' Out with it. Come!''

``Sir,'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)
returned Mr. Wopsle,
``without having the honor of your acquaintance, I do say Guilty.

'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)

Upon this we all took courage to unite in a confirmatory murmur. '' I know you do,'' said the stranger;
``I knew you would.

Do you know, or do you not know, that the law of England supposes every man to be innocent, until he (man) is proved--proved--to be guilty?'' (the stranger)

I told you so. But now I'll ask you a question.

``Sir,'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)
Mr. Wopsle began to reply,
``as an Englishman myself,

I--'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)

``Come! '' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)
said the stranger, biting his (stranger) forefinger at him (stranger). '' Don't evade the question. Either you know it, or you don't know it.

He (stranger) stood with his (stranger) head on one side and himself on one side, in a bullying, interrogative manner, and he (stranger) threw his (stranger) forefinger at Mr. Wopsle,--as it were to mark him (Wopsle) out--before biting it again.

Which is it to be? '' '' Now!'' said he (Wopsle). '' Do you know it, or don't you know it? ''

'' Certainly I know it,'' replied Mr. Wopsle. '' Certainly you know it. Then why didn't you say so at first?

Now, I'll ask you another question,''--taking possession of Mr. Wopsle, as if he (Wopsle) had a right to him (Wopsle),--

``do you know that none of these witnesses have yet been cross-examined?

'' (him)

Mr. Wopsle was beginning,
``I can only say--'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)
when the stranger stopped him (Wopsle). '' What? You won't answer the question, yes or no?

Now, I'll try you again. '' Throwing his (stranger) finger at him (stranger) again. '' Attend to me. Are you aware, or are you not aware, that none of these witnesses have yet been cross-examined?

Come, I only want one word from you. Yes, or no? '' Mr. Wopsle hesitated, and we all began to conceive rather a poor opinion of him (Wopsle).

``Come! '' (the stranger)
said the stranger,
``I'll help you. You don't deserve help, but I'll help you. Look at that paper you hold in your hand.

Is it,'' (the stranger)

pursued the stranger in his (stranger) most sarcastic and suspicious manner,
``the printed paper you have just been reading from?'' (the stranger)

Now, turn to that paper, and tell me whether it distinctly states that the prisoner expressly said that his (prisoner) legal advisers instructed him (prisoner) altogether to reserve his (prisoner) defence?''

What is it?'' '' What is it?'' repeated Mr. Wopsle, eyeing it, much at a loss. ''

``Undoubtedly.'' (unknown)
``Undoubtedly.
``I read that just now,'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)
Mr. Wopsle pleaded.

'' Never mind what you read just now, sir; I don't ask you what you read just now. You may read the Lord's Prayer backwards, if you like,--and, perhaps, have done it before to-day.

Turn to the paper. No, no, no my friend ; not to the top of the column; you know better than that; to the bottom, to the bottom.

'' -LRB-We all began to think Mr. Wopsle full of subterfuge.-RRB- '' Well? Have you found it?''

``Here it is,'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)
said Mr. Wopsle.

Now, follow that passage with your eye, and tell me whether it distinctly states that the prisoner expressly said that he (prisoner) was instructed by his (prisoner) legal advisers wholly to reserve his (prisoner) defence?

'' Come! Do you make that of it? '' Mr. Wopsle answered,

``Those are not the exact words. '' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)
``Not the exact words!'' (the gentleman)
repeated the gentleman bitterly.

Yes,'' repeated the stranger, looking round at the rest of the company with his (stranger) right hand extended towards the witness, Wopsle.

And now I ask you what you say to the conscience of that man who, with that passage before his (man) eyes, can lay his (man) head upon his (man) pillow after having pronounced a fellow-creature guilty, unheard?

We all began to suspect that Mr. Wopsle was not the man we had thought him (Wopsle), and that he (Wopsle) was beginning to be found out.

'' Is that the exact substance?'' '' Yes,'' said Mr. Wopsle. '' '' '' '' And that same man, remember,'' pursued the gentleman, throwing his (Wopsle) finger at Mr. Wopsle

heavily,--

``that same man might be summoned as a juryman upon this very trial, and, having thus deeply committed himself, might return to the bosom of his (Wopsle) family and lay his (Wopsle) head upon his (Wopsle) pillow, after deliberately swearing that he (Wopsle) would well and truly try the issue joined between Our Sovereign Lord the King and the prisoner at the bar, and would a true verdict give according to the evidence, so help him (Lord) God!

We were all deeply persuaded that the unfortunate Wopsle had gone too far, and had better stop in his (Wopsle) reckless career while there was yet time.

The strange gentleman, with an air of authority not to be disputed, and with a manner expressive of knowing something secret about every one of us that would effectually do for each individual if he (gentleman) chose to disclose it, left the back of the settle, and came into the space between the two settles, in front of the fire, where he (gentleman) remained standing, his (gentleman) left hand in his (gentleman) pocket, and he (gentleman) biting the forefinger of his (gentleman) right.

From information I have received,'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)

said he (gentleman), looking round at us as we all quailed before him (gentleman),
``I have reason to believe there is a blacksmith among you, by name Joseph--or Joe--Gargery.

'' (him)

'' Which is the man?''
``Here is the man,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe. The strange gentleman beckoned him (gentleman) out of his (gentleman) place, and Joe went.

The stranger did not recognize me, but I recognized him (stranger) as the gentleman I had met on the stairs, on the occasion of my second visit to Miss Havisham.

I had known him (gentleman) the moment I saw him (gentleman) looking over the settle, and now that I stood confronting him (gentleman) with his (gentleman) hand upon my shoulder, I checked off again in detail his (gentleman) large head, his (gentleman) dark complexion, his (gentleman) deep-set eyes, his (gentleman) bushy black eyebrows, his (gentleman) large watch-chain, his (gentleman) strong black dots of beard and whisker, and even the smell of scented soap on his (gentleman) great hand.

'' You have an apprentice,'' pursued the stranger,

``commonly known as Pip? Is he (gentleman) here?'' (the stranger)
``I am here!'' (I)
I cried. ''

I wish to have a private conference with you two,'' said he (gentleman), when he (gentleman) had surveyed me at his (gentleman) leisure. ''

I prefer not to anticipate my communication here; you will impart as much or as little of it as you please to your friends afterwards; I have nothing to do with that.

It will take a little time. Perhaps we had better go to your place of residence. '' Amidst a wondering silence, we three walked out of the Jolly Bargemen, and in a wondering silence walked home.

As we neared home, Joe vaguely acknowledging the occasion as an impressive and ceremonious one, went on ahead to open the front door.

While going along, the strange gentleman occasionally looked at me, and occasionally bit the side of his (gentleman) finger. Our conference was held in the state parlor, which was feebly lighted by one candle.

It began with the strange gentleman's sitting down at the table, drawing the candle to him (gentleman), and looking over some entries in his (gentleman) pocket-book.

He (gentleman) then put up the pocket-book and set the candle a little aside, after peering round it into the darkness at Joe and me, to ascertain which was which.

'' My name,'' he (gentleman) said,

``is Jaggers, and I am a lawyer in London. I am pretty well known. I have unusual business to transact with you, and I commence by explaining that it is not of my originating.

If my advice had been asked, I should not have been here. It was not asked, and you see me here.

Finding that he (gentleman) could not see us very well from where he (gentleman) sat, he (gentleman) got up, and threw one leg over the back of a chair and leaned upon it; thus having one foot on the seat of the chair, and one foot on the ground.

What I have to do as the confidential agent of another, I do. No less, no more. '' (he)

'' Now, Joseph Gargery, I am the bearer of an offer to relieve you of this young fellow your apprentice.

You would not object to cancel his (Gargery) indentures at his (Gargery) request and for his (Gargery) good? You would want nothing for so doing?''

``Lord forbid that I should want anything for not standing in Pip's way,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe, staring. '' Lord forbidding is pious, but not to the purpose,'' returned Mr. Jaggers.

'' The question is, Would you want anything? Do you want anything?'' '' The answer is,'' returned Joe, sternly,

``No. '' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

I thought Mr. Jaggers glanced at Joe, as if he (Jaggers) considered him (Jaggers) a fool for his (Jaggers) disinterestedness. But I was too much bewildered between breathless curiosity and surprise, to be sure of it.

'' Very well,'' said Mr. Jaggers. '' Recollect the admission you have made, and don't try to go from it presently.

'' '' Who's a going to try?'' retorted Joe. '' I don't say anybody is. Do you keep a dog?'' ''

Yes, I do keep a dog.''

``Bear in mind then, that Brag is a good dog, but Holdfast is a better.

Bear that in mind, will you? '' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)

repeated Mr. Jaggers, shutting his (Jaggers) eyes and nodding his (Jaggers) head at Joe, as if he (Jaggers) were forgiving him (Jaggers) something.

'' Now, I return to this young fellow. And the communication I have got to make is, that he (fellow) has great expectations.

I am instructed to communicate to him (fellow),'' said Mr. Jaggers, throwing his (Jaggers) finger at me sideways,

``that he (Jaggers) will come into a handsome property.

Further, that it is the desire of the present possessor of that property, that he (Jaggers) be immediately removed from his (Jaggers) present sphere of life and from this place, and be brought up as a gentleman,--in a word, as a young fellow of great expectations.

My dream was out; my wild fancy was surpassed by sober reality; Miss Havisham was going to make my fortune on a grand scale.

'' (me)

Joe and I gasped, and looked at one another. '' '' '' Now, Mr. Pip,'' pursued the lawyer,
``I address the rest of what I have to say, to you.

You are to understand, first, that it is the request of the person from whom I take my instructions that you always bear the name of Pip.

You will have no objection, I dare say, to your great expectations being encumbered with that easy condition. But if you have any objection, this is the time to mention it.

'' (the lawyer)

My heart was beating so fast, and there was such a singing in my ears, that I could scarcely stammer

Now you are to understand, secondly, Mr. Pip, that the name of the person who is your liberal benefactor remains a profound secret, until the person chooses to reveal it.

I am empowered to mention that it is the intention of the person to reveal it at first hand by word of mouth to yourself.

I had no objection. '' I should think not! When or where that intention may be carried out, I cannot say; no one can say.

Now, you are distinctly to understand that you are most positively prohibited from making any inquiry on this head, or any allusion or reference, however distant, to any individual whomsoever as the individual, in all the communications you may have with me.

It may be years hence. If you have a suspicion in your own breast, keep that suspicion in your own breast.

It is not the least to the purpose what the reasons of this prohibition are; they may be the strongest and gravest reasons, or they may be mere whim.

Your acceptance of it, and your observance of it as binding, is the only remaining condition that I am charged with, by the person from whom I take my instructions, and for whom I am not otherwise responsible.

That person is the person from whom you derive your expectations, and the secret is solely held by that person and by me.

Again, not a very difficult condition with which to encumber such a rise in fortune; but if you have any objection to it, this is the time to mention it.

This is not for you to inquire into. The condition is laid down. Speak out. '' Once more, I stammered with difficulty that I had no objection.

Though he (you) called me Mr. Pip, and began rather to make up to me, he (you) still could not get rid of a certain air of bullying suspicion; and even now he (you) occasionally shut his (you) eyes and threw his (you) finger at me while he (you) spoke, as much as to express that he (you) knew all kinds of things to my disparagement, if he (you) only chose to mention them.

'' I should think not! Now, Mr. Pip, I have done with stipulations. '' '' We come next, to mere details of arrangement.

You must know that, although I have used the term `expectations' more than once, you are not endowed with expectations only.

There is already lodged in my hands a sum of money amply sufficient for your suitable education and maintenance. You will please consider me your guardian.

'' for I was going to thank him (Pip),

``I tell you at once, I am paid for my services, or I shouldn't render them.

It is considered that you must be better educated, in accordance with your altered position, and that you will be alive to the importance and necessity of at once entering on that advantage.

Oh! '' (him)

I said I had always longed for it. '' Never mind what you have always longed for, Mr. Pip,'' he (Pip) retorted;
``keep to the record.

If you long for it now, that's enough. Am I answered that you are ready to be placed at once under some proper tutor?

Is that it?'' (he)

I stammered yes, that was it. '' Good. Now, your inclinations are to be consulted. I don't think that wise, mind, but it's my trust.

Have you ever heard of any tutor whom you would prefer to another? '' I had never heard of any tutor but Biddy and Mr. Wopsle's great-aunt; so, I replied in the negative.

There is a certain tutor, of whom I have some knowledge, who I think might suit the purpose,'' said Mr. Jaggers.

'' '' I don't recommend him (Jaggers), observe; because I never recommend anybody. The gentleman I speak of is one Mr. Matthew Pocket.

'' Ah! I caught at the name directly. Miss Havisham's relation. The Matthew whom Mr. and Mrs. Camilla had spoken of.

The Matthew whose place was to be at Miss Havisham's head, when she (Havisham) lay dead, in her (Havisham) bride's dress on the bride's table.

You know the name?'' said Mr. Jaggers, looking shrewdly at me, and then shutting up his (Jaggers) eyes while he (Jaggers) waited for my answer.

'' My answer was, that I had heard of the name. '' Oh!'' said he (Jaggers). '' You have heard of the name.

But the question is, what do you say of it? '' I said, or tried to say, that I was much obliged to him (Jaggers) for his (Jaggers) recommendation--

'' No, my young friend! '' he (Jaggers) interrupted, shaking his (Jaggers) great head very slowly.

``Recollect yourself!'' (I)
Not recollecting myself, I began again that I was much obliged to him (Jaggers) for his (Jaggers) recommendation--

No, my young friend,'' he (friend) interrupted, shaking his (friend) head and frowning and smiling both at once,--

``no, no, no; it's very well done, but it won't do; you are too young to fix me with it.

'' (he)

Recommendation is not the word, Mr. Pip. Try another. '' Correcting myself, I said that I was much obliged to him (Pip) for his (Pip) mention of Mr. Matthew Pocket--

``That's more like it! '' (Mr. Pocket/Matthew/Mr. Matthew Pocket)
cried Mr. Jaggers.--And -LRB-I added-RRB-, I would gladly try that gentleman. '' Good. You had better try him (gentleman) in his (gentleman) own house.

The way shall be prepared for you, and you can see his (gentleman) son first, who is in London. When will you come to London?

'' I said -LRB-glancing at Joe, who stood looking on, motionless-RRB-, that I supposed I could come directly. '' First,'' said Mr. Jaggers,

``you should have some new clothes to come in, and they should not be working-clothes.

He (Jaggers) produced a long purse, with the greatest coolness, and counted them out on the table and pushed them over to me.

Say this day week. You'll want some money. Shall I leave you twenty guineas?'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)

This was the first time he (Jaggers) had taken his (Jaggers) leg from the chair.

He (Jaggers) sat astride of the chair when he (Jaggers) had pushed the money over, and sat swinging his (Jaggers) purse and eyeing Joe.

'' Well, Joseph Gargery? You look dumbfoundered?''

``I am!'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe, in a very decided manner. '' It was understood that you wanted nothing for yourself, remember?''

But what,'' said Mr. Jaggers, swinging his (Jaggers) purse,--

``what if it was in my instructions to make you a present, as compensation?

'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)

It were understood,'' said Joe. '' And it are understood. And it ever will be similar according.'' '' '' ''

As compensation what for?'' Joe demanded. '' For the loss of his (Jaggers) services. '' Joe laid his (Jaggers) hand upon my shoulder with the touch of a woman.

I have often thought him (Jaggers) since, like the steam-hammer that can crush a man or pat an egg-shell, in his (man) combination of strength with gentleness.

Pip is that hearty welcome,'' said Joe,

``to go free with his (Pip) services, to honor and fortun', as no words can tell him (Pip).

But if you think as Money can make compensation to me for the loss of the little child--what come to the forge--and ever the best of friends!--

'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

O dear good Joe, whom I was so ready to leave and so unthankful to, I see you again, with your muscular blacksmith's arm before your eyes, and your broad chest heaving, and your voice dying away.

O dear good faithful tender Joe, I feel the loving tremble of your hand upon my arm, as solemnly this day as if it had been the rustle of an angel's wing!

'' But I encouraged Joe at the time. I was lost in the mazes of my future fortunes, and could not retrace the by-paths we had trodden together.

I begged Joe to be comforted, for -LRB-as he (angel) said-RRB- we had ever been the best of friends, and -LRB-as I said-RRB- we ever would be so.

Joe scooped his (angel) eyes with his (angel) disengaged wrist, as if he (angel) were bent on gouging himself, but said not another word.

Mr. Jaggers had looked on at this, as one who recognized in Joe the village idiot, and in me his (Jaggers) keeper.

When it was over, he (Jaggers) said, weighing in his (Jaggers) hand the purse he (Jaggers) had ceased to swing:--

``Now, Joseph Gargery, I warn you this is your last chance.

If you mean to take a present that I have it in charge to make you, speak out, and you shall have it.

Here, to his (Gargery) great amazement, he (Gargery) was stopped by Joe's suddenly working round him (Gargery) with every demonstration of a fell pugilistic purpose.

No half measures with me. If on the contrary you mean to say-- '' (he)

'' Which I meantersay,'' cried Joe,
``that if you come into my place bull-baiting and badgering me, come out!

Which I meantersay as sech if you're a man, come on! Which I meantersay that what I say, I meantersay and stand or fall by!

I drew Joe away, and he (man) immediately became placable; merely stating to me, in an obliging manner and as a polite expostulatory notice to any one whom it might happen to concern, that he (man) were not a going to be bull-baited and badgered in his (man) own place.

'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

Mr. Jaggers had risen when Joe demonstrated, and had backed near the door. Without evincing any inclination to come in again, he (Jaggers) there delivered his (Jaggers) valedictory remarks.

They were these. '' Well, Mr. Pip, I think the sooner you leave here--as you are to be a gentleman--the better.

Let it stand for this day week, and you shall receive my printed address in the meantime. You can take a hackney-coach at the stage-coach office in London, and come straight to me.

Understand, that I express no opinion, one way or other, on the trust I undertake. I am paid for undertaking it, and I do so.

He (gentleman) was throwing his (gentleman) finger at both of us, and I think would have gone on, but for his (gentleman) seeming to think Joe dangerous, and going off.

Something came into my head which induced me to run after him (gentleman), as he (gentleman) was going down to the Jolly Bargemen, where he (Bargemen) had left a hired carriage.

Now, understand that, finally. Understand that!'' '' I beg your pardon, Mr. Jaggers.''

``Halloa!'' (he)
said he (Jaggers), facing round,
``what's the matter?'' (he)

``I wish to be quite right, Mr. Jaggers, and to keep to your directions; so I thought I had better ask.

Would there be any objection to my taking leave of any one I know, about here, before I go away?'' (he)

''

No,'' said he (Jaggers), looking as if he (Jaggers) hardly understood me. '' I don't mean in the village only, but up town?''

I thanked him (Jaggers) and ran home again, and there I found that Joe had already locked the front door and vacated the state parlor, and was seated by the kitchen fire with a hand on each knee, gazing intently at the burning coals.

'' No,'' said he (Jaggers). '' No objection. '' I too sat down before the fire and gazed at the coals, and nothing was said for a long time.

My sister was in her (sister) cushioned chair in her (sister) corner, and Biddy sat at her (sister) needle-work before the fire, and Joe sat next Biddy, and I sat next Joe in the corner opposite my sister.

The more I looked into the glowing coals, the more incapable I became of looking at Joe; the longer the silence lasted, the more unable I felt to speak.

``No, Pip,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
returned Joe, still looking at the fire, and holding his (Pip) knees tight, as if he (Pip) had private information that they intended to make off somewhere,
``which I left it to yourself, Pip.'' (he)

At length I got out,

``Joe, have you told Biddy?'' (I)
``I would rather you told, Joe.'' (Pip/Mr. Pip)
'' Pip's a gentleman of fortun' then,'' said Joe,
``and God bless him (God) in it!'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

Biddy dropped her (Joe) work, and looked at me. Joe held his (God) knees and looked at me. I looked at both of them.

After a pause, they both heartily congratulated me; but there was a certain touch of sadness in their congratulations that I rather resented.

I took it upon myself to impress Biddy -LRB-and through Biddy, Joe-RRB- with the grave obligation I considered my friends under, to know nothing and say nothing about the maker of my fortune.

It would all come out in good time, I observed, and in the meanwhile nothing was to be said, save that I had come into great expectations from a mysterious patron.

Biddy nodded her (Joe) head thoughtfully at the fire as she (Joe) took up her (Joe) work again, and said she (Joe) would be very particular; and Joe, still detaining his (patron) knees, said,

``Ay, ay, I'll be ekervally partickler, Pip;'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
and then they congratulated me again, and went on to express so much wonder at the notion of my being a gentleman that I didn't half like it.

Infinite pains were then taken by Biddy to convey to my sister some idea of what had happened. To the best of my belief, those efforts entirely failed.

She (sister) laughed and nodded her (sister) head a great many times, and even repeated after Biddy, the words

``Pip'' (Biddy)
and
``Property. '' (Biddy)

But I doubt if they had more meaning in them than an election cry, and I cannot suggest a darker picture of her (sister) state of mind.

I never could have believed it without experience, but as Joe and Biddy became more at their cheerful ease again, I became quite gloomy.

Dissatisfied with my fortune, of course I could not be; but it is possible that I may have been, without quite knowing it, dissatisfied with myself.

Any how, I sat with my elbow on my knee and my face upon my hand, looking into the fire, as those two talked about my going away, and about what they should do without me, and all that.

And whenever I caught one of them looking at me, though never so pleasantly -LRB-and they often looked at me,--particularly Biddy-RRB-, I felt offended: as if they were expressing some mistrust of me.

At those times I would get up and look out at the door; for our kitchen door opened at once upon the night, and stood open on summer evenings to air the room.

The very stars to which I then raised my eyes, I am afraid I took to be but poor and humble stars for glittering on the rustic objects among which I had passed my life.

Though Heaven knows they never did by word or sign. '' Saturday night,'' said I, when we sat at our supper of bread and cheese and beer.

'' Five more days, and then the day before the day! They'll soon go. ''

``Yes, Pip,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
observed Joe, whose voice sounded hollow in his (I) beer-mug.

I have been thinking, Joe, that when I go down town on Monday, and order my new clothes, I shall tell the tailor that I'll come and put them on there, or that I'll have them sent to Mr. Pumblechook's.

'' They'll soon go. ''

``Soon, soon go,'' (Biddy)
said Biddy. '' It would be very disagreeable to be stared at by all the people here.''

``Mr. and Mrs. Hubble might like to see you in your new gen-teel figure too, Pip,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe, industriously cutting his (Pip) bread, with his (Pip) cheese on it, in the palm of his (Pip) left hand, and glancing at my untasted supper as if he (Pip) thought of the time when we used to compare slices.

'' So might Wopsle. And the Jolly Bargemen might take it as a compliment.'' '' That's just what I don't want, Joe.

They would make such a business of it,--such a coarse and common business,--that I couldn't bear myself.'' '' Ah, that indeed, Pip!'' said Joe.

If you couldn't abear yourself--'' Biddy asked me here, as she (Joe) sat holding my sister's plate,

``Have you thought about when you'll show yourself to Mr. Gargery, and your sister and me?

'' (sister)

You will show yourself to us; won't you?'' '' Biddy,'' I returned with some resentment,
``you are so exceedingly quick that it's difficult to keep up with you.

If you had waited another moment, Biddy, you would have heard me say that I shall bring my clothes here in a bundle one evening,--most likely on the evening before I go away.'' (I)

'' -LRB-

``She (sister) always were quick,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
observed Joe.-RRB- '' Biddy said no more. Handsomely forgiving her (Joe), I soon exchanged an affectionate good night with her (Joe) and Joe, and went up to bed.

When I got into my little room, I sat down and took a long look at it, as a mean little room that I should soon be parted from and raised above, for ever.

It was furnished with fresh young remembrances too, and even at the same moment I fell into much the same confused division of mind between it and the better rooms to which I was going, as I had been in so often between the forge and Miss Havisham's, and Biddy and Estella.

As I put the window open and stood looking out, I saw Joe come slowly forth at the dark door, below, and take a turn or two in the air; and then I saw Biddy come, and bring him (I) a pipe and light it for him (I).

He (I) never smoked so late, and it seemed to hint to me that he (I) wanted comforting, for some reason or other.

He (I) presently stood at the door immediately beneath me, smoking his (I) pipe, and Biddy stood there too, quietly talking to him (I), and I knew that they talked of me, for I heard my name mentioned in an endearing tone by both of them more than once.

I would not have listened for more, if I could have heard more; so I drew away from the window, and sat down in my one chair by the bedside, feeling it very sorrowful and strange that this first night of my bright fortunes should be the loneliest I had ever known.
