Looking towards the open window, I saw light wreaths from Joe's pipe floating there, and I fancied it was like a blessing from Joe,--not obtruded on me or paraded before me, but pervading the air we shared together.

I put my light out, and crept into bed; and it was an uneasy bed now, and I never slept the old sound sleep in it any more.

Chapter XIX Morning made a considerable difference in my general prospect of Life, and brightened it so much that it scarcely seemed the same.

What lay heaviest on my mind was, the consideration that six days intervened between me and the day of departure; for I could not divest myself of a misgiving that something might happen to London in the meanwhile, and that, when I got there, it would be either greatly deteriorated or clean gone.

Joe and Biddy were very sympathetic and pleasant when I spoke of our approaching separation; but they only referred to it when I did.

After breakfast, Joe brought out my indentures from the press in the best parlor, and we put them in the fire, and I felt that I was free.

With all the novelty of my emancipation on me, I went to church with Joe, and thought perhaps the clergyman wouldn't have read that about the rich man and the kingdom of Heaven, if he (man) had known all.

After our early dinner, I strolled out alone, purposing to finish off the marshes at once, and get them done with.

As I passed the church, I felt -LRB-as I had felt during service in the morning-RRB- a sublime compassion for the poor creatures who were destined to go there, Sunday after Sunday, all their lives through, and to lie obscurely at last among the low green mounds.

I promised myself that I would do something for them one of these days, and formed a plan in outline for bestowing a dinner of roast-beef and plum-pudding, a pint of ale, and a gallon of condescension, upon everybody in the village.

If I had often thought before, with something allied to shame, of my companionship with the fugitive whom I had once seen limping among those graves, what were my thoughts on this Sunday, when the place recalled the wretch, ragged and shivering, with his (myself) felon iron and badge!

My comfort was, that it happened a long time ago, and that he (myself) had doubtless been transported a long way off, and that he (myself) was dead to me, and might be veritably dead into the bargain.

The sun had been shining brightly all day on the roof of my attic, and the room was warm. No more low, wet grounds, no more dikes and sluices, no more of these grazing cattle,--though

they seemed, in their dull manner, to wear a more respectful air now, and to face round, in order that they might stare as long as possible at the possessor of such great expectations,--farewell, monotonous acquaintances of my childhood, henceforth I was for London and greatness; not for smith's work in general, and for you!

I made my exultant way to the old Battery, and, lying down there to consider the question whether Miss Havisham intended me for Estella, fell asleep.

When I awoke, I was much surprised to find Joe sitting beside me, smoking his (smith) pipe. He (smith) greeted me with a cheerful smile on my opening my eyes, and said,--

``As being the last time, Pip, I thought I'd foller.'' (me)
'' And Joe, I am very glad you did so.''
``Thankee, Pip.'' (unknown)

``You may be sure, dear Joe,'' (I)
I went on, after we had shaken hands,
``that I shall never forget you.'' (I)
``No, no, Pip!'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe, in a comfortable tone,
``I'm sure of that.

Ay, ay, old chap! Bless you, it were only necessary to get it well round in a man's mind, to be certain on it.

But it took a bit of time to get it well round, the change come so oncommon plump; didn't it? '' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

I should have liked him (man) to have betrayed emotion, or to have said,

``It does you credit, Pip,'' (him)
or something of that sort.

Therefore, I made no remark on Joe's first head; merely saying as to his (Pip) second, that the tidings had indeed come suddenly, but that I had always wanted to be a gentleman, and had often and often speculated on what I would do, if I were one.

Somehow, I was not best pleased with Joe's being so mightily secure of me. '' Have you though?'' said Joe.

``Astonishing!'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

It's a pity now, Joe,'' said I,

``that you did not get on a little more, when we had our lessons here; isn't it?'' (I)

It were always a pity as I was so awful dull; but it's no more of a pity now, than it was--this day twelvemonth--don't you see?

'' '' Well, I don't know,'' returned Joe. '' I'm so awful dull. I'm only master of my own trade. ''

What I had meant was, that when I came into my property and was able to do something for Joe, it would have been much more agreeable if he (master) had been better qualified for a rise in station.

So, when we had walked home and had had tea, I took Biddy into our little garden by the side of the lane, and, after throwing out in a general way for the elevation of her (Joe) spirits, that I should never forget her (Joe), said I had a favor to ask of her (Joe).

He (master) was so perfectly innocent of my meaning, however, that I thought I would mention it to Biddy in preference. ''

And it is, Biddy,'' said I,

``that you will not omit any opportunity of helping Joe on, a little. '' (I)
``How helping him (master) on?

'' (Biddy)

asked Biddy, with a steady sort of glance. '' Well! Joe is a dear good fellow,--in fact , I think he (fellow) is the dearest fellow that ever lived,--but he (fellow) is rather backward in some things.

Although I was looking at Biddy as I spoke, and although she (Joe) opened her (Joe) eyes very wide when I had spoken, she (Joe) did not look at me.

For instance, Biddy, in his (fellow) learning and his (fellow) manners. '' '' O, his (fellow) manners! won't his (fellow) manners do then?'' asked Biddy, plucking a black-currant leaf.

'' My dear Biddy, they do very well here-- ''

``O! they do very well here? '' (Biddy)
interrupted Biddy, looking closely at the leaf in her (Joe) hand.

out,--but if I were to remove Joe into a higher sphere, as I shall hope to remove him (fellow) when I fully come into my property, they would hardly do him (fellow) justice.''

It was such a very provoking question -LRB-for it had never in the most distant manner occurred to me-RRB-, that I said,

``Hear me '' (I)
And don't you think he (fellow) knows that?'' asked Biddy. snappishly,-- '' Biddy, what do you mean? '' Biddy, having rubbed the leaf to pieces between her (Joe)

the smell of a black-currant bush has ever since recalled to me that evening in the little garden by the side of the lane,--said,

``Have you never considered that he (fellow) may be proud?'' (me)

O! there are many kinds of pride,'' said Biddy, looking full at me and shaking her (Joe) head; ``pride is not all of one kind--

hands,--and

``Proud? '' (me)
I repeated, with disdainful emphasis. '' ''
``Well? What are you stopping for?'' (I.)
said I.
``Not all of one kind,'' (I.)
resumed Biddy.

He (fellow) may be too proud to let any one take him (fellow) out of a place that he (fellow) is competent to fill, and fills well and with respect.

To tell you the truth, I think he (fellow) is; though it sounds bold in me to say so, for you must know him (fellow) far better than I do.''

''

``Now, Biddy,'' (I)
said I,
``I am very sorry to see this in you. I did not expect to see this in you.

You are envious, Biddy, and grudging. You are dissatisfied on account of my rise in fortune, and you can't help showing it.'' (I)

'' If you have the heart to think so,'' returned Biddy,

``say so. Say so over and over again, if you have the heart to think so.

If you have the heart to be so, you mean, Biddy,'' (Biddy)

said I, in a virtuous and superior tone;
``don't put it off upon me.

I did intend to ask you to use any little opportunities you might have after I was gone, of improving dear Joe.

'' (I)

'' I am very sorry to see it, and it's a --it's a bad side of human nature. But after this I ask you nothing.

I am extremely sorry to see this in you, Biddy,'' I repeated. '' It's a--it's a bad side of human nature.

``Whether you scold me or approve of me,'' (Biddy)
returned poor Biddy,
``you may equally depend upon my trying to do all that lies in my power, here, at all times.

'' (Biddy)

And whatever opinion you take away of me, shall make no difference in my remembrance of you. Yet a gentleman should not be unjust neither,'' said Biddy, turning away her (I) head.

I again warmly repeated that it was a bad side of human nature -LRB-in which sentiment, waiving its application, I have since seen reason to think I was right-RRB-, and I walked down the little path away from Biddy, and Biddy went into the house, and I went out at the garden gate and took a dejected stroll until supper-time; again feeling it very sorrowful and strange that this, the second night of my bright fortunes, should be as lonely and unsatisfactory as the first.

Putting on the best clothes I had, I went into town as early as I could hope to find the shops open, and presented myself before Mr. Trabb, the tailor, who was having his (Trabb) breakfast in the parlor behind his (Trabb) shop, and who did not think it worth his (Trabb) while to come out to me, but called me into him (Trabb).

But, morning once more brightened my view, and I extended my clemency to Biddy, and we dropped the subject. '' Well!'' said Mr. Trabb, in a hail-fellow-well-met kind of way.

Mr. Trabb had sliced his (Trabb) hot roll into three feather-beds, and was slipping butter in between the blankets, and covering it up.

He (Trabb) was a prosperous old bachelor, and his (Trabb) open window looked into a prosperous little garden and orchard, and there was a prosperous iron safe let into the wall at the side of his (Trabb) fireplace, and I did not doubt that heaps of his (Trabb) prosperity were put away in it in bags.

Mr. Trabb,'' said I, ``it's an unpleasant thing to have to mention, because it looks like boasting; but I have come into a handsome property.

He (Trabb) forgot the butter in bed, got up from the bedside, and wiped his (Trabb) fingers on the tablecloth, exclaiming,

``Lord bless my soul!'' (He)

``I am going up to my guardian in London,'' (I)
said I, casually drawing some guineas out of my pocket and looking at them;
``and I want a fashionable suit of clothes to go in.

'' (I)

How are you, and what can I do for you?'' '' '' A change passed over Mr. Trabb. I wish to pay for them,'' I added--otherwise I thought he (Trabb) might only pretend to make them,
``with ready money.'' (he)

My dear sir,'' said Mr. Trabb, as he (Trabb) respectfully bent his (Trabb) body, opened his (Trabb) arms, and took the liberty of touching me on the outside of each elbow,

``don't hurt me by mentioning that.

'' (me)

May I venture to congratulate you? Would you do me the favor of stepping into the shop? '' Mr. Trabb's boy was the most audacious boy in all that country-side.

He (Trabb) was still sweeping when I came out into the shop with Mr. Trabb, and he (Trabb) knocked the broom against all possible corners and obstacles, to express -LRB-as I understood it-RRB- equality with any blacksmith, alive or dead.

Hold that noise,'' said Mr. Trabb, with the greatest sternness,

``or I'll knock your head off!--Do me the favor to be seated, sir.

Now, this,'' (Trabb/Mr. Trabb)

said Mr. Trabb, taking down a roll of cloth, and tiding it out in a flowing manner over the counter, preparatory to getting his (Trabb) hand under it to show the gloss,
``is a very sweet article.

When I had entered he (Trabb) was sweeping the shop, and he (Trabb) had sweetened his (Trabb) labors by sweeping over me. '' (Trabb/Mr. Trabb)

I can recommend it for your purpose, sir, because it really is extra super.

-LRB-To the boy, and with a dreadfully severe stare; foreseeing the danger of that miscreant's brushing me with it, or making some other sign of familiarity.-RRB-

Mr. Trabb never removed his (Trabb) stern eye from the boy until he (Trabb) had deposited number four on the counter and was at a safe distance again.

But you shall see some others. Give me Number Four, you!'' Then he (Trabb) commanded him (Trabb) to bring number five, and number eight.

And let me have none of your tricks here,'' said Mr. Trabb,

``or you shall repent it, you young scoundrel, the longest day you have to live.

Mr. Trabb then bent over number four, and in a sort of deferential confidence recommended it to me as a light article for summer wear, an article much in vogue among the nobility and gentry, an article that it would ever be an honor to him (gentry) to reflect upon a distinguished fellow-townsman's -LRB-if he (gentry) might claim me for a fellow-townsman-RRB- having worn.

Are you bringing numbers five and eight, you vagabond,'' (Trabb/Mr. Trabb)

said Mr. Trabb to the boy after that, ``or shall I kick you out of the shop and bring them myself?

I selected the materials for a suit, with the assistance of Mr. Trabb's judgment, and re-entered the parlor to be measured.

For although Mr. Trabb had my measure already, and had previously been quite contented with it, he (Trabb) said apologetically that it ``wouldn't do under existing circumstances, sir,--wouldn't do at all.

So, Mr. Trabb measured and calculated me in the parlor, as if I were an estate and he (Trabb) the finest species of surveyor, and gave himself such a world of trouble that I felt that no suit of clothes could possibly remunerate him (Trabb) for his (Trabb) pains.

When he (Trabb) had at last done and had appointed to send the articles to Mr. Pumblechook's on the Thursday evening, he (Pumblechook) said, with his (Pumblechook) hand upon the parlor lock,

``I know, sir, that London gentlemen cannot be expected to patronize local work, as a rule; but if you would give me a turn now and then in the quality of a townsman, I should greatly esteem it.

'' (he)

'' '' '' '' Good morning, sir, much obliged.--Door! '' The last word was flung at the boy, who had not the least notion what it meant.

But I saw him (boy) collapse as his (boy) master rubbed me out with his (boy) hands, and my first decided experience of the stupendous power of money was, that it had morally laid upon his (boy) back Trabb's boy.

After this memorable event, I went to the hatter's, and the bootmaker's, and the hosier's, and felt rather like Mother Hubbard's dog whose outfit required the services of so many trades.

It was not necessary to explain everywhere that I had come into a handsome property; but whenever I said anything to that effect, it followed that the officiating tradesman ceased to have his (tradesman) attention diverted through the window by the High Street, and concentrated his (tradesman) mind upon me.

When I had ordered everything I wanted, I directed my steps towards Pumblechook's, and, as I approached that gentleman's place of business, I saw him (Pumblechook) standing at his (Pumblechook) door.

I also went to the coach-office and took my place for seven o'clock on Saturday morning. He (Pumblechook) was waiting for me with great impatience.

He (Pumblechook) had prepared a collation for me in the Barnwell parlor, and he (Barnwell) too ordered his (Barnwell) shopman to

``come out of the gangway'' (shopman)
as my sacred person passed.

My dear friend,'' said Mr. Pumblechook, taking me by both hands, when he (Pumblechook) and I and the collation were alone,

``I give you joy of your good fortune.

He (Pumblechook) had been out early with the chaise-cart, and had called at the forge and heard the news. '' (I)

Well deserved, well deserved!

To think,'' said Mr. Pumblechook, after snorting admiration at me for some moments,

``that I should have been the humble instrument of leading up to this, is a proud reward.

'' (me)

This was coming to the point, and I thought it a sensible way of expressing himself. '' '' I begged Mr. Pumblechook to remember that nothing was to be ever said or hinted, on that point.

My dear young friend,'' said Mr. Pumblechook;

``if you will allow me to call you so--'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)

and Mr. Pumblechook took me by both hands again, and communicated a movement to his (Pumblechook) waistcoat, which had an emotional appearance, though it was rather low down,

'' (me)

'' said Mr. Pumblechook, in the way of a compassionate adjuration.
``Joseph!! Joseph!!! '' (he)
Thereupon he (Joseph) shook his (Joseph) head and tapped it, expressing his (Joseph) sense of deficiency in Joseph.

Here is a chicken had round from the Boar, here is a tongue had round from the Boar, here's one or two little things had round from the Boar,

'' But my dear young friend,'' said Mr. Pumblechook,

``you must be hungry, you must be exhausted. Be seated. that I hope you may not despise.

But do I,'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)

said Mr. Pumblechook, getting up again the moment after he (Pumblechook) had sat down,
``see afore me, him (Pumblechook) as I ever sported with in his (Pumblechook) times of happy infancy?

And may I--may I--? '' (he)

This May I, meant might he (Pumblechook) shake hands? I consented, and he (Pumblechook) was fervent, and then sat down again.

'' Here is wine,'' said Mr. Pumblechook.

``Let us drink, Thanks to Fortune, and may she (Pumblechook) ever pick out her (Pumblechook) favorites with equal judgment!

And yet I cannot,'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)

said Mr. Pumblechook, getting up again,
``see afore me One--and likewise drink to One--without again expressing-- May I--may I--?

'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)

I said he (Pumblechook) might, and he (Pumblechook) shook hands with me again, and emptied his (Pumblechook) glass and turned it upside down.

I did the same; and if I had turned myself upside down before drinking, the wine could not have gone more direct to my head.

Mr. Pumblechook helped me to the liver wing, and to the best slice of tongue -LRB-none of those out-of-the-way No Thoroughfares of Pork now-RRB-, and took, comparatively speaking, no care of himself at all.

You little thought,'' said Mr. Pumblechook, apostrophizing the fowl in the dish,

``when you was a young fledgling, what was in store for you.

'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)

Ah! poultry, poultry! You little thought you was to be refreshment beneath this humble roof for one as --Call it a weakness, if you will,'' said Mr. Pumblechook, getting up again,
``but may I? may I--?

'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)

It began to be unnecessary to repeat the form of saying he (Pumblechook) might, so he (Pumblechook) did it at once. How he (Pumblechook) ever did it so often without wounding himself with my knife, I don't know.

'' And your sister,'' he (Pumblechook) resumed, after a little steady eating,

``which had the honor of bringing you up by hand!

It's a sad picter, to reflect that she (sister)'s no longer equal to fully understanding the honor. May-- '' (he)

I saw he (Pumblechook) was about to come at me again, and I stopped him (Pumblechook).

'' We'll drink her (sister) health,'' said I.

``Ah!'' (I.)
cried Mr. Pumblechook, leaning back in his (Pumblechook) chair, quite flaccid with admiration, ``that's the way you know 'em, sir!

said the servile Pumblechook, putting down his (Pumblechook) untasted glass in a hurry and getting up again,

'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)

the noble-minded, sir! Ever forgiving and ever affable. '' When he (Pumblechook) had done it, he (Pumblechook) resumed his (Pumblechook) seat and drank to my sister.

``Let us never be blind,'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)
said Mr. Pumblechook,
``to her (sister) faults of temper, but it is to be hoped she (sister) meant well.

At about this time, I began to observe that he (Pumblechook) was getting flushed in the face; as to myself, I felt all face, steeped in wine and smarting.

I mentioned to Mr. Pumblechook that I wished to have my new clothes sent to his (Pumblechook) house, and he (Pumblechook) was ecstatic on my so distinguishing him (Pumblechook).

'' (Mr. Pumblechook/Pumblechook)

I mentioned my reason for desiring to avoid observation in the village, and he (Pumblechook) lauded it to the skies. There was nobody but himself, he (Pumblechook) intimated, worthy of my confidence, and--in short, might he (Pumblechook)?

Then he (Pumblechook) asked me tenderly if I remembered our boyish games at sums, and how we had gone together to have me bound apprentice, and, in effect, how he (Pumblechook) had ever been my favorite fancy and my chosen friend?

If I had taken ten times as many glasses of wine as I had, I should have known that he (Pumblechook) never had stood in that relation towards me, and should in my heart of hearts have repudiated the idea.

Yet for all that, I remember feeling convinced that I had been much mistaken in him (Pumblechook), and that he (Pumblechook) was a sensible, practical, good-hearted prime fellow.

By degrees he (Pumblechook) fell to reposing such great confidence in me, as to ask my advice in reference to his (Pumblechook) own affairs.

He (Pumblechook) mentioned that there was an opportunity for a great amalgamation and monopoly of the corn and seed trade on those premises, if enlarged, such as had never occurred before in that or any other neighborhood.

What alone was wanting to the realization of a vast fortune, he (Pumblechook) considered to be More Capital. Those were the two little words, more capital.

Now it appeared to him (Pumblechook) -LRB-Pumblechook-RRB- that if that capital were got into the business, through a sleeping partner, sir,--which sleeping partner would have nothing to do but walk in, by self or deputy, whenever he (deputy) pleased, and examine the books,--and walk in twice a year and take his (deputy) profits away in his (deputy) pocket, to the tune of fifty per cent,--it appeared to him (deputy) that that might be an opening for a young gentleman of spirit combined with property, which would be worthy of his (gentleman) attention.

But what did I think? He (gentleman) had great confidence in my opinion, and what did I think? I gave it as my opinion.

The united vastness and distinctness of this view so struck him (gentleman), that he (gentleman) no longer asked if he (gentleman) might shake hands with me, but said he (gentleman) really must,--and did.

We drank all the wine, and Mr. Pumblechook pledged himself over and over again to keep Joseph up to the mark -LRB-I don't know what mark-RRB-, and to render me efficient and constant service

He (Pumblechook) also made known to me for the first time in my life, and certainly after having kept his (Pumblechook) secret wonderfully well, that he (Pumblechook) had always said of me,

``That boy is no common boy, and mark me, his (boy) fortun' will be no common fortun'.

He (boy) said with a tearful smile that it was a singular thing to think of now, and I said so too.

Finally, I went out into the air, with a dim perception that there was something unwonted in the conduct of the sunshine, and found that I had slumberously got to the turnpike without having taken any account of the road.

'' (me)

Wait a bit!'' -LRB-I don't know what service-RRB-. '' There, I was roused by Mr. Pumblechook's hailing me. He (Pumblechook) was a long way down the sunny street, and was making expressive gestures for me to stop.

I stopped, and he (Pumblechook) came up breathless. '' No, my dear friend,'' said he (friend), when he (friend) had recovered wind for speech.

'' Not if I can help it. This occasion shall not entirely pass without that affability on your part.--May I, as an old friend and well-wisher?

We shook hands for the hundredth time at least, and he (well-wisher) ordered a young carter out of my way with the greatest indignation.

Then, he (well-wisher) blessed me and stood waving his (well-wisher) hand to me until I had passed the crook in the road; and then I turned into a field and had a long nap under a hedge before I pursued my way home.

I had scant luggage to take with me to London, for little of the little I possessed was adapted to my new station.

But I began packing that same afternoon, and wildly packed up things that I knew I should want next morning, in a fiction that there was not a moment to be lost.

So, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday, passed; and on Friday morning I went to Mr. Pumblechook's, to put on my new clothes and pay my visit to Miss Havisham.

Mr. Pumblechook's own room was given up to me to dress in, and was decorated with clean towels expressly for the event.

Probably every new and eagerly expected garment ever put on since clothes came in, fell a trifle short of the wearer's expectation.

But after I had had my new suit on some half an hour, and had gone through an immensity of posturing with Mr. Pumblechook's very limited dressing-glass, in the futile endeavor to see my legs, it seemed to fit me better.

May I? '' My clothes were rather a disappointment, of course. It being market morning at a neighboring town some ten miles off, Mr. Pumblechook was not at home.

I had not told him (Pumblechook) exactly when I meant to leave, and was not likely to shake hands with him (Pumblechook) again before departing.

This was all as it should be, and I went out in my new array, fearfully ashamed of having to pass the shopman, and suspicious after all that I was at a personal disadvantage, something like Joe's in his (Pumblechook) Sunday suit.

I went circuitously to Miss Havisham's by all the back ways, and rang at the bell constrainedly, on account of the stiff long fingers of my gloves.

Sarah Pocket came to the gate, and positively reeled back when she (Pocket) saw me so changed; her (Pocket) walnut-shell countenance likewise turned from brown to green and yellow.

'' You?'' said she (Pocket). '' You? Good gracious! What do you want?''

``I am going to London, Miss Pocket,'' (I)
said I,
``and want to say good-bye to Miss Havisham.

I was not expected, for she (Pocket) left me locked in the yard, while she (Pocket) went to ask if I were to be admitted.

'' (I)

After a very short delay, she (Pocket) returned and took me up, staring at me all the way. Miss Havisham was taking exercise in the room with the long spread table, leaning on her (Havisham) crutch stick.

The room was lighted as of yore, and at the sound of our entrance, she (Havisham) stopped and turned. She (Havisham) was then just abreast of the rotted bride-cake.

``I start for London, Miss Havisham, to-morrow,'' (I)
I was exceedingly careful what I said,
``and I thought you would kindly not mind my taking leave of you.

This is a gay figure, Pip,'' (I)

said she (Havisham), making her (Havisham) crutch stick play round me, as if she (Havisham), the fairy godmother who had changed me, were bestowing the finishing gift.

'' Don't go, Sarah,'' she (Sarah) said. '' Well, Pip? '' '' '' '' I have come into such good fortune since I saw you last, Miss Havisham,'' I murmured.

'' And I am so grateful for it, Miss Havisham!''

``Ay, ay!'' (she)
said she (Sarah), looking at the discomfited and envious Sarah, with delight.

'' I have seen Mr. Jaggers. I have heard about it, Pip. So you go to-morrow?'' '' Yes, Miss Havisham.'' ''

And you are adopted by a rich person?'' '' Yes, Miss Havisham.''

``Not named?'' (unknown)
'' No, Miss Havisham. '' '' And Mr. Jaggers is made your guardian?''

'' Yes, Miss Havisham. '' She (Sarah) quite gloated on these questions and answers, so keen was her (Sarah) enjoyment of Sarah Pocket's jealous dismay.

'' Well!'' she (Sarah) went on;

``you have a promising career before you. Be good--deserve it--and abide by Mr. Jaggers's instructions. '' (she)

She (Sarah) looked at me, and looked at Sarah, and Sarah's countenance wrung out of her (Sarah) watchful face a cruel smile. ''

Good-bye, Pip!--you will always keep the name of Pip, you know.'' '' Yes, Miss Havisham.''

``Good-bye, Pip!'' (She)
She (Sarah) stretched out her (Sarah) hand, and I went down on my knee and put it to my lips.

I had not considered how I should take leave of her (Sarah); it came naturally to me at the moment to do this.

She (Sarah) looked at Sarah Pocket with triumph in her (Pocket) weird eyes, and so I left my fairy godmother, with both her (Pocket) hands on her (Pocket) crutch stick, standing in the midst of the dimly lighted room beside the rotten bride-cake that was hidden in cobwebs.

Sarah Pocket conducted me down, as if I were a ghost who must be seen out. She (Pocket) could not get over my appearance, and was in the last degree confounded.

I said

``Good-bye, Miss Pocket;'' (I)
but she (Pocket) merely stared, and did not seem collected enough to know that I had spoken.

Clear of the house, I made the best of my way back to Pumblechook's, took off my new clothes, made them into a bundle, and went back home in my older dress, carrying it--to speak the truth--much more at my ease too, though I had the bundle to carry.

And now, those six days which were to have run out so slowly, had run out fast and were gone, and to-morrow looked me in the face more steadily than I could look at it.

As the six evenings had dwindled away, to five, to four, to three, to two, I had become more and more appreciative of the society of Joe and Biddy.

On this last evening, I dressed my self out in my new clothes for their delight, and sat in my splendor until bedtime.

We had a hot supper on the occasion, graced by the inevitable roast fowl, and we had some flip to finish with.

I was to leave our village at five in the morning, carrying my little hand-portmanteau, and I had told Joe that I wished to walk away all alone.

I am afraid--sore afraid--that this purpose originated in my sense of the contrast there would be between me and Joe, if we went to the coach together.

I had pretended with myself that there was nothing of this taint in the arrangement; but when I went up to my little room on this last night, I felt compelled to admit that it might be so, and had an impulse upon me to go down again and entreat Joe to walk with me in the morning.

All night there were coaches in my broken sleep, going to wrong places instead of to London, and having in the traces, now dogs, now cats, now pigs, now men,--never horses.

We were all very low, and none the higher for pretending to be in spirits. I did not. Fantastic failures of journeys occupied me until the day dawned and the birds were singing.

Then, I got up and partly dressed, and sat at the window to take a last look out, and in taking it fell asleep.

Biddy was astir so early to get my breakfast, that, although I did not sleep at the window an hour, I smelt the smoke of the kitchen fire when I started up with a terrible idea that it must be late in the afternoon.

But long after that, and long after I had heard the clinking of the teacups and was quite ready, I wanted the resolution to go downstairs.

After all, I remained up there, repeatedly unlocking and unstrapping my small portmanteau and locking and strapping it up again, until Biddy called to me that I was late.

I got up from the meal, saying with a sort of briskness, as if it had only just occurred to me,

``Well! I suppose I must be off!

and then I kissed my sister who was laughing and nodding and shaking in her (sister) usual chair, and kissed Biddy, and threw my arms around Joe's neck.

It was a hurried breakfast with no taste in it. '' (me)

Then I took up my little portmanteau and walked out.

The last I saw of them was, when I presently heard a scuffle behind me, and looking back, saw Joe throwing an old shoe after me and Biddy throwing another old shoe.

I stopped then, to wave my hat, and dear old Joe waved his (sister) strong right arm above his (sister) head, crying huskily

``Hooroar!'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
and Biddy put her (Joe) apron to her (Joe) face.

I walked away at a good pace, thinking it was easier to go than I had supposed it would be, and reflecting that it would never have done to have had an old shoe thrown after the coach, in sight of all the High Street.

But the village was very peaceful and quiet, and the light mists were solemnly rising, as if to show me the world, and I had been so innocent and little there, and all beyond was so unknown and great, that in a moment with a strong heave and sob I broke into tears.

It was by the finger-post at the end of the village, and I laid my hand upon it, and said,

``Good-bye, O my dear, dear friend!'' (I)

Heaven knows we need never be ashamed of our tears, for they are rain upon the blinding dust of earth, overlying our hard hearts.

I whistled and made nothing of going. I was better after I had cried than before,--more sorry, more aware of my own ingratitude, more gentle.

So subdued I was by those tears, and by their breaking out again in the course of the quiet walk, that when I was on the coach, and it was clear of the town, I deliberated with an aching heart whether I would not get down when we changed horses and walk back, and have another evening at home, and a better parting.

We changed, and I had not made up my mind, and still reflected for my comfort that it would be quite practicable to get down and walk back, when we changed again.

And while I was occupied with these deliberations, I would fancy an exact resemblance to Joe in some man coming along the road towards us, and my heart would beat high.--As if he (man) could possibly be there!

We changed again, and yet again, and it was now too late and too far to go back, and I went on.

If I had cried before, I should have had Joe with me then. And the mists had all solemnly risen now, and the world lay spread before me.

This is the end of the first stage of Pip's expectations. Chapter XX The journey from our town to the metropolis was a journey of about five hours.

It was a little past midday when the four-horse stage-coach by which I was a passenger, got into the ravel of traffic frayed out about the Cross Keys, Wood Street, Cheapside, London.

We Britons had at that time particularly settled that it was treasonable to doubt our having and our being the best of everything: otherwise, while I was scared by the immensity of London, I think I might have had some faint doubts whether it was not rather ugly, crooked, narrow, and dirty.

Mr. Jaggers had duly sent me his (Jaggers) address; it was, Little Britain, and he (Jaggers) had written after it on his (Jaggers) card,

``just out of Smithfield, and close by the coach-office.

Nevertheless, a hackney-coachman, who seemed to have as many capes to his (Jaggers) greasy great-coat as he (Jaggers) was years old, packed me up in his (Jaggers) coach and hemmed me in with a folding and jingling barrier of steps, as if he (Jaggers) were going to take me fifty miles.

His (Jaggers) getting on his (Jaggers) box, which I remember to have been decorated with an old weather-stained pea-green hammercloth moth-eaten into rags, was quite a work of time.

It was a wonderful equipage, with six great coronets outside, and ragged things behind for I don't know how many footmen to hold on by, and a harrow below them, to prevent amateur footmen from yielding to the temptation.

I had scarcely had time to enjoy the coach and to think how like a straw-yard it was, and yet how like a rag-shop, and to wonder why the horses' nose-bags were kept inside, when I observed the coachman beginning to get down, as if we were going to stop presently.

'' (he)

And stop we presently did, in a gloomy street, at certain offices with an open door, whereon was painted MR.

JAGGERS. '' How much? '' I asked the coachman. The coachman answered,

``A shilling--unless you wish to make it more. '' (The coachman)

I naturally said I had no wish to make it more. '' Then it must be a shilling,'' observed the coachman.

'' I don't want to get into trouble. I know him (JAGGERS)!'' He (JAGGERS) darkly closed an eye at Mr. Jaggers's name, and shook his (Jaggers) head.

When he (Jaggers) had got his (Jaggers) shilling, and had in course of time completed the ascent to his (Jaggers) box, and had got away -LRB-which appeared to relieve his (Jaggers) mind-RRB-, I went into the front office with my little portmanteau in my hand and asked,

Was Mr. Jaggers at home? '' He (Jaggers) is not,'' returned the clerk. '' He (Jaggers) is in Court at present. Am I addressing Mr. Pip?

'' I signified that he (Jaggers) was addressing Mr. Pip. '' Mr. Jaggers left word, would you wait in his (Jaggers) room. He (Jaggers) couldn't say how long he (Jaggers) might be, having a case on.

But it stands to reason, his (Jaggers) time being valuable, that he (Jaggers) won't be longer than he (Jaggers) can help. '' With those words, the clerk opened a door, and ushered me into an inner chamber at the back.

Here, we found a gentleman with one eye, in a velveteen suit and knee-breeches, who wiped his (gentleman) nose with his (gentleman) sleeve on being interrupted in the perusal of the newspaper.

I began to say that I hoped I was not interrupting, when the clerk shoved this gentleman out with as little ceremony as I ever saw used, and tossing his (gentleman) fur cap out after him (gentleman), left me alone.

Mr. Jaggers's room was lighted by a skylight only, and was a most dismal place; the skylight, eccentrically pitched like a broken head, and the distorted adjoining houses looking as if they had twisted themselves to peep down at me through it.

There were not so many papers about, as I should have expected to see; and there were some odd objects about, that I should not have expected to see,--such as an old rusty pistol, a sword in a scabbard, several strange-looking boxes and packages, and two dreadful casts on a shelf, of faces peculiarly swollen, and twitchy about the nose.

Mr. Jaggers's own high-backed chair was of deadly black horsehair, with rows of brass nails round it, like a coffin; and I fancied I could see how he (Jaggers) leaned back in it, and bit his (Jaggers) forefinger at the clients.

The room was but small, and the clients seemed to have had a habit of backing up against the wall; the wall, especially opposite to Mr. Jaggers's chair, being greasy with shoulders.

I recalled, too, that the one-eyed gentleman had shuffled forth against the wall when I was the innocent cause of his (gentleman) being turned out.

I sat down in the cliental chair placed over against Mr. Jaggers's chair, and became fascinated by the dismal atmosphere of the place.

I called to mind that the clerk had the same air of knowing something to everybody else's disadvantage, as his (Jaggers) master had.

I wondered how many other clerks there were upstairs, and whether they all claimed to have the same detrimental mastery of their fellow-creatures.

'' Go and wait outside, Mike,'' said the clerk. I wondered what was the history of all the odd litter about the room, and how it came there.

I wondered whether the two swollen faces were of Mr. Jaggers's family, and, if he (Jaggers) were so unfortunate as to have had a pair of such ill-looking relations, why he (Jaggers) stuck them on that dusty perch for the blacks and flies to settle on, instead of giving them a place at home.

Of course I had no experience of a London summer day, and my spirits may have been oppressed by the hot exhausted air, and by the dust and grit that lay thick on everything.

But I sat wondering and waiting in Mr. Jaggers's close room, until I really could not bear the two casts on the shelf above Mr. Jaggers's chair, and got up and went out.

When I told the clerk that I would take a turn in the air while I waited, he (Jaggers) advised me to go round the corner

So I came into Smithfield; and the shameful place, being all asmear with filth and fat and blood and foam, seemed to stick to me.

So, I rubbed it off with all possible speed by turning into a street where I saw the great black dome of Saint Paul's bulging at me from behind a grim stone building which a bystander said was Newgate Prison.

Following the wall of the jail, I found the roadway covered with straw to deaden the noise of passing vehicles; and from this, and from the quantity of people standing about smelling strongly of spirits and beer, I inferred that the trials were on.

While I looked about me here, an exceedingly dirty and partially drunk minister of justice asked me if I would like to step in and hear a trial or so: informing me that he (minister) could give me a front place for half a crown, whence

I should command a full view of the Lord Chief Justice in his (Chief) wig and robes,--mentioning that awful personage like waxwork, and presently offering him (Chief) at the reduced price of eighteen-pence.

As I declined the proposal on the plea of an appointment, he (Chief) was so good as to take me into a yard and show me where the gallows was kept, and also where people were publicly whipped, and then he (Chief) showed me the Debtors' Door, out of which culprits came to be hanged; heightening the interest of that dreadful portal by giving me to understand that

``four on 'em'' (me)
would come out at that door the day after to-morrow at eight in the morning, to be killed in a row.

This was horrible, and gave me a sickening idea of London; the more so as the Lord Chief Justice's proprietor wore -LRB-from his (proprietor) hat down to his (proprietor) boots and up again to his (proprietor) pocket-handkerchief inclusive-RRB- mildewed clothes which had evidently not belonged to him (proprietor) originally, and which I took it into my head he (proprietor) had bought cheap of the executioner.

I dropped into the office to ask if Mr. Jaggers had come in yet, and I found he (Jaggers) had not, and I strolled out again.

This time, I made the tour of Little Britain, and turned into Bartholomew Close; and now I became aware that other people were waiting about for Mr. Jaggers, as well as I.

There were two men of secret appearance lounging in Bartholomew Close, and thoughtfully fitting their feet into the cracks of the pavement as they talked together, one of whom said to the other when they first passed me, that ``Jaggers would do it if it was to be done.

There was a knot of three men and two women standing at a corner, and one of the women was crying on her (I) dirty shawl, and the other comforted her (I) by saying, as she (I) pulled her (I) own shawl over her (I) shoulders,

``Jaggers is for him (Jaggers), `Melia, and what more could you have?

and I should come into Smithfield. Under these circumstances I thought myself well rid of him (Jaggers) for a shilling. '' (she)

''

There was a red-eyed little Jew who came into the Close while I was loitering there, in company with a second little Jew whom he (Jew) sent upon an errand; and while the messenger was gone, I remarked this Jew, who was of a highly excitable temperament, performing a jig of anxiety under a lamp-post and accompanying himself, in a kind of frenzy, with the words,

``O Jaggerth, Jaggerth, Jaggerth!

These testimonies to the popularity of my guardian made a deep impression on me, and I admired and wondered more than ever.

At length, as I was looking out at the iron gate of Bartholomew Close into Little Britain, I saw Mr. Jaggers coming across the road towards me.

all otherth ith Cag-Maggerth, give me Jaggerth!'' (this Jew)

All the others who were waiting saw him (Jaggers) at the same time, and there was quite a rush at him (Jaggers).

Mr. Jaggers, putting a hand on my shoulder and walking me on at his (Jaggers) side without saying anything to me, addressed himself to his (Jaggers) followers.

First, he (Jaggers) took the two secret men. '' Now, I have nothing to say to you,'' said Mr. Jaggers, throwing his (Jaggers) finger at them.

'' I want to know no more than I know. As to the result, it's a toss-up. I told you from the first it was a toss-up.

We made the money up this morning, sir,'' said one of the men, submissively, while the other perused Mr. Jaggers's face.

Have you paid Wemmick?'' '' '' I don't ask you when you made it up, or where, or whether you made it up at all.

Has Wemmick got it?'' '' Yes, sir,'' said both the men together. '' Very well; then you may go. Now, I won't have it!'' said Mr Jaggers, waving his (Jaggers) hand at them to put them behind him (Jaggers).

'' If you say a word to me, I'll throw up the case.''

``We thought, Mr. Jaggers--'' (the men)
one of the men began, pulling off his (Jaggers) hat.

'' That's what I told you not to do,'' said Mr. Jaggers. '' You thought! I think for you; that's enough for you.

If I want you, I know where to find you; I don't want you to find me. Now I won't have it.

The two men looked at one another as Mr. Jaggers waved them behind again, and humbly fell back and were heard no more.

And now you!'' said Mr. Jaggers, suddenly stopping, and turning on the two women with the shawls, from whom the three men had meekly separated,--

``Oh!

I won't hear a word. '' (the men)

'' Amelia, is it?'' '' Yes, Mr. Jaggers. '' '' And do you remember,'' retorted Mr. Jaggers,
``that

but for me you wouldn't be here and couldn't be here?'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)

'' O yes, sir! '' exclaimed both women together. ''

Lord bless you, sir, well we knows that!'' '' Then why,'' said Mr. Jaggers,

``do you come here?'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
'' My Bill, sir!''

the crying woman pleaded. '' Now, I tell you what!'' said Mr. Jaggers. '' Once for all. If you don't know that your Bill's in good hands, I know it.

And if you come here bothering about your Bill, I'll make an example of both your Bill and you, and let him (Bill) slip through my fingers.

Have you paid Wemmick?'' '' O yes, sir! Every farden.''

``Very well. Then you have done all you have got to do.

Say another word--one single word--and Wemmick shall give you your money back. '' (the women)

This terrible threat caused the two women to fall off immediately.

No one remained now but the excitable Jew, who had already raised the skirts of Mr. Jaggers's coat to his (Jaggers) lips several times.

'' I don't know this man!'' said Mr. Jaggers, in the same devastating strain:

``What does this fellow want?'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
'' Ma thear Mithter Jaggerth.

Hown brother to Habraham Latharuth?'' '' Who's he (Jaggers)?'' said Mr. Jaggers. '' Let go of my coat. '' The suitor, kissing the hem of the garment again before relinquishing it, replied,

``Habraham Latharuth, on thuthpithion of plate.'' (The suitor)

'' You're too late,'' said Mr. Jaggers. '' I am over the way.''

``Holy father, Mithter Jaggerth!'' (acquaintance)

said Mr. Jaggers,
``and there's an end of it. Get out of the way.'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
``Mithter Jaggerth! Half a moment!

My hown cuthen'th gone to Mithter Wemmick at thith prethent minute, to hoffer him (Jaggers) hany termth. Mithter Jaggerth! Half a quarter of a moment!

My guardian threw his (Jaggers) supplicant off with supreme indifference, and left him (Jaggers) dancing on the pavement as if it were red hot.

Without further interruption, we reached the front office, where we found the clerk and the man in velveteen with the fur cap.

Well, Mas'r Jaggers,'' (Cock Robin)

returned Mike, in the voice of a sufferer from a constitutional cold;
``arter a deal o' trouble, I've found one, sir, as might do.

Here's Mike,'' (a sufferer)

Mr. Jaggers suddenly became most irate. '' (the client)

You infernal scoundrel, how dare you tell ME that? '' The client looked scared, but bewildered too, as if he (client) were unconscious what he (client) had done.

``Spooney!'' (the clerk)
said the clerk, in a low voice, giving him (client) a stir with his (client) elbow. '' Soft Head! Need you say it face to face?''

``Now, I ask you, you blundering booby,'' (guardian)
said my guardian, very sternly, ``once more and for the last time, what the man you have brought here is prepared to swear?

Mike looked hard at my guardian, as if he (Mike) were trying to learn a lesson from his (Mike) face, and slowly replied,

``Ayther to character, or to having been in his (Mike) company and never left him (Mike) all the night in question.'' (he)

Mike looked at his (Mike) cap, and looked at the floor, and looked at the ceiling, and looked at the clerk, and even looked at me, before beginning to reply in a nervous manner,

''

``What? You WILL, will you? '' (guardian)

``He (Mike) is dressed like a `spectable pieman. A sort of a pastry-cook.'' (Mike)
``Is he (Mike) here?'' (guardian)
asked my guardian. '' I left him (Mike),'' said Mike, ``a setting on some doorsteps round the corner.

We all three went to it, behind the wire blind, and presently saw the client go by in an accidental manner, with a murderous-looking tall individual, in a short suit of white linen and a paper cap.

This guileless confectioner was not by any means sober, and had a black eye in the green stage of recovery, which was painted over.

``Tell him (individual) to take his (individual) witness away directly,'' (guardian)
said my guardian to the clerk, in extreme disgust, ``and ask him (individual) what he (individual) means by bringing such a fellow as that.

My guardian then took me into his (individual) own room, and while he (individual) lunched, standing, from a sandwich-box and a pocket-flask of sherry -LRB-he (individual) seemed to bully his (individual) very sandwich as he (individual) ate it-RRB-, informed me what arrangements he (individual) had made for me.

I was to go to

``Barnard's Inn,'' (I)
to young Mr. Pocket's rooms, where a bed had been sent in for my accommodation; I was to remain with young Mr. Pocket until Monday; on Monday I was to go with him (Pocket) to his (Pocket) father's house on a visit, that I might try how I liked it.

Also, I was told what my allowance was to be,--it was a very liberal one,--and had handed to me from one of my guardian's drawers, the cards of certain tradesmen with whom I was to deal for all kinds of clothes, and such other things as I could in reason want.

''

``Take him (Pocket) past that window, and let me see him (Pocket). '' (unknown)
The window indicated was the office window. '' ''

You will find your credit good, Mr. Pip,'' said my guardian, whose flask of sherry smelt like a whole caskful, as he (Pip) hastily refreshed himself,

``but I shall by this means be able to check your bills, and to pull you up if I find you outrunning the constable.

After I had pondered a little over this encouraging sentiment, I asked Mr. Jaggers if I could send for a coach?

Of course you'll go wrong somehow, but that's no fault of mine. '' (he)

He (coach) said it was not worth while , I was so near my destination; Wemmick should walk round with me, if I pleased.

Another clerk was rung down from upstairs to take his (Wemmick) place while he (Wemmick) was out, and I accompanied him (Wemmick) into the street, after shaking hands with my guardian.

We found a new set of people lingering outside, but Wemmick made a way among them by saying coolly yet decisively,

``I tell you it's no use; he (Wemmick) won't have a word to say to one of you;'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
and we soon got clear of them, and went on side by side.

Chapter XXI Casting my eyes on Mr. Wemmick as we went along, to see what he (Wemmick) was like in the light of day, I found him (Wemmick) to be a dry man, rather short in stature, with a square wooden face, whose expression seemed to have been imperfectly chipped out with a dull-edged chisel.

There were some marks in it that might have been dimples, if the material had been softer and the instrument finer, but which, as it was, were only dints.

The chisel had made three or four of these attempts at embellishment over his (Wemmick) nose, but had given them up without an effort to smooth them off.

I judged him (Wemmick) to be a bachelor from the frayed condition of his (Wemmick) linen, and he (Wemmick) appeared to have sustained a good many bereavements; for he (Wemmick) wore at least four mourning rings, besides a brooch representing a lady and a weeping willow at a tomb with an urn on it.

I noticed, too, that several rings and seals hung at his (Wemmick) watch-chain, as if he (Wemmick) were quite laden with remembrances of departed friends.

I then found that Wemmick was the clerk in the next room. He (Wemmick) had glittering eyes,--small, keen, and black,--and thin wide mottled lips.

He (Wemmick) had had them, to the best of my belief, from forty to fifty years. '' So you were never in London before?'' said Mr. Wemmick to me.

'' No,'' said I.

``I was new here once,'' (I.)
said Mr. Wemmick. '' Rum to think of now!''
``You are well acquainted with it now?

'' (unknown)

``Why, yes,'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
said Mr. Wemmick. '' I know the moves of it.''
``Is it a very wicked place? '' (I)
I asked, more for the sake of saying something than for information.

'' You may get cheated, robbed, and murdered in London. But there are plenty of people anywhere, who'll do that for you.

'' '' If there is bad blood between you and them,'' said I, to soften it off a little. '' O!

I don't know about bad blood,'' returned Mr. Wemmick;

``there's not much bad blood about. They'll do it, if there's anything to be got by it.'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

He (Wemmick) wore his (Wemmick) hat on the back of his (Wemmick) head, and looked straight before him (Wemmick): walking in a self-contained way as if there were nothing in the streets to claim his (Wemmick) attention.

``That makes it worse. '' (unknown)
``You think so?'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
returned Mr. Wemmick. '' Much about the same, I should say. '' His (Wemmick) mouth was such a post-office of a mouth that he (Wemmick) had a mechanical appearance of smiling.

We had got to the top of Holborn Hill before I knew that it was merely a mechanical appearance, and that he (Wemmick) was not smiling at all.

'' Do you know where Mr. Matthew Pocket lives? '' I asked Mr. Wemmick. '' Yes,'' said he (Wemmick), nodding in the direction.

'' At Hammersmith, west of London.''

``Is that far?'' (unknown)
``Well! Say five miles. '' (unknown)
``Do you know him (Wemmick)?'' (unknown)
``Why, you're a regular cross-examiner!'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
said Mr. Wemmick, looking at me with an approving air.

There was an air of toleration or depreciation about his (Wemmick) utterance of these words that rather depressed me; and I was still looking sideways at his (Wemmick) block of a face in search of any encouraging note to the text, when he (Wemmick) said here we were at Barnard's Inn.

My depression was not alleviated by the announcement, for, I had supposed that establishment to be an hotel kept by Mr. Barnard, to which the Blue Boar in our town was a mere public-house.

Whereas I now found Barnard to be a disembodied spirit, or a fiction, and his (Barnard) inn the dingiest collection of shabby buildings ever squeezed together in a rank corner as a club for Tom-cats.

We entered this haven through a wicket-gate, and were disgorged by an introductory passage into a melancholy little square that looked to me like a flat burying-ground.

I thought it had the most dismal trees in it, and the most dismal sparrows, and the most dismal cats, and the most dismal houses -LRB-in number half a dozen or so-RRB-, that I had ever seen.

I thought the windows of the sets of chambers into which those houses were divided were in every stage of dilapidated blind and curtain, crippled flower-pot, cracked glass, dusty decay, and miserable makeshift;

while To Let, To Let, To Let, glared at me from empty rooms, as if no new wretches ever came there, and the vengeance of the soul of Barnard were being slowly appeased by the gradual suicide of the present occupants and their unholy interment under the gravel.

A frowzy mourning of soot and smoke attired this forlorn creation of Barnard, and it had strewn ashes on its head, and was undergoing penance and humiliation as a mere dust-hole.

Thus far my sense of sight; while dry rot and wet rot and all the silent rots that rot in neglected roof and cellar,--rot of rat and mouse and bug and coaching-stables near at hand besides--addressed themselves faintly to my sense of smell, and moaned,

``Try Barnard's Mixture.

'' (I)

Yes, I know him (Barnard). I know him (Barnard)! '' '' So imperfect was this realization of the first of my great expectations, that I looked in dismay at Mr. Wemmick.

He (Wemmick) led me into a corner and conducted me up a flight of stairs,--which appeared to me to be slowly collapsing into sawdust, so that one of those days the upper lodgers would look out at their doors and find themselves without the means of coming down,--to a set of chambers on the top floor.

'' Ah!'' said he (Wemmick), mistaking me;

``the retirement reminds you of the country. So it does me. '' (me)
MR. POCKET, JUN.

, was painted on the door, and there was a label on the letter-box,

``Return shortly. '' (unknown)
``He (Wemmick) hardly thought you'd come so soon,'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
Mr. Wemmick explained.

'' You don't want me any more?'' '' No, thank you,'' said I.

``As I keep the cash,'' (I.)
Mr. Wemmick observed,
``we shall most likely meet pretty often.

Good day. '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

``Good day. '' (I)
I put out my hand, and Mr. Wemmick at first looked at it as if he (Wemmick) thought I wanted something.

Then he (Wemmick) looked at me, and said, correcting himself,--

``To be sure! Yes. You're in the habit of shaking hands? '' (me)

I was rather confused, thinking it must be out of the London fashion, but said yes. '' I have got so out of it!'' said Mr. Wemmick,--

``except at last.

When we had shaken hands and he (Wemmick) was gone, I opened the staircase window and had nearly beheaded myself, for, the lines had rotted away, and it came down like the guillotine.

Very glad, I'm sure, to make your acquaintance. Good day! '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

Happily it was so quick that I had not put my head out.

After this escape, I was content to take a foggy view of the Inn through the window's encrusting dirt, and to stand dolefully looking out, saying to myself that London was decidedly overrated.

Mr. Pocket, Junior's, idea of Shortly was not mine, for I had nearly maddened myself with looking out for half an hour, and had written my name with my finger several times in the dirt of every pane in the window, before I heard footsteps on the stairs.

Gradually there arose before me the hat, head, neckcloth, waistcoat, trousers, boots, of a member of society of about my own standing.

He (member) had a paper-bag under each arm and a pottle of strawberries in one hand, and was out of breath. ''

I am extremely sorry; but I knew there was a coach from your part of the country at midday, and I thought you would come by that one.

Mr. Pip?'' said he (Pip). '' Mr. Pocket?'' said I.

``Dear me!'' (I.)
he (Pocket) exclaimed. '' The fact is, I have been out on your account,--not that that is any excuse,--for

I thought, coming from the country, you might like a little fruit after dinner, and I went to Covent Garden Market to get it good.

'' For a reason that I had, I felt as if my eyes would start out of my head. I acknowledged his (Pocket) attention incoherently, and began to think this was a dream.

As he (Pocket) was fast making jam of his (Pocket) fruit by wrestling with the door while the paper-bags were under his (Pocket) arms, I begged him (Pocket) to allow me to hold them.

'' Dear me!'' said Mr. Pocket, Junior. '' This door sticks so!'' He (Pocket) relinquished them with an agreeable smile, and combated with the door as if it were a wild beast.

It yielded so suddenly at last, that he (Pocket) staggered back upon me, and I staggered back upon the opposite door, and we both laughed.

But still I felt as if my eyes must start out of my head, and as if this must be a dream.

'' Pray come in,'' said Mr. Pocket, Junior.

``Allow me to lead the way. I am rather bare here, but I hope you'll be able to make out tolerably well till Monday.

My father thought you would get on more agreeably through to-morrow with me than with him (father), and might like to take a walk about London.

As to our table, you won't find that bad, I hope, for it will be supplied from our coffee-house here, and -LRB-it is only right I should add-RRB- at your expense, such being Mr. Jaggers's directions.

As to our lodging, it's not by any means splendid, because I have my own bread to earn, and my father hasn't anything to give me, and I shouldn't be willing to take it, if he (father) had.

This is our sitting-room,--just such chairs and tables and carpet and so forth, you see, as they could spare from home.

I am sure I shall be very happy to show London to you. You mustn't give me credit for the tablecloth and spoons and castors, because they come for you from the coffee-house.

This is your bedroom; the furniture's hired for the occasion, but I trust it will answer the purpose; if you should want anything, I'll go and fetch it.

This is my little bedroom; rather musty, but Barnard's is musty. The chambers are retired, and we shall be alone together, but we shan't fight, I dare say.

But dear me, I beg your pardon, you're holding the fruit all this time. Pray let me take these bags from you.

As I stood opposite to Mr. Pocket, Junior, delivering him (Junior) the bags, One, Two, I saw the starting appearance come into his (Junior) own eyes that I knew to be in mine, and he (Junior) said, falling back,--

I am quite ashamed. '' (Lord)

'' Lord bless me, you're the prowling boy!'' '' And you,'' said I,
``are the pale young gentleman!'' (I)

Chapter XXII The pale young gentleman and I stood contemplating one another in Barnard's Inn, until we both burst out laughing.

'' The idea of its being you!'' said he (Barnard). '' The idea of its being you!'' said I. And then we contemplated one another afresh, and laughed again.

Well!'' said the pale young gentleman, reaching out his (gentleman) hand good-humoredly,

``it's all over now, I hope, and it will be magnanimous in you if you'll forgive me for having knocked you about so.

I derived from this speech that Mr. Herbert Pocket -LRB-for Herbert was the pale young gentleman's name-RRB- still rather confounded his (Herbert) intention with his (Herbert) execution.

'' (the gentleman)

'' But I made a modest reply, and we shook hands warmly. '' You hadn't come into your good fortune at that time?'' said Herbert Pocket.

'' No,'' said I.

``No,'' (I.)
he (Pocket) acquiesced:
``I heard it had happened very lately. I was rather on the lookout for good fortune then.'' (he)

``Indeed?'' (unknown)
'' Yes. Miss Havisham had sent for me, to see if she (Havisham) could take a fancy to me. But she (Havisham) couldn't,--at all events, she (Havisham) didn't.

'' I thought it polite to remark that I was surprised to hear that. '' Bad taste,'' said Herbert, laughing,

``but a fact.

Yes, she (Havisham) had sent for me on a trial visit, and if I had come out of it successfully, I suppose I should have been provided for

He (Herbert) was arranging his (Herbert) fruit in plates while we talked, which divided his (Herbert) attention, and was the cause of his (Herbert) having made this lapse of a word.

; perhaps I should have been what-you-may-called it to Estella.'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

'' What's that? '' I asked, with sudden gravity. '' Affianced,'' he (Herbert) explained, still busy with the fruit.

'' Betrothed. Engaged. What's-his-named. Any word of that sort. ''

``How did you bear your disappointment? '' (I)
I asked. '' Pooh!

'' said he (Herbert),

``I didn't care much for it. She (Estella)'s a Tartar.'' (he)
``Miss Havisham?'' (unknown)
``I don't say no to that, but I meant Estella.

That girl's hard and haughty and capricious to the last degree, and has been brought up by Miss Havisham to wreak revenge on all the male sex.

'' (she)

'' What relation is she (Estella) to Miss Havisham?''
``None,'' (he)
said he (Herbert). '' Only adopted.''
``Why should she (Estella) wreak revenge on all the male sex?

What revenge?'' (unknown)

``Lord, Mr. Pip!'' (he)
said he (Pip). '' Don't you know?'' '' No,'' said I.
``Dear me! It's quite a story, and shall be saved till dinner-time.

I told him (Pip), and he (Pip) was attentive until I had finished, and then burst out laughing again, and asked me if I was sore afterwards?

And now let me take the liberty of asking you a question. How did you come there, that day? '' (I.)

I didn't ask him (Pip) if he (Pip) was, for my conviction on that point was perfectly established.

'' Mr. Jaggers is your guardian, I understand? '' he (Jaggers) went on. '' Yes.''

``You know he (Jaggers) is Miss Havisham's man of business and solicitor, and has her (Pip) confidence when nobody else has?

I answered with a constraint I made no attempt to disguise, that I had seen Mr. Jaggers in Miss Havisham's house on the very day of our combat, but never at any other time, and that I believed he (Jaggers) had no recollection of having ever seen me there.

He (Jaggers) was so obliging as to suggest my father for your tutor, and he (Jaggers) called on my father to propose it.

'' (me)

This was bringing me -LRB-I felt-RRB- towards dangerous ground. '' Of course he (Jaggers) knew about my father from his (Jaggers) connection with Miss Havisham.

My father is Miss Havisham's cousin; not that that implies familiar intercourse between them, for he (father) is a bad courtier and will not propitiate her (Havisham).

I had never seen any one then, and I have never seen any one since, who more strongly expressed to me, in every look and tone, a natural incapacity to do anything secret and mean.

'' Herbert Pocket had a frank and easy way with him (Pocket) that was very taking. There was something wonderfully hopeful about his (Pocket) general air, and something that at the same time whispered to me

I became imbued with the notion on that first occasion before we sat down to dinner, but I cannot define by what means.

He (Pocket) was still a pale young gentleman, and had a certain conquered languor about him (Pocket) in the midst of his (Pocket) spirits and briskness, that did not seem indicative of natural strength.

he (Pocket) would never be very successful or rich. I don't know how this was. He (Pocket) had not a handsome face, but it was better than handsome: being extremely amiable and cheerful.

His (Pocket) figure was a little ungainly, as in the days when my knuckles had taken such liberties with it, but it looked as if it would always be light and young.

Whether Mr. Trabb's local work would have sat more gracefully on him (Trabb) than on me, may be a question; but I am conscious that he (Trabb) carried off his (Trabb) rather old clothes much better than I carried off my new suit.

As he (Trabb) was so communicative, I felt that reserve on my part would be a bad return unsuited to our years.

I further mentioned that as I had been brought up a blacksmith in a country place, and knew very little of the ways of politeness, I would take it as a great kindness in him (blacksmith) if he (blacksmith) would give me a hint whenever he (blacksmith) saw me at a loss or going wrong.

I therefore told him (blacksmith) my small story, and laid stress on my being forbidden to inquire who my benefactor was. ''

With pleasure,'' said he (benefactor),

``though I venture to prophesy that you'll want very few hints. I dare say we shall be often together, and I should like to banish any needless restraint between us.

Will you do me the favour to begin at once to call me by my Christian name, Herbert? '' (he)

I thanked him (Herbert) and said I would.

I don't take to Philip,'' said he (Philip), smiling,

``for it sounds like a moral boy out of the spelling-book, who was so lazy that he (Philip) fell into a pond, or so fat that he (Philip) couldn't see out of his (Philip) eyes, or so avaricious that he (Philip) locked up his (Philip) cake till the mice ate it, or so determined to go a bird's-nesting that he (Philip) got himself eaten by bears who lived handy in the neighborhood.

I informed him (Philip) in exchange that my Christian name was Philip. '' (he)

I tell you what I should like. We are so harmonious, and you have been a blacksmith,--would

you mind it?''

``I shouldn't mind anything that you propose,'' (I)
I answered,
``but I don't understand you.'' (I)
``Would you mind Handel for a familiar name?

Then, my dear Handel,'' (he)

said he (Handel), turning round as the door opened,
``here is the dinner, and I must beg of you to take the top of the table, because the dinner is of your providing.

There's a charming piece of music by Handel, called the Harmonious Blacksmith. '' (he)

``I should like it very much.'' (me)
'' ''

It was a nice little dinner,--seemed to me then a very Lord Mayor's Feast,--and it acquired additional relish from being eaten under those independent circumstances, with no old people by, and with London all around us.

This again was heightened by a certain gypsy character that set the banquet off; for while the table was, as Mr. Pumblechook might have said, the lap of luxury,--being entirely furnished forth from the coffee-house,--the circumjacent region of sitting-room was of a comparatively pastureless and shifty character; imposing on the waiter the wandering habits of putting the covers on the floor -LRB-where he (waiter) fell over them-RRB-, the melted butter in the arm-chair, the bread on the bookshelves, the cheese in the coal-scuttle, and the boiled fowl into my bed in the next

This I would not hear of, so he (waiter) took the top, and I faced him (waiter). room,--where I found much of its parsley and butter in a state of congelation when I retired for the night.

All this made the feast delightful, and when the waiter was not there to watch me, my pleasure was without alloy.

We had made some progress in the dinner, when I reminded Herbert of his (Herbert) promise to tell me about Miss Havisham.

Let me introduce the topic, Handel, by mentioning that in London it is not the custom to put the knife in the mouth,--for fear of accidents,--and that while the fork is reserved for that use, it is not put further in than necessary.

'' True,'' he (Handel) replied. '' I'll redeem it at once. It is scarcely worth mentioning, only it's as well to do as other people do.

You get at your mouth better -LRB-which after all is the object-RRB-, and you save a good deal of the attitude of opening oysters, on the part of the right elbow.

Also, the spoon is not generally used over-hand, but under. This has two advantages. '' He (Handel) offered these friendly suggestions in such a lively way, that we both laughed and I scarcely blushed.

'' Now,'' he (Handel) pursued,

``concerning Miss Havisham. Miss Havisham, you must know, was a spoilt child. Her (you) mother died when she (you) was a baby, and her (you) father denied her (you) nothing.

I don't know why it should be a crack thing to be a brewer; but it is indisputable that while you cannot possibly be genteel and bake, you may be as genteel as never was and brew.

Her (you) father was a country gentleman down in your part of the world, and was a brewer. You see it every day.'' (he)

Yet a gentleman may not keep a public-house; may he (gentleman)?'' said I.

``Not on any account,'' (I.)
returned Herbert;
``but a public-house may keep a gentleman.

'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

Well! Mr. Havisham was very rich and very proud. So was his (Mr.) daughter.''
``Miss Havisham was an only child? '' (I)

I hazarded. '' Stop a moment, I am coming to that. No, she (Havisham) was not an only child; she (Havisham) had a half-brother.

Her (Havisham) father privately married again--his (father) cook, I rather think.''

``I thought he (father) was proud,'' (I.)
said I.
``My good Handel, so he (Handel) was.

When she (Havisham) was dead, I apprehend he (Handel) first told his (Handel) daughter what he (Handel) had done, and then the son became a part of the family, residing in the house you are acquainted with.

He (son) married his (son) second wife privately, because he (son) was proud, and in course of time she (wife) died. As the son grew a young man, he (son) turned out riotous, extravagant, undutiful,--altogether bad.

At last his (son) father disinherited him (son); but he (son) softened when he (son) was dying, and left him (son) well off, though not nearly so well off as Miss Havisham.--Take another glass of wine, and excuse my mentioning that society as a body does not expect one to be so strictly conscientious in emptying one's glass, as to turn it bottom upwards with the rim on one's nose.

'' (I.)

I had been doing this, in an excess of attention to his (son) recital. I thanked him (son), and apologized. He (son) said,
``Not at all,'' (He)
and resumed. ''

Her (son) half-brother had now ample means again, but what with debts and what with new madness wasted them most fearfully again.

There were stronger differences between him (half-brother) and her (son) than there had been between him (half-brother) and his (half-brother) father, and it is suspected that he (half-brother) cherished a deep and mortal grudge against her (son) as having influenced the father's anger.

Now, I come to the cruel part of the story,--merely breaking off, my dear Handel, to remark that a dinner-napkin will not go into a tumbler.

Miss Havisham was now an heiress, and you may suppose was looked after as a great match. '' Why I was trying to pack mine into my tumbler, I am wholly unable to say.

I only know that I found myself, with a perseverance worthy of a much better cause, making the most strenuous exertions to compress it within those limits.

Again I thanked him (Handel) and apologized, and again he (Handel) said in the cheerfullest manner,

``Not at all, I am sure!'' (he)
and resumed.

There appeared upon the scene--say at the races, or the public balls, or anywhere else you like--a certain man, who made love to Miss Havisham.

I never saw him (man) -LRB-for this happened five-and-twenty years ago, before you and I were, Handel-RRB-, but I have heard my father mention that he (Handel) was a showy man, and the kind of man for the purpose.

But that he (man) was not to be, without ignorance or prejudice, mistaken for a gentleman, my father most strongly asseverates; because it is a principle of his (father) that no man who was not a true gentleman at heart ever was, since the world began, a true gentleman in manner.

He (gentleman) says, no varnish can hide the grain of the wood; and that the more varnish you put on, the more the grain will express itself.

I believe she (man) had not shown much susceptibility up to that time; but all the susceptibility she (man) possessed certainly came out then, and she (man) passionately loved him (gentleman).

'' Well! This man pursued Miss Havisham closely, and professed to be devoted to her (Havisham). There is no doubt that she (Havisham) perfectly idolized him (man).

He (man) practised on her (Havisham) affection in that systematic way, that he (man) got great sums of money from her (Havisham), and he (man) induced her (Havisham) to buy her (Havisham) brother out of a share in the brewery -LRB-which had been weakly left him (man) by his (man) father-RRB- at an immense price, on the plea that when he (man) was her (Havisham) husband he (man) must hold and manage it all.

Your guardian was not at that time in Miss Havisham's counsels, and she (Havisham) was too haughty and too much in love to be advised by any one.

Her (Havisham) relations were poor and scheming, with the exception of my father; he (father) was poor enough, but not time-serving or jealous.

The only independent one among them, he (father) warned her (Havisham) that she (Havisham) was doing too much for this man, and was placing herself too unreservedly in his (man) power.

She (Havisham) took the first opportunity of angrily ordering my father out of the house, in his (father) presence, and my father has never seen her (Havisham) since.

I thought of her (Havisham) having said,

``Matthew will come and see me at last when I am laid dead upon that table;'' (I)
and I asked Herbert whether his (Herbert) father was so inveterate against her (Havisham)?

It's not that,'' said he (father),

``but she (Havisham) charged him (father), in the presence of her (Havisham) intended husband, with being disappointed in the hope of fawning upon her (Havisham) for his (husband) own advancement, and, if he (husband) were to go to her (Havisham) now, it would look true--even to him (husband)--and even to her (Havisham).

The marriage day was fixed, the wedding dresses were bought, the wedding tour was planned out, the wedding guests were invited.

'' (he)

'' To return to the man and make an end of him (man). The day came, but not the bridegroom. He (bridegroom) wrote her (Havisham) a letter--''
``Which she (Havisham) received,'' (her)
I struck in,
``when she (Havisham) was dressing for her (Havisham) marriage?

At twenty minutes to nine?'' (I)

``At the hour and minute,'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
said Herbert, nodding,
``at which she (Havisham) afterwards stopped all the clocks.

What was in it, further than that it most heartlessly broke the marriage off, I can't tell you, because I don't know.

When she (Havisham) recovered from a bad illness that she (Havisham) had, she (Havisham) laid the whole place waste, as you have seen it, and she (Havisham) has never since looked upon the light of day.'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

All I know of it; and indeed I only know so much, through piecing it out for myself; for my father always avoids it, and, even when Miss Havisham invited me to go there, told me no more of it than it was absolutely requisite I should understand.

It has been supposed that the man to whom she (Havisham) gave her (Havisham) misplaced confidence acted throughout in concert with her (Havisham) half-brother; that it was a conspiracy between them; and that they shared the profits.''

``Is that all the story? '' (I)
I asked, after considering it. '' But I have forgotten one thing.
``I wonder he (half-brother) didn't marry her (Havisham) and get all the property,'' (I.)
said I.

``He (half-brother) may have been married already, and her (Havisham) cruel mortification may have been a part of her (Havisham) half-brother's scheme,'' (I.)
said Herbert.

'' Mind! I don't know that.'' '' What became of the two men? '' I asked, after again considering the subject. ''

They fell into deeper shame and degradation--if there can be deeper--and ruin.''

``Are they alive now?'' (unknown)
``I don't know. '' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)
''

You said just now that Estella was not related to Miss Havisham, but adopted. When adopted?'' Herbert shrugged his (Herbert) shoulders. ''

And now, Handel,'' said he (Handel), finally throwing off the story as it were,

``there is a perfectly open understanding between us.

There has always been an Estella, since I have heard of a Miss Havisham. I know no more. All that I know about Miss Havisham, you know.

'' (he)

'' And all that I know,'' I retorted,
``you know.'' (I)
``I fully believe it. So there can be no competition or perplexity between you and me.

And as to the condition on which you hold your advancement in life,--namely, that you are not to inquire or discuss to whom you owe it,--you may be very sure that it will never be encroached upon, or even approached, by me, or by any one belonging to me.

In truth, he (you) said this with so much delicacy, that I felt the subject done with, even though I should be under his (you) father's roof for years and years to come.
