Yet he (you) said it with so much meaning, too, that I felt he (you) as perfectly understood Miss Havisham to be my benefactress, as I understood the fact myself.

It had not occurred to me before, that he (you) had led up to the theme for the purpose of clearing it out of our way; but we were so much the lighter and easier for having broached it, that I now perceived this to be the case.

'' (I)

We were very gay and sociable, and I asked him (you), in the course of conversation, what he (you) was? He (you) replied, ``A capitalist,--an Insurer of Ships.

I suppose he (you) saw me glancing about the room in search of some tokens of Shipping, or capital, for he (you) added,

``In the City.

I had grand ideas of the wealth and importance of Insurers of Ships in the City, and I began to think with awe of having laid a young Insurer on his (you) back, blackened his (you) enterprising eye, and cut his (you) responsible head open.

But again there came upon me, for my relief, that odd impression that Herbert Pocket would never be very successful or rich.

'' (he)

'' '' I shall not rest satisfied with merely employing my capital in insuring ships. I shall buy up some good Life Assurance shares, and cut into the Direction.

I shall also do a little in the mining way. None of these things will interfere with my chartering a few thousand tons on my own account.

I think I shall trade,'' said he (Pocket), leaning back in his (Pocket) chair,

``to the East Indies, for silks, shawls, spices, dyes, drugs, and precious woods.

It's an interesting trade.'' (he)

'' And the profits are large?'' said I.
``Tremendous!'' (I.)
said he (Pocket). I wavered again, and began to think here were greater expectations than my own.

I think I shall trade, also,'' said he (Pocket), putting his (Pocket) thumbs in his (Pocket) waist-coat pockets,

``to the West Indies, for sugar, tobacco, and rum.

'' (he)

Also to Ceylon, specially for elephants' tusks. ''
``You will want a good many ships,'' (I.)
said I.
``A perfect fleet,'' (I.)
said he (Pocket).

Quite overpowered by the magnificence of these transactions, I asked him (Pocket) where the ships he (Pocket) insured mostly traded to at present?

'' I haven't begun insuring yet,'' he (Pocket) replied. '' I am looking about me. '' Somehow, that pursuit seemed more in keeping with Barnard's Inn.

I said -LRB-in a tone of conviction-RRB-,

``Ah-h!'' (I)
'' Yes. I am in a counting-house, and looking about me.''
``Is a counting-house profitable?

'' (I)

I asked. '' To--do you mean to the young fellow who's in it?'' he (fellow) asked, in reply.
``Yes; to you.'' (unknown)

``Why, n-no; not to me. '' (He)
He (fellow) said this with the air of one carefully reckoning up and striking a balance.

This certainly had not a profitable appearance, and I shook my head as if I would imply that it would be difficult to lay by much accumulative capital from such a source of income.

'' Not directly profitable. That is, it doesn't pay me anything, and I have to--keep myself. '' '' But the thing is,'' said Herbert Pocket,

``that you look about you.

It struck me as a singular implication that you couldn't be out of a counting-house, you know, and look about you; but I silently deferred to his (Pocket) experience.

That's the grand thing. You are in a counting-house, you know, and you look about you. '' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

'' Then the time comes,'' said Herbert,
``when you see your opening.

And you go in, and you swoop upon it and you make your capital, and then there you are! When you have once made your capital, you have nothing to do but employ it.

'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

This was very like his (Herbert) way of conducting that encounter in the garden; very like. His (Herbert) manner of bearing his (Herbert) poverty, too, exactly corresponded to his (Herbert) manner of bearing that defeat.

It seemed to me that he (Herbert) took all blows and buffets now with just the same air as he (Herbert) had taken mine then.

It was evident that he (Herbert) had nothing around him (Herbert) but the simplest necessaries, for everything that I remarked upon turned out to have been sent in on my account from the coffee-house or somewhere else.

Yet, having already made his (Herbert) fortune in his (Herbert) own mind, he (Herbert) was so unassuming with it that I felt quite grateful to him (Herbert) for not being puffed up.

In the evening we went out for a walk in the streets, and went half-price to the Theatre; and next day we went to church at Westminster Abbey, and in the afternoon we walked in the Parks; and I wondered who shod all the horses there, and wished Joe did.

It was a pleasant addition to his (Herbert) naturally pleasant ways, and we got on famously. On a moderate computation, it was many months, that Sunday, since I had left Joe and Biddy.

That I could have been at our old church in my old church-going clothes, on the very last Sunday that ever was, seemed a combination of impossibilities, geographical and social, solar and lunar.

Yet in the London streets so crowded with people and so brilliantly lighted in the dusk of evening, there were depressing hints of reproaches for that I had put the poor old kitchen at home so far away; and in the dead of night, the footsteps of some incapable impostor of a porter mooning about Barnard's Inn, under pretence of watching it, fell hollow on my heart.

On the Monday morning at a quarter before nine, Herbert went to the counting-house to report himself,--to look about him (Herbert), too,

The space interposed between myself and them partook of that expansion, and our marshes were any distance off. I suppose,--and I bore him (Herbert) company.

He (Herbert) was to come away in an hour or two to attend me to Hammersmith, and I was to wait about for him (Herbert).

It appeared to me that the eggs from which young Insurers were hatched were incubated in dust and heat, like the eggs of ostriches, judging from the places to which those incipient giants repaired on a Monday morning.

Nor did the counting-house where Herbert assisted, show in my eyes as at all a good Observatory; being a back second floor up a yard, of a grimy presence in all particulars, and with a look into another back second floor, rather than a look out.

I waited about until it was noon, and I went upon `Change, and I saw fluey men sitting there under the bills about shipping, whom I took to be great merchants, though I couldn't understand why they should all be out of spirits.

When Herbert came, we went and had lunch at a celebrated house which I then quite venerated, but now believe to have been the most abject superstition in Europe, and where I could not help noticing, even then, that there was much more gravy on the tablecloths and knives and waiters' clothes, than in the steaks.

This collation disposed of at a moderate price -LRB-considering the grease, which was not charged for-RRB-, we went back to Barnard's Inn and got my little portmanteau, and then took coach for Hammersmith.

We arrived there at two or three o'clock in the afternoon, and had very little way to walk to Mr. Pocket's house.

Lifting the latch of a gate, we passed direct into a little garden overlooking the river, where Mr. Pocket's children were playing about.

And unless I deceive myself on a point where my interests or prepossessions are certainly not concerned, I saw that Mr. and Mrs. Pocket's children were not growing up or being brought up, but were tumbling up.

Mrs. Pocket was sitting on a garden chair under a tree, reading, with her (Mr.) legs upon another garden chair; and Mrs. Pocket's two nurse-maids were looking about them while the children played.

'' Mamma,'' said Herbert,

``this is young Mr. Pip. '' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
Upon which Mrs. Pocket received me with an appearance of amiable dignity.

Master Alick and Miss Jane,'' cried one of the nurses to two of the children, ``if you go a bouncing up against them bushes you'll fall over into the river and be drownded, and what'll your pa say then?

At the same time this nurse picked up Mrs. Pocket's handkerchief, and said,

``If that don't make six times you've dropped it, Mum!'' (this nurse)

'' '' Upon which Mrs. Pocket laughed and said,

``Thank you, Flopson,'' (unknown)
and settling herself in one chair only, resumed her (Mum) book.

Her (Mum) countenance immediately assumed a knitted and intent expression as if she (Mum) had been reading for a week, but before she (Mum) could have read half a dozen lines, she (Mum) fixed her (Mum) eyes upon me, and said,

``I hope your mamma is quite well?

This unexpected inquiry put me into such a difficulty that I began saying in the absurdest way that if there had been any such person I had no doubt she (Mum) would have been quite well and would have been very much obliged and would have sent her (Mum) compliments, when the nurse came to my rescue.

'' (me)

'' Well!'' she (Mum) cried, picking up the pocket-handkerchief, ``if that don't make seven times! What ARE you a doing of this afternoon, Mum!

Mrs. Pocket received her (Pocket) property, at first with a look of unutterable surprise as if she (Pocket) had never seen it before, and then with a laugh of recognition, and said,

``Thank you, Flopson,'' (she)
and forgot me, and went on reading.

I found, now I had leisure to count them, that there were no fewer than six little Pockets present, in various stages of tumbling up.

'' I had scarcely arrived at the total when a seventh was heard, as in the region of air, wailing dolefully.

Millers, who was the other nurse, retired into the house, and by degrees the child's wailing was hushed and stopped, as if it were a young ventriloquist with something in its mouth.

'' If there ain't Baby! '' said Flopson, appearing to think it most surprising.

``Make haste up, Millers. '' (I)
Mrs. Pocket read all the time, and I was curious to know what the book could be.

We were waiting, I supposed, for Mr. Pocket to come out to us; at any rate we waited there, and so I had an opportunity of observing the remarkable family phenomenon that whenever any of the children strayed near Mrs. Pocket in their play, they always tripped themselves up and tumbled over her (Pocket),--always very much to her (Pocket) momentary astonishment, and their own more enduring lamentation.

I was at a loss to account for this surprising circumstance, and could not help giving my mind to speculations about it, until by and by Millers came down with the baby, which baby was handed to Flopson, which Flopson was handing it to Mrs. Pocket, when she (Pocket) too went fairly head foremost over Mrs. Pocket, baby and all, and was caught by Herbert and myself.

'' Gracious me, Flopson! '' said Mrs. Pocket, looking off her (Pocket) book for a moment,

``everybody's tumbling!'' (Mrs. Pocket)
``Gracious you, indeed, Mum!

'' (Flopson)

returned Flopson, very red in the face;
``what have you got there?'' (Flopson)
``I got here, Flopson?'' (unknown)
asked Mrs. Pocket. ''

Why, if it ain't your footstool!'' cried Flopson. '' And if you keep it under your skirts like that, who's to help tumbling?

Mrs. Pocket acted on the advice, and inexpertly danced the infant a little in her (Mum) lap, while the other children played about it.

This had lasted but a very short time, when Mrs. Pocket issued summary orders that they were all to be taken into the house for a nap.

Thus I made the second discovery on that first occasion, that the nurture of the little Pockets consisted of alternately tumbling up and lying down.

Under these circumstances, when Flopson and Millers had got the children into the house, like a little flock of sheep, and Mr. Pocket came out of it to make my acquaintance, I was not much surprised to find that Mr. Pocket was a gentleman with a rather perplexed expression of face, and with his (Pocket) very gray hair disordered on his (Pocket) head, as if he (Pocket) didn't quite see his (Pocket) way to putting anything straight.

Here! Take the baby, Mum, and give me your book. '' Chapter XXIII Mr. Pocket said he (Pocket) was glad to see me, and he (Pocket) hoped I was not sorry to see him (Pocket).

He (Pocket) was a young-looking man, in spite of his (Pocket) perplexities and his (Pocket) very gray hair, and his (Pocket) manner seemed quite natural.

I use the word natural, in the sense of its being unaffected; there was something comic in his (Pocket) distraught way, as though it would have been downright ludicrous but for his (Pocket) own perception that it was very near being so.

When he (Pocket) had talked with me a little, he (Pocket) said to Mrs. Pocket, with a rather anxious contraction of his (Pocket) eyebrows, which were black and handsome,

``Belinda, I hope you have welcomed Mr. Pip?

'' (he)

For, I really am not,'' he (Pip) added, with his (Pip) son's smile,
``an alarming personage. '' (son)
'' And she (Belinda) looked up from her (Belinda) book, and said, ``Yes.

She (Belinda) then smiled upon me in an absent state of mind, and asked me if I liked the taste of orange-flower water?

As the question had no bearing, near or remote, on any foregone or subsequent transaction, I consider it to have been thrown out, like her (Belinda) previous approaches, in general conversational condescension.

I found out within a few hours, and may mention at once, that Mrs. Pocket was the only daughter of a certain quite accidental deceased Knight, who had invented for himself a conviction that his (Knight) deceased father would have been made a Baronet but for somebody's determined opposition arising out of entirely personal motives,--I forget whose, if I ever knew,--the

Sovereign's, the Prime Minister's, the Lord Chancellor's, the Archbishop of Canterbury's, anybody's,--and had tacked himself on to the nobles of the earth in right of this quite supposititious fact.

I believe he (Archbishop) had been knighted himself for storming the English grammar at the point of the pen, in a desperate address engrossed on vellum, on the occasion of the laying of the first stone of some building or other, and for handing some Royal Personage either the trowel or the mortar.

Be that as it may, he (Archbishop) had directed Mrs. Pocket to be brought up from her (anybody) cradle as one who in the nature of things must marry a title, and who was to be guarded from the acquisition of plebeian domestic knowledge.

So successful a watch and ward had been established over the young lady by this judicious parent, that she (lady) had grown up highly ornamental, but perfectly helpless and useless.

With her (lady) character thus happily formed, in the first bloom of her (lady) youth she (lady) had encountered Mr. Pocket: who was also in the first bloom of youth, and not quite decided whether to mount to the Woolsack, or to roof himself in with a mitre.

As his (Pocket) doing the one or the other was a mere question of time, he (Pocket) and Mrs. Pocket had taken Time by the forelock -LRB-when, to judge from its length, it would seem to have wanted cutting-RRB-, and had married without the knowledge of the judicious parent.

The judicious parent, having nothing to bestow or withhold but his (Pocket) blessing, had handsomely settled that dower upon them after a short struggle, and had informed Mr. Pocket that his (Pocket) wife was ``a treasure for a Prince.

Mr. Pocket had invested the Prince's treasure in the ways of the world ever since, and it was supposed to have brought him (Pocket) in but indifferent interest.

Still, Mrs. Pocket was in general the object of a queer sort of respectful pity, because she (wife) had not married a title; while Mr. Pocket was the object of a queer sort of forgiving reproach, because he (Pocket) had never got one.

Mr. Pocket took me into the house and showed me my room: which was a pleasant one, and so furnished as that I could use it with comfort for my own private sitting-room.

He (Pocket) then knocked at the doors of two other similar rooms, and introduced me to their occupants, by name Drummle and Startop.

Startop, younger in years and appearance, was reading and holding his (Drummle) head, as if he (Drummle) thought himself in danger of exploding it with too strong a charge of knowledge.

Both Mr. and Mrs. Pocket had such a noticeable air of being in somebody else's hands, that I wondered who really was in possession of the house and let them live there, until I found this unknown power to be the servants.

It was a smooth way of going on, perhaps, in respect of saving trouble; but it had the appearance of being expensive, for the servants felt it a duty they owed to themselves to be nice in their eating and drinking, and to keep a deal of company downstairs.

They allowed a very liberal table to Mr. and Mrs. Pocket, yet it always appeared to me that by far the best part of the house to have boarded in would have been the kitchen,--always supposing the boarder capable of self-defence, for, before I had been there a week, a neighboring lady with whom the family were personally unacquainted, wrote in to say that she (lady) had seen Millers slapping the baby.

This greatly distressed Mrs. Pocket, who burst into tears on receiving the note, and said that it was an extraordinary thing that the neighbors couldn't mind their own business.

By degrees I learnt, and chiefly from Herbert, that Mr. Pocket had been educated at Harrow and at Cambridge, where he (Pocket) had distinguished himself; but that when he (Pocket) had had the happiness of marrying Mrs. Pocket very early in life, he (Pocket) had impaired his (Pocket) prospects and taken up the calling of a Grinder.

After grinding a number of dull blades,--of whom it was remarkable that their fathers, when influential, were always going to help him (Pocket) to preferment, but always forgot to do it when the blades had left the Grindstone,--he (Pocket) had wearied of that poor work and had come to London.

Here, after gradually failing in loftier hopes, he (Pocket) had

``read'' (he)
with divers who had lacked opportunities or neglected them, and had refurbished divers others for special occasions, and had turned his (Pocket) acquirements to the account of literary compilation and correction, and on such means, added to some very moderate private resources, still maintained the house I saw.

Mr. and Mrs. Pocket had a toady neighbor; a widow lady of that highly sympathetic nature that she (Pocket) agreed with everybody, blessed everybody, and shed smiles and tears on everybody, according to circumstances.

This lady's name was Mrs. Coiler, and I had the honor of taking her (Coiler) down to dinner on the day of my installation.

She (Coiler) gave me to understand on the stairs, that it was a blow to dear Mrs. Pocket that dear Mr. Pocket should be under the necessity of receiving gentlemen to read with him (Pocket).

That did not extend to me, she (Coiler) told me in a gush of love and confidence -LRB-at that time, I had known her (Coiler) something less than five minutes-RRB-; if they were all like Me, it would be quite another thing.

But dear Mrs. Pocket,'' said Mrs. Coiler,

``after her (Coiler) early disappointment -LRB-not that dear Mr. Pocket was to blame in that-RRB-, requires so much luxury and elegance--

'' (Mrs. Coiler)

'' Drummle, an old-looking young man of a heavy order of architecture, was whistling. '' '' '' Yes, ma'am,'' I said, to stop her (Coiler), for I was afraid she (Coiler) was going to cry.

'' And she (Coiler) is of so aristocratic a disposition-- '' '' Yes, ma'am,'' I said again, with the same object as before.

'' --That it is hard,'' said Mrs. Coiler,

``to have dear Mr. Pocket's time and attention diverted from dear Mrs. Pocket.

I could not help thinking that it might be harder if the butcher's time and attention were diverted from dear Mrs. Pocket; but I said nothing, and indeed had enough to do in keeping a bashful watch upon my company manners.

It came to my knowledge, through what passed between Mrs. Pocket and Drummle while I was attentive to my knife and fork, spoon, glasses, and other instruments of self-destruction, that Drummle, whose Christian name was Bentley, was actually the next heir but one to a baronetcy.

It further appeared that the book I had seen Mrs. Pocket reading in the garden was all about titles, and that she (Bentley) knew the exact date at which her (Bentley) grandpapa would have come into the book, if he (Drummle) ever had come at all.

Drummle didn't say much, but in his (Drummle) limited way -LRB-he (Drummle) struck me as a sulky kind of fellow-RRB- he (Drummle) spoke as one of the elect, and recognized Mrs. Pocket as a woman and a sister.

No one but themselves and Mrs. Coiler the toady neighbor showed any interest in this part of the conversation, and it appeared to me that it was painful to Herbert; but it promised to last a long time, when the page came in with the announcement of a domestic affliction.

To my unutterable amazement, I now, for the first time, saw Mr. Pocket relieve his (Pocket) mind by going through a performance that struck me as very extraordinary, but which made no impression on anybody else, and with which I soon became as familiar as the rest.

He (Pocket) laid down the carving-knife and fork,--being engaged in carving, at the moment,--put his (Pocket) two hands into his (Pocket) disturbed hair, and appeared to make an extraordinary effort to lift himself up by it.

When he (Pocket) had done this, and had not lifted himself up at all, he (Pocket) quietly went on with what he (Pocket) was about.

'' (Mrs. Coiler)

It was, in effect, that the cook had mislaid the beef. Mrs. Coiler then changed the subject and began to flatter me.

She (Coiler) had a serpentine way of coming close at me when she (Coiler) pretended to be vitally interested in the friends and localities I had left, which was altogether snaky and fork-tongued; and when she (Coiler) made an occasional bounce upon Startop -LRB-who said very little to her (Coiler)-RRB-, or upon Drummle -LRB-who said less-RRB-, I rather envied them for being on the opposite side of the table.

After dinner the children were introduced, and Mrs. Coiler made admiring comments on their eyes, noses, and legs,--a sagacious way of improving their minds.

There were four little girls, and two little boys, besides the baby who might have been either, and the baby's next successor who was as yet neither.

They were brought in by Flopson and Millers, much as though those two non-commissioned officers had been recruiting somewhere for children and had enlisted these, while Mrs. Pocket looked at the young Nobles that ought to have been as if she (Coiler) rather thought she (Coiler) had had the pleasure of inspecting them before, but didn't quite know what to make of them.

I liked it for a few moments, but she (Coiler) flattered me so very grossly that the pleasure was soon over. ''

Here! Give me your fork, Mum, and take the baby,'' said Flopson. '' Don't take it that way, or you'll get its head under the table.

Thus advised, Mrs. Pocket took it the other way, and got its head upon the table; which was announced to all present by a prodigious concussion.

'' '' Dear, dear! Give it me back, Mum,'' said Flopson;

``and Miss Jane, come and dance to baby, do! '' (Flopson)

One of the little girls, a mere mite who seemed to have prematurely taken upon herself some charge of the others, stepped out of her (Jane) place by me, and danced to and from the baby until it left off crying, and laughed.

Then, all the children laughed, and Mr. Pocket -LRB-who in the meantime had twice endeavored to lift himself up by the hair-RRB- laughed, and we all laughed and were glad.

Flopson, by dint of doubling the baby at the joints like a Dutch doll, then got it safely into Mrs. Pocket's lap, and gave it the nut-crackers to play with; at the same time recommending Mrs. Pocket to take notice that the handles of that instrument were not likely to agree with its eyes, and sharply charging Miss Jane to look after the same.

Then, the two nurses left the room, and had a lively scuffle on the staircase with a dissipated page who had waited at dinner, and who had clearly lost half his (baby) buttons at the gaming-table.

I was made very uneasy in my mind by Mrs. Pocket's falling into a discussion with Drummle respecting two baronetcies, while she (Jane) ate a sliced orange steeped in sugar and wine, and, forgetting all about the baby on her (Jane) lap, who did most appalling things with the nut-crackers.

At length little Jane, perceiving its young brains to be imperilled, softly left her (Jane) place, and with many small artifices coaxed the dangerous weapon away.

Mrs. Pocket finishing her (Jane) orange at about the same time, and not approving of this, said to Jane,--

``You naughty child, how dare you?

Go and sit down this instant!'' (Jane/Miss Jane)

``Mamma dear,'' (the girl ood)
lisped the little girl,
``baby ood have put hith eyeth out. '' (the girl ood)
``How dare you tell me so?'' (unknown)
retorted Mrs. Pocket.

Mrs. Pocket's dignity was so crushing, that I felt quite abashed, as if I myself had done something to rouse it.

``Go and sit down in your chair this moment!'' (Belinda)
'' Belinda,'' remonstrated Mr. Pocket, from the other end of the table,
``how can you be so unreasonable?

Jane only interfered for the protection of baby.'' (Mr. Pocket/Matthew/Mr. Matthew Pocket)

``I will not allow anybody to interfere,'' (I)
said Mrs. Pocket. '' I am surprised, Matthew, that you should expose me to the affront of interference.''

``Good God!'' (Mr. Pocket/Matthew/Mr. Matthew Pocket)
cried Mr. Pocket, in an outbreak of desolate desperation.
``Are infants to be nut-crackered into their tombs, and is nobody to save them?'' (unknown)

``I will not be interfered with by Jane,'' (that offender)
said Mrs. Pocket, with a majestic glance at that innocent little offender. ''

Mr. Pocket got his (Pocket) hands in his (Pocket) hair again, and this time really did lift himself some inches out of his (Pocket) chair.

I hope I know my poor grandpapa's position. Jane, indeed! ''

``Hear this!'' (he)
he (Pocket) helplessly exclaimed to the elements. '' Babies are to be nut-crackered dead, for people's poor grandpapa's positions!

'' Then he (Pocket) let himself down again, and became silent. We all looked awkwardly at the tablecloth while this was going on.

A pause succeeded, during which the honest and irrepressible baby made a series of leaps and crows at little Jane, who appeared to me to be the only member of the family -LRB-irrespective of servants-RRB- with whom it had any decided acquaintance.

'' Mr. Drummle,'' said Mrs. Pocket,

``will you ring for Flopson? Jane, you undutiful little thing, go and lie down. Now, baby darling, come with ma!

It doubled itself up the wrong way over Mrs. Pocket's arm, exhibited a pair of knitted shoes and dimpled ankles to the company in lieu of its soft face, and was carried out in the highest state of mutiny.

And it gained its point after all, for I saw it through the window within a few minutes, being nursed by little Jane.

It happened that the other five children were left behind at the dinner-table, through Flopson's having some private engagement, and their not being anybody else's business.

'' (Mrs. Pocket)

The baby was the soul of honor, and protested with all its might. I thus became aware of the mutual relations between them and Mr. Pocket, which were exemplified in the following manner.

Mr. Pocket, with the normal perplexity of his (Pocket) face heightened and his (Pocket) hair rumpled, looked at them for some minutes, as if he (Pocket) couldn't make out how they came to be boarding and lodging in that establishment, and why they hadn't been billeted by Nature on somebody else.

Then, in a distant Missionary way he (Pocket) asked them certain questions,--as why little Joe had that hole in his (Pocket) frill, who said, Pa, Flopson was going to mend it when she (Joe) had time,--and

Then, he (Pocket) melted into parental tenderness, and gave them a shilling apiece and told them to go and play; and then as they went out, with one very strong effort to lift himself up by the hair he (Pocket) dismissed the hopeless subject.

how little Fanny came by that whitlow, who said, Pa, Millers was going to poultice it when she (Fanny) didn't forget. In the evening there was rowing on the river.

I was pretty good at most exercises in which country boys are adepts, but as I was conscious of wanting elegance of style for the Thames,--not to say for other waters,--I at once engaged to place myself under the tuition of the winner of a prize-wherry who plied at our stairs, and to whom I was introduced by my new allies.

As Drummle and Startop had each a boat, I resolved to set up mine, and to cut them both out. This practical authority confused me very much by saying I had the arm of a blacksmith.

If he (blacksmith) could have known how nearly the compliment lost him (blacksmith) his (blacksmith) pupil, I doubt if he (blacksmith) would have paid it.

There was a supper-tray after we got home at night, and I think we should all have enjoyed ourselves, but for a rather disagreeable domestic occurrence.

Mr. Pocket was in good spirits, when a housemaid came in, and said,

``If you please, sir, I should wish to speak to you.'' (a housemaid)

``Speak to your master?'' (Mrs. Pocket)
said Mrs. Pocket, whose dignity was roused again. '' How can you think of such a thing?

Go and speak to Flopson. Or speak to me--at some other time.''

``Begging your pardon, ma'am,'' (the housemaid)
returned the housemaid,
``I should wish to speak at once, and to speak to master.

'' (the housemaid)

Hereupon, Mr. Pocket went out of the room, and we made the best of ourselves until he (Pocket) came back. ''

Here's the cook lying insensibly drunk on the kitchen floor, with a large bundle of fresh butter made up in the cupboard ready to sell for grease!

This is a pretty thing, Belinda!'' said Mr. Pocket, returning with a countenance expressive of grief and despair. '' '' Mrs. Pocket instantly showed much amiable emotion, and said,

``This is that odious Sophia's doing!'' (I)

Did I not see her (Sophia) with my own eyes and hear her (Sophia) with my own ears, come into the room just now and ask to speak to you?''

'' What do you mean, Belinda?'' demanded Mr. Pocket. '' Sophia has told you,'' said Mrs. Pocket. '' '' But has she (Sophia) not taken me downstairs, Belinda,'' returned Mr. Pocket,

``and shown me the woman, and the bundle too?'' (Mr. Pocket/Matthew/Mr. Matthew Pocket)

'' And do you defend her (Belinda), Matthew,'' said Mrs. Pocket,

``for making mischief? '' (Mrs. Pocket)
Mr. Pocket uttered a dismal groan. ''

Besides, the cook has always been a very nice respectful woman, and said in the most natural manner when she (woman) came to look after the situation, that she (woman) felt I was born to be a Duchess.

Am I, grandpapa's granddaughter, to be nothing in the house?'' said Mrs. Pocket. '' '' There was a sofa where Mr. Pocket stood, and he (Pocket) dropped upon it in the attitude of the Dying Gladiator.

Still in that attitude he (Pocket) said, with a hollow voice,

``Good night, Mr. Pip,'' (he)
when I deemed it advisable to go to bed and leave him (Pip).

After two or three days, when I had established myself in my room and had gone backwards and forwards to London several times, and had ordered all I wanted of my tradesmen, Mr. Pocket and I had a long talk together.

He (Pocket) knew more of my intended career than I knew myself, for he (Pocket) referred to his (Pocket) having been told by Mr. Jaggers that I was not designed for any profession, and that I should be well enough educated for my destiny if I could

``hold my own'' (I)
with the average of young men in prosperous circumstances.

He (Pocket) advised my attending certain places in London, for the acquisition of such mere rudiments as I wanted, and my investing him (Pocket) with the functions of explainer and director of all my studies.

He (director) hoped that with intelligent assistance I should meet with little to discourage me, and should soon be able to dispense with any aid but his (director).

Through his (director) way of saying this, and much more to similar purpose, he (director) placed himself on confidential terms with me in an admirable manner; and I may state at once that he (director) was always so zealous and honorable in fulfilling his (director) compact with me, that he (director) made me zealous and honorable in fulfilling mine with him (director).

Chapter XXIV I acquiesced, of course, knowing nothing to the contrary. If he (director) had shown indifference as a master, I have no doubt

I should have returned the compliment as a pupil; he (pupil) gave me no such excuse, and each of us did the other justice.

Nor did I ever regard him (pupil) as having anything ludicrous about him (pupil)--or anything but what was serious, honest, and good--in his (pupil) tutor communication with me.

When these points were settled, and so far carried out as that I had begun to work in earnest, it occurred to me that if I could retain my bedroom in Barnard's Inn, my life would be agreeably varied, while my manners would be none the worse for Herbert's society.

Mr. Pocket did not object to this arrangement, but urged that before any step could possibly be taken in it, it must be submitted to my guardian.

I felt that this delicacy arose out of the consideration that the plan would save Herbert some expense, so I went off to Little Britain and imparted my wish to Mr. Jaggers.

If I could buy the furniture now hired for me,'' said I,

``and one or two other little things, I should be quite at home there.

'' (I)

''
``Go it!'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
said Mr. Jaggers, with a short laugh. '' I told you you'd get on. Well! How much do you want?

'' I said I didn't know how much.

``Come! '' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
retorted Mr. Jaggers. '' How much? Fifty pounds?''
``O, not nearly so much.'' (unknown)

''

``More than that, eh!'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
retorted Mr. Jaggers, lying in wait for me, with his (Jaggers) hands in his (Jaggers) pockets, his (Jaggers) head on one side, and his (Jaggers) eyes on the wall behind me;
``how much more?'' (me)

``Five pounds?'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
said Mr. Jaggers. This was such a great fall, that I said in discomfiture, ``O, more than that.
``It is so difficult to fix a sum,'' (I)
said I, hesitating.

``Come!'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
said Mr. Jaggers. '' Let's get at it. Twice five; will that do? Three times five; will that do? Four times five; will that do?

'' I said I thought that would do handsomely. '' Four times five will do handsomely, will it?'' said Mr. Jaggers, knitting his (Jaggers) brows.

'' Now, what do you make of four times five?'' '' What do I make of it?''

``Ah!'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
said Mr. Jaggers;
``how much?'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)

``I suppose you make it twenty pounds,'' (I)
said I, smiling. '' Never mind what I make it, my friend,'' observed Mr. Jaggers, with a knowing and contradictory toss of his (Jaggers) head.

'' I want to know what you make it.'' '' Twenty pounds, of course.''

``Wemmick!'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
said Mr. Jaggers, opening his (Jaggers) office door.

This strongly marked way of doing business made a strongly marked impression on me, and that not of an agreeable kind.

Mr. Jaggers never laughed; but he (Jaggers) wore great bright creaking boots, and, in poising himself on these boots, with his (Jaggers) large head bent down and his (Jaggers) eyebrows joined together, awaiting an answer, he (Jaggers) sometimes caused the boots to creak, as if they laughed in a dry and suspicious way.

As he (Jaggers) happened to go out now, and as Wemmick was brisk and talkative, I said to Wemmick that I hardly knew what to make of Mr. Jaggers's manner.

``Tell him (Jaggers) that, and he (Jaggers)'ll take it as a compliment,'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
answered Wemmick;
``he (Wemmick) don't mean that you should know what to make of it.--Oh!

'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

Take Mr. Pip's written order, and pay him (Pip) twenty pounds. '' '' for I looked surprised,
``it's not personal; it's professional: only professional.

Wemmick was at his (Wemmick) desk, lunching--and crunching--on a dry hard biscuit; pieces of which he (Wemmick) threw from time to time into his (Wemmick) slit of a mouth, as if he (Wemmick) were posting them.

'' (I)

'' Always seems to me,'' said Wemmick,
``as if he (Wemmick) had set a man-trap and was watching it. Suddenly-click-- you're caught!'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

Without remarking that man-traps were not among the amenities of life, I said I supposed he (Wemmick) was very skilful? '' Deep,'' said Wemmick,

``as Australia.

Pointing with his (Wemmick) pen at the office floor, to express that Australia was understood, for the purposes of the figure, to be symmetrically on the opposite spot of the globe.

'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

'' If there was anything deeper,'' added Wemmick, bringing his (Wemmick) pen to paper,
``he (Wemmick)'d be it. '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
Then, I said I supposed he (Wemmick) had a fine business, and Wemmick said,
``Ca-pi-tal!'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

Then I asked if there were many clerks? to which he (Wemmick) replied,--

``We don't run much into clerks, because there's only one Jaggers, and people won't have him (Jaggers) at second hand.

There are only four of us. Would you like to see 'em? You are one of us, as I may say.

When Mr. Wemmick had put all the biscuit into the post, and had paid me my money from a cash-box in a safe, the key of which safe he (Wemmick) kept somewhere down his (Wemmick) back and produced from his (Wemmick) coat-collar like an iron-pigtail, we went upstairs.

The house was dark and shabby, and the greasy shoulders that had left their mark in Mr. Jaggers's room seemed to have been shuffling up and down the staircase for years.

In the front first floor, a clerk who looked something between a publican and a rat-catcher--a large pale, puffed, swollen man--was attentively engaged with three or four people of shabby appearance, whom he (man) treated as unceremoniously as everybody seemed to be treated who contributed to Mr. Jaggers's coffers.

In the room over that, a little flabby terrier of a clerk with dangling hair -LRB-his (terrier) cropping seemed to have been forgotten when he (terrier) was a puppy-RRB- was similarly engaged with a man with weak eyes, whom Mr. Wemmick presented to me as a smelter who kept his (Wemmick) pot always boiling, and who would melt me anything

'' (he)

I accepted the offer. '' Getting evidence together,'' said Mr. Wemmick, as we came out,
``for the Bailey. '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
I pleased,--and who was in an excessive white-perspiration, as if he (Wemmick) had been trying his (Wemmick) art on himself.

In a back room, a high-shouldered man with a face-ache tied up in dirty flannel, who was dressed in old black clothes that bore the appearance of having been waxed, was stooping over his (man) work of making fair copies of the notes of the other two gentlemen, for Mr. Jaggers's own use.

This was all the establishment. When we went downstairs again, Wemmick led me into my guardian's room, and said,

``This you've seen already.'' (guardian)

``Pray,'' (I)
said I, as the two odious casts with the twitchy leer upon them caught my sight again,
``whose likenesses are those?'' (I)

``These?'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
said Wemmick, getting upon a chair, and blowing the dust off the horrible heads before bringing them down. '' These are two celebrated ones.

This chap -LRB-why you must have come down in the night and been peeping into the inkstand, to get this blot upon your eyebrow, you old rascal!-RRB-

Famous clients of ours that got us a world of credit. murdered his (rascal) master, and, considering that he (rascal) wasn't brought up to evidence, didn't plan it badly.''

'' I asked, recoiling from the brute, as Wemmick spat upon his (Wemmick) eyebrow and gave it a rub with his (Wemmick) sleeve.

``Is it like him (Wemmick)? ``Like him (Wemmick)? It's himself, you know. The cast was made in Newgate, directly after he (Wemmick) was taken down.

He (Wemmick) then explained this affectionate apostrophe, by touching his (Wemmick) brooch representing the lady and the weeping willow at the tomb with the urn upon it, and saying,

``Had it made for me, express!'' (the lady willow)

You had a particular fancy for me, hadn't you, Old Artful?'' said Wemmick.

``Is the lady anybody?'' (I.)
said I.
``No,'' (I.)
returned Wemmick.

No; deuce a bit of a lady in the case, Mr. Pip, except one,--and she (lady) wasn't of this slender lady-like sort, and you wouldn't have caught her (lady) looking after this urn, unless there was something to drink in it.

'' Only his (Pip) game. -LRB-You liked your bit of game, didn't you?-RRB- '' Wemmick's attention being thus directed to his (Wemmick) brooch, he (Wemmick) put down the cast, and polished the brooch with his (Wemmick) pocket-handkerchief.

'' Did that other creature come to the same end? '' I asked. '' He (Wemmick) has the same look. '' ''

You're right,'' said Wemmick;

``it's the genuine look. Much as if one nostril was caught up with a horse-hair and a little fish-hook.

Yes, he (Wemmick) came to the same end; quite the natural end here, I assure you. He (Wemmick) forged wills, this blade did, if he (Wemmick) didn't also put the supposed testators to sleep too.

You were a gentlemanly Cove, though '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

-LRB-Mr. Wemmick was again apostrophizing-RRB-, ``and you said you could write Greek. Yah, Bounceable!

Before putting his (Wemmick) late friend on his (Wemmick) shelf again, Wemmick touched the largest of his (Wemmick) mourning rings and said,

``Sent out to buy it for me, only the day before.

While he (Wemmick) was putting up the other cast and coming down from the chair, the thought crossed my mind that all his (Wemmick) personal jewelry was derived from like sources.

As he (Wemmick) had shown no diffidence on the subject, I ventured on the liberty of asking him (Wemmick) the question, when he (Wemmick) stood before me, dusting his (Wemmick) hands.

What a liar you were! I never met such a liar as you!'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

'' '' O yes,'' he (liar) returned, ``these are all gifts of that kind.

One brings another, you see; that's the way of it. I always take 'em. They're curiosities. And they're property. They may not be worth much, but, after all, they're property and portable.

It don't signify to you with your brilliant lookout, but as to myself, my guiding-star always is, `Get hold of portable property'.

``If at any odd time when you have nothing better to do, you wouldn't mind coming over to see me at Walworth, I could offer you a bed, and I should consider it an honor.

I have not much to show you; but such two or three curiosities as I have got you might like to look over; and I am fond of a bit of garden and a summer-house.

'' (I)

When I had rendered homage to this light, he (you) went on to say, in a friendly manner:-- '' I said I should be delighted to accept his (you) hospitality.

'' Thankee,'' said he (you);

``then we'll consider that it's to come off, when convenient to you. Have you dined with Mr. Jaggers yet?'' (he)

``Not yet. '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
'' Well,'' said Wemmick,
``he (Wemmick)'ll give you wine, and good wine. I'll give you punch, and not bad punch.

And now I'll tell you something. When you go to dine with Mr. Jaggers, look at his (Jaggers) housekeeper.'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

'' Shall I see something very uncommon?''

'' Well,'' said Wemmick,

``you'll see a wild beast tamed. Not so very uncommon, you'll tell me. I reply, that depends on the original wildness of the beast, and the amount of taming.

It won't lower your opinion of Mr. Jaggers's powers. Keep your eye on it. '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

I told him (Jaggers) I would do so, with all the interest and curiosity that his (Jaggers) preparation awakened.

As I was taking my departure, he (Jaggers) asked me if I would like to devote five minutes to seeing Mr. Jaggers ``at it?

For several reasons, and not least because I didn't clearly know what Mr. Jaggers would be found to be

``at,'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
I replied in the affirmative.

We dived into the City, and came up in a crowded police-court, where a blood-relation -LRB-in the murderous sense-RRB- of the deceased, with the fanciful taste in brooches, was standing at the bar, uncomfortably chewing something; while my guardian had a woman under examination or cross-examination,--I don't know which,--and was striking her (woman), and the bench, and everybody present, with awe.

If anybody, of whatsoever degree, said a word that he (I) didn't approve of, he (I) instantly required to have it ``taken down.

If anybody wouldn't make an admission, he (I) said,

``I'll have it out of you!'' (he)
and if anybody made an admission, he (I) said,
``Now I have got you!'' (he)

Thieves and thief-takers hung in dread rapture on his (I) words, and shrank when a hair of his (I) eyebrows turned in their direction.

I couldn't make out, for he (I) seemed to me to be grinding the whole place in a mill; I only know that when I stole out on tiptoe, he (I) was not on the side of the bench; for, he (I) was making the legs of the old gentleman who presided, quite convulsive under the table, by his (I) denunciations of his (I) conduct as the representative of British law and justice in that chair that day.

Chapter XXV Bentley Drummle, who was so sulky a fellow that he (fellow) even took up a book as if its writer had done him (writer) an injury, did not take up an acquaintance in a more agreeable spirit.

Heavy in figure, movement, and comprehension,--in the sluggish complexion of his (acquaintance) face, and in the large, awkward tongue that seemed to loll about in his (acquaintance) mouth as he (acquaintance) himself lolled about in

'' '' The magistrates shivered under a single bite of his (acquaintance) finger. Which side he (acquaintance) was on a room,--he (acquaintance) was idle, proud, niggardly, reserved, and suspicious.

He (acquaintance) came of rich people down in Somersetshire, who had nursed this combination of qualities until they made the discovery that it was just of age and a blockhead.

Thus, Bentley Drummle had come to Mr. Pocket when he (Pocket) was a head taller than that gentleman, and half a dozen heads thicker than most gentlemen.

Startop had been spoilt by a weak mother and kept at home when he (Pocket) ought to have been at school, but he (Pocket) was devotedly attached to her (mother), and admired her (mother) beyond measure.

He (Pocket) had a woman's delicacy of feature, and was--

``as you may see, though you never saw her (mother),'' (a woman)
said Herbert to me--
``exactly like his (Herbert) mother.

It was but natural that I should take to him (Herbert) much more kindly than to Drummle, and that, even in the earliest evenings of our boating, he (Herbert) and I should pull homeward abreast of one another, conversing from boat to boat, while Bentley Drummle came up in our wake alone, under the overhanging banks and among the rushes.

He (Herbert) would always creep in-shore like some uncomfortable amphibious creature, even when the tide would have sent him (Herbert) fast upon his (Herbert) way; and I always think of him (Herbert) as coming after us in the dark or by the back-water, when our own two boats were breaking the sunset or the moonlight in mid-stream.

I presented him (Herbert) with a half-share in my boat, which was the occasion of his (Herbert) often coming down to Hammersmith; and my possession of a half-share in his (Herbert) chambers often took me up to London.

I have an affection for the road yet -LRB-though it is not so pleasant a road as it was then-RRB-, formed in the impressibility of untried youth and hope.

'' (me)

Herbert was my intimate companion and friend. We used to walk between the two places at all hours. When I had been in Mr. Pocket's family a month or two, Mr. and Mrs. Camilla turned up.

Camilla was Mr. Pocket's sister. Georgiana, whom I had seen at Miss Havisham's on the same occasion, also turned up. She (Georgiana) was a cousin,--an indigestive single woman, who called her (Georgiana) rigidity religion, and her (Georgiana) liver love.

These people hated me with the hatred of cupidity and disappointment. As a matter of course, they fawned upon me in my prosperity with the basest meanness.

Towards Mr. Pocket, as a grown-up infant with no notion of his (Pocket) own interests, they showed the complacent forbearance I had heard them express.

Mrs. Pocket they held in contempt; but they allowed the poor soul to have been heavily disappointed in life, because that shed a feeble reflected light upon themselves.

I soon contracted expensive habits, and began to spend an amount of money that within a few short months I should have thought almost fabulous; but through good and evil I stuck to my books.

These were the surroundings among which I settled down, and applied myself to my education. There was no other merit in this, than my having sense enough to feel my deficiencies.

I got on fast; and, with one or the other always at my elbow to give me the start I wanted, and clear obstructions out of my road, I must have been as great a dolt as Drummle if I had done less.

I had not seen Mr. Wemmick for some weeks, when I thought I would write him (Wemmick) a note and propose to go home with him (Wemmick) on a certain evening.

He (Wemmick) replied that it would give him (Wemmick) much pleasure, and that he (Wemmick) would expect me at the office at six o'clock.

Thither I went, and there I found him (Wemmick), putting the key of his (Wemmick) safe down his (Wemmick) back as the clock struck.

Between Mr. Pocket and Herbert '' Did you think of walking down to Walworth?'' said he (Pocket). '' Certainly,'' said I, ``if you approve.

``Very much,'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
was Wemmick's reply,
``for I have had my legs under the desk all day, and shall be glad to stretch them.

'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

Now, I'll tell you what I have got for supper, Mr. Pip. I have got a stewed steak,--which is of home

I think it's tender, because the master of the shop was a Juryman in some cases of ours the other day, and we let him (master) down easy.

I reminded him (master) of it when I bought the fowl, and I said,

``Pick us out a good one, old Briton, because if we had chosen to keep you in the box another day or two, we could easily have done it.

preparation,--and a cold roast fowl,--which is from the cook's-shop. '' (I)

He (cook) said to that,
``Let me make you a present of the best fowl in the shop.

'' (He)

I let him (cook), of course. As far as it goes, it's property and portable. You don't object to an aged parent, I hope?

I really thought he (cook) was still speaking of the fowl, until he (cook) added,

``Because I have got an aged parent at my place.

'' (he)

'' I then said what politeness required. '' So, you haven't dined with Mr. Jaggers yet? '' he (Jaggers) pursued, as we walked along.

'' Not yet. '' '' He (Jaggers) told me so this afternoon when he (Jaggers) heard you were coming. I expect you'll have an invitation to-morrow.

He (Jaggers)'s going to ask your pals, too. Three of 'em; ain't there? '' Although I was not in the habit of counting Drummle as one of my intimate associates, I answered,

``Yes.'' (I)

Well, he (Drummle)'s going to ask the whole gang,''--I hardly felt complimented by the word,--

``and whatever he (Drummle) gives you, he (Drummle)'ll give you good.

And there's another rum thing in his (Drummle) house,'' (I)

proceeded Wemmick, after a moment's pause, as if the remark followed on the housekeeper understood;
``he (Wemmick) never lets a door or window be fastened at night.'' (the housekeeper)

'' Don't look forward to variety, but you'll have excellence. '' Is he (Wemmick) never robbed?'' '' That's it! '' returned Wemmick.

I have heard him (Wemmick), a hundred times, if I have heard him (Wemmick) once, say to regular cracksmen in our front office,

``You know where I live; now, no bolt is ever drawn there; why don't you do a stroke of business with me?

'' (him)

He (Wemmick) says, and gives it out publicly,
``I want to see the man who'll rob me.'' (He)
Lord bless you, Come;

can't I tempt you? '' Not a man of them, sir, would be bold enough to try it on, for love or money.''

``They dread him (man) so much?'' (I.)
said I.
``Dread him (man),'' (I.)
said Wemmick. '' I believe you they dread him (Wemmick). Not but what he (Wemmick)'s artful, even in his (Wemmick) defiance of them.

No silver, sir. Britannia metal, every spoon. '' '' So they wouldn't have much,'' I observed,

``even if they-- '' (I)
``Ah!

But he (Wemmick) would have much,'' (I)

said Wemmick, cutting me short,
``and they know it. He (Wemmick)'d have their lives, and the lives of scores of 'em.

He (Wemmick)'d have all he (Wemmick) could get. And it's impossible to say what he (Wemmick) couldn't get, if he (Wemmick) gave his (Wemmick) mind to it.

'' (me)

I was falling into meditation on my guardian's greatness, when Wemmick remarked:--
``As to the absence of plate, that's only his (Wemmick) natural depth, you know.

A river's its natural depth, and he (Wemmick)'s his (Wemmick) natural depth. Look at his (Wemmick) watch-chain. That's real enough. '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

'' It's very massive,'' said I.
``Massive?

'' (I.)

repeated Wemmick. '' I think so. And his (Wemmick) watch is a gold repeater, and worth a hundred pound if it's worth a penny.

Mr. Pip, there are about seven hundred thieves in this town who know all about that watch; there's not a man, a woman, or a child, among them, who wouldn't identify the smallest link in that chain, and drop it as if it was red hot, if inveigled into touching it.

At first with such discourse, and afterwards with conversation of a more general nature, did Mr. Wemmick and I beguile the time and the road, until he (Wemmick) gave me to understand that we had arrived in the district of Walworth.

It appeared to be a collection of back lanes, ditches, and little gardens, and to present the aspect of a rather dull retirement.

Wemmick's house was a little wooden cottage in the midst of plots of garden, and the top of it was cut out and painted like a battery mounted with guns.

I highly commended it, I think it was the smallest house I ever saw; with the queerest gothic windows -LRB-by far the greater part of them sham-RRB-, and a gothic door almost too small to get in at.

'' '' My own doing,'' said Wemmick. '' Looks pretty; don't it? '' '' That's a real flagstaff, you see,'' said Wemmick,

``and on Sundays I run up a real flag.

Then look here. After I have crossed this bridge, I hoist it up--so--and cut off the communication. '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

The bridge was a plank, and it crossed a chasm about four feet wide and two deep.

But it was very pleasant to see the pride with which he (Wemmick) hoisted it up and made it fast; smiling as he (Wemmick) did so, with a relish and not merely mechanically.

'' At nine o'clock every night, Greenwich time,'' said Wemmick,

``the gun fires. There he (Wemmick) is, you see! And when you hear him (Wemmick) go, I think you'll say he (Wemmick)'s a Stinger.

'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

The piece of ordnance referred to, was mounted in a separate fortress, constructed of lattice-work. It was protected from the weather by an ingenious little tarpaulin contrivance in the nature of an umbrella.

it's a principle with me, if you have an idea, carry it out and keep it up,--I don't know whether that's your opinion--'' I said, decidedly.

'' Then, at the back,'' said Wemmick,

``out of sight, so as not to impede the idea of fortifications,--for '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
--At

; then, I knock together my own little frame, you see, and grow cucumbers; and you'll judge at supper what sort of a salad I can raise.

So, sir,'' said Wemmick, smiling again, but seriously too, as he (Wemmick) shook his (Wemmick) head,

``if you can suppose the little place besieged, it would hold out a devil of a time in point of provisions.

Then, he (devil) conducted me to a bower about a dozen yards off, but which was approached by such ingenious twists of path that it took quite a long time to get at; and in this retreat our glasses were already set forth.

the back, there's a pig, and there are fowls and rabbits '' (he)

Our punch was cooling in an ornamental lake, on whose margin the bower was raised.

This piece of water -LRB-with an island in the middle which might have been the salad for supper-RRB- was of a circular form, and he (it) had constructed a fountain in it, which, when you set a little mill going and took a cork out of a pipe, played to that powerful extent that it made the back of your hand quite wet.

I am my own engineer, and my own carpenter, and my own plumber, and my own gardener, and my own Jack of all Trades,'' said Wemmick, in acknowledging my compliments.

'' '' Well; it's a good thing, you know. It brushes the Newgate cobwebs away, and pleases the Aged. You wouldn't mind being at once introduced to the Aged, would you?

There we found, sitting by a fire, a very old man in a flannel coat: clean, cheerful, comfortable, and well cared for, but intensely deaf.

It wouldn't put you out? '' I expressed the readiness I felt, and we went into the castle. '' Well aged parent,'' said Wemmick, shaking hands with him (Wemmick) in a cordial and jocose way,

``how am you?'' (him)

'' All right, John; all right! '' replied the old man. '' Here's Mr. Pip, aged parent,'' said Wemmick,

``and I wish you could hear his (Wemmick) name.

This is a fine place of my son's, sir,'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

cried the old man, while I nodded as hard as I possibly could.

Nod away at him (man), Mr. Pip; that's what he (Pip) likes. Nod away at him (Pip), if you please, like winking!'' '' ''

This spot and these beautiful works upon it ought to be kept together by the Nation, after my son's time, for the people's enjoyment.''

'' said Wemmick, contemplating the old man, with his (Wemmick) hard face really softened;

``there's a nod for you;'' (the man)
giving him (Wemmick) a tremendous one;
``there's another for you;'' (him)
giving him (Wemmick) a still more tremendous one; ``you like that, don't you?

This is a pretty pleasure-ground, sir.

``You're as proud of it as Punch; ain't you, Aged? If you're not tired, Mr. Pip--though I know it's tiring to strangers--will you tip him (Pip) one more?

We left him (Pip) bestirring himself to feed the fowls, and we sat down to our punch in the arbor; where Wemmick told me, as he (Wemmick) smoked a pipe, that it had taken him (Wemmick) a good many years to bring the property up to its present pitch of perfection.

You can't think how it pleases him (Wemmick). '' (I)

I tipped him (Wemmick) several more, and he (Wemmick) was in great spirits. '' Is it your own, Mr. Wemmick?''

``O yes,'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
said Wemmick,
``I have got hold of it, a bit at a time. It's a freehold, by George!'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
``Is it indeed?

I hope Mr. Jaggers admires it?'' (unknown)

``Never seen it,'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
said Wemmick. '' Never heard of it. Never seen the Aged. Never heard of him (Wemmick).

When I go into the office, I leave the Castle behind me, and when I come into the Castle, I leave the office behind me.

No; the office is one thing, and private life is another. If it's not in any way disagreeable to you, you'll oblige me by doing the same.

I don't wish it professionally spoken about. '' Of course I felt my good faith involved in the observance of his (Wemmick) request.

The punch being very nice, we sat there drinking it and talking, until it was almost nine o'clock. '' Getting near gun-fire,'' said Wemmick then, as he (Wemmick) laid down his (Wemmick) pipe; ``it's the Aged's treat.

Proceeding into the Castle again, we found the Aged heating the poker, with expectant eyes, as a preliminary to the performance of this great nightly ceremony.

Wemmick stood with his (Wemmick) watch in his (Wemmick) hand until the moment was come for him (Wemmick) to take the red-hot poker from the Aged, and repair to the battery.

He (Wemmick) took it, and went out, and presently the Stinger went off with a Bang that shook the crazy little box of a cottage as if it must fall to pieces, and made every glass and teacup in it ring.

Upon this, the Aged--who I believe would have been blown out of his (Wemmick) arm-chair but for holding on by the elbows--cried out exultingly, ``He (Wemmick)'s fired!

and I nodded at the old gentleman until it is no figure of speech to declare that I absolutely could not see him (Wemmick).

They were mostly of a felonious character; comprising the pen with which a celebrated forgery had been committed, a distinguished razor or two, some locks of hair, and several manuscript confessions written under condemnation,--upon which Mr. Wemmick set particular value as being, to use his (Wemmick) own words,

``every one of 'em Lies, sir.

'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

I heerd him (Wemmick)!'' The interval between that time and supper Wemmick devoted to showing me his (Wemmick) collection of curiosities. ''

These were agreeably dispersed among small specimens of china and glass, various neat trifles made by the proprietor of the museum, and some tobacco-stoppers carved by the Aged.

They were all displayed in that chamber of the Castle into which I had been first inducted, and which served, not only as the general sitting-room but as the kitchen too, if I might judge from a saucepan on the hob, and a brazen bijou over the fireplace designed for the suspension of a roasting-jack.

When she (Wemmick) had laid the supper-cloth, the bridge was lowered to give her (Wemmick) means of egress, and she (Wemmick) withdrew for the night.

The supper was excellent; and though the Castle was rather subject to dry-rot insomuch that it tasted like a bad nut, and though the pig might have been farther off, I was heartily pleased with my whole entertainment.

Nor was there any drawback on my little turret bedroom, beyond there being such a very thin ceiling between me and the flagstaff, that when I lay down on my back in bed, it seemed as if I had to balance that pole on my forehead all night.

There was a neat little girl in attendance, who looked after the Aged in the day. Wemmick was up early in the morning, and I am afraid I heard him (Wemmick) cleaning my boots.

After that, he (Wemmick) fell to gardening, and I saw him (Wemmick) from my gothic window pretending to employ the Aged, and nodding at him (Wemmick) in a most devoted manner.

Our breakfast was as good as the supper, and at half-past eight precisely we started for Little Britain. By degrees, Wemmick got dryer and harder as we went along, and his (Wemmick) mouth tightened into a post-office again.

and he (Wemmick) pulled out his (Wemmick) key from his (Wemmick) coat-collar, he (Wemmick) looked as unconscious of his (Wemmick) Walworth property as if the Castle and the drawbridge and the arbor and the lake and the fountain and the Aged, had all been blown into space together by the last discharge of the Stinger.

It fell out as Wemmick had told me it would, that I had an early opportunity of comparing my guardian's establishment with that of his (Wemmick) cashier and clerk.

My guardian was in his (Wemmick) room, washing his (Wemmick) hands with his (Wemmick) scented soap, when I went into the office from Walworth; and he (Wemmick) called me to him (Wemmick), and gave me the invitation for myself and friends which Wemmick had prepared me to receive.

At last, when we got to his (Wemmick) place of business Chapter XXVI '' No ceremony,'' he (Wemmick) stipulated, ``and no dinner dress, and say to-morrow.

I asked him (Wemmick) where we should come to -LRB-for I had no idea where he (Wemmick) lived-RRB-, and I believe it was in his (Wemmick) general objection to make anything like an admission, that he (Wemmick) replied,

``Come here, and

I embrace this opportunity of remarking that he (Wemmick) washed his (Wemmick) clients off, as if he (Wemmick) were a surgeon or a dentist.

He (Wemmick) had a closet in his (Wemmick) room, fitted up for the purpose, which smelt of the scented soap like a perfumer's shop.

It had an unusually large jack-towel on a roller inside the door, and he (Wemmick) would wash his (Wemmick) hands, and wipe them and dry them all over this towel, whenever he (Wemmick) came in from a police court or dismissed a client from his (Wemmick) room.

When I and my friends repaired to him (Wemmick) at six o'clock next day, he (Wemmick) seemed to have been engaged on a case of a darker complexion than usual, for we found him (Wemmick) with his (Wemmick) head butted into this closet, not only washing his (Wemmick) hands, but laving his (Wemmick) face and gargling his (Wemmick) throat.

And even when he (Wemmick) had done all that, and had gone all round the jack-towel, he (Wemmick) took out his (Wemmick) penknife and scraped the case out of his (Wemmick) nails before he (Wemmick) put his (Wemmick) coat on.

There were some people slinking about as usual when we passed out into the street, who were evidently anxious to speak with him (Wemmick); but there was something so conclusive in the halo of scented soap which encircled his (Wemmick) presence, that they gave it up for that day.

As we walked along westward, he (Wemmick) was recognized ever and again by some face in the crowd of the streets, and whenever that happened he (Wemmick) talked louder to me; but he (Wemmick) never otherwise recognized anybody, or took notice that anybody recognized him (Wemmick).

'' (he)

I'll take you home with me. '' He (Wemmick) conducted us to Gerrard Street, Soho, to a house on the south side of that street.

He (Wemmick) took out his (Wemmick) key and opened the door, and we all went into a stone hall, bare, gloomy, and little used.

Rather a stately house of its kind, but dolefully in want of painting, and with dirty windows. So, up a dark brown staircase into a series of three dark brown rooms on the first floor.

There were carved garlands on the panelled walls, and as he (Wemmick) stood among them giving us welcome, I know what kind of loops I thought they looked like.

Dinner was laid in the best of these rooms; the second was his (Wemmick) dressing-room; the third, his (Wemmick) bedroom. He (Wemmick) told us that he (Wemmick) held the whole house, but rarely used more of it than we saw.

The table was comfortably laid--no silver in the service, of course--and at the side of his (Wemmick) chair was a capacious dumb-waiter, with a variety of bottles and decanters on it, and four dishes of fruit for dessert.

There was a bookcase in the room; I saw from the backs of the books, that they were about evidence, criminal law, criminal biography, trials, acts of Parliament, and such things.

I noticed throughout, that he (Wemmick) kept everything under his (Wemmick) own hand, and distributed everything himself. The furniture was all very solid and good, like his (Wemmick) watch-chain.

In a corner was a little table of papers with a shaded lamp: so that he (Wemmick) seemed to bring the office home with him (Wemmick) in that respect too, and to wheel it out of an evening and fall to work.

It had an official look, however, and there was nothing merely ornamental to be seen. As he (Wemmick) had scarcely seen my three companions until now,--for he (Wemmick) and I had walked

together,--he (Wemmick) stood on the hearth-rug, after ringing the bell, and took a searching look at them. To my surprise, he (Wemmick) seemed at once to be principally if not solely interested in Drummle. ''

Pip,'' said he (Wemmick), putting his (Wemmick) large hand on my shoulder and moving me to the window,

``I don't know one from the other.

Who's the Spider?'' (me)

``The spider?'' (I.)
said I.
``The blotchy, sprawly, sulky fellow. '' (I.)
'' That's Bentley Drummle,'' I replied;
``the one with the delicate face is Startop.

'' (I)

Not making the least account of
``the one with the delicate face,'' (he)
he (fellow) returned,
``Bentley Drummle is his (fellow) name, is it?

He (fellow) immediately began to talk to Drummle: not at all deterred by his (fellow) replying in his (fellow) heavy reticent way, but apparently led on by it to screw discourse out of him (fellow).

I was looking at the two, when there came between me and them the housekeeper, with the first dish for the table.

I like the look of that fellow. '' (he)

She (housekeeper) was a woman of about forty, I supposed,--but I may have thought her (housekeeper) younger than she (housekeeper) was.

I cannot say whether any diseased affection of the heart caused her (housekeeper) lips to be parted as if she (housekeeper) were panting, and her (housekeeper) face to bear a curious expression of suddenness and flutter; but I know that I had been to see Macbeth at the theatre, a night or two before, and that her (housekeeper) face looked to me as if it were all disturbed by fiery air, like the faces I had seen rise out of the Witches' caldron.

She (housekeeper) set the dish on, touched my guardian quietly on the arm with a finger to notify that dinner was ready, and vanished.

We took our seats at the round table, and my guardian kept Drummle on one side of him (Drummle), while Startop sat on the other.

It was a noble dish of fish that the housekeeper had put on table, and we had a joint of equally choice mutton afterwards, and then an equally choice bird.

Sauces, wines, all the accessories we wanted, and all of the best, were given out by our host from his (Drummle) dumb-waiter; and when they had made the circuit of the table, he (Drummle) always put them back again.

Similarly, he (Drummle) dealt us clean plates and knives and forks, for each course, and dropped those just disused into two baskets on the ground by his (Drummle) chair.

Rather tall, of a lithe nimble figure, extremely pale, with large faded eyes, and a quantity of streaming hair. No other attendant than the housekeeper appeared.

Years afterwards, I made a dreadful likeness of that woman, by causing a face that had no other natural resemblance to it than it derived from flowing hair to pass behind a bowl of flaming spirits in a dark room.

Induced to take particular notice of the housekeeper, both by her (housekeeper) own striking appearance and by Wemmick's preparation, I observed that whenever she (housekeeper) was in the room she (housekeeper) kept her (housekeeper) eyes attentively on my guardian, and that she (housekeeper) would remove her (housekeeper) hands from any dish she (housekeeper) put before him (Wemmick), hesitatingly, as if she (housekeeper) dreaded his (Wemmick) calling her (housekeeper) back, and wanted him (Wemmick) to speak when she (housekeeper) was nigh, if he (Wemmick) had anything to say.

I fancied that I could detect in his (Wemmick) manner a consciousness of this, and a purpose of always holding her (housekeeper) in suspense.

Dinner went off gayly, and although my guardian seemed to follow rather than originate subjects, I knew that he (Wemmick) wrenched the weakest part of our dispositions out of us.

For myself, I found that I was expressing my tendency to lavish expenditure, and to patronize Herbert, and to boast of my great prospects, before I quite knew that I had opened my lips.

It was so with all of us, but with no one more than Drummle: the development of whose inclination to gird in a grudging and suspicious way at the rest, was screwed out of him (Herbert) before the fish was taken off.

It was not then, but when we had got to the cheese, that our conversation turned upon our rowing feats, and that Drummle was rallied for coming up behind of a night in that slow amphibious way of his (Drummle).

Drummle upon this, informed our host that he (Drummle) much preferred our room to our company, and that as to skill he (Drummle) was more than our master, and that as to strength he (Drummle) could scatter us like chaff.

By some invisible agency, my guardian wound him (Drummle) up to a pitch little short of ferocity about this trifle; and he (Drummle) fell to baring and spanning his (Drummle) arm to show how muscular it was, and we all fell to baring and spanning our arms in a ridiculous manner.

Now the housekeeper was at that time clearing the table; my guardian, taking no heed of her (housekeeper), but with the side of his (Drummle) face turned from her (housekeeper), was leaning back in his (Drummle) chair biting the side of his (Drummle) forefinger and showing an interest in Drummle, that, to me, was quite inexplicable.

She (housekeeper) set on every dish; and I always saw in her (housekeeper) face, a face rising out of the caldron. Suddenly, he (Drummle) clapped his (Drummle) large hand on the housekeeper's, like a trap, as she (housekeeper) stretched it across the table.

So suddenly and smartly did he (Drummle) do this, that we all stopped in our foolish contention. '' If you talk of strength,'' said Mr. Jaggers,

``I'll show you a wrist.

Molly, let them see your wrist. '' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)

Her (Molly) entrapped hand was on the table, but she (Molly) had already put her (Molly) other hand behind her (Molly) waist.

'' Master,'' she (Molly) said, in a low voice, with her (Molly) eyes attentively and entreatingly fixed upon him (Master). '' Don't. ''

``I'll show you a wrist,'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
repeated Mr. Jaggers, with an immovable determination to show it.

Molly,'' said Mr. Jaggers, not looking at her (Molly), but obstinately looking at the opposite side of the room,

``let them see both your wrists.

'' (her)

Molly, let them see your wrist.''
``Master,'' (she)
she (Molly) again murmured.
``Please!'' (unknown)
'' Show them. Come!'' He (Master) took his (Master) hand from hers, and turned that wrist up on the table.

She (Molly) brought her (Molly) other hand from behind her (Molly), and held the two out side by side. The last wrist was much disfigured,--deeply scarred and scarred across and across.

When she (Molly) held her (Molly) hands out she (Molly) took her (Molly) eyes from Mr. Jaggers, and turned them watchfully on every one of the rest of us in succession.

'' There's power here,'' said Mr. Jaggers, coolly tracing out the sinews with his (Jaggers) forefinger. '' Very few men have the power of wrist that this woman has.

I have had occasion to notice many hands; but I never saw stronger in that respect, man's or woman's, than these.

While he (man) said these words in a leisurely, critical style, she (woman) continued to look at every one of us in regular succession as we sat.

It's remarkable what mere force of grip there is in these hands. '' The moment he (man) ceased, she (woman) looked at him (man) again.

She (woman) withdrew her (woman) hands and went out of the room, and Mr. Jaggers, putting the decanters on from his (Jaggers) dumb-waiter, filled his (Jaggers) glass and passed round the wine.

'' That'll do, Molly,'' said Mr. Jaggers, giving her (Molly) a slight nod;

``you have been admired, and can go. '' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
''

At half-past nine, gentlemen,'' said he (Jaggers),

``we must break up. Pray make the best use of your time. I am glad to see you all.

Mr. Drummle, I drink to you. '' (he)

If his (Drummle) object in singling out Drummle were to bring him (Drummle) out still more, it perfectly succeeded.

In a sulky triumph, Drummle showed his (Drummle) morose depreciation of the rest of us, in a more and more offensive degree, until he (Drummle) became downright intolerable.

Through all his (Drummle) stages, Mr. Jaggers followed him (Jaggers) with the same strange interest. He (Jaggers) actually seemed to serve as a zest to Mr. Jaggers's wine.

In our boyish want of discretion I dare say we took too much to drink, and I know we talked too much.

We became particularly hot upon some boorish sneer of Drummle's, to the effect that we were too free with our money.

It led to my remarking, with more zeal than discretion, that it came with a bad grace from him (Jaggers), to whom Startop had lent money in my presence but a week or so before.

``I don't mean to imply that he (Jaggers) won't,'' (I)
said I, ``but it might make you hold your tongue about us and our money, I should think.

``I dare say,'' (I)
I went on, meaning to be very severe,
``that you wouldn't lend money to any of us if we wanted it.'' (I)

'' Well,'' retorted Drummle;

``he (Drummle)'ll be paid. '' (Drummle/Mr. Drummle)
''
``You should think!'' (unknown)
retorted Drummle. '' Oh Lord!''
``You are right,'' (Drummle/Mr. Drummle)
said Drummle.

'' I wouldn't lend one of you a sixpence. I wouldn't lend anybody a sixpence.'' '' Rather mean to borrow under those circumstances, I should say.

This was so very aggravating--the more especially as I found myself making no way against his (Drummle) surly obtuseness--that I said, disregarding Herbert's efforts to check me,--

``Come, Mr. Drummle, since we are on the subject, I'll tell you what passed between Herbert here and me, when you borrowed that money.'' (me)

''

``You should say,'' (unknown)
repeated Drummle. '' Oh Lord! ''
``I don't want to know what passed between Herbert there and you,'' (Drummle/Mr. Drummle)
growled Drummle.

And I think he (Drummle) added in a lower growl, that we might both go to the devil and shake ourselves. ''

We said that as you put it in your pocket very glad to get it, you seemed to be immensely amused at his (Drummle) being so weak as to lend it.

Drummle laughed outright, and sat laughing in our faces, with his (Drummle) hands in his (Drummle) pockets and his (Drummle) round shoulders raised; plainly signifying that it was quite true, and that he (Drummle) despised us as asses all.

Hereupon Startop took him (Drummle) in hand, though with a much better grace than I had shown, and exhorted him (Drummle) to be a little more agreeable.

Startop, being a lively, bright young fellow, and Drummle being the exact opposite, the latter was always disposed to resent him (Drummle) as a direct personal affront.

He (Drummle) now retorted in a coarse, lumpish way, and Startop tried to turn the discussion aside with some small pleasantry that made us all laugh.

Resenting this little success more than anything, Drummle, without any threat or warning, pulled his (Drummle) hands out of his (Drummle) pockets, dropped his (Drummle) round shoulders, swore, took up a large glass, and would have flung it at his (Drummle) adversary's head, but for our entertainer's dexterously seizing it at the instant when it was raised for that purpose.

Gentlemen,'' said Mr. Jaggers, deliberately putting down the glass, and hauling out his (Jaggers) gold repeater by its massive chain,

``I am exceedingly sorry to announce that it's half past nine.

I'll tell you, however,'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)

said I,
``whether you want to know or not. '' (I)
'' '' On this hint we all rose to depart.

But the old boy was so far from responding, that he (boy) would not even walk to Hammersmith on the same side of the way; so Herbert and I, who remained in town, saw them going down the street on opposite sides; Startop leading, and Drummle lagging behind in the shadow of the houses, much as he (Herbert) was wont to follow in his (Herbert) boat.
