As the door was not yet shut, I thought I would leave Herbert there for a moment, and run upstairs again to say a word to my guardian.

I found him (Herbert) in his (Herbert) dressing-room surrounded by his (Herbert) stock of boots, already hard at it, washing his (Herbert) hands of us.

I told him (Herbert) I had come up again to say how sorry I was that anything disagreeable should have occurred, and that I hoped he (Herbert) would not blame me much.

Before we got to the street door, Startop was cheerily calling Drummle

``old boy,'' (Drummle/Mr. Drummle)
as if nothing had happened.
``Pooh! '' (he)
said he (Drummle), sluicing his (Drummle) face, and speaking through the water-drops;
``it's nothing, Pip.

I like that Spider though. '' (he)

He (Drummle) had turned towards me now, and was shaking his (Drummle) head, and blowing, and towelling himself.

'' I am glad you like him (Drummle), sir,'' said I--

``but I don't. '' (I)
'' No, no,'' my guardian assented;
``don't have too much to do with him (Drummle).

Keep as clear of him (Drummle) as you can. But I like the fellow, Pip; he (Pip) is one of the true sort.

But I am not a fortune-teller,'' (guardian)

he (Pip) said, letting his (Pip) head drop into a festoon of towel, and towelling away at his (Pip) two ears.

Why, if I was a fortune-teller--'' Looking out of the towel, he (Pip) caught my eye. '' '' You know what I am, don't you?

In about a month after that, the Spider's time with Mr. Pocket was up for good, and, to the great relief of all the house but

Good night, Pip.''

``Good night, sir. '' (he)
Mrs. Pocket, he (Pocket) went home to the family hole. Chapter XXVII '' MY DEAR MR

I write this by request of Mr. Gargery, for to let you know that he (Gargery) is going to London in company with Mr. Wopsle and would be glad if agreeable to be allowed to see you.

PIP:-- '' He (Wopsle) would call at Barnard's Hotel Tuesday morning at nine o'clock, when if not agreeable please leave word. Your poor sister is much the same as when you left.

We talk of you in the kitchen every night, and wonder what you are saying and doing. If now considered in the light of a liberty, excuse it for the love of poor old days.

No more, dear Mr. Pip, from your ever obliged, and affectionate servant,

``BIDDY. '' (servant)
'' P.S.. He (servant) wishes me most particular to write what larks.

I hope and do not doubt it will be agreeable to see him (servant), even though a gentleman, for you had ever a good heart, and he (gentleman) is a worthy, worthy man.

I have read him (gentleman) all, excepting only the last little sentence, and he (gentleman) wishes me most particular to write again what larks.

He (gentleman) says you will understand. '' I received this letter by the post on Monday morning, and therefore its appointment was for next day.

Not with pleasure, though I was bound to him (gentleman) by so many ties; no; with considerable disturbance, some mortification, and a keen sense of incongruity.

Let me confess exactly with what feelings I looked forward to Joe's coming. If I could have kept him (gentleman) away by paying money, I certainly would have paid money.

My greatest reassurance was that he (gentleman) was coming to Barnard's Inn, not to Hammersmith, and consequently would not fall in Bentley Drummle's way.

I had little objection to his (gentleman) being seen by Herbert or his (gentleman) father, for both of whom I had a respect; but I had the sharpest sensitiveness as to his (gentleman) being seen by Drummle, whom I held in contempt.

So, throughout life, our worst weaknesses and meannesses are usually committed for the sake of the people whom we most despise.

I had begun to be always decorating the chambers in some quite unnecessary and inappropriate way or other, and very expensive those wrestles with Barnard proved to be.

By this time, the rooms were vastly different from what I had found them, and I enjoyed the honor of occupying a few prominent pages in the books of a neighboring upholsterer.

I had got on so fast of late, that I had even started a boy in boots,--top boots,--in bondage and slavery to whom I might have been said to pass my days.

For, after I had made the monster -LRB-out of the refuse of my washerwoman's family-RRB-, and had clothed him (boy) with a blue coat, canary waistcoat, white cravat, creamy breeches, and the boots already mentioned, I had to find him (boy) a little to do and a great deal to eat; and with both of those horrible requirements he (boy) haunted my existence.

This avenging phantom was ordered to be on duty at eight on Tuesday morning in the hall, -LRB-it was two feet square, as charged for floorcloth,-RRB- and Herbert suggested certain things for breakfast that he (Herbert) thought Joe would like.

While I felt sincerely obliged to him (Herbert) for being so interested and considerate, I had an odd half-provoked sense of suspicion upon me, that if Joe had been coming to see him (Herbert), he (Herbert) wouldn't have been quite so brisk about it.

However, I came into town on the Monday night to be ready for Joe, and I got up early in the morning, and caused the sitting-room and breakfast-table to assume their most splendid appearance.

Unfortunately the morning was drizzly, and an angel could not have concealed the fact that Barnard was shedding sooty tears outside the window, like some weak giant of a Sweep.

As the time approached I should have liked to run away, but the Avenger pursuant to orders was in the hall, and presently I heard Joe on the staircase.

I knew it was Joe, by his (Barnard) clumsy manner of coming upstairs, --his (Barnard) state boots being always too big for him (Barnard),--and by the time it took him (Barnard) to read the names on the other floors in the course of his (Barnard) ascent.

When at last he (Barnard) stopped outside our door, I could hear his (Barnard) finger tracing over the painted letters of my name, and I afterwards distinctly heard him (Barnard) breathing in at the keyhole.

I thought he (Barnard) never would have done wiping his (Barnard) feet, and that I must have gone out to lift him (Barnard) off the mat, but at last he (Barnard) came in.

Finally he (Barnard) gave a faint single rap, and Pepper--such was the compromising name of the avenging boy--announced

``Mr. Gargery! '' (the boy)
''

'' With his (Gargery) good honest face all glowing and shining, and his (Gargery) hat put down on the floor between us, he (Gargery) caught both my hands and worked them straight up and down, as if I had been the last-patented Pump.

Joe, how are you, Joe?''

``Pip, how AIR you, Pip? '' (I)
I am glad to see you, Joe. Give me your hat.

But Joe, taking it up carefully with both hands, like a bird's-nest with eggs in it, wouldn't hear of parting with that piece of property, and persisted in standing talking over it in a most uncomfortable way.

'' Joe considered a little before he (I) discovered this word;

``as to be sure you are a honor to your king and country.'' (he)

'' '' Which you have that growed,'' said Joe,

``and that swelled, and that gentle-folked; '' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
And you, Joe, look wonderfully well.''

``Thank God,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe,
``I'm ekerval to most. And your sister, she (Joe)'s no worse than she (Joe) were. And Biddy, she (Joe)'s ever right and ready.

All this time -LRB-still with both hands taking great care of the bird's-nest-RRB-, Joe was rolling his (God) eyes round and round the room, and round and round the flowered pattern of my dressing-gown.

And all friends is no backerder, if not no forarder. ' Ceptin Wopsle; he (God)'s had a drop. '' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

'' Had a drop, Joe?''

'' Why yes,'' said Joe, lowering his (God) voice,

``he (God)'s left the Church and went into the playacting. Which the playacting have likeways brought him (God) to London along with me.

And his (God) wish were,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

said Joe, getting the bird's-nest under his (God) left arm for the moment, and groping in it for an egg with his (God) right; ``if no offence, as I would `and you that.

I took what Joe gave me, and found it to be the crumpled play-bill of a small metropolitan theatre, announcing the first appearance, in that very week, of

``the celebrated Provincial Amateur of Roscian renown, whose unique performance in the highest tragic walk of our National Bard has lately occasioned so great a sensation in local dramatic circles.'' (me)

''

``Were you at his (Bard) performance, Joe? '' (I)
I inquired. '' I were,'' said Joe, with emphasis and solemnity. '' Was there a great sensation?''

Though I put it to yourself, sir, whether it were calc`lated to keep a man up to his (man) work with a good hart, to be continiwally cutting in betwixt him (man) and the Ghost with

``Amen!'' (the Ghost)

A man may have had a misfortun' and been in the Church,'' said Joe, lowering his (man) voice to an argumentative and feeling tone, ``but that is no reason why you should put him (man) out at such a time.

Which I meantersay, if the ghost of a man's own father cannot be allowed to claim his (father) attention, what can, Sir?

Still more, when his (father) mourning `at is unfortunately made so small as that the weight of the black feathers brings it off, try to keep it on how you may.

``Why,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe,
``yes, there certainly were a peck of orange-peel. Partickler when he (father) see the ghost. '' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
A ghost-seeing effect in Joe's own countenance informed me that Herbert had entered the room.

So, I presented Joe to Herbert, who held out his (Herbert) hand; but Joe backed from it, and held on by the bird's-nest.

Your servant, Sir,'' said Joe,

``which I hope as you and Pip'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
--here his (servant) eye fell on the Avenger, who was putting some toast on table, and so plainly denoted an intention to make that young gentleman one of the family, that I frowned it down and confused him (gentleman) more--
``I meantersay, you two gentlemen,--which

For the present may be a werry good inn, according to London opinions,'' (him)

said Joe, confidentially,
``and I believe its character do stand it; but I wouldn't keep a pig in it

'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

I hope as you get your elths in this close spot? myself,--not in the case that I wished him (character) to fatten wholesome and to eat with a meller flavor on him (character).

Having borne this flattering testimony to the merits of our dwelling-place, and having incidentally shown this tendency to call me

``sir,'' (me)
Joe, being invited to sit down to table, looked all round the room for a suitable spot on which to deposit his (character) hat,--as if it were only on some very few rare substances in nature that it could find a resting place,--and ultimately stood it on an extreme corner of the chimney-piece, from which it ever afterwards fell off at intervals.

'' '' Do you take tea, or coffee, Mr. Gargery? '' asked Herbert, who always presided of a morning. '' Thankee, Sir,'' said Joe, stiff from head to foot, ``I'll take whichever is most agreeable to yourself.

``Thankee, Sir,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
returned Joe, evidently dispirited by the proposal,
``since you are so kind as make chice of coffee, I will not run contrairy to your own opinions.

'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

'' What do you say to coffee?'' But don't you never find it a little `eating?''
``Say tea then,'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
said Herbert, pouring it out.

Here Joe's hat tumbled off the mantel-piece, and he (Herbert) started out of his (Herbert) chair and picked it up, and fitted it to the same exact spot.

As if it were an absolute point of good breeding that it should tumble off again soon. '' When did you come to town, Mr. Gargery?''

``Were it yesterday afternoon?'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe, after coughing behind his (Gargery) hand, as if he (Gargery) had had time to catch the whooping-cough since he (Gargery) came.

'' No it were not. Yes it were. Yes. It were yesterday afternoon'' -LRB-with an appearance of mingled wisdom, relief, and strict impartiality-RRB-.

'' Have you seen anything of London yet?''

``Why, yes, Sir,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe,
``me and Wopsle went off straight to look at the Blacking Ware'us.

But we didn't find that it come up to its likeness in the red bills at the shop doors; which I meantersay,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

added Joe, in an explanatory manner,
``as it is there drawd too architectooralooral.

I really believe Joe would have prolonged this word -LRB-mightily expressive to my mind of some architecture that I know-RRB- into a perfect Chorus, but for his (we) attention being providentially attracted by his (we) hat, which was toppling.

Indeed, it demanded from him (we) a constant attention, and a quickness of eye and hand, very like that exacted by wicket-keeping.

He (we) made extraordinary play with it, and showed the greatest skill; now, rushing at it and catching it neatly as it dropped; now, merely stopping it midway, beating it up, and humoring it in various parts of the room and against a good deal of the pattern of the paper on the wall, before he (we) felt it safe to close with it; finally splashing it into the slop-basin, where I took the liberty of laying hands upon it.

'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

As to his (we) shirt-collar, and his (we) coat-collar, they were perplexing to reflect upon,--insoluble mysteries both. Why should a man scrape himself to that extent, before he (man) could consider himself full dressed?

Then he (man) fell into such unaccountable fits of meditation, with his (man) fork midway between his (man) plate and his (man) mouth; had his (man) eyes attracted in such strange directions; was afflicted with such remarkable coughs; sat so far from the table, and dropped so much more than he (man) ate, and pretended that he (man) hadn't dropped it; that I was heartily glad when Herbert left us for the City.

I had neither the good sense nor the good feeling to know that this was all my fault, and that if I had been easier with Joe, Joe would have been easier with me.

I felt impatient of him (Herbert) and out of temper with him (Herbert); in which condition he (Herbert) heaped coals of fire on my head.

Why should he (Herbert) suppose it necessary to be purified by suffering for his (Herbert) holiday clothes? '' Us two being now alone, sir,''--began Joe.

'' Joe,'' I interrupted, pettishly,

``how can you call me, sir?'' (I)
Joe looked at me for a single instant with something faintly like reproach.

Utterly preposterous as his (Herbert) cravat was, and as his (Herbert) collars were, I was conscious of a sort of dignity in the look.

Us two being now alone,'' resumed Joe,

``and me having the intentions and abilities to stay not many minutes more, I will now conclude--leastways begin--to mention what have led to my having had the present honor.

For was it not,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

said Joe, with his (Herbert) old air of lucid exposition,
``that my only wish were to be useful to you, I should not have had the honor of breaking wittles in the company and abode of gentlemen.

'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

'' I was so unwilling to see the look again, that I made no remonstrance against this tone. '' Well, sir,'' pursued Joe,
``this is how it were.

I were at the Bargemen t`other night, Pip;'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

--whenever he (Pip) subsided into affection, he (Pip) called me Pip, and whenever he (Pip) relapsed into politeness he (Pip) called me sir;
``when there come up in his (Pip) shay-cart, Pumblechook.

Which that same identical,'' (me)

said Joe, going down a new track,
``do comb my `air the wrong way sometimes, awful, by giving out up and down town as it were him (Pip) which ever had your infant companionation and were looked upon as a playfellow by yourself.'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

``Nonsense. It was you, Joe.'' (I)
'' Which I fully believed it were, Pip,'' said Joe, slightly tossing his (Pip) head,
``though it signify little now, sir.

a pipe and a pint of beer do give refreshment to the workingman, sir, and do not over stimilate-RRB-, and his (Pip) word were, `Joseph, Miss Havisham she (Joe) wish to speak to you.''' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

Well, Pip; this same identical, which his (Pip) manners is given to blusterous, come to me at the Bargemen -LRB-wot

``Miss Havisham, Joe?'' (me)

''`She (Joe) wish,' were Pumblechook's word, `to speak to you.' '' Joe sat and rolled his (Pumblechook) eyes at the ceiling. '' Yes, Joe?

Go on, please.'' '' Next day, sir,'' said Joe, looking at me as if I were a long way off,

``having cleaned myself, I go and I see Miss A.

Which I say, sir,'' (I)

replied Joe, with an air of legal formality, as if he (Pumblechook) were making his (Pumblechook) will,
``Miss A., or otherways Havisham.

'' (he)

``Miss A., Joe? Miss Havisham? '' (unknown)
'' Her (Joe) expression air then as follering: `Mr. Gargery. You air in correspondence with Mr. Pip?'

-LRB-When I married your sister, sir, I said 'I will;' and when I answered your friend, Pip, I said 'I am.'-RRB- `Would you tell him (Pip), then,' said she (sister), `that which Estella has come home and would be glad to see him (Pip).'

Having had a letter from you, I were able to say 'I am.' '' I felt my face fire up as I looked at Joe.

I hope one remote cause of its firing may have been my consciousness that if I had known his (Pip) errand, I should have given him (Pip) more encouragement.

Biddy,'' pursued Joe,

``when I got home and asked her (Joe) fur to write the message to you, a little hung back.

Biddy says, 'I know he (Pip) will be very glad to have it by word of mouth, it is holiday time, you want to see him (Pip), go!'

I have now concluded, sir,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

said Joe, rising from his (Pip) chair,
``and, Pip, I wish you ever well and ever prospering to a greater and a greater height.'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

'' '' But you are not going now, Joe?'' '' Yes I am,'' said Joe. '' But you are coming back to dinner, Joe?''

'' No I am not,'' said Joe. Our eyes met, and all the

``Sir'' (he)
melted out of that manly heart as he (Pip) gave me his (Pip) hand. ''

Pip, dear old chap, life is made of ever so many partings welded together, as I may say, and one man's a blacksmith, and one's a whitesmith, and one's a goldsmith, and one's a coppersmith.

Diwisions among such must come, and must be met as they come. If there's been any fault at all to-day, it's mine.

You and me is not two figures to be together in London; nor yet anywheres else but what is private, and beknown, and understood among friends.

It ain't that I am proud, but that I want to be right, as you shall never see me no more in these clothes.

You won't find half so much fault in me if you think of me in my forge dress, with my hammer in my hand, or even my pipe.

You won't find half so much fault in me if, supposing as you should ever wish to see me, you come and put your head in at the forge window and see Joe the blacksmith, there, at the old anvil, in the old burnt apron, sticking to the old work.

I'm wrong in these clothes. I'm wrong out of the forge, the kitchen, or off th' meshes. I'm awful dull, but I hope I've beat out something nigh the rights of this at last.

And so GOD bless you, dear old Pip, old chap , GOD bless you! '' I had not been mistaken in my fancy that there was a simple dignity in him (GOD).

The fashion of his (GOD) dress could no more come in its way when he (GOD) spoke these words than it could come in its way in Heaven.

As soon as I could recover myself sufficiently, I hurried out after him (GOD) and looked for him (GOD) in the neighboring streets; but he (GOD) was gone.

Chapter XXVIII It was clear that I must repair to our town next day, and in the first flow of my repentance, it was equally clear that I must stay at Joe's.

But, when I had secured my box-place by to-morrow's coach, and had been down to Mr. Pocket's and back, I was not by any means convinced on the last point, and began to invent reasons and make excuses for putting up at the Blue Boar.

I should be an inconvenience at Joe's; I was not expected, and my bed would not be ready; I should be too far from Miss Havisham's, and she (Joe) was exacting and mightn't like it.

He (Pocket) touched me gently on the forehead, and went out. All other swindlers upon earth are nothing to the self-swindlers, and with such pretences did I cheat myself.

That I should innocently take a bad half-crown of somebody else's manufacture is reasonable enough; but that I should knowingly reckon the spurious coin of my own make as good money!

An obliging stranger, under pretence of compactly folding up my bank-notes for security's sake, abstracts the notes and gives me nutshells; but what is his (stranger) sleight of hand to mine, when I fold up my own nutshells and pass them on myself as notes!

Having settled that I must go to the Blue Boar, my mind was much disturbed by indecision whether or not to take the Avenger.

It was tempting to think of that expensive Mercenary publicly airing his (stranger) boots in the archway of the Blue Boar's posting-yard; it was almost solemn to imagine him (stranger) casually produced in the tailor's shop, and confounding the disrespectful senses of Trabb's boy.

On the other hand, Trabb's boy might worm himself into his (boy) intimacy and tell him (boy) things; or, reckless and desperate wretch as I knew he (boy) could be, might hoot him (boy) in the High Street.

Surely a curious thing. My patroness, too, might hear of him (boy), and not approve. On the whole, I resolved to leave the Avenger behind.

It was the afternoon coach by which I had taken my place, and, as winter had now come round, I should not arrive at my destination until two or three hours after dark.

Our time of starting from the Cross Keys was two o'clock. I arrived on the ground with a quarter of an hour to spare, attended by the Avenger,--if

I may connect that expression with one who never attended on me if he (coach) could possibly help it. At that time it was customary to carry Convicts down to the dock-yards by stage-coach.

As I had often heard of them in the capacity of outside passengers, and had more than once seen them on the high road dangling their ironed legs over the coach roof, I had no cause to be surprised when Herbert, meeting me in the yard, came up and told me there were two convicts going down with me.

But I had a reason that was an old reason now for constitutionally faltering whenever I heard the word

``convict. '' (I)

``You don't mind them, Handel?'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
said Herbert. '' O no!''
``I thought you seemed as if you didn't like them?'' (unknown)
``I can't pretend that I do like them, and I suppose you don't particularly.

But I don't mind them.'' (unknown)

``See! There they are,'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
said Herbert,
``coming out of the Tap. What a degraded and vile sight it is!

They had been treating their guard, I suppose, for they had a gaoler with them, and all three came out wiping their mouths on their hands.

'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

The two convicts were handcuffed together, and had irons on their legs,--irons of a pattern that I knew well. They wore the dress that I likewise knew well.

Their keeper had a brace of pistols, and carried a thick-knobbed bludgeon under his (keeper) arm; but he (keeper) was on terms of good understanding with them, and stood with them beside him (keeper), looking on at the putting-to of the horses, rather with an air as if the convicts were an interesting Exhibition not formally open at the moment, and he (keeper) the Curator.

One was a taller and stouter man than the other, and appeared as a matter of course, according to the mysterious ways of the world, both convict and free, to have had allotted to him (keeper) the smaller suit of clothes.

His (keeper) arms and legs were like great pincushions of those shapes, and his (keeper) attire disguised him (keeper) absurdly; but I knew his (keeper) half-closed eye at one glance.

There stood the man whom I had seen on the settle at the Three Jolly Bargemen on a Saturday night, and who had brought me down with his (Bargemen) invisible gun!

It was easy to make sure that as yet he (Bargemen) knew me no more than if he (Bargemen) had never seen me in his (Bargemen) life.

He (Bargemen) looked across at me, and his (Bargemen) eye appraised my watch-chain, and then he (Bargemen) incidentally spat and said something to the other convict, and they laughed and slued themselves round with a clink of their coupling manacle, and looked at something else.

The great numbers on their backs, as if they were street doors; their coarse mangy ungainly outer surface, as if they were lower animals; their ironed legs, apologetically garlanded with pocket-handkerchiefs; and the way in which all present looked at them and kept from them; made them -LRB-as Herbert had said-RRB- a most disagreeable and degraded spectacle.

It came out that the whole of the back of the coach had been taken by a family removing from London, and that there were no places for the two prisoners but on the seat in front behind the coachman.

Hereupon, a choleric gentleman, who had taken the fourth place on that seat, flew into a most violent passion, and said that it was a breach of contract to mix him (gentleman) up with such villainous company, and that it was poisonous, and pernicious, and infamous, and shameful, and I don't know what else.

At this time the coach was ready and the coachman impatient, and we were all preparing to get up, and the prisoners had come over with their keeper,--bringing with them that curious flavor of bread-poultice, baize, rope-yarn, and hearthstone, which attends the convict presence.

But this was not the worst of it. '' Don't take it so much amiss, sir,'' pleaded the keeper to the angry passenger;

``I'll sit next you myself.

I'll put 'em on the outside of the row. They won't interfere with you, sir. You needn't know they're there.'' (the passenger)

''

And don't blame me,'' growled the convict I had recognized. '' I don't want to go. I am quite ready to stay behind.

As fur as I am concerned any one's welcome to my place. ''

``Or mine,'' (I)
said the other, gruffly. '' I wouldn't have incommoded none of you, if I'd had my way.

'' Then they both laughed, and began cracking nuts, and spitting the shells about.--As I really think I should have liked to do myself, if I had been in their place and so despised.

At length, it was voted that there was no help for the angry gentleman, and that he (gentleman) must either go in his (gentleman) chance company or remain behind.

So he (gentleman) got into his (gentleman) place, still making complaints, and the keeper got into the place next him (keeper), and the convicts hauled themselves up as well as they could, and the convict I had recognized sat behind me with his (keeper) breath on the hair of my head.

'' Good-bye, Handel!'' Herbert called out as we started. I thought what a blessed fortune it was, that he (Herbert) had found another name for me than Pip.

It is impossible to express with what acuteness I felt the convict's breathing, not only on the back of my head, but all along my spine.

The sensation was like being touched in the marrow with some pungent and searching acid, it set my very teeth on edge.

He (Herbert) seemed to have more breathing business to do than another man, and to make more noise in doing it; and I was conscious of growing high-shouldered on one side, in my shrinking endeavors to fend him (Herbert) off.

It made us all lethargic before we had gone far, and when we had left the Half-way House behind, we habitually dozed and shivered and were silent.

I dozed off, myself, in considering the question whether I ought to restore a couple of pounds sterling to this creature before losing sight of him (Herbert), and how it could best be done.

In the act of dipping forward as if I were going to bathe among the horses, I woke in a fright and took the question up again.

But I must have lost it longer than I had thought, since, although I could recognize nothing in the darkness and the fitful lights and shadows of our lamps, I traced marsh country in the cold damp wind that blew at us.

Cowering forward for warmth and to make me a screen against the wind, the convicts were closer to me than before.

The very first words I heard them interchange as I became conscious, were the words of my own thought,

``Two One Pound notes.

The weather was miserably raw, and the two cursed the cold. '' (I)

``How did he (convicts) get 'em?'' (I)
said the convict I had never seen.

'' How should I know? '' returned the other. '' He (convicts) had 'em stowed away somehows. Giv him (convicts) by friends, I expect.

''

``I wish,'' (unknown)
said the other, with a bitter curse upon the cold,
``that I had 'em here. '' (unknown)
``Two one pound notes, or friends?'' (unknown)

``Two one pound notes. I'd sell all the friends I ever had for one, and think it a blessed good bargain.

So he (convicts) says,'' (I)

resumed the convict I had recognized,--
``it was all said and done in half a minute, behind a pile of timber in the Dock-yard,--`You're

Would I find out that boy that had fed him (boy) and kep his (boy) secret, and give him (boy) them two one pound notes?

Well? So he (boy) says--? '' (I)

'' a going to be discharged?' Yes, I was. Yes, I would. And I did.'' ''

More fool you,'' growled the other. '' I'd have spent 'em on a Man, in wittles and drink. He (Man) must have been a green one.

Mean to say he (Man) knowed nothing of you?''

``Not a ha`porth. Different gangs and different ships. He (Man) was tried again for prison breaking, and got made a Lifer.'' (unknown)

'' And was that--Honor!--the only time you worked out, in this part of the country?'' '' The only time. ''

``What might have been your opinion of the place?'' (unknown)

``A most beastly place. Mudbank, mist, swamp, and work; work, swamp, mist, and mudbank. '' (unknown)
They both execrated the place in very strong language, and gradually growled themselves out, and had nothing left to say.

After overhearing this dialogue, I should assuredly have got down and been left in the solitude and darkness of the highway, but for feeling certain that the man had no suspicion of my identity.

Indeed, I was not only so changed in the course of nature, but so differently dressed and so differently circumstanced, that it was not at all likely he (man) could have known me without accidental help.

Still, the coincidence of our being together on the coach, was sufficiently strange to fill me with a dread that some other coincidence might at any moment connect me, in his (coach) hearing, with my name.

For this reason, I resolved to alight as soon as we touched the town, and put myself out of his (coach) hearing.

My little portmanteau was in the boot under my feet; I had but to turn a hinge to get it out; I threw it down before me, got down after it, and was left at the first lamp on the first stones of the town pavement.

As to the convicts, they went their way with the coach, and I knew at what point they would be spirited off to the river.

In my fancy, I saw the boat with its convict crew waiting for them at the slime-washed stairs,--again heard the gruff

``Give way, you!

This device I executed successfully. '' (crew)

like and order to dogs,--again saw the wicked Noah's Ark lying out on the black water.

I could not have said what I was afraid of, for my fear was altogether undefined and vague, but there was great fear upon me.

As I walked on to the hotel, I felt that a dread, much exceeding the mere apprehension of a painful or disagreeable recognition, made me tremble.

I am confident that it took no distinctness of shape, and that it was the revival for a few minutes of the terror of childhood.

The coffee-room at the Blue Boar was empty, and I had not only ordered my dinner there, but had sat down to it, before the waiter knew me.

As soon as he (waiter) had apologized for the remissness of his (waiter) memory, he (waiter) asked me if he (waiter) should send Boots for Mr. Pumblechook?

The waiter -LRB-it was he (waiter) who had brought up the Great Remonstrance from the Commercials, on the day when I was bound-RRB- appeared surprised, and took the earliest opportunity of putting a dirty old copy of a local newspaper so directly in my way, that I took it up and read this paragraph:-- Our readers will learn, not altogether without interest, in reference to the recent romantic rise in fortune of a young artificer in iron of this neighborhood -LRB-what a theme, by the way, for the magic pen of our as yet not universally acknowledged townsman TOOBY, the poet of our columns!-RRB- that the youth's earliest patron, companion, and friend, was a highly respected individual not entirely unconnected with the corn and seed trade, and whose eminently convenient and commodious business premises are situate within a hundred miles of the High Street.

It is not wholly irrespective of our personal feelings that we record HIM as the Mentor of our young Telemachus, for it is good to know that our town produced the founder of the latter's fortunes.

'' No,'' said I,

``certainly not. '' (I)
Does the thought-contracted brow of the local Sage or the lustrous eye of local Beauty inquire whose fortunes?

I entertain a conviction, based upon large experience, that if in the days of my prosperity I had gone to the North Pole, I should have met somebody there, wandering Esquimaux or civilized man, who would have told me that Pumblechook was my earliest patron and the founder of my fortunes.

We believe that Quintin Matsys was the BLACKSMITH of Antwerp. VERB. SAP. Chapter XXIX Betimes in the morning I was up and out.

It was too early yet to go to Miss Havisham's, so I loitered into the country on Miss Havisham's side of town,--which

was not Joe's side; I could go there to-morrow,--thinking about my patroness, and painting brilliant pictures of her (Joe) plans for me.

She (Joe) had adopted Estella, she (Joe) had as good as adopted me, and it could not fail to be her (Joe) intention to bring us together.

She (Joe) reserved it for me to restore the desolate house, admit the sunshine into the dark rooms, set the clocks a-going and the cold hearths

a-blazing, tear down the cobwebs, destroy the vermin,--in short, do all the shining deeds of the young Knight of romance, and marry the Princess.

I had stopped to look at the house as I passed; and its seared red brick walls, blocked windows, and strong green ivy clasping even the stacks of chimneys with its twigs and tendons, as if with sinewy old arms, had made up a rich attractive mystery, of which I was the hero.

But, though she (Princess) had taken such strong possession of me, though my fancy and my hope were so set upon her (Princess), though her (Princess) influence on my boyish life and character had been all-powerful, I did not, even that romantic morning, invest her (Princess) with any attributes save those she (Princess) possessed.

I mention this in this place, of a fixed purpose, because it is the clew by which I am to be followed into my poor labyrinth.

Estella was the inspiration of it, and the heart of it, of course. According to my experience, the conventional notion of a lover cannot be always true.

The unqualified truth is, that when I loved Estella with the love of a man, I loved her (Estella) simply because I found her (Estella) irresistible.

Once for all; I knew to my sorrow, often and often, if not always, that I loved her (Estella) against reason, against promise, against peace, against hope, against happiness, against all discouragement that could be.

Once for all; I loved her (Estella) none the less because I knew it, and it had no more influence in restraining me than if I had devoutly believed her (Estella) to be human perfection.

When I had rung at the bell with an unsteady hand, I turned my back upon the gate, while I tried to get my breath and keep the beating of my heart moderately quiet.

I heard the side-door open, and steps come across the courtyard; but I pretended not to hear, even when the gate swung on its rusty hinges.

I so shaped out my walk as to arrive at the gate at my old time. Being at last touched on the shoulder, I started and turned.

I started much more naturally then, to find myself confronted by a man in a sober gray dress. The last man I should have expected to see in that place of porter at Miss Havisham's door.

'' Orlick!''

``Ah, young master, there's more changes than yours. But come in, come in. It's opposed to my orders to hold the gate open.

'' (I)

I entered and he (Orlick) swung it, and locked it, and took the key out. '' Yes! '' said he (Orlick), facing round, after doggedly preceding me a few steps towards the house.

'' Here I am! ''

``How did you come here?'' (unknown)
``I come her (porter),'' (he)
he (Orlick) retorted,
``on my legs. I had my box brought alongside me in a barrow.'' (he)

``Are you here for good?'' (unknown)
``I ain't here for harm, young master, I suppose? '' (I)
I was not so sure of that.

I had leisure to entertain the retort in my mind, while he (master) slowly lifted his (master) heavy glance from the pavement, up my legs and arms, to my face.

'' Then you have left the forge? '' I said. '' Do this look like a forge? '' replied Orlick, sending his (Orlick) glance all round him (Orlick) with an air of injury.

'' Now, do it look like it? '' I asked him (Orlick) how long he (Orlick) had left Gargery's forge? '' One day is so like another here,'' he (Orlick) replied,

``that I don't know without casting it up.

However, I come here some time since you left. '' (he)

``I could have told you that, Orlick.'' (unknown)
``Ah!'' (he)
said he (Orlick), dryly.

By this time we had come to the house, where I found his (Orlick) room to be one just within the side-door, with a little window in it looking on the courtyard.

'' But then you've got to be a scholar. '' In its small proportions, it was not unlike the kind of place usually assigned to a gate-porter in Paris.

Certain keys were hanging on the wall, to which he (scholar) now added the gate key; and his (scholar) patchwork-covered bed was in a little inner division or recess.

The whole had a slovenly, confined, and sleepy look, like a cage for a human dormouse; while he (scholar), looming dark and heavy in the shadow of a corner by the window, looked like the human dormouse for whom it was fitted up,--as indeed he (scholar) was.

No,'' said he (scholar);

``not till it got about that there was no protection on the premises, and it come to be considered dangerous, with convicts and Tag and Rag and Bobtail going up and down.

And then I was recommended to the place as a man who could give another man as good as he (man) brought, and I took it.

'' (he)

I never saw this room before,'' I remarked;
``but there used to be no Porter here.'' (I)
'' It's easier than bellowsing and hammering.--That's loaded, that is.

My eye had been caught by a gun with a brass-bound stock over the chimney-piece, and his (Porter) eye had followed mine.

'' '' Well,'' said I, not desirous of more conversation,

``shall I go up to Miss Havisham?'' (I)
``Burn me, if I know!'' (I)

I give this here bell a rap with this here hammer, and you go on along the passage till you meet somebody.''

he (Porter) retorted, first stretching himself and then shaking himself; ``my orders ends here, young master.

``I am expected, I believe?'' (unknown)
``Burn me twice over, if I can say!'' (he)
said he (master).

Upon that, I turned down the long passage which I had first trodden in my thick boots, and he (master) made his (master) bell sound.

At the end of the passage, while the bell was still reverberating, I found Sarah Pocket, who appeared to have now become constitutionally green and yellow by reason of me.

'' Oh!'' said she (Pocket). '' You, is it, Mr. Pip?''

``It is, Miss Pocket. I am glad to tell you that Mr. Pocket and family are all well.

'' (unknown)

``Are they any wiser?'' (Sarah Pocket/Sarah/Miss Sarah Pocket)
said Sarah, with a dismal shake of the head;
``they had better be wiser, than well.

Ah, Matthew, Matthew! You know your way, sir?'' (Sarah Pocket/Sarah/Miss Sarah Pocket)

Tolerably, for I had gone up the staircase in the dark, many a time.

I ascended it now, in lighter boots than of yore, and tapped in my old way at the door of Miss Havisham's room.

She (Sarah) was in her (Sarah) chair near the old table, in the old dress, with her (Sarah) two hands crossed on her (Sarah) stick, her (Sarah) chin resting on them, and her (Sarah) eyes on the fire.

Sitting near her (Sarah), with the white shoe, that had never been worn, in her (Sarah) hand, and her (Sarah) head bent as she (Sarah) looked at it, was an elegant lady whom I had never seen.

``Come in, Pip,'' (Miss Havisham)
Miss Havisham continued to mutter, without looking round or up;

'' (Miss Havisham)

'' (I)

She (queen) looked up at me suddenly, only moving her (queen) eyes, and repeated in a grimly playful manner,--
``Well?'' (me)

``Well?'' (The lady)

The lady whom I had never seen before, lifted up her (lady) eyes and looked archly at me, and then I saw that the eyes were Estella's eyes.

But she (Estella) was so much changed, was so much more beautiful, so much more womanly, in all things winning admiration, had made such wonderful advance, that I seemed to have made none.

I fancied, as I looked at her (Estella), that I slipped hopelessly back into the coarse and common boy again. O the sense of distance and disparity that came upon me, and the inaccessibility that came about her (Estella)!

I stammered something about the pleasure I felt in seeing her (Estella) again, and about my having looked forward to it, for a long, long time.

Do you find her (Estella) much changed, Pip?'' asked Miss Havisham, with her (Havisham) greedy look, and striking her (Havisham) stick upon a chair that stood between them, as a sign to me to sit down there.

When I came in, Miss Havisham, I thought there was nothing of Estella in the face or figure; but now it all settles down so curiously into the old--

She (Estella) gave me her (Estella) hand. '' '' ''

``What? You are not going to say into the old Estella?'' (Miss Havisham)
Miss Havisham interrupted.

'' She (Havisham) was proud and insulting, and you wanted to go away from her (Havisham). Don't you remember? '' I said confusedly that that was long ago, and that I knew no better then, and the like.

Estella smiled with perfect composure, and said she (Estella) had no doubt of my having been quite right, and of her (Estella) having been very disagreeable.

'' Is he (Estella) changed? '' Miss Havisham asked her (Havisham). '' Very much,'' said Estella, looking at me. '' Less coarse and common?'' said Miss Havisham, playing with Estella's hair.

Estella laughed, and looked at the shoe in her (Estella) hand, and laughed again, and looked at me, and put the shoe down.

We sat in the dreamy room among the old strange influences which had so wrought upon me, and I learnt that she (Estella) had but just come home from France, and that she (Estella) was going to London.

Proud and wilful as of old, she (Estella) had brought those qualities into such subjection to her (Estella) beauty that it was impossible and out of nature--or I thought so--to separate them from her (Estella) beauty.

Truly it was impossible to dissociate her (Estella) presence from all those wretched hankerings after money and gentility that had disturbed my boyhood,--from all those ill-regulated aspirations that had first made me ashamed of home and Joe,--from all those visions that had raised her (Joe) face in the glowing fire, struck it out of the iron on the anvil, extracted it from the darkness of night to look in at the wooden window of the forge, and flit away.

In a word, it was impossible for me to separate her (Joe), in the past or in the present, from the innermost life of my life.

It was settled that I should stay there all the rest of the day, and return to the hotel at night, and to London to-morrow.

When we had conversed for a while, Miss Havisham sent us two out to walk in the neglected garden: on our coming in by and by, she (Havisham) said, I should wheel her (Havisham) about a little, as in times of yore.

So, Estella and I went out into the garden by the gate through which I had strayed to my encounter with the pale young gentleman, now Herbert;

I, trembling in spirit and worshipping the very hem of her (Estella) dress; she (Estella), quite composed and most decidedly not worshipping the hem of mine.

She (Estella) treated me as a boy still, but she (Estella) lured me on. As we drew near to the place of encounter, she (Estella) stopped and said,--

``I must have been a singular little creature to hide and see that fight that day; but I did, and I enjoyed it very much.'' (she)

I remember I entertained a great objection to your adversary, because I took it ill that he (adversary) should be brought here to pester me with his (adversary) company.''

'' You rewarded me very much.''

``Did I? '' (she)
she (Estella) replied, in an incidental and forgetful way. '' '' He (adversary) and I are great friends now.

I made the admission with reluctance, for it seemed to have a boyish look, and she (Estella) already treated me more than enough like a boy.

''

``Are you? I think I recollect though, that you read with his (boy) father?'' (unknown)

``And necessarily,'' (she)

In my conscience, I doubt very much whether I had any lingering intention left of going to see Joe; but if I had, this observation put it to flight.

You had no idea of your impending good fortune, in those times?'' (she)

said Estella, with a slight wave of her (Estella) hand, signifying in the fighting times.

The air of completeness and superiority with which she (Estella) walked at my side, and the air of youthfulness and submission with which I walked at hers, made a contrast that I strongly felt.

It would have rankled in me more than it did, if I had not regarded myself as eliciting it by being so set apart for her (Estella) and assigned to her (Estella).

The garden was too overgrown and rank for walking in with ease, and after we had made the round of it twice or thrice, we came out again into the brewery yard.

I showed her (Estella) to a nicety where I had seen her (Estella) walking on the casks, that first old day, and she (Estella) said, with a cold and careless look in that direction, ``Did I?

I verily believe that her (Estella) not remembering and not minding in the least, made me cry again, inwardly,--and that is the sharpest crying of all.

You must know,'' said Estella, condescending to me as a brilliant and beautiful woman might,

``that I have no heart,--if that has anything to do with my memory.

'' (a woman)

'' I got through some jargon to the effect that I took the liberty of doubting that. That I knew better.

That there could be no such beauty without it. '' Oh! I have a heart to be stabbed in or shot in

, I have no doubt,'' said Estella,

``and of course if it ceased to beat I should cease to be. But you know what I mean.

I have no softness there, no--sympathy--sentiment--nonsense. '' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)

What was it that was borne in upon my mind when she (Estella) stood still and looked attentively at me?

In some of her (Estella) looks and gestures there was that tinge of resemblance to Miss Havisham which may often be noticed to have been acquired by children, from grown person with whom they have been much associated and secluded, and which, when childhood is passed, will produce a remarkable occasional likeness of expression between faces that are otherwise quite different.

Anything that I had seen in Miss Havisham? No. And yet I could not trace this to Miss Havisham. I looked again, and though she (Estella) was still looking at me, the suggestion was gone.

I have never had any such thing. '' As my eyes followed her (Estella) white hand, again the same dim suggestion that I could not possibly grasp crossed me.

My involuntary start occasioned her (Estella) to lay her (Estella) hand upon my arm. Instantly the ghost passed once more and was gone.

What was it? '' What is the matter?'' asked Estella. '' Are you scared again?''

``I should be, if I believed what you said just now,'' (I)
I replied, to turn it off.

Miss Havisham will soon be expecting you at your old post, though I think that might be laid aside now, with other old belongings.

'' Then you don't? Very well. It is said, at any rate. Let us make one more round of the garden, and then go in.

Come! You shall not shed tears for my cruelty to-day; you shall be my Page, and give me your shoulder. ''

Her (Havisham) handsome dress had trailed upon the ground. She (Havisham) held it in one hand now, and with the other lightly touched my shoulder as we walked.

If the green and yellow growth of weed in the chinks of the old wall had been the most precious flowers that ever blew, it could not have been more cherished in my remembrance.

There was no discrepancy of years between us to remove her (Havisham) far from me; we were of nearly the same age, though of course the age told for more in her (Havisham) case than in mine; but the air of inaccessibility which her (Havisham) beauty and her (Havisham) manner gave her (Havisham), tormented me in the midst of my delight, and at the height of the assurance I felt that our patroness had chosen us for one another.

At last we went back into the house, and there I heard, with surprise, that my guardian had come down to see Miss Havisham on business, and would come back to dinner.

The old wintry branches of chandeliers in the room where the mouldering table was spread had been lighted while we were out, and Miss Havisham was in her (Havisham) chair and waiting for me.

It was like pushing the chair itself back into the past, when we began the old slow circuit round about the ashes of the bridal feast.

But, in the funereal room, with that figure of the grave fallen back in the chair fixing its eyes upon her (Havisham), Estella looked more bright and beautiful than before, and I was under stronger enchantment.

We walked round the ruined garden twice or thrice more, and it was all in bloom for me. Wretched boy! The time so melted away, that our early dinner-hour drew close at hand, and Estella left us to prepare herself.

We had stopped near the centre of the long table, and Miss Havisham, with one of her (Estella) withered arms stretched out of the chair, rested that clenched hand upon the yellow cloth.

As Estella looked back over her (Estella) shoulder before going out at the door, Miss Havisham kissed that hand to her (Havisham), with a ravenous intensity that was of its kind quite dreadful.

Then, Estella being gone and we two left alone, she (Estella) turned to me, and said in a whisper,--

``Is she (Estella) beautiful, graceful, well-grown?

She (Estella) drew an arm round my neck, and drew my head close down to hers as she (Estella) sat in the chair.

Do you admire her (Estella)?'' (me)

'' Everybody must who sees her (Estella), Miss Havisham. '' '' Love her (Estella), love her (Estella), love her (Estella)! How does she (Estella) use you?''

``Love her (Estella), love her (Estella), love her (Estella)!

If she (Estella) tears your heart to pieces,--and as it gets older and stronger it will tear deeper,--love her (Estella), love her (Estella), love her (Estella)!'' (she)

If she (Estella) favors you, love her (Estella). If she (Estella) wounds you, love her (Estella). Never had I seen such passionate eagerness as was joined to her (Estella) utterance of these words.

I could feel the muscles of the thin arm round my neck swell with the vehemence that possessed her (Estella). '' Hear me, Pip!

I adopted her (Estella), to be loved. I bred her (Estella) and educated her (Estella), to be loved. I developed her (Estella) into what she (Estella) is, that she (Estella) might be loved.

She (Estella) said the word often enough, and there could be no doubt that she (Estella) meant to say it; but if the often repeated word had been hate instead of love--despair--revenge--

Love her (Estella)!'' dire death--it could not have sounded from her (Estella) lips more like a curse. '' I'll tell you,'' said she (Estella), in the same hurried passionate whisper,

``what real love is.

It is blind devotion, unquestioning self-humiliation, utter submission, trust and belief against yourself and against the whole world, giving up your whole heart and soul to the smiter--as I did!

For she (Estella) rose up in the chair, in her (Estella) shroud of a dress, and struck at the air as if she (Estella) would as soon have struck herself against the wall and fallen dead.

'' (she)

When she (Estella) came to that, and to a wild cry that followed that, I caught her (Estella) round the waist. All this passed in a few seconds.

As I drew her (Estella) down into her (Estella) chair, I was conscious of a scent that I knew, and turning, saw my guardian in the room.

He (my) always carried -LRB-I have not yet mentioned it, I think-RRB- a pocket-handkerchief of rich silk and of imposing proportions, which was of great value to him (my) in his (my) profession.

I have seen him (my) so terrify a client or a witness by ceremoniously unfolding this pocket-handkerchief as if he (my) were immediately going to blow his (my) nose, and then pausing, as if he (my) knew he (my) should not have time to do it before such client or witness committed himself, that the self-committal has followed directly, quite as a matter of course.

When I saw him (client) in the room he (client) had this expressive pocket-handkerchief in both hands, and was looking at us. On meeting my eye, he (client) said plainly, by a momentary and silent pause in that attitude,

``Indeed?

Singular!'' (he)

and then put the handkerchief to its right use with wonderful effect. Miss Havisham had seen him (client) as soon as I, and was -LRB-like everybody else-RRB- afraid of him (client).

This brought us to the dinner-table, where she (Estella) and Sarah Pocket awaited us. Mr. Jaggers presided, Estella sat opposite to him (Jaggers), I faced my green and yellow friend.

We dined very well, and were waited on by a maid-servant whom I had never seen in all my comings and goings, but who, for anything I know, had been in that mysterious house the whole time.

After dinner a bottle of choice old port was placed before my guardian -LRB-he (Jaggers) was evidently well acquainted with the vintage-RRB-, and the two ladies left us.

Anything to equal the determined reticence of Mr. Jaggers under that roof I never saw elsewhere, even in him (Jaggers). He (Jaggers) kept his (Jaggers) very looks to himself, and scarcely directed his (Jaggers) eyes to Estella's face once during dinner.

When she (Estella) spoke to him (Jaggers), he (Jaggers) listened, and in due course answered, but never looked at her (Estella), that I could see.

On the other hand, she (Estella) often looked at him (Jaggers), with interest and curiosity, if not distrust, but his (Jaggers) face never showed the least consciousness.

Throughout dinner he (Jaggers) took a dry delight in making Sarah Pocket greener and yellower, by often referring in conversation with me to my expectations; but here, again, he (Jaggers) showed no consciousness, and even made it appear that he (Jaggers) extorted--and even did extort, though I don't know how--those references out of my innocent self.

And when he (Jaggers) and I were left alone together, he (Jaggers) sat with an air upon him (Jaggers) of general lying by in consequence of information he (Jaggers) possessed, that really was too much for me.

He (Jaggers) held it between himself and the candle, tasted the port, rolled it in his (Jaggers) mouth, swallowed it, looked at his (Jaggers) glass again, smelt the port, tried it, drank it, filled again, and cross-examined the glass again, until I was as nervous as if I had known the wine to be telling him (Jaggers) something to my disadvantage.

Three or four times I feebly thought I would start conversation; but whenever he (Jaggers) saw me going to ask him (Jaggers) anything, he (Jaggers) looked at me with his (Jaggers) glass in his (Jaggers) hand, and rolling his (Jaggers) wine about in his (Jaggers) mouth, as if requesting me to take notice that it was of no use, for he (Jaggers) couldn't answer.

I think Miss Pocket was conscious that the sight of me involved her (me) in the danger of being goaded to madness, and perhaps tearing off her (me) cap,--which was a very hideous one, in the nature of a muslin mop,--and strewing the ground with her (me)

He (Jaggers) cross-examined his (Jaggers) very wine when he (Jaggers) had nothing else in hand. hair,--which assuredly had never grown on her (me) head. She (me) did not appear when we afterwards went up to Miss Havisham's room, and we four played at whist.

In the interval, Miss Havisham, in a fantastic way, had put some of the most beautiful jewels from her (me) dressing-table into Estella's hair, and about her (me) bosom and arms; and I saw even my guardian look at her (me) from under his (Jaggers) thick eyebrows, and raise them a little, when her (me) loveliness was before him (Jaggers), with those rich flushes of glitter and color in it.

Of the manner and extent to which he (Jaggers) took our trumps into custody, and came out with mean little cards at the ends of hands, before which the glory of our Kings and Queens was utterly abased, I say nothing; nor, of the feeling that I had, respecting his (Jaggers) looking upon us personally in the light of three very obvious and poor riddles that he (Jaggers) had found out long ago.

It was not that I knew I could never bear to speak to him (Jaggers) about her (our), that I knew I could never bear to hear him (Jaggers) creak his (Jaggers) boots at her (our), that I knew I could never bear to see him (Jaggers) wash his (Jaggers) hands of her (our)

; it was, that my admiration should be within a foot or two of him (Jaggers),--it was, that my feelings should be in the same place with him (Jaggers),--that, was the agonizing circumstance.

We played until nine o'clock, and then it was arranged that when Estella came to London I should be forewarned of her (Estella) coming and should meet her (Estella) at the coach; and then I took leave of her (Estella), and touched her (Estella) and left her (Estella).

What I suffered from, was the incompatibility between his (coach) cold presence and my feelings towards Estella. My guardian lay at the Boar in the next room to mine.

I adapted them for my own repetition, and said to my pillow, ``I love her (Estella), I love her (Estella), I love her (Estella)!

Far into the night, Miss Havisham's words,

``Love her (Havisham), love her (Havisham), love her (Havisham)!'' (Miss Havisham)
sounded in my ears. '' hundreds of times.

Then I thought if she (Havisham) were, as I feared, by no means rapturously grateful for that destiny yet, when would she (Havisham) begin to be interested in me?

Then, a burst of gratitude came upon me, that she (Havisham) should be destined for me, once the blacksmith's boy. When should I awaken the heart within her (Havisham) that was mute and sleeping now?

But I never thought there was anything low and small in my keeping away from Joe, because I knew she (Joe) would be contemptuous of him (boy).

It was but a day gone, and Joe had brought the tears into my eyes; they had soon dried, God forgive me! soon dried.

After well considering the matter while I was dressing at the Blue Boar in the morning, I resolved to tell my guardian that I doubted Orlick's being the right sort of man to fill a post of trust at Miss Havisham's.

Why of course he (man) is not the right sort of man, Pip,'' said my guardian, comfortably satisfied beforehand on the general head,

``because the man who fills the post of trust never is the right sort of man.

It seemed quite to put him (man) into spirits to find that this particular post was not exceptionally held by the right sort of man, and he (man) listened in a satisfied manner while I told him (man) what knowledge I had of Orlick.

Ah me! I thought those were high and great emotions. Chapter XXX '' (guardian man)

'' '' Very good, Pip,'' he (Pip) observed, when I had concluded,
``I'll go round presently, and pay our friend off.

Rather alarmed by this summary action, I was for a little delay, and even hinted that our friend himself might be difficult to deal with.

Oh no he (friend) won't,'' (I)

said my guardian, making his (friend) pocket-handkerchief-point, with perfect confidence; ``I should like to see him (friend) argue the question with me.

As we were going back together to London by the midday coach, and as I breakfasted under such terrors of Pumblechook that I could scarcely hold my cup, this gave me an opportunity of saying that I wanted a walk, and that I would go on along the London road while Mr. Jaggers was occupied, if he (Jaggers) would let the coachman know that I would get into my place when overtaken.

By then making a loop of about a couple of miles into the open country at the back of Pumblechook's premises, I got round into the High Street again, a little beyond that pitfall, and felt myself in comparative security.

It was interesting to be in the quiet old town once more, and it was not disagreeable to be here and there suddenly recognized and stared after.

One or two of the tradespeople even darted out of their shops and went a little way down the street before me, that they might turn, as if they had forgotten something, and pass me face to face,--on which occasions I don't know whether they or I made the worse pretence; they of not doing it, or I of not seeing it.

Still my position was a distinguished one, and I was not at all dissatisfied with it, until Fate threw me in the way of that unlimited miscreant, Trabb's boy.

Casting my eyes along the street at a certain point of my progress, I beheld Trabb's boy approaching, lashing himself with an empty blue bag.

Deeming that a serene and unconscious contemplation of him (boy) would best beseem me, and would be most likely to quell his (boy) evil mind, I advanced with that expression of countenance, and was rather congratulating myself on my success, when suddenly the knees of Trabb's boy smote together, his (Trabb) hair uprose, his (Trabb) cap fell off, he (Trabb) trembled violently in every limb, staggered out into the road, and crying to the populace,

``Hold me!

'' (the populace)

'' '' I was thus enabled to fly from the Blue Boar immediately after breakfast. I'm so frightened! '' feigned to be in a paroxysm of terror and contrition, occasioned by the dignity of my appearance.

As I passed him (Trabb), his (Trabb) teeth loudly chattered in his (Trabb) head, and with every mark of extreme humiliation, he (Trabb) prostrated himself in the dust.

I had not advanced another two hundred yards when, to my inexpressible terror, amazement, and indignation, I again beheld Trabb's boy approaching.

His (boy) blue bag was slung over his (boy) shoulder, honest industry beamed in his (boy) eyes, a determination to proceed to Trabb's with cheerful briskness was indicated in his (Trabb) gait.

With a shock he (Trabb) became aware of me, and was severely visited as before; but this time his (Trabb) motion was rotatory, and he (Trabb) staggered round and round me with knees more afflicted, and with uplifted hands as if beseeching for mercy.

This was a hard thing to bear, but this was nothing. He (Trabb) was coming round a narrow corner. His (Trabb) sufferings were hailed with the greatest joy by a knot of spectators, and I felt utterly confounded.

I had not got as much further down the street as the post-office, when I again beheld Trabb's boy shooting round by a back way.

He (Trabb) wore the blue bag in the manner of my great-coat, and was strutting along the pavement towards me on the opposite side of the street, attended by a company of delighted young friends to whom he (Trabb) from time to time exclaimed, with a wave of his (Trabb) hand,

``Don't know yah!

'' (he)

Words cannot state the amount of aggravation and injury wreaked upon me by Trabb's boy, when passing abreast of me, he (Trabb) pulled up his (Trabb) shirt-collar, twined his (Trabb) side-hair, stuck an arm akimbo, and smirked extravagantly by, wriggling his (Trabb) elbows and body, and drawling to his (Trabb) attendants,
``Don't know yah, don't know yah, `pon

The disgrace attendant on his (attendant) immediately afterwards taking to crowing and pursuing me across the bridge with crows, as from an exceedingly dejected fowl who had known me when I was a blacksmith, culminated the disgrace with which I left the town, and was, so to speak, ejected by it into the open country.

But unless I had taken the life of Trabb's boy on that occasion, I really do not even now see what I could have done save endure.

To have struggled with him (Trabb) in the street, or to have exacted any lower recompense from him (Trabb) than his (Trabb) heart's best blood, would have been futile and degrading.

Moreover, he (Trabb) was a boy whom no man could hurt; an invulnerable and dodging serpent who, when chased into a corner, flew out again between his (Trabb) captor's legs, scornfully yelping.

I wrote, however, to Mr. Trabb by next day's post, to say that Mr. Pip must decline to deal further with one who could so far forget what he (Pip) owed to the best interests of society, as to employ a boy who excited Loathing in every respectable mind.

The coach, with Mr. Jaggers inside, came up in due time, and I took my box-seat again, and arrived in London safe,--but not sound, for my heart was gone.

As soon as I arrived, I sent a penitential codfish and barrel of oysters to Joe -LRB-as reparation for not having gone myself-RRB-, and then went on to Barnard's Inn.

This time, he (Barnard) was entirely changed. my soul don't know yah!'' (attendants)

I found Herbert dining on cold meat, and delighted to welcome me back.

Having despatched The Avenger to the coffee-house for an addition to the dinner, I felt that I must open my breast that very evening to my friend and chum.

As confidence was out of the question with The Avenger in the hall, which could merely be regarded in the light of an antechamber to the keyhole, I sent him (friend) to the Play.

A better proof of the severity of my bondage to that taskmaster could scarcely be afforded, than the degrading shifts to which I was constantly driven to find him (friend) employment.

Dinner done and we sitting with our feet upon the fender, I said to Herbert,

``My dear Herbert, I have something very particular to tell you.'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

So mean is extremity, that I sometimes sent him (Herbert) to Hyde Park corner to see what o'clock it was. '' My dear Handel,'' he (Handel) returned,

``I shall esteem and respect your confidence.'' (he)

Herbert crossed his (Herbert) feet, looked at the fire with his (Herbert) head on one side, and having looked at it in vain for some time, looked at me because I didn't go on.

said I,
``and one other person. '' (I)

Estella. '' (I)

'' Well, Herbert? Is that all you say?

Well?'' '' What next, I mean?'' said Herbert. '' Of course I know that. ''

said I.

``How do I know it, Handel? Why, from you.'' (I.)
``I never told you.'' (unknown)
``Told me! You have never told me when you have got your hair cut, but I have had senses to perceive it.

You have always adored her (I), ever since I have known you. You brought your adoration and your portmanteau here together. Told me!

When you told me your own story, you told me plainly that you began adoring her (I) the first time you saw her (I), when you were very young indeed.'' (unknown)

``Very well, then,'' (I)
said I, to whom this was a new and not unwelcome light,
``I have never left off adoring her (I).

Why, you have always told me all day long. And she (I) has come back, a most beautiful and most elegant creature.

And I saw her (I) yesterday. And if I adored her (I) before, I now doubly adore her (I).'' (I)

``Lucky for you then, Handel,'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
said Herbert,
``that you are picked out for her (I) and allotted to her (I).

Without encroaching on forbidden ground, we may venture to say that there can be no doubt between ourselves of that fact.

Have you any idea yet, of Estella's views on the adoration question? '' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

I shook my head gloomily. '' Oh! She (Estella) is thousands of miles away, from me,'' said I.
``Patience, my dear Handel: time enough, time enough.

But you have something more to say?'' (I.)

``I am ashamed to say it,'' (I)
I returned,
``and yet it's no worse to say it than to think it.

You call me a lucky fellow. Of course, I am. I was a blacksmith's boy but yesterday ; I am--what shall I say I am--to-day?'' (I)

``Say a good fellow, if you want a phrase,'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
returned Herbert, smiling, and clapping his (Herbert) hand on the back of mine--
``a good fellow, with impetuosity and hesitation, boldness and diffidence, action and dreaming, curiously mixed in him (Herbert).

'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

I stopped for a moment to consider whether there really was this mixture in my character. On the whole, I by no means recognized the analysis, but thought it not worth disputing.

When I ask what I am to call myself to-day, Herbert,'' I went on,

``I suggest what I have in my thoughts.

I know I have done nothing to raise myself in life, and that Fortune alone has raised me; that is being very lucky.

'' (I)

You say I am lucky. And yet, when I think of Estella--'' -LRB-
``And when don't you, you know? '' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)
Herbert threw in, with his (Herbert) eyes on the fire; which I thought kind and sympathetic of him (Herbert).-RRB-

''--Then, my dear Herbert, I cannot tell you how dependent and uncertain I feel, and how exposed to hundreds of chances.

Avoiding forbidden ground, as you did just now, I may still say that on the constancy of one person -LRB-naming no person-RRB- all my expectations depend.

In saying this, I relieved my mind of what had always been there, more or less, though no doubt most since yesterday.

And at the best, how indefinite and unsatisfactory, only to know so vaguely what they are!'' '' Now, Handel,'' Herbert replied, in his (Herbert) gay, hopeful way,

``it seems to me that in the despondency of the tender passion, we are looking into our gift-horse's mouth with a magnifying-glass.

Likewise, it seems to me that, concentrating our attention on the examination, we altogether overlook one of the best points of the animal.

Didn't you tell me that your guardian, Mr. Jaggers, told you in the beginning, that you were not endowed with expectations only?

you believe that of all men in London, Mr. Jaggers is the man to hold his (Jaggers) present relations towards you unless he (Jaggers) were sure of his (Jaggers) ground?

I said I could not deny that this was a strong point.

I said it -LRB-people often do so, in such cases-RRB- like a rather reluctant concession to truth and justice;--as if I wanted to deny it!

I should think it was a strong point,'' said Herbert,

``and I should think you would be puzzled to imagine a stronger; as to the rest, you must bide your guardian's time, and he (Herbert) must bide his (Herbert) client's time.

'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

You'll be one-and-twenty before you know where you are, and then perhaps you'll get some further enlightenment. At all events, you'll be nearer getting it, for it must come at last.

''

``What a hopeful disposition you have! '' (I)
said I, gratefully admiring his (Herbert) cheery ways. '' I ought to have,'' said Herbert, ``for I have not much else.

I must acknowledge, by the by, that the good sense of what I have just said is not my own, but my father's.

The only remark I ever heard him (father) make on your story, was the final one,

``The thing is settled and done, or Mr. Jaggers would not be in it.

And now before I say anything more about my father, or my father's son, and repay confidence with confidence, I want to make myself seriously disagreeable to you for a moment,--positively repulsive.'' (him)

``Now, Handel, I am quite free from the flavor of sour grapes, upon my soul and honor!

I turned my head aside, for, with a rush and a sweep, like the old marsh winds coming up from the sea,

a feeling like that which had subdued me on the morning when I left the forge, when the mists were solemnly rising, and when I laid my hand upon the village finger-post, smote upon my heart again.

Not being bound to her (my), can you not detach yourself from her (my)?--I told you I should be disagreeable. '' (unknown)

There was silence between us for a little while.

said Herbert, getting up with a lively shake as if he (Herbert) had been asleep, and stirring the fire,

So he (Herbert) went round the room and shook the curtains out, put the chairs in their places, tidied the books and so forth that were lying about, looked into the hall, peeped into the letter-box, shut the door, and came back to his (Herbert) chair by the fire: where he (Herbert) sat down, nursing his (Herbert) left leg in both arms.

'' (he)

``You can't detach yourself?'' (unknown)
'' No. Impossible!''

'' No. Impossible!'' '' '' I was going to say a word or two, Handel, concerning my father and my father's son.

I am afraid it is scarcely necessary for my father's son to remark that my father's establishment is not particularly brilliant in its housekeeping.

'' '' There is always plenty, Herbert,'' said I, to say something encouraging. '' O yes! and so the dustman says, I believe, with the strongest approval, and

so does the marine-store shop in the back street. Gravely, Handel, for the subject is grave enough, you know how it is as well as I do.

I suppose there was a time once when my father had not given matters up; but if ever there was, the time is gone.

May I ask you if you have ever had an opportunity of remarking, down in your part of the country, that the children of not exactly suitable marriages are always most particularly anxious to be married?

'' This was such a singular question, that I asked him (father) in return,

``Is it so?'' (him)
``I don't know,'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
said Herbert,
``that's what I want to know.

Because it is decidedly the case with us. My poor sister Charlotte, who was next me and died before she (Charlotte) was fourteen, was a striking example.

In her (Charlotte) desire to be matrimonially established, you might suppose her (Charlotte) to have passed her (Charlotte) short existence in the perpetual contemplation of domestic bliss.

Little Jane is the same. Little Alick in a frock has already made arrangements for his (Herbert) union with a suitable young person at Kew.

And indeed, I think we are all engaged, except the baby. '' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

``Then you are?'' (I.)
said I.

said Herbert;

``but it's a secret. '' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
I assured him (Herbert) of my keeping the secret, and begged to be favored with further particulars.

He (Herbert) had spoken so sensibly and feelingly of my weakness that I wanted to know something about his (Herbert) strength. '' May I ask the name?

He (Herbert) makes tremendous rows,--roars, and pegs at the floor with some frightful instrument. '' In looking at me and then laughing heartily, Herbert for the time recovered his (Herbert) usual lively manner.

returned Herbert,
``because I never hear him (Herbert), without expecting him (Herbert) to come tumbling through the ceiling.

'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

Don't you expect to see him (Herbert)?'' said I. But I don't know how long the rafters may hold. '' He (Herbert) added as a self-evident proposition, engendering low spirits,
``But you can't marry, you know, while you're looking about you.

As we contemplated the fire, and as I thought what a difficult vision to realize this same Capital sometimes was, I put my hands in my pockets.

A folded piece of paper in one of them attracting my attention, I opened it and found it to be the play-bill I had received from Joe, relative to the celebrated provincial amateur of Roscian renown.

'' (spirits)

'' And bless my heart,'' I involuntarily added aloud,
``it's to-night!'' (I)
This changed the subject in an instant, and made us hurriedly resolve to go to the play.

So, when I had pledged myself to comfort and abet Herbert in the affair of his (Herbert) heart by all practicable and impracticable means, and when Herbert had told me that his (Herbert) affianced already knew me by reputation and that I should be presented to her (Joe), and when we had warmly shaken hands upon our mutual confidence, we blew out our candles, made up our fire, locked our door, and issued forth in quest of Mr. Wopsle and Denmark.

On our arrival in Denmark, we found the king and queen of that country elevated in two arm-chairs on a kitchen-table, holding a Court.

The whole of the Danish nobility were in attendance; consisting of a noble boy in the wash-leather boots of a gigantic ancestor, a venerable Peer with a dirty face who seemed to have risen from the people late in life, and the Danish chivalry with a comb in its hair and a pair of white silk legs, and presenting on the whole a feminine appearance.

My gifted townsman stood gloomily apart, with folded arms, and I could have wished that his (Peer) curls and forehead had been more probable.

The late king of the country not only appeared to have been troubled with a cough at the time of his (king) decease, but to have taken it with him (king) to the tomb, and to have brought it back.

The royal phantom also carried a ghostly manuscript round its truncheon, to which it had the appearance of occasionally referring, and that too, with an air of anxiety and a tendency to lose the place of reference which were suggestive of a state of mortality.

It was this, I conceive, which led to the Shade's being advised by the gallery to

``turn over!'' (the Shade)
--a recommendation which it took extremely ill.

It was likewise to be noted of this majestic spirit, that whereas it always appeared with an air of having been out a long time and walked an immense distance, it perceptibly came from a closely contiguous wall.

The Queen of Denmark, a very buxom lady, though no doubt historically brazen, was considered by the public to have too much brass about her (lady); her (lady) chin being attached to her (lady) diadem by a broad band of that metal -LRB-as if she (lady) had a gorgeous toothache-RRB-, her (lady) waist being encircled by another, and each of her (lady) arms by another, so that she (lady) was openly mentioned as

``the kettle-drum.

The noble boy in the ancestral boots was inconsistent, representing himself, as it were in one breath, as an able seaman, a strolling actor, a grave-digger, a clergyman, and a person of the utmost importance at a Court fencing-match, on the authority of whose practised eye and nice discrimination the finest strokes were judged.

This gradually led to a want of toleration for him (clergyman), and even--on his (clergyman) being detected in holy orders, and declining to perform the funeral service--to the general indignation taking the form of nuts.
