Lastly, Ophelia was a prey to such slow musical madness, that when, in course of time, she (Ophelia) had taken off her (Ophelia) white muslin scarf, folded it up, and buried it, a sulky man who had been long cooling his (man) impatient nose against an iron bar in the front row of the gallery, growled,

Chapter XXXI Several curious little circumstances transpired as the action proceeded. This occasioned its terrors to be received derisively. '' (she)

``Now the baby's put to bed let's have supper!

'' (unknown)

Which, to say the least of it, was out of keeping. Upon my unfortunate townsman all these incidents accumulated with playful effect.

As for example; on the question whether 'twas nobler in the mind to suffer, some roared yes, and some no, and some inclining to both opinions said

``Toss up for it;'' (unknown)
and quite a Debating Society arose.

When he (my) asked what should such fellows as he (my) do crawling between earth and heaven, he (my) was encouraged with loud cries of

``Hear, hear!

Whenever that undecided Prince had to ask a question or state a doubt, the public helped him (Prince) out with it. '' (he)

When he (Prince) appeared with his (Prince) stocking disordered -LRB-its disorder expressed, according to usage, by one very neat fold in the top, which I suppose to be always got up with a flat iron-RRB-, a conversation took place in the gallery respecting the paleness of his (Prince) leg, and whether it was occasioned by the turn the ghost had given him (Prince).

On his (Prince) taking the recorders,--very like a little black flute that had just been played in the orchestra and handed out at the door,--he (Prince) was called upon unanimously for Rule Britannia.

When he (Prince) recommended the player not to saw the air thus, the sulky man said,

``And don't you do it, neither; you're a deal worse than him (man)!'' (the man)

But his (man) greatest trials were in the churchyard, which had the appearance of a primeval forest, with a kind of small ecclesiastical wash-house on one side, and a turnpike gate on the other.

Mr. Wopsle in a comprehensive black cloak, being descried entering at the turnpike, the gravedigger was admonished in a friendly way, ``Look out!

And I grieve to add that peals of laughter greeted Mr. Wopsle on every one of these occasions. Here's the undertaker a coming, to see how you're a getting on with your work!

I believe it is well known in a constitutional country that Mr. Wopsle could not possibly have returned the skull, after moralizing over it, without dusting his (Wopsle) fingers on a white napkin taken from his (Wopsle) breast; but even that innocent and indispensable action did not pass without the comment,

``Wai-ter!'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)

The arrival of the body for interment -LRB-in an empty black box with the lid tumbling open-RRB-, was the signal for a general joy, which was much enhanced by the discovery, among the bearers, of an individual obnoxious to identification.

The joy attended Mr. Wopsle through his (Wopsle) struggle with Laertes on the brink of the orchestra and the grave, and slackened no more until he (Wopsle) had tumbled the king off the kitchen-table, and had died by inches from the ankles upward.

We had made some pale efforts in the beginning to applaud Mr. Wopsle; but they were too hopeless to be persisted in.

I laughed in spite of myself all the time, the whole thing was so droll; and yet I had a latent impression that there was something decidedly fine in Mr. Wopsle's elocution,--not for old associations' sake, I am afraid, but because it was very slow, very dreary, very uphill and downhill, and very unlike any way in which any man in any natural circumstances of life or death ever expressed himself about anything.

When the tragedy was over, and he (man) had been called for and hooted, I said to Herbert,

``Let us go at once, or perhaps we shall meet him (Herbert).

'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

Therefore we had sat, feeling keenly for him (Herbert), but laughing, nevertheless, from ear to ear. '' We made all the haste we could downstairs, but we were not quick enough either.

Standing at the door was a Jewish man with an unnatural heavy smear of eyebrow, who caught my eyes as we advanced, and said, when we came up with him (man),--

``Mr. Pip and friend?

'' (him)

Identity of Mr. Pip and friend confessed. '' Mr. Waldengarver,'' said the man,
``would be glad to have the honor.'' (the man)

``Waldengarver? '' (I)
I repeated--when Herbert murmured in my ear,
``Probably Wopsle.'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
``Oh!'' (I.)
said I.
``Yes. Shall we follow you?'' (I.)
'' A few steps, please.

'' When we were in a side alley, he (Herbert) turned and asked,

``How did you think he (Herbert) looked?--I dressed him (Herbert). '' (he)

I don't know what he (Herbert) had looked like, except a funeral; with the addition of a large Danish sun or star hanging round his (Herbert) neck by a blue ribbon, that had given him (Herbert) the appearance of being insured in some extraordinary Fire Office.

But I said he (Herbert) had looked very nice. '' When he (Herbert) come to the grave,'' said our conductor,

``he (conductor) showed his (conductor) cloak beautiful.

But, judging from the wing, it looked to me that when he (conductor) see the ghost in the queen's apartment, he (conductor) might have made more of his (conductor) stockings.

I modestly assented, and we all fell through a little dirty swing door, into a sort of hot packing-case immediately behind it.

Here Mr. Wopsle was divesting himself of his (Wopsle) Danish garments, and here there was just room for us to look at him (Wopsle) over one another's shoulders, by keeping the packing-case door, or lid, wide open.

'' (conductor)

'' Gentlemen,'' said Mr. Wopsle,
``I am proud to see you. I hope, Mr. Pip, you will excuse my sending round.

I had the happiness to know you in former times, and the Drama has ever had a claim which has ever been acknowledged, on the noble and the affluent.

'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)

Meanwhile, Mr. Waldengarver, in a frightful perspiration, was trying to get himself out of his (Waldengarver) princely sables. '' Skin the stockings off Mr. Waldengarver,'' said the owner of that property,
``or you'll bust 'em.

Bust 'em, and you'll bust five-and-thirty shillings. Shakspeare never was complimented with a finer pair. Keep quiet in your chair now, and leave 'em to me.

With that, he (Waldengarver) went upon his (Waldengarver) knees, and began to flay his (Waldengarver) victim; who, on the first stocking coming off, would certainly have fallen over backward with his (Waldengarver) chair, but for there being no room to fall anyhow.

'' (the owner)

I had been afraid until then to say a word about the play. But then, Mr. Waldengarver looked up at us complacently, and said,--

``Gentlemen, how did it seem to you, to go, in front?'' (Mr. Waldengarver)
Herbert said from behind -LRB-at the same time poking me-RRB-,
``Capitally.

'' (me)

So I said
``Capitally.'' (I)
``How did you like my reading of the character, gentlemen?'' (Mr. Waldengarver)
said Mr. Waldengarver, almost, if not quite, with patronage.

Herbert said from behind -LRB-again poking me-RRB-,

``Massive and concrete. '' (me)
So I said boldly, as if I had originated it, and must beg to insist upon it,
``Massive and concrete.'' (I)

``I am glad to have your approbation, gentlemen,'' (Mr. Waldengarver)
said Mr. Waldengarver, with an air of dignity, in spite of his (Waldengarver) being ground against the wall at the time, and holding on by the seat of the chair.

But I'll tell you one thing, Mr. Waldengarver,'' said the man who was on his (Waldengarver) knees,

``in which you're out in your reading.

'' (the man)

Now mind! I don't care who says contrairy; I tell you so. You're out in your reading of Hamlet when you get your legs in profile.

The last Hamlet as I dressed, made the same mistakes in his (Waldengarver) reading at rehearsal, till I got him (Waldengarver) to put a large red wafer on each of his (Waldengarver) shins, and then at that rehearsal -LRB-which was the last-RRB-

I went in front, sir, to the back of the pit, and whenever his (Waldengarver) reading brought him (Waldengarver) into profile, I called out

``I don't see no wafers!'' (I)

And at night his (Waldengarver) reading was lovely. '' Mr. Waldengarver smiled at me, as much as to say

``a faithful Dependent--I overlook his (Waldengarver) folly;'' (me)
and then said aloud,

``My view is a little classic and thoughtful for them here; but they will improve, they will improve.'' (me)
Herbert and I said together, O, no doubt they would improve.

Did you observe, gentlemen,'' said Mr. Waldengarver,

``that there was a man in the gallery who endeavored to cast derision on the service,--I

'' (Mr. Waldengarver)

mean, the representation? '' We basely replied that we rather thought we had noticed such a man. I added,
``He (man) was drunk, no doubt.'' (I)

``O dear no, sir,'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)
said Mr. Wopsle,
``not drunk. His (Wopsle) employer would see to that, sir. His (Wopsle) employer would not allow him (Wopsle) to be drunk.

'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)

``You know his (Wopsle) employer?'' (I)
said I. Mr. Wopsle shut his (Wopsle) eyes, and opened them again; performing both ceremonies very slowly.

You must have observed, gentlemen,'' said he (Wopsle),

``an ignorant and a blatant ass, with a rasping throat and a countenance expressive of low malignity, who went through--I will not say sustained--the rôle -LRB-if I may use a French expression-RRB- of Claudius, King of Denmark.

Without distinctly knowing whether I should have been more sorry for Mr. Wopsle if he (Wopsle) had been in despair, I was so sorry for him (Wopsle) as it was, that I took the opportunity of his (Wopsle) turning round to have his (Wopsle) braces put on,--which

'' (he)

That is his (Wopsle) employer, gentlemen. Such is the profession!'' jostled us out at the doorway,--to ask Herbert what he (Herbert) thought of having him (Herbert) home to supper?

; therefore I invited him (Herbert), and he (Herbert) went to Barnard's with us, wrapped up to the eyes, and we did our best for him (Herbert), and he (Herbert) sat until two o'clock in the morning, reviewing his (Herbert) success and developing his (Herbert) plans.

I forget in detail what they were, but I have a general recollection that he (Herbert) was to begin with reviving the Drama, and to end with crushing it; inasmuch as his (Herbert) decease would leave it utterly bereft and without a chance or hope.

Miserably I went to bed after all, and miserably thought of Estella, and miserably dreamed that my expectations were all cancelled, and that I had to give my hand in marriage to Herbert's Clara, or play Hamlet to Miss Havisham's Ghost, before twenty thousand people, without knowing twenty words of it.

One day when I was busy with my books and Mr. Pocket, I received a note by the post, the mere outside of which threw me into a great flutter; for, though I had never seen the handwriting in which it was addressed, I divined whose hand it was.

It had no set beginning, as Dear Mr. Pip, or Dear Pip, or Dear Sir, or Dear Anything, but ran thus:--

Herbert said he (Herbert) thought it would be kind to do so Chapter XXXII

``I am to come to London the day after to-morrow by the midday coach.

I believe it was settled you should meet me? At all events Miss Havisham has that impression, and I write in obedience to it.

If there had been time, I should probably have ordered several suits of clothes for this occasion; but as there was not, I was fain to be content with those I had.

She (Havisham) sends you her (Havisham) regard. '' (he)

Yours, ESTELLA. '' My appetite vanished instantly, and I knew no peace or rest until the day arrived.

Not that its arrival brought me either; for, then I was worse than ever, and began haunting the coach-office in Wood Street, Cheapside, before the coach had left the Blue Boar in our town.

, I still felt as if it were not safe to let the coach-office be out of my sight longer than five minutes at a time; and in this condition of unreason I had performed the first half-hour of a watch of four or five hours, when Wemmick ran against me.

For all that I knew this perfectly well '' Halloa, Mr. Pip,'' said he (Pip);

``how do you do? I should hardly have thought this was your beat.

I explained that I was waiting to meet somebody who was coming up by coach, and I inquired after the Castle and the Aged.

I have a notion of firing eighty-two times, if the neighborhood shouldn't complain, and that cannon of mine should prove equal to the pressure.

'' (he)

'' Both flourishing thankye,'' said Wemmick,
``and particularly the Aged. He (Wemmick)'s in wonderful feather. He (Wemmick)'ll be eighty-two next birthday. However, this is not London talk.

Where do you think I am going to?'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

``To the office?'' (I)
said I, for he (Wemmick) was tending in that direction. ''

We are in a banker's-parcel case just at present, and I have been down the road taking a squint at the scene of action, and thereupon must have a word or two with our client.''

Next thing to it,'' returned Wemmick, ``I am going to Newgate.

``Did your client commit the robbery? '' (I)
I asked. ''

Bless your soul and body, no,'' answered Wemmick, very drily. '' But he (Wemmick) is accused of it. So might you or I be.

Either of us might be accused of it, you know. ''

``Only neither of us is,'' (I)
I remarked. '' Yah!'' said Wemmick, touching me on the breast with his (Wemmick) forefinger;
``you're a deep one, Mr. Pip!

I had so much time to spare, that the proposal came as a relief, notwithstanding its irreconcilability with my latent desire to keep my eye on the coach-office.

Muttering that I would make the inquiry whether I had time to walk with him (Wemmick), I went into the office, and ascertained from the clerk with the nicest precision and much to the trying of his (Wemmick) temper, the earliest moment at which the coach could be expected,--which

Would you like to have a look at Newgate? Have you time to spare? '' (me)

I knew beforehand, quite as well as he (coach).

I then rejoined Mr. Wemmick, and affecting to consult my watch, and to be surprised by the information I had received, accepted his (Wemmick) offer.

We were at Newgate in a few minutes, and we passed through the lodge where some fetters were hanging up on the bare walls among the prison rules, into the interior of the jail.

At that time jails were much neglected, and the period of exaggerated reaction consequent on all public wrongdoing--and which is always its heaviest and longest punishment--was still far off.

So, felons were not lodged and fed better than soldiers -LRB-to say nothing of paupers-RRB-, and seldom set fire to their prisons with the excusable object of improving the flavor of their soup.

It was visiting time when Wemmick took me in, and a potman was going his (Wemmick) rounds with beer; and the prisoners, behind bars in yards, were buying beer, and talking to friends; and a frowzy, ugly, disorderly, depressing scene it was.

This was first put into my head by his (Wemmick) seeing a shoot that had come up in the night, and saying,

``What, Captain Tom?

It struck me that Wemmick walked among the prisoners much as a gardener might walk among his (Wemmick) plants. Are you there?

Ah, indeed!'' (unknown)

and also,
``Is that Black Bill behind the cistern? Why I didn't look for you these two months; how do you find yourself?'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

Equally in his (Wemmick) stopping at the bars and attending to anxious whisperers,--always singly,--Wemmick with his (Wemmick) post-office in an immovable state, looked at them while in conference, as if he (Wemmick) were taking particular notice of the advance they had made, since last observed, towards coming out in full blow at their trial.

He (Wemmick) was highly popular, and I found that he (Wemmick) took the familiar department of Mr. Jaggers's business; though something of the state of Mr. Jaggers hung about him (Jaggers) too, forbidding approach beyond certain limits.

His (Jaggers) personal recognition of each successive client was comprised in a nod, and in his (Jaggers) settling his (Jaggers) hat a little easier on his (Jaggers) head with both hands, and then tightening the post-office, and putting his (Jaggers) hands in his (Jaggers) pockets.

In one or two instances there was a difficulty respecting the raising of fees, and then Mr. Wemmick, backing as far as possible from the insufficient money produced, said, ``it's no use, my boy.

If you are unable to make up your quantum, my boy, you had better address yourself to a principal; there are plenty of principals in the profession, you know, and what is not worth the while of one, may be worth the while of another

I'm only a subordinate. I can't take it. Don't go on in that way with a subordinate. ; that's my recommendation to you, speaking as a subordinate.

Thus, we walked through Wemmick's greenhouse, until he (Wemmick) turned to me and said,

``Notice the man I shall shake hands with.

Don't try on useless measures. Why should you? Now, who's next? '' (me)

'' I should have done so, without the preparation, as he (Wemmick) had shaken hands with no one yet.

Almost as soon as he (Wemmick) had spoken, a portly upright man -LRB-whom I can see now, as I write-RRB- in a well-worn olive-colored frock-coat, with a peculiar pallor overspreading the red in his (man) complexion, and eyes that went wandering about when he (man) tried to fix them, came up to a corner of the bars, and put his (man) hand to his (man) hat--which had a greasy and fatty surface like cold broth--with a half-serious and half-jocose military salute.

'' Colonel, to you! '' said Wemmick;

``how are you, Colonel?'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
'' All right, Mr. Wemmick. '' '' Everything was done that could be done, but the evidence was too strong for us, Colonel.''

``Yes, it was too strong, sir,--but I don't care. '' (unknown)
``No, no,'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
said Wemmick, coolly,
``you don't care. '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
Then, turning to me,
``Served His (Wemmick) Majesty this man.

'' (me)

and the man's eyes looked at me, and then looked over my head, and then looked all round me, and then he (Wemmick) drew his (Wemmick) hand across his (Wemmick) lips and laughed.

Was a soldier in the line and bought his (Wemmick) discharge. '' I said,

``Indeed? '' (I)
I think I shall be out of this on Monday, sir,'' he (Wemmick) said to Wemmick.

``I am glad to have the chance of bidding you good-bye, Mr. Wemmick,'' (the man)
said the man, stretching out his (Wemmick) hand between two bars.

'' Perhaps,'' returned my friend,

``but there's no knowing. '' (friend)
'' Thankye,'' said Wemmick, shaking hands with him (Wemmick). '' Same to you, Colonel.''

If what I had upon me when taken had been real, Mr. Wemmick,'' said the man, unwilling to let his (Wemmick) hand go,

``I should have asked the favor of your wearing another ring--in acknowledgment of your attentions.

'' (the man)

''
``I'll accept the will for the deed,'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
said Wemmick. '' By the by; you were quite a pigeon-fancier. ''

The man looked up at the sky. '' I am told you had a remarkable breed of tumblers. Could you commission any friend of yours to bring me a pair, if you've no further use for 'em?''

``It shall be done, sir.'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
'' All right,'' said Wemmick,
``they shall be taken care of. Good afternoon, Colonel. Good-bye! '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

They shook hands again, and as we walked away Wemmick said to me,

``A Coiner, a very good workman. The Recorder's report is made to-day, and he (Wemmick) is sure to be executed on Monday.

With that, he (Wemmick) looked back, and nodded at this dead plant, and then cast his (Wemmick) eyes about him (Wemmick) in walking out of the yard, as if he (Wemmick) were considering what other pot would go best in its place.

As we came out of the prison through the lodge, I found that the great importance of my guardian was appreciated by the turnkeys, no less than by those whom they held in charge.

Well, Mr. Wemmick,'' (me)

said the turnkey, who kept us between the two studded and spiked lodge gates, and who carefully locked one before he (Wemmick) unlocked the other,
``what's Mr. Jaggers going to do with that water-side murder?

Still you see, as far as it goes, a pair of pigeons are portable property all the same. '' (he)

'' Is he (Jaggers) going to make it manslaughter, or what's he (Jaggers) going to make of it?

''

``Why don't you ask him (Jaggers)? '' (unknown)
returned Wemmick. '' O yes, I dare say!'' said the turnkey. '' Now, that's the way with them here, Mr. Pip,'' remarked Wemmick, turning to me with his (Wemmick) post-office elongated.

They don't mind what they ask of me, the subordinate; but you'll never catch 'em asking any questions of my principal.''

``Is this young gentleman one of the `prentices or articled ones of your office?'' (the turnkey)
asked the turnkey, with a grin at Mr. Wemmick's humor.

'' '' There he (Wemmick) goes again, you see!'' cried Wemmick,

``I told you so! Asks another question of the subordinate before his (Wemmick) first is dry!

Well, supposing Mr. Pip is one of them?'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

``Why then,'' (the turnkey)
said the turnkey, grinning again,
``he (Wemmick) knows what Mr. Jaggers is.'' (the turnkey)

'' cried Wemmick, suddenly hitting out at the turnkey in a facetious way, ``you're dumb as one of your own keys when you have to do with my principal, you know you are.

``Yah! Let us out, you old fox, or I'll get him (fox) to bring an action against you for false imprisonment. '' (The turnkey)

The turnkey laughed, and gave us good day, and stood laughing at us over the spikes of the wicket when we descended the steps into the street.

Mind you, Mr. Pip,'' said Wemmick, gravely in my ear, as he (Wemmick) took my arm to be more confidential;

``I don't know that Mr. Jaggers does a better thing than the way in which he (Jaggers) keeps himself so high.

'' (he)

He (Jaggers)'s always so high. His (Jaggers) constant height is of a piece with his (Jaggers) immense abilities. That Colonel durst no more take leave of him (Jaggers), than that turnkey durst ask him (Jaggers) his (Jaggers) intentions respecting a case.

Then, between his (Jaggers) height and them, he (Jaggers) slips in his (Jaggers) subordinate,--don't you see?--and so he (Jaggers) has 'em, soul and body. ''

To confess the truth, I very heartily wished, and not for the first time, that I had had some other guardian of minor abilities.

Mr. Wemmick and I parted at the office in Little Britain, where suppliants for Mr. Jaggers's notice were lingering about as usual, and I returned to my watch in the street of the coach-office, with some three hours on hand.

I consumed the whole time in thinking how strange it was that I should be encompassed by all this taint of prison and crime; that, in my childhood out on our lonely marshes on a winter evening, I should have first encountered it; that, it should have reappeared on two occasions, starting out like a stain that was faded but not gone; that, it should in this new way pervade my fortune and advancement.

While my mind was thus engaged, I thought of the beautiful young Estella, proud and refined, coming towards me, and I thought with absolute abhorrence of the contrast between the jail and her (Estella).

I wished that Wemmick had not met me, or that I had not yielded to him (Wemmick) and gone with him (Wemmick), so that, of all days in the year on this day, I might not have had Newgate in my breath and on my clothes.

I beat the prison dust off my feet as I sauntered to and fro, and I shook it out of my dress, and I exhaled its air from my lungs.

So contaminated did I feel, remembering who was coming, that the coach came quickly after all, and I was not yet free from the soiling consciousness of Mr. Wemmick's conservatory, when I saw her (Wemmick) face at the coach window and her (Wemmick) hand waving to me.

I was very much impressed, and not for the first time, by my guardian's subtlety. What was the nameless shadow which again in that one instant had passed?

Chapter XXXIII In her (Wemmick) furred travelling-dress, Estella seemed more delicately beautiful than she (Estella) had ever seemed yet, even in my eyes.

Her (Estella) manner was more winning than she (Estella) had cared to let it be to me before, and I thought I saw Miss Havisham's influence in the change.

We stood in the Inn Yard while she (Estella) pointed out her (Estella) luggage to me, and when it was all collected I remembered--having forgotten everything but herself in the meanwhile--that I knew nothing of her (Estella) destination.

Our lesson is, that there are two Richmonds, one in Surrey and one in Yorkshire, and that mine is the Surrey Richmond.

'' I am going to Richmond,'' she (Estella) told me. '' The distance is ten miles. I am to have a carriage, and you are to take me.

This is my purse, and you are to pay my charges out of it. O, you must take the purse! We have no choice, you and I, but to obey our instructions.

We are not free to follow our own devices, you and I.'' As she (Estella) looked at me in giving me the purse, I hoped there was an inner meaning in her (Estella) words.

She (Estella) said them slightingly, but not with displeasure. '' A carriage will have to be sent for, Estella. Will you rest here a little?''

``Yes, I am to rest here a little, and I am to drink some tea, and you are to take care of me the while.

She (Estella) drew her (Estella) arm through mine, as if it must be done, and I requested a waiter who had been staring at the coach like a man who had never seen such a thing in his (man) life, to show us a private sitting-room.

Upon that, he (man) pulled out a napkin, as if it were a magic clew without which he (man) couldn't find the way upstairs, and led us to the black hole of the establishment, fitted up with a diminishing mirror -LRB-quite a superfluous article, considering the hole's proportions-RRB-, an anchovy sauce-cruet, and somebody's pattens.

On my objecting to this retreat, he (man) took us into another room with a dinner-table for thirty, and in the grate a scorched leaf of a copy-book under a bushel of coal-dust.

which, proving to be merely,

``Some tea for the lady,'' (him)
sent him (man) out of the room in a very low state of mind.

I was, and I am, sensible that the air of this chamber, in its strong combination of stable with soup-stock, might have led one to infer that the coaching department was not doing well, and that the enterprising proprietor was boiling down the horses for the refreshment department.

'' Having looked at this extinct conflagration and shaken his (proprietor) head, he (proprietor) took my order; Yet the room was all in all to me, Estella being in it.

I thought that with her (Estella) I could have been happy there for life. -LRB-I was not at all happy there at the time, observe, and I knew it well.-RRB-

I am going to live,'' said she (Estella),

``at a great expense, with a lady there, who has the power--or says she (Estella) has--of taking me about, and introducing me, and showing people to me and showing me to people.

'' (she)

Where are you going to, at Richmond? '' I asked Estella. '' ''
``I suppose you will be glad of variety and admiration?'' (unknown)

``Yes, I suppose so. '' (She)
She (Estella) answered so carelessly, that I said,
``You speak of yourself as if you were some one else.'' (I)

Come, come,'' said Estella, smiling delightfully, ``you must not expect me to go to school to you; I must talk in my own way.

``Where did you learn how I speak of others? How do you thrive with Mr. Pocket?'' (unknown)
``I live quite pleasantly there; at least--'' (me)
It appeared to me that I was losing a chance.

'' At least?'' repeated Estella. '' As pleasantly as I could anywhere, away from you. ''

``You silly boy,'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)
said Estella, quite composedly,
``how can you talk such nonsense?

Your friend Mr. Matthew, I believe, is superior to the rest of his (Matthew) family?'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)

``Very superior indeed. He (Matthew) is nobody's enemy--

'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)

``Don't add but his (Matthew) own,'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)
interposed Estella,
``for I hate that class of man. But he (Matthew) really is disinterested, and above small jealousy and spite, I have heard?'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)

You have not every reason to say so of the rest of his (Matthew) people,'' said Estella, nodding at me with an expression of face that was at once grave and rallying, ``for they beset Miss Havisham with reports and insinuations to your disadvantage.

They watch you, misrepresent you, write letters about you -LRB-anonymous sometimes-RRB-, and you are the torment and the occupation of their lives.

``I am sure I have every reason to say so. '' (those people)
'' You can scarcely realize to yourself the hatred those people feel for you.''

``They do me no harm, I hope? '' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)
Instead of answering, Estella burst out laughing. This was very singular to me, and I looked at her (Estella) in considerable perplexity.

When she (Estella) left off--and she (Estella) had not laughed languidly, but with real enjoyment--I said, in my diffident way with her (Estella),-- ''

I hope I may suppose that you would not be amused if they did me any harm. '' '' No, no you may be sure of that,'' said Estella.

'' You may be certain that I laugh because they fail. O, those people with Miss Havisham, and the tortures they undergo!

She (Havisham) laughed again, and even now when she (Havisham) had told me why, her (Havisham) laughter was very singular to me, for I could not doubt its being genuine, and yet it seemed too much for the occasion.

I thought there must really be something more here than I knew; she (Havisham) saw the thought in my mind, and answered it.

It is not easy for even you.'' said Estella,

``to know what satisfaction it gives me to see those people thwarted, or what an enjoyable sense of the ridiculous I have when they are made ridiculous.

You had not your little wits sharpened by their intriguing against you, suppressed and defenceless, under the mask of sympathy and pity and what not that is soft and soothing.

You did not gradually open your round childish eyes wider and wider to the discovery of that impostor of a woman who calculates her (woman) stores of peace of mind for when she (woman) wakes up in the night.

'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)

'' For you were not brought up in that strange house from a mere baby. I was. I had. I did.

'' It was no laughing matter with Estella now, nor was she (Estella) summoning these remembrances from any shallow place. I would not have been the cause of that look of hers for all my expectations in a heap.

First, notwithstanding the proverb that constant dropping will wear away a stone, you may set your mind at rest that these people never will--never would, in hundred years--impair your ground with Miss Havisham, in any particular, great or small.

Second, I am beholden to you as the cause of their being so busy and so mean in vain, and there is my hand upon it.

'' Two things I can tell you,'' said Estella. '' '' As she (Estella) gave it to me playfully,--for her (Estella) darker mood had been but Momentary,--I held it and put it to my lips.

'' You ridiculous boy,'' said Estella,

``will you never take warning? Or do you kiss my hand in the same spirit in which I once let you kiss my cheek?'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)

'' What spirit was that?'' said I.

``I must think a moment. A spirit of contempt for the fawners and plotters.

'' (I.)

'' If I say yes, may I kiss the cheek again?''
``You should have asked before you touched the hand.

Now,'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)

said Estella, gliding away the instant I touched her (Estella) cheek,
``you are to take care that I have some tea, and you are to take me to Richmond.

Her (Estella) reverting to this tone as if our association were forced upon us, and we were mere puppets, gave me pain; but everything in our intercourse did give me pain.

Whatever her (Estella) tone with me happened to be, I could put no trust in it, and build no hope on it; and yet I went on against trust and against hope.

But, yes, if you like. '' (I)

I leaned down, and her (Estella) calm face was like a statue's. '' '' Why repeat it a thousand times?

I rang for the tea, and the waiter, reappearing with his (waiter) magic clew, brought in by degrees some fifty adjuncts to that refreshment, but of tea not a glimpse.

A teaboard, cups and saucers, plates, knives and forks -LRB-including carvers-RRB-, spoons -LRB-various-RRB-, saltcellars, a meek little muffin confined with the utmost precaution under a strong iron cover, Moses in the bulrushes typified by a soft bit of butter in a quantity of parsley, a pale loaf with a powdered head, two proof impressions of the bars of the kitchen fireplace on triangular bits of bread, and ultimately a fat family urn; which the waiter staggered in with, expressing in his (waiter) countenance burden and suffering.

After a prolonged absence at this stage of the entertainment, he (waiter) at length came back with a casket of precious appearance containing twigs.

These I steeped in hot water, and so from the whole of these appliances extracted one cup of I don't know what for Estella.

The bill paid, and the waiter remembered, and the ostler not forgotten, and the chambermaid taken into consideration,--in a word, the whole house bribed into a state of contempt and animosity, and Estella's purse much lightened,--we got into our post-coach and drove away.

So it always was. Turning into Cheapside and rattling up Newgate Street, we were soon under the walls of which I was so ashamed.

'' What place is that?'' Estella asked me. I made a foolish pretence of not at first recognizing it, and then told her (Estella).

As she (Estella) looked at it, and drew in her (Estella) head again, murmuring,

``Wretches! '' (she)
I would not have confessed to my visit for any consideration.

Mr. Jaggers,'' said I, by way of putting it neatly on somebody else,

``has the reputation of being more in the secrets of that dismal place than any man in London.'' (somebody)

'' '' He (man) is more in the secrets of every place, I think,'' said Estella, in a low voice. '' You have been accustomed to see him (man) often, I suppose?

''

``I have been accustomed to see him (man) at uncertain intervals, ever since I can remember. But I know him (man) no better now, than I did before I could speak plainly.

What is your own experience of him (man)? Do you advance with him (man)?'' (I)

'' Once habituated to his (man) distrustful manner,'' said I,
``I have done very well.

'' (I)

``Are you intimate?'' (unknown)
``I have dined with him (man) at his (man) private house.'' (I)
'' I fancy,'' said Estella, shrinking
``that must be a curious place.'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)

I should have been chary of discussing my guardian too freely even with her (Estella); but I should have gone on with the subject so far as to describe the dinner in Gerrard Street, if we had not then come into a sudden glare of gas.

It seemed, while it lasted, to be all alight and alive with that inexplicable feeling I had had before; and when we were out of it, I was as much dazed for a few moments as if I had been in lightning.

So we fell into other talk, and it was principally about the way by which we were travelling, and about what parts of London lay on this side of it, and what on that.

The great city was almost new to her (it), she (it) told me, for she (it) had never left Miss Havisham's neighborhood until she (it) had gone to France, and she (it) had merely passed through London then in going and returning.

``It is a curious place. '' (I)
I asked her (it) if my guardian had any charge of her (it) while she (it) remained here?

It was impossible for me to avoid seeing that she (it) cared to attract me; that she (it) made herself winning, and would have won me even if the task had needed pains.

Yet this made me none the happier, for even if she (it) had not taken that tone of our being disposed of by others, I should have felt that she (it) held my heart in her (it) hand because she (it) wilfully chose to do it, and not because it would have wrung any tenderness in her (it) to crush it and throw it away.

When we passed through Hammersmith, I showed her (it) where Mr. Matthew Pocket lived, and said it was no great way from Richmond, and that I hoped I should see her (it) sometimes.

O yes, you are to see me; you are to come when you think proper; you are to be mentioned to the family; indeed you are already mentioned.

To that she (it) emphatically said

``God forbid!'' (she)
and no more. '' '' I inquired was it a large household she (it) was going to be a member of?

'' No; there are only two; mother and daughter. The mother is a lady of some station, though not averse to increasing her (mother) income.

``It is a part of Miss Havisham's plans for me, Pip,'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)
said Estella, with a sigh, as if she (Estella) were tired;
``I am to write to her (Estella) constantly and see her (Estella) regularly and report how I go on,--I and the jewels,--for

'' (she)

``I wonder Miss Havisham could part with you again so soon. '' (she)
they are nearly all mine now. '' It was the first time she (Havisham) had ever called me by my name.

We came to Richmond all too soon, and our destination there was a house by the green,--a staid old house, where hoops and powder and patches, embroidered coats, rolled stockings, ruffles and swords, had had their court days many a time.

Some ancient trees before the house were still cut into fashions as formal and unnatural as the hoops and wigs and stiff skirts; but their own allotted places in the great procession of the dead were not far off, and they would soon drop into them and go the silent way of the rest.

A bell with an old voice--which I dare say in its time had often said to the house, Here is the green farthingale, Here is the diamond-hilted sword, Here are the shoes with red heels and the blue solitaire--sounded gravely in the moonlight, and two cherry-colored maids came fluttering out to receive Estella.

The doorway soon absorbed her (Estella) boxes, and she (Estella) gave me her (Estella) hand and a smile, and said good night, and was absorbed likewise.

And still I stood looking at the house, thinking how happy I should be if I lived there with her (Estella), and knowing that I never was happy with her (Estella), but always miserable.

I got into the carriage to be taken back to Hammersmith, and I got in with a bad heart-ache, and I got out with a worse heart-ache.

At our own door, I found little Jane Pocket coming home from a little party escorted by her (Jane) little lover; and I envied her (Jane) little lover, in spite of his (lover) being subject to Flopson.

Mr. Pocket was out lecturing; for, he (Pocket) was a most delightful lecturer on domestic economy, and his (Pocket) treatises on the management of children and servants were considered the very best text-books on those themes.

But Mrs. Pocket was at home, and was in a little difficulty, on account of the baby's having been accommodated with a needle-case to keep him (Pocket) quiet during the unaccountable absence -LRB-with a relative in the Foot Guards-RRB- of Millers.

And more needles were missing than it could be regarded as quite wholesome for a patient of such tender years either to apply externally or to take as a tonic.

Mr. Pocket being justly celebrated for giving most excellent practical advice, and for having a clear and sound perception of things and a highly judicious mind, I had some notion in my heart-ache of begging him (Pocket) to accept my confidence.

But happening to look up at Mrs. Pocket as she (Pocket) sat reading her (Pocket) book of dignities after prescribing Bed as a sovereign remedy for baby, I thought--

As I had grown accustomed to my expectations, I had insensibly begun to notice their effect upon myself and those around me.

Their influence on my own character I disguised from my recognition as much as possible, but I knew very well that it was not all good.

Of course she (Pocket) did so purposely, and knew that I should treasure it up. Well--No, I wouldn't. Chapter XXXIV I lived in a state of chronic uneasiness respecting my behavior to Joe.

When I woke up in the night,--like Camilla,--I used to think, with a weariness on my spirits, that I should have been happier and better if I had never seen Miss Havisham's face, and had risen to manhood content to be partners with Joe in the honest old forge.

Many a time of an evening, when I sat alone looking at the fire, I thought, after all there was no fire like the forge fire and the kitchen fire at home.

Yet Estella was so inseparable from all my restlessness and disquiet of mind, that I really fell into confusion as to the limits of my own part in its production.

That is to say, supposing I had had no expectations, and yet had had Estella to think of, I could not make out to my satisfaction that I should have done much better.

Now, concerning the influence of my position on others, I was in no such difficulty, and so I perceived--though dimly enough perhaps--that it was not beneficial to anybody, and, above all, that it was not beneficial to Herbert.

My lavish habits led his (Herbert) easy nature into expenses that he (Herbert) could not afford, corrupted the simplicity of his (Herbert) life, and disturbed his (Herbert) peace with anxieties and regrets.

I was not at all remorseful for having unwittingly set those other branches of the Pocket family to the poor arts they practised; because such littlenesses were their natural bent, and would have been evoked by anybody else, if I had left them slumbering.

But Herbert's was a very different case, and it often caused me a twinge to think that I had done him (Herbert) evil service in crowding his (Herbert) sparely furnished chambers with incongruous upholstery work, and placing the Canary-breasted Avenger at his (Herbert) disposal.

My conscience was not by any means comfortable about Biddy. So now, as an infallible way of making little ease great ease, I began to contract a quantity of debt.

At Startop's suggestion, we put ourselves down for election into a club called The Finches of the Grove: the object of which institution I have never divined, if it were not that the members should dine expensively once a fortnight, to quarrel among themselves as much as possible after dinner, and to cause six waiters to get drunk on the stairs.

I know that these gratifying social ends were so invariably accomplished, that Herbert and I understood nothing else to be referred to in the first standing toast of the society: which ran

``Gentlemen, may the present promotion of good feeling ever reign predominant among the Finches of the Grove.

The Finches spent their money foolishly -LRB-the Hotel we dined at was in Covent Garden-RRB-, and the first Finch I saw when I had the honor of joining the Grove was Bentley Drummle, at that time floundering about town in a cab of his (Finch) own, and doing a great deal of damage to the posts at the street corners.

Occasionally, he (Finch) shot himself out of his (Finch) equipage headforemost over the apron; and I saw him (Finch) on one occasion deliver himself at the door of the Grove in this unintentional way--like coals.

But here I anticipate a little, for I was not a Finch, and could not be, according to the sacred laws of the society, until I came of age.

In my confidence in my own resources, I would willingly have taken Herbert's expenses on myself; but Herbert was proud, and I could make no such proposal to him (Herbert).

I could hardly begin but Herbert must begin too, so he (Herbert) soon followed. '' (I)

So he (Herbert) got into difficulties in every direction, and continued to look about him (Herbert).

When we gradually fell into keeping late hours and late company, I noticed that he (Herbert) looked about him (Herbert) with a desponding eye at breakfast-time; that he (Herbert) began to look about him (Herbert) more hopefully about mid-day; that he (Herbert) drooped when he (Herbert) came into dinner; that he (Herbert) seemed to descry Capital in the distance, rather clearly, after dinner; that he (Herbert) all but realized Capital towards midnight; and that at about two o'clock in the morning, he (Herbert) became so deeply despondent again as to talk of buying a rifle and going to America, with a general purpose of compelling buffaloes to make his (Herbert) fortune.

I was usually at Hammersmith about half the week, and when I was at Hammersmith I haunted Richmond, whereof separately by and by.

Herbert would often come to Hammersmith when I was there, and I think at those seasons his (Herbert) father would occasionally have some passing perception that the opening he (Herbert) was looking for, had not appeared yet.

But in the general tumbling up of the family, his (Herbert) tumbling out in life somewhere, was a thing to transact itself somehow.

While Mrs. Pocket tripped up the family with her (Herbert) footstool, read her (Herbert) book of dignities, lost her (Herbert) pocket-handkerchief, told us about her (Herbert) grandpapa, and taught the young idea how to shoot, by shooting it into bed whenever it attracted her (Herbert) notice.

As I am now generalizing a period of my life with the object of clearing my way before me, I can scarcely do so better than by at once completing the description of our usual manners and customs at Barnard's Inn.

We spent as much money as we could, and got as little for it as people could make up their minds to give us.

In the meantime Mr. Pocket grew grayer, and tried oftener to lift himself out of his (Pocket) perplexities by the hair. We were always more or less miserable, and most of our acquaintance were in the same condition.

There was a gay fiction among us that we were constantly enjoying ourselves, and a skeleton truth that we never did.

To the best of my belief, our case was in the last aspect a rather common one. Every morning, with an air ever new, Herbert went into the City to look about him (Herbert).

I often paid him (Herbert) a visit in the dark back-room in which he (Herbert) consorted with an ink-jar, a hat-peg, a coal-box, a string-box, an almanac, a desk and stool, and a ruler; and I do not remember that I ever saw him (ruler) do anything else but look about him (ruler).

If we all did what we undertake to do, as faithfully as Herbert did, we might live in a Republic of the Virtues.

He (Herbert) had nothing else to do, poor fellow, except at a certain hour of every afternoon to

``go to Lloyd's'' (fellow)
--in observance of a ceremony of seeing his (Lloyd) principal, I think.

When he (Lloyd) felt his (Lloyd) case unusually serious, and that he (Lloyd) positively must find an opening, he (Lloyd) would go on `Change at a busy time, and walk in and out, in a kind of gloomy country dance figure, among the assembled magnates.

For,'' says Herbert to me, coming home to dinner on one of those special occasions,

``I find the truth to be, Handel, that an opening won't come to one, but one must go to it,--so

He (Handel) never did anything else in connection with Lloyd's that I could find out, except come back again. '' (me)

I have been.

'' If we had been less attached to one another, I think we must have hated one another regularly every morning.

I detested the chambers beyond expression at that period of repentance, and could not endure the sight of the Avenger's livery; which had a more expensive and a less remunerative appearance then than at any other time in the four-and-twenty hours.

As we got more and more into debt, breakfast became a hollower and hollower form, and, being on one occasion at breakfast-time threatened -LRB-by letter-RRB- with legal proceedings,

``not unwholly unconnected,'' (I)
as my local paper might put it,
``with jewelery,'' (I)
I went so far as to seize the Avenger by his (my) blue collar and shake him (my) off his (my) feet,--so that he (my) was actually in the air, like a booted Cupid,--for presuming to suppose that we wanted a roll.

At certain times--meaning at uncertain times, for they depended on our humor--I would say to Herbert, as if it were a remarkable discovery,--

My dear Handel,'' Herbert would say to me, in all sincerity,

``if you will believe me, those very words were on my lips, by a strange coincidence.'' (me)

'' My dear Herbert, we are getting on badly. '' ''

``Then, Herbert,'' (I)
I would respond,
``let us look into our affairs.

I always thought this was business, this was the way to confront the thing, this was the way to take the foe by the throat.

We ordered something rather special for dinner, with a bottle of something similarly out of the common way, in order that our minds might be fortified for the occasion, and we might come well up to the mark.

Dinner over, we produced a bundle of pens, a copious supply of ink, and a goodly show of writing and blotting paper.

'' (I)

We always derived profound satisfaction from making an appointment for this purpose. And I know Herbert thought so too. For there was something very comfortable in having plenty of stationery.

I would then take a sheet of paper, and write across the top of it, in a neat hand, the heading,

``Memorandum of Pip's debts'' (I)
; with Barnard's Inn and the date very carefully added.

Each of us would then refer to a confused heap of papers at his (Barnard) side, which had been thrown into drawers, worn into holes in pockets, half burnt in lighting candles, stuck for weeks into the looking-glass, and otherwise damaged.

The sound of our pens going refreshed us exceedingly, insomuch that I sometimes found it difficult to distinguish between this edifying business proceeding and actually paying the money.

Herbert would also take a sheet of paper, and write across it with similar formalities,

``Memorandum of Herbert's debts. '' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
In point of meritorious character, the two things seemed about equal.

When we had written a little while, I would ask Herbert how he (Herbert) got on? Herbert probably would have been scratching his (Herbert) head in a most rueful manner at the sight of his (Herbert) accumulating figures.

'' They are mounting up, Handel,'' Herbert would say;

``upon my life, they are mounting up.'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
``Be firm, Herbert,'' (I)
I would retort, plying my own pen with great assiduity.

'' Look the thing in the face. Look into your affairs. Stare them out of countenance.'' '' So I would, Handel, only they are staring me out of countenance.

After a time he (Handel) would give up once more, on the plea that he (Handel) had not got Cobbs's bill, or Lobbs's, or Nobbs's, as the case might be.

'' However, my determined manner would have its effect, and Herbert would fall to work again. '' Then, Herbert, estimate; estimate it in round numbers, and put it down.

''

``What a fellow of resource you are! '' (friend)
my friend would reply, with admiration. '' Really your business powers are very remarkable.

'' I thought so too. I established with myself, on these occasions, the reputation of a first-rate man of business,--prompt, decisive, energetic, clear, cool-headed.

When I had got all my responsibilities down upon my list, I compared each with the bill, and ticked it off.

When I had no more ticks to make, I folded all my bills up uniformly, docketed each on the back, and tied the whole into a symmetrical bundle.

Then I did the same for Herbert -LRB-who modestly said he (Herbert) had not my administrative genius-RRB-, and felt that I had brought his (Herbert) affairs into a focus for him (Herbert).

My self-approval when I ticked an entry was quite a luxurious sensation. My business habits had one other bright feature, which I called ``leaving a Margin.

For example; supposing Herbert's debts to be one hundred and sixty-four pounds four-and-twopence, I would say,

``Leave a margin, and put them down at two hundred.

Or, supposing my own to be four times as much, I would leave a margin, and put them down at seven hundred.

I had the highest opinion of the wisdom of this same Margin, but I am bound to acknowledge that on looking back, I deem it to have been an expensive device.

For, we always ran into new debt immediately, to the full extent of the margin, and sometimes, in the sense of freedom and solvency it imparted, got pretty far on into another margin.

But there was a calm, a rest, a virtuous hush, consequent on these examinations of our affairs that gave me, for the time, an admirable opinion of myself.

Soothed by my exertions, my method, and Herbert's compliments, I would sit with his (Herbert) symmetrical bundle and my own on the table before me among the stationary, and feel like a Bank of some sort, rather than a private individual.

I had fallen into my serene state one evening, when we heard a letter dropped through the slit in the said door, and fall on the ground.

It's for you, Handel,'' (I)

said Herbert, going out and coming back with it,
``and I hope there is nothing the matter.

'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

'' We shut our outer door on these solemn occasions, in order that we might not be interrupted. '' ''

The letter was signed Trabb & Co., and its contents were simply, that I was an honored sir, and that they begged to inform me that Mrs. J. Gargery had departed this life on Monday last at twenty minutes past six in the evening, and that my attendance was requested at the interment on Monday next at three o'clock in the afternoon.

It was the first time that a grave had opened in my road of life, and the gap it made in the smooth ground was wonderful.

This was in allusion to its heavy black seal and border. Chapter XXXV The figure of my sister in her (sister) chair by the kitchen fire, haunted me night and day.

That the place could possibly be, without her (sister), was something my mind seemed unable to compass; and whereas she (sister) had seldom or never been in my thoughts of late, I had now the strangest ideas that she (sister) was coming towards me in the street, or that she (sister) would presently knock at the door.

In my rooms too, with which she (sister) had never been at all associated, there was at once the blankness of death and a perpetual suggestion of the sound of her (sister) voice or the turn of her (sister) face or figure, as if she (sister) were still alive and had been often there.

Whatever my fortunes might have been, I could scarcely have recalled my sister with much tenderness. But I suppose there is a shock of regret which may exist without much tenderness.

Under its influence -LRB-and perhaps to make up for the want of the softer feeling-RRB- I was seized with a violent indignation against the assailant from whom she (sister) had suffered so much; and I felt that on sufficient proof I could have revengefully pursued Orlick, or any one else, to the last extremity.

Having written to Joe, to offer him (Orlick) consolation, and to assure him (Orlick) that I would come to the funeral, I passed the intermediate days in the curious state of mind I have glanced at.

I went down early in the morning, and alighted at the Blue Boar in good time to walk over to the forge.

It was fine summer weather again, and, as I walked along, the times when I was a little helpless creature, and my sister did not spare me, vividly returned.

For now, the very breath of the beans and clover whispered to my heart that the day must come when it would be well for my memory that others walking in the sunshine should be softened as they thought of me.

At last I came within sight of the house, and saw that Trabb and Co. had put in a funereal execution and taken possession.

Two dismally absurd persons, each ostentatiously exhibiting a crutch done up in a black bandage,--as if that instrument could possibly communicate any comfort to anybody,--were posted at the front door; and in one of them I recognized a postboy discharged from the Boar for turning a young couple into a sawpit on their bridal morning, in consequence of intoxication rendering it necessary for him (I) to ride his (I) horse clasped round the neck with both arms.

All the children of the village, and most of the women, were admiring these sable warders and the closed windows of the house and forge; and as I came up, one of the two warders -LRB-the postboy-RRB- knocked at the door,--implying that I was far too much exhausted by grief to have strength remaining to knock for myself.

Another sable warder -LRB-a carpenter, who had once eaten two geese for a wager-RRB- opened the door, and showed me into the best parlor.

Here, Mr. Trabb had taken unto himself the best table, and had got all the leaves up, and was holding a kind of black Bazaar, with the aid of a quantity of black pins.

At the moment of my arrival, he (Trabb) had just finished putting somebody's hat into black long-clothes, like an African baby; so he (Trabb) held out his (Trabb) hand for mine.

But I, misled by the action, and confused by the occasion, shook hands with him (Trabb) with every testimony of warm affection.

Poor dear Joe, entangled in a little black cloak tied in a large bow under his (Trabb) chin, was seated apart at the upper end of the room; where, as chief mourner, he (mourner) had evidently been stationed by Trabb.

But they returned with a gentle tone upon them that softened even the edge of Tickler. When I bent down and said to him (mourner),

``Dear Joe, how are you?

'' (him)

he (Joe) said,
``Pip, old chap, you knowed her (Joe) when she (Joe) were a fine figure of a--'' (he)
and clasped my hand and said no more.

When I had spoken to Biddy, as I thought it not a time for talking I went and sat down near Joe, and there began to wonder in what part of the house it--

Biddy, looking very neat and modest in her (Joe) black dress, went quietly here and there, and was very helpful. she (Joe)--my sister--was.

, I looked about for the table of refreshments; it was scarcely visible until one had got accustomed to the gloom, but there was a cut-up plum cake upon it, and there were cut-up oranges, and sandwiches, and biscuits, and two decanters that I knew very well as ornaments, but had never seen used in all my life; one full of port, and one of sherry.

Standing at this table, I became conscious of the servile Pumblechook in a black cloak and several yards of hatband, who was alternately stuffing himself, and making obsequious movements to catch my attention.

The moment he (it) succeeded, he (it) came over to me -LRB-breathing sherry and crumbs-RRB-, and said in a subdued voice,

``May I, dear sir?'' (me)
and did.

The air of the parlor being faint with the smell of sweet-cake I then descried Mr. and Mrs. Hubble; the last-named in a decent speechless paroxysm in a corner.

We were all going to

``follow,'' (Trabb/Mr. Trabb)
and were all in course of being tied up separately -LRB-by Trabb-RRB- into ridiculous bundles.

Which I meantersay, Pip,'' Joe whispered me, as we were being what Mr. Trabb called

``formed'' (Trabb/Mr. Trabb)
in the parlor, two and two,--and

it was dreadfully like a preparation for some grim kind of dance;

``which I meantersay, sir, as I would in preference have carried her (Joe) to the church myself, along with three or four friendly ones wot come to it with willing harts and arms, but it were considered wot the neighbors would look down on such and would be of opinions as it were wanting in respect.'' (Trabb/Mr. Trabb)

''

``Pocket-handkerchiefs out, all!'' (Trabb/Mr. Trabb)
cried Mr. Trabb at this point, in a depressed business-like voice. '' Pocket-handkerchiefs out! We are ready!

So we all put our pocket-handkerchiefs to our faces, as if our noses were bleeding, and filed out two and two;

The remains of my poor sister had been brought round by the kitchen door, and, it being a point of Undertaking ceremony that the six bearers must be stifled and blinded under a horrible black velvet housing with a white border, the whole looked like a blind monster with twelve human legs, shuffling and blundering along, under the guidance of two keepers,--the postboy and his (my) comrade.

The neighborhood, however, highly approved of these arrangements, and we were much admired as we went through the village; the more youthful and vigorous part of the community making dashes now and then to cut us off, and lying in wait to intercept us at points of vantage.

At such times the more exuberant among them called out in an excited manner on our emergence round some corner of expectancy,

``Here they come!'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

'' Joe and I; Biddy and Pumblechook; Mr. and Mrs. Hubble.

``Here they are! '' (unknown)
and we were all but cheered.

In this progress I was much annoyed by the abject Pumblechook, who, being behind me, persisted all the way as a delicate attention in arranging my streaming hatband, and smoothing my cloak.

My thoughts were further distracted by the excessive pride of Mr. and Mrs. Hubble, who were surpassingly conceited and vainglorious in being members of so distinguished a procession.

And now the range of marshes lay clear before us, with the sails of the ships on the river growing out of it; and we went into the churchyard, close to the graves of my unknown parents, Philip Pirrip, late of this parish, and Also Georgiana, Wife of the Above.

And there, my sister was laid quietly in the earth, while the larks sang high above it, and the light wind strewed it with beautiful shadows of clouds and trees.

Of the conduct of the worldly minded Pumblechook while this was doing, I desire to say no more than it was all addressed to me; and that even when those noble passages were read which remind humanity how it brought nothing into the world and can take nothing out, and

how it fleeth like a shadow and never continueth long in one stay, I heard him (I) cough a reservation of the case of a young gentleman who came unexpectedly into large property.

When we got back, he (I) had the hardihood to tell me that he (I) wished my sister could have known I had done her (sister) so much honor, and to hint that she (sister) would have considered it reasonably purchased at the price of her (sister) death.

After that, he (I) drank all the rest of the sherry, and Mr. Hubble drank the port, and the two talked -LRB-which I have since observed to be customary in such cases-RRB- as if they were of quite another race from the deceased, and were notoriously immortal.

, I felt sure, and to tell the Jolly Bargemen that he (Bargemen) was the founder of my fortunes and my earliest benefactor.

When they were all gone, and when Trabb and his (Trabb) men--but not his (Trabb) Boy; I looked for him (Trabb)--had crammed their mummery into bags, and were gone too, the house felt wholesomer.

Soon afterwards, Biddy, Joe, and I, had a cold dinner together; but we dined in the best parlor, not in the old kitchen, and Joe was so exceedingly particular what he (Trabb) did with his (Trabb) knife and fork and the saltcellar and what not, that there was great restraint upon us.

But after dinner, when I made him (Trabb) take his (Trabb) pipe, and when I had loitered with him (Trabb) about the forge, and when we sat down together on the great block of stone outside it, we got on better.

I noticed that after the funeral Joe changed his (Trabb) clothes so far, as to make a compromise between his (Trabb) Sunday dress and working dress; in which the dear fellow looked natural, and like the Man he (Man) was.

He (Man) was very much pleased by my asking if I might sleep in my own little room, and I was pleased too

Finally, he (Man) went away with Mr. and Mrs. Hubble,--to make an evening of it ; for I felt that I had done rather a great thing in making the request.

When the shadows of evening were closing in, I took an opportunity of getting into the garden with Biddy for a little talk.

'' Biddy,'' said I,

``I think you might have written to me about these sad matters. '' (I)
``Do you, Mr. Pip?'' (Biddy)
said Biddy.

``Don't suppose that I mean to be unkind, Biddy, when I say I consider that you ought to have thought that.

She (you) was so quiet, and had such an orderly, good, and pretty way with her (you), that I did not like the thought of making her (you) cry again.

'' (I)

I should have written if I had thought that.'' ''
``Do you, Mr. Pip? '' (she)
After looking a little at her (you) downcast eyes as she (you) walked beside me, I gave up that point.

'' I suppose it will be difficult for you to remain here now, Biddy dear?'' '' Oh! I can't do so, Mr. Pip,'' said Biddy, in a tone of regret but still of quiet conviction.

'' I have been speaking to Mrs. Hubble, and I am going to her (Hubble) to-morrow. I hope we shall be able to take some care of Mr. Gargery, together, until he (Gargery) settles down.

''

``How are you going to live, Biddy? If you want any mo--'' (Biddy)
``How am I going to live? '' (Biddy)
repeated Biddy, striking in, with a momentary flush upon her (Hubble) face.

'' I'll tell you, Mr. Pip. I am going to try to get the place of mistress in the new school nearly finished here.

I can be well recommended by all the neighbors, and I hope I can be industrious and patient, and teach myself while I teach others.

You know, Mr. Pip,'' pursued Biddy, with a smile, as she (mistress) raised her (mistress) eyes to my face,

``the new schools are not like the old, but I learnt a good deal from you after that time, and have had time since then to improve.

'' (she)

``I think you would always improve, Biddy, under any circumstances. '' (unknown)
``Ah! Except in my bad side of human nature,'' (Biddy)
murmured Biddy.

It was not so much a reproach as an irresistible thinking aloud. Well! I thought I would give up that point too.

So, I walked a little further with Biddy, looking silently at her (I) downcast eyes. '' I have not heard the particulars of my sister's death, Biddy.''

She (I) had been in one of her (I) bad states--though they had got better of late, rather than worse--for four days, when she (I) came out of it in the evening, just at tea-time, and said quite plainly, `Joe.'

As she (Joe) had never said any word for a long while, I ran and fetched in Mr. Gargery from the forge.

She (Joe) made signs to me that she (Joe) wanted him (Gargery) to sit down close to her (Joe), and wanted me to put her (Joe) arms round his (Gargery) neck.

'' They are very slight, poor thing. So I put them round his (Gargery) neck, and she (Joe) laid her (Joe) head down on his (Gargery) shoulder quite content and satisfied.

And so she (Joe) never lifted her (Joe) head up any more, and it was just an hour later when we laid it down on her (Joe) own bed, because we found she (Joe) was gone.''

Biddy cried; the darkening garden, and the lane, and the stars that were coming out, were blurred in my own sight.

And so she (Joe) presently said `Joe' again, and once `Pardon,' and once `Pip.' '' Nothing was ever discovered, Biddy? ''

``Nothing.'' (unknown)

``Do you know what is become of Orlick?'' (unknown)
``I should think from the color of his (Orlick) clothes that he (Orlick) is working in the quarries.'' (unknown)

``Of course you have seen him (Orlick) then?--Why are you looking at that dark tree in the lane?'' (unknown)
``I saw him (Orlick) there, on the night she (Joe) died.

No; I have seen him (Orlick) there, since we have been walking here.--It is of no use,'' (Biddy)

said Biddy, laying her (Joe) hand upon my arm, as I was for running out,
``you know I would not deceive you

'' (I)

``That was not the last time either, Biddy?'' (I)
'' ; he (Orlick) was not there a minute, and he (Orlick) is gone.

It revived my utmost indignation to find that she (Joe) was still pursued by this fellow, and I felt inveterate against him (fellow).

I told her (Joe) so, and told her (Joe) that I would spend any money or take any pains to drive him (fellow) out of that country.

By degrees she (Joe) led me into more temperate talk, and she (Joe) told me how Joe loved me, and how Joe never complained of anything,--she (Joe)

'' didn't say, of me; she (Joe) had no need; I knew what she (Joe) meant,--but ever did his (fellow) duty in his (fellow) way of life, with a strong hand, a quiet tongue, and a gentle heart.

Indeed, it would be hard to say too much for him (fellow),'' said I;

``and Biddy, we must often speak of these things, for of course I shall be often down here now.

'' (I)

I am not going to leave poor Joe alone.'' Biddy said never a single word. '' Biddy, don't you hear me?''

'' Yes, Mr. Pip. ''

``Not to mention your calling me Mr. Pip,--which appears to me to be in bad taste,

Biddy,--what do you mean? '' (I)

'' What do I mean?'' asked Biddy, timidly. '' Biddy,'' said I, in a virtuously self-asserting manner,
``I must request to know what you mean by this?'' (I)

'' By this?'' said Biddy. '' Now, don't echo,'' I retorted. '' You used not to echo, Biddy.''

``Used not!'' (Biddy)
said Biddy.

'' O Mr. Pip! Used! '' Well! I rather thought I would give up that point too. After another silent turn in the garden, I fell back on the main position.

Biddy,'' said I, ``I made a remark respecting my coming down here often, to see Joe, which you received with a marked silence.

``Are you quite sure, then, that you WILL come to see him (Pip) often?'' (Biddy)
asked Biddy, stopping in the narrow garden walk, and looking at me under the stars with a clear and honest eye.

'' Have the goodness, Biddy, to tell me why.'' '' O dear me!'' said I, as if I found myself compelled to give up Biddy in despair.

'' This really is a very bad side of human nature! Don't say any more, if you please, Biddy. This shocks me very much.

For which cogent reason I kept Biddy at a distance during supper, and when I went up to my own old little room, took as stately a leave of her (I) as I could, in my murmuring soul, deem reconcilable with the churchyard and the event of the day.

As often as I was restless in the night, and that was every quarter of an hour, I reflected what an unkindness, what an injury, what an injustice, Biddy had done me.

'' Early in the morning I was to go. Early in the morning I was out, and looking in, unseen, at one of the wooden windows of the forge.

There I stood, for minutes, looking at Joe, already at work with a glow of health and strength upon his (I) face that made it show as if the bright sun of the life in store for him (I) were shining on it.

'' Good-bye, dear Joe!--No, don't wipe it off--for God's sake, give me your blackened hand!--I shall be down soon and often.

''

``Never too soon, sir,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe,
``and never too often, Pip!'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
Biddy was waiting for me at the kitchen door, with a mug of new milk and a crust of bread.

'' Biddy,'' said I, when I gave her (Joe) my hand at parting,

``I am not angry, but I am hurt. '' (I)

'' No, don't be hurt,'' she (Joe) pleaded quite pathetically;

``let only me be hurt, if I have been ungenerous. '' (she)
Once more, the mists were rising as I walked away.

If they disclosed to me, as I suspect they did, that I should not come back, and that Biddy was quite right, all I can say is,--they were quite right too.

Chapter XXXVI Herbert and I went on from bad to worse, in the way of increasing our debts, looking into our affairs, leaving Margins, and the like exemplary transactions; and Time went on, whether or no, as he (Herbert) has a way of doing; and I came of age,--in fulfilment of Herbert's prediction, that I should do so before I knew where I was.

As he (Herbert) had nothing else than his (Herbert) majority to come into, the event did not make a profound sensation in Barnard's Inn.

But we had looked forward to my one-and-twentieth birthday, with a crowd of speculations and anticipations, for we had both considered that my guardian could hardly help saying something definite on that occasion.

Herbert himself had come of age eight months before me. I had taken care to have it well understood in Little Britain when my birthday was.

On the day before it, I received an official note from Wemmick, informing me that Mr. Jaggers would be glad if I would call upon him (Jaggers) at five in the afternoon of the auspicious day.

This convinced us that something great was to happen, and threw me into an unusual flutter when I repaired to my guardian's office, a model of punctuality.

In the outer office Wemmick offered me his (Wemmick) congratulations, and incidentally rubbed the side of his (Wemmick) nose with a folded piece of tissue-paper that I liked the look of.

It was November, and my guardian was standing before his (Wemmick) fire leaning his (Wemmick) back against the chimney-piece, with his (Wemmick) hands under his (Wemmick) coattails.

But he (Wemmick) said nothing respecting it, and motioned me with a nod into my guardian's room. '' Well, Pip ,'' said he (Pip),

``I must call you Mr. Pip to-day.

Congratulations, Mr. Pip. '' (he)

We shook hands,--he (Pip) was always a remarkably short shaker,--and I thanked him (Pip). '' Take a chair, Mr. Pip,'' said my guardian.

As I sat down, and he (Pip) preserved his (Pip) attitude and bent his (Pip) brows at his (Pip) boots, I felt at a disadvantage, which reminded me of that old time when I had been put upon a tombstone.

The two ghastly casts on the shelf were not far from him (Pip), and their expression was as if they were making a stupid apoplectic attempt to attend to the conversation.

Now my young friend,'' my guardian began, as if I were a witness in the box,

``I am going to have a word or two with you.'' (a witness)

What do you suppose,'' said Mr. Jaggers, bending forward to look at the ground, and then throwing his (Jaggers) head back to look at the ceiling,--

``what

'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)

'' If you please, sir. '' '' do you suppose you are living at the rate of?''
``At the rate of, sir?'' (unknown)

``At,'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
repeated Mr. Jaggers, still looking at the ceiling,
``the--rate--of? '' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
And then looked all round the room, and paused with his (Jaggers) pocket-handkerchief in his (Jaggers) hand, half-way to his (Jaggers) nose.

I had looked into my affairs so often, that I had thoroughly destroyed any slight notion I might ever have had of their bearings.

This reply seemed agreeable to Mr. Jaggers, who said,

``I thought so!'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
and blew his (Jaggers) nose with an air of satisfaction.

Reluctantly, I confessed myself quite unable to answer the question. '' Now, I have asked you a question, my friend,'' said Mr. Jaggers.

``Of course it would be a great relief to me to ask you several questions, sir; but I remember your prohibition.'' (me)

'' Have you anything to ask me?''

``Ask one,'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
said Mr. Jaggers.
``Is my benefactor to be made known to me to-day?'' (unknown)

'' No. Ask another.''

``Is that confidence to be imparted to me soon?'' (unknown)
``Waive that, a moment,'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
said Mr. Jaggers,
``and ask another.

'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)

I looked about me, but there appeared to be now no possible escape from the inquiry, ``Have-I--anything to receive, sir?

On that, Mr. Jaggers said, triumphantly,

``I thought we should come to it!'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
and called to Wemmick to give him (Jaggers) that piece of paper.

You have been drawing pretty freely here; your name occurs pretty often in Wemmick's cash-book; but you are in debt, of course?''

'' Wemmick appeared, handed it in, and disappeared. '' Now, Mr. Pip,'' said Mr. Jaggers, ``attend, if you please.

``I am afraid I must say yes, sir.'' (I)

``I don't ask you what you owe, because you don't know; and if you did know, you wouldn't tell me; you would say less.

``You know you must say yes; don't you?'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
said Mr. Jaggers. '' Yes, sir.'' Yes, yes, my friend,'' cried Mr. Jaggers, waving his (Jaggers) forefinger to stop me as I made a show of protesting:

``it's likely enough that you think you wouldn't, but you would. You'll excuse me, but I know better than you. Now, take this piece of paper in your hand.

You have got it? Very good. Now, unfold it and tell me what it is.'' (I)

'' This is a bank-note,'' said I,
``for five hundred pounds.

'' (I)

'' That is a bank-note,'' repeated Mr. Jaggers,
``for five hundred pounds. And a very handsome sum of money too, I think.

You consider it so? '' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)

``How could I do otherwise!'' (unknown)
``Ah! But answer the question,'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
said Mr. Jaggers. '' Undoubtedly.''
``You consider it, undoubtedly, a handsome sum of money.

Now, that handsome sum of money, Pip, is your own. It is a present to you on this day, in earnest of your expectations.

And at the rate of that handsome sum of money per annum, and at no higher rate, you are to live until the donor of the whole appears.

That is to say, you will now take your money affairs entirely into your own hands, and you will draw from Wemmick one hundred and twenty-five pounds per quarter, until you are in communication with the fountain-head, and no longer with the mere agent.

As I have told you before, I am the mere agent. I execute my instructions, and I am paid for doing so.

I was beginning to express my gratitude to my benefactor for the great liberality with which I was treated, when Mr. Jaggers stopped me.

I am not paid, Pip,'' (he)

said he (Jaggers), coolly,
``to carry your words to any one;'' (he)
and then gathered up his (Jaggers) coat-tails, as he (Jaggers) had gathered up the subject, and stood frowning at his (Jaggers) boots as if he (Jaggers) suspected them of designs against him (Jaggers).

I think them injudicious, but I am not paid for giving any opinion on their merits. '' '' After a pause, I hinted,-- ''

There was a question just now, Mr. Jaggers, which you desired me to waive for a moment. I hope I am doing nothing wrong in asking it again?

I might have known that he (Jaggers) would never help me out; but it took me aback to have to shape the question afresh, as if it were quite new.

Is it likely,'' I said, after hesitating,

``that my patron, the fountain-head you have spoken of, Mr. Jaggers, will soon--'' (I)
there I delicately stopped.

'' '' What is it?'' said he (Jaggers). '' '' Will soon what?'' asked Mr. Jaggers. '' That's no question as it stands, you know.

``Will soon come to London,'' (I)
said I, after casting about for a precise form of words,
``or summon me anywhere else?'' (I)

``Now, here,'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
replied Mr. Jaggers, fixing me for the first time with his (Jaggers) dark deep-set eyes,
``we must revert to the evening when we first encountered one another in your village.

'' (me)

What did I tell you then, Pip?''
``You told me, Mr. Jaggers, that it might be years hence when that person appeared.'' (I)

As we looked full at one another, I felt my breath come quicker in my strong desire to get something out of him (Jaggers).
