And as I felt that it came quicker, and as I felt that he (Jaggers) saw that it came quicker, I felt that I had less chance than ever of getting anything out of him (Jaggers).

``Just so,'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
said Mr. Jaggers,
``that's my answer. '' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
'' Do you suppose it will still be years hence, Mr. Jaggers?

Mr. Jaggers shook his (Jaggers) head,--not in negativing the question, but in altogether negativing the notion that he (Jaggers) could anyhow be got to answer it,--and the two horrible casts of the twitched faces looked, when my eyes strayed up to them, as if they had come to a crisis in their suspended attention, and were going to sneeze.

``Come!'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
said Mr. Jaggers, warming the backs of his (Jaggers) legs with the backs of his (Jaggers) warmed hands,
``I'll be plain with you, my friend Pip.

'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)

That's a question I must not be asked. You'll understand that better, when I tell you it's a question that might compromise me.

He (Pip) bent down so low to frown at his (Pip) boots, that he (Pip) was able to rub the calves of his (Pip) legs in the pause he (Pip) made.

Come! I'll go a little further with you; I'll say something more. '' '' When that person discloses,'' said Mr. Jaggers, straightening himself,

``you and that person will settle your own affairs.

When that person discloses, my part in this business will cease and determine. When that person discloses, it will not be necessary for me to know anything about it.

And that's all I have got to say. '' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)

We looked at one another until I withdrew my eyes, and looked thoughtfully at the floor.

From this last speech I derived the notion that Miss Havisham, for some reason or no reason, had not taken him (Jaggers) into her (my) confidence as to her (my) designing me for Estella; that he (Jaggers) resented this, and felt a jealousy about it; or that he (Jaggers) really did object to that scheme, and would have nothing to do with it.

When I raised my eyes again, I found that he (Jaggers) had been shrewdly looking at me all the time, and was doing so still.

'' If that is all you have to say, sir,'' I remarked,

``there can be nothing left for me to say.

'' (I)

He (Jaggers) nodded assent, and pulled out his (Jaggers) thief-dreaded watch, and asked me where I was going to dine? I replied at my own chambers, with Herbert.

As a necessary sequence, I asked him (Herbert) if he (Herbert) would favor us with his (Herbert) company, and he (Herbert) promptly accepted the invitation.

But he (Herbert) insisted on walking home with me, in order that I might make no extra preparation for him (Herbert), and first he (Herbert) had a letter or two to write, and -LRB-of course-RRB- had his (Herbert) hands to wash.

The fact was, that when the five hundred pounds had come into my pocket, a thought had come into my head which had been often there before; and it appeared to me that Wemmick was a good person to advise with concerning such thought.

So I said I would go into the outer office and talk to Wemmick. He (Wemmick) had already locked up his (Wemmick) safe, and made preparations for going home.

He (Wemmick) had left his (Wemmick) desk, brought out his (Wemmick) two greasy office candlesticks and stood them in line with the snuffers on a slab near the door, ready to be extinguished; he (Wemmick) had raked his (Wemmick) fire low, put his (Wemmick) hat and great-coat ready, and was beating himself all over the chest with his (Wemmick) safe-key, as an athletic exercise after business.

Wemmick tightened his (Wemmick) post-office and shook his (Wemmick) head, as if his (Wemmick) opinion were dead against any fatal weakness of that sort.

'' Mr. Wemmick,'' said I,

``I want to ask your opinion. I am very desirous to serve a friend. '' (I)
''

This friend,'' I pursued,

``is trying to get on in commercial life, but has no money, and finds it difficult and disheartening to make a beginning.

Now I want somehow to help him (friend) to a beginning. '' (I)

``With money down?'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
said Wemmick, in a tone drier than any sawdust.

With some money down,'' I replied, for an uneasy remembrance shot across me of that symmetrical bundle of papers at home--

``with some money down, and perhaps some anticipation of my expectations.'' (me)

''

``Mr. Pip,'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
said Wemmick,
``I should like just to run over with you on my fingers, if you please, the names of the various bridges up as high as Chelsea Reach.

He (Wemmick) had checked off each bridge in its turn, with the handle of his (Wemmick) safe-key on the palm of his (Wemmick) hand.

Let's see; there's London, one; Southwark, two; Blackfriars, three; Waterloo, four; Westminster, five; Vauxhall, six. '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

'' There's as many as six, you see, to choose from.

``I don't understand you,'' (I.)
said I.
``Choose your bridge, Mr. Pip,'' (I.)
returned Wemmick,
``and take a walk upon your bridge, and pitch your money into the Thames over the centre arch of your bridge, and you know the end of it.

'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

Serve a friend with it, and you may know the end of it too,--but it's a less pleasant and profitable end.

'' I could have posted a newspaper in his (friend) mouth, he (friend) made it so wide after saying this. '' This is very discouraging,'' said I.

``Meant to be so,'' (I.)
said Wemmick.

Then is it your opinion,'' I inquired, with some little indignation,

``that a man should never--'' (I)
''--Invest portable property in a friend?'' said Wemmick.

'' '' Certainly he (Wemmick) should not. Unless he (Wemmick) wants to get rid of the friend,--and then it becomes a question how much portable property it may be worth to get rid of him (Wemmick).''

'' And that,'' said I,

``is your deliberate opinion, Mr. Wemmick?'' (I)
'' That,'' he (Wemmick) returned,
``is my deliberate opinion in this office.'' (he)

``Ah!'' (I)
said I, pressing him (Wemmick), for I thought I saw him (Wemmick) near a loophole here;
``but would that be your opinion at Walworth?'' (him)

``Mr. Pip,'' (he)
he (Pip) replied, with gravity,
``Walworth is one place, and this office is another. Much as the Aged is one person, and Mr. Jaggers is another.

They must not be confounded together. My Walworth sentiments must be taken at Walworth; none but my official sentiments can be taken in this office.'' (he)

``Very well,'' (I)
said I, much relieved,
``then I shall look you up at Walworth, you may depend upon it.'' (I)
``Mr. Pip,'' (he)
he (Pip) returned,
``you will be welcome there, in a private and personal capacity.

We had held this conversation in a low voice, well knowing my guardian's ears to be the sharpest of the sharp.

As he (Pip) now appeared in his (Pip) doorway, towelling his (Pip) hands, Wemmick got on his (Wemmick) great-coat and stood by to snuff out the candles.

We all three went into the street together, and from the door-step Wemmick turned his (Wemmick) way, and Mr. Jaggers and I turned ours.

I could not help wishing more than once that evening, that Mr. Jaggers had had an Aged in Gerrard Street, or a Stinger, or a Something, or a Somebody, to unbend his (Jaggers) brows a little.

It was an uncomfortable consideration on a twenty-first birthday, that coming of age at all seemed hardly worth while in such a guarded and suspicious world as he (Jaggers) made of it.

He (Jaggers) was a thousand times better informed and cleverer than Wemmick, and yet I would a thousand times rather have had Wemmick to dinner.

And Mr. Jaggers made not me alone intensely melancholy, because, after he (Jaggers) was gone, Herbert said of himself, with his (Herbert) eyes fixed on the fire, that he (Herbert) thought he (Herbert) must have committed a felony and forgotten the details of it, he (Herbert) felt so dejected and guilty.

Chapter XXXVII Deeming Sunday the best day for taking Mr. Wemmick's Walworth sentiments, I devoted the next ensuing Sunday afternoon to a pilgrimage to the Castle.

On arriving before the battlements, I found the Union Jack flying and the drawbridge up; but undeterred by this show of defiance and resistance, I rang at the gate, and was admitted in a most pacific manner by the Aged.

My son, sir,'' (he)

said the old man, after securing the drawbridge,
``rather had it in his (man) mind that you might happen to drop in, and he (man) left word that he (man) would soon be home from his (man) afternoon's walk.

I nodded at the old gentleman as Wemmick himself might have nodded, and we went in and sat down by the fireside.

'' (the man)

'' He (Wemmick) is very regular in his (Wemmick) walks, is my son. Very regular in everything, is my son. '' ''

You made acquaintance with my son, sir,'' said the old man, in his (man) chirping way, while he (man) warmed his (man) hands at the blaze,

``at his (man) office, I expect?

'' (he)

I nodded. '' Hah! I have heerd that my son is a wonderful hand at his (son) business, sir? '' I nodded hard.

Which makes it more surprising in my son,'' said the old man, ``for he (man) was not brought up to the Law, but to the Wine-Coopering.

Curious to know how the old gentleman stood informed concerning the reputation of Mr. Jaggers, I roared that name at him (Jaggers).

He (Jaggers) threw me into the greatest confusion by laughing heartily and replying in a very sprightly manner, ``No, to be sure; you're right.

And to this hour I have not the faintest notion what he (Jaggers) meant, or what joke he (Jaggers) thought I had made.

As I could not sit there nodding at him (Jaggers) perpetually, without making some other attempt to interest him (Jaggers), I shouted at inquiry whether his (Jaggers) own calling in life had been

``the Wine-Coopering.

By dint of straining that term out of myself several times and tapping the old gentleman on the chest to associate it with him (gentleman), I at last succeeded in making my meaning understood.

'' (I)

Yes; so they tell me. His (gentleman) business is the Law? '' I nodded harder. '' '' '' '' '' No,'' said the old gentleman;
``the warehousing, the warehousing.

First, over yonder;'' (the gentleman warehousing)

he (gentleman) appeared to mean up the chimney, but I believe he (gentleman) intended to refer me to Liverpool;
``and then in the City of London here.

--Yes, hard of hearing; having that infirmity coming upon me, my son he (son) went into the Law, and he (son) took charge of me, and he (son) by little and little made out this elegant and beautiful property.

But returning to what you said, you know,'' (me)

pursued the old man, again laughing heartily, ``what I say is, No to be sure; you're right.

I was modestly wondering whether my utmost ingenuity would have enabled me to say anything that would have amused him (man) half as much as this imaginary pleasantry, when I was startled by a sudden click in the wall on one side of the chimney, and the ghostly tumbling open of a little wooden flap with

``JOHN'' (I)
upon it.

However, having an infirmity--for I am hard of hearing, sir-- '' I expressed in pantomime the greatest astonishment. '' '' The old man, following my eyes, cried with great triumph,

It was worth any money to see Wemmick waving a salute to me from the other side of the moat, when we might have shaken hands across it with the greatest ease.

The Aged was so delighted to work the drawbridge, that I made no offer to assist him (man), but stood quiet until Wemmick had come across, and had presented me to Miss Skiffins; a lady by whom he (Wemmick) was accompanied.

``My son's come home!'' (Miss Skiffins)
and we both went out to the drawbridge. Miss Skiffins was of a wooden appearance, and was, like her (Skiffins) escort, in the post-office branch of the service.

She (Skiffins) might have been some two or three years younger than Wemmick, and I judged her (Skiffins) to stand possessed of portable property.

The cut of her (Skiffins) dress from the waist upward, both before and behind, made her (Skiffins) figure very like a boy's kite; and I might have pronounced her (Skiffins) gown a little too decidedly orange, and her (Skiffins) gloves a little too intensely green.

I was not long in discovering that she (Skiffins) was a frequent visitor at the Castle; for, on our going in, and my complimenting Wemmick on his (Wemmick) ingenious contrivance for announcing himself to the Aged, he (Wemmick) begged me to give my attention for a moment to the other side of the chimney, and disappeared.

Presently another click came, and another little door tumbled open with

``Miss Skiffins'' (Miss Skiffins)
on it; then Miss Skiffins shut up and John tumbled open; then Miss Skiffins and John both tumbled open together, and finally shut up together.

On Wemmick's return from working these mechanical appliances, I expressed the great admiration with which I regarded them, and he (John) said,

``Well, you know, they're both pleasant and useful to the Aged.

And by George, sir, it's a thing worth mentioning, that of all the people who come to this gate, the secret of those pulls is only known to the Aged, Miss Skiffins, and me!'' (he)

But she (Skiffins) seemed to be a good sort of fellow, and showed a high regard for the Aged. '' And Mr. Wemmick made them,'' added Miss Skiffins,

``with his (Wemmick) own hands out of his (Wemmick) own head.

While Miss Skiffins was taking off her (Skiffins) bonnet -LRB-she (Skiffins) retained her (Skiffins) green gloves during the evening as an outward and visible sign that there was company-RRB-, Wemmick invited me to take a walk with him (Wemmick) round the property, and see how the island looked in wintertime.

Thinking that he (Wemmick) did this to give me an opportunity of taking his (Wemmick) Walworth sentiments, I seized the opportunity as soon as we were out of the Castle.

'' (Miss Skiffins)

Having thought of the matter with care, I approached my subject as if I had never hinted at it before.

I informed Wemmick that I was anxious in behalf of Herbert Pocket, and I told him (Pocket) how we had first met, and how we had fought.

I glanced at Herbert's home, and at his (Herbert) character, and at his (Herbert) having no means but such as he (Herbert) was dependent on his (Herbert) father for; those, uncertain and unpunctual.

I alluded to the advantages I had derived in my first rawness and ignorance from his (Herbert) society, and I confessed that I feared I had but ill repaid them, and that he (Herbert) might have done better without me and my expectations.

Keeping Miss Havisham in the background at a great distance, I still hinted at the possibility of my having competed with him (Herbert) in his (Herbert) prospects, and at the certainty of his (Herbert) possessing a generous soul, and being far above any mean distrusts, retaliations, or designs.

For all these reasons -LRB-I told Wemmick-RRB-, and because he (Wemmick) was my young companion and friend, and I had a great affection for him (Wemmick), I wished my own good fortune to reflect some rays upon him (Wemmick), and therefore I sought advice from Wemmick's experience and knowledge of men and affairs, how I could best try with my resources to help Herbert to some present income,--say of a hundred a year, to keep him (Herbert) in good hope and heart,--and gradually to buy him (Herbert) on to some small partnership.

I begged Wemmick, in conclusion, to understand that my help must always be rendered without Herbert's knowledge or suspicion, and that there was no one else in the world with whom I could advise.

I wound up by laying my hand upon his (Herbert) shoulder, and saying, ``I can't help confiding in you, though I know it must be troublesome to you; but that is your fault, in having ever brought me here.

Wemmick was silent for a little while, and then said with a kind of start,

``Well you know, Mr. Pip, I must tell you one thing.

'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

This is devilish good of you.''
``Say you'll help me to be good then,'' (I.)
said I.
``Ecod,'' (I.)
replied Wemmick, shaking his (Wemmick) head,
``that's not my trade.'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

'' Nor is this your trading-place,'' said I.

``You are right,'' (I.)
he (Wemmick) returned. '' You hit the nail on the head.

Mr. Pip, I'll put on my considering-cap, and I think all you want to do may be done by degrees. Skiffins -LRB-that's her (you) brother-RRB- is an accountant and agent.

``On the contrary,'' (he)
said he (agent),
``I thank you, for though we are strictly in our private and personal capacity, still it may be mentioned that there are Newgate cobwebs about, and it brushes them away.

After a little further conversation to the same effect, we returned into the Castle where we found Miss Skiffins preparing tea.

The responsible duty of making the toast was delegated to the Aged, and that excellent old gentleman was so intent upon it that he (gentleman) seemed to me in some danger of melting his (gentleman) eyes.

I'll look him (gentleman) up and go to work for you.'' (he)

``I thank you ten thousand times.'' (unknown)
'' It was no nominal meal that we were going to make, but a vigorous reality.

The Aged prepared such a hay-stack of buttered toast, that I could scarcely see him (gentleman) over it as it simmered on an iron stand hooked on to the top-bar; while Miss Skiffins brewed such a jorum of tea, that the pig in the back premises became strongly excited, and repeatedly expressed his (gentleman) desire to participate in the entertainment.

The flag had been struck, and the gun had been fired, at the right moment of time, and I felt as snugly cut off from the rest of Walworth as if the moat were thirty feet wide by as many deep.

Nothing disturbed the tranquillity of the Castle, but the occasional tumbling open of John and Miss Skiffins: which little doors were a prey to some spasmodic infirmity that made me sympathetically uncomfortable until I got used to it.

I inferred from the methodical nature of Miss Skiffins's arrangements that she (Skiffins) made tea there every Sunday night; and I rather suspected that a classic brooch she (Skiffins) wore, representing the profile of an undesirable female with a very straight nose and a very new moon, was a piece of portable property that had been given her (Skiffins) by Wemmick.

We ate the whole of the toast, and drank tea in proportion, and it was delightful to see how warm and greasy we all got after it.

After a short pause of repose, Miss Skiffins--in the absence of the little servant who, it seemed, retired to the bosom of her (Skiffins) family on Sunday afternoons--washed up the tea-things, in a trifling lady-like amateur manner that compromised none of us.

Then, she (Skiffins) put on her (Skiffins) gloves again, and we drew round the fire, and Wemmick said,

``Now, Aged Parent, tip us the paper.

Wemmick explained to me while the Aged got his (Wemmick) spectacles out, that this was according to custom, and that it gave the old gentleman infinite satisfaction to read the news aloud.

The Aged especially, might have passed for some clean old chief of a savage tribe, just oiled. '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

'' I won't offer an apology,'' said Wemmick,
``for he (Wemmick) isn't capable of many pleasures--are you, Aged P.?'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

'' All right, John, all right,'' returned the old man, seeing himself spoken to. '' Only tip him (John) a nod every now

and then when he (John) looks off his (John) paper,'' said Wemmick,

``and he (Wemmick)'ll be as happy as a king. We are all attention,

Aged One.'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

'' All right, John, all right! '' returned the cheerful old man, so busy and so pleased, that it really was quite charming.

The Aged's reading reminded me of the classes at Mr. Wopsle's great-aunt's, with the pleasanter peculiarity that it seemed to come through a keyhole.

As he (Wopsle) wanted the candles close to him (Wopsle), and as he (Wopsle) was always on the verge of putting either his (Wopsle) head or the newspaper into them, he (Wopsle) required as much watching as a powder-mill.

But Wemmick was equally untiring and gentle in his (Wemmick) vigilance, and the Aged read on, quite unconscious of his (Wemmick) many rescues.

As Wemmick and Miss Skiffins sat side by side, and as I sat in a shadowy corner, I observed a slow and gradual elongation of Mr. Wemmick's mouth, powerfully suggestive of his (Wemmick) slowly and gradually stealing his (Wemmick) arm round Miss Skiffins's waist.

In course of time I saw his (Wemmick) hand appear on the other side of Miss Skiffins; but at that moment Miss Skiffins neatly stopped him (Wemmick) with the green glove, unwound his (Wemmick) arm again as if it were an article of dress, and with the greatest deliberation laid it on the table before her (Skiffins).

Whenever he (Wemmick) looked at us, we all expressed the greatest interest and amazement, and nodded until he (Wemmick) resumed again. Miss Skiffins's composure while she (Skiffins) did this was one of the most remarkable sights I have ever seen, and

if I could have thought the act consistent with abstraction of mind, I should have deemed that Miss Skiffins performed it mechanically.

By and by, I noticed Wemmick's arm beginning to disappear again, and gradually fading out of view. Shortly afterwards, his (Wemmick) mouth began to widen again.

After an interval of suspense on my part that was quite enthralling and almost painful, I saw his (Wemmick) hand appear on the other side of Miss Skiffins.

Instantly, Miss Skiffins stopped it with the neatness of a placid boxer, took off that girdle or cestus as before, and laid it on the table.

Taking the table to represent the path of virtue, I am justified in stating that during the whole time of the Aged's reading, Wemmick's arm was straying from the path of virtue and being recalled to it by Miss Skiffins.

This was the time for Wemmick to produce a little kettle, a tray of glasses, and a black bottle with a porcelain-topped cork, representing some clerical dignitary of a rubicund and social aspect.

With the aid of these appliances we all had something warm to drink, including the Aged, who was soon awake again.

At last, the Aged read himself into a light slumber. Miss Skiffins mixed, and I observed that she (himself) and Wemmick drank out of one glass.

Of course I knew better than to offer to see Miss Skiffins home, and under the circumstances I thought I had best go first; which I did, taking a cordial leave of the Aged, and having passed a pleasant evening.

Before a week was out, I received a note from Wemmick, dated Walworth, stating that he (Wemmick) hoped he (Wemmick) had made some advance in that matter appertaining to our private and personal capacities, and that he (Wemmick) would be glad if I could come and see him (Wemmick) again upon it.

So, I went out to Walworth again, and yet again, and yet again, and I saw him (Wemmick) by appointment in the City several times, but never held any communication with him (Wemmick) on the subject in or near Little Britain.

The upshot was, that we found a worthy young merchant or shipping-broker, not long established in business, who wanted intelligent help, and who wanted capital, and who in due course of time and receipt would want a partner.

Between him (merchant) and me, secret articles were signed of which Herbert was the subject, and I paid him (Herbert) half of my five hundred pounds down, and engaged for sundry other payments: some, to fall due at certain dates out of my income: some, contingent on my coming into my property.

Miss Skiffins's brother conducted the negotiation. Wemmick pervaded it throughout, but never appeared in it. The whole business was so cleverly managed, that Herbert had not the least suspicion of my hand being in it.

I never shall forget the radiant face with which he (Herbert) came home one afternoon, and told me, as a mighty piece of news, of his (Herbert) having fallen in with one Clarriker -LRB-the young merchant's name-RRB-, and of Clarriker's having shown an extraordinary inclination towards him (Herbert), and of his (Herbert) belief that the opening had come at last.

Day by day as his (Herbert) hopes grew stronger and his (Herbert) face brighter, he (Herbert) must have thought me a more and more affectionate friend, for I had the greatest difficulty in restraining my tears of triumph when I saw him (Herbert) so happy.

At length, the thing being done, and he (Herbert) having that day entered Clarriker's House, and he (Herbert) having talked to me for a whole evening in a flush of pleasure and success, I did really cry in good earnest when I went to bed, to think that my expectations had done some good to somebody.

But, before I proceed to narrate it, and before I pass on to all the changes it involved, I must give one chapter to Estella.

A great event in my life, the turning point of my life, now opens on my view. It is not much to give to the theme that so long filled my heart.

If that staid old house near the Green at Richmond should ever come to be haunted when I am dead, it will be haunted, surely, by my ghost.

O the many, many nights and days through which the unquiet spirit within me haunted that house when Estella lived there!

The lady with whom Estella was placed, Mrs. Brandley by name, was a widow, with one daughter several years older than Estella.

The mother looked young, and the daughter looked old; the mother's complexion was pink, and the daughter's was yellow; the mother set up for frivolity, and the daughter for theology.

Chapter XXXVIII Let my body be where it would, my spirit was always wandering, wandering, wandering, about that house. They were in what is called a good position, and visited, and were visited by, numbers of people.

Little, if any, community of feeling subsisted between them and Estella, but the understanding was established that they were necessary to her (Estella), and that she (Estella) was necessary to them.

In Mrs. Brandley's house and out of Mrs. Brandley's house, I suffered every kind and degree of torture that Estella could cause me.

The nature of my relations with her (Estella), which placed me on terms of familiarity without placing me on terms of favor, conduced to my distraction.

She (Estella) made use of me to tease other admirers, and she (Estella) turned the very familiarity between herself and me to the account of putting a constant slight on my devotion to her (Estella).

Mrs. Brandley had been a friend of Miss Havisham's before the time of her (Brandley) seclusion. If I had been her (Brandley) secretary, steward, half-brother, poor

I had been a younger brother of her (Brandley) appointed husband,--I could not have seemed to myself further from my hopes when I was nearest to her (Brandley).

The privilege of calling her (Brandley) by her (Brandley) name and hearing her (Brandley) call me by mine became, under the circumstances an aggravation of my trials; and while I think it likely that it almost maddened her (Brandley) other lovers, I know too certainly that it almost maddened me.

No doubt my jealousy made an admirer of every one who went near her (Brandley); but there were more than enough of them without that.

I saw her (Brandley) often at Richmond, I heard of her (Brandley) often in town, and I used often to take her (Brandley) and the Brandleys on the water; there were picnics, fête days, plays, operas, concerts, parties, all sorts of pleasures, through which I pursued her (Brandley),--and they were all miseries to me.

I never had one hour's happiness in her (Brandley) society, and yet my mind all round the four-and-twenty hours was harping on the happiness of having her (Brandley) with me unto death.

Throughout this part of our intercourse,--and it lasted, as will presently be seen, for what I then thought a long time,--she (Brandley) habitually reverted to that tone which expressed that our association was forced upon us.

There were other times when she (Brandley) would come to a sudden check in this tone and in all her (Brandley) many tones, and would seem to pity me. ''

Pip, Pip,'' she (Brandley) said one evening, coming to such a check, when we sat apart at a darkening window of the house in Richmond;

``will you never take warning?'' (she)

relation,--if She (Brandley) had admirers without end. '' Of what? ''

``Of me.'' (unknown)
``Warning not to be attracted by you, do you mean, Estella?'' (I)

I should have replied that Love was commonly reputed blind, but for the reason that I always was restrained--and this was not the least of my miseries--by a feeling that it was ungenerous to press myself upon her (Estella), when she (Estella) knew that she (Estella) could not choose but obey Miss Havisham.

My dread always was, that this knowledge on her (Estella) part laid me under a heavy disadvantage with her (Estella) pride, and made me the subject of a rebellious struggle in her (Estella) bosom.

At any rate,'' said I, ``I have no warning given me just now, for you wrote to me to come to you, this time.

``Do I mean! If you don't know what I mean, you are blind. '' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)
'' '' '' That's true,'' said Estella, with a cold careless smile that always chilled me.

After looking at the twilight without, for a little while, she (Estella) went on to say:-- '' The time has come round when Miss Havisham wishes to have me for a day at Satis.

She (Estella) would rather I did not travel alone, and objects to receiving my maid, for she (Estella) has a sensitive horror of being talked of by such people.

You are to take me there, and bring me back, if you will. Can you take me?''

``Can I take you, Estella!'' (unknown)

``You can then? The day after to-morrow, if you please. You are to pay all charges out of my purse, You hear the condition of your going?'' (I)

And must obey,'' said I. This was all the preparation I received for that visit, or for others like it; Miss Havisham never wrote to me, nor had I ever so much as seen her (Havisham) handwriting.

We went down on the next day but one, and we found her (Havisham) in the room where I had first beheld her (Havisham), and it is needless to add that there was no change in Satis House.

She (Havisham) was even more dreadfully fond of Estella than she (Estella) had been when I last saw them together; I repeat the word advisedly, for there was something positively dreadful in the energy of her (Estella) looks and embraces.

She (Estella) hung upon Estella's beauty, hung upon her (Estella) words, hung upon her (Estella) gestures, and sat mumbling her (Estella) own trembling fingers while she (Estella) looked at her (Estella), as though she (Estella) were devouring the beautiful creature she (Estella) had reared.

From Estella she (Estella) looked at me, with a searching glance that seemed to pry into my heart and probe its wounds.

'' '' How does she (Estella) use you, Pip; how does she (Estella) use you? '' she (Estella) asked me again, with her (Estella) witch-like eagerness, even in Estella's hearing.

But, when we sat by her (Estella) flickering fire at night, she (Estella) was most weird; for then, keeping Estella's hand drawn through her (Estella) arm and clutched in her (Estella) own hand, she (Estella) extorted from her (Estella), by dint of referring back to what Estella had told her (Estella) in her (Estella) regular letters, the names and conditions of the men whom she (Estella) had fascinated; and as Miss Havisham dwelt upon this roll, with the intensity of a mind mortally hurt and diseased, she (Estella) sat with her (Estella) other hand on her (Estella) crutch stick, and her (Estella) chin on that, and her (Estella) wan bright eyes glaring at me, a very spectre.

I saw in this, wretched though it made me, and bitter the sense of dependence and even of degradation that it awakened,--I saw in this that Estella was set to wreak Miss Havisham's revenge on men, and that she (Estella) was not to be given to me until she (Estella) had gratified it for a term.

Sending her (Estella) out to attract and torment and do mischief, Miss Havisham sent her (Havisham) with the malicious assurance that she (Havisham) was beyond the reach of all admirers, and that all who staked upon that cast were secured to lose.

I saw in this that I, too, was tormented by a perversion of ingenuity, even while the prize was reserved for me.

I saw in this the reason for my being staved off so long and the reason for my late guardian's declining to commit himself to the formal knowledge of such a scheme.

I saw in this, a reason for her (Havisham) being beforehand assigned to me. In a word, I saw in this Miss Havisham as I had her (Havisham) then

and there before my eyes, and always had had her (Havisham) before my eyes; and I saw in this, the distinct shadow of the darkened and unhealthy house in which her (Havisham) life was hidden from the sun.

They were high from the ground, and they burnt with the steady dulness of artificial light in air that is seldom renewed.

As I looked round at them, and at the pale gloom they made, and at the stopped clock, and at the withered articles of bridal dress upon the table and the ground, and at her (Havisham) own awful figure with its ghostly reflection thrown large by the fire upon the ceiling and the wall, I saw in everything the construction that my mind had come to, repeated and thrown back to me.

My thoughts passed into the great room across the landing where the table was spread, and I saw it written, as it were, in the falls of the cobwebs from the centre-piece, in the crawlings of the spiders on the cloth, in the tracks of the mice as they betook their little quickened hearts behind the panels, and in the gropings and pausings of the beetles on the floor.

The candles that lighted that room of hers were placed in sconces on the wall. It happened on the occasion of this visit that some sharp words arose between Estella and Miss Havisham.

We were seated by the fire, as just now described, and Miss Havisham still had Estella's arm drawn through her (Havisham) own, and still clutched Estella's hand in hers, when Estella gradually began to detach herself.

She (Estella) had shown a proud impatience more than once before, and had rather endured that fierce affection than accepted or returned it.

It was the first time I had ever seen them opposed.

``What!'' (Miss Havisham)
said Miss Havisham, flashing her (Havisham) eyes upon her (Havisham),
``are you tired of me?'' (her)

``Only a little tired of myself,'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)
replied Estella, disengaging her (Estella) arm, and moving to the great chimney-piece, where she (Estella) stood looking down at the fire.

'' Speak the truth, you ingrate!'' cried Miss Havisham, passionately striking her (Havisham) stick upon the floor;

``you are tired of me.

'' (Miss Havisham)

Estella looked at her (Estella) with perfect composure, and again looked down at the fire. Her (Estella) graceful figure and her (Estella) beautiful face expressed a self-possessed indifference to the wild heat of the other

'' said Estella, preserving her (Estella) attitude of indifference as she (Estella) leaned against the great chimney-piece and only moving her (Estella) eyes;

``do you reproach me for being cold?

, that was almost cruel. '' (she)

You stock and stone! '' exclaimed Miss Havisham. '' You cold, cold heart!''
``What? You?'' (unknown)

``Are you not? '' (unknown)
was the fierce retort. '' You should know,'' said Estella. '' I am what you have made me.

Take all the praise, take all the blame; take all the success, take all the failure; in short, take me.''

``O, look at her (Estella), look at her (Estella)!'' (Miss Havisham)
cried Miss Havisham, bitterly;

Where I took her (Havisham) into this wretched breast when it was first bleeding from its stabs, and where I have lavished years of tenderness upon her (Havisham)!''

``At least I was no party to the compact,'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)
said Estella, ``for if I could walk and speak, when it was made, it was as much as I could do.

``Look at her (Estella) so hard and thankless, on the hearth where she (Estella) was reared! But what would you have? You have been very good to me, and I owe everything to you.

What would you have?'' (unknown)

``Love,'' (unknown)
replied the other. '' You have it. '' '' I have not,'' said Miss Havisham. ''

Mother by adoption,'' retorted Estella, never departing from the easy grace of her (Estella) attitude, never raising her (Estella) voice as the other did, never yielding either to anger or tenderness,--

``mother by adoption, I have said that I owe everything to you.

All I possess is freely yours. All that you have given me, is at your command to have again. Beyond that, I have nothing.

And if you ask me to give you, what you never gave me, my gratitude and duty cannot do impossibilities.'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)

''

Did I never give her (mother) a burning love, inseparable from jealousy at all times, and from sharp pain, while she (mother) speaks thus to me!

Did I never give her (mother) love!'' cried Miss Havisham, turning wildly to me. '' Let her (mother) call me mad, let her (mother) call me mad!''

``Why should I call you mad,'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)
returned Estella,
``I, of all people? Does any one live, who knows what set purposes you have, half as well as I do?

I who have sat on this same hearth on the little stool that is even now beside you there, learning your lessons and looking up into your face, when your face was strange and frightened me!'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)

Does any one live, who knows what a steady memory you have, half as well as I do?

``Soon forgotten!'' (unknown)
moaned Miss Havisham.

'' Times soon forgotten!'' '' No, not forgotten,'' retorted Estella,--

``not forgotten, but treasured up in my memory. When have you found me false to your teaching?

When have you found me unmindful of your lessons? When have you found me giving admission here,'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)

she (Estella) touched her (Estella) bosom with her (Estella) hand,
``to anything that you excluded?

Be just to me.'' (she)

``So proud, so proud! '' (Miss Havisham)
moaned Miss Havisham, pushing away her (Havisham) gray hair with both her (Havisham) hands.

'' Who taught me to be proud? '' returned Estella. '' Who praised me when I learnt my lesson?''

``So hard, so hard!

'' (Miss Havisham)

moaned Miss Havisham, with her (Havisham) former action. '' Who taught me to be hard? '' returned Estella. '' Who praised me when I learnt my lesson?''

'' But to be proud and hard to me! '' Miss Havisham quite shrieked, as she (Havisham) stretched out her (Havisham) arms. ''

Estella looked at her (Estella) for a moment with a kind of calm wonder, but was not otherwise disturbed; when the moment was past, she (Estella) looked down at the fire again.

I cannot think,'' said Estella, raising her (Estella) eyes after a silence

``why you should be so unreasonable when I come to see you after a separation.

Estella, Estella, Estella, to be proud and hard to me!'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)

'' I have never forgotten your wrongs and their causes. I have never been unfaithful to you or your schooling.

I have never shown any weakness that I can charge myself with.''

``Would it be weakness to return my love?'' (unknown)
exclaimed Miss Havisham.

``I begin to think,'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)
said Estella, in a musing way, after another moment of calm wonder,
``that I almost understand how this comes about.

If you had brought up your adopted daughter wholly in the dark confinement of these rooms, and had never let her (daughter) know that there was such a thing as the daylight by which she (daughter) had never once seen your face,--if

you had done that, and then, for a purpose had wanted her (daughter) to understand the daylight and know all about it, you would have been disappointed and angry?

'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)

Miss Havisham, with her (Havisham) head in her (Havisham) hands, sat making a low moaning, and swaying herself on her (Havisham) chair, but gave no answer.

Or,'' said Estella,--

``which is a nearer case,--if you had taught her (Estella), from the dawn of her (Estella) intelligence, with your utmost energy and might, that there was such a thing as daylight, but that it was made to be her (Estella) enemy and destroyer, and she (Estella) must always turn against it, for it had blighted you and would else blight her (Estella);--if you had done this, and then, for a purpose, had wanted her (Estella) to take naturally to the daylight and she (Estella) could not do it, you would have been disappointed and angry?

'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)

But yes, yes, she (Estella) would call it so!'' '' '' Miss Havisham sat listening -LRB-or it seemed so, for I could not see her (Havisham) face-RRB-, but still made no answer.

'' So,'' said Estella,

``I must be taken as I have been made. The success is not mine, the failure is not mine, but the two together make me.

Miss Havisham had settled down, I hardly knew how, upon the floor, among the faded bridal relics with which it was strewn.

I took advantage of the moment--I had sought one from the first--to leave the room, after beseeching Estella's attention to her (Estella), with a movement of my hand.

Miss Havisham's gray hair was all adrift upon the ground, among the other bridal wrecks, and was a miserable sight to see.

It was with a depressed heart that I walked in the starlight for an hour and more, about the courtyard, and about the brewery, and about the ruined garden.

'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)

When I left, Estella was yet standing by the great chimney-piece, just as she (Estella) had stood throughout. When I at last took courage to return to the room

, I found Estella sitting at Miss Havisham's knee, taking up some stitches in one of those old articles of dress that were dropping to pieces, and of which I have often been reminded since by the faded tatters of old banners that I have seen hanging up in cathedrals.

Afterwards, Estella and I played at cards, as of yore,--only we were skilful now, and played French games,--and so the evening wore away, and I went to bed.

It was the first time I had ever lain down to rest in Satis House, and sleep refused to come near me.

She (Estella) was on this side of my pillow, on that, at the head of the bed, at the foot, behind the half-opened door of the dressing-room, in the dressing-room, in the room overhead, in the room beneath,--everywhere.

At last, when the night was slow to creep on towards two o'clock, I felt that I absolutely could no longer bear the place as a place to lie down in, and that I must get up.

I therefore got up and put on my clothes, and went out across the yard into the long stone passage, designing to gain the outer courtyard and walk there for the relief of my mind.

But I was no sooner in the passage than I extinguished my candle; for I saw Miss Havisham going along it in a ghostly manner, making a low cry.

I lay in that separate building across the courtyard. A thousand Miss Havishams haunted me. I followed her (I) at a distance, and saw her (I) go up the staircase.

She (I) carried a bare candle in her (I) hand, which she (I) had probably taken from one of the sconces in her (I) own room, and was a most unearthly object by its light.

Standing at the bottom of the staircase, I felt the mildewed air of the feast-chamber, without seeing her (I) open the door, and I heard her (I) walking there, and so across into her (I) own room, and so across again into that, never ceasing the low cry.

After a time, I tried in the dark both to get out, and to go back, but I could do neither until some streaks of day strayed in and showed me where to lay my hands.

During the whole interval, whenever I went to the bottom of the staircase, I heard her (I) footstep, saw her (I) light pass above, and heard her (I) ceaseless low cry.

Before we left next day, there was no revival of the difference between her (I) and Estella, nor was it ever revived on any similar occasion; and there were four similar occasions, to the best of my remembrance.

Nor, did Miss Havisham's manner towards Estella in anywise change, except that I believed it to have something like fear infused among its former characteristics.

It is impossible to turn this leaf of my life, without putting Bentley Drummle's name upon it; or I would, very gladly.

On a certain occasion when the Finches were assembled in force, and when good feeling was being promoted in the usual manner by nobody's agreeing with anybody else, the presiding Finch called the Grove to order, forasmuch as Mr. Drummle had not yet toasted a lady; which, according to the solemn constitution of the society, it was the brute's turn to do that day.

I thought I saw him (Drummle) leer in an ugly way at me while the decanters were going round, but as there was no love lost between us, that might easily be.

What was my indignant surprise when he (Drummle) called upon the company to pledge him (Drummle) to

``Estella!'' (him)
'' Estella who?'' said I.

``Never you mind,'' (I.)
retorted Drummle. '' Estella of where?'' said I.
``You are bound to say of where. '' (I.)
Which he (Drummle) was, as a Finch.

'' Of Richmond, gentlemen,'' said Drummle, putting me out of the question,

``and a peerless beauty. '' (me)
Much he (Drummle) knew about peerless beauties, a mean, miserable idiot!

I whispered Herbert. '' I know that lady,'' said Herbert, across the table, when the toast had been honored.

``Do you?'' (Drummle/Mr. Drummle)
said Drummle.

This was the only retort--except glass or crockery--that the heavy creature was capable of making; but, I became as highly incensed by it as if it had been barbed with wit, and I immediately rose in my place and said that I could not but regard it as being like the honorable Finch's impudence to come down to that Grove,--we always talked about coming down to that Grove, as a neat Parliamentary turn of expression,--down to that Grove, proposing a lady of whom he (Grove) knew nothing.

'' And so do I,'' I added, with a scarlet face. '' Do you?'' said Drummle. '' O, Lord!'' Mr. Drummle, upon this, starting up, demanded what I meant by that?

Whether it was possible in a Christian country to get on without blood, after this, was a question on which the Finches were divided.

The debate upon it grew so lively, indeed, that at least six more honorable members told six more, during the discussion, that they believed they knew where they were to be found.

However, it was decided at last -LRB-the Grove being a Court of Honor-RRB- that if Mr. Drummle would bring never so slight a certificate from the lady, importing that he (Drummle) had the honor of her (lady) acquaintance, Mr. Pip must express his (Pip) regret, as a gentleman and a Finch, for ``having been betrayed into a warmth which.

Next day was appointed for the production -LRB-lest our honor should take cold from delay-RRB-, and next day Drummle appeared with a polite little avowal in Estella's hand, that she (Estella) had had the honor of dancing with him (Finch) several times.

This left me no course but to regret that I had been

``betrayed into a warmth which,'' (I)
and on the whole to repudiate, as untenable, the idea that I was to be found anywhere.

Drummle and I then sat snorting at one another for an hour, while the Grove engaged in indiscriminate contradiction, and finally the promotion of good feeling was declared to have gone ahead at an amazing rate.

Whereupon I made him (Finch) the extreme reply that I believed he (Finch) knew where I was to be found. '' I tell this lightly, but it was no light thing to me.

For, I cannot adequately express what pain it gave me to think that Estella should show any favor to a contemptible, clumsy, sulky booby, so very far below the average.

To the present moment, I believe it to have been referable to some pure fire of generosity and disinterestedness in my love for her (Estella), that I could not endure the thought of her (Estella) stooping to that hound.

No doubt I should have been miserable whomsoever she (Estella) had favored; but a worthier object would have caused me a different kind and degree of distress.

It was easy for me to find out, and I did soon find out, that Drummle had begun to follow her (Estella) closely, and that she (Estella) allowed him (Drummle) to do it.

He (Drummle) held on, in a dull persistent way, and Estella held him (Drummle) on; now with encouragement, now with discouragement, now almost flattering him (Drummle), now openly despising him (Drummle), now knowing him (Drummle) very well, now scarcely remembering who he (Drummle) was.

The Spider, as Mr. Jaggers had called him (Jaggers), was used to lying in wait, however, and had the patience of his (Jaggers) tribe.

Added to that, he (Jaggers) had a blockhead confidence in his (Jaggers) money and in his (Jaggers) family greatness, which sometimes did him (Jaggers) good service,--almost taking the place of concentration and determined purpose.

So, the Spider, doggedly watching Estella, outwatched many brighter insects, and would often uncoil himself and drop at the right nick of time.

At a certain Assembly Ball at Richmond -LRB-there used to be Assembly Balls at most places then-RRB-, where Estella had outshone all other beauties, this blundering Drummle so hung about her (Estella), and with so much toleration on her (Estella) part, that I resolved to speak to her (Estella) concerning him (Drummle).

I took the next opportunity; which was when she (Estella) was waiting for Mrs. Blandley to take her (Estella) home, and was sitting apart among some flowers, ready to go.

A little while, and he (Drummle) was always in pursuit of her (Estella), and he (Drummle) and I crossed one another every day. I was with her (Estella), for I almost always accompanied them to and from such places.

``Say rather, I should not be; for I have my letter to Satis House to write, before I go to sleep.'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)

'' Are you tired, Estella?''

``Rather, Pip. '' (unknown)
``You should be. '' (unknown)
``Recounting to-night's triumph?'' (I.)
said I.
``Surely a very poor one, Estella.

'' (I.)

'' What do you mean? I didn't know there had been any.'' '' Estella,'' said I,
``do look at that fellow in the corner yonder, who is looking over here at us.

'' (I)

``Why should I look at him (fellow)? '' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)
returned Estella, with her (Estella) eyes on me instead. '' What is there in that fellow in the corner yonder,--to use your words,--that I need look at?''

``Indeed, that is the very question I want to ask you,'' (I.)
said I.
``For he (fellow) has been hovering about you all night.'' (I.)

'' Moths, and all sorts of ugly creatures,'' replied Estella, with a glance towards him (fellow),

``hover about a lighted candle. Can the candle help it?'' (him)

'' No,'' I returned;

``but cannot the Estella help it?'' (I)
``Well!'' (she)
said she (Estella), laughing, after a moment,
``perhaps. Yes. Anything you like.'' (she)

'' But, Estella, do hear me speak. It makes me wretched that you should encourage a man so generally despised as Drummle.

You know he (man) is despised. ''

``Well?'' (she)
said she (Estella). '' You know he (man) is as ungainly within as without. A deficient, ill-tempered, lowering, stupid fellow.

''

``Well?'' (she)
said she (Estella). '' You know he (fellow) has nothing to recommend him (fellow) but money and a ridiculous roll of addle-headed predecessors; now, don't you?''

To overcome the difficulty of getting past that monosyllable, I took it from her (Estella), and said, repeating it with emphasis, ``Well!

``Well?'' (she)
said she (Estella) again; and each time she (Estella) said it, she (Estella) opened her (Estella) lovely eyes the wider. Then, that is why it makes me wretched.

Now, if I could have believed that she (Estella) favored Drummle with any idea of making me-me--wretched, I should have been in better heart about it; but in that habitual way of hers, she (Estella) put me so entirely out of the question, that I could believe nothing of the kind.

'' '' Pip,'' said Estella, casting her (Estella) glance over the room,

``don't be foolish about its effect on you. It may have its effect on others, and may be meant to have.

Yes it is,'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)

said I,
``because I cannot bear that people should say, `she (Estella) throws away her (Estella) graces and attractions on a mere boor, the lowest in the crowd.'

It's not worth discussing.'' (I)

'' ''
``I can bear it,'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)
said Estella. '' Oh! don't be so proud, Estella, and so inflexible.''

``Calls me proud and inflexible in this breath!'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)
said Estella, opening her (Estella) hands. '' And in his (I) last breath reproached me for stooping to a boor!''

There is no doubt you do,'' said I, something hurriedly, ``for I have seen you give him (I) looks and smiles this very night, such as you never give to--me.

``Do you want me then,'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)
said Estella, turning suddenly with a fixed and serious, if not angry, look,
``to deceive and entrap you?'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)

'' ''

``Do you deceive and entrap him (I), Estella?'' (others)
'' Yes, and many others,--all of them but you. Here is Mrs. Brandley.

* And now that I have given the one chapter to the theme that so filled my heart, and so often made it ache and ache again, I pass on unhindered, to the event that had impended over me longer yet; the event that had begun to be prepared for, before I knew that the world held Estella, and in the days when her (Estella) baby intelligence was receiving its first distortions from Miss Havisham's wasting hands.

In the Eastern story, the heavy slab that was to fall on the bed of state in the flush of conquest was slowly wrought out of the quarry, the tunnel for the rope to hold it in its place was slowly carried through the leagues of rock, the slab was slowly raised and fitted in the roof, the rope was rove to it and slowly taken through the miles of hollow to the great iron ring.

All being made ready with much labor, and the hour come, the sultan was aroused in the dead of the night, and the sharpened axe that was to sever the rope from the great iron ring was put into his (sultan) hand, and he (sultan) struck with it, and the rope parted and rushed away, and the ceiling fell.

So, in my case; all the work, near and afar, that tended to the end, had been accomplished; and in an instant the blow was struck, and the roof of my stronghold dropped upon me.

Not another word had I heard to enlighten me on the subject of my expectations, and my twenty-third birthday was a week gone.

I'll say no more. '' * Chapter XXXIX I was three-and-twenty years of age. We had left Barnard's Inn more than a year, and lived in the Temple.

Mr. Pocket and I had for some time parted company as to our original relations, though we continued on the best terms.

I hope arose out of the restless and incomplete tenure on which I held my means,--I had a taste for reading, and read regularly so many hours a day.

That matter of Herbert's was still progressing, and everything with me was as I have brought it down to the close of the last preceding chapter.

Our chambers were in Garden-court, down by the river. Notwithstanding my inability to settle to anything,--which Business had taken Herbert on a journey to Marseilles.

Dispirited and anxious, long hoping that to-morrow or next week would clear my way, and long disappointed, I sadly missed the cheerful face and ready response of my friend.

I was alone, and had a dull sense of being alone. It was wretched weather; stormy and wet, stormy and wet; and mud, mud, mud, deep in all the streets.

Day after day, a vast heavy veil had been driving over London from the East, and it drove still, as if in the East there were an Eternity of cloud and wind.

So furious had been the gusts, that high buildings in town had had the lead stripped off their roofs; and in the country, trees had been torn up, and sails of windmills carried away; and gloomy accounts had come in from the coast, of shipwreck and death.

Violent blasts of rain had accompanied these rages of wind, and the day just closed as I sat down to read had been the worst of all.

Alterations have been made in that part of the Temple since that time, and it has not now so lonely a character as it had then, nor is it so exposed to the river.

We lived at the top of the last house, and the wind rushing up the river shook the house that night, like discharges of cannon, or breakings of a sea.

When the rain came with it and dashed against the windows, I thought, raising my eyes to them as they rocked, that I might have fancied myself in a storm-beaten lighthouse.

Occasionally, the smoke came rolling down the chimney as though it could not bear to go out into such a night; and when I set the doors open and looked down the staircase, the staircase lamps were blown out; and when I shaded my face with my hands and looked through the black windows -LRB-opening them ever so little was out of the question in the teeth of such wind and rain-RRB-

, I saw that the lamps in the court were blown out, and that the lamps on the bridges and the shore were shuddering, and that the coal-fires in barges on the river were being carried away before the wind like red-hot splashes in the rain.

As I shut it, Saint Paul's, and all the many church-clocks in the City--some leading, some accompanying, some following--struck that hour.

The sound was curiously flawed by the wind; and I was listening, and thinking how the wind assailed and tore it, when I heard a footstep on the stair.

I read with my watch upon the table, purposing to close my book at eleven o'clock. What nervous folly made me start, and awfully connect it with the footstep of my dead sister, matters not.

It was past in a moment, and I listened again, and heard the footstep stumble in coming on. Remembering then, that the staircase-lights were blown out, I took up my reading-lamp and went out to the stair-head.

Whoever was below had stopped on seeing my lamp, for all was quiet. '' There is some one down there, is there not?

'' I called out, looking down. '' Yes,'' said a voice from the darkness beneath. '' What floor do you want?''

'' The top. Mr. Pip. '' '' That is my name.--There is nothing the matter?'' '' Nothing the matter,'' returned the voice.

And the man came on. I stood with my lamp held out over the stair-rail, and he (man) came slowly within its light.

It was a shaded lamp, to shine upon a book, and its circle of light was very contracted; so that he (man) was in it for a mere instant, and then out of it.

In the instant, I had seen a face that was strange to me, looking up with an incomprehensible air of being touched and pleased by the sight of me.

Moving the lamp as the man moved, I made out that he (man) was substantially dressed, but roughly, like a voyager by sea.

That he (man) was a muscular man, strong on his (man) legs, and that he (man) was browned and hardened by exposure to weather.

As he (man) ascended the last stair or two, and the light of my lamp included us both, I saw, with a stupid kind of amazement, that he (man) was holding out both his (man) hands to me.

That he (man) had long iron-gray hair. That his (man) age was about sixty. '' Pray what is your business? '' I asked him (man).

'' My business? '' he (man) repeated, pausing. '' Ah! Yes. I will explain my business, by your leave.''

``Do you wish to come in?'' (I)

I had asked him (man) the question inhospitably enough, for I resented the sort of bright and gratified recognition that still shone in his (man) face.

'' Yes,'' he (man) replied;

``I wish to come in, master. '' (he)
I resented it, because it seemed to imply that he (man) expected me to respond to it.

But I took him (man) into the room I had just left, and, having set the lamp on the table, asked him (man) as civilly as I could to explain himself.

He (man) looked about him (man) with the strangest air,--an air of wondering pleasure, as if he (man) had some part in the things

Then, I saw that his (man) head was furrowed and bald, and that the long iron-gray hair grew only on its sides.

he (man) admired,--and he (man) pulled off a rough outer coat, and his (man) hat. But, I saw nothing that in the least explained him (man).

On the contrary, I saw him (man) next moment, once more holding out both his (man) hands to me. '' What do you mean?

'' said I, half suspecting him (man) to be mad. He (man) stopped in his (man) looking at me, and slowly rubbed his (man) right hand over his (man) head.

It's disapinting to a man,'' he (man) said, in a coarse broken voice,

``arter having looked for`ard so distant, and come so fur; but you're not to blame for that,--neither on us is to blame for that.

He (man) sat down on a chair that stood before the fire, and covered his (man) forehead with his (man) large brown veinous hands.

'' (he)

I'll speak in half a minute. Give me half a minute, please. '' I looked at him (man) attentively then, and recoiled a little from him (man); but I did not know him (man).

'' There's no one nigh,'' said he (man), looking over his (man) shoulder;

``is there?'' (he)
``Why do you, a stranger coming into my rooms at this time of the night, ask that question?'' (I.)
said I.

``You're a game one,'' (I.)
he (stranger) returned, shaking his (stranger) head at me with a deliberate affection, at once most unintelligible and most exasperating;
``I'm glad you've grow'd up, a game one!

But don't catch hold of me. You'd be sorry arterwards to have done it. '' (me)

I relinquished the intention he (stranger) had detected, for I knew him (stranger)!

If the wind and the rain had driven away the intervening years, had scattered all the intervening objects, had swept us to the churchyard where we first stood face to face on such different levels, I could not have known my convict more distinctly than I knew him (stranger) now as he (stranger) sat in the chair before the fire.

No need to take a file from his (stranger) pocket and show it to me; no need to take the handkerchief from his (stranger) neck and twist it round his (stranger) head; no need to hug himself with both his (stranger) arms, and take a shivering turn across the room, looking back at me for recognition.

Even yet I could not recall a single feature, but I knew him (stranger)! I knew him (stranger) before he (stranger) gave me one of those aids, though, a moment before

, I had not been conscious of remotely suspecting his (stranger) identity. He (stranger) came back to where I stood, and again held out both his (stranger) hands.

Not knowing what to do,--for, in my astonishment I had lost my self-possession,--I reluctantly gave him (stranger) my hands. He (stranger) grasped them heartily, raised them to his (stranger) lips, kissed them, and still held them.

At a change in his (stranger) manner as if he (stranger) were even going to embrace me, I laid a hand upon his (stranger) breast and put him (stranger) away.

'' You acted noble, my boy,'' said he (stranger). '' Noble, Pip! And I have never forgot it!''

``Stay!'' (I.)
said I.
``Keep off!

If you are grateful to me for what I did when I was a little child, I hope you have shown your gratitude by mending your way of life.

Still, however you have found me out, there must be something good in the feeling that has brought you here, and I will not repulse you; but surely you must understand that--I--

My attention was so attracted by the singularity of his (Pip) fixed look at me, that the words died away on my tongue.

If you have come here to thank me, it was not necessary. '' (I.)

'' You was a saying,'' he (Pip) observed, when we had confronted one another in silence,
``that surely I must understand.

What, surely must I understand?'' (he)

``That I cannot wish to renew that chance intercourse with you of long ago, under these different circumstances.

I am glad to believe you have repented and recovered yourself. I am glad to tell you so. I am glad that, thinking I deserve to be thanked, you have come to thank me.

But our ways are different ways, none the less. You are wet, and you look weary. Will you drink something before you go?

'' (He)

He (you) had replaced his (you) neckerchief loosely, and had stood, keenly observant of me, biting a long end of it. ''

I think,'' he (you) answered, still with the end at his (you) mouth and still observant of me,

``that I will drink -LRB-I thank you-RRB-

afore I go. '' (me)

There was a tray ready on a side-table. I brought it to the table near the fire, and asked him (you) what he (you) would have?

He (you) touched one of the bottles without looking at it or speaking, and I made him (you) some hot rum and water.

I tried to keep my hand steady while I did so, but his (you) look at me as he (you) leaned back in his (you) chair with the long draggled end of his (you) neckerchief between his (you) teeth--evidently forgotten--made my hand very difficult to master.

When at last I put the glass to him (you), I saw with amazement that his (you) eyes were full of tears. Up to this time I had remained standing, not to disguise that I wished him (you) gone.

I hope,'' said I, hurriedly putting something into a glass for myself, and drawing a chair to the table,

``that you will not think I spoke harshly to you just now.

But I was softened by the softened aspect of the man, and felt a touch of reproach. '' (I)

I had no intention of doing it, and I am sorry for it if I did.

As I put my glass to my lips, he (man) glanced with surprise at the end of his (man) neckerchief, dropping from his (man) mouth when he (man) opened it, and stretched out his (man) hand.

I wish you well and happy!'' I gave him (man) mine, and then he (man) drank, and drew his (man) sleeve across his (man) eyes and forehead.

I've been a sheep-farmer, stock-breeder, other trades besides, away in the new world,'' said he (man);

``many a thousand mile of stormy water off from this.

'' (he)

How are you living? '' I asked him (man). '' ''
``I hope you have done well?'' (unknown)
``I've done wonderfully well.

There's others went out alonger me as has done well too, but no man has done nigh as well as me.

I'm famous for it. '' (unknown)

``I am glad to hear it. '' (unknown)
``I hope to hear you say so, my dear boy.

Without stopping to try to understand those words or the tone in which they were spoken, I turned off to a point that had just come into my mind.

'' (a messenger)

'' Have you ever seen a messenger you once sent to me,'' I inquired,
``since he (boy) undertook that trust?'' (I)
``Never set eyes upon him (boy).

I warn't likely to it. '' (He)

'' He (boy) came faithfully, and he (boy) brought me the two one-pound notes. I was a poor boy then, as you know, and to a poor boy they were a little fortune.

But, like you, I have done well since, and you must let me pay them back. You can put them to some other poor boy's use.

He (boy) watched me as I laid my purse upon the table and opened it, and he (boy) watched me as I separated two one-pound notes from its contents.

'' I took out my purse. They were clean and new, and I spread them out and handed them over to him (boy).

Still watching me, he (boy) laid them one upon the other, folded them long-wise, gave them a twist, set fire to them at the lamp, and dropped the ashes into the tray.

May I make so bold,'' he (boy) said then, with a smile that was like a frown, and with a frown that was like a smile,

``as ask you how you have done well, since you and me was out on them lone shivering marshes?'' (he)

He (boy) emptied his (boy) glass, got up, and stood at the side of the fire, with his (boy) heavy brown hand on the mantel-shelf.

He (boy) put a foot up to the bars, to dry and warm it, and the wet boot began to steam; but, he (boy) neither looked at it, nor at the fire, but steadily looked at me.

When my lips had parted, and had shaped some words that were without sound, I forced myself to tell him (boy) -LRB-though I could not do it distinctly-RRB-, that I had been chosen to succeed to some property.

''

``How?'' (unknown)
``Ah!'' (I)
It was only now that I began to tremble. '' Might a mere warmint ask what property?'' said he (boy).

I faltered,

``I don't know.'' (I)
``Might a mere warmint ask whose property?'' (he)
said he (boy). I faltered again,
``I don't know. '' (I)

``Could I make a guess, I wonder,'' (unknown)
said the Convict,
``at your income since you come of age! As to the first figure now.

With my heart beating like a heavy hammer of disordered action, I rose out of my chair, and stood with my hand upon the back of it, looking wildly at him (boy).

Five? '' (a guardian)

'' Concerning a guardian,'' he (boy) went on. '' There ought to have been some guardian, or such-like, whiles you was a minor.

All the truth of my position came flashing on me; and its disappointments, dangers, disgraces, consequences of all kinds, rushed in in such a multitude that I was borne down by them and had to struggle for every breath I drew.

Put it,'' he (boy) resumed,

``as the employer of that lawyer whose name begun with a J, and might be Jaggers,--put it as he (Jaggers) had come over sea to Portsmouth, and had landed there, and had wanted to come on to you. '

Some lawyer, maybe. As to the first letter of that lawyer's name now. Would it be J? '' (he)

'' However, you have found me out,' you says just now.

Well! However, did I find you out? Why, I wrote from Portsmouth to a person in London, for particulars of your address.

That person's name? Why, Wemmick. '' I could not have spoken one word, though it had been to save my life.

I stood, with a hand on the chair-back and a hand on my breast, where I seemed to be suffocating,--I stood so, looking wildly at him (I), until I grasped at the chair, when the room began to surge and turn.

He (I) caught me, drew me to the sofa, put me up against the cushions, and bent on one knee before me, bringing the face that I now well remembered, and that I shuddered at, very near to mine.

'' Yes, Pip, dear boy, I've made a gentleman on you! It's me wot has done it! I swore that time, sure as ever I earned a guinea, that guinea should go to you.

I swore arterwards, sure as ever I spec`lated and got rich, you should get rich. I lived rough, that you should live smooth; I worked hard, that you should be above work.

What odds, dear boy? Do I tell it, fur you to feel a obligation? Not a bit. I tell it, fur you to know as that there hunted dunghill dog

The abhorrence in which I held the man, the dread I had of him (man), the repugnance with which I shrank from him (man), could not have been exceeded if he (man) had been some terrible beast.

wot you kep life in , got his (man) head so high that he (man) could make a gentleman,--and, Pip, you're him (man)!'' ''

Look`ee here, Pip. I'm your second father. You're my son,--more to me nor any son. I've put away money, only for you to spend.

When I was a hired-out shepherd in a solitary hut, not seeing no faces but faces of sheep till I half forgot wot

I drops my knife many a time in that hut when I was a-eating my dinner or my supper, and I says, `Here's the boy again, a looking at me whiles I eats and drinks!'

men's and women's faces wos like, I see yourn. I see you there a many times, as plain as ever I see you on them misty marshes. '

Lord strike me dead!' I says each time,--and I goes out in the air to say it under the open heavens,--`but

wot , if I gets liberty and money, I'll make that boy a gentleman!' And I done it. Why, look at you, dear boy!

Look at these here lodgings o'yourn, fit for a lord! A lord? Ah! You shall show money with lords for wagers, and beat 'em!''

In his (lord) heat and triumph, and in his (lord) knowledge that I had been nearly fainting, he (lord) did not remark on my reception of all this.

``Look`ee here!'' (he)
he (lord) went on, taking my watch out of my pocket, and turning towards him (lord) a ring on my finger, while I recoiled from his (lord) touch as if he (lord) had been a snake,
``a gold `un and a beauty: that's a gentleman's, I hope!

It was the one grain of relief I had. A diamond all set round with rubies; that's a gentleman's, I hope!

Look at your linen; fine and beautiful! Look at your clothes; better ain't to be got! And your books too,'' (he)

turning his (gentleman) eyes round the room,
``mounting up, on their shelves, by hundreds!

And you read 'em; don't you? I see you'd been a reading of 'em when I come in. Ha, ha, ha!

You shall read 'em to me, dear boy! And if they're in foreign languages wot I don't understand, I shall be just as proud as if I did.

'' (he)

Again he (boy) took both my hands and put them to his (boy) lips, while my blood ran cold within me. ''

Don't you mind talking, Pip,'' said he (Pip), after again drawing his (Pip) sleeve over his (Pip) eyes and forehead, as the click came in his (Pip) throat which I well

he (Pip) was all the more horrible to me that he (Pip) was so much in earnest;

``you can't do better nor keep quiet, dear boy.

remembered,--and You ain't looked slowly forward to this as I have; you wosn't prepared for this as I wos. But didn't you never think it might be me?'' (he)

``O no, no, no,'' (I)
I returned,
``Never, never!'' (I)
'' Well, you see it wos me, and single-handed. Never a soul in it but my own self and Mr. Jaggers.

''

``Was there no one else? '' (I)
I asked. '' No,'' said he (Jaggers), with a glance of surprise:
``who else should there be?

And, dear boy, how good looking you have growed! There's bright eyes somewheres--eh? Isn't there bright eyes somewheres, wot you love the thoughts on?

Not that a gentleman like you, so well set up as you, can't win 'em off of his (gentleman) own game; but money shall back you!

'' (he)

O Estella, Estella! '' They shall be yourn, dear boy, if money can buy 'em. Let me finish wot I was a telling you, dear boy.

From that there hut and that there hiring-out, I got money left me by my master -LRB-which died, and had been the same as me-RRB-, and got my liberty and went for myself.

In every single thing I went for, I went for you. ' Lord strike a blight upon it,' I says, wotever it was I went for, `if it ain't for him (Lord)!'

It all prospered wonderful. As I giv' you to understand just now, I'm famous for it. It was the money left me, and the gains of the first few year wot

I sent home to Mr. Jaggers--all for you--when he (Jaggers) first come arter you, agreeable to my letter. '' O that he (Jaggers) had never come!

That he (Jaggers) had left me at the forge,--far from contented, yet, by comparison happy! '' And then, dear boy, it was a recompense to me,

The blood horses of them colonists might fling up the dust over me as I was walking; what do I say?

look`ee here, to know in secret that I was making a gentleman. I says to myself, `I'm making a better gentleman nor ever you'll be!'

When one of 'em says to another, `He (gentleman) was a convict, a few year ago, and is a ignorant common fellow now, for all he (fellow)'s lucky,' what do I say?

I says to myself, `If I ain't a gentleman, nor yet ain't got no learning, I'm the owner of such. All on you owns stock and land; which on you owns a brought-up London gentleman?'

And this way I held steady afore my mind that I would for certain come one day and see my boy, and make myself known to him (boy), on his (boy) own ground.

This way I kep myself a going. '' He (boy) laid his (boy) hand on my shoulder. I shuddered at the thought that for anything I knew, his (boy) hand might be stained with blood.

But I held to it, and the harder it was, the stronger I held, for I was determined, and my mind firm made up.

'' It warn't easy, Pip, for me to leave them parts, nor yet it warn't safe. At last I done it.

Throughout, I had seemed to myself to attend more to the wind and the rain than to him (Pip); even now, I could not separate his (Pip) voice from those voices, though those were loud and his (Pip) was silent.

Dear boy, I done it! '' I tried to collect my thoughts, but I was stunned. '' Where will you put me?

'' he (Pip) asked, presently. '' I must be put somewheres, dear boy.'' '' To sleep?'' said I.

``Yes. And to sleep long and sound,'' (I.)
he (boy) answered;
``for I've been sea-tossed and sea-washed, months and months.'' (he)

'' My friend and companion,'' said I, rising from the sofa,

``is absent; you must have his (friend) room.'' (I)
'' He (friend) won't come back to-morrow; will he (friend)?''

Because, look`ee here, dear boy,'' he (boy) said, dropping his (boy) voice, and laying a long finger on my breast in an impressive manner,

``caution is necessary.

'' (he)

No,'' said I, answering almost mechanically, in spite of my utmost efforts;
``not to-morrow. '' (I)
'' ''
``How do you mean?

Caution?'' (unknown)

``By G--, it's Death!'' (unknown)
'' What's death? ''
``I was sent for life. It's death to come back. There's been overmuch coming back of late years, and I should of a certainty be hanged if took.

Nothing was needed but this; the wretched man, after loading wretched me with his (man) gold and silver chains for years, had risked his (man) life to come to me, and I held it there in my keeping!

If I had loved him (man) instead of abhorring him (man); if I had been attracted to him (man) by the strongest admiration and affection, instead of shrinking from him (man) with the strongest repugnance; it could have been no worse.

'' (unknown)

On the contrary, it would have been better, for his (man) preservation would then have naturally and tenderly addressed my heart.

My first care was to close the shutters, so that no light might be seen from without, and then to close and make fast the doors.

While I did so, he (man) stood at the table drinking rum and eating biscuit; and when I saw him (man) thus engaged, I saw my convict on the marshes at his (man) meal again.

When I had gone into Herbert's room, and had shut off any other communication between it and the staircase than through the room in which our conversation had been held, I asked him (Herbert) if he (Herbert) would go to bed?

It almost seemed to me as if he (Herbert) must stoop down presently, to file at his (Herbert) leg. He (Herbert) said yes, but asked me for some of my

``gentleman's linen'' (me)
to put on in the morning.

I brought it out, and laid it ready for him (Herbert), and my blood again ran cold when he (Herbert) again took me by both hands to give me good night.

I got away from him (Herbert), without knowing how I did it, and mended the fire in the room where we had been together, and sat down by it, afraid to go to bed.

For an hour or more, I remained too stunned to think; and it was not until I began to think, that I began fully to know how wrecked I was, and how the ship in which I had sailed was gone to pieces.

Miss Havisham's intentions towards me, all a mere dream; Estella not designed for me; I only suffered in Satis House as a convenience, a sting for the greedy relations, a model with a mechanical heart to practise on when no other practice was at hand; those were the first smarts I had.

knew not what crimes, and liable to be taken out of those rooms where I sat thinking, and hanged at the Old Bailey door, that I had deserted Joe.
