And I should be false and base if I did not tell you, whether it is acceptable to you or no, and whether you are inclined to give credence to it or no, that you deeply wrong both Mr. Matthew Pocket and his (Pocket) son Herbert, if you suppose them to be otherwise than generous, upright, open, and incapable of anything designing or mean.''

'' I know them to have been as honestly under my delusion as I myself. '' They are your friends,'' said Miss Havisham.

They made themselves my friends,'' said I,

``when they supposed me to have superseded them; and when Sarah Pocket, Miss Georgiana, and Mistress Camilla were not my friends, I think.

'' (I)

'' This contrasting of them with the rest seemed, I was glad to see, to do them good with her (Pocket).

She (Pocket) looked at me keenly for a little while, and then said quietly,--

``What do you want for them?'' (me)
'' Only,'' said I,
``that you would not confound them with the others.

They may be of the same blood, but, believe me, they are not of the same nature. '' (I)

Still looking at me keenly, Miss Havisham repeated,--

conscious that I reddened a little, ``as that I could hide from you, even if I desired, that I do want something.

Miss Havisham, if you would spare the money to do my friend Herbert a lasting service in life, but which from the nature of the case must be done without his (Herbert) knowledge, I could show you how.

``What do you want for them?'' (unknown)
``I am not so cunning, you see,'' (I)
I said, in answer, ''
``Why must it be done without his (Herbert) knowledge?

Because,'' (I)

said I,
``I began the service myself, more than two years ago, without his (Herbert) knowledge, and I don't want to be betrayed.

'' (I)

she (you) asked, settling her (you) hands upon her (you) stick, that she (you) might regard me the more attentively. '' Why I fail in my ability to finish it, I cannot explain.

It is a part of the secret which is another person's and not mine. '' She (you) gradually withdrew her (you) eyes from me, and turned them on the fire.

After watching it for what appeared in the silence and by the light of the slowly wasting candles to be a long time, she (you) was roused by the collapse of some of the red coals, and looked towards me again--at first, vacantly--then, with a gradually concentrating attention.

When Miss Havisham had fixed her (Havisham) attention on me, she (Havisham) said, speaking as if there had been no lapse in our dialogue,--

All this time Estella knitted on.

``What else?'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)
'' Estella,'' said I, turning to her (Estella) now, and trying to command my trembling voice,
``you know I love you.

She (Estella) raised her (Estella) eyes to my face, on being thus addressed, and her (Estella) fingers plied their work, and she (Estella) looked at me with an unmoved countenance.

You know that I have loved you long and dearly. '' (I)

I saw that Miss Havisham glanced from me to her (Havisham), and from her (Havisham) to me.

'' I should have said this sooner, but for my long mistake. It induced me to hope that Miss Havisham meant us for one another.

While I thought you could not help yourself, as it were, I refrained from saying it. But I must say it now.

'' Preserving her (Havisham) unmoved countenance, and with her (Havisham) fingers still going, Estella shook her (Estella) head. '' I know,'' said I, in answer to that action,--

``I know.

I have no hope that I shall ever call you mine, Estella. I am ignorant what may become of me very soon

, how poor I may be, or where I may go. Still, I love you. I have loved you ever since I first saw you in this house.

It would have been cruel in Miss Havisham, horribly cruel, to practise on the susceptibility of a poor boy, and to torture me through all these years with a vain hope and an idle pursuit, if she (Estella) had reflected on the gravity of what she (Estella) did.

'' (I)

Looking at me perfectly unmoved and with her (Estella) fingers busy, she (Estella) shook her (Estella) head again. '' But I think she (Estella) did not.

I saw Miss Havisham put her (Havisham) hand to her (Havisham) heart and hold it there, as she (Havisham) sat looking by turns at Estella and at me.

I think that, in the endurance of her (Estella) own trial, she (Estella) forgot mine, Estella. '' '' It seems,'' said Estella, very calmly,

``that there are sentiments, fancies,--I don't know how to call them,--which

I am not able to comprehend. When you say you love me, I know what you mean, as a form of words; but nothing more.

You address nothing in my breast, you touch nothing there. I don't care for what you say at all. I have tried to warn you of this; now, have I not?

'' (Estella/Miss Estella/ESTELLA)

I said in a miserable manner,
``Yes.'' (I)
'' Yes. But you would not be warned, for you thought I did not mean it.

Now, did you not think so?''

``I thought and hoped you could not mean it. You, so young, untried, and beautiful, Estella!

Surely it is not in Nature.'' (unknown)

``It is in my nature,'' (she)
she (Estella) returned. And then she (Estella) added, with a stress upon the words,
``It is in the nature formed within me.

I make a great difference between you and all other people when I say so much. I can do no more.'' (she)

``Is it not true,'' (I)
said I,
``that Bentley Drummle is in town here, and pursuing you?'' (I)
``It is quite true,'' (she)
she (Drummle) replied, referring to him (It) with the indifference of utter contempt.

'' That you encourage him (It), and ride out with him (It), and that he (It) dines with you this very day? '' She (Drummle) seemed a little surprised that I should know it, but again replied,

``Quite true.'' (I)

``You cannot love him (It), Estella!'' (she)
Her (Estella) fingers stopped for the first time, as she (Estella) retorted rather angrily,
``What have I told you?

Do you still think, in spite of it, that I do not mean what I say?'' (she)

``You would never marry him (It), Estella?'' (She)

She (Estella) looked towards Miss Havisham, and considered for a moment with her (Havisham) work in her (Havisham) hands. Then she (Havisham) said,

``Why not tell you the truth?

I dropped my face into my hands, but was able to control myself better than I could have expected, considering what agony it gave me to hear her (Havisham) say those words.

When I raised my face again, there was such a ghastly look upon Miss Havisham's, that it impressed me, even in my passionate hurry and grief.

I am going to be married to him (Havisham). '' (she)

'' Estella, dearest Estella, do not let Miss Havisham lead you into this fatal step.

Miss Havisham gives you to him (Havisham), as the greatest slight and injury that could be done to the many far better men who admire you, and to the few who truly love you.

Among those few there may be one who loves you even as dearly, though he (Havisham) has not loved you as long, as I. Take him (Havisham), and I can bear it better, for your sake!

My earnestness awoke a wonder in her (Havisham) that seemed as if it would have been touched with compassion, if she (Havisham) could have rendered me at all intelligible to her (Havisham) own mind.

Put me aside for ever,--you have done so, I well know,--but bestow yourself on some worthier person than Drummle. '' ''

I am going,'' she (Havisham) said again, in a gentler voice,

``to be married to him (Havisham). The preparations for my marriage are making, and I shall be married soon.

Why do you injuriously introduce the name of my mother by adoption? It is my own act.'' (she)

'' Your own act, Estella, to fling yourself away upon a brute?''

Should I fling myself away upon the man who would the soonest feel -LRB-if people do feel such things-RRB- that I took nothing to him (man)?

'' On whom should I fling myself away? '' she (Estella) retorted, with a smile. '' There! It is done. I shall do well enough, and so will my husband.

As to leading me into what you call this fatal step, Miss Havisham would have had me wait, and not marry yet; but I am tired of the life I have led, which has very few charms for me, and I am willing enough to change it.

Say no more. We shall never understand each other.''

``Such a mean brute, such a stupid brute! '' (I)
I urged, in despair.

'' Don't be afraid of my being a blessing to him (husband),'' said Estella; ``I shall not be that. Come! Here is my hand.

I answered, as my bitter tears fell fast on her (Estella) hand, do what I would to restrain them;

``even if I remained in England and could hold my head up with the rest, how could I see you Drummle's wife?'' (I)

Do we part on this, you visionary boy--or man?''

``O Estella!'' (unknown)
``Nonsense,'' (she)
she (Estella) returned,--
``nonsense. This will pass in no time.'' (she)
''

Never, Estella!''

``You will get me out of your thoughts in a week. '' (unknown)
``Out of my thoughts! You are part of my existence, part of myself.

You have been in every line I have ever read since I first came here, the rough common boy whose poor heart you wounded even then.

You have been in every prospect I have ever seen since,--on the river, on the sails of the ships, on the marshes, in the clouds, in the light, in the darkness, in the wind, in the woods, in the sea, in the streets.

The stones of which the strongest London buildings are made are not more real, or more impossible to be displaced by your hands, than your presence and influence have been to me, there and everywhere, and will be.

Estella, to the last hour of my life, you cannot choose but remain part of my character, part of the little good in me, part of the evil.

But, in this separation, I associate you only with the good; and I will faithfully hold you to that always, for you must have done me far more good than harm, let me feel now what sharp distress I may.

You have been the embodiment of every graceful fancy that my mind has ever become acquainted with. O God bless you, God forgive you!'' (I)

In what ecstasy of unhappiness I got these broken words out of myself, I don't know. The rhapsody welled up within me, like blood from an inward wound, and gushed out.

I remembered,--and soon afterwards with stronger reason,--that while Estella looked at me merely with incredulous wonder, the spectral figure of Miss Havisham, her (Havisham) hand still covering her (Havisham) heart, seemed all resolved into a ghastly stare of pity and remorse.

I held her (Havisham) hand to my lips some lingering moments, and so I left her (Havisham). But ever afterwards, All done, all gone!

So much was done and gone, that when I went out at the gate, the light of the day seemed of a darker color than when I went in.

For a while, I hid myself among some lanes and by-paths, and then struck off to walk all the way to London.

For, I had by that time come to myself so far as to consider that I could not go back to the inn and see Drummle there; that I could not bear to sit upon the coach and be spoken to; that I could do nothing half so good for myself as tire myself out.

Pursuing the narrow intricacies of the streets which at that time tended westward near the Middlesex shore of the river, my readiest access to the Temple was close by the river-side, through Whitefriars.

I was not expected till to-morrow; but I had my keys, and, if Herbert were gone to bed, could get to bed myself without disturbing him (Herbert).

As it seldom happened that I came in at that Whitefriars gate after the Temple was closed, and as I was very muddy and weary, I did not take it ill that the night-porter examined me with much attention as he (Herbert) held the gate a little way open for me to pass in.

It was past midnight when I crossed London Bridge. To help his (Herbert) memory I mentioned my name. '' I was not quite sure, sir, but I thought so.

Here's a note, sir. The messenger that brought it, said would you be so good as read it by my lantern?

It was directed to Philip Pip, Esquire, and on the top of the superscription were the words,

``PLEASE READ THIS, HERE.

'' (Esquire)

Much surprised by the request, I took the note. '' I opened it, the watchman holding up his (watchman) light, and read inside, in Wemmick's writing,--

Chapter XLV Turning from the Temple gate as soon as I had read the warning, I made the best of my way to Fleet Street, and there got a late hackney chariot and drove to the Hummums in Covent Garden.

In those times a bed was always to be got there at any hour of the night, and the chamberlain, letting me in at his (chamberlain) ready wicket, lighted the candle next in order on his (chamberlain) shelf, and showed me straight into the bedroom next in order on his (chamberlain) list.

It was a sort of vault on the ground floor at the back, with a despotic monster of a four-post bedstead in it, straddling over the whole place, putting one of his (chamberlain) arbitrary legs into the fireplace and another into the doorway, and squeezing the wretched little washing-stand in quite a Divinely Righteous manner.

As I had asked for a night-light, the chamberlain had brought me in, before he (chamberlain) left me, the good old constitutional rushlight of those virtuous days--an object like the ghost of a walking-cane, which instantly broke its back if it were touched, which nothing could ever be lighted at, and which was placed in solitary confinement at the bottom of a high tin tower, perforated with round holes that made a staringly wide-awake pattern on the walls.

When I had got into bed, and lay there footsore, weary, and wretched, I found that I could no more close my own eyes than I could close the eyes of this foolish Argus.

``DON'T GO HOME. '' (unknown)
And thus, in the gloom and death of the night, we stared at one another. What a doleful night!

There was an inhospitable smell in the room, of cold soot and hot dust; and, as I looked up into the corners of the tester over my head, I thought what a number of blue-bottle flies from the butchers', and earwigs from the market, and grubs from the country, must be holding on up there, lying by for next summer.

This led me to speculate whether any of them ever tumbled down, and then I fancied that I felt light falls on my face,--a disagreeable turn of thought, suggesting other and more objectionable approaches up my back.

How anxious, how dismal, how long! When I had lain awake a little while, those extraordinary voices with which silence teems began to make themselves audible.

At about the same time, the eyes on the wall acquired a new expression, and in every one of those staring rounds I saw written, DON'T GO HOME.

The closet whispered, the fireplace sighed, the little washing-stand ticked, and one guitar-string played occasionally in the chest of drawers. Whatever night-fancies and night-noises crowded on me, they never warded off this DON'T GO HOME.

Not long before, I had read in the newspapers, how a gentleman unknown had come to the Hummums in the night, and had gone to bed, and had destroyed himself, and had been found in the morning weltering in blood.

It came into my head that he (gentleman) must have occupied this very vault of mine, and I got out of bed to assure myself that there were no red marks about; then opened the door to look out into the passages, and cheer myself with the companionship of a distant light, near which I knew the chamberlain to be dozing.

But all this time, why I was not to go home, and what had happened at home, and when I should go home, and whether Provis was safe at home, were questions occupying my mind so busily, that one might have supposed there could be no more room in it for any other theme.

Even when I thought of Estella, and how we had parted that day forever, and when I recalled all the circumstances of our parting, and all her (Estella) looks and tones, and the action of her (Estella) fingers while she (Estella) knitted,--even

It plaited itself into whatever I thought of, as a bodily pain would have done. then I was pursuing, here and there and everywhere,

When at last I dozed, in sheer exhaustion of mind and body, it became a vast shadowy verb which I had to conjugate.

Imperative mood, present tense: Do not thou go home, let him (I) not go home, let us not go home, do not ye or you go home

Then potentially: I may not and I cannot go home; and I might not, could not, would not, and should not go home; until I felt that I was going distracted, and rolled over on the pillow, and looked at the staring rounds upon the wall again.

I had left directions that I was to be called at seven; for it was plain that I must see Wemmick before seeing any one else, and equally plain that this was a case in which his (Wemmick) Walworth sentiments only could be taken.

It was a relief to get out of the room where the night had been so miserable, and I needed no second knocking at the door to startle me from my uneasy bed.

the caution, Don't go home. , let not them go home. The Castle battlements arose upon my view at eight o'clock.

The little servant happening to be entering the fortress with two hot rolls, I passed through the postern and crossed the drawbridge in her (them) company, and so came without announcement into the presence of Wemmick as he (Wemmick) was making tea for himself and the Aged.

An open door afforded a perspective view of the Aged in bed. '' Halloa, Mr. Pip!'' said Wemmick. '' You did come home, then?''

'' Yes,'' I returned;

``but I didn't go home.'' (I)
'' That's all right,'' said he (Wemmick), rubbing his (Wemmick) hands. '' I left a note for you at each of the Temple gates, on the chance.

Which gate did you come to? '' I told him (Wemmick). '' I'll go round to the others in the course of the day and destroy the notes,'' said Wemmick;

``it's a good rule never to leave documentary evidence if you can help it, because you don't know when it may be put in.

I'm going to take a liberty with you. Would you mind toasting this sausage for the Aged P.? '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

I said I should be delighted to do it.

Then you can go about your work, Mary Anne,'' said Wemmick to the little servant;

``which leaves us to ourselves, don't you see, Mr. Pip?

I thanked him (Pip) for his (Pip) friendship and caution, and our discourse proceeded in a low tone, while I toasted the Aged's sausage and he (Pip) buttered the crumb of the Aged's roll.

'' (the servant)

'' he (Pip) added, winking, as she (Anne) disappeared. '' Now, Mr. Pip, you know,'' said Wemmick,
``you and I understand one another.

We are in our private and personal capacities, and we have been engaged in a confidential transaction before to-day. Official sentiments are one thing.

I was so very nervous, that I had already lighted the Aged's sausage like a torch, and been obliged to blow it out.

I accidentally heard, yesterday morning,'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

said Wemmick,
``being in a certain place where I once took you,--even between you and me, it's as well not to mention names when avoidable--'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
``Much better not,'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
said I.

``I heard there by chance, yesterday morning,'' (I.)
said Wemmick,
``that a certain person not altogether of uncolonial pursuits, and not unpossessed of portable property,--I don't know who it may really be,--we won't name this person--'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
``Not necessary,'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
said I. ''--Had made some little stir in a certain part of the world where a good many people go, not always in gratification of their own inclinations, and not quite irrespective of the government expense--

'' In watching his (Wemmick) face, I made quite a firework of the Aged's sausage, and greatly discomposed both my own attention and Wemmick's; for which I apologized.

We are extra official. '' I cordially assented. ''

``I understand you.'' (unknown)
'' --By disappearing from such place, and being no more heard of thereabouts.

From which,'' said Wemmick,

``conjectures had been raised and theories formed. I also heard that you at your chambers in Garden Court, Temple, had been watched, and might be watched again.'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

'' By whom?'' said I.

``I wouldn't go into that,'' (I.)
said Wemmick, evasively,
``it might clash with official responsibilities. I heard it, as I have in my time heard other curious things in the same place.

He (Wemmick) took the toasting-fork and sausage from me as he (Wemmick) spoke, and set forth the Aged's breakfast neatly on a little tray.

Previous to placing it before him (Wemmick), he (Wemmick) went into the Aged's room with a clean white cloth, and tied the same under the old gentleman's chin, and propped him (gentleman) up, and put his (gentleman) nightcap on one side, and gave him (gentleman) quite a rakish air.

I don't tell it you on information received. I heard it. '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

Then he (gentleman) placed his (gentleman) breakfast before him (gentleman) with great care, and said,
``All right, ain't you, Aged P.?

As there seemed to be a tacit understanding that the Aged was not in a presentable state, and was therefore to be considered invisible, I made a pretence of being in complete ignorance of these proceedings.

This watching of me at my chambers -LRB-which I have once had reason to suspect-RRB-,'' (him)

I said to Wemmick when he (Wemmick) came back,
``is inseparable from the person to whom you have adverted; is it?

'' (he)

To which the cheerful Aged replied,
``All right, John, my boy, all right!'' (unknown)
'' '' Wemmick looked very serious. ''

I couldn't undertake to say that, of my own knowledge. I mean, I couldn't undertake to say it was at first.

As I saw that he (John) was restrained by fealty to Little Britain from saying as much as he (John) could, and as I knew with thankfulness to him (John) how far out of his (John) way he (John) went to say what he (John) did, I could not press him (John).

But I told him (John), after a little meditation over the fire, that I would like to ask him (John) a question, subject to his (John) answering or not answering, as he (John) deemed right, and sure that his (John) course would be right.

He (John) paused in his (John) breakfast, and crossing his (John) arms, and pinching his (John) shirt-sleeves -LRB-his (John) notion of in-door comfort was to sit without any coat-RRB-, he (John) nodded to me once, to put my question.

But it either is, or it will be, or it's in great danger of being. '' '' You have heard of a man of bad character, whose true name is Compeyson?''

He (character) gave me one other nod, compressed the post-office exceedingly, gave me one last nod, and went on with his (character) breakfast.

Now,'' said Wemmick,

``questioning being over,'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
which he (Wemmick) emphasized and repeated for my guidance,
``I come to what I did, after hearing what I heard.

He (Wemmick) answered with one other nod. '' (he)

Is he (Wemmick) living? '' One other nod. '' Is he (Wemmick) in London?'' '' I went to Garden Court to find you; not finding you, I went to Clarriker's to find Mr. Herbert.''

Without mentioning any names or going into any details, I gave him (Herbert) to understand that if he (Herbert) was aware of anybody--Tom, Jack, or Richard--being about the chambers, or about the immediate neighborhood, he (Richard) had better get Tom, Jack, or Richard out of the way while you were out of the way.''

'' And him (Richard) you found?'' said I, with great anxiety. '' And him (Richard) I found.

``He (Richard) would be greatly puzzled what to do?'' (He)

He (Richard) was puzzled what to do; not the less, because I gave him (Richard) my opinion that it was not safe to try to get Tom, Jack, or Richard too far out of the way at present.

'' Mr. Pip, I'll tell you something. Under existing circumstances, there is no place like a great city when you are once in it.

Don't break cover too soon. Lie close. Wait till things slacken, before you try the open, even for foreign air. ''

I thanked him (Pip) for his (Pip) valuable advice, and asked him (Pip) what Herbert had done?

``Mr. Herbert,'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
said Wemmick,
``after being all of a heap for half an hour, struck out a plan.

He (Wemmick) mentioned to me as a secret, that he (Wemmick) is courting a young lady who has, as no doubt you are aware, a bedridden

Which Pa, having been in the Purser line of life, lies a-bed in a bow-window where he (Wemmick) can see the ships sail up and down the river.

'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

``Not personally,'' (I)
said I. The truth was, that she (Purser) had objected to me as an expensive companion who did Herbert no good, and

that, when Herbert had first proposed to present me to her (Purser), she (Purser) had received the proposal with such very moderate warmth, that Herbert had felt himself obliged to confide the state of the case to me, with a view to the lapse of a little time before I made her (Purser) acquaintance.

When I had begun to advance Herbert's prospects by stealth, I had been able to bear this with cheerful philosophy: he (Herbert) and his (Herbert) affianced, for their part, had naturally not been very anxious to introduce a third person into their interviews; and thus, although I was assured that I had risen in Clara's esteem, and although the young lady and I had long regularly interchanged messages and remembrances by Herbert, I had never seen her (lady).

The house with the bow-window,'' said Wemmick,

``being by the river-side, down the Pool there between Limehouse and Greenwich, and being kept, it seems, by a very respectable widow who has a furnished upper floor to let, Mr. Herbert put it to me, what did I think of that as a temporary tenement for Tom, Jack, or Richard?

Pa.. You are acquainted with the young lady, most probably? However, I did not trouble Wemmick with these particulars. '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

Now, I thought very well of it, for three reasons I'll give you.

That is to say: Firstly. It's altogether out of all your beats, and is well away from the usual heap of streets great and small.

Secondly. Without going near it yourself, you could always hear of the safety of Tom, Jack, or Richard, through Mr. Herbert.

After a while and when it might be prudent, if you should want to slip Tom, Jack, or Richard on board a foreign packet-boat, there he (Richard) is--ready.

Thirdly. '' Much comforted by these considerations, I thanked Wemmick again and again, and begged him (Wemmick) to proceed. '' Well, sir!

Mr. Herbert threw himself into the business with a will, and by nine o'clock last night he (Herbert) housed Tom, Jack, or Richard,--whichever

At the old lodgings it was understood that he (Richard) was summoned to Dover, and, in fact, he (Richard) was taken down the Dover road and cornered out of it.

Now, another great advantage of all this is, that it was done without you, and when, if any one was concerning himself about your movements, you must be known to be ever so many miles off and quite otherwise engaged.

This diverts suspicion and confuses it; and for the same reason I recommended that, even if you came back last night, you should not go home.

it may be,--you and I don't want to know,--quite successfully. It brings in more confusion, and you want confusion. '' Wemmick, having finished his (Wemmick) breakfast, here looked at his (Wemmick) watch, and began to get his (Wemmick) coat on.

And now, Mr. Pip,'' said he (Pip), with his (Pip) hands still in the sleeves,

``I have probably done the most I can do; but if I can ever do more,--from a Walworth point of view, and in a strictly private and personal capacity,--I shall be glad to do it.

There can be no harm in your going here to-night, and seeing for yourself that all is well with Tom, Jack, or Richard, before you go home,--which is another reason for your not going home last night.

You are very welcome, I am sure, Mr. Pip'' (he)

; his (Pip) hands were now out of his (Pip) sleeves, and I was shaking them;
``and let me finally impress one important point upon you.

'' (I)

Here's the address. But, after you have gone home, don't go back here. '' He (Pip) laid his (Pip) hands upon my shoulders, and added in a solemn whisper:

``Avail yourself of this evening to lay hold of his (Pip) portable property. You don't know what may happen to him (Pip). Don't let anything happen to the portable property.

'' (He)

Quite despairing of making my mind clear to Wemmick on this point, I forbore to try. '' Time's up,'' said Wemmick,
``and I must be off.

If you had nothing more pressing to do than to keep here till dark, that's what I should advise. You look very much worried, and it would do you good to have a perfectly quiet day with the Aged,--he (Wemmick)'ll

be up presently,--and a little bit of--you remember the pig?'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

``Of course,'' (I.)
said I.
``Well; and a little bit of him (Wemmick).

That sausage you toasted was his (Wemmick), and he (Wemmick) was in all respects a first-rater. Do try him (Wemmick), if it is only for old acquaintance sake.

Good-bye, Aged Parent! '' (I.)

in a cheery shout. '' All right, John; all right, my boy!'' piped the old man from within.

I soon fell asleep before Wemmick's fire, and the Aged and I enjoyed one another's society by falling asleep before it more or less all day.

We had loin of pork for dinner, and greens grown on the estate; and I nodded at the Aged with a good intention whenever I failed to do it drowsily.

When it was quite dark, I left the Aged preparing the fire for toast; and I inferred from the number of teacups, as well as from his (Wemmick) glances at the two little doors in the wall, that Miss Skiffins was expected.

Eight o'clock had struck before I got into the air, that was scented, not disagreeably, by the chips and shavings of the long-shore boat-builders, and mast, oar, and block makers.

All that water-side region of the upper and lower Pool below Bridge was unknown ground to me; and when I struck down by the river, I found that the spot I wanted was not where I had supposed it to be, and was anything but easy to find.

It was called Mill Pond Bank, Chinks's Basin; and I had no other guide to Chinks's Basin than the Old Green Copper Rope-walk.

It matters not what stranded ships repairing in dry docks I lost myself among, what old hulls of ships in course of being knocked to pieces, what ooze and slime and other dregs of tide, what yards of ship-builders and ship-breakers, what rusty anchors blindly biting into the ground, though for years off duty, what mountainous country of accumulated casks and timber, how many rope-walks that were not the Old Green Copper.

After several times falling short of my destination and as often overshooting it, I came unexpectedly round a corner, upon Mill Pond Bank.

It was a fresh kind of place, all circumstances considered, where the wind from the river had room to turn itself round; and there were two or three trees in it, and there was the stump of a ruined windmill, and there was the Old Green Copper Rope-walk,--whose long and narrow vista

Chapter XLVI I could trace in the moonlight, along a series of wooden frames set in the ground, that looked like superannuated haymaking-rakes which had grown old and lost most of their teeth.

Selecting from the few queer houses upon Mill Pond Bank a house with a wooden front and three stories of bow-window -LRB-not bay-window, which is another thing-RRB-, I looked at the plate upon the door, and read there, Mrs. Whimple.

That being the name I wanted, I knocked, and an elderly woman of a pleasant and thriving appearance responded. She (woman) was immediately deposed, however, by Herbert, who silently led me into the parlor and shut the door.

It was an odd sensation to see his (Herbert) very familiar face established quite at home in that very unfamiliar room and region; and I found myself looking at him (Herbert), much as I looked at the corner-cupboard with the glass and china, the shells upon the chimney-piece, and the colored engravings on the wall, representing the death of Captain Cook, a ship-launch, and his (Cook) Majesty King George the Third in a state coachman's wig, leather-breeches, and top-boots, on the terrace at Windsor.

My dear girl is with her (girl) father; and if you'll wait till she (girl) comes down, I'll make you known to her (girl), and then we'll go upstairs.

'' All is well, Handel,'' said Herbert,

``and he (Herbert) is quite satisfied, though eager to see you. That's her (girl) father. '' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

I had become aware of an alarming growling overhead, and had probably expressed the fact in my countenance. '' I am afraid he (father) is a sad old rascal,'' said Herbert, smiling,

``but I have never seen him (Herbert).

Don't you smell rum? He (Herbert) is always at it.'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

``At rum?'' (I.)
said I.
``Yes,'' (I.)
returned Herbert,
``and you may suppose how mild it makes his (Herbert) gout.

He (Herbert) persists, too, in keeping all the provisions upstairs in his (Herbert) room, and serving them out. He (Herbert) keeps them on shelves over his (Herbert) head, and will weigh them all.

His (Herbert) room must be like a chandler's shop. '' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

While he (Herbert) thus spoke, the growling noise became a prolonged roar, and then died away.

A man with the gout in his (man) right hand--and everywhere else--can't expect to get through a Double Gloucester without hurting himself.

'' What else can be the consequence,'' said Herbert, in explanation,

``if he (Herbert) will cut the cheese? '' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
He (Herbert) seemed to have hurt himself very much, for he (Herbert) gave another furious roar.

To have Provis for an upper lodger is quite a godsend to Mrs. Whimple,'' said Herbert,

``for of course people in general won't stand that noise.

'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

A curious place, Handel; isn't it? '' It was a curious place, indeed; but remarkably well kept and clean. ''

Mrs. Whimple,'' said Herbert, when I told him (Herbert) so,

``is the best of housewives, and I really do not know what my Clara would do without her (Clara) motherly help.

For, Clara has no mother of her (Clara) own, Handel, and no relation in the world but old Gruffandgrim. '' (him)

``Surely that's not his (Handel) name, Herbert?'' (the son)

But what a blessing it is for the son of my father and mother to love a girl who has no relations, and who can never bother herself or anybody else about her (girl) family!''

Herbert had told me on former occasions, and now reminded me, that he (Herbert) first knew Miss Clara Barley when she (Clara) was completing her (Clara) education at an establishment at Hammersmith, and that on her (Clara) being recalled home to nurse her (Clara) father, he (father) and she (Clara) had confided their affection to the motherly Mrs. Whimple, by whom it had been fostered and regulated with equal kindness and discretion, ever since.

It was understood that nothing of a tender nature could possibly be confided to old Barley, by reason of his (father) being totally unequal to the consideration of any subject more psychological than Gout, Rum, and Purser's stores.

As we were thus conversing in a low tone while Old Barley's sustained growl vibrated in the beam that crossed the ceiling, the room door opened, and a very pretty, slight, dark-eyed girl of twenty or so came in with a basket in her (girl) hand: whom Herbert tenderly relieved of the basket, and presented, blushing, as

``Clara.

She (Clara) really was a most charming girl, and might have passed for a captive fairy, whom that truculent Ogre, Old Barley, had pressed into his (Ogre) service.

Look here,'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

said Herbert, showing me the basket, with a compassionate and tender smile, after we had talked a little; ``here's poor Clara's supper, served out every night.

``No, no,'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
said Herbert,
``that's my name for him (Herbert). His (Herbert) name is Mr. Barley. '' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
'' Here's her (Clara) allowance of bread, and here's her (Clara) slice of cheese, and here's her (Clara) rum,--which

Two mutton-chops, three potatoes, some split peas, a little flour, two ounces of butter, a pinch of salt, and all this black pepper.

I drink. This is Mr. Barley's breakfast for to-morrow, served out to be cooked. It's stewed up together, and taken hot, and it's a nice thing for the gout, I should think!

There was something so natural and winning in Clara's resigned way of looking at these stores in detail, as Herbert pointed them out; and something so confiding, loving, and innocent in her (Clara) modest manner of yielding herself to Herbert's embracing arm; and something so gentle in her (Clara), so much needing protection on Mill Pond Bank, by Chinks's Basin, and the Old Green Copper Rope-walk, with Old Barley growling in the beam,--that I would not have undone the engagement between her (Clara) and Herbert for all the money in the pocket-book

I was looking at her (Clara) with pleasure and admiration, when suddenly the growl swelled into a roar again, and a frightful bumping noise was heard above, as if a giant with a wooden leg were trying to bore it through the ceiling to come at us.

'' I had never opened. Upon this Clara said to Herbert,

``Papa wants me, darling!'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
and ran away. '' There is an unconscionable old shark for you!'' said Herbert.

'' What do you suppose he (Herbert) wants now, Handel?''

``I don't know,'' (I.)
said I.
``Something to drink?'' (I.)
'' That's it! '' cried Herbert, as if I had made a guess of extraordinary merit.

'' He (Herbert) keeps his (Herbert) grog ready mixed in a little tub on the table. Wait a moment, and you'll hear Clara lift him (Herbert) up to take some.

There he (Herbert) goes!'' Another roar, with a prolonged shake at the end. '' Now,'' said Herbert, as it was succeeded by silence,

``he (Herbert)'s drinking.

Now,'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

said Herbert, as the growl resounded in the beam once more,
``he (Herbert)'s down again on his (Herbert) back!'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
Clara returned soon afterwards, and Herbert accompanied me upstairs to see our charge.

As we passed Mr. Barley's door, he (Herbert) was heard hoarsely muttering within, in a strain that rose and fell like wind, the following Refrain, in which I substitute good wishes for something quite the reverse:--

``Ahoy! Bless your eyes, here's old Bill Barley. Here's old Bill Barley, bless your eyes. Here's old Bill Barley on the flat of his (Barley) back, by the Lord.

Lying on the flat of his (Barley) back like a drifting old dead flounder, here's your old Bill Barley, bless your eyes.

In this strain of consolation, Herbert informed me the invisible Barley would commune with himself by the day and night together;

Often, while it was light, having, at the same time, one eye at a telescope which was fitted on his (Herbert) bed for the convenience of sweeping the river.

In his (Herbert) two cabin rooms at the top of the house, which were fresh and airy, and in which Mr. Barley was less audible than below, I found Provis comfortably settled.

He (Barley) expressed no alarm, and seemed to feel none that was worth mentioning; but it struck me that he (Barley) was softened,--indefinably, for I could not have said how, and could never afterwards recall how when I tried, but certainly.

The opportunity that the day's rest had given me for reflection had resulted in my fully determining to say nothing to him (Barley) respecting Compeyson.

For anything I knew, his (Barley) animosity towards the man might otherwise lead to his (Barley) seeking him (Barley) out and rushing on his (Barley) own destruction.

Therefore, when Herbert and I sat down with him (Herbert) by his (Herbert) fire, I asked him (Herbert) first of all whether he (Herbert) relied on Wemmick's judgment and sources of information?

``Then, I have talked with Wemmick,'' (I)
said I,
``and have come to tell you what caution he (Wemmick) gave me and what advice.

I did accurately, with the reservation just mentioned; and I told him (Wemmick) how Wemmick had heard, in Newgate prison -LRB-whether from officers or prisoners I could not say-RRB-, that he (Wemmick) was under some suspicion, and that my chambers had been watched; how Wemmick had recommended his (Wemmick) keeping close for a time, and my keeping away from him (Wemmick); and what Wemmick had said about getting him (Wemmick) abroad.

I added, that of course, when the time came, I should go with him (Wemmick), or should follow close upon him (Wemmick), as might be safest in Wemmick's judgment.

What was to follow that I did not touch upon; neither, indeed, was I at all clear or comfortable about it in my own mind, now that I saw him (Wemmick) in that softer condition, and in declared peril for my sake.

As to altering my way of living by enlarging my expenses, I put it to him (Wemmick) whether in our present unsettled and difficult circumstances, it would not be simply ridiculous, if it were no worse?

Ahoy! Bless you. '' (I)

'' Ay, ay, dear boy! '' he (boy) answered, with a grave nod,
``Jaggers knows.'' (he)
'' This He (Jaggers) could not deny this, and indeed was very reasonable throughout.

He (Jaggers) would do nothing to make it a desperate venture, and he (Jaggers) had very little fear of his (Jaggers) safety with such good help.

Herbert, who had been looking at the fire and pondering, here said that something had come into his (Herbert) thoughts arising out of Wemmick's suggestion, which it might be worth while to pursue.

His (Herbert) coming back was a venture, he (Herbert) said, and he (Herbert) had always known it to be a venture. '' We are both good watermen, Handel, and could take him (Handel) down the river ourselves when the right time comes.

No boat would then be hired for the purpose, and no boatmen; that would save at least a chance of suspicion, and any chance is worth saving.

Never mind the season; don't you think it might be a good thing if you began at once to keep a boat at the Temple stairs, and were in the habit of rowing up and down the river?

You fall into that habit, and then who notices or minds? Do it twenty or fifty times, and there is nothing special in your doing it

We agreed that it should be carried into execution, and that Provis should never recognize us if we came below Bridge, and rowed past Mill Pond Bank.

But we further agreed that he (Provis) should pull down the blind in that part of his (Provis) window which gave upon the east, whenever he (Provis) saw us and all was right.

Our conference being now ended, and everything arranged, I rose to go; remarking to Herbert that he (Herbert) and I had better not go home together, and that I would take half an hour's start of him (Herbert).

I don't like to leave you here,'' I said to Provis,

``though I cannot doubt your being safer here than near me.

the twenty-first or fifty-first. '' (Provis/Mr. Provis)

I liked this scheme, and Provis was quite elated by it. '' Good-bye!'' '' Dear boy,'' he (boy) answered, clasping my hands,
``I don't know when we may meet again, and I don't like good-bye.

Say good night!'' (he)

``Good night! Herbert will go regularly between us, and when the time comes you may be certain I shall be ready.

We thought it best that he (Herbert) should stay in his (Herbert) own rooms; and we left him (Herbert) on the landing outside his (Herbert) door, holding a light over the stair-rail to light us downstairs.

Looking back at him (Herbert), I thought of the first night of his (Herbert) return, when our positions were reversed, and when I little supposed my heart could ever be as heavy and anxious at parting from him (Herbert) as it was now.

Old Barley was growling and swearing when we repassed his (Herbert) door, with no appearance of having ceased or of meaning to cease.

Good night, good night! '' (I)

When we got to the foot of the stairs, I asked Herbert whether he (Herbert) had preserved the name of Provis.

He (Provis) also explained that the utmost known of Mr. Campbell there was, that he (Campbell) -LRB-Herbert-RRB- had Mr. Campbell consigned to him (Campbell), and felt a strong personal interest in his (Campbell) being well cared for, and living a secluded life.

So, when we went into the parlor where Mrs. Whimple and Clara were seated at work, I said nothing of my own interest in Mr. Campbell, but kept it to myself.

When I had taken leave of the pretty, gentle, dark-eyed girl, and of the motherly woman who had not outlived her (woman) honest sympathy with a little affair of true love, I felt as if the Old Green Copper Rope-walk had grown quite a different place.

Old Barley might be as old as the hills, and might swear like a whole field of troopers, but there were redeeming youth and trust and hope enough in Chinks's Basin to fill it to overflowing.

He (Green) replied, certainly not, and that the lodger was Mr. Campbell. And then I thought of Estella, and of our parting, and went home very sadly.

The windows of the rooms on that side, lately occupied by Provis, were dark and still, and there was no lounger in Garden Court.

I walked past the fountain twice or thrice before I descended the steps that were between me and my rooms, but I was quite alone.

All things were as quiet in the Temple as ever I had seen them. Herbert, coming to my bedside when he (Herbert) came in,--for I went straight to bed, dispirited and fatigued,--made the same report.

Opening one of the windows after that, he (Herbert) looked out into the moonlight, and told me that the pavement was as solemnly empty as the pavement of any cathedral at that same hour.

It was soon done, and the boat was brought round to the Temple stairs, and lay where I could reach her (Herbert) within a minute or two.

Next day I set myself to get the boat. Then, I began to go out as for training and practice: sometimes alone, sometimes with Herbert.

I was often out in cold, rain, and sleet, but nobody took much note of me after I had been out a few times.

It was Old London Bridge in those days, and at certain states of the tide there was a race and fall of water there which gave it a bad reputation.

But I knew well enough how to `shoot' the bridge after seeing it done, and so began to row about among the shipping in the Pool, and down to Erith.

The first time I passed Mill Pond Bank, Herbert and I were pulling a pair of oars; and, both in going and returning, we saw the blind towards the east come down.

Herbert was rarely there less frequently than three times in a week, and he (Herbert) never brought me a single word of intelligence that was at all alarming.

Still, I knew that there was cause for alarm, and I could not get rid of the notion of being watched.

Once received, it is a haunting idea; how many undesigning persons I suspected of watching me, it would be hard to calculate.

At first, I kept above Blackfriars Bridge; but as the hours of the tide changed, I took towards London Bridge. In short, I was always full of fears for the rash man who was in hiding.

Herbert had sometimes said to me that he (Herbert) found it pleasant to stand at one of our windows after dark, when the tide was running down, and to think that it was flowing, with everything it bore, towards Clara.

But I thought with dread that it was flowing towards Magwitch, and that any black mark on its surface might be his (Magwitch) pursuers, going swiftly, silently, and surely, to take him (Magwitch).

If I had never known him (Magwitch) out of Little Britain, and had never enjoyed the privilege of being on a familiar footing at the Castle, I might have doubted him (Magwitch); not so for a moment, knowing him (Magwitch) as I did.

Chapter XLVII Some weeks passed without bringing any change. We waited for Wemmick, and he (Wemmick) made no sign. My worldly affairs began to wear a gloomy appearance, and I was pressed for money by more than one creditor.

Even I myself began to know the want of money -LRB-I mean of ready money in my own pocket-RRB-, and to relieve it by converting some easily spared articles of jewelery into cash.

But I had quite determined that it would be a heartless fraud to take more money from my patron in the existing state of my uncertain thoughts and plans.

Therefore, I had sent him (patron) the unopened pocket-book by Herbert, to hold in his (Herbert) own keeping, and I felt a kind of satisfaction--whether it was a false kind or a true, I hardly know--in not having profited by his (Herbert) generosity since his (Herbert) revelation of himself.

Fearful of having it confirmed, though it was all but a conviction, I avoided the newspapers, and begged Herbert -LRB-to whom I had confided the circumstances of our last interview-RRB- never to speak of her (Herbert) to me.

Why I hoarded up this last wretched little rag of the robe of hope that was rent and given to the winds, how do I know?

As the time wore on, an impression settled heavily upon me that Estella was married. Why did you who read this, commit that not dissimilar inconsistency of your own last year, last month, last week?

It was an unhappy life that I lived; and its one dominant anxiety, towering over all its other anxieties, like a high mountain above a range of mountains, never disappeared from my view.

Let me start from my bed as I would, with the terror fresh upon me that he (my) was discovered; let me sit listening, as I would with dread, for Herbert's returning step at night, lest it should be fleeter than ordinary, and winged with evil news,--for all that, and much more to like purpose, the round of things went on.

Condemned to inaction and a state of constant restlessness and suspense, I rowed about in my boat, and waited, waited, waited, as I best could.

There were states of the tide when, having been down the river, I could not get back through the eddy-chafed arches and starlings of old London Bridge; then, I left my boat at a wharf near the Custom House, to be brought up afterwards to the Temple stairs.

I was not averse to doing this, as it served to make me and my boat a commoner incident among the water-side people there.

Still, no new cause for fear arose. From this slight occasion sprang two meetings that I have now to tell of.

One afternoon, late in the month of February, I came ashore at the wharf at dusk. I had pulled down as far as Greenwich with the ebb tide, and had turned with the tide.

It had been a fine bright day, but had become foggy as the sun dropped, and I had had to feel my way back among the shipping, pretty carefully.

As it was a raw evening, and I was cold, I thought I would comfort myself with dinner at once; and as I had hours of dejection and solitude before me if I went home to the Temple, I thought I would afterwards go to the play.

The theatre where Mr. Wopsle had achieved his (Wopsle) questionable triumph was in that water-side neighborhood -LRB-it is nowhere now-RRB-, and to that theatre I resolved to go.

I was aware that Mr. Wopsle had not succeeded in reviving the Drama, but, on the contrary, had rather partaken of its decline.

He (Wopsle) had been ominously heard of, through the play-bills, as a faithful Black, in connection with a little girl of noble birth, and a monkey.

And Herbert had seen him (Herbert) as a predatory Tartar of comic propensities, with a face like a red brick, and an outrageous hat all over bells.

I dined at what Herbert and I used to call a geographical chop-house, where there were maps of the world in porter-pot rims on every half-yard of the tablecloths, and charts of gravy on every one of the knives,--to this day there is scarcely a single chop-house within the Lord Mayor's dominions which is not geographical,--and wore out the time in dozing over crumbs, staring at gas, and baking in a hot blast of dinners.

Both in going and returning, I had seen the signal in his (Mayor) window, All well. By and by, I roused myself, and went to the play.

There, I found a virtuous boatswain in His (Mayor) Majesty's service,--a most excellent man, though I could have wished his (Mayor) trousers not quite so tight in some places, and not quite so loose in others,--who knocked all the little men's hats over their eyes, though he (Mayor) was very generous and brave, and who wouldn't hear of anybody's paying taxes, though he (Mayor) was very patriotic.

He (Mayor) had a bag of money in his (Mayor) pocket, like a pudding in the cloth, and on that property married a young person in bed-furniture, with great rejoicings; the whole population of Portsmouth -LRB-nine in number at the last census-RRB- turning out on the beach to rub their own hands and shake everybody else's, and sing

``Fill, fill!

A certain dark-complexioned Swab, however, who wouldn't fill, or do anything else that was proposed to him (Mayor), and whose heart was openly stated -LRB-by the boatswain-RRB- to be as black as his (Mayor) figure-head, proposed to two other Swabs to get all mankind into difficulties; which was so effectually done -LRB-the Swab family having considerable political influence-RRB- that it took half the evening to set things right, and then it was only brought about through an honest little grocer with a white hat, black gaiters, and red nose, getting into a clock, with a gridiron, and listening, and coming out, and knocking everybody down from behind with the gridiron whom he (Mayor) couldn't confute with what he (Mayor) had overheard.

This led to Mr. Wopsle's -LRB-who had never been heard of before-RRB- coming in with a star and garter on, as a plenipotentiary of great power direct from the Admiralty, to say that the Swabs were all to go to prison on the spot, and that he (Wopsle) had brought the boatswain down the Union Jack, as a slight acknowledgment of his (Jack) public services.

The boatswain, unmanned for the first time, respectfully dried his (Jack) eyes on the Jack, and then cheering up, and addressing Mr. Wopsle as Your Honor, solicited permission to take him (Wopsle) by the fin.

Mr. Wopsle, conceding his (Wopsle) fin with a gracious dignity, was immediately shoved into a dusty corner, while everybody danced a hornpipe; and from that corner, surveying the public with a discontented eye, became aware of me.

The second piece was the last new grand comic Christmas pantomime, in the first scene of which, it pained me to suspect that I detected Mr. Wopsle with red worsted legs under a highly magnified phosphoric countenance and a shock of red curtain-fringe for his (Wopsle) hair, engaged in the manufacture of thunderbolts in a mine, and displaying great cowardice when his (Wopsle) gigantic master came home -LRB-very hoarse-RRB- to dinner.

But he (Wopsle) presently presented himself under worthier circumstances; for, the Genius of Youthful Love being in want of assistance,--on account of the parental brutality of an ignorant farmer who opposed the choice of his (farmer) daughter's heart, by purposely falling upon the object, in a flour-sack, out of the first-floor window,--summoned a sententious Enchanter; and he (farmer), coming up from the antipodes rather unsteadily, after an apparently violent journey, proved to be Mr. Wopsle in a high-crowned hat, with a necromantic work in one volume under his (Wopsle) arm.

The business of this enchanter on earth being principally to be talked at, sung at, butted at, danced at, and flashed at with fires of various colors, he (Wopsle) had a good deal of time on his (Wopsle) hands.

And I observed, with great surprise, that he (Wopsle) devoted it to staring in my direction as if he (Wopsle) were lost in amazement.

There was something so remarkable in the increasing glare of Mr. Wopsle's eye, and he (Wopsle) seemed to be turning so many things over in his (Wopsle) mind and to grow so confused, that I could not make it out.

I sat thinking of it long after he (Wopsle) had ascended to the clouds in a large watch-case, and still I could not make it out.

I was still thinking of it when I came out of the theatre an hour afterwards, and found him (Wopsle) waiting for me near the door.

'' (everybody)

'' How do you do?'' said I, shaking hands with him (Wopsle) as we turned down the street together. '' I saw that you saw me.''

``It is the strangest thing,'' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)
said Mr. Wopsle, drifting into his (Wopsle) lost look again; ``and yet I could swear to him (Wopsle).

``Saw you, Mr. Pip!'' (he)
he (Pip) returned. '' Yes, of course I saw you. But who else was there?''
``Who else?'' (I)
''

Whether I should have noticed him (Pip) at first but for your being there,'' said Mr. Wopsle, going on in the same lost way,

``I can't be positive; yet I think I should.

Involuntarily I looked round me, as I was accustomed to look round me when I went home; for these mysterious words gave me a chill.

Becoming alarmed, I entreated Mr. Wopsle to explain his (Wopsle) meaning. '' (Mr. Wopsle/Wopsle)

'' '' Oh! He (Wopsle) can't be in sight,'' said Mr. Wopsle.

'' He (Wopsle) went out before I went off. I saw him (Wopsle) go. '' Having the reason that I had for being suspicious, I even suspected this poor actor.

I mistrusted a design to entrap me into some admission. Therefore I glanced at him (actor) as we walked on together, but said nothing.

I had a ridiculous fancy that he (actor) must be with you, Mr. Pip, till I saw that you were quite unconscious of him (Pip), sitting behind you there like a ghost.

My former chill crept over me again, but I was resolved not to speak yet, for it was quite consistent with his (Pip) words that he (Pip) might be set on to induce me to connect these references with Provis.

'' '' Of course, I was perfectly sure and safe that Provis had not been there. '' I dare say you wonder at me, Mr. Pip; indeed, I see you do.

But it is so very strange! You'll hardly believe what I am going to tell you. I could hardly believe it myself, if you told me.''

Mr. Pip, you remember in old times a certain Christmas Day, when you were quite a child, and I dined at Gargery's, and some soldiers came to the door to get a pair of handcuffs mended?''

And you remember that there was a chase after two convicts, and that we joined in it, and that Gargery took you on his (Pip) back, and that I took the lead, and you kept up with me as well as you could?''

``Indeed?'' (I.)
said I. ``No, indeed.
``I remember it very well.'' (unknown)
''
``I remember it all very well. '' (he)
Better than he (Pip) thought,--except the last clause.

And you remember that we came up with the two in a ditch, and that there was a scuffle between them, and that one of them had been severely handled and much mauled about the face by the other?''

And that the soldiers lighted torches, and put the two in the centre, and that we went on to see the last of them, over the black marshes, with the torchlight shining on their faces,--I am particular about that,--with the torchlight shining on their faces, when there was an outer ring of dark night all about us?''

''

``I see it all before me.'' (I.)
'' '' Yes,'' said I.
``I remember all that.'' (I.)
``Then, Mr. Pip, one of those two prisoners sat behind you tonight.

I saw him (Pip) over your shoulder.'' (unknown)

``Steady!'' (I)
I thought. I asked him (Pip) then,
``Which of the two do you suppose you saw?'' (him)

'' The one who had been mauled,'' he (Pip) answered readily,

``and I'll swear I saw him (Pip)! The more I think of him (Pip), the more certain I am of him (Pip).

This is very curious!'' (he)

said I, with the best assumption I could put on of its being nothing more to me.

I cannot exaggerate the enhanced disquiet into which this conversation threw me, or the special and peculiar terror I felt at Compeyson's having been behind me

``like a ghost.

For if he (Pip) had ever been out of my thoughts for a few moments together since the hiding had begun, it was in those very moments when he (Pip) was closest to me; and to think that I should be so unconscious and off my guard after all my care was as if I had shut an avenue of a hundred doors to keep him (guard) out, and then had found him (guard) at my elbow.

I could not doubt, either, that he (guard) was there, because I was there, and that, however slight an appearance of danger there might be about us, danger was always near and active.

'' (me)

'' '' Very curious indeed! '' '' I put such questions to Mr. Wopsle as, When did the man come in?

It was not until he (man) had seen him (man) for some time that he (man) began to identify him (man); but he (man) had from the first vaguely associated him (man) with me, and known him (man) as somehow belonging to me in the old village time.

He (man) could not tell me that; he (man) saw me, and over my shoulder he (man) saw the man. How was he (man) dressed?

I believed not too, for, although in my brooding state I had taken no especial notice of the people behind me, I thought it likely that a face at all disfigured would have attracted my attention.

When Mr. Wopsle had imparted to me all that he (Wopsle) could recall or I extract, and when I had treated him (Wopsle) to a little appropriate refreshment, after the fatigues of the evening, we parted.

Prosperously, but not noticeably otherwise; he (Wopsle) thought, in black. Was his (Wopsle) face at all disfigured? No, he (Wopsle) believed not. It was between twelve and one o'clock when I reached the Temple, and the gates were shut.

No one was near me when I went in and went home. Herbert had come in, and we held a very serious council by the fire.

But there was nothing to be done, saving to communicate to Wemmick what I had that night found out, and to remind him (Wemmick) that we waited for his (Wemmick) hint.

As I thought that I might compromise him (Wemmick) if I went too often to the Castle, I made this communication by letter.

I wrote it before I went to bed, and went out and posted it; and again no one was near me.

Herbert and I agreed that we could do nothing else but be very cautious. And we were very cautious indeed,--more cautious than before, if that were possible,--and

I for my part never went near Chinks's Basin, except when I rowed by, and then I only looked at Mill Pond Bank as I looked at anything else.

Chapter XLVIII The second of the two meetings referred to in the last chapter occurred about a week after the first.

I had again left my boat at the wharf below Bridge; the time was an hour earlier in the afternoon; and, undecided where to dine, I had strolled up into Cheapside, and was strolling along it, surely the most unsettled person in all the busy concourse, when a large hand was laid upon my shoulder by some one overtaking me.

It was Mr. Jaggers's hand, and he (Jaggers) passed it through my arm. '' As we are going in the same direction, Pip, we may walk together.

Well,'' I returned, glad for once to get the better of him (Jaggers) in cross-examination,

``I do not know, for I have not made up my mind.'' (him)

Where are you bound for?''

``For the Temple, I think,'' (I.)
said I.
``Don't you know?'' (I.)
said Mr. Jaggers. ''
``You are going to dine?'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
said Mr. Jaggers.

'' You don't mind admitting that, I suppose?'' '' No,'' I returned,

``I don't mind admitting that.'' (I)
'' And are not engaged?''

``I don't mind admitting also that I am not engaged.'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
'' Then,'' said Mr. Jaggers,
``come and dine with me. '' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)

I was going to excuse myself, when he (Jaggers) added,

``Wemmick's coming. '' (he)
So I changed my excuse into an acceptance,--the few words I had uttered, serving for the beginning of either,--and

we went along Cheapside and slanted off to Little Britain, while the lights were springing up brilliantly in the shop windows, and the street lamp-lighters, scarcely finding ground enough to plant their ladders on in the midst of the afternoon's bustle, were skipping up and down and running in and out, opening more red eyes in the gathering fog than my rushlight tower at the Hummums had opened white eyes in the ghostly wall.

At the office in Little Britain there was the usual letter-writing, hand-washing, candle-snuffing, and safe-locking , that closed the business of the day.

As I stood idle by Mr. Jaggers's fire, its rising and falling flame made the two casts on the shelf look as if they were playing a diabolical game at bo-peep with me; while the pair of coarse, fat office candles that dimly lighted Mr. Jaggers as he (Jaggers) wrote in a corner were decorated with dirty winding-sheets, as if in remembrance of a host of hanged clients.

We went to Gerrard Street, all three together, in a hackney-coach: And, as soon as we got there, dinner was served.

Although I should not have thought of making, in that place, the most distant reference by so much as a look to Wemmick's Walworth sentiments, yet I should have had no objection to catching his (Wemmick) eye now and then in a friendly way.

He (Wemmick) turned his (Wemmick) eyes on Mr. Jaggers whenever he (Jaggers) raised them from the table, and was as dry and distant to me as if there were twin Wemmicks, and this was the wrong one.

But it was not to be done. '' Did you send that note of Miss Havisham's to Mr. Pip, Wemmick? '' Mr. Jaggers asked, soon after we began dinner.

'' No, sir,'' returned Wemmick;

``it was going by post, when you brought Mr. Pip into the office. Here it is.

It's a note of two lines, Pip,'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

said Mr. Jaggers, handing it on,
``sent up to me by Miss Havisham on account of her (Havisham) not being sure of your address.

'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)

He (Jaggers) handed it to his (Jaggers) principal instead of to me. '' She (Havisham) tells me that she (Havisham) wants to see you on a little matter of business you mentioned to her (Havisham).

You'll go down?'' '' Yes,'' said I, casting my eyes over the note, which was exactly in those terms. '' When do you think of going down?''

``I have an impending engagement,'' (I)
said I, glancing at Wemmick, who was putting fish into the post-office,
``that renders me rather uncertain of my time.

If Mr. Pip has the intention of going at once,'' (I)

said Wemmick to Mr. Jaggers,
``he (Wemmick) needn't write an answer, you know.

Receiving this as an intimation that it was best not to delay, I settled that I would go to-morrow, and said so.

At once, I think. '' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)

'' '' Wemmick drank a glass of wine, and looked with a grimly satisfied air at Mr. Jaggers, but not at me.

'' So, Pip! Our friend the Spider,'' said Mr. Jaggers,

``has played his (Jaggers) cards. He (Jaggers) has won the pool. '' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
It was as much as I could do to assent.

'' Hah! He (Jaggers) is a promising fellow--in his (Jaggers) way--but he (Jaggers) may not have it all his (Jaggers) own way. The stronger will win in the end, but the stronger has to be found out first.

''

``Surely,'' (I)
I interrupted, with a burning face and heart,
``you do not seriously think that he (Jaggers) is scoundrel enough for that, Mr. Jaggers?'' (I)

If he (Jaggers) should turn to and beat her (Jaggers), he (Jaggers) may possibly get the strength on his (Jaggers) side; if it should be a question of intellect, he (Jaggers) certainly will not.

It would be chance work to give an opinion how a fellow of that sort will turn out in such circumstances, because it's a toss-up between two results.''

If he (fellow) should turn to, and beat her (Jaggers)--

``I didn't say so, Pip. I am putting a case. '' (he)
May I ask what they are?''

'' A fellow like our friend the Spider,'' answered Mr. Jaggers,

``either beats or cringes. He (Jaggers) may cringe and growl, or cringe and not growl; but he (Jaggers) either beats or cringes.

So here's to Mrs. Bentley Drummle,'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)

said Mr. Jaggers, taking a decanter of choicer wine from his (Jaggers) dumb-waiter, and filling for each of us and for himself,
``and may the question of supremacy be settled to the lady's satisfaction!

Ask Wemmick his (Wemmick) opinion.'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)

'' Either beats or cringes,'' said Wemmick, not at all addressing himself to me. '' To the satisfaction of the lady and the gentleman, it never will be.

Now, Molly, Molly, Molly, Molly, how slow you are to-day! '' She (Molly) was at his (Wemmick) elbow when he (Wemmick) addressed her (Molly), putting a dish upon the table.

As she (Molly) withdrew her (Molly) hands from it, she (Molly) fell back a step or two, nervously muttering some excuse. And a certain action of her (Molly) fingers, as she (Molly) spoke, arrested my attention.

'' What's the matter?'' said Mr. Jaggers. '' Nothing. Only the subject we were speaking of,'' said I,

``was rather painful to me.

She (Molly) stood looking at her (Molly) master, not understanding whether she (Molly) was free to go, or whether he (master) had more to say to her (Molly) and would call her (Molly) back if she (Molly) did go.

'' (I)

The action of her (Molly) fingers was like the action of knitting. Her (Molly) look was very intent. Surely, I had seen exactly such eyes and such hands on a memorable occasion very lately!

He (master) dismissed her (Molly), and she (Molly) glided out of the room. But she (Molly) remained before me as plainly as if she (Molly) were still there.

I looked at those hands, I looked at those eyes, I looked at that flowing hair; and I compared them with other hands, other eyes, other hair, that I knew of, and with what those might be after twenty years of a brutal husband and a stormy life.

I looked again at those hands and eyes of the housekeeper, and thought of the inexplicable feeling that had come over me when I last walked--not alone--in the ruined garden, and through the deserted brewery.

I thought how the same feeling had come back when I saw a face looking at me, and a hand waving to me from a stage-coach window; and how it had come back again and had flashed about me like lightning, when I had passed in a carriage--not alone--through a sudden glare of light in a dark street.

I thought how one link of association had helped that identification in the theatre, and how such a link, wanting before, had been riveted for me now, when I had passed by a chance swift from Estella's name to the fingers with their knitting action, and the attentive eyes.

Mr. Jaggers had seen me with Estella, and was not likely to have missed the sentiments I had been at no pains to conceal.

He (Jaggers) nodded when I said the subject was painful to me, clapped me on the back, put round the wine again, and went on with his (Jaggers) dinner.

Only twice more did the housekeeper reappear, and then her (housekeeper) stay in the room was very short, and Mr. Jaggers was sharp with her (housekeeper).

But her (housekeeper) hands were Estella's hands, and her (housekeeper) eyes were Estella's eyes, and if she (housekeeper) had reappeared a hundred times I could have been neither more sure nor less sure that my conviction was the truth.

It was a dull evening, for Wemmick drew his (Wemmick) wine, when it came round, quite as a matter of business,--just as he (Wemmick) might have drawn his (Wemmick) salary when that came round,--and with his (Wemmick) eyes on his (Wemmick) chief, sat in a state of perpetual readiness for cross-examination.

As to the quantity of wine, his (Wemmick) post-office was as indifferent and ready as any other post-office for its quantity of letters.

From my point of view, he (Wemmick) was the wrong twin all the time, and only externally like the Wemmick of Walworth.

Even when we were groping among Mr. Jaggers's stock of boots for our hats, I felt that the right twin was on his (Jaggers) way back; and we had not gone half a dozen yards down Gerrard Street in the Walworth direction, before I found that I was walking arm in arm with the right twin, and that the wrong twin had evaporated into the evening air.

And I felt absolutely certain that this woman was Estella's mother. We took our leave early, and left together. '' Well!'' said Wemmick,

``that's over!

He (Wemmick)'s a wonderful man, without his (Wemmick) living likeness; but I feel that I have to screw myself up when I dine with

him (Wemmick),--and I dine more comfortably unscrewed. '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

I felt that this was a good statement of the case, and told him (Wemmick) so.

'' Wouldn't say it to anybody but yourself,'' he (Wemmick) answered. '' I know that what is said between you and me goes no further.

'' I asked him (Wemmick) if he (Wemmick) had ever seen Miss Havisham's adopted daughter, Mrs. Bentley Drummle. He (Wemmick) said no. To avoid being too abrupt, I then spoke of the Aged and of Miss Skiffins.

He (Wemmick) looked rather sly when I mentioned Miss Skiffins, and stopped in the street to blow his (Wemmick) nose, with a roll of the head, and a flourish not quite free from latent boastfulness.

Wemmick,'' said I,

``do you remember telling me, before I first went to Mr. Jaggers's private house, to notice that housekeeper?'' (I)

''

``Did I?'' (he)
he (Jaggers) replied. '' Ah, I dare say I did. Deuce take me,'' he (Jaggers) added, suddenly,
``I know I did.

I find I am not quite unscrewed yet. '' (he)

'' A wild beast tamed, you called her (housekeeper).'' '' And what do you call her (housekeeper)?''

'' The same. How did Mr. Jaggers tame her (housekeeper), Wemmick?'' '' That's his (Wemmick) secret. She (housekeeper) has been with him (Wemmick) many a long year.

''

``I wish you would tell me her (housekeeper) story. I feel a particular interest in being acquainted with it. You know that what is said between you and me goes no further.'' (unknown)

``Well!'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
Wemmick replied,
``I don't know her (housekeeper) story,--that is, I don't know all of it. But what I do know I'll tell you.

We are in our private and personal capacities, of course. '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

``Of course. '' (woman)
'' A score or so of years ago, that woman was tried at the Old Bailey for murder, and was acquitted.

She (woman) was a very handsome young woman, and I believe had some gypsy blood in her (woman). Anyhow, it was hot enough when it was up, as you may suppose.''

Mr. Jaggers was for her (woman),'' pursued Wemmick, with a look full of meaning,

``and worked the case in a way quite astonishing.

It was a desperate case, and it was comparatively early days with him (Wemmick) then, and he (Wemmick) worked it to general admiration; in fact, it may almost be said to have made him (Wemmick).

He (Wemmick) worked it himself at the police-office, day after day for many days, contending against even a committal; and at the trial where he (Wemmick) couldn't work it himself, sat under counsel, and--every one knew--put in all the salt and pepper.

'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

But she (it) was acquitted.'' '' The murdered person was a woman,--a woman a good ten years older, very much larger, and very much stronger.

They both led tramping lives, and this woman in Gerrard Street here had been married very young, over the broomstick -LRB-as we say-RRB-, to a tramping man, and was a perfect fury in point of jealousy.

The murdered woman,--more a match for the man, certainly, in point of years--was found dead in a barn near Hounslow Heath.

It was a case of jealousy. There had been a violent struggle, perhaps a fight. She (woman) was bruised and scratched and torn, and had been held by the throat, at last, and choked.

Now, there was no reasonable evidence to implicate any person but this woman, and on the improbabilities of her (woman) having been able to do it Mr. Jaggers principally rested his (Jaggers) case.

You may be sure,'' said Wemmick, touching me on the sleeve,

``that he (Wemmick) never dwelt upon the strength of her (woman) hands then, though he (Wemmick) sometimes does now.

'' (me)

I had told Wemmick of his (Wemmick) showing us her (woman) wrists, that day of the dinner party. '' Well, sir!'' Wemmick went on; ``it happened--happened, don't you see?--that

this woman was so very artfully dressed from the time of her (woman) apprehension, that she (woman) looked much slighter than she (woman) really was; in particular, her (woman) sleeves are always remembered to have been so skilfully contrived that her (woman) arms had quite a delicate look.

She (woman) had only a bruise or two about her (woman),--nothing for a tramp,--but the backs of her (woman) hands were lacerated, and the question was,

Now, Mr. Jaggers showed that she (woman) had struggled through a great lot of brambles which were not as high as her (woman) face; but which she (woman) could not have got through and kept her (woman) hands out of; and bits of those brambles were actually found in her (woman) skin and put in evidence, as well as the fact that the brambles in question were found on examination to have been broken through, and to have little shreds of her (woman) dress and little spots of blood upon them here and there.

But the boldest point he (Jaggers) made was this: it was attempted to be set up, in proof of her (woman) jealousy, that she (woman) was under strong suspicion of having, at about the time of the murder, frantically destroyed her (woman) child by this man--some three years old--to revenge herself upon him (man).

Mr. Jaggers worked that in this way:

``We say these are not marks of finger-nails, but marks of brambles, and we show you the brambles.

Was it with finger-nails? You say they are marks of finger-nails, and you set up the hypothesis that she (woman) destroyed her (woman) child.

For anything we know, she (woman) may have destroyed her (woman) child, and the child in clinging to her (woman) may have scratched her (woman) hands.

You must accept all consequences of that hypothesis. What then? You are not trying her (woman) for the murder of her (woman) child; why don't you?

As to this case, if you will have scratches, we say that, for anything we know, you may have accounted for them, assuming for the sake of argument that you have not invented them?'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)

``To sum up, sir,'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
said Wemmick,
``Mr. Jaggers was altogether too many for the jury, and they gave in.'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
``Has she (woman) been in his (Jaggers) service ever since?'' (unknown)

Yes; but not only that,'' said Wemmick,

``she (woman) went into his (Wemmick) service immediately after her (woman) acquittal, tamed as she (woman) is now.

She (woman) has since been taught one thing and another in the way of her (woman) duties, but she (woman) was tamed from the beginning.'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

''

``Do you remember the sex of the child?'' (unknown)
``Said to have been a girl.'' (unknown)
``You have nothing more to say to me to-night?

We exchanged a cordial good-night, and I went home, with new matter for my thoughts, though with no relief from the old.

Putting Miss Havisham's note in my pocket, that it might serve as my credentials for so soon reappearing at Satis House, in case her (Havisham) waywardness should lead her (Havisham) to express any surprise at seeing me, I went down again by the coach next day.

But I alighted at the Halfway House, and breakfasted there, and walked the rest of the distance; for I sought to get into the town quietly by the unfrequented ways, and to leave it in the same manner.

'' (unknown)

'' Nothing. I got your letter and destroyed it. Nothing. '' Chapter XLIX The best light of the day was gone when I passed along the quiet echoing courts behind the High Street.
