The nooks of ruin where the old monks had once had their refectories and gardens, and where the strong walls were now pressed into the service of humble sheds and stables, were almost as silent as the old monks in their graves.

The cathedral chimes had at once a sadder and a more remote sound to me, as I hurried on avoiding observation, than they had ever had before; so, the swell of the old organ was borne to my ears like funeral music; and the rooks, as they hovered about the gray tower and swung in the bare high trees of the priory garden, seemed to call to me that the place was changed, and that Estella was gone out of it for ever.

An elderly woman, whom I had seen before as one of the servants who lived in the supplementary house across the back courtyard, opened the gate.

The lighted candle stood in the dark passage within, as of old, and I took it up and ascended the staircase alone.

Looking in at the door, after knocking in vain, I saw her (woman) sitting on the hearth in a ragged chair, close before, and lost in the contemplation of, the ashy fire.

Doing as I had often done, I went in, and stood touching the old chimney-piece, where she (woman) could see me when she (woman) raised her (woman) eyes.

There was an air of utter loneliness upon her (woman), that would have moved me to pity though she (woman) had wilfully done me a deeper injury than I could charge her (woman) with.

As I stood compassionating her (woman), and thinking how, in the progress of time, I too had come to be a part of the wrecked fortunes of that house, her (woman) eyes rested on me.

Miss Havisham was not in her (Havisham) own room, but was in the larger room across the landing. She (Havisham) stared, and said in a low voice,

``Is it real?'' (She)

``It is I, Pip. Mr. Jaggers gave me your note yesterday, and I have lost no time.'' (unknown)
``Thank you. Thank you.

As I brought another of the ragged chairs to the hearth and sat down, I remarked a new expression on her (Havisham) face, as if she (Havisham) were afraid of me.

I want,'' (she)

she (Havisham) said,
``to pursue that subject you mentioned to me when you were last here, and to show you that I am not all stone.

'' (she)

When I said some reassuring words, she (Havisham) stretched out her (Havisham) tremulous right hand, as though she (Havisham) was going to touch me; but she (Havisham) recalled it again before I understood the action, or knew how to receive it.

'' '' But perhaps you can never believe, now, that there is anything human in my heart? '' You said, speaking for your friend, that you could tell me how to do something useful and good.

Something that you would like done, is it not?'' '' Something that I would like done very much. '' '' What is it?

I had not got far into it, when I judged from her (Havisham) looks that she (Havisham) was thinking in a discursive way of me, rather than of what I said.

It seemed to be so; for, when I stopped speaking, many moments passed before she (Havisham) showed that she (Havisham) was conscious of the fact.

Do you break off,'' she (Havisham) asked then, with her (Havisham) former air of being afraid of me,

``because you hate me too much to bear to speak to me?'' (me)

'' I began explaining to her (Havisham) that secret history of the partnership. '' '' No, no,'' I answered,

``how can you think so, Miss Havisham!

I stopped because I thought you were not following what I said. '' (I)

``Perhaps I was not,'' (she)
she (Havisham) answered, putting a hand to her (Havisham) head.

She (Havisham) set her (Havisham) hand upon her (Havisham) stick in the resolute way that sometimes was habitual to her (Havisham), and looked at the fire with a strong expression of forcing herself to attend.

I went on with my explanation, and told her (Havisham) how I had hoped to complete the transaction out of my means, but how in this I was disappointed.

That part of the subject -LRB-I reminded her (Havisham)-RRB- involved matters which could form no part of my explanation, for they were the weighty secrets of another.

``Begin again, and let me look at something else. Stay! Now tell me. '' (unknown)
'' So!'' said she (Havisham), assenting with her (Havisham) head, but not looking at me.

'' And how much money is wanting to complete the purchase? '' I was rather afraid of stating it, for it sounded a large sum.

'' Nine hundred pounds. '' '' If I give you the money for this purpose, will you keep my secret as you have kept your own?''

'' Quite as faithfully.'' '' And your mind will be more at rest? ''

``Much more at rest. '' (unknown)
``Are you very unhappy now?'' (She)

She (Havisham) asked this question, still without looking at me, but in an unwonted tone of sympathy. I could not reply at the moment, for my voice failed me.

She (Havisham) put her (Havisham) left arm across the head of her (Havisham) stick, and softly laid her (Havisham) forehead on it. '' I am far from happy, Miss Havisham; but I have other causes of disquiet than any you know of.

They are the secrets I have mentioned. '' After a little while, she (Havisham) raised her (Havisham) head, and looked at the fire again.

'' It is noble in you to tell me that you have other causes of unhappiness. Is it true?''

``Too true.

'' (unknown)

``Can I only serve you, Pip, by serving your friend? Regarding that as done, is there nothing I can do for you yourself?

'' (unknown)

``Nothing. I thank you for the question. I thank you even more for the tone of the question. But there is nothing.

There were none there, and she (Havisham) took from her (Havisham) pocket a yellow set of ivory tablets, mounted in tarnished gold, and wrote upon them with a pencil in a case of tarnished gold that hung from her (Havisham) neck.

'' (She)

She (Havisham) presently rose from her (Havisham) seat, and looked about the blighted room for the means of writing. '' You are still on friendly terms with Mr. Jaggers?

This is an authority to him (Jaggers) to pay you that money, to lay out at your irresponsible discretion for your friend.

I keep no money here; but if you would rather Mr. Jaggers knew nothing of the matter, I will send it to you.''

''

``Quite. I dined with him (Jaggers) yesterday.'' (unknown)
'' ``Thank you, Miss Havisham; I have not the least objection to receiving it from him (Jaggers).

She (your) read me what she (your) had written; and it was direct and clear, and evidently intended to absolve me from any suspicion of profiting by the receipt of the money.

I took the tablets from her (your) hand, and it trembled again, and it trembled more as she (your) took off the chain to which the pencil was attached, and put it in mine.

If you can ever write under my name,

``I forgive her (your),'' (unknown)
though ever so long after my broken heart is dust pray do it!''

'' All this she (your) did without looking at me. '' My name is on the first leaf.

``O Miss Havisham,'' (I)
said I,
``I can do it now.

There have been sore mistakes; and my life has been a blind and thankless one; and I want forgiveness and direction far too much, to be bitter with you.

She (your) turned her (your) face to me for the first time since she (your) had averted it, and, to my amazement, I may even add to my terror, dropped on her (your) knees at my feet; with her (your) folded hands raised to me in the manner in which, when her (your) poor heart was young and fresh and whole, they must often have been raised to heaven from her (your) mother's side.

To see her (your) with her (your) white hair and her (your) worn face kneeling at my feet gave me a shock through all my frame.

I entreated her (your) to rise, and got my arms about her (your) to help her (your) up; but she (your) only pressed that hand of mine which was nearest to her (your) grasp, and hung her (your) head over it and wept.

I had never seen her (your) shed a tear before, and, in the hope that the relief might do her (your) good, I bent over her (your) without speaking.

'' (I)

She (your) was not kneeling now, but was down upon the ground.
``O! '' (she)
she (your) cried, despairingly. '' What have I done!

What have I done!'' '' If you mean, Miss Havisham, what have you done to injure me, let me answer. Very little.

I should have loved her (Havisham) under any circumstances. Is she (Havisham) married?''

``Yes. '' (me)
It was a needless question, for a new desolation in the desolate house had told me so.

'' What have I done! What have I done! '' She (Havisham) wrung her (Havisham) hands, and crushed her (Havisham) white hair, and returned to this cry over and over again.

That she (Havisham) had done a grievous thing in taking an impressionable child to mould into the form that her (Havisham) wild resentment, spurned affection, and wounded pride found vengeance in, I knew full well.

But that, in shutting out the light of day, she (Havisham) had shut out infinitely more; that, in seclusion, she (Havisham) had secluded herself from a thousand natural and healing influences; that, her (Havisham) mind, brooding solitary, had grown diseased, as all minds do and must and will that reverse the appointed order of their Maker, I knew equally well.

And could I look upon her (Havisham) without compassion, seeing her (Havisham) punishment in the ruin she (Havisham) was, in her (Havisham) profound unfitness for this earth on which she (Havisham) was placed, in the vanity of sorrow which had become a master mania, like the vanity of penitence, the vanity of remorse, the vanity of unworthiness, and other monstrous vanities that have been curses in this world?

Until you spoke to her (Havisham) the other day, and until I saw in you a looking-glass that showed me what I once felt myself, I did not know what I had done.

'' What have I done! '' I knew not how to answer, or how to comfort her (Havisham). '' What have I done!

What have I done! '' And so again, twenty, fifty times over, What had she (Havisham) done! '' Miss Havisham,'' I said, when her (Havisham) cry had died away,

``you may dismiss me from your mind and conscience.

But Estella is a different case, and if you can ever undo any scrap of what you have done amiss in keeping a part of her (Estella) right nature away from her (Estella), it will be better to do that than to bemoan the past through a hundred years.

'' (I)

``Yes, yes, I know it. But, Pip--my dear! '' (me)
There was an earnest womanly compassion for me in her (Estella) new affection.

'' My dear! Believe this: when she (Estella) first came to me, I meant to save her (Estella) from misery like my own.

But as she (Estella) grew, and promised to be very beautiful, I gradually did worse, and with my praises, and with my jewels, and with my teachings, and with this figure of myself always before her (Estella), a warning to back and point my lessons, I stole her (Estella) heart away, and put ice in its place.''

At first, I meant no more.'' '' Well, well!'' said I.

``I hope so.'' (I.)
''
``Better,'' (I)
I could not help saying,
``to have left her (Estella) a natural heart, even to be bruised or broken.

'' (I)

With that, Miss Havisham looked distractedly at me for a while, and then burst out again, What had she (Estella) done!

If you knew all my story,'' she (Estella) pleaded,

``you would have some compassion for me and a better understanding of me.'' (she)

``Miss Havisham,'' (I)
I answered, as delicately as I could,
``I believe I may say that I do know your story, and have known it ever since I first left this neighborhood.

'' (I)

It has inspired me with great commiseration, and I hope I understand it and its influences. Does what has passed between us give me any excuse for asking you a question relative to Estella?

Not as she (Estella) is, but as she (Estella) was when she (Estella) first came here? '' She (Estella) was seated on the ground, with her (Estella) arms on the ragged chair, and her (Estella) head leaning on them.

She (Estella) looked full at me when I said this, and replied,

``Go on.'' (I)
``Whose child was Estella? '' (She)
She (Estella) shook her (Estella) head.

'' You don't know? '' She (Estella) shook her (Estella) head again. '' But Mr. Jaggers brought her (Estella) here, or sent her (Estella) here?''

She (Estella) answered in a low whisper and with caution: ``I had been shut up in these rooms a long time -LRB-I don't know how long

; you know what time the clocks keep here-RRB-, when I told him (Jaggers) that I wanted a little girl to rear and love, and save from my fate.

I had first seen him (Jaggers) when I sent for him (Jaggers) to lay this place waste for me; having read of him (Jaggers) in the newspapers, before I and the world parted.

``Brought her (girl) here.'' (unknown)
``Will you tell me how that came about?'' (He)
He (Jaggers) told me that he (Jaggers) would look about him (Jaggers) for such an orphan child.

One night he (Jaggers) brought her (girl) here asleep, and I called her (girl) Estella. ''

``Might I ask her (Estella) age then?'' (unknown)
``Two or three.

So convinced I was of that woman's being her (woman) mother, that I wanted no evidence to establish the fact in my own mind.

She (woman) herself knows nothing, but that she (woman) was left an orphan and I adopted her (woman). '' (I)

But, to any mind, I thought, the connection here was clear and straight.

What more could I hope to do by prolonging the interview? I had succeeded on behalf of Herbert, Miss Havisham had told me all she (woman) knew of Estella, I had said and done what I could to ease her (Estella) mind.

No matter with what other words we parted; we parted. Twilight was closing in when I went downstairs into the natural air.

I called to the woman who had opened the gate when I entered, that I would not trouble her (woman) just yet, but would walk round the place before leaving.

For I had a presentiment that I should never be there again, and I felt that the dying light was suited to my last view of it.

By the wilderness of casks that I had walked on long ago, and on which the rain of years had fallen since, rotting them in many places, and leaving miniature swamps and pools of water upon those that stood on end, I made my way to the ruined garden.

I went all round it; round by the corner where Herbert and I had fought our battle; round by the paths where Estella and I had walked.

Taking the brewery on my way back, I raised the rusty latch of a little door at the garden end of it, and walked through.

I was going out at the opposite door,--not easy to open now, for the damp wood had started and swelled, and the hinges were yielding, and the threshold was encumbered with a growth of fungus,--when

A childish association revived with wonderful force in the moment of the slight action, and I fancied that I saw Miss Havisham hanging to the beam.

So strong was the impression, that I stood under the beam shuddering from head to foot before I knew it was a fancy,--though to be sure I was there in an instant.

The mournfulness of the place and time, and the great terror of this illusion, though it was but momentary, caused me to feel an indescribable awe as I came out between the open wooden gates where I had once wrung my hair after Estella had wrung my heart.

Passing on into the front courtyard, I hesitated whether to call the woman to let me out at the locked gate of which she (woman) had the key, or first to go upstairs and assure myself that Miss Havisham was as safe and well as I had left her (Havisham).

So cold, so lonely, so dreary all! I turned my head to look back. I took the latter course and went up.

I looked into the room where I had left her (Havisham), and I saw her (Havisham) seated in the ragged chair upon the hearth close to the fire, with her (Havisham) back towards me.

In the moment when I was withdrawing my head to go quietly away, I saw a great flaming light spring up.

In the same moment I saw her (Havisham) running at me, shrieking, with a whirl of fire blazing all about her (Havisham), and soaring at least as many feet above her (Havisham) head as she (Havisham) was high.

I had a double-caped great-coat on, and over my arm another thick coat. That I got them off, closed with her (Havisham), threw her (Havisham) down, and got them over her (Havisham)

; that I dragged the great cloth from the table for the same purpose, and with it dragged down the heap of rottenness in the midst, and all the ugly things that sheltered there; that we were on the ground struggling like desperate enemies, and that the closer I covered her (Havisham), the more wildly she (Havisham) shrieked and tried to free herself,--that

I knew nothing until I knew that we were on the floor by the great table, and that patches of tinder yet alight were floating in the smoky air, which, a moment ago, had been her (Havisham) faded bridal dress.

Then, I looked round and saw the disturbed beetles and spiders running away over the floor, and the servants coming in with breathless cries at the door.

I still held her (Havisham) forcibly down with all my strength, like a prisoner who might escape; and I doubt if I even knew who she (Havisham) was, or why we had struggled, or that she (Havisham) had been in flames, or that the flames were out, until I saw the patches of tinder that had been her (Havisham) garments no longer alight but falling in a black shower around us.

this occurred I knew through the result, but not through anything I felt, or thought, or knew I did. She (Havisham) was insensible, and I was afraid to have her (Havisham) moved, or even touched.

Assistance was sent for, and I held her (Havisham) until it came, as if I unreasonably fancied -LRB-I think I did-RRB- that, if I let her (Havisham) go, the fire would break out again and consume her (Havisham).

When I got up, on the surgeon's coming to her (Havisham) with other aid, I was astonished to see that both my hands were burnt; for, I had no knowledge of it through the sense of feeling.

On examination it was pronounced that she (Havisham) had received serious hurts, but that they of themselves were far from hopeless; the danger lay mainly in the nervous shock.

By the surgeon's directions, her (Havisham) bed was carried into that room and laid upon the great table, which happened to be well suited to the dressing of her (Havisham) injuries.

When I saw her (Havisham) again, an hour afterwards, she (Havisham) lay, indeed, where I had seen her (Havisham) strike her (Havisham) stick, and had heard her (Havisham) say that she (Havisham) would lie one day.

Though every vestige of her (Havisham) dress was burnt, as they told me, she (Havisham) still had something of her (Havisham) old ghastly bridal appearance; for, they had covered her (Havisham) to the throat with white cotton-wool, and as she (Havisham) lay with a white sheet loosely overlying that, the phantom air of something that had been and was changed was still upon her (Havisham).

I found, on questioning the servants, that Estella was in Paris, and I got a promise from the surgeon that he (surgeon) would write to her (Estella) by the next post.

I took upon myself; intending to communicate with Mr. Matthew Pocket only, and leave him (Pocket) to do as he (Pocket) liked about informing the rest.

Miss Havisham's family This I did next day, through Herbert, as soon as I returned to town. There was a stage, that evening, when she (Havisham) spoke collectedly of what had happened, though with a certain terrible vivacity.

Towards midnight she (Havisham) began to wander in her (Havisham) speech; and after that it gradually set in that she (Havisham) said innumerable times in a low solemn voice,

``What have I done! '' (she)
And then,
``When she (Havisham) first came, I meant to save her (Havisham) from misery like mine. '' (She)

She (Havisham) never changed the order of these three sentences, but she (Havisham) sometimes left out a word in one or other of them; never putting in another word, but always leaving a blank and going on to the next word.

As I could do no service there, and as I had, nearer home, that pressing reason for anxiety and fear which even her (Havisham) wanderings could not drive out of my mind, I decided, in the course of the night that I would return by the early morning coach, walking on a mile or so, and being taken up clear of the town.

At about six o'clock of the morning, therefore, I leaned over her (Havisham) and touched her (Havisham) lips with mine, just as they said, not stopping for being touched, ``Take the pencil and write under my name, 'I forgive her (Havisham).'

And then,

``Take the pencil and write under my name, 'I forgive her (Havisham)!' '' (unknown)
'' Chapter L My hands had been dressed twice or thrice in the night, and again in the morning.

My left arm was a good deal burned to the elbow, and, less severely, as high as the shoulder; it was very painful, but the flames had set in that direction, and I felt thankful it was no worse.

It was bandaged, of course, but much less inconveniently than my left hand and arm; those I carried in a sling; and I could only wear my coat like a cloak, loose over my shoulders and fastened at the neck.

My right hand was not so badly burnt but that I could move the fingers. My hair had been caught by the fire, but not my head or face.

When Herbert had been down to Hammersmith and seen his (Herbert) father, he (Herbert) came back to me at our chambers, and devoted the day to attending on me.

He (Herbert) was the kindest of nurses, and at stated times took off the bandages, and steeped them in the cooling liquid that was kept ready, and put them on again, with a patient tenderness that I was deeply grateful for.

At first, as I lay quiet on the sofa, I found it painfully difficult, I might say impossible, to get rid of the impression of the glare of the flames, their hurry and noise, and the fierce burning smell.

If I dozed for a minute, I was awakened by Miss Havisham's cries, and by her (Havisham) running at me with all that height of fire above her (Havisham) head.

This pain of the mind was much harder to strive against than any bodily pain I suffered; and Herbert, seeing that, did his (Herbert) utmost to hold my attention engaged.

That was made apparent by our avoidance of the subject, and by our agreeing--without agreement--to make my recovery of the use of my hands a question of so many hours, not of so many weeks.

Neither of us spoke of the boat, but we both thought of it. My first question when I saw Herbert had been of course, whether all was well down the river?

As he (Herbert) replied in the affirmative, with perfect confidence and cheerfulness, we did not resume the subject until the day was wearing away.

But then, as Herbert changed the bandages, more by the light of the fire than by the outer light, he (Herbert) went back to it spontaneously.

'' I sat with Provis last night, Handel, two good hours. ''

``Where was Clara?'' (unknown)
'' Dear little thing!'' said Herbert.

'' She (Clara) was up and down with Gruffandgrim all the evening. He (Herbert) was perpetually pegging at the floor the moment she (Clara) left his (Herbert) sight.

I doubt if he (Herbert) can hold out long, though. What with rum and pepper,--and pepper and rum,--I should think his (Herbert) pegging must be nearly over.''

``How can I take care of the dear child otherwise?--Lay your arm out upon the back of the sofa, my dear boy, and I'll sit down here, and get the bandage off so gradually that you shall not know when it comes.

'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

And then you will be married, Herbert?'' I was speaking of Provis. Do you know, Handel, he (Handel) improves?''
``I said to you

I thought he (Handel) was softened when I last saw him (Handel). '' (unknown)

``So you did. And so he (Handel) is. He (Handel) was very communicative last night, and told me more of his (Handel) life.

You remember his (Handel) breaking off here about some woman that he (Handel) had had great trouble with.--Did I hurt you? '' (I)

I had started, but not under his (Handel) touch.

His (Handel) words had given me a start. '' I had forgotten that, Herbert, but I remember it now you speak of it.

''

``Well! He (Herbert) went into that part of his (Herbert) life, and a dark wild part it is. Shall I tell you?

Herbert bent forward to look at me more nearly, as if my reply had been rather more hurried or more eager than he (Herbert) could quite account for.

Or would it worry you just now?'' (unknown)

``Tell me by all means. Every word. '' (unknown)
'' Your head is cool? '' he (Herbert) said, touching it.

``It seems,'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
said Herbert, ''--there's a bandage off most charmingly, and now comes the cool one,--makes you shrink at first, my poor dear fellow, don't it?

seems that the woman was a young woman, and a jealous woman, and a revengeful woman; revengeful, Handel, to the last degree.

'' Quite,'' said I.

To what last degree?''

``Murder.--Does it strike too cold on that sensitive place?'' (I)
``I don't feel it. How did she (woman) murder?

``Why, the deed may not have merited quite so terrible a name,'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
said Herbert,
``but, she (woman) was tried for it, and Mr. Jaggers defended her (woman), and the reputation of that defence first made his (Herbert) name known to Provis.

Whom did she (woman) murder?'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

It was another and a stronger woman who was the victim, and there had been a struggle--in a barn.

Who began it, or how fair it was, or how unfair, may be doubtful; but how it ended is certainly not doubtful, for the victim was found throttled.''

``Was the woman brought in guilty?'' (unknown)
'' No; she (woman) was acquitted.--My poor Handel, I hurt you!''
``It is impossible to be gentler, Herbert.

Yes? What else?'' (This woman Provis)

'' This acquitted young woman and Provis had a little child; a little child of whom Provis was exceedingly fond.

On the evening of the very night when the object of her (woman) jealousy was strangled as I tell you, the young woman presented herself before Provis for one moment, and swore that she (woman) would destroy the child -LRB-which was in her (woman) possession-RRB-, and he (Provis) should never see it again; then she (woman) vanished.--There's the worst arm comfortably in the sling once more, and now there remains but

'' There comes the darkest part of Provis's life. She (woman) did.'' '' That is, he (Provis) says she (woman) did. '' '' He (Provis) says it all.

``Now, whether,'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
pursued Herbert,
``he (Herbert) had used the child's mother ill, or whether he (Herbert) had used the child's mother well, Provis doesn't say; but she (mother) had shared some four or five years of the wretched life he (Provis) described to us at this fireside, and he (Provis) seems to have felt pity for her (mother), and forbearance towards her (mother).

Therefore, fearing he (Provis) should be called upon to depose about this destroyed child, and so be the cause of her (mother) death, he (Provis) hid himself -LRB-much as he (Provis) grieved for the child-RRB-, kept himself dark, as he (Provis) says, out of the way and out of the trial, and was only vaguely talked of as a certain man called Abel, out of whom the jealousy arose.

I have no other information. '' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

'' No, to be sure. '' After the acquittal she (mother) disappeared, and thus he (Abel) lost the child and the child's mother.

That evil genius, Compeyson, the worst of scoundrels among many scoundrels, knowing of his (Abel) keeping out of the way at that time and of his (Abel) reasons for doing so, of course afterwards held the knowledge over his (Abel) head as a means of keeping him (Abel) poorer and working him (Abel) harder.

''

``I want to ask-- '' (boy)
'' A moment, my dear boy, and I have done. It was clear last night that this barbed the point of Provis's animosity.''

His (Herbert) expression was, 'a round score o' year ago, and a`most directly after I took up wi' Compeyson.' How old were you when you came upon him (Herbert) in the little churchyard?'' (he)

It had happened some three or four years then, he (Herbert) said, and you brought into his (Herbert) mind the little girl so tragically lost, who would have been about your age.''

'' You are rather excited, but you are quite yourself.''

``I know I am quite myself. And the man we have in hiding down the river, is Estella's Father.

'' (I)

Chapter LI What purpose I had in view when I was hot on tracing out and proving Estella's parentage, I cannot say.

It will presently be seen that the question was not before me in a distinct shape until it was put before me by a wiser head than my own.

But when Herbert and I had held our momentous conversation, I was seized with a feverish conviction that I ought to hunt the matter

I ought not to let it rest, but that I ought to see Mr. Jaggers, and come at the bare truth.

I really do not know whether I felt that I did this for Estella's sake, or whether I was glad to transfer to the man in whose preservation I was so much concerned some rays of the romantic interest that had so long surrounded me.

down,--that Perhaps the latter possibility may be the nearer to the truth. Any way, I could scarcely be withheld from going out to Gerrard Street that night.

Herbert's representations that, if I did, I should probably be laid up and stricken useless, when our fugitive's safety would depend upon me, alone restrained my impatience.

On the understanding, again and again reiterated, that, come what would, I was to go to Mr. Jaggers to-morrow , I at length submitted to keep quiet, and to have my hurts looked after, and to stay at home.

Early next morning we went out together, and at the corner of Giltspur Street by Smithfield, I left Herbert to go his (Herbert) way into the City, and took my way to Little Britain.

There were periodical occasions when Mr. Jaggers and Wemmick went over the office accounts, and checked off the vouchers, and put all things straight.

On these occasions, Wemmick took his (Wemmick) books and papers into Mr. Jaggers's room, and one of the upstairs clerks came down into the outer office.

Finding such clerk on Wemmick's post that morning, I knew what was going on; but I was not sorry to have Mr. Jaggers and Wemmick together, as Wemmick would then hear for himself that I said nothing to compromise him (Wemmick).

Although I had sent Mr. Jaggers a brief account of the accident as soon as I had arrived in town, yet I had to give him (Jaggers) all the details now; and the speciality of the occasion caused our talk to be less dry and hard, and less strictly regulated by the rules of evidence, than it had been before.

My appearance, with my arm bandaged and my coat loose over my shoulders, favored my object. While I described the disaster, Mr. Jaggers stood, according to his (Jaggers) wont, before the fire.

Wemmick leaned back in his (Wemmick) chair, staring at me, with his (Wemmick) hands in the pockets of his (Wemmick) trousers, and his (Wemmick) pen put horizontally into the post.

The two brutal casts, always inseparable in my mind from the official proceedings, seemed to be congestively considering whether they didn't smell fire at the present moment.

My narrative finished, and their questions exhausted, I then produced Miss Havisham's authority to receive the nine hundred pounds for Herbert.

Mr. Jaggers's eyes retired a little deeper into his (Jaggers) head when I handed him (Jaggers) the tablets, but he (Jaggers) presently handed them over to Wemmick, with instructions to draw the check for his (Jaggers) signature.

While that was in course of being done, I looked on at Wemmick as he (Jaggers) wrote, and Mr. Jaggers, poising and swaying himself on his (Jaggers) well-polished boots, looked on at me.

I am sorry, Pip,'' said he (Jaggers), as I put the check in my pocket, when he (Jaggers) had signed it,

``that we do nothing for you.'' (he)

``Miss Havisham was good enough to ask me,'' (I)
I returned,
``whether she (Havisham) could do nothing for me, and I told her (Havisham) No.

'' (I)

''
``Everybody should know his (Jaggers) own business,'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
said Mr. Jaggers. And I saw Wemmick's lips form the words ``portable property.

``I should not have told her (Havisham) No, if I had been you,'' (Mr Jaggers/Jaggers)

As I thought the time was now come for pursuing the theme I had at heart, I said, turning on Mr. Jaggers:--

'' (Mr Jaggers/Jaggers)

'' '' Every man's business,'' said Wemmick, rather reproachfully towards me,

'' I did ask something of Miss Havisham, however, sir.

I asked her (Havisham) to give me some information relative to her (Havisham) adopted daughter, and she (Havisham) gave me all she (Havisham) possessed.''

``Did she (Havisham)?'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
said Mr. Jaggers, bending forward to look at his (Jaggers) boots and then straightening himself.

``I know more of the history of Miss Havisham's adopted child than Miss Havisham herself does, sir. I know her (Havisham) mother.

'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)

Mr. Jaggers looked at me inquiringly, and repeated

said Mr. Jaggers.

'' And so have you, sir. And you have seen her (Mother) still more recently. ''

``Yes?'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
said Mr. Jaggers. '' Perhaps I know more of Estella's history than even you do,'' said I.

A certain stop that Mr. Jaggers came to in his (Jaggers) manner--he (Jaggers) was too self-possessed to change his (Jaggers) manner, but he (Jaggers) could not help its being brought to an indefinably attentive stop--assured me that he (Jaggers) did not know who her (Estella) father was.

This I had strongly suspected from Provis's account -LRB-as Herbert had repeated it-RRB- of his (Herbert) having kept himself dark; which I pieced on to the fact that he (Herbert) himself was not Mr. Jaggers's client until some four years later, and when he (Jaggers) could have no reason for claiming his (Jaggers) identity.

But, I could not be sure of this unconsciousness on Mr. Jaggers's part before, though I was quite sure of it now.

``I know her (Estella) father too. '' (unknown)
'' So! You know the young lady's father, Pip?'' said Mr. Jaggers. '' Yes,'' I replied,
``and his (Jaggers) name is Provis--from New South Wales.

It was the slightest start that could escape a man, the most carefully repressed and the sooner checked, but he (man) did start, though he (man) made it a part of the action of taking out his (man) pocket-handkerchief.

How Wemmick received the announcement I am unable to say; for I was afraid to look at him (Wemmick) just then, lest Mr. Jaggers's sharpness should detect that there had been some communication unknown to him (Jaggers) between us.

And on what evidence, Pip,'' (I)

asked Mr. Jaggers, very coolly, as he (Jaggers) paused with his (Jaggers) handkerchief half way to his (Jaggers) nose,
``does Provis make this claim?'' (he)

He (Provis) does not make it,'' said I,

``and has never made it, and has no knowledge or belief that his (Provis) daughter is in existence.

My reply was so unexpected, that Mr. Jaggers put the handkerchief back into his (Jaggers) pocket without completing the usual performance, folded his (Jaggers) arms, and looked with stern attention at me, though with an immovable face.

Then I told him (Jaggers) all I knew, and how I knew it; with the one reservation that I left him (Jaggers) to infer that I knew from Miss Havisham what I in fact knew from Wemmick.

'' (I)

Even Mr. Jaggers started when I said those words. '' '' '' For once, the powerful pocket-handkerchief failed. I was very careful indeed as to that.

Nor did I look towards Wemmick until I had finished all I had to tell, and had been for some time silently meeting Mr. Jaggers's look.

When I did at last turn my eyes in Wemmick's direction, I found that he (Jaggers) had unposted his (Jaggers) pen, and was intent upon the table before him (Jaggers).

'' Hah!'' said Mr. Jaggers at last, as he (Jaggers) moved towards the papers on the table. '' What item was it you were at,

But I could not submit to be thrown off in that way, and I made a passionate, almost an indignant appeal, to him (Jaggers) to be more frank and manly with me.

I reminded him (Jaggers) of the false hopes into which I had lapsed, the length of time they had lasted, and the discovery I had made: and I hinted at the danger that weighed upon my spirits.

I represented myself as being surely worthy of some little confidence from him (Jaggers), in return for the confidence I had just now imparted.

I said that I did not blame him (Jaggers), or suspect him (Jaggers), or mistrust him (Jaggers), but I wanted assurance of the truth from him (Jaggers).

And if he (Jaggers) asked me why I wanted it, and why I thought I had any right to it, I would tell him (Jaggers), little as he (Jaggers) cared for such poor dreams, that I had loved Estella dearly and long, and that although I had lost her (Estella), and must live a bereaved life, whatever concerned her (Estella) was still nearer and dearer to me than anything else in the world.

And seeing that Mr. Jaggers stood quite still and silent, and apparently quite obdurate, under this appeal, I turned to Wemmick, and said,

``Wemmick, I know you to be a man with a gentle heart.

I have seen your pleasant home, and your old father, and all the innocent, cheerful playful ways with which you refresh your business life.

And I entreat you to say a word for me to Mr. Jaggers, and to represent to him (Jaggers) that, all circumstances considered, he (Jaggers) ought to be more open with me!

I have never seen two men look more oddly at one another than Mr. Jaggers and Wemmick did after this apostrophe.

At first, a misgiving crossed me that Wemmick would be instantly dismissed from his (Wemmick) employment; but it melted as I saw Mr. Jaggers relax into something like a smile, and Wemmick become bolder.

Wemmick, when Mr. Pip came in? '' (I)

'' '' What's all this?'' said Mr. Jaggers. '' You with an old father, and you with pleasant and playful ways?''

``Pip,'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
said Mr. Jaggers, laying his (Jaggers) hand upon my arm, and smiling openly, ``this man must be the most cunning impostor in all London.

``Well!'' (unknown)
returned Wemmick. '' If I don't bring 'em here, what does it matter?'' ''
``Not a bit of it,'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
returned Wemmick, growing bolder and bolder.

'' I think you're another. '' Again they exchanged their former odd looks, each apparently still distrustful that the other was taking him (Wemmick) in.

'' You with a pleasant home?'' said Mr. Jaggers. '' Since it don't interfere with business,'' returned Wemmick,

``let it be so.

Now, I look at you, sir, I shouldn't wonder if you might be planning and contriving to have a pleasant home of your own one of these days, when you're tired of all this work.

Pip,'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

said he (Wemmick),
``we won't talk about `poor dreams;' you know more about such things than I, having much fresher experience of that kind.

'' (he)

Mr. Jaggers nodded his (Jaggers) head retrospectively two or three times, and actually drew a sigh. '' But now about this other matter.

I'll put a case to you. Mind! I admit nothing. '' He (Jaggers) waited for me to declare that I quite understood that he (Jaggers) expressly said that he (Jaggers) admitted nothing.

Put the case that a woman, under such circumstances as you have mentioned, held her (woman) child concealed, and was obliged to communicate the fact to her (woman) legal adviser, on his (adviser) representing to her (woman) that he (adviser) must know, with an eye to the latitude of his (adviser) defence, how the fact stood about that child.

Put the case that, at the same time he (adviser) held a trust to find a child for an eccentric rich lady to adopt and bring up.''

``Put the case that he (adviser) lived in an atmosphere of evil, and that all he (adviser) saw of children was their being generated in great numbers for certain destruction.

Put the case that he (adviser) often saw children solemnly tried at a criminal bar, where they were held up to be seen; put the case that he (adviser) habitually knew of their being imprisoned, whipped, transported, neglected, cast out, qualified in all ways for the hangman, and growing up to be hanged.

Put the case that pretty nigh all the children he (hangman) saw in his (hangman) daily business life he (hangman) had reason to look upon as so much spawn, to develop into the fish that were to come to his (hangman) net,--to be prosecuted, defended, forsworn, made orphans, bedevilled somehow.

``Put the case, Pip, that here was one pretty little child out of the heap who could be saved; whom the father believed dead, and dared make no stir about; as to whom, over the mother, the legal adviser had this power:

``I know what you did, and how you did it.

'' (the adviser)

Now, Pip,'' said Mr. Jaggers, ``put this case.
``I follow you, sir.'' (unknown)
''
``I follow you, sir.'' (unknown)
You came so and so, you did such and such things to divert suspicion.

Part with the child, unless it should be necessary to produce it to clear you, and then it shall be produced.

I have tracked you through it all, and I tell it you all. Give the child into my hands, and I will do my best to bring you off.

If you are saved, your child is saved too; if you are lost, your child is still saved. '' Put the case that this was done, and that the woman was cleared.''

``I understand you perfectly.'' (I)
'' But that I make no admissions?'' '' That you make no admissions. '' And Wemmick repeated,
``No admissions.'' (unknown)

``Put the case, Pip, that passion and the terror of death had a little shaken the woman's intellects, and that when she (woman) was set at liberty, she (woman) was scared out of the ways of the world, and went to him (Pip) to be sheltered.

Put the case that he (Pip) took her (woman) in, and that he (Pip) kept down the old, wild, violent nature whenever he (Pip) saw an inkling of its breaking out, by asserting his (Pip) power over her (woman) in the old way.

Do you comprehend the imaginary case? '' (unknown)

``Quite.'' (unknown)
``Put the case that the child grew up, and was married for money.

That the mother and father, unknown to one another, were dwelling within so many miles, furlongs, yards if you like, of one another.

That the mother was still living. That the father was still living. That the secret was still a secret, except that you had got wind of it.

Put that last case to yourself very carefully. '' (unknown)

``I do. '' (unknown)
``I ask Wemmick to put it to himself very carefully.

'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

And Wemmick said,
``I do.'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
``For whose sake would you reveal the secret? For the father's? I think he (father) would not be much the better for the mother.

For the mother's? I think if she (mother) had done such a deed she (mother) would be safer where she (mother) was. For the daughter's?

I think it would hardly serve her (mother) to establish her (mother) parentage for the information of her (mother) husband, and to drag her (mother) back to disgrace, after an escape of twenty years, pretty secure to last for life.

But add the case that you had loved her (mother), Pip, and had made her (mother) the subject of those `poor dreams' which have, at one time or another, been in the heads of more men than you think likely, then I tell you that you had better--and would much sooner when you had thought well of it--chop off that bandaged left hand of yours with your bandaged right hand, and then pass the chopper on to Wemmick there, to cut that off too.

'' (I)

I looked at Wemmick, whose face was very grave. He (Pip) gravely touched his (Pip) lips with his (Pip) forefinger. I did the same.

Now, Wemmick,'' said the latter then, resuming his (Pip) usual manner,

``what item was it you were at when Mr. Pip came in?

Standing by for a little, while they were at work, I observed that the odd looks they had cast at one another were repeated several times: with this difference now, that each of them seemed suspicious, not to say conscious, of having shown himself in a weak and unprofessional light to the other.

For this reason, I suppose, they were now inflexible with one another; Mr. Jaggers being highly dictatorial, and Wemmick obstinately justifying himself whenever there was the smallest point in abeyance for a moment.

Mr. Jaggers did the same. '' (I)

'' I had never seen them on such ill terms; for generally they got on very well indeed together.

But they were both happily relieved by the opportune appearance of Mike, the client with the fur cap and the habit of wiping his (Mike) nose on his (Mike) sleeve, whom I had seen on the very first day of my appearance within those walls.

This individual, who, either in his (Mike) own person or in that of some member of his (Mike) family, seemed to be always in trouble -LRB-which in that place meant Newgate-RRB-, called to announce that his (Mike) eldest daughter was taken up on suspicion of shoplifting.

As he (Mike) imparted this melancholy circumstance to Wemmick, Mr. Jaggers standing magisterially before the fire and taking no share in the proceedings, Mike's eye happened to twinkle with a tear.

'' What are you about?'' demanded Wemmick, with the utmost indignation. '' What do you come snivelling here for?''

``I didn't go to do it, Mr. Wemmick.

'' (unknown)

``You did,'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
said Wemmick. '' How dare you? You're not in a fit state to come here, if you can't come here without spluttering like a bad pen.

What do you mean by it?'' '' A man can't help his (man) feelings, Mr. Wemmick,'' pleaded Mike. '' His (Wemmick) what?'' demanded Wemmick, quite savagely.

``Say that again!'' (unknown)
``Now look here my man,'' (Mr. Jaggers/Jaggers/MR. JAGGERS)
said Mr. Jaggers, advancing a step, and pointing to the door.
``Get out of this office.

So, the unfortunate Mike very humbly withdrew, and Mr. Jaggers and Wemmick appeared to have re-established their good understanding, and went to work again with an air of refreshment upon them as if they had just had lunch.

I'll have no feelings here. Get out.'' (unknown)

``It serves you right,'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
said Wemmick,
``Get out. '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
Chapter LII From Little Britain

I went, with my check in my pocket, to Miss Skiffins's brother, the accountant; and Miss Skiffins's brother, the accountant, going straight to Clarriker's and bringing Clarriker to me, I had the great satisfaction of concluding that arrangement.

It was the only good thing I had done, and the only completed thing I had done, since I was first apprised of my great expectations.

Clarriker informing me on that occasion that the affairs of the House were steadily progressing, that he (accountant) would now be able to establish a small branch-house in the East which was much wanted for the extension of the business, and that Herbert in his (Herbert) new partnership capacity would go out and take charge of it, I found that I must have prepared for a separation from my friend, even though my own affairs had been more settled.

And now, indeed, I felt as if my last anchor were loosening its hold, and I should soon be driving with the winds and waves.

But there was recompense in the joy with which Herbert would come home of a night and tell me of these changes,

little imagining that he (Herbert) told me no news, and would sketch airy pictures of himself conducting Clara Barley to the land of the Arabian Nights, and of me going out to join them -LRB-with a caravan of camels, I believe-RRB-, and of our all going up the Nile and seeing wonders.

Without being sanguine as to my own part in those bright plans, I felt that Herbert's way was clearing fast, and that old Bill Barley had but to stick to his (Barley) pepper and rum, and his (Barley) daughter would soon be happily provided for.

My left arm, though it presented no bad symptoms, took, in the natural course, so long to heal that I was still unable to get a coat on.

On a Monday morning, when Herbert and I were at breakfast, I received the following letter from Wemmick by the post.

We had now got into the month of March. My right arm was tolerably restored; disfigured, but fairly serviceable. '' Walworth.

Early in the week, or say Wednesday, you might do what you know of, if you felt disposed to try it.

When I had shown this to Herbert and had put it in the fire--but not before we had both got it by heart--we considered what to do.

Burn this as soon as read. Now burn. '' For, of course my being disabled could now be no longer kept out of view.

I have thought it over again and again,'' said Herbert,

``and I think I know a better course than taking a Thames waterman.

'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

Take Startop. A good fellow, a skilled hand, fond of us, and enthusiastic and honorable. '' I had thought of him (fellow) more than once.

Let him (fellow) suppose it a mere freak, but a secret one, until the morning comes: then let him (fellow) know that there is urgent reason for your getting Provis aboard and away.

'' But how much would you tell him (Provis), Herbert?''

``It is necessary to tell him (Herbert) very little. You go with him (Herbert)?'' (me)

It had seemed to me, in the many anxious considerations I had given the point, almost indifferent what port we made for,--Hamburg,

``No doubt. '' (I)
``Where? '' (he)
Rotterdam, Antwerp,--the place signified little, so that he (Herbert) was out of England. Any foreign steamer that fell in our way and would take us up would do.

I had always proposed to myself to get him (Herbert) well down the river in the boat; certainly well beyond Gravesend, which was a critical place for search or inquiry if suspicion were afoot.

As foreign steamers would leave London at about the time of high-water, our plan would be to get down the river by a previous ebb-tide, and lie by in some quiet spot until we could pull off to one.

The time when one would be due where we lay, wherever that might be, could be calculated pretty nearly, if we made inquiries beforehand.

We found that a steamer for Hamburg was likely to suit our purpose best, and we directed our thoughts chiefly to that vessel.

But we noted down what other foreign steamers would leave London with the same tide, and we satisfied ourselves that we knew the build and color of each.

We then separated for a few hours: I, to get at once such passports as were necessary; Herbert, to see Startop at his (Herbert) lodgings.

We both did what we had to do without any hindrance, and when we met again at one o'clock reported it done.

Herbert assented to all this, and we went out immediately after breakfast to pursue our investigations. I, for my part, was prepared with passports; Herbert had seen Startop, and he (Herbert) was more than ready to join.

Those two should pull a pair of oars, we settled, and I would steer; our charge would be sitter, and keep quiet; as speed was not our object, we should make way enough.

We arranged that Herbert should not come home to dinner before going to Mill Pond Bank that evening; that he (Herbert) should not go there at all to-morrow evening, Tuesday; that he (Herbert) should prepare Provis to come down to some stairs hard by the house, on Wednesday, when he (Provis) saw us approach, and not sooner; that all the arrangements with him (Provis) should be concluded that Monday night; and that he (Provis) should be communicated with no more in any way, until we took him (Provis) on board.

On opening the outer door of our chambers with my key, I found a letter in the box, directed to me; a very dirty letter, though not ill-written.

These precautions well understood by both of us, I went home. It had been delivered by hand -LRB-of course, since I left home-RRB-, and its contents were these:--

``If you are not afraid to come to the old marshes to-night or to-morrow night at nine, and to come to the little sluice-house by the limekiln, you had better come.

If you want information regarding your uncle Provis, you had much better come and tell no one, and lose no time.

You must come alone. Bring this with you. '' (I)

I had had load enough upon my mind before the receipt of this strange letter.

And the worst was, that I must decide quickly, or I should miss the afternoon coach, which would take me down in time for to-night.

What to do now, I could not tell. To-morrow night I could not think of going, for it would be too close upon the time of the flight.

And again, for anything I knew, the proffered information might have some important bearing on the flight itself. If I had had ample time for consideration, I believe I should still have gone.

Having hardly any time for consideration,--my watch showing me that the coach started within half an hour,--I resolved to go. I should certainly not have gone, but for the reference to my Uncle Provis.

It is so difficult to become clearly possessed of the contents of almost any letter, in a violent hurry, that I had to read this mysterious epistle again twice, before its injunction to me to be secret got mechanically into my mind.

Yielding to it in the same mechanical kind of way, I left a note in pencil for Herbert, telling him (Herbert) that as I should be so soon going away, I knew not for how long, I had decided to hurry down and back, to ascertain for myself how Miss Havisham was faring.

I had then barely time to get my great-coat, lock up the chambers, and make for the coach-office by the short by-ways.

If I had taken a hackney-chariot and gone by the streets, I should have missed my aim; going as I did, I caught the coach just as it came out of the yard.

That, coming on Wemmick's letter and the morning's busy preparation, turned the scale. I was the only inside passenger, jolting away knee-deep in straw, when I came to myself.

For I really had not been myself since the receipt of the letter; it had so bewildered me, ensuing on the hurry of the morning.

The morning hurry and flutter had been great; for, long and anxiously as I had waited for Wemmick, his (Wemmick) hint had come like a surprise at last.

And now I began to wonder at myself for being in the coach, and to doubt whether I had sufficient reason for being there, and to consider whether I should get out presently and go back, and to argue against ever heeding an anonymous communication, and, in short, to pass through all those phases of contradiction and indecision to which I suppose very few hurried people are strangers.

I reasoned as I had reasoned already without knowing it,--if that be reasoning,--in case any harm should befall him (coach) through my not going, how could I ever forgive myself!

It was dark before we got down, and the journey seemed long and dreary to me, who could see little of it inside, and who could not go outside in my disabled state.

Still, the reference to Provis by name mastered everything. Avoiding the Blue Boar, I put up at an inn of minor reputation down the town, and ordered some dinner.

While it was preparing, I went to Satis House and inquired for Miss Havisham; she (Havisham) was still very ill, though considered something better.

My inn had once been a part of an ancient ecclesiastical house, and I dined in a little octagonal common-room, like a font.

As I was not able to cut my dinner, the old landlord with a shining bald head did it for me.

This bringing us into conversation, he (I) was so good as to entertain me with my own story,--of course with the popular feature that Pumblechook was my earliest benefactor and the founder of my fortunes.

'' Do you know the young man?'' said I.

``Know him (man)! '' (I.)
repeated the landlord. '' Ever since he (man) was--no height at all.''

``Ay, he (man) comes back,'' (friends)
said the landlord, ``to his (man) great friends, now and again, and gives the cold shoulder to the man that made him (man).

``Does he (man) ever come back to this neighborhood?'' (unknown)
''
``What man is that?'' (Him)
'' Him (man) that I speak of,'' said the landlord.

'' Mr. Pumblechook. ''

``Is he (Pumblechook) ungrateful to no one else?'' (he)
'' No doubt he (Pumblechook) would be, if he (Pumblechook) could,'' returned the landlord,
``but he (Pumblechook) can't.

And why? Because Pumblechook done everything for him (Pumblechook).'' (he)

``Does Pumblechook say so?'' (unknown)
``Say so! '' (He)
replied the landlord. '' He (Pumblechook) han't no call to say so.''

'' But does he (Pumblechook) say so?''

``It would turn a man's blood to white wine winegar to hear him (man) tell of it, sir,'' (I)
said the landlord.

I thought,

``Yet Joe, dear Joe, you never tell of it. Long-suffering and loving Joe, you never complain. Nor you, sweet-tempered Biddy!'' (I)

``Your appetite's been touched like by your accident,'' (unknown)
said the landlord, glancing at the bandaged arm under my coat.
``Try a tenderer bit.'' (I)

'' No, thank you,'' I replied, turning from the table to brood over the fire. '' I can eat no more.

Please take it away. '' I had never been struck at so keenly, for my thanklessness to Joe, as through the brazen impostor Pumblechook.

The falser he (Pumblechook), the truer Joe; the meaner he (Pumblechook), the nobler Joe. My heart was deeply and most deservedly humbled as I mused over the fire for an hour or more.

The striking of the clock aroused me, but not from my dejection or remorse, and I got up and had my coat fastened round my neck, and went out.

I had previously sought in my pockets for the letter, that I might refer to it again; but I could not find it, and was uneasy to think that it must have been dropped in the straw of the coach.

I knew very well, however, that the appointed place was the little sluice-house by the limekiln on the marshes, and the hour nine.

It was a dark night, though the full moon rose as I left the enclosed lands, and passed out upon the marshes.

Towards the marshes I now went straight, having no time to spare. Chapter LIII Beyond their dark line there was a ribbon of clear sky, hardly broad enough to hold the red large moon.

In a few minutes she (coach) had ascended out of that clear field, in among the piled mountains of cloud. There was a melancholy wind, and the marshes were very dismal.

A stranger would have found them insupportable, and even to me they were so oppressive that I hesitated, half inclined to go back.

But I knew them well, and could have found my way on a far darker night, and had no excuse for returning, being there.

The direction that I took was not that in which my old home lay, nor that in which we had pursued the convicts.

My back was turned towards the distant Hulks as I walked on, and, though I could see the old lights away on the spits of sand, I saw them over my shoulder.

I knew the limekiln as well as I knew the old Battery, but they were miles apart; so that, if a light had been burning at each point that night, there would have been a long strip of the blank horizon between the two bright specks.

At first, I had to shut some gates after me, and now and then to stand still while the cattle that were lying in the banked-up pathway arose and blundered down among the grass and reeds.

So, having come there against my inclination, I went on against it. But after a little while I seemed to have the whole flats to myself.

The lime was burning with a sluggish stifling smell, but the fires were made up and left, and no workmen were visible.

It lay directly in my way, and had been worked that day, as I saw by the tools and barrows that were lying about.

Coming up again to the marsh level out of this excavation,--for the rude path lay through it,--I saw a light in the old sluice-house.

It was another half-hour before I drew near to the kiln. Hard by was a small stone-quarry. I quickened my pace, and knocked at the door with my hand.

Waiting for some reply, I looked about me, noticing how the sluice was abandoned and broken, and how the house--of wood with a tiled roof--would not be proof against the weather much longer, if it were so even now, and how the mud and ooze were coated with lime, and how the choking vapor of the kiln crept in a ghostly way towards me.

Still there was no answer, and I knocked again. No answer still, and I tried the latch. It rose under my hand, and the door yielded.

Looking in, I saw a lighted candle on a table, a bench, and a mattress on a truckle bedstead. As there was a loft above, I called,

``Is there any one here?

'' (I)

but no voice answered. Then I looked at my watch, and, finding that it was past nine, called again,
``Is there any one here?

'' (I)

There being still no answer, I went out at the door, irresolute what to do. It was beginning to rain fast.

Seeing nothing save what I had seen already, I turned back into the house, and stood just within the shelter of the doorway, looking out into the night.

While I was considering that some one must have been there lately and must soon be coming back, or the candle would not be burning, it came into my head to look if the wick were long.

I turned round to do so, and had taken up the candle in my hand, when it was extinguished by some violent shock; and the next thing I comprehended was, that I had been caught in a strong running noose, thrown over my head from behind.

'' Now,'' said a suppressed voice with an oath,

``I've got you!'' (unknown)
'' What is this? '' I cried, struggling. ''

Not only were my arms pulled close to my sides, but the pressure on my bad arm caused me exquisite pain.

Sometimes, a strong man's hand, sometimes a strong man's breast, was set against my mouth to deaden my cries, and with a hot breath always close to me, I struggled ineffectually in the dark, while I was fastened tight to the wall.

Who is it? Help, help, help! '' '' And now,'' said the suppressed voice with another oath,

``call out again, and I'll make short work of you!

'' (I)

Faint and sick with the pain of my injured arm, bewildered by the surprise, and yet conscious how easily this threat could be put in execution, I desisted, and tried to ease my arm were it ever so little.

But, it was bound too tight for that. I felt as if, having been burnt before, it were now being boiled.

The sudden exclusion of the night, and the substitution of black darkness in its place, warned me that the man had closed a shutter.

I strained my sight upon the sparks that fell among the tinder, and upon which he (man) breathed and breathed, match in hand, but I could only see his (man) lips, and the blue point of the match; even those but fitfully.

After groping about for a little, he (man) found the flint and steel he (man) wanted, and began to strike a light. The tinder was damp,--no wonder there,--and one after another

As the sparks fell thick and bright about him (man), I could see his (man) hands, and touches of his (man) face, and could make out that he (man) was seated and bending over the table; but nothing more.

Presently I saw his (man) blue lips again, breathing on the tinder, and then a flare of light flashed up, and showed me Orlick.

the sparks died out. The man was in no hurry, and struck again with the flint and steel. Whom I had looked for, I don't know.

I had not looked for him (man). Seeing him (man), I felt that I was in a dangerous strait indeed, and I kept my eyes upon him (man).

Then he (man) put the candle away from him (man) on the table, so that he (man) could see me, and sat with his (man) arms folded on the table and looked at me.

I made out that I was fastened to a stout perpendicular ladder a few inches from the wall,--a fixture there,--the means of ascent to the loft above.

He (man) lighted the candle from the flaring match with great deliberation, and dropped the match, and trod it out. '' Now,'' said he (man), when we had surveyed one another for some time,

``I've got you.'' (he)

``Unbind me. Let me go!'' (unknown)
``Ah!'' (he)
he (man) returned,
``I'll let you go. I'll let you go to the moon , I'll let you go to the stars.

All in good time. '' (he)

``Why have you lured me here?'' (unknown)
``Don't you know?'' (he)
said he (man), with a deadly look. ''

Why have you set upon me in the dark? '' '' Because I mean to do it all myself. One keeps a secret better than two.

His (man) enjoyment of the spectacle I furnished, as he (man) sat with his (man) arms folded on the table, shaking his (man) head at me and hugging himself, had a malignity in it that made me tremble.

As I watched him (man) in silence, he (man) put his (man) hand into the corner at his (man) side, and took up a gun with a brass-bound stock.

O you enemy, you enemy! '' '' Do you know this?'' said he (man), making as if he (man) would take aim at me.

'' Do you know where you saw it afore? Speak, wolf!'' '' Yes,'' I answered. '' You cost me that place.

You did. Speak!'' '' What else could I do?'' '' You did that, and that would be enough, without more. How dared you to come betwixt me and a young woman I liked?''

``When did I?'' (unknown)
'' When didn't you? It was you as always give Old Orlick a bad name to her (woman).''
``You gave it to yourself; you gained it for yourself.

I could have done you no harm, if you had done yourself none.'' (a liar)

'' You're a liar. And you'll take any pains, and spend any money, to drive me out of this country, will you?

'' said he (liar), repeating my words to Biddy in the last interview I had with her (woman). '' Now, I'll tell you a piece of information.

It was never so well worth your while to get me out of this country as it is to-night. Ah! If it was all your money twenty times told, to the last brass farden!''

As he (liar) shook his (liar) heavy hand at me, with his (liar) mouth snarling like a tiger's, I felt that it was true.

I'm a going,'' said he (liar), bringing his (liar) fist down upon the table with a heavy blow, and rising as the blow fell to give it greater force,--

``I'm

He (liar) leaned forward staring at me, slowly unclenched his (liar) hand and drew it across his (liar) mouth as if his (liar) mouth watered for me, and sat down again.

'' (he)

What are you going to do to me?'' '' a going to have your life!'' '' You was always in Old Orlick's way since ever you was a child.

You goes out of his (Orlick) way this present night. He (Orlick)'ll have no more on you. You're dead. '' I felt that I had come to the brink of my grave.

More than that,'' said he (Orlick), folding his (Orlick) arms on the table again,

``I won't have a rag of you, I won't have a bone of you, left on earth.

I'll put your body in the kiln,--I'd carry two such to it, on my Shoulders,--and, let people suppose what they may of you, they shall never know nothing.

For a moment I looked wildly round my trap for any chance of escape; but there was none. '' (he)

'' My mind, with inconceivable rapidity followed out all the consequences of such a death.

Estella's father would believe I had deserted him (father), would be taken, would die accusing me; even Herbert would doubt me, when he (Herbert) compared the letter I had left for him (Herbert) with the fact that I had called at Miss Havisham's gate for only a moment; Joe and Biddy would never know how sorry I had been that night, none would ever know what I had suffered, how true I had meant to be, what an agony I had passed through.

The death close before me was terrible, but far more terrible than death was the dread of being misremembered after death.

And so quick were my thoughts, that I saw myself despised by unborn generations,--Estella's children, and their children,--while the wretch's words were yet on his (me) lips.

'' Now, wolf,'' said he (me),

``afore I kill you like any other beast,--which is wot I mean to do and wot I have tied you up for,--I'll

It had passed through my thoughts to cry out for help again; though few could know better than I, the solitary nature of the spot, and the hopelessness of aid.

have a good look at you and a good goad at you. O you enemy! '' (he)

But as he (me) sat gloating over me, I was supported by a scornful detestation of him (me) that sealed my lips.

Above all things, I resolved that I would not entreat him (me), and that I would die making some last poor resistance to him (me).

Softened as my thoughts of all the rest of men were in that dire extremity; humbly beseeching pardon, as I did, of Heaven; melted at heart, as I was, by the thought that I had taken no farewell, and never now could take farewell of those who were dear to me, or could explain myself to them, or ask for their compassion on my miserable errors,--still, if I could have killed him (me), even in dying, I would have done it.

Around his (me) neck was slung a tin bottle, as I had often seen his (me) meat and drink slung about him (me) in other days.

He (me) brought the bottle to his (me) lips, and took a fiery drink from it; and I smelt the strong spirits that I saw flash into his (me) face.

He (me) had been drinking, and his (me) eyes were red and bloodshot.

``Wolf! '' (he)
said he (Wolf), folding his (Wolf) arms again,
``Old Orlick's a going to tell you somethink.

Again my mind, with its former inconceivable rapidity, had exhausted the whole subject of the attack upon my sister, her (sister) illness, and her (sister) death, before his (Wolf) slow and hesitating speech had formed these words.

It was you as did for your shrew sister. '' (he)

'' It was you, villain,'' said I.
``I tell you it was your doing,--I

tell you it was done through you,'' (I.)

he (villain) retorted, catching up the gun, and making a blow with the stock at the vacant air between us.

I left her (sister) for dead, and if there had been a limekiln as nigh her (sister) as there is now nigh you, she (sister) shouldn't have come to life again.

'' I come upon her (sister) from behind, as I come upon you to-night. I giv' it her (sister)! But it warn't Old Orlick

as did it; it was you. You was favored, and he (Orlick) was bullied and beat. Old Orlick bullied and beat, eh?

Now you pays for it. You done it; now you pays for it. '' He (Orlick) drank again, and became more ferocious.

I saw by his (Orlick) tilting of the bottle that there was no great quantity left in it. I distinctly understood that he (Orlick) was working himself up with its contents to make an end of me.

I knew that when I was changed into a part of the vapor that had crept towards me but a little while before, like my own warning ghost, he (Orlick) would do as he (Orlick) had done in my sister's case,--make all haste to the town, and be seen slouching about there drinking at the alehouses.

My rapid mind pursued him (Orlick) to the town, made a picture of the street with him (Orlick) in it, and contrasted its lights and life with the lonely marsh and the white vapor creeping over it, into which I should have dissolved.

It was not only that I could have summed up years and years and years while he (Orlick) said a dozen words, but that what he (Orlick) did say presented pictures to me, and not mere words.

In the excited and exalted state of my brain, I could not think of a place without seeing it, or of persons without seeing them.

It is impossible to overstate the vividness of these images, and yet I was so intent, all the time, upon him (Orlick) himself,--who would not be intent on the tiger crouching to spring!--that

I knew that every drop it held was a drop of my life. I knew of the slightest action of his (Orlick) fingers.

When he (Orlick) had drunk this second time, he (Orlick) rose from the bench on which he (Orlick) sat, and pushed the table aside.

Then, he (Orlick) took up the candle, and, shading it with his (Orlick) murderous hand so as to throw its light on me, stood before me, looking at me and enjoying the sight.

'' Wolf, I'll tell you something more. It was Old Orlick as you tumbled over on your stairs that night. ''

I saw the staircase with its extinguished lamps. I saw the shadows of the heavy stair-rails, thrown by the watchman's lantern on the wall.

I saw the rooms that I was never to see again; here, a door half open; there, a door closed; all the articles of furniture around.

You and her (Wolf) have pretty well hunted me out of this country, so far as getting a easy living in it goes, and I've took up with new companions, and new masters.

'' And why was Old Orlick there? I'll tell you something more, wolf. Some of 'em writes my letters when I wants 'em wrote,--do

I've had a firm mind and a firm will to have your life, since you was down here at your sister's burying.

you mind?--writes my letters, wolf! They writes fifty hands; they're not like sneaking you, as writes but one. I han't seen a way to get you safe, and I've looked arter you to know your ins and outs.

For, says Old Orlick to himself, `Somehow or another I'll have him (Orlick)!' What! When I looks for you, I finds your uncle Provis, eh?

Provis in his (Provis) rooms, the signal whose use was over, pretty Clara, the good motherly woman, old Bill Barley on his (Barley) back, all drifting by, as on the swift stream of my life fast running out to sea!

'' Mill Pond Bank, and Chinks's Basin, and the Old Green Copper Rope-walk, all so clear and plain! '' You with a uncle too!

Why, I know'd you at Gargery's when you was so small a wolf that I could have took your weazen betwixt this finger and thumb and chucked you away dead -LRB-as I'd thoughts o' doing, odd times, when I see you loitering amongst the pollards on a Sunday-RRB-, and you hadn't found no uncles then.

But when Old Orlick come for to hear that your uncle Provis had most like wore the leg-iron wot Old Orlick had picked up, filed asunder, on these meshes ever so many year ago, and wot he (Orlick) kep by him (Orlick) till he (Orlick) dropped your sister with it, like a bullock, as he (Orlick) means to drop you--hey?--when he (Orlick) come for to hear that--hey?

In his (Orlick) savage taunting, he (Orlick) flared the candle so close at me that I turned my face aside to save it from the flame.

Old Orlick knowed you was burnt, Old Orlick knowed you was smuggling your uncle Provis away, Old Orlick's a match for you and

No, not you! ''

``Ah!'' (he)
he (Orlick) cried, laughing, after doing it again,
``the burnt child dreads the fire! know'd you'd come to-night!

Now I'll tell you something more, wolf, and this ends it. There's them that's as good a match for your uncle Provis as Old Orlick has been for you.

Let him (Orlick) `ware them, when no man can't find a rag of his (man) dear relation's clothes, nor yet a bone of his (man) body.

, I know the name!--alive in the same land with them, and that's had such sure information of him (man) when he (man) was alive in another land, as that he (man) couldn't and shouldn't leave it unbeknown and put them in danger.

Let him (man) `ware them, when he (man)'s lost his (man) nevvy! There's them that can't and that won't have Magwitch,--yes P'raps it's them that writes fifty hands, and that's not like sneaking you as writes but one. '

He (Magwitch) flared the candle at me again, smoking my face and hair, and for an instant blinding me, and turned his (Magwitch) powerful back as he (Magwitch) replaced the light on the table.

Ware Compeyson, Magwitch, and the gallows! '' (he)

I had thought a prayer, and had been with Joe and Biddy and Herbert, before he (Herbert) turned towards me again.

There was a clear space of a few feet between the table and the opposite wall. Within this space, he (Herbert) now slouched backwards and forwards.

His (Herbert) great strength seemed to sit stronger upon him (Herbert) than ever before, as he (Herbert) did this with his (Herbert) hands hanging loose and heavy at his (Herbert) sides, and with his (Herbert) eyes scowling at me.

Wild as my inward hurry was, and wonderful the force of the pictures that rushed by me instead of thoughts, I could yet clearly understand that, unless he (Herbert) had resolved that I was within a few moments of surely perishing out of all human knowledge, he (Herbert) would never have told me what he (Herbert) had told.

I had no grain of hope left. Of a sudden, he (Herbert) stopped, took the cork out of his (Herbert) bottle, and tossed it away.

Light as it was, I heard it fall like a plummet. He (Herbert) swallowed slowly, tilting up the bottle by little and little, and now he (Herbert) looked at me no more.

Then, with a sudden hurry of violence and swearing horribly, he (Herbert) threw the bottle from him (Herbert), and stooped; and I saw in his (Herbert) hand a stone-hammer with a long heavy handle.

The resolution I had made did not desert me, for, without uttering one vain word of appeal to him (Herbert), I shouted out with all my might, and struggled with all my might.

It was only my head and my legs that I could move, but to that extent I struggled with all the force, until then unknown, that was within me.

In the same instant I heard responsive shouts, saw figures and a gleam of light dash in at the door, heard voices and tumult, and saw Orlick emerge from a struggle of men, as if it were tumbling water, clear the table at a leap, and fly out into the night.

After a blank, I found that I was lying unbound, on the floor, in the same place, with my head on some one's knee.

My eyes were fixed on the ladder against the wall, when I came to myself,--had opened on it before my mind saw it,--and thus as I recovered consciousness, I knew that I was in the place where I had lost it.

Too indifferent at first, even to look round and ascertain who supported me, I was lying looking at the ladder, when there came between me and it a face.

The last few drops of liquor he (it) poured into the palm of his (it) hand, and licked up. The face of Trabb's boy!

At these words, the face of him (Trabb) who supported me looked over into mine, and I saw my supporter to be--

``Herbert!

'' (supporter)

I think he (Herbert)'s all right!'' said Trabb's boy, in a sober voice;
``but ain't he (boy) just pale though! '' (Trabb boy)
Great Heaven!''

``Softly,'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
said Herbert. '' Gently, Handel. Don't be too eager.'' '' And our old comrade, Startop!'' I cried, as he (comrade) too bent over me.

``Remember what he (comrade) is going to assist us in,'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
said Herbert,
``and be calm. '' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
The allusion made me spring up; though I dropped again from the pain in my arm.

'' The time has not gone by, Herbert, has it? What night is to-night? How long have I been here? ''

For, I had a strange and strong misgiving that I had been lying there a long time--a day and a night,--two days and nights,--more.

'' The time has not gone by. It is still Monday night.''

``Thank God!'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
'' And you have all to-morrow, Tuesday, to rest in,'' said Herbert.

'' But you can't help groaning, my dear Handel. What hurt have you got? Can you stand?'' '' Yes, yes,'' said I,

``I can walk.

I have no hurt but in this throbbing arm. '' (I)

They laid it bare, and did what they could. It was violently swollen and inflamed, and I could scarcely endure to have it touched.

But, they tore up their handkerchiefs to make fresh bandages, and carefully replaced it in the sling, until we could get to the town and obtain some cooling lotion to put upon it.

In a little while we had shut the door of the dark and empty sluice-house, and were passing through the quarry on our way back.

Trabb's boy--Trabb's overgrown young man now--went before us with a lantern, which was the light I had seen come in at the door.
