But, the moon was a good two hours higher than when I had last seen the sky, and the night, though rainy, was much lighter.

The white vapor of the kiln was passing from us as we went by, and as I had thought a prayer before, I thought a thanksgiving now.

Entreating Herbert to tell me how he (Herbert) had come to my rescue,--which at first he (Herbert) had flatly refused to do, but had insisted on my remaining quiet,--I learnt that I had in my hurry dropped the letter, open, in our chambers, where he (Herbert), coming home to bring with him (Herbert) Startop whom he (Herbert) had met in the street on his (Herbert) way to me, found it, very soon after I was gone.

Its tone made him (Herbert) uneasy, and the more so because of the inconsistency between it and the hasty letter I had left for him (Herbert).

His (Herbert) uneasiness increasing instead of subsiding, after a quarter of an hour's consideration, he (Herbert) set off for the coach-office with Startop, who volunteered his (Herbert) company, to make inquiry when the next coach went down.

Finding that the afternoon coach was gone, and finding that his (coach) uneasiness grew into positive alarm, as obstacles came in his (coach) way, he (coach) resolved to follow in a post-chaise.

So he (coach) and Startop arrived at the Blue Boar, fully expecting there to find me, or tidings of me; but, finding neither, went on to Miss Havisham's, where they lost me.

Hereupon they went back to the hotel -LRB-doubtless at about the time when I was hearing the popular local version of my own story-RRB- to refresh themselves and to get some one to guide them out upon the marshes.

Among the loungers under the Boar's archway happened to be Trabb's Boy,--true to his (Trabb) ancient habit of happening to be everywhere where he (Trabb) had no business,--and

Thus Trabb's boy became their guide, and with him (boy) they went out to the sluice-house, though by the town way to the marshes, which I had avoided.

Now, as they went along, Herbert reflected, that I might, after all, have been brought there on some genuine and serviceable errand tending to Provis's safety, and, bethinking himself that in that case interruption must be mischievous, left his (Provis) guide and Startop on the edge of the quarry, and went on by himself, and stole round the house two or three times, endeavouring to ascertain whether all was right within.

As he (Provis) could hear nothing but indistinct sounds of one deep rough voice -LRB-this was while my mind was so busy-RRB-, he (Provis) even at last began to doubt whether I was there, when suddenly I cried out loudly, and he (Provis) answered the cries, and rushed in, closely followed by the other two.

When I told Herbert what had passed within the house, he (Herbert) was for our immediately going before a magistrate in the town, late at night as it was, and getting out a warrant.

But, I had already considered that such a course, by detaining us there, or binding us to come back, might be fatal to Provis.

Trabb's boy had seen me passing from Miss Havisham's in the direction of my dining-place. There was no gainsaying this difficulty, and we relinquished all thoughts of pursuing Orlick at that time.

For the present, under the circumstances, we deemed it prudent to make rather light of the matter to Trabb's boy; who, I am convinced, would have been much affected by disappointment, if he (Trabb) had known that his (Trabb) intervention saved me from the limekiln.

Not that Trabb's boy was of a malignant nature, but that he (boy) had too much spare vivacity, and that it was in his (boy) constitution to want variety and excitement at anybody's expense.

When we parted, I presented him (boy) with two guineas -LRB-which seemed to meet his (boy) views-RRB-, and told him (boy) that I was sorry ever to have had an ill opinion of him (boy) -LRB-which made no impression on him (boy) at all-RRB-.

Wednesday being so close upon us, we determined to go back to London that night, three in the post-chaise; the rather, as we should then be clear away before the night's adventure began to be talked of.

Herbert got a large bottle of stuff for my arm; and by dint of having this stuff dropped over it all the night through, I was just able to bear its pain on the journey.

It was daylight when we reached the Temple, and I went at once to bed, and lay in bed all day.

My terror, as I lay there, of falling ill, and being unfitted for to-morrow, was so besetting, that I wonder it did not disable me of itself.

It would have done so, pretty surely, in conjunction with the mental wear and tear I had suffered, but for the unnatural strain upon me that to-morrow was.

No precaution could have been more obvious than our refraining from communication with him (me) that day; yet this again increased my restlessness.

I started at every footstep and every sound, believing that he (me) was discovered and taken, and this was the messenger to tell me so.

I persuaded myself that I knew he (me) was taken; that there was something more upon my mind than a fear or a presentiment; that the fact had occurred, and I had a mysterious knowledge of it.

As the days wore on, and no ill news came, as the day closed in and darkness fell, my overshadowing dread of being disabled by illness before to-morrow morning altogether mastered me.

So anxiously looked forward to, charged with such consequences, its results so impenetrably hidden, though so near. My burning arm throbbed, and my burning head throbbed, and I fancied I was beginning to wander.

I counted up to high numbers, to make sure of myself, and repeated passages that I knew in prose and verse.

It happened sometimes that in the mere escape of a fatigued mind, I dozed for some moments or forgot; then I would say to myself with a start,

``Now it has come, and I am turning delirious!'' (I)

Whenever I fell asleep, I awoke with the notion I had had in the sluice-house, that a long time had elapsed and the opportunity to save him (I) was gone.

About midnight I got out of bed and went to Herbert, with the conviction that I had been asleep for four-and-twenty hours, and that Wednesday was past.

They kept me very quiet all day, and kept my arm constantly dressed, and gave me cooling drinks. It was the last self-exhausting effort of my fretfulness, for after that I slept soundly.

The winking lights upon the bridges were already pale, the coming sun was like a marsh of fire on the horizon.

The river, still dark and mysterious, was spanned by bridges that were turning coldly gray, with here and there at top a warm touch from the burning in the sky.

As I looked along the clustered roofs, with church-towers and spires shooting into the unusually clear air, the sun rose up, and a veil seemed to be drawn from the river, and millions of sparkles burst out upon its waters.

Wednesday morning was dawning when I looked out of window. From me too, a veil seemed to be drawn, and I felt strong and well.

I could not dress myself without help; but I made up the fire, which was still burning, and got some coffee ready for them.

In good time they too started up strong and well, and we admitted the sharp morning air at the windows, and looked at the tide that was still flowing towards us.

When it turns at nine o'clock,'' said Herbert, cheerfully,

``look out for us, and stand ready, you over there at Mill Pond Bank!

It was one of those March days when the sun shines hot and the wind blows cold: when it is summer in the light, and winter in the shade.

Herbert lay asleep in his (Herbert) bed, and our old fellow-student lay asleep on the sofa. '' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

'' Chapter LIV We had our pea-coats with us, and I took a bag.

Where I might go, what I might do, or when I might return, were questions utterly unknown to me; nor did I vex my mind with them, for it was wholly set on Provis's safety.

I only wondered for the passing moment, as I stopped at the door and looked back, under what altered circumstances I should next see those rooms, if ever.

We loitered down to the Temple stairs, and stood loitering there, as if we were not quite decided to go upon the water at all.

Of all my worldly possessions I took no more than the few necessaries that filled the bag. Of course, I had taken care that the boat should be ready and everything in order.

After a little show of indecision, which there were none to see but the two or three amphibious creatures belonging to our Temple stairs, we went on board and cast off; Herbert in the bow, I steering.

The tide, beginning to run down at nine, and being with us until three, we intended still to creep on after it had turned, and row against it until dark.

We should then be well in those long reaches below Gravesend, between Kent and Essex, where the river is broad and solitary, where the water-side inhabitants are very few, and where lone public-houses are scattered here and there, of which we could choose one for a resting-place.

It was then about high-water,--half-past eight. Our plan was this. There, we meant to lie by all night. The steamer for Hamburg and the steamer for Rotterdam would start from London at about nine on Thursday morning.

We should know at what time to expect them, according to where we were, and would hail the first; so that, if by any accident we were not taken abroad, we should have another chance.

The relief of being at last engaged in the execution of the purpose was so great to me that I felt it difficult to realize the condition in which I had been a few hours before.

The crisp air, the sunlight, the movement on the river, and the moving river itself,--the road that ran with us, seeming to sympathize with us, animate us, and encourage us

I felt mortified to be of so little use in the boat; but, there were few better oarsmen than my two friends, and they rowed with a steady stroke that was to last all day.

At that time, the steam-traffic on the Thames was far below its present extent, and watermen's boats were far more numerous.

Of barges, sailing colliers, and coasting-traders, there were perhaps, as many as now; but of steam-ships, great and small, not a tithe or a twentieth part so many.

Early as it was, there were plenty of scullers going here and there that morning, and plenty of barges dropping down with the tide; the navigation of the river between bridges, in an open boat, was a much easier and commoner matter in those days than it is in these; and we went ahead among many skiffs and wherries briskly.

Old London Bridge was soon passed, and old Billingsgate Market with its oyster-boats and Dutchmen, and the White Tower and Traitor's Gate, and we were in among the tiers of shipping.

Here were the Leith, Aberdeen, and Glasgow steamers, loading and unloading goods, and looking immensely high out of the water as we passed alongside; here, were colliers by the score and score, with the coal-whippers plunging off stages on deck, as counterweights to measures of coal swinging up, which were then rattled over the side into barges; here, at her (colliers) moorings was to-morrow's steamer for Rotterdam, of which we took good notice; and here to-morrow's for Hamburg, under whose bowsprit we crossed.

We knew the distinguishing marks of each vessel. on,--freshened me with new hope. And now I, sitting in the stern, could see, with a faster beating heart,

Mill Pond Bank and Mill Pond stairs. '' Is he (we) there?'' said Herbert. '' Not yet. '' '' Right! He (Herbert) was not to come down till he (Herbert) saw us.

Can you see his (Herbert) signal? ''

``Not well from here; but I think I see it.--Now I see him (Herbert)! Pull both.

Easy, Herbert. Oars! '' (he)

We touched the stairs lightly for a single moment, and he (Herbert) was on board, and we were off again.

He (Herbert) had a boat-cloak with him (Herbert), and a black canvas bag; and he (Herbert) looked as like a river-pilot as my heart could have wished.

'' Dear boy! '' he (boy) said, putting his (boy) arm on my shoulder, as he (boy) took his (boy) seat. '' Faithful dear boy, well done.

Again among the tiers of shipping, in and out, avoiding rusty chain-cables frayed hempen hawsers and bobbing buoys, sinking for the moment floating broken baskets, scattering floating chips of wood and shaving, cleaving floating scum of coal, in and out, under the figure-head of the John of Sunderland making a speech to the winds -LRB-as is done by many Johns-RRB-, and the Betsy of Yarmouth with a firm formality of bosom and her (Betsy) knobby eyes starting two inches out of her (Betsy) head; in and out, hammers going in ship-builders' yards, saws going at timber, clashing engines going at things unknown, pumps going in leaky ships, capstans going, ships going out to sea, and unintelligible sea-creatures roaring curses over the bulwarks at respondent lightermen, in and out,--out at last upon the clearer river, where the ships' boys might take their fenders in, no longer fishing in troubled waters with them over the side, and where the festooned sails might fly out to the wind.

At the stairs where we had taken him (respondent) abroad, and ever since, I had looked warily for any token of our being suspected.

We certainly had not been, and at that time as certainly we were not either attended or followed by any boat.

If we had been waited on by any boat, I should have run in to shore, and have obliged her (boys) to go on, or to make her (boys) purpose evident.

Thankye, thankye!'' I had seen none. But we held our own without any appearance of molestation. He (respondent) had his (respondent) boat-cloak on him (respondent), and looked, as I have said, a natural part of the scene.

It was remarkable -LRB-but perhaps the wretched life he (respondent) had led accounted for it-RRB- that he (respondent) was the least anxious of any of us.

He (respondent) was not indifferent, for he (respondent) told me that he (respondent) hoped to live to see his (respondent) gentleman one of the best of gentlemen in a foreign country; he (respondent) was not disposed to be passive or resigned, as I understood it; but he (respondent) had no notion of meeting danger half way.

If you knowed, dear boy,'' he (boy) said to me,

``what it is to sit here alonger my dear boy and have my smoke, arter having been day by day betwixt four walls, you'd envy me.

When it came upon him (boy), he (boy) confronted it, but it must come before he (boy) troubled himself. '' (me)

But you don't know what it is.''

``I think I know the delights of freedom,'' (I)
I answered. '' Ah,'' said he (boy), shaking his (boy) head gravely. '' But you don't know it equal to me.

You must have been under lock and key, dear boy, to know it equal to me,--but I ain't a going to be low.

It occurred to me as inconsistent, that, for any mastering idea, he (boy) should have endangered his (boy) freedom, and even his (boy) life.

But I reflected that perhaps freedom without danger was too much apart from all the habit of his (boy) existence to be to him (boy) what it would be to another man.

I was not far out, since he (boy) said, after smoking a little:--

``You see, dear boy, when I was over yonder, t`other side the world, I was always a looking to this side; and it come flat to be there, for all I was a growing rich.

'' (he)

Everybody knowed Magwitch, and Magwitch could come, and Magwitch could go, and nobody's head would be troubled about him (Magwitch). They ain't so easy concerning me here

, dear boy,--wouldn't be, leastwise, if they knowed where I was.'' '' If all goes well,'' said I,

``you will be perfectly free and safe again within a few hours.

He (boy) dipped his (boy) hand in the water over the boat's gunwale, and said, smiling with that softened air upon him (boy) which was not new to me:--

'' (I)

'' Well,'' he (boy) returned, drawing a long breath,
``I hope so.'' (he)
'' And think so? '' '' Ay, I s`pose I think so, dear boy.

We'd be puzzled to be more quiet and easy-going than we are at present. But--it's a flowing so soft and pleasant through the water,

p`raps, as makes me think it--I was a thinking through my smoke just then, that we can no more see to the bottom of the next few hours than we can see to the bottom of this river what I catches hold of.

Nor yet we can't no more hold their tide than I can hold this. And it's run through my fingers and gone, you see!

But for your face I should think you were a little despondent,'' said I.

``Not a bit on it, dear boy!

It comes of flowing on so quiet, and of that there rippling at the boat's head making a sort of a Sunday tune.

He (boy) put his (boy) pipe back in his (boy) mouth with an undisturbed expression of face, and sat as composed and contented as if we were already out of England.

Yet he (boy) was as submissive to a word of advice as if he (boy) had been in constant terror; for, when we ran ashore to get some bottles of beer into the boat, and he (boy) was stepping out

'' (I.)

holding up his (boy) dripping hand. '' Maybe I'm a growing a trifle old besides. '' , I hinted that I thought he (boy) would be safest where he (boy) was, and he (boy) said.

'' Do you, dear boy?'' and quietly sat down again. The air felt cold upon the river, but it was a bright day, and the sunshine was very cheering.

The tide ran strong, I took care to lose none of it, and our steady stroke carried us on thoroughly well.

By imperceptible degrees, as the tide ran out, we lost more and more of the nearer woods and hills, and dropped lower and lower between the muddy banks, but the tide was yet with us when we were off Gravesend.

As our charge was wrapped in his (it) cloak, I purposely passed within a boat or two's length of the floating Custom House, and so out to catch the stream, alongside of two emigrant ships, and under the bows of a large transport with troops on the forecastle looking down at us.

And soon the tide began to slacken, and the craft lying at anchor to swing, and presently they had all swung round, and the ships that were taking advantage of the new tide to get up to the Pool began to crowd upon us in a fleet, and we kept under the shore, as much out of the strength of the tide now as we could, standing carefully off from low shallows and mudbanks.

Our oarsmen were so fresh, by dint of having occasionally let her (us) drive with the tide for a minute or two, that a quarter of an hour's rest proved full as much as they wanted.

It was like my own marsh country, flat and monotonous, and with a dim horizon; while the winding river turned and turned, and the great floating buoys upon it turned and turned, and everything else seemed stranded and still.

For now the last of the fleet of ships was round the last low point we had headed; and the last green barge, straw-laden, with a brown sail, had followed; and some ballast-lighters, shaped like a child's first rude imitation of a boat, lay low in the mud; and a little squat shoal-lighthouse on open piles stood crippled in the mud on stilts and crutches; and slimy stakes stuck out of the mud, and slimy stones stuck out of the mud, and red landmarks and tidemarks stuck out of the mud, and an old landing-stage and an old roofless building slipped into the mud, and all about us was stagnation and mud.

We got ashore among some slippery stones while we ate and drank what we had with us, and looked about. We pushed off again, and made what way we could.

It was much harder work now, but Herbert and Startop persevered, and rowed and rowed and rowed until the sun went down.

There was the red sun, on the low level of the shore, in a purple haze, fast deepening into black; and there was the solitary flat marsh; and far away there were the rising grounds, between which and us there seemed to be no life, save here and there in the foreground a melancholy gull.

As the night was fast falling, and as the moon, being past the full, would not rise early, we held a little council; a short one, for clearly our course was to lie by at the first lonely tavern we could find.

By that time the river had lifted us a little, so that we could see above the bank. So, they plied their oars once more, and I looked out for anything like a house.

It was very cold, and, a collier coming by us, with her (us) galley-fire smoking and flaring, looked like a comfortable home.

The night was as dark by this time as it would be until morning; and what light we had, seemed to come more from the river than the sky, as the oars in their dipping struck at a few reflected stars.

Thus we held on, speaking little, for four or five dull miles. At this dismal time we were evidently all possessed by the idea that we were followed.

As the tide made, it flapped heavily at irregular intervals against the shore; and whenever such a sound came, one or other of us was sure to start, and look in that direction.

Here and there, the set of the current had worn down the bank into a little creek, and we were all suspicious of such places, and eyed them nervously.

Sometimes,

``What was that ripple? '' (unknown)
one of us would say in a low voice. Or another , ``Is that a boat yonder?

And afterwards we would fall into a dead silence, and I would sit impatiently thinking with what an unusual amount of noise the oars worked in the thowels.

At length we descried a light and a roof, and presently afterwards ran alongside a little causeway made of stones that had been picked up hard by.

Leaving the rest in the boat, I stepped ashore, and found the light to be in a window of a public-house.

It was a dirty place enough, and I dare say not unknown to smuggling adventurers; but there was a good fire in the kitchen, and there were eggs and bacon to eat, and various liquors to drink.

No other company was in the house than the landlord, his (It) wife, and a grizzled male creature, the

``Jack'' (a male creature)
of the little causeway, who was as slimy and smeary as if he (Jack) had been low-water mark too.

With this assistant, I went down to the boat again, and we all came ashore, and brought out the oars, and rudder and boat-hook, and all else, and hauled her (wife) up for the night.

We made a very good meal by the kitchen fire, and then apportioned the bedrooms: Herbert and Startop were to occupy one; I and our charge the other.

We found the air as carefully excluded from both, as if air were fatal to life; and there were more dirty clothes and bandboxes under the beds than I should have thought the family possessed.

'' Also, there were two double-bedded rooms,--

``such as they were,'' (unknown)
the landlord said. But we considered ourselves well off, notwithstanding, for a more solitary place we could not have found.

While we were comforting ourselves by the fire after our meal, the Jack--who was sitting in a corner, and who had a bloated pair of shoes on, which he (Jack) had exhibited while we were eating our eggs and bacon, as interesting relics that he (Jack) had taken a few days ago from the feet of a drowned seaman washed ashore--asked me if we had seen a four-oared galley going up with the tide?

When I told him (Jack) No, he (Jack) said she (Jack) must have gone down then, and yet she (Jack)

``took up too,'' (she)
when she (Jack) left there.

'' They must ha' thought better on't for some reason or another,'' said the Jack,

``and gone down. '' (Jack)
'' A four-oared galley, did you say?'' said I.
``A four,'' (I.)
said the Jack,
``and two sitters.

'' (Jack)

``Did they come ashore here?'' (unknown)
'' They put in with a stone two-gallon jar for some beer. I'd ha' been glad to pison the beer myself,'' said the Jack,
``or put some rattling physic in it.

'' (Jack)

``Why?'' (unknown)
``I know why,'' (Jack)
said the Jack. He (Jack) spoke in a slushy voice, as if much mud had washed into his (Jack) throat.

He (Jack) thinks,'' said the landlord, a weakly meditative man with a pale eye, who seemed to rely greatly on his (Jack) Jack,--

``he (Jack) thinks they was, what they wasn't.

'' (Jack)

''
``I knows what I thinks,'' (Jack)
observed the Jack. '' You thinks Custum `Us, Jack?'' said the landlord. '' I do,'' said the Jack.

In the infinite meaning of his (Jack) reply and his (Jack) boundless confidence in his (Jack) views, the Jack took one of his (Jack) bloated shoes off, looked into it, knocked a few stones out of it on the kitchen floor, and put it on again.

'' Then you're wrong, Jack.''

``AM I!'' (He)
He (Jack) did this with the air of a Jack who was so right that he (Jack) could afford to do anything.

'' Why, what do you make out that they done with their buttons then, Jack? '' asked the landlord, vacillating weakly.

``Done with their buttons? '' (Jack)
returned the Jack. '' Chucked 'em overboard. Swallered 'em. Sowed 'em, to come up small salad.

A Custum `Us officer knows what to do with his (Jack) Buttons,'' said the Jack, repeating the obnoxious word with the greatest contempt,

``when they comes betwixt him (Jack) and his (Jack) own light.

A four and two sitters don't go hanging and hovering, up with one tide and down with another, and both with and against another, without there being Custum `Us at the bottom of it.

Saying which he (Jack) went out in disdain; and the landlord, having no one to reply upon, found it impracticable to pursue the subject.

Done with their buttons!'' (Jack)

``Don't be cheeky, Jack,'' (unknown)
remonstrated the landlord, in a melancholy and pathetic way. '' '' This dialogue made us all uneasy, and me very uneasy.

The dismal wind was muttering round the house, the tide was flapping at the shore, and I had a feeling that we were caged and threatened.

A four-oared galley hovering about in so unusual a way as to attract this notice was an ugly circumstance that I could not get rid of.

When I had induced Provis to go up to bed, I went outside with my two companions -LRB-Startop by this time knew the state of the case-RRB-, and held another council.

Whether we should remain at the house until near the steamer's time, which would be about one in the afternoon, or whether we should put off early in the morning, was the question we discussed.

On the whole we deemed it the better course to lie where we were, until within an hour or so of the steamer's time, and then to get out in her (companions) track, and drift easily with the tide.

Having settled to do this, we returned into the house and went to bed. I lay down with the greater part of my clothes on, and slept well for a few hours.

When I awoke, the wind had risen, and the sign of the house -LRB-the Ship-RRB- was creaking and banging about, with noises that startled me.

It commanded the causeway where we had hauled up our boat, and, as my eyes adapted themselves to the light of the clouded moon, I saw two men looking into her (me).

They passed by under the window, looking at nothing else, and they did not go down to the landing-place which I could discern to be empty, but struck across the marsh in the direction of the Nore.

Rising softly, for my charge lay fast asleep, I looked out of the window. My first impulse was to call up Herbert, and show him (Herbert) the two men going away.

But reflecting, before I got into his (Herbert) room, which was at the back of the house and adjoined mine, that he (Herbert) and Startop had had a harder day than I, and were fatigued, I forbore.

In that light, however, I soon lost them, and, feeling very cold, lay down to think of the matter, and fell asleep again.

As we walked to and fro, all four together, before breakfast, I deemed it right to recount what I had seen.

Going back to my window, I could see the two men moving over the marsh. We were up early. Again our charge was the least anxious of the party.

It was very likely that the men belonged to the Custom House, he (I) said quietly, and that they had no thought of us.

However, I proposed that he (I) and I should walk away together to a distant point we could see, and that the boat should take us aboard there, or as near there as might prove feasible, at about noon.

I tried to persuade myself that it was so,--as, indeed, it might easily be. This being considered a good precaution, soon after breakfast he (I) and I set forth, without saying anything at the tavern.

He (I) smoked his (I) pipe as we went along, and sometimes stopped to clap me on the shoulder. One would have supposed that it was I who was in danger, not he (I), and that he (I) was reassuring me.

As we approached the point, I begged him (I) to remain in a sheltered place, while I went on to reconnoitre; for it was towards it that the men had passed in the night.

There was no boat off the point, nor any boat drawn up anywhere near it, nor were there any signs of the men having embarked there.

We spoke very little. He (I) complied, and I went on alone. But, to be sure, the tide was high, and there might have been some footpints under water.

When he (I) looked out from his (I) shelter in the distance, and saw that I waved my hat to him (I) to come up, he (I) rejoined me, and there we waited; sometimes lying on the bank, wrapped in our coats, and sometimes moving about to warm ourselves, until we saw our boat coming round.

We got aboard easily, and rowed out into the track of the steamer. By that time it wanted but ten minutes of one o'clock, and we began to look out for her (me) smoke.

But, it was half-past one before we saw her (me) smoke, and soon afterwards we saw behind it the smoke of another steamer.

As they were coming on at full speed, we got the two bags ready, and took that opportunity of saying good-bye to Herbert and Startop.

We had all shaken hands cordially, and neither Herbert's eyes nor mine were quite dry, when I saw a four-oared galley shoot out from under the bank but a little way ahead of us, and row out into the same track.

A stretch of shore had been as yet between us and the steamer's smoke, by reason of the bend and wind of the river; but now she (I) was visible, coming head on.

I called to Herbert and Startop to keep before the tide, that she (I) might see us lying by for her (I), and I adjured Provis to sit quite still, wrapped in his (Provis) cloak.

He (Provis) answered cheerily,

``Trust to me, dear boy,'' (He)
and sat like a statue. Meantime the galley, which was very skilfully handled, had crossed us, let us come up with her (I), and fallen alongside.

Leaving just room enough for the play of the oars, she (I) kept alongside, drifting when we drifted, and pulling a stroke or two when we pulled.

attentively,--as did all the rowers; the other sitter was wrapped up, much as Provis was, and seemed to shrink, and whisper some instruction to the steerer as he (Provis) looked at us.

Startop could make out, after a few minutes, which steamer was first, and gave me the word

``Hamburg,'' (me)
in a low voice, as we sat face to face.

Of the two sitters one held the rudder-lines, and looked at us Not a word was spoken in either boat. She (sitter) was nearing us very fast, and the beating of her (sitter) peddles grew louder and louder.

I felt as if her (sitter) shadow were absolutely upon us, when the galley hailed us. I answered. '' You have a returned Transport there,'' said the man who held the lines.

'' That's the man, wrapped in the cloak. His (man) name is Abel Magwitch, otherwise Provis. I apprehend that man, and call upon him (Provis) to surrender, and you to assist.

They had pulled one sudden stroke ahead, had got their oars in, had run athwart us, and were holding on to our gunwale, before we knew what they were doing.

This caused great confusion on board the steamer, and I heard them calling to us, and heard the order given to stop the paddles, and heard them stop, but felt her (Magwitch) driving down upon us irresistibly.

In the same moment, I saw the steersman of the galley lay his (Provis) hand on his (Provis) prisoner's shoulder, and saw that both boats were swinging round with the force of the tide, and saw that all hands on board the steamer were running forward quite frantically.

Still, in the same moment, I saw the prisoner start up, lean across his (prisoner) captor, and pull the cloak from the neck of the shrinking sitter in the galley.

Still in the same moment, I saw that the face disclosed, was the face of the other convict of long ago.

Still, in the same moment, I saw the face tilt backward with a white terror on it that I shall never forget, and heard a great cry on board the steamer, and a loud splash in the water, and felt the boat sink from under me.

It was but for an instant that I seemed to struggle with a thousand mill-weirs and a thousand flashes of light; that instant past, I was taken on board the galley.

'' At the same moment, without giving any audible direction to his (me) crew, he (me) ran the galley abroad of us. Herbert was there, and Startop was there; but our boat was gone, and the two convicts were gone.

What with the cries aboard the steamer, and the furious blowing off of her (me) steam, and her (me) driving on, and our driving on, I could not at first distinguish sky from water or shore from shore; but the crew of the galley righted her (me) with great speed, and, pulling certain swift strong strokes ahead, lay upon their oars, every man looking silently and eagerly at the water astern.

No man spoke, but the steersman held up his (man) hand, and all softly backed water, and kept the boat straight and true before it.

Presently a dark object was seen in it, bearing towards us on the tide. As it came nearer, I saw it to be Magwitch, swimming, but not swimming freely.

He (Magwitch) was taken on board, and instantly manacled at the wrists and ankles. The galley was kept steady, and the silent, eager look-out at the water was resumed.

By the time she (Magwitch) had been hailed and stopped, both steamers were drifting away from us, and we were rising and falling in a troubled wake of water.

The look-out was kept, long after all was still again and the two steamers were gone; but everybody knew that it was hopeless now.

At length we gave it up, and pulled under the shore towards the tavern we had lately left, where we were received with no little surprise.

But, the Rotterdam steamer now came up, and apparently not understanding what had happened, came on at speed. Here I was able to get some comforts for Magwitch,--Provis

He (Magwitch) told me that he (Magwitch) believed himself to have gone under the keel of the steamer, and to have been struck on the head in rising.

The injury to his (Magwitch) chest -LRB-which rendered his (Magwitch) breathing extremely painful-RRB- he (Magwitch) thought he (Magwitch) had received against the side of the galley.

He (Magwitch) added that he (Magwitch) did not pretend to say what he (Magwitch) might or might not have done to Compeyson, but that, in the moment of his (Magwitch) laying his (Magwitch) hand on his (Magwitch) cloak to identify him (Magwitch), that villain had staggered up and staggered back, and they had both gone overboard together, when the sudden wrenching of him (villain) -LRB-Magwitch-RRB- out of our boat, and the endeavor of his (Magwitch) captor to keep him (Magwitch) in it, had capsized us.

He (Magwitch) told me in a whisper that they had gone down fiercely locked in each other's arms, and that there had been a struggle under water, and that he (Magwitch) had disengaged himself, struck out, and swum away.

no longer,--who had received some very severe injury in the Chest, and a deep cut in the head. I never had any reason to doubt the exact truth of what he (Magwitch) thus told me.

When I asked this officer's permission to change the prisoner's wet clothes by purchasing any spare garments I could get at the public-house, he (prisoner) gave it readily: merely observing that he (prisoner) must take charge of everything his (prisoner) prisoner had about him (prisoner).

The officer who steered the galley gave the same account of their going overboard. So the pocket-book which had once been in my hands passed into the officer's.

He (officer) further gave me leave to accompany the prisoner to London; but declined to accord that grace to my two friends.

The Jack at the Ship was instructed where the drowned man had gone down, and undertook to search for the body in the places where it was likeliest to come ashore.

Probably, it took about a dozen drowned men to fit him (Jack) out completely; and that may have been the reason why the different articles of his (Jack) dress were in various stages of decay.

We remained at the public-house until the tide turned, and then Magwitch was carried down to the galley and put on board.

His (Magwitch) interest in its recovery seemed to me to be much heightened when he (Magwitch) heard that it had stockings on. Herbert and Startop were to get to London by land, as soon as they could.

We had a doleful parting, and when I took my place by Magwitch's side, I felt that that was my place henceforth while he (Magwitch) lived.

For now, my repugnance to him (Magwitch) had all melted away; and in the hunted, wounded, shackled creature who held my hand in his (Magwitch), I only saw a man who had meant to be my benefactor, and who had felt affectionately, gratefully, and generously, towards me with great constancy through a series of years.

I only saw in him (Magwitch) a much better man than I had been to Joe. His (Magwitch) breathing became more difficult and painful as the night drew on, and often he (Magwitch) could not repress a groan.

I tried to rest him (Magwitch) on the arm I could use, in any easy position; but it was dreadful to think that I could not be sorry at heart for his (Magwitch) being badly hurt, since it was unquestionably best that he (Magwitch) should die.

That there were, still living, people enough who were able and willing to identify him (Magwitch), I could not doubt. That he (Magwitch) would be leniently treated, I could not hope.

He (Magwitch) who had been presented in the worst light at his (Magwitch) trial, who had since broken prison and had been tried again, who had returned from transportation under a life sentence, and who had occasioned the death of the man who was the cause of his (man) arrest.

As we returned towards the setting sun we had yesterday left behind us, and as the stream of our hopes seemed all running back, I told him (man) how grieved I was to think that he (man) had come home for my sake.

'' Dear boy,'' he (boy) answered,

``I'm quite content to take my chance. I've seen my boy, and he (boy) can be a gentleman without me.

'' (he)

No. I had thought about that, while we had been there side by side. No. Apart from any inclinations of my own, I understood Wemmick's hint now.

I foresaw that, being convicted, his (Wemmick) possessions would be forfeited to the Crown. '' Lookee here, dear boy,'' said he (boy)

``It's best as a gentleman should not be knowed to belong to me now.

Sit where I can see you when I am swore to, for the last o' many times, and I don't ask no more.'' (he)

Only come to see me as if you come by chance alonger Wemmick.

``I will never stir from your side,'' (I)
said I,
``when I am suffered to be near you.

I felt his (boy) hand tremble as it held mine, and he (boy) turned his (boy) face away as he (boy) lay in the bottom of the boat, and I heard that old sound in his (boy) throat,--softened now, like all the rest of him (boy).

It was a good thing that he (boy) had touched this point, for it put into my mind what I might not otherwise have thought of until too late,--that

Please God, I will be as true to you as you have been to me! '' (I)

he (God) need never know how his (God) hopes of enriching me had perished.

He (God) was taken to the Police Court next day, and would have been immediately committed for trial, but that it was necessary to send down for an old officer of the prison-ship from which he (officer) had once escaped, to speak to his (officer) identity.

Nobody doubted it; but Compeyson, who had meant to depose to it, was tumbling on the tides, dead, and it happened that there was not at that time any prison officer in London who could give the required evidence.

I had gone direct to Mr. Jaggers at his (Jaggers) private house, on my arrival over night, to retain his (Jaggers) assistance, and Mr. Jaggers on the prisoner's behalf would admit nothing.

It was the sole resource; for he (Jaggers) told me that the case must be over in five minutes when the witness was there, and that no power on earth could prevent its going against us.

Mr. Jaggers was querulous and angry with me for having

``let it slip through my fingers,'' (me)
and said we must memorialize by and by, and try at all events for some of it.

But he (Jaggers) did not conceal from me that, although there might be many cases in which the forfeiture would not be exacted, there were no circumstances in this case to make it one of them.

Chapter LV I imparted to Mr. Jaggers my design of keeping him (Jaggers) in ignorance of the fate of his (Jaggers) wealth. I understood that very well.

I was not related to the outlaw, or connected with him (outlaw) by any recognizable tie; he (outlaw) had put his (outlaw) hand to no writing or settlement in my favor before his (outlaw) apprehension, and to do so now would be idle.

I had no claim, and I finally resolved, and ever afterwards abided by the resolution, that my heart should never be sickened with the hopeless task of attempting to establish one.

There appeared to be reason for supposing that the drowned informer had hoped for a reward out of this forfeiture, and had obtained some accurate knowledge of Magwitch's affairs.

When his (Magwitch) body was found, many miles from the scene of his (Magwitch) death, and so horribly disfigured that he (Magwitch) was only recognizable by the contents of his (Magwitch) pockets, notes were still legible, folded in a case he (Magwitch) carried.

Among these were the name of a banking-house in New South Wales, where a sum of money was, and the designation of certain lands of considerable value.

Both these heads of information were in a list that Magwitch, while in prison, gave to Mr. Jaggers, of the possessions he (Jaggers) supposed I should inherit.

His (Jaggers) ignorance, poor fellow, at last served him (Jaggers); he (Jaggers) never mistrusted but that my inheritance was quite safe, with Mr. Jaggers's aid.

After three days' delay, during which the crown prosecution stood over for the production of the witness from the prison-ship, the witness came, and completed the easy case.

It was at this dark time of my life that Herbert returned home one evening, a good deal cast down, and said,--

He (Herbert) was committed to take his (Herbert) trial at the next Sessions, which would come on in a month.

``My dear Handel, I fear I shall soon have to leave you.

We shall lose a fine opportunity if I put off going to Cairo, and I am very much afraid I must go, Handel, when you most need me.'' (unknown)

``Herbert, I shall always need you, because I shall always love you; but my need is no greater now than at another time.

'' (partner)

His (Herbert) partner having prepared me for that, I was less surprised than he (Herbert) thought. '' '' ``You will be so lonely.

``You know that I am always with him (Herbert) to the full extent of the time allowed, and that I should be with him (Herbert) all day long, if I could.

'' (unknown)

``I have not leisure to think of that,'' (I.)
said I. And when I come away from him (Herbert), you know that my thoughts are with him (Herbert).

The dreadful condition to which he (Herbert) was brought, was so appalling to both of us, that we could not refer to it in plainer words.

My dear fellow,'' said Herbert,

``let the near prospect of our separation--for, it is very near--be my justification for troubling you about yourself.

'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

'' Have you thought of your future?'' '' No, for I have been afraid to think of any future.'' ''

But yours cannot be dismissed; indeed, my dear dear Handel, it must not be dismissed. I wish you would enter on it now, as far as a few friendly words go, with me.''

``I will,'' (I.)
said I.
``In this branch house of ours, Handel, we must have a-- '' (I.)
I saw that his (Handel) delicacy was avoiding the right word, so I said,

And I hope it is not at all unlikely that he (Handel) may expand -LRB-as a clerk of your acquaintance has expanded-RRB- into a partner.

There was something charmingly cordial and engaging in the manner in which after saying

``Now, Handel,'' (he)
as if it were the grave beginning of a portentous business exordium, he (Handel) had suddenly given up that tone, stretched out his (Handel) honest hand, and spoken like a schoolboy.

Clara and I have talked about it again and again,'' Herbert pursued, ``and the dear little thing begged me only this evening, with tears in her (Clara) eyes, to say to you that, if you will live with us when we come together, she (Clara) will do her (Clara) best to make you happy, and to convince her (Clara) husband's friend that he (friend) is her (Clara) friend too.

``A clerk. '' (unknown)
``A clerk. Now, Handel,--in short, my dear boy, will you come to me? '' (Handel)
'' We should get on so well, Handel!''

I thanked her (clerk) heartily, and I thanked him (Handel) heartily, but said I could not yet make sure of joining him (Handel) as he (Handel) so kindly offered.

Secondly, there was a vague something lingering in my thoughts that will come out very near the end of this slight narrative.

But if you thought, Herbert, that you could, without doing any injury to your business, leave the question open for a little while--''

``For any while,'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
cried Herbert.

Firstly, my mind was too preoccupied to be able to take in the subject clearly. Secondly,--Yes! '' '' Six months, a year!''

Herbert was highly delighted when we shook hands on this arrangement, and said he (Herbert) could now take courage to tell me that he (Herbert) believed he (Herbert) must go away at the end of the week.

And Clara?'' said I.

``The dear little thing,'' (I.)
returned Herbert, ``holds dutifully to her (Clara) father as long as he (Herbert) lasts; but he (Herbert) won't last long.

``Not so long as that,'' (I.)
said I.
``Two or three months at most. '' (I.)
'' Mrs. Whimple confides to me that he (Herbert) is certainly going.

''

``Not to say an unfeeling thing,'' (I)
said I,
``he (Herbert) cannot do better than go. '' (I)
``I am afraid that must be admitted,'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)
said Herbert;

``and then I shall come back for the dear little thing, and the dear little thing and I will walk quietly into the nearest church.

The blessed darling comes of no family, my dear Handel, and never looked into the red book, and hasn't a notion about her (Whimple) grandpapa.

On the Saturday in that same week, I took my leave of Herbert,--full of bright hope, but sad and sorry to leave me,--as

I went into a coffee-house to write a little note to Clara, telling her (Clara) he (Herbert) had gone off, sending his (Herbert) love to her (Clara) over and over again, and then went to my lonely

Remember! What a fortune for the son of my mother!'' (Herbert/Herbert Pocket)

he (son) sat on one of the seaport mail coaches. home,--if it deserved the name; for it was now no home to me, and I had no home anywhere.

I had not seen him (son) alone since the disastrous issue of the attempted flight; and he (son) had come, in his (son) private and personal capacity, to say a few words of explanation in reference to that failure.

On the stairs I encountered Wemmick, who was coming down, after an unsuccessful application of his (Wemmick) knuckles to my door. ''

The late Compeyson,'' said Wemmick, ``had by little and little got at the bottom of half of the regular business now transacted; and it was from the talk of some of his (Wemmick) people in trouble -LRB-some of his (Wemmick) people being always in trouble-RRB- that I heard what I did.

I kept my ears open, seeming to have them shut, until I heard that he (Wemmick) was absent, and I thought that would be the best time for making the attempt.

I can only suppose now, that it was a part of his (Wemmick) policy, as a very clever man, habitually to deceive his (Wemmick) own instruments.

``I am as sure of that, Wemmick, as you can be, and I thank you most earnestly for all your interest and friendship.

You don't blame me, I hope, Mr. Pip? I am sure I tried to serve you, with all my heart.'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

''

It's a bad job,'' said Wemmick, scratching his (Wemmick) head, ``and I assure you I haven't been so cut up for a long time.

``Thank you, thank you very much. What I look at is the sacrifice of so much portable property. Dear me!'' (unknown)
``What I think of, Wemmick, is the poor owner of the property.

Of course, there can be no objection to your being sorry for him (owner), and I'd put down a five-pound note myself to get him (owner) out of it.

The late Compeyson having been beforehand with him (owner) in intelligence of his (owner) return, and being so determined to bring him (owner) to book, I do not think he (owner) could have been saved.

'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

'' Yes, to be sure,'' said Wemmick. '' But what I look at is this. Whereas, the portable property certainly could have been saved.

That's the difference between the property and the owner, don't you see? '' I invited Wemmick to come upstairs, and refresh himself with a glass of grog before walking to Walworth.

While he (Wemmick) was drinking his (Wemmick) moderate allowance, he (Wemmick) said, with nothing to lead up to it, and after having appeared rather fidgety,--

He (Wemmick) accepted the invitation. '' What do you think of my meaning to take a holiday on Monday, Mr. Pip?''

``Why, I suppose you have not done such a thing these twelve months.

'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

'' These twelve years, more likely,'' said Wemmick. '' Yes. I'm going to take a holiday. More than that; I'm going to take a walk.

More than that; I'm going to ask you to take a walk with me. '' I was about to excuse myself, as being but a bad companion just then, when Wemmick anticipated me.

'' I know your engagements,'' said he (Wemmick),

``and I know you are out of sorts, Mr. Pip. But if you could oblige me, I should take it as a kindness.

It ain't a long walk, and it's an early one. Say it might occupy you -LRB-including breakfast on the walk-RRB- from eight to twelve.

Couldn't you stretch a point and manage it? '' (he)

He (Pip) had done so much for me at various times, that this was very little to do for him (Pip).

I said I could manage it,--would manage it,--and he (Pip) was so very much pleased by my acquiescence, that I was pleased too.

At his (Pip) particular request, I appointed to call for him (Pip) at the Castle at half past eight on Monday morning, and so we parted for the time.

Punctual to my appointment, I rang at the Castle gate on the Monday morning, and was received by Wemmick himself, who struck me as looking tighter than usual, and having a sleeker hat on.

The Aged must have been stirring with the lark, for, glancing into the perspective of his (Wemmick) bedroom, I observed that his (Wemmick) bed was empty.

When we had fortified ourselves with the rum and milk and biscuits, and were going out for the walk with that training preparation on us, I was considerably surprised to see Wemmick take up a fishing-rod, and put it over his (Wemmick) shoulder.

Within, there were two glasses of rum and milk prepared, and two biscuits. '' Why, we are not going fishing!'' said I.

``No,'' (I.)
returned Wemmick,
``but I like to walk with one.

'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

I thought this odd; however, I said nothing, and we set off. We went towards Camberwell Green, and when we were thereabouts, Wemmick said suddenly,--

There was nothing very surprising in that; but again, I was rather surprised, when he (Wemmick) said, as if he (Wemmick) were animated by a brilliant idea,--

``Halloa! Here's a church! '' (he)
``Let's go in! '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
We went in, Wemmick leaving his (Wemmick) fishing-rod in the porch, and looked all round.

In the mean time, Wemmick was diving into his (Wemmick) coat-pockets, and getting something out of paper there.

``Halloa!'' (he)
said he (Wemmick). ''

As the gloves were white kid gloves, and as the post-office was widened to its utmost extent, I now began to have my strong suspicions.

Here's a couple of pair of gloves! Let's put 'em on!'' They were strengthened into certainty when I beheld the Aged enter at a side door, escorting a lady.

That discreet damsel was attired as usual, except that she (damsel) was now engaged in substituting for her (damsel) green kid gloves a pair of white.

``Halloa!'' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
said Wemmick. '' Here's Miss Skiffins! Let's have a wedding. '' The Aged was likewise occupied in preparing a similar sacrifice for the altar of Hymen.

The old gentleman, however, experienced so much difficulty in getting his (gentleman) gloves on, that Wemmick found it necessary to put him (gentleman) with his (gentleman) back against a pillar, and then to get behind the pillar himself and pull away at them, while I for my part held the old gentleman round the waist, that he (gentleman) might present an equal and safe resistance.

By dint of this ingenious scheme, his (gentleman) gloves were got on to perfection. The clerk and clergyman then appearing, we were ranged in order at those fatal rails.

True to his (gentleman) notion of seeming to do it all without preparation, I heard Wemmick say to himself, as he (Wemmick) took something out of his (Wemmick) waistcoat-pocket before the service began, ``Halloa!

I acted in the capacity of backer, or best-man, to the bridegroom; while a little limp pew-opener in a soft bonnet like a baby's, made a feint of being the bosom friend of Miss Skiffins.

The responsibility of giving the lady away devolved upon the Aged, which led to the clergyman's being unintentionally scandalized, and it happened thus.

When he (clergyman) said,

``Who giveth this woman to be married to this man?'' (he)
the old gentleman, not in the least knowing what point of the ceremony we had arrived at, stood most amiably beaming at the ten commandments.

'' The old gentleman being still in a state of most estimable unconsciousness, the bridegroom cried out in his (bridegroom) accustomed voice,

Here's a ring! '' Upon which, the clergyman said again, ``WHO giveth this woman to be married to this man?

``Now Aged P. you know; who giveth?

'' (he)

To which the Aged replied with great briskness, before saying that he (man) gave,
``All right, John, all right, my boy!'' (he)

And the clergyman came to so gloomy a pause upon it, that I had doubts for the moment whether we should get completely married that day.

It was completely done, however, and when we were going out of church Wemmick took the cover off the font, and put his (Wemmick) white gloves in it, and put the cover on again.

Now, Mr. Pip,'' said Wemmick, triumphantly shouldering the fishing-rod as we came out, ``let me ask you whether anybody would suppose this to be a wedding-party!

Breakfast had been ordered at a pleasant little tavern, a mile or so away upon the rising ground beyond the green; and there was a bagatelle board in the room, in case we should desire to unbend our minds after the solemnity.

It was pleasant to observe that Mrs. Wemmick no longer unwound Wemmick's arm when it adapted itself to her (Wemmick) figure, but sat in a high-backed chair against the wall, like a violoncello in its case, and submitted to be embraced as that melodious instrument might have done.

We had an excellent breakfast, and when any one declined anything on table, Wemmick said,

``Provided by contract, you know; don't be afraid of it!

Mrs. Wemmick, more heedful of the future, put her (Wemmick) white gloves in her (Wemmick) pocket and assumed her (Wemmick) green. '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)

'' ''

I drank to the new couple, drank to the Aged, drank to the Castle, saluted the bride at parting, and made myself as agreeable as I could.

Wemmick came down to the door with me, and I again shook hands with him (Wemmick), and wished him (Wemmick) joy.

``Thankee! '' (Wemmick/Mr. Wemmick)
said Wemmick, rubbing his (Wemmick) hands.

'' She (bride)'s such a manager of fowls, you have no idea. You shall have some eggs, and judge for yourself. I say, Mr. Pip!

'' calling me back, and speaking low. '' This is altogether a Walworth sentiment, please.''

``I understand. Not to be mentioned in Little Britain,'' (I.)
said I. Wemmick nodded.

'' After what you let out the other day, Mr. Jaggers may as well not know of it. He (Jaggers) might think my brain was softening, or something of the kind.

He (Jaggers) lay in prison very ill, during the whole interval between his (Jaggers) committal for trial and the coming round of the Sessions.

He (Jaggers) had broken two ribs, they had wounded one of his (Jaggers) lungs, and he (Jaggers) breathed with great pain and difficulty, which increased daily.

It was a consequence of his (Jaggers) hurt that he (Jaggers) spoke so low as to be scarcely audible; therefore he (Jaggers) spoke very little.

But he (Jaggers) was ever ready to listen to me; and it became the first duty of my life to say to him (Jaggers), and read to him (Jaggers), what I knew he (Jaggers) ought to hear.

Being far too ill to remain in the common prison, he (Jaggers) was removed, after the first day or so, into the infirmary.

And but for his (Jaggers) illness he (Jaggers) would have been put in irons, for he (Jaggers) was regarded as a determined prison-breaker, and I know not what else.

Although I saw him (Jaggers) every day, it was for only a short time; hence, the regularly recurring spaces of our separation were long enough to record on his (Jaggers) face any slight changes that occurred in his (Jaggers) physical state.

I do not recollect that I once saw any change in it for the better; he (Jaggers) wasted, and became slowly weaker and worse, day by day, from the day when the prison door closed upon him (Jaggers).

'' Chapter LVI This gave me opportunities of being with him (Jaggers) that I could not otherwise have had. The kind of submission or resignation that he (Jaggers) showed was that of a man who was tired out.

I sometimes derived an impression, from his (Jaggers) manner or from a whispered word or two which escaped him (Jaggers), that he (Jaggers) pondered over the question whether he (Jaggers) might have been a better man under better circumstances.

But he (Jaggers) never justified himself by a hint tending that way, or tried to bend the past out of its eternal shape.

It happened on two or three occasions in my presence, that his (Jaggers) desperate reputation was alluded to by one or other of the people in attendance on him (Jaggers).

A smile crossed his (Jaggers) face then, and he (Jaggers) turned his (Jaggers) eyes on me with a trustful look, as if he (Jaggers) were confident that I had seen some small redeeming touch in him (Jaggers), even so long ago as when I was a little child.

When the Sessions came round, Mr. Jaggers caused an application to be made for the postponement of his (Jaggers) trial until the following Sessions.

As to all the rest, he (Jaggers) was humble and contrite, and I never knew him (Jaggers) complain. It was obviously made with the assurance that he (Jaggers) could not live so long, and was refused.

No objection was made to my getting close to the dock, on the outside of it, and holding the hand that he (Jaggers) stretched forth to me.

The trial came on at once, and, when he (Jaggers) was put to the bar, he (Jaggers) was seated in a chair. The trial was very short and very clear.

Such things as could be said for him (Jaggers) were said,--how he (Jaggers) had taken to industrious habits, and had thriven lawfully and reputably.

But nothing could unsay the fact that he (Jaggers) had returned, and was there in presence of the Judge and Jury. It was impossible to try him (Judge) for that, and do otherwise than find him (Judge) guilty.

At that time, it was the custom -LRB-as I learnt from my terrible experience of that Sessions-RRB- to devote a concluding day to the passing of Sentences, and to make a finishing effect with the Sentence of Death.

But for the indelible picture that my remembrance now holds before me, I could scarcely believe, even as I write these words, that I saw two-and-thirty men and women put before the Judge to receive that sentence together.

The whole scene starts out again in the vivid colors of the moment, down to the drops of April rain on the windows of the court, glittering in the rays of April sun.

Penned in the dock, as I again stood outside it at the corner with his (Judge) hand in mine, were the two-and-thirty men and women; some defiant, some stricken with terror, some sobbing and weeping, some covering their faces, some staring gloomily about.

Foremost among the two-and-thirty was he (Judge); seated, that he (Judge) might get breath enough to keep life in him (Judge). There had been shrieks from among the women convicts; but they had been stilled, and a hush had succeeded.

The sheriffs with their great chains and nosegays, other civic gewgaws and monsters, criers, ushers, a great gallery full of people,--a large theatrical

Among the wretched creatures before him (Judge) whom he (Judge) must single out for special address was one who almost from his (Judge) infancy had been an offender against the laws; who, after repeated imprisonments and punishments, had been at length sentenced to exile for a term of years; and who, under circumstances of great violence and daring, had made his (Judge) escape and been re-sentenced to exile for life.

That miserable man would seem for a time to have become convinced of his (man) errors, when far removed from the scenes of his (man) old offences, and to have lived a peaceable and honest life.

But in a fatal moment, yielding to those propensities and passions, the indulgence of which had so long rendered him (man) a scourge to society, he (man) had quitted his (man) haven of rest and repentance, and had come back to the country where he (man) was proscribed.

Being here presently denounced, he (man) had for a time succeeded in evading the officers of Justice, but being at length seized while in the act of flight, he (Justice) had resisted them, and had--he (Justice) best knew whether by express design, or in the blindness of his (Justice) hardihood--caused the death of his (Justice) denouncer, to whom his (Justice) whole career was known.

The appointed punishment for his (Justice) return to the land that had cast him (Justice) out, being Death, and his (Justice) case being this aggravated case, he (Justice) must prepare himself to Die.

The sun was striking in at the great windows of the court, through the glittering drops of rain upon the glass, and it made a broad shaft of light between the two-and-thirty and the Judge, linking both together, and perhaps reminding some among the audience how both were passing on, with absolute equality, to the greater Judgment that knoweth all things, and cannot err.

Rising for a moment, a distinct speck of face in this way of light, the prisoner said,

``My Lord, I have received my sentence of Death from the Almighty, but I bow to yours,'' (the prisoner)
and sat down again.

audience,--looked on, as the two-and-thirty and the Judge were solemnly confronted. Then the Judge addressed them. There was some hushing, and the Judge went on with what he (Judge) had to say to the rest.

Then they were all formally doomed, and some of them were supported out, and some of them sauntered out with a haggard look of bravery, and a few nodded to the gallery, and two or three shook hands, and others went out chewing the fragments of herb they had taken from the sweet herbs lying about.

He (Judge) went last of all, because of having to be helped from his (Judge) chair, and to go very slowly; and he (Judge) held my hand while all the others were removed, and while the audience got up -LRB-putting their dresses right, as they might at church or elsewhere-RRB-, and pointed down at this criminal or at that, and most of all at him (Judge) and me.

I earnestly hoped and prayed that he (Judge) might die before the Recorder's Report was made; but, in the dread of his (Judge) lingering on, I began that night to write out a petition to the Home Secretary of State, setting forth my knowledge of him (Secretary), and how it was that he (Secretary) had come back for my sake.

I wrote it as fervently and pathetically as I could; and when I had finished it and sent it in, I wrote out other petitions to such men in authority as I hoped were the most merciful, and drew up one to the Crown itself.

For several days and nights after he (Secretary) was sentenced I took no rest except when I fell asleep in my chair, but was wholly absorbed in these appeals.

And after I had sent them in, I could not keep away from the places where they were, but felt as if they were more hopeful and less desperate when I was near them.

In this unreasonable restlessness and pain of mind I would roam the streets of an evening, wandering by those offices and houses where I had left the petitions.

To the present hour, the weary western streets of London on a cold, dusty spring night, with their ranges of stern, shut-up mansions, and their long rows of lamps, are melancholy to me from this association.

Seeing, or fancying, that I was suspected of an intention of carrying poison to him (them), I asked to be searched before I sat down at his (them) bedside, and told the officer who was always there, that I was willing to do anything that would assure him (them) of the singleness of my designs.

The daily visits I could make him (them) were shortened now, and he (them) was more strictly kept. Nobody was hard with him (them) or with me.

The officer always gave me the assurance that he (officer) was worse, and some other sick prisoners in the room, and some other prisoners who attended on them as sick nurses, -LRB-malefactors, but not incapable of kindness, God be thanked!-RRB-

As the days went on, I noticed more and more that he (God) would lie placidly looking at the white ceiling, with an absence of light in his (God) face until some word of mine brightened it for an instant, and then it would subside again.

Sometimes he (God) was almost or quite unable to speak, then he (God) would answer me with slight pressures on my hand, and I grew to understand his (God) meaning very well.

The number of the days had risen to ten, when I saw a greater change in him (God) than I had seen yet.

There was duty to be done, and it was done, but not harshly. always joined in the same report. His (God) eyes were turned towards the door, and lighted up as I entered.

'' Dear boy,'' he (boy) said, as I sat down by his (boy) bed:

``I thought you was late. But I knowed you couldn't be that.'' (I)

``It is just the time,'' (I.)
said I.
``I waited for it at the gate. '' (I.)
``You always waits at the gate; don't you, dear boy?'' (unknown)

'' Yes. Not to lose a moment of the time.''

``Thank`ee dear boy, thank`ee. God bless you! You've never deserted me, dear boy.

'' (I)

I pressed his (boy) hand in silence, for I could not forget that I had once meant to desert him (boy). ''

And what's the best of all,'' he (boy) said,

``you've been more comfortable alonger me, since I was under a dark cloud, than when the sun shone.

Do what he (boy) would, and love me though he (boy) did, the light left his (boy) face ever and again, and a film came over the placid look at the white ceiling.

That's best of all. '' (he)

He (boy) lay on his (boy) back, breathing with great difficulty. '' Are you in much pain to-day?''

He (boy) smiled, and I understood his (boy) touch to mean that he (boy) wished to lift my hand, and lay it on his (boy) breast.

``I don't complain of none, dear boy. '' (unknown)
``You never do complain. '' (He)
He (boy) had spoken his (boy) last words. I laid it there, and he (boy) smiled again, and put both his (boy) hands upon it.

The allotted time ran out, while we were thus; but, looking round, I found the governor of the prison standing near me, and he (governor) whispered,

``You needn't go yet.

'' (he)

I thanked him (governor) gratefully, and asked,
``Might I speak to him (governor), if he (governor) can hear me?'' (him)
The governor stepped aside, and beckoned the officer away.

The change, though it was made without noise, drew back the film from the placid look at the white ceiling, and he (governor) looked most affectionately at me.

'' Dear Magwitch, I must tell you now, at last. You understand what I say? '' A gentle pressure on my hand.

'' You had a child once, whom you loved and lost. '' A stronger pressure on my hand. '' She (governor) lived, and found powerful friends.

With a last faint effort, which would have been powerless but for my yielding to it and assisting it, he (governor) raised my hand to his (governor) lips.

She (governor) is living now. She (governor) is a lady and very beautiful. And I love her (governor)!'' Then, he (governor) gently let it sink upon his (governor) breast again, with his (governor) own hands lying on it.

Mindful, then, of what we had read together, I thought of the two men who went up into the Temple to pray, and I knew there were no better words that I could say beside his (governor) bed, than

``O Lord, be merciful to him (governor) a sinner!'' (I)

The placid look at the white ceiling came back, and passed away, and his (governor) head dropped quietly on his (governor) breast. Chapter LVII

Now that I was left wholly to myself, I gave notice of my intention to quit the chambers in the Temple as soon as my tenancy could legally determine, and in the meanwhile to underlet them.

At once I put bills up in the windows; for, I was in debt, and had scarcely any money, and began to be seriously alarmed by the state of my affairs.

I ought rather to write that I should have been alarmed if I had had energy and concentration enough to help me to the clear perception of any truth beyond the fact that I was falling very ill.

The late stress upon me had enabled me to put off illness, but not to put it away; I knew that it was coming on me now, and I knew very little else, and was even careless as to that.

For a day or two, I lay on the sofa, or on the floor,--anywhere, according as I happened to sink down,--with a heavy head and aching limbs, and no purpose, and no power.

Then there came, one night which appeared of great duration, and which teemed with anxiety and horror; and when in the morning I tried to sit up in my bed and think of it, I found I could not do so.

Whether I really had been down in Garden Court in the dead of the night, groping about for the boat that I supposed to be there; whether I had two or three times come to myself on the staircase with great terror, not knowing how I had got out of bed; whether I had found myself lighting the lamp, possessed by the idea that he (my) was coming up the stairs, and that the lights were blown out; whether I had been inexpressibly harassed by the distracted talking, laughing, and groaning of some one, and had half suspected those sounds to be of my own making; whether there had been a closed iron furnace in a dark corner of the room, and a voice had called out, over and over again, that Miss Havisham was consuming within it,--these were things that I tried to settle with myself and get into some order, as I lay that morning on my bed.

But the vapor of a limekiln would come between me and them, disordering them all, and it was through the vapor at last that I saw two men looking at me.

Well, sir,'' returned one of them, bending down and touching me on the shoulder,

``this is a matter that you'll soon arrange, I dare say, but you're arrested.

'' (me)

What do you want? '' I asked, starting;
``I don't know you.'' (I)
'' ''
``What is the debt?'' (unknown)
``Hundred and twenty-three pound, fifteen, six.

Jeweller's account, I think. '' (unknown)

'' What is to be done?''
``You had better come to my house,'' (the man)
said the man.

'' I keep a very nice house. '' I made some attempt to get up and dress myself. When I next attended to them, they were standing a little off from the bed, looking at me.

I still lay there. '' You see my state,'' said I.

``I would come with you if I could; but indeed I am quite unable.

Perhaps they replied, or argued the point, or tried to encourage me to believe that I was better than I thought.

If you take me from here, I think I shall die by the way. '' (I.)

Forasmuch as they hang in my memory by only this one slender thread

That I had a fever and was avoided, that I suffered greatly, that I often lost my reason, that the time seemed interminable, that I confounded impossible existences with my own identity; that I was a brick in the house-wall, and yet entreating to be released from the giddy place where the builders had set me; that I was a steel beam of a vast engine, clashing and whirling over a gulf, and yet that I implored in my own person to have the engine stopped, and my part in it hammered off; that I passed through these phases of disease, I know of my own remembrance, and did in some sort know at the time.

That I sometimes struggled with real people, in the belief that they were murderers, and that I would all at once comprehend that they meant to do me good, and would then sink exhausted in their arms, and suffer them to lay me down, I also knew at the time.

, I don't know what they did, except that they forbore to remove me. But, above all, I knew that there was a constant tendency in all these

people,--who, when I was very ill, would present all kinds of extraordinary transformations of the human face, and would be much dilated in size,--above all, I say, I knew that there was an extraordinary tendency in all these people, sooner or later, to settle down into the likeness of Joe.

After I had turned the worst point of my illness, I began to notice that while all its other features changed, this one consistent feature did not change.

Whoever came about me, still settled down into Joe. I opened my eyes in the night, and I saw, in the great chair at the bedside, Joe.

I opened my eyes in the day, and, sitting on the window-seat, smoking his (I) pipe in the shaded open window, still I saw Joe.

I sank back on my pillow after drinking, and the face that looked so hopefully and tenderly upon me was the face of Joe.

I asked for cooling drink, and the dear hand that gave it me was Joe's. At last, one day, I took courage, and said,

``Is it Joe?'' (I)

And the dear old home-voice answered,

``Which it air, old chap.'' (unknown)
``O Joe, you break my heart! Look angry at me, Joe.

For Joe had actually laid his (Joe) head down on the pillow at my side, and put his (Joe) arm round my neck, in his (Joe) joy that I knew him (Joe).

Strike me, Joe. Tell me of my ingratitude. Don't be so good to me!'' (Pip/Mr. Pip)

'' Which dear old Pip, old chap,'' said Joe,
``you and me was ever friends.

And when you're well enough to go out for a ride--what larks!'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

After which, Joe withdrew to the window, and stood with his (chap) back towards me, wiping his (chap) eyes.

And as my extreme weakness prevented me from getting up and going to him (chap), I lay there, penitently whispering,

``O God bless him (God)!

Joe's eyes were red when I next found him (God) beside me; but I was holding his (God) hand, and we both felt happy.

O God bless this gentle Christian man!'' (I)

'' How long, dear Joe? '' '' Which you meantersay, Pip, how long have your illness lasted, dear old chap?

'' '' Yes, Joe.'' '' It's the end of May, Pip. To-morrow is the first of June.'' '' And have you been here all that time, dear Joe?''

For, as I says to Biddy when the news of your being ill were brought by letter, which it were brought by the post, and being formerly single

he (chap) is now married though underpaid for a deal of walking and shoe-leather, but wealth were not a object on his (chap) part, and marriage were the great wish of his (chap) hart--

``Pretty nigh, old chap. '' (he)
``It is so delightful to hear you, Joe! But I interrupt you in what you said to Biddy.'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

Which it were,'' said Joe,

``that how you might be amongst strangers, and that how you and me having been ever friends, a wisit at such a moment might not prove unacceptabobble.

'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

And Biddy, her (Joe) word were, `Go to him (chap), without loss of time.' That,'' said Joe, summing up with his (chap) judicial air,
``were the word of Biddy. '

In short, I shouldn't greatly deceive you,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

Joe added, after a little grave reflection,
``if I represented to you that the word of that young woman were, `without a minute's loss of time.'

There Joe cut himself short, and informed me that I was to be talked to in great moderation, and that I was to take a little nourishment at stated frequent times, whether I felt inclined for it or not, and that I was to submit myself to all his (you) orders.

So I kissed his (you) hand, and lay quiet, while he (you) proceeded to indite a note to Biddy, with my love in it.

As I lay in bed looking at him (you), it made me, in my weak state, cry again with pleasure to see the pride with which he (you) set about his (you) letter.

My bedstead, divested of its curtains, had been removed, with me upon it, into the sitting-room, as the airiest and largest, and the carpet had been taken away, and the room kept always fresh and wholesome night and day.

At my own writing-table, pushed into a corner and cumbered with little bottles, Joe now sat down to his (you) great work, first choosing a pen from the pen-tray as if it were a chest of large tools, and tucking up his (you) sleeves as if he (you) were going to wield a crow-bar or sledgehammer.

It was necessary for Joe to hold on heavily to the table with his (you) left elbow, and to get his (you) right leg well out behind him (you), before he (you) could begin; and when he (you) did begin he (you) made every downstroke so slowly that it might have been six feet long, while at every upstroke I could hear his (you) pen spluttering extensively.

He (you) had a curious idea that the inkstand was on the side of him (you) where it was not, and constantly dipped his (you) pen into space, and seemed quite satisfied with the result.

Occasionally, he (you) was tripped up by some orthographical stumbling-block; but on the whole he (you) got on very well indeed; and when he (you) had signed his (you) name, and had removed a finishing blot from the paper to the crown of his (you) head with his (you) two forefingers, he (you) got up and hovered about the table, trying the effect of his (you) performance from various points of view, as it lay there, with unbounded satisfaction.

Not to make Joe uneasy by talking too much, even if I had been able to talk much, I deferred asking him (you) about Miss Havisham until next day.

Go to him (you),' Biddy say, `without loss of time.' '' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)

Evidently Biddy had taught Joe to write. He (you) shook his (you) head when I then asked him (you) if she (Joe) had recovered.

``Why you see, old chap,'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
said Joe, in a tone of remonstrance, and by way of getting at it by degrees,
``I wouldn't go so far as to say that, for that's a deal to say; but she (Joe) ain't--'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
``Living, Joe?'' (Joe/Mrs. Joe/Joe Gargery)
